DOC.HEADLINE: TRAVEL PROCEDURES TO BE SIMPLIFIED FOR MAINLAND PROFESSIONALS

TEXT.P: The application process for mainland Chinese professionals traveling to Taiwan will be simplified, Tseng Wen-chang, commissioner of the Bureau of Entry & Exit, said on Monday.

From July 1, 13 categories of mainland professionals, including hi-tech technicians, business leaders, and agricultural experts, will be able to apply at a single window of the Bureau of Entry & Exit for approval to visit Taiwan.
The application, which now takes an average of three months to process, is expected to take only one month.

Under current regulations, mainland professionals must submit invitations from Taiwan's foundations, academic groups or non-profit groups, then apply to the related government agencies before applications are sent to the Bureau of Entry & Exit.
The Bureau of Entry & Exit then reviews the applications with officials from National Security Council, the Ministry of Justice, Mainland Affairs Council, before giving the green light.
Officials said the simplified procedures are expected to enhance cross-strait exchanges.

DOC.HEADLINE: MA CANDIDACY BOOSTS KMT'S MORALE, SAY OVERSEAS PARTY MEMBERS
DOC.DATELINE: San Francisco, May 31 (CNA) (By Neil Lu & Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: Former Justice Minister Ma Ying-jeou's announcement that he was entering the race for Taipei mayor sent a shock through Taipei political circles and has breathed new life into the Kuomintang sectors in the United States, a KMT source in western US said on Sunday.
Ma's announcement has suddenly cleared a cloud that has shadowed the Republic of China's ruling party caused by its long-time failure to produce a proper candidate for the mayoral election.
An associate professor at National Chengchi University, Ma had continually rejected the KMT's call for his candidacy in the year-end Taipei mayoral election until Saturday.

At a press conference shortly after his father registered on his behalf in the KMT primaries, Ma said he is entering the race to meet public expectations. While Ma had previously said he would not run unless the political environment had changed, he said he was enlightened by a great number of supporters recently and decided that he himself should help bring about that change.

Chao Chuan-san, a senior member of the KMT headquarters in western US, said he personally is thankful to Ma for changing his mind at the last minute to jump into the race on behalf of the KMT after deciding to discard his personal issues with the party.

Chao said all KMT members on the westcoast of the United States are relieved now that Ma, a KMT stalwart who has enjoyed high approval ratings in almost all public opinion polls in Taiwan in the past, has decided to run for the KMT in the Taipei mayoral race. "We believe Ma will win back the Taipei mayorship for the KMT," he said.
Cheng Kwang-chih, another senior KMT member in the western US who is now attending a conference in Washington, D.C., also gave his support for Ma over a telephone interview on Sunday.

Cheng said Ma's pitching into the race signifies the beginning of a new round of esprit de corps in Taiwan's ruling party, a new strength which will help the party to win in all local or legislative elections in years to come.

DOC.HEADLINE: WRECKAGE OF MISSING F-16 LOCATED IN WATERS OFF PENGHU

TEXT.P: Following 70 days of intensive search, a naval minesweeper finally pinpointed the wreckage of an Air Force F-16 jetfighter in waters off the coast of Penghu Sunday evening, military sources reported on Monday.
The sources said debris of the jetfighter scattered to more than 10 places beneath waters some 10 miles west of Hsiyu, a small islet of the Penghu (Pescadore) island group.

Naval officers aboard the minesweeper were quoted as saying they were almost sure the wreckage belonged to the two-seater F-16 from the Chiayi airbase in southern Taiwan which lost contact during a routine training flight on March 20.
The sources said the navy has dispatched additional naval vessels to join search and salvage operations.
The bodies of the two air force pilots aboard the missing fighter -- flight instructor Wen Chin-sung and trainee Chang Chia-cheng -- have not yet been discovered, according to the sources.

The ill-fated F-16, with the serial number 6828, was on a training flight in skies about 50 kilometers southwest of Makung in the offshore Penghu County when it lost contact with authorities at around 2:30 p.m.
The military has since mobilized numerous naval ships and aircraft for search and rescue operations. Such efforts had been futile until Sunday.

Under its 10-year military modernization plan, the Republic of China struck a deal with the United States in 1992 to purchase 150 F-16 A/B jetfighters. Each plane reportedly costs more than US$20 million. Forty-four of them have been delivered to Taiwan. The first F-16 squadron was formed last October and another squadron was commissioned earlier this year.

DOC.HEADLINE: AUSTRALIA FACES BATTLE OVER GREAT BARRIER REEF

TEXT.P: A battle is brewing over oil rich reserves in Australia's Great Barrier Reef in Queensland with multi-national oil companies pitted against environmentalists over the issue.

Major oil companies, including Esso and Southern Pacific Petroleum NL, have estimated the oil reserves along the Great Barrier Reef at about 16 billion barrels and have expressed an interest in sourcing the shale oil.

Environmentalists, however, including members of the Democrats Party, have urged the federal government to prohibit oil prospecting in the area. Queensland Premier Rob Borbidge, meanwhile, has ruled out allowing companies to mining the shale oil on the Great Barrier Reef.
"The Great Barrier Reef is one of the greatest national and international resources. There will be no mining. There are no plans for mining," Borbidge said.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAICHUNG CITY GOVERNMENT TO ASK SCHOOL TO SUSPEND OPERATIONS

TEXT.P: A Taichung school in central Taiwan will have to suspend its operations and pay a fine of NT$60,000 (US$1,800) for violating zoning regulations, Lin Fang-min, an official of the Taichung City Government, said on Monday.
Lin, director of the Bureau of Public Works of Taichung City Government, made the remarks while fielding questions in Taichung City Council.
City Councilor Hsieh Ming-yuan pointed out that the site of the Taichung American School, located at the Taken section of Taichung City, was designated as a posh residential zone.
Hsieh said that the builder rented the tract of land to Anna Lee, President Lee Teng-hui's daughter, who did not apply to have the land rezoned before using it for the school.

Hsieh said the regulations allow Taken builders to construct residential homes, hotels, entertainment facilities, agricultural and other necessary public facilities, which includes kindergartens, nurseries and retirement homes.

The case has attracted a great deal of attention due to the involvement of Anna Lee, founder and principal of the Taichung American School, which offers a total of 15 classes, from kindergarten to 12th grade.

The school was also found to be in violation of regulations concerning a ban on accepting local students. As a foreign school, it may only accept foreign students, or Taiwan students who possess dual citizenship.

DOC.HEADLINE: COSMETICS, AIR FRESHENERS SAID TO CONTAIN CARCINOGENIC MUSK XYLENE

TEXT.P: Australia is concerned about British reports of cosmetics and air fresheners containing musk xylene, which reportedly causes cancer.

Reckitt and Colman, a manufacturer of international household products, told reporters that the company decided to investigate and test a wide range of cosmetics and air-fresheners in Australia after British government scientists had disclosed recently that one key ingredient, linked to cancer, can remain in human body almost indefinitely.

British scientists have announced that they would test cosmetics and air fresheners in their country that contain musk xylene, which is one of a family of low-cost chemicals created to mimic natural musk, an expensive scent extracted from deer glands and is commonly used in perfumes, soaps and other products.
Concern in the U.K. follows a laboratory test by Japanese scientists who found mice exposed to high quantities of musk xylene developed liver tumors.
A more extensive investigation in Germany showed the human body took three months to break down half the amount of the substance.
Products containing musk xylene include certain perfumes, shaving products, fly spray, and detergent.
A spokesman for Reckitt and Colman in Sydney told the mass circulation newspaper The Australian that his company would investigate to see whether its products in Australia contained musk xylene.

DOC.HEADLINE: E.U. OFFERS FEW SIGNS OF PROGRESS IN FARM REFORM TALKS

TEXT.P: European Union agriculture ministers offered few signs of progress in negotiations to reform the E.U. cereal, beef and dairy sectors, according to reports from the Geneva-based World Trade Organization (WTO) Sunday.
Ministers did, however, underscore what the most controversial issues will be during negotiations in the months to come.

Evidence of difficulties ahead came in a joint declaration after a two-day monthly meeting of the ministers. The declaration relates to a proposal by the E.U. Commission, the E.U. executive, to reduce guaranteed E.U. cereal, beef and dairy prices in the year 2000 and to increase direct E.U. farm aid from that year to compensate for the price reductions.

The proposal would cut the cereal support price by 20 percent in 2000, the beef support price by 30 percent in the period between 2000 and 2003, and butter and skimmed milk powder support prices by 15 percent between the same period.

It would also increase the overall E.U. milk quota by 2 percent between 2000-2003, extend the milk quota system until 2006 and give E.U. countries a greater say over how to allocate E.U. beef and dairy aid.

Key negotiating issues are the extent of the proposed price cuts, the level of proposed extra farm aid and the proposed right of E.U. countries to allocate beef and dairy aid according to national priorities, the WTO report said.
In addition, the proposed size and extension of milk quotas after 2000 will be significant issues, the report said.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC INTERIOR MINISTER CALLS FOR CROSS-STRAIT EFFORTS IN CRIME FIGHTING

TEXT.P: Interior Minister Huang Chu-wen on Monday urged that concerted cross-strait efforts at cracking down on crime be made the top issue on the agenda once both sides of the Taiwan Strait resume talks.

In his report delivered at a regular Kuomintang weekly meeting on the operations of the Ministry of the Interior (MOI), Huang cited the larger number of Taiwan criminals hiding in mainland China than those repatriated back to Taiwan as one of the reasons that necessitate closer contact and cooperation between authorities from the two sides on crime fighting issues.

There are at least 191 Taiwan criminals who have fled the country and have sought refuge in mainland China, compared to only 43 others who were repatriated from the mainland back to Taiwan, Huang noted.

He urged the Cabinet-level Mainland Affairs Council, the top government agency in charge of formulating Taiwan's policy toward mainland China, and the semi-official Straits Exchange Foundation, an intermediary body authorized to handle cross-strait exchanges in the absence of formal ties with mainland China, to see to it that crime fighting and related affairs be put on the top of the agenda of the cross-strait dialogue.

Mainland China has been the "black hole" of Taiwan's law enforcement endeavor, Huang said. Not only do wanted criminals from Taiwan hide in the mainland, but also stolen automobiles and motorbikes often end up there and a large volume of smuggled weapons and drugs in Taiwan originate from the mainland, he stated.

Huang said it is hoped that representatives from the two sides of the Taiwan Strait will meet soon and talk on arms and drugs smuggling, fishery disputes, piracy in the seas, and other related issues to help restore social order and security on both sides.

In addition to seeking mainland China's cooperation, Huang said the MOI is also striving to improve its own proficiency, including expanding investigation and arresting operations overseas, bolstering exchanges and cooperation with international police authorities, beefing up Taiwan's coastal policing forces, and strengthening security forces at harbors and fishing ports islandwide.

DOC.HEADLINE: TIME IS MAYOR CHEN'S BIGGEST CHALLENGE

TEXT.P: Taipei City Mayor Chen Shui-bian said on Monday that his biggest challenge now is the clock, and vowed to improve city works during the second half of the year.

The popular Chen, of the opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP), had no comment on the man chosen by the ruling Kuomintang (KMT) to run against him in the year-end Taipei City mayoral election, saying only that the KMT's problems will not be resolved in the short term, or by one man alone.
The mayor said that his most urgent task is continuing to push for reforms and more efficient city government which will allow Taipei City's residents to enjoy a higher quality of life.
The announcement over the weekend that former Justice Minister Ma Ying-jeou will enter the mayoral race for the KMT poses a grave threat to Chen, who has enjoyed wide popularity so far.
Recent poll results show that Ma will be a formidable rival in the race, with a popularity rating on a par with, or even surpassing, the incumbent mayor's.
However, Chen emphasized that the poll results should only be taken as a reference, adding that he still has strong conviction about his ability to win the race.

Saying that his city works will not bear fruit during his first four-year term, he appealed to the electorate to give him four more years of mandate to allow him to complete his agenda to build a better Taipei.

DOC.HEADLINE: SHARE PRICES SUFFER HEAVY PLUNGE ON TAIEX

TEXT.P: Share prices opened low and closed even lower on the Taipei Stock Exchange (TAIEX) on Monday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, plunging 297.09 points to close at 7,606.25.
The bourse opened at the day's high of 7,860.05 and experienced a low of 7,574.51.
Dealers said a pessimistic atmosphere prevailed in the market after a heavy plunge in electronics stocks, with buyer confidence on the edge of breakdown.
Losers outnumbered gainers by 438 to 17, with 19 issues remaining unchanged.
A total of 1.93 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$99.69 billion.

All eight major categories lost ground, with electrical stocks dropping the most at 5.2 percent, followed by pulp and paper issues at 5.1 percent, construction shares at 3.3 percent, both bank and insurance stocks and textile issues at 3.1 percent, foodstuff shares at 2.9 percent, plastics and chemical stocks at 2.6 percent, and cement issues at 2.2 percent.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAC URGES ENTREPRENEURS TO STICK TO `NO HASTE, BE PATIENT' POLICY

TEXT.P: Chang King-yuh, chairman of the Cabinet-level Mainland Affairs Council (MAC), on Monday urged Taiwan's entrepreneurs to adhere to the government's "no haste, be patient" policy until Beijing improves conditions for their personal security and interests.

Chang made the remarks in an address to a meeting held for the members of the Taiwan Merchants in Mainland China Association. In view of the recent arrests of Taiwan businessmen on charges of espionage in the mainland, he said, Taiwan's entrepreneurs have to consider the risks of investing there, and they should stick to the "no haste, be patient" policy espoused by the government, for their own safety and prosperity.

Chang stressed that in order to enhance services to Taiwan businesspeople in mainland China, the MAC will expand the integration of resources between the government and private enterprises, and provide cross-strait trade and economic information and a consultancy service.

DOC.HEADLINE: NATIONAL ASSEMBLY SPEAKER TO ATTEND US SENATOR'S FUNERAL

TEXT.P: ROC National Assembly Speaker Fredrick Chien, on behalf of President Lee Teng-hui, left for the United States on Monday to attend the funeral on June 3 of late Senator Barry Goldwater.
Goldwater, one of the ROC's staunchest American supporters, died of natural causes on Friday at his home in Phoenix, Arizona. He was 89.
His family said the funeral will be held on Wednesday at the Arizona State University in Tempe, which the former senator attended as a young man, although he never graduated.
Stephen Chen, chief ROC representative in the United States, telegraphed the condolences of the ROC government and people to Mrs. Goldwater last Friday upon hearing of Goldwater's death.
In his telegraph, Chen lauded Goldwater as "truly one of the greatest statesmen of the 20th century... a hero who battled with all forms of tyranny and injustice so that we might live in liberty."

NA Speaker Chien was appointed presidential envoy to the Goldwater funeral in part because he held the posts of chief ROC representative in the United States between 1983 and 1988, and of ROC foreign minister between 1990 and 1996. He has also maintained close and long-term relationships with the many friends he made in the US.

ROC diplomats in the US capital described Goldwater as the most loyal friend of the ROC. Over the past five decades, he was always there, standing up to speak for the ROC's cause amid turbulent relations across the Taiwan Strait, they said.

In December 1978, after former President Jimmy Carter announced US recognition of the Beijing authorities, Goldwater filed a suit with the US Supreme Court against Carter, accusing him of violating the US Constitution by recognizing the communist regime.
One of Goldwater's greatest contributions to the ROC before he retired from the US Congress in 1987 was his strenuous efforts in pushing for the enactment of the Taiwan Relations Act in 1978.

This act has since contributed to the protection of Taiwan's security, allowing Taiwan to develop political democracy and secure economic prosperity. It has also provided a framework for the US and Taiwan to continuously develop bilateral relations in the absence of formal diplomatic ties.

DOC.HEADLINE: ASIAN CRISIS OPENING DOOR FOR SYDNEY AS KEY FINANCIAL CENTER

TEXT.P: The Asian financial crisis has opened "a window of opportunity" for Sydney to become a key financial center for international banks and financial markets, but a stronger promotional blitz should be made to achieve that goal, according to the Sydney Futures Exchange (SFE).

SFE chief executive Les Hosking, who also serves as chairman of the Australian government's financial center task force, said Australia's strong regulatory framework and stable corporate culture can make Sydney a strategic location to develop financial services and security trading sectors on a global scale.
He said concerns over regulatory systems in Hong Kong and Singapore have created the potential for Sydney to make some major inroads in that direction.
"The timing is good to push what Australia has to offer and the sea-change in technology is breaking down our disadvantage of distance," he said.
Based on their growth in the past 20 years, both Hong Kong and Singapore have developed stronger markets in foreign exchange and equities.

The current disadvantages for Australia are its small population of about 18.5 million and its uncompetitive tax regime which serve as key impediments to attracting more financial businesses to Sydney, Hosking said.
He said if these disadvantages are negated with investment incentives, Sydney will have no problem of becoming the financial center of Asia.
He said: "Tokyo has lost preeminence in the region, with some people suggesting that this has been through mismanagement and corruption."

He said his task force will deliver a status report later this month in which he will recommend that the Australian government seize the opportunity by offering investment incentives through stronger marketing promotions.

He said the government should establish a marketing bureau to promote Australia as a base for financial service companies because the country is well-placed to win more contracts providing back-office capabilities for Asian banks in the future as a result of its stable economy.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN SEEKS PARTNER FOR F-5 FIGHTER UPGRADE

TEXT.P: Taiwan's Aero Industry Development Center (AIDC) is looking for a new partner to upgrade its F-5 jet fighters for advanced pilot training, following the dissolution of a business agreement with US Northrop Grumman Corp., according to the latest issue of US Defense News.

The weekly reported from Washington that AIDC and Northrop Grumman allowed their October business agreement to lapse due to the inability of the Los Angeles-based contractor to secure US export licenses for software source codes needed for the upgrades.
A Northrop spokesman told Defense News that his company continues to maintain contact with AIDC in the hope of pursuing other areas of cooperation.

A US State Department source noted that export license requests to Taiwan are generally scrutinized because of sensitivity associated with Washington's official relationship with Beijing and unofficial ties with Taipei.

In a May 26 interview with Defense News, the source added that many export licenses for Taiwan are currently delayed pending the outcome of US President Bill Clinton's June summit in Beijing with mainland Chinese President Jiang Zemin.
The original Northrop-AIDC plan called for prototype construction of the Northrop Grumman F-5 IV, a version of the F-5 that mimics the avionics and cockpit characteristics of the US F-16 fighter.

Defense News said Taiwan is seeking to form a new international partnership that mates AIDC's manufacturing capabilities and the Taiwan military's excess fleet of 100 single-seat F-5Es with a Western aircraft design, engineering and marketing firm.

DOC.HEADLINE: EXECUTIVE YUAN ESTABLISHES SOUTHERN TAIWAN SERVICE CENTER

TEXT.P: The Executive Yuan has established a new southern Taiwan service center in the hope that it will allow "spring to come to Kaohsiung," Premier Vincent Siew said on Monday at the center's opening ceremony.

Siew pointed out that feedback obtained during his many visits to southern Taiwan in his capacity as premier shows that the public longs for more central government support for regional developments, prompting the decision to establish a government administration service center in the southern Taiwan region.
P.K. Chiang, chairman of the Council for Economic Planning and Development under the Executive Yuan, will serve concurrently as the new director of the service center.

Immediately following the opening ceremony, Siew presided over the first Executive Yuan meeting ever to be held in Kaohsiung, where various major regional developments, such as the progress on the Tainan Science-based Industrial Park, were discussed.

Voicing his hope that the various ministries and commissions will consult local opinion via personal visits to southern Taiwan before making major decisions affecting development projects in the region, Siew stressed that his new "mobile Cabinet" will be able to instigate many administrative actions.

Kaohsiung Mayor Wu Den-yih recognized Siew's support for the new center and said he hopes that the central leadership will visit regional localities more often to understand the condition of the people, but he also took the opportunity to express his indignation at the injustice of 100 years of north-south inequality.
The mayor said he hopes Siew will make more frequent visits to southern Taiwan to better understand local needs.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC MINISTER IN SINGAPORE FOR APEC MEET

TEXT.P: Republic of China Minister of Transportation and Communications Lin Feng-cheng arrived in Singapore on Monday to participate in the Asia Pacific Economic (APEC) Forum's Third Ministerial Meeting on the Telecommunications and Information Industry, which opens on June 3.

He was accompanied by his wife and members of the ROC delegation, including senior officials of the Ministry of Transportation and Communications (MOTC) and leaders in the telecommunications and information industry.

The ministerial meeting is being preceded by two days of meetings between senior officials of the APEC member countries to discuss and prepare proposals and documents for their ministers to finalize and adopt at the three-day ministerial meeting.
Chen Wen-hsien, chairman of the International Affairs Committee of the MOTC, who flew into Singapore on Sunday, attended the senior officials meeting on Monday on behalf of the ROC delegation.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAINLAND SPIES IN TAIWAN SAID NOT TO EXCEED DOUBLE DIGITS

TEXT.P: The number of mainland Chinese secret agents in Taiwan doesn't exceed 100, the Republic of China's intelligence chief reported on Monday.

Yin Tsung-wen, director of the National Security Bureau, said in a speech at National Chengchi University that mainland China has taken advantage of increased exchanges across the Taiwan Strait to send intelligence agents to Taiwan through various channels.

However, Yin said he doesn't think that the number of mainland agents working in Taiwan is as large as has been reported. "My observation is that the actual number should be no more than two digits," he claimed.

Asked why the government has not taken action against these agents, Yin said that as a country ruled by law, the ROC must abide by the law in handling this kind of affair. He stressed that all suspected mainland agents are monitored closely by local security and intelligence authorities.

Yin further pointed out that the major intelligence threat to Taiwan doesn't come from Beijing's spies here, but from Taiwan people who visit mainland China. He said the National Security Bureau has stepped up surveillance of local people suspected of funneling military and technological secrets to the mainland.

Quoting official statistics, Yin said Taiwan residents have made more than 12 million visits to the mainland since the ROC lifted a cross-strait travel ban in 1987, while mainland people have made about 300,000 visits to Taiwan.

"It is noteworthy that after the Chinese Communist Party held a working meeting on Taiwan affairs last month, mainland authorities have vowed to increase efforts to court the people of Taiwan," Yin cautioned, adding that mainland China has employed "united front" tactics in an attempt to win the hearts and minds of Taiwan residents.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAINLAND DISSIDENTS TO MARK TIANANMEN MASSACRE
DOC.DATELINE: New York, May 31 (CNA) (By Huang Kung-chun and Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: Twelve dissidents in northwestern mainland China released an open letter on Sunday calling on the people of mainland China to stand up and seek vindication for the June 4, 1989 Tiananmen massacre, in which thousands of pro-democracy protesters were killed in a show of military force by Beijing's communist authorities.
According to the US-based "China Human Rights," an organization which advocates democracy for mainland China, the twelve dissidents included Ma Xiaoming, Lin Mu, and Gao Junsheng.

Lin Mu, a leading voice of dissent based in the northwestern region of the mainland, once served as a secretary of Hu Yaobang, the late secretary-general of the Chinese Communist Party (CCP), and president of the Northwest University. He has been under constant persecution and monitoring by mainland Chinese state security forces after launching a series of dissident activities in recent years.

In the letter, the 12 dissidents first conveyed their condolences to the families of the victims killed in the incident and paid their respects to those pro-democracy fighters who are still imprisoned. They went on to point out that the corruption and the violation of the rule of law now rampant in the mainland government are direct results of the clampdown on democratic activists nine years ago.
The only way to ease the displeasure of the people and resolve the corruption and injustice which abounds in mainland society is to "reassess" the June 4 incident, the letter points out.

It is the first time that mainland democracy activists have issued such an open letter to the public, rather than to government authorities, and it seems to be a bid to use the force of public opinion to find a solution to the problems, the human rights group said.

A day earlier, 21 other dissidents in Beijing, Fujian, Hunan, Liaoning, and Zhejiang issued their own statement calling on mainland China's National People's Congress, the State Council, and the CCP's to apologize for the June 4 incident, according to a Hong Kong-based human rights group.
They demanded that mainland authorities concede their error in opening fire on their patriotic countrymen and issue a public apology to the entire country.

They also demanded that mainland authorities erect a commemorative plaque for the protesters killed in the demonstration, and recognize human rights as a universal principle by releasing all political prisoners, as well as allowing dissidents living in exile overseas to return to the mainland.

DOC.HEADLINE: TOBACCO AND WINE MONOPOLY BUREAU TO BECOME STATE-RUN COMPANY

TEXT.P: The Taiwan Provincial Government announced on Monday that the Taiwan Tobacco & Wine Monopoly Bureau will become a government enterprise before July 1999.

The decision was made at a provincial administration meeting in which the government agreed to change the bureau into an single state-run company with a profit-oriented management system, said Chin Chin-sen, a provincial government spokesperson . The company will be divided into four sections: tobacco, wine, beer and marketing.
Eventually the company will be privatized, Chin said.
As a state-run enterprise, the company will have initial temporary capital of NT$32 billion with total assets of NT$100 billion.
Governor James Soong has requested that the legal rights and benefits of the bureau's personnel be protected during the transition, Chin said.

DOC.HEADLINE: NO BREAKTHROUGH IN SEARCH FOR F-16: AIR FORCE

TEXT.P: No major breakthrough has been made in search of an F-16 jetfighter which lost contact during a routine training flight on March 20, the Air Force General Headquarters (AFGH) said on Monday.

"The search for the missing plane is still going on," the AFGH said in a press release, adding that neither the wreckage of the plane nor the bodies of the two pilots aboard have so far been discovered.

The Air Force issued the statement in an apparent attempt to clarify earlier reports that a naval minesweeper pinpointed the wreckage of the ill-fated F-16 beneath waters some 10 miles west of Hsiyu, a small islet of the Penghu (Pescadore) island group, on Sunday evening.

The Air Force said the reports were incorrect. It pledged to continue its search for the missing aircraft in cooperation with the Navy. In addition, the Air Force said, it plans to employ foreign salvage experts to assist in the operations.

The twin-seater F-16, with the serial number 6828, was on a training flight in skies about 50 kilometers southwest of Makung in the offshore Penghu County when it lost contact with military authorities at around 2:30 pm on March 20.
The military has since mobilized numerous naval ships and aircraft for search and rescue operations. Such efforts have been futile so far.

Under its 10-year military modernization plan, the Republic of China struck a deal with the United States in 1992 for purchasing 150 F-16 A/B jetfighters. Each plane reportedly costs more than US$20 million. Forty-four of them have been delivered to Taiwan. The first F-16 squadron was formed last October and another squadron was commissioned earlier this year.

DOC.HEADLINE: DRUNK DRIVERS TO SPEND MORE TIME IN COMPULSORY EDUCATION CLASSES

TEXT.P: The length of compulsory drivers' education classes for drunk drivers is being extended from half a day to a whole day, effective Tuesday, Taipei city government traffic authorities announced Monday.
Classes will run from 9:00 a.m. to 3:30 p.m. every Tuesday. Afterward participants will be tested on the class, and anyone failing the test must retake the class.

Traffic police said that fines, which range from NT$6,000 to NT$12,000, are a poor drunk driving deterrent to the city's higher-income residents, while six-month driving suspensions are useless, given the police's inability to determine whether all motorists are properly licensed.
Day-long drivers' education classes, however, will inconvenience busy Taiwan residents and, perhaps, deter them from drinking and driving in the future, police said.

Regulations that require drunk drivers to attend the classes were among new measures enacted by the city government late last year to reduce the number of car accidents. Other measures in the package include higher drunk driving fines and one that prohibits drunk drivers from driving their cars away after being stopped.

Drivers who refuse to attend the classes will be fined NT$1,800. In addition, the traffic supervision office will not allow them to transfer automobile registrations nor will the office accept license plates and registrations from cars the owners intend to discard, which means the owners must continue to pay taxes on those vehicles.
The first class took place on Dec. 12 last year with Taipei Mayor Chen Shui-bian teaching the class himself to demonstrate his government's determination to crack down on drunk driving.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAINLAND CHINESE PUBLIC SECURITY AUTHORITIES GETTING BUSIER

TEXT.P: With the ninth anniversary of the June 4 Tiananmen incident drawing near, mainland Chinese public security officers have stepped up their efforts to control the activities of dissidents in the country, according to a newspaper report.

The Hong Kong Standard Monday quoted officials of the New York-based Chinese Democracy and Justice Party as saying that mainland Chinese public security authorities have briefly detained about 20 dissidents recently. Ten other dissidents have been asked not to leave their homes before June 4. Of those who have been detained, two are still in jail.

Beijing officials are more nervous in June each year because of the Tiananmen incident, in which at least hundreds of pro-democracy students perished under military crackdown on June 4, 1989. The officials are especially nervous this year, because President Bill Clinton will visit Beijing in late June.
The newspaper also quoted officials of the party as saying that it has established branches on the Chinese mainland.

DOC.HEADLINE: NT DOLLAR FALLS BELOW PSYCHOLOGICAL THRESHOLD

TEXT.P: The New Taiwan dollar dropped NT$0.241 against the US dollar Monday, closing at a five-month low of NT$34.23.
Dealers warned that the local currency's drop reflects fears that Asia's financial meltdown is starting to adversely affect Taiwan, which until now had escaped from the crisis relatively unharmed.
That same sentiment is affecting Taiwan's stock market as well. Share prices fell a sharp 3.76 percent at the close of Monday's session.
Pessimism about Taiwan's economic growth triggered heavy selling. The Taiwan Stock Exchange's weighted price index moved down 297.09 points to 7,606.25, the year's worst single-day tumble.
The NT dollar opened at the day's high of 33.978, and fell to 34.28 before recovering slightly. Interbank trading, meanwhile, amounted to US$402 million.

DOC.HEADLINE: SCIENTISTS WARN OF HOTTER WEATHER

TEXT.P: Scientists have warned that temperatures might increase all over the world, and sea levels might rise to cause floods in the next 50 years if global warming continues unabated at its present rate.
Temperatures will increase by almost 2 degrees Centigrade in the next 50 years, and water levels will rise by about 30 centimeters, spelling disaster for some low-lying countries.

Singaporeans have already had a taste of higher temperatures, with average monthly temperatures last year higher than those of the previous 15 years by 0.4 to 1.3 degrees, according to the Meteorological Service Singapore (MSS).
But temperatures have also been rising elsewhere, with temperatures worldwide reaching their highest levels in the 20th century last year.
As for the rising water levels in the next 50 years, Singapore has low topography, with more than 60 percent of its land not exceeding 15 meters above sea level.
Its coastal areas are also generally flat with extensive land reclamation, said the MSS.

However, according to the Singapore Environment Ministry, a rise in sea levels would not have a severe impact on Singapore because of its comprehensive drainage network, and redevelopment that raises land levels.
Each year, the Singapore government spends about S$70 million on drainage improvements, the ministry added.

DOC.HEADLINE: INDUSTRIAL MOGUL URGED TO SUPPORT 'NO HASTE' POLICY

TEXT.P: Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) Chairman Chang King-yuh on Monday called on one of Taiwan's leading business tycoons to continue supporting the government's "no hast, be patient" policy toward investment in mainland China.
Chang made the appeal after a local newspaper reported that Formosa Plastics Group (FPG) Chairman Y. C. Wang arrived in Zhangzhou in the southeastern mainland province of Fujian on Sunday.
Chang said the veteran petrocehmical baron once assured the Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) that he will not violate the government's cautious mainland investment policy.
"Mr. Wang himself has said he would abide by government policy...We believe he has in mind the delicate ties between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait," Chang said.
Commenting on Wang's mainland trip, Chang said the government currently doesn't ban local entrepreneurs from making market inspection tours of the mainland.

The Taipei-based Commercial Times reported on Monday that Wang is making a low-profile trip to the mainland and will meet with mainland Chinese Premier Zhu Rongji to brief him on a controversial power plant project in Zhangzhou.

The report said Wang will fly to Beijing after visiting the site of the thermal power plant being constructed. Wang reportedly would seek the mainland premier's understanding of the fact that, in order to circumvent current Taiwan restrictions on mainland investment, the FPG had had to transfer its holding in the US$3 billion Zhangzhou power plant project to a foreign investor. Wang told the local press earlier this year that the FPG will buy the stake back once Taiwan's investment regulations are eased.
Wang's mainland trip comes at a sensitive time, Four Taiwan merchants were recently arrested on the mainland on charges of espionage.

The FPG's three flagship companies -- Formosa Plastics Corp., Nan Ya Plastics Corp., and Formosa Chemical and Fiber Corp. -- originally planned to jointly hold a 60 percent stake in the Zhangzhou power plant, which is scheduled to come on line in the year 2000.

President Lee Teng-hui ordered a review of the mainland investment policy in late 1996 as Beijing stepped up its efforts to isolate the Republic of China on Taiwan in the international community. Lee's "no haste, be patient" policy is also aimed at preventing Taiwan from becoming too reliant on the mainland market as Beijing has never renouced its attempt to use force against the island.
Under the tightened restrictions, local companies are banned from investing in any mainland infrastructure project worth more than US$50 million.

DOC.HEADLINE: HONG KONG DESCRIBED AS MAINLAND CHINA'S LABORATORY FOR DEMOCRACY

TEXT.P: Inevitably, the modest acts of democracy in Hong Kong will be noticed by mainland Chinese citizens, a Canadian newspaper said in an editorial on Monday.
Many of these citizens will then ask: "If our fellow citizens in Hong Kong can vote for their legislators, however incomplete and imperfect the election, why can't we?" said The Ottawa Citizen.

It pointed out that mainland China's leaders have long held that "western-style" democracy is not compatible with what they call "Asian values." Hong Kong's latest elections put the lie to this, the daily said.
Last June, when the world was watching the impending handover of Hong Kong to mainland China, The Economist published an editorial entitled "How Hong Kong Can Change China," the Citizen said.
The magazine was asking if it is possible that instead of mainland China taking over Hong Kong, Hong Kong might conquer mainland China with its powerhouse economy and fledgling democratic structures?
"One year later, we pose the question anew," said the Citizen.

Last Sunday's election delivered "a loud raspberry to anyone who would limit rights and freedom," it noted. In the next few days, many Hong Kongers will go further by participating in the Tiananmen Square commemorations, it added.
It stressed that respect for human rights is the wave of the present and the future. Western leaders -- including US President Bill Clinton -- must continue to press Beijing for reform, it said.
However, nothing teaches like example. "If so, Hong Kong's pluralistic values may yet conquer the East," the editorial commented.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHEN CHAO-MING PROMOTED TO AIR FORCE COMMANDER-IN-CHIEF

TEXT.P: Air Force Deputy Commander-in-Chief Lt. Gen. Chen Chao-ming has been promoted to general and will replace Gen. Huang Hsien-yung as Air Force commander-in-chief, effective on June 11, the Ministry of National Defense announced Monday.
Huang has been reassigned as a strategic advisor to the president, according to a news release from the Military Spokesman's Office.
Meanwhile, another deputy commander-in-chief, Lt. Gen. Huang Ching-Ying, has been appointed special advisor to the chief of the general staff.
Army Commander-in-Chief Gen. Tang Yao-ming, whose term as head of the Army General Headquarters had been set to expire, has been permitted to remain at his post until June 30, 1999.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN SECURITY LEADER EMPHASIZES BEIJING'S MILITARY THREAT

TEXT.P: Beijing's ability to launch a military attack against Taiwan should not be underestimated given its redeployment of troops and jet fighters along the mainland's southern and eastern coasts, a Taiwan security leader warned on Monday.
Even more worrisome is the fact that Beijing has drawn up military scenarios that cast Taiwan as the enemy, said Yin Tsung-wen, director of the National Security Bureau.
Yin raised the warnings in a speech at Taipei's National Chengchi University as part of the NSB's efforts to recruit university graduates into the organization.
He noted that the mainland has redeployed forces formerly stationed along its Russian border to coastal areas in mainland's southern and eastern sections in the wake of the Soviet Union's collapse.
Newly-acquired, Russian-made Sukhoi-27 jet fighters, as well as the mainland's own F-8s, have been deployed in those regions as well, bringing Taiwan into the fighters' combat range.

Besides emphasizing Beijing's ability to attack Taiwan and warning the island not to relax its guard, Yin called "hasty reunification with mainland China," "hasty independence for Taiwan" and "counter-intelligence operations" the three most dangerous threats Taiwan faces.
These areas all fall within the NSB's area of concern, Yin further noted.

The NSB has determined that the missiles fired during tests Beijing conducted in the run-up to Taiwan's presidential elections in 1996 represented the first part of Beijing's landing operations against the island.

Beijing initially planned a four-stage assault, in which missile strikes would first damage Taiwan's military facilities. Mainland forces would then secure air and naval supremacy. Finally, an amphibious assault would be launched, Yin said.

The 1991 Persian Gulf War, however, underscored the importance of electronic warfare, and Beijing has since revised its plans to include an electronic warfare component. In fact, such warfare would now precede missile strikes, Yin said.

DOC.HEADLINE: NEW PARTY RULES OUT SUPPORTING MA YING-JEOU

TEXT.P: The opposition New Party at a press conference on Monday ruled out supporting Ma Ying-Jeou, who on Saturday unexpectedly announced his candidacy in the ruling Kuomintang's Taipei mayoral primary.

The announcement of Ma, an associate professor at Chengchi University and former justice minister, came as a shock to the New Party, which had pledged on Saturday full support for its own mayoral candidate, former Finance Minister Wang Chien-shien.

Yok Mu-ming, secretary-general of New Party's National Campaign and Development Committee, noted that after saying repeatedly he would not run, Ma's announcement surprised not only the New Party and fellow opposition party the Democratic Progressive Party but also members of the Presidential Office, the Executive Yuan and the KMT's Central Committee.

Yok said some KMT members are suspicious of Ma's about-face and are trying to uncover his real motives. There is concern that Ma is being manipulated by forces within the KMT that oppose President Lee.
Jaw Shau-kong, the NP's general-manager of elections, also called Ma a "tool of the anti-Lee forces."

Lee Sheng-feng, manager of the NP's mayoral primaries, said at the press conference that Ma's participation in the election has sped up the splintering of the KMT and increased its sense of paralysis.
Lee said that if the New Party were to back Ma, it would become embroiled in the KMT's family feud. The move would ultimately drag the New Party down, he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI COMPUTER EXPO TO OPEN

TEXT.P: As the Taipei Computer Exposition 1998 opens on Tuesday, the China External Trade Development Council (CETRA) has invited American information industrialists to the fair to capitalize on the local currency's devaluation by ordering components from local suppliers.

The US Board of Marketing Associates, which is composed of information industrialists with annual revenues exceeding US$50 million, has been asked by the CETRA to encourage its members to visit Taiwan and order Taiwan-made mother boards.
CETRA officials predict 16,000 foreign buyers will come to the island for the show.

Although the output of Taiwan's information and electronics industry surged by more than 20 percent in 1997 to US$35.7 billion, products were made mainly for foreign original equipment manufacturers. As a result, CETRA is trying to pitch sales of products carrying Taiwan companies' own brand names.
Nearly 1,000 companies applied for stalls in the exhibition, but there was only enough space to accommodate 892, CETRA officials said.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN ALLOWS IMPORT OF THAI-MADE AUTOMOBILES

TEXT.P: Board of Foreign Trade (BOFT) officials confirmed on Monday that Taiwan has agreed to grant Thailand an initial import quota of 4,000 compact cars, with an annual increases of 10 percent.

The deal was made before Minister of Economic Affairs Wang Chih-kang left for Geneva to attend last month's WTO ministerial meeting, the official said. Taiwan's previous quota called for 1,500 Thai-made cars to be imported, with yearly increases of 20 percent.

While saying that he believes the increased quota will not have an impact on Taiwan's automobile makers, the official stressed that Thailand had requested new terms on chicken, rice products and automobile imports. Taiwan, however, only agreed to make concessions on cars, he said.
Reports indicate US-based General Motors (GM), Thailand, is the only company that is nearly ready to begin exporting automobiles to Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: SEF WILL CONTINUE TO ARRANGE EXCHANGES WITH ARATS: SEF VICE CHAIRMAN

TEXT.P: Strait Exchange Foundation Vice Chairman Shi Hwei-yow said on Monday that the SEF will never stop trying to arrange meetings and conduct visits and exchanges with its mainland Chinese counterpart, the Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait (ARATS).

Shi made the remarks while commenting on a message received from the ARATS on Monday regarding an invitation sent by the SEF on May 12. The SEF had invited an ARATS representative to visit Taiwan sometime in May.
But the ARATS replied by saying it would prefer to first set conditions on the scope of the visit and then commission its deputy secretary general to form a visiting group to Taiwan.
The reply also reiterated that the ARATS continues to welcome a visit to the mainland by SEF Chairman Koo Chen-fu.
The SEF and the ARATS are intermediary bodies that represent the governments across the Taiwan Strait in the absence of official relations.

Shi said any high-ranking meetings or talks between the SEF and the ARATS should be aimed at settling practical problems. One such example, he said, is the recent detainment of four Taiwan businessmen on spying charges.

DOC.HEADLINE: KAOHSIUNG MAYOR TO ANNOUNCE CANDIDACY BID

TEXT.P: Incumbent Kaohsiung Mayor Wu Den-yih has decided to seek candidacy in the ruling Kuomintang (KMT) to take part in the mayoral race slated for the end of the year in this southern port city.
Tsai Ling-yih, Wu's wife, confirmed local press reports of Wu's re-election bid to CNA Tuesday morning, saying that Wu will call a news conference to announce his decision later in the day.

Wu's decision came after Premier Vincent Siew inaugurated on Monday a southern service center of the Executive Yuan in Kaohsiung, following Wu's requests for greater central government support in the city's development.
Despite repeated calls and support from the KMT and the general public, Wu had been reluctant to reveal whether he would seek the KMT's nomination to run in the year-end race.

Meanwhile, sources close to Vice President Lien Chan said Wu has informed Lien of his decision to participate in the mayoral race by telephone Tuesday morning. According to the sources, Wu expressed to Lien his determination of winning the election.
Former Justice Minister Ma Ying-jeou unexpectedly announced his bid to seek the candidacy in the KMT's primary for Taipei mayorship over the weekend.

DOC.HEADLINE: SHARE PRICES DOWN ON TAIEX

TEXT.P: Share prices fell on the Taiwan Stock Exchange Tuesday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, dropping 40.61 points to finish at 7565.64.
The bourse opened at the day's high of 7671.21 and experienced a low of 7523.5.
Losers outnumbered gainers 265 to 157, with 59 remaining unchanged. In all, 1.89 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$105.96 billion (US$3.12 billion).
Plastic and chemical stocks rose 0.2 percent, while financial shares edged up 0.1 percent.

Both foodstuff shares and paper and pulp stocks fell the most at 1.3 percent, follwed by construction shares as well as electrical engineering issues at 1.1 percent. Textile issues moved down 0.4 percent, while cement shares edged down 0.2 percent.
