DOC.HEADLINE: HK PEOPLE HAVE DISCOVERED DEMOCRACY AND WANT MORE OF IT

TEXT.P: The results of Hong Kong's elections last week indicate that voters accept electing a limited number of legislative council members for now, but will demand greater electoral powers when Chief Executive Tung Chee-hwa's term runs out in 2002, the Bangkok Post said Monday in an editorial.
The English-language daily said Beijing would be wise to realize its perception of the Hong Kong public is wrong.
"Last week's vote showed that democracy is so important to Hong Kong's people -- so important they would walk through a flood to get it," it said.
"The people of Hong Kong have interests that go well beyond their pursuit of business and the almighty Hong Kong dollar.

"Hong Kongers not only turned out for the first democratic election on Chinese soil in recorded history. They turned out in record numbers," the editorial said, pointing out that more than 50 percent of eligible Hong Kong voters turned up at the polls.

The percentage rate of voter turn-out is said to be more than that in Bangkok, even for the most controversial elections. Hong Kong's people have sent a message to their new leaders in Beijing, the editorial continued, adding that now they have discovered democracy, Hong Kong people want more of it and they are prepared to go through much inconvenience for it.

Commenting on the election of a minority of representatives to the parliament in Hong Kong, the Bangkok Post said the new parliament is controlled by a combination of communists and anti-democratic business interests.
"These two groups are combined in their opposition to democracy in Hong Kong and in (mainland) China," the paper continued.
"The communists believe in a single-party system where the people's representatives are conveniently chosen for them by the all-knowing leadership.

"Narrow-minded business interests still far behind the fast-developing times, think that democracy will somehow make Hong Kong unstable -- either because debate will expose rifts in society, or because Beijing will get upset again, as it did at the Tiananmen massacre."

DOC.HEADLINE: WORLD EQUESTRIAN GAMES TO BE HELD IN ROME

TEXT.P: The third World Equestrian Games '98 (WEG) will take place in Rome, Italy from September 30 to October 11 with contestants from over 30 countries set to compete.

Rome replaces Dublin as the sight of this year's games, WEG honorary presidents Maria Luisa Monti Riffeser and Dott. Andrea Riffeser Monti told a press conference here Monday. Also present at the press conference were Francesco Rutelli, mayor of Rome, and Franco Mistretta, Italian Consul General in New York.
Horses and riders will compete for the world championship titles in five disciplines: dressage, three-day event, vaulting, driving and show jumping.

The Flaminio Stadium, restored for the games, and Pratoni del Vivaro located in the Castelli Romani Park, have been selected as sights for the event which is expected to draw the attention of sports lovers around the world and the international press.

DOC.HEADLINE: CANADA WELCOMES TAIWAN HIGH-TECH BUSINESS INVESTORS

TEXT.P: Canada offers Taiwan's business community with enormous opportunities, just as the markets of Taiwan have attracted Canada's most innovative and entrepreneurial businesses, Canada's Industry Minister John Manley said Monday.

Speaking in Ottawa at the 12th joint meeting of the Canada-Taiwan Business Association, Manley urged Taiwan's business leaders to seek opportunities for investment and trade, and to build upon the solid foundation of cooperation between the two countries.
He said Canada has built its strengths in natural resources to value-added, knowledge-intensive industries, particularly in the transportation and communication sectors.
"Clearly, Canada has much to offer the information and communications technology needs of Taiwan," he told some 200 business and government leaders from both countries over lunch at a downtown hotel.

"I would like to emphasize that we are looking for Taiwan investment and expertise as well," Manley added, noting that Canada wants to build a semiconductor facility, "and Taiwan would make an excellent partner for such a venture."

Canada has an annual semiconductor trade deficit of US$3 billion, even though it has world-class design skills and laboratories. Taiwan is strong in manufacturing, marketing, and possesses abundant capital. Another high-tech industry which Manley sees great potential for cooperation between Canada and Taiwan is telecommunications. He announced that his department had just signed a memorandum of understanding with Taiwan's Directorate General of Telecommunications which will "close the loop on the initial stage of a cooperation agreement in the fields of communications and information technologies."

"Canada welcomes the growing openness in Taiwan's telecommunications market," the minister said, adding that he hoped the memorandum will further improve the climate of cooperation between the two countries.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN COACHES HELP BOOST PARAGUAYAN VOLLEYBALL AND PING-PONG TEAMS

TEXT.P: Under the guidance of Taiwanese volleyball and ping-pong coaches, Paraguay's national teams have come away with top prizes in recent South American tournaments.

Volleyball coach Ou Fu-hsing and ping-pong coach Benito Huang were invited to assist the teams. Ou has been in Asuncion as a volleyball coach since August 1996 and his tenure will expire in August this year. After his stay in Paraguay, the country's team has recovered its former glory days in volleyball as it was the runner-up among eight teams in a South American tournament. Paraguay had not placed in such a tournament since 1965.

Huang arrived in Paraguay in April this year. Since then, the Paraguayan national table tennis team and the junior team have won many championships in international tournaments, including one which was held on May 30-31. On that occasion, the Paraguayan selection defeated all the other three teams of the South Common Market, in the men's singles, women's singles, men's doubles, women's doubles and mixed doubles.

DOC.HEADLINE: CANADA, TAIWAN SIGN COOPERATION MEMORANDUM

TEXT.P: Canada and Taiwan signed a memorandum of understanding (MOU) for cooperation in the fields of communications and information technologies Monday.

According to the memorandum, both sides will exchange information on their respective policies and regulations, technical standards and certification as well as the transfer of technology and discuss multilateral issues.
The purpose of the MOU is to help each side better know and understand the other's organizational structure and regulations in the two industries.

Both parties agree to facilitate the exchange of communications and information technology personnel, specialists and delegations, and to engage in joint research projects. They also agree to jointly organize technical seminars, symposia and meetings.
The two sides agree to make reciprocal arrangement for the mutual recognition of each other's test reports, certification and test procedures, and laboratories.
Industry Canada's Spectrum, Information Technologies and Telecommunications Sector and Taiwan's Chunghwa Telecom Co., Ltd. have been designated as the executive agencies to implement the MOU.

The MOU was signed by Shirley Serafini, associate deputy minister of Industry Canada, and Chin-yen Fang, representative of the Taipei Economic and Cultural Office in Canada. George S.Y. Chen, executive vice minister of transportation and communications, witnessed the signing in Ottawa.

DOC.HEADLINE: CANADA URGES TAIWAN TO SIGN DOUBLE TAXATION AVOIDANCE PACT

TEXT.P: Canada's international trade minister urged Taiwan Monday to speed up negotiations over an agreement to avoid double taxation.

Sergio Marchi told a joint meeting of the Canada-Taiwan Business Association, "Geography may not have made us neighbors, but history has made us friends and the time has come for commerce to make us partners."

As Taiwan has become Canada's ninth largest trading partner, with Canadian exports to Taiwan exceeding C$2 billion last year, there are several significant initiatives to facilitate trade between the two countries, Marchi said.
For example, he pointed out, he hoped progress will be made on an agreement to avoid double taxation.
"This would benefit Canadians operating in Taiwan and Taiwanese operating in Canada, and I think this is something that should be done -- and done quickly," he added.

He said during a recent meeting in Geneva with Taiwan's minister of economic affairs, Dr. C.K. Wang, they discussed the potential for closer economic ties -- "a relationship that I am determined to see flourish and grow."

Marchi lauded Taiwan for being a dynamic economy which "has weathered the regional pressures better than most, and its resilience is clear testimony both to its internal strengths and its international reputation."

Turning to bilateral trade problems, the minister said concerns regarding access for foreign companies "will have to be addressed" as Taiwan prepares for its membership in the World Trade Organization.
He urged Taiwan to "dedicate itself to a non-discriminatory system of trade," referring to Taiwan's preferential treatment to some US farm products that Canada does not enjoy.
Another trade issue is trade imbalance, as "Taiwan sells almost twice as much to Canada as it buys from us," Marchi pointed out.
To balance trade and increase economic cooperation, he suggested that Taiwan buy more of Canada's quality goods and services and consider Canada's investment environment which is "second to none."

He mentioned the increasing people-to-people exchanges between the two countries, in the forms of tourists and students, but did not divulge the economic benefits they -- and thousands of economic immigrants -- bring to Canada every year.
A Taipei official said that if these non-trade figures are counted, Taiwan might be on the deficit side of "overall" economic exchanges.

DOC.HEADLINE: ESTRADA COMMITS TO PEACE AND IMPROVED ARMED FORCES

TEXT.P: Philippine President-elect Joseph Estrada Monday said his top priorities are the attainment of peace, the modernization of the Armed Forces of the Philippines (AFP) and improved living standards for AFP soldiers and personnel.

Estrada made the comment and discussed defense and security matters in a closed-door meeting with President Fidel Ramos and the top military brass at Camp Aguinaldo. It was the second in a series of top-level briefings initiated by Malacanang for the incoming officials of the next administration.
Estrada said his administration is determined to enhance the security and military capabilities of the AFP by fully implementing long-term AFP modernization.
He also vowed to take up the peace process by continuing peace talks initiated by the Ramos administration with both communist and Muslim separatist rebels.

"My incoming administration is determined to pursue the peace process, more so the implementation of peace and development programs that would spell a lasting solution to these insurgencies," he said.
In an effort to fulfill the campaign pledge of Estrada's LAMMP party, the president-elect said he will push for a package of measures to improve the living standards of soldiers and the AFP.

President Ramos earlier announced that he would meet with members of the Cabinet, their counterparts from the incoming administration and Estrada to ensure the smooth transfer of power, which is scheduled to take place on June 30, 1998.
Vice President-elect Gloria Macapagal Arroyo was also present at the meeting.
"This briefing will go a long way in safeguarding and securing our nation and pursuing its basic needs, especially in improving the quality of life of the masses," said Estrada.

DOC.HEADLINE: CITIES CALL FOR NO BEGGARS, LOITERERS DURING OLYMPICS

TEXT.P: Mayors of Sydney, Liverpool and other cities in New South Wales are pushing for wide-ranging powers to clear the streets of hawkers, beggars and loiterers in the lead-up to and during the 2000 Olympic Games.

They have lodged a joint proposal to Minister for Local Government J. Page, who is understood to have some reservations about granting such powers to the mayors because he believes the proposal will be difficult to pass in the Upper House of New South Wales, according to mass circulation newspaper The Sydney Morning Herald.
The move by the mayors mirrors similar action taken by Atlanta when the city hosted the 1996 Olympic Games by introducing tough loitering laws to sweep the homeless off the streets.
Page believes that some members of the Upper House would oppose the joint proposal because the offense of "loitering" was omitted from ordinances in the Local Government Act of 1993.

DOC.HEADLINE: US TO SELL ADVANCED F-16 RADARS TO TAIWAN
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, June 1 (CNA) (By Jay Chen and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: In a move likely to boost the confidence in Taiwan, the US Department of Defense on Monday announced the proposed sale of advanced radar systems for installation on the island's newly acquired F-16 jetfighters.

Pending congressional approval, the deal involves the provision of 28 sets of Pathfinder/Sharpshooter navigation and targeting pods, their integration with the F-16 fighters, training, maintenance and relevant support, the Pentagon said in a press notice.
The deal will cost an estimated US$160 million.
This marks the first time that the United States has agreed to sell the sophisticated nighttime combat equipment to Taiwan since the two countries struck a deal in 1992 for the sale of 150 F-16s.
The Pentagon said the Pathfinder/Sharpshooter pods will help Taiwan's F-16 pilots navigate at low altitudes and allow them to target weapons more accurately.
According to defense industry sources, the new equipment will also give 28 of Taiwan's F-16s the capability to combat at night.

The Republic of China's representative office in the United States would not comment on the Pentagon announcement, other than to point out that it is an established US policy to furnish Taiwan with adequate defensive weapons.

Nevertheless, Stephen Chen, the de facto ROC ambassador to the US, said he was pleased to hear the announcement amid rumors that the Clinton administration may be considering suspending arms sales to Taiwan in an attempt to improve ties with mainland China.

This marks the second major weaponry deal between the US and Taiwan so far this year. In January, the Pentagon announced the lease of three Knox-class frigates and related equipment to the ROC Navy at a cost of US$300 million.

The Pentagon said in its brief notice to the press that the Pathfinder/Sharpshooter deal will not affect the basic military balance in the region, nor will there be adverse impact on US defense readiness.

The Pentagon further said the sale will not require the assignment of any additional US government personnel in Taiwan, while the prime contractor, Lockheed Martin Corp., will send five to six representatives to provide technical support for about three to six months.
The Pentagon has informed Congress of the planned arms sales to Taiwan. Congress has 60 days to object to the deal, otherwise the sale will go forward.
According to Pentagon sources, Taiwan made the overture to purchase the advanced equipment for installation on its F-16 fighters during the 1997 Taipei-Washington weaponry deals meeting.

Taiwan has taken delivery of 80 F-16s and 20 of them are still in the US being used for training of ROC pilots at American air bases. According to the terms of the 1992 purchase contract, the delivery should be finalized by the turn of the century.

DOC.HEADLINE: INDIVIDUAL DEBT IN AUSTRALIA HITS RECORD HIGH

TEXT.P: Individual debt in Australia hit a record high of A$61 billion (US$40.7 billion) at the end of March 1998 due to growing personal loans, higher credit card bills and greater use of overdrafts, according to the Australian Bureau of Statistics (ABS).
The figure compares to A$53.4 billion (US$36.3 billion) from the same period last year, according to the ABS figures, which excludes loans for buying homes and operating businesses.
ABS officials and economists attributed the surge of individual debt to low interest rates, loyalty programs and "easy" money.
The surge in individual debt has become a growing concern for consumer groups because people will find it difficult to repay their debts next year, they said.
Analysts also said Australian banks have already begun setting aside increased reserves in expectation of more bad debts.

"Lower interest rates makes it more attractive for people to borrow. Loyalty programs on credit cards have also had a major impact. People now balance their points rather than balancing their debt," said Andrew Willink, managing director of the Cannex Australia Ptd.
"Credit is far easier to get. Now you can just pick up your phone and have a cheque delivered to your door," he added.
Peter Kell, industrial officer of the Australian Consumers' Association in Sydney, said Olympic credit cards are attractive to customers because the holders can avoid paying bank fees.
Many consumers used credit cards to minimize fees and charges paid to financial institutions, he said.

"We hope consumers are going into it with their eyes open. People have to keep in mind that we are at a low point in the interest rate cycle and they must be wary about not going in too deep," Kell added.

DOC.HEADLINE: ECONOMICS MINISTER REAFFIRMS BAN ON INVESTING IN MAINLAND PETROCHEMICAL INDUSTRY

TEXT.P: Minister of Economic Affairs Wang Chih-kang reaffirmed on Tuesday the government's ban on investment in the petrochemical industry in the mainland will stand.

Wang made the remarks following reports that Y.C. Wang, chairman of Taiwan's Formosa Plastics Group (FPG), met with Fujian Province officials in southeastern mainland Monday to discuss his stance on a power plant initiated by the FPG in 1996.

Reports also stated that Y.C. Wang would meet with mainland Premier Zhu Rongzi Tuesday to explain that he would have to temporarily transfer 60 percent of the stakes in the proposed plant and will buy back the stakes in due time so as not to contravene the government's ban.
Wang said the ministry will closely monitor reports that the Taiwan tycoon will transfer the stakes of the proposed plant to the investors in the United States.

FPG's Wang applied for government permission to build the US$3 billion thermal power plant in Zhangzhou, Fujian Province in early 1996, but withdrew the application after President Lee Teng-hui called for a slowdown in mainland investment in August 1996.

Economic officials said the ministry will continue to monitor FPG's capital movement. So far, there has been no transferring of money from FPG's three enterprises -- Formosa Plastics Corp., Nan Ya Plastics Corp., and Formosa Chemical & Fiber Corp., overseas.
Officials also said the three flagship enterprises of the FPG are all listed companies, and the transfer of money overseas will have to be approved by the shareholders first.

DOC.HEADLINE: SHARES PRICES DOWN ON TAIEX

TEXT.P: Share prices opened high but closed lower on the Taipei Stock Exchange (TAIEX) on Tuesday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, decreasing 40.61 points to close at 7,565.64.
The bourse opened at the day's high of 7,671,21 and experienced a low of 7,523.5.
Dealers said the market, after six trading days of index plunging down by nearly 800 points, experienced quite a fluctuation in Tuesday's trading with buyer confidence remaining low.
Losers outnumbered gainers by 265 to 157, with 59 issues remaining unchanged.

A total of 1.89 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$105.96 billion, increasing in value but decreasing in volume from the previous trading session which saw 1.93 billion stocks change hands on a market turnover of NT$99.69 billion.

Six of the eight major categories lost ground, with both foodstuff stocks and pulp and paper issues moving down the most at 1.3 percent, followed by both construction shares and electrical stocks at 1.1 percent, textile issues at 0.4 percent and cement shares at 0.2 percent.
Meanwhile, the plastics and chemical category posted a gain, moving up by 0.2 percent, followed by bank and insurance stocks at 0.1 percent.

The 10 listed companies enjoying the largest turnover in Tuesday's trading were: Ever Fortune Industries; Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing; United Micro Electronics; ASE; ACER; Picvue Electronics; Kinpo Electronics; Compal Electronic, Inc.; Mitac International Corp.; and Winbond Electronics Corp.

DOC.HEADLINE: FAMILIES OF ALLEGED SPIES PLEAD AT LEGISLATURE

TEXT.P: Liu Sung-fan, president of the Legislative Yuan, stressed on Tuesday that he believes in the innocence of the four Taiwan businessmen who have been arrested in mainland China on charges of espionage, and he urged the Beijing authorities to investigate the case as soon as possible and to allow their families to visit them.

Liu made the remarks during a meeting with the families of the four men, where he said the entire legislature is very concerned over the arrests, and added that as they lack the special training required to act as intelligence agents, it is impossible that the four men could have undertaken any spying activities.

In a written statement, the dependents of the four businessmen said that although tens of thousands of Taiwan businessmen have invested in mainland China, the separation of more than 40 years between the two sides sometimes causes misunderstandings, which might be the case in the recent arrests.

The statement expressed the hope that Liu, in his capacity as president of the Legislature, will urge the Beijing authorities to provide a secure investment environment for Taiwan businessmen and that the incident will have a happy ending.

Liu was scheduled to meet Premier Vincent Siew later that afternoon, where he said he would ask the relevant administrative departments to provide every assistance possible to the arrested businessmen.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP TO LAUNCH 'SAVE TAIWAN' CAMPAIGN ON EVE OF CLINTON-JIANG SUMMIT

TEXT.P: A group of lawmakers from the opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) said on Tuesday they will launch a series of activities demanding US President Bill Clinton not to sacrifice Taiwan's rights and interests during his forthcoming state visit to mainland China.
DPP Legislators Yeh Chu-lan, Hung Chi-chang, Chang Chun-hsiung and Ko Chien-ming declared at a news conference that they have form a "Save Taiwan, Defend Formosa" alliance to promote their cause.

Also present at the press conference were several other DPP heavyweights, including party advisors Lin Yi-hsiung and Wang Shih-chien, as well as Frank Hsieh, the DPP candidate for the year-end Kaohsiung mayoral election.
Yeh said the alliance is aimed at reminding Clinton not to put Taiwan people's rights and interests at stake during his summit talks with mainland Chinese President Jiang Zemin.

As part of its action plan, Yeh said, the alliance will launch a three-day signature campaign at the Taipei Railway Station from June 20. "We hope to collect at least 10,000 signatures to underscore our concern about Taiwan's security."

Meanwhile, the alliance will organize a delegation to travel to the United States later this month to convey Taiwan people's worry or unease over the possible adverse impact on their well-being of the Clinton-Jiang summit.
In addition, the alliance will set up a website on Internet for local people to air their views or opinions on all related issues to US policymakers.
The alliance will also sponsor an "anti-sellout" vigil at the 2-28 Peace Park in downtown Taipei on June 24 to call on Clinton not to boost ties with Beijing at the expense of Taipei.

At the end of the vigil, Yeh said, the alliance will issue a declaration, reaffirming its stance that Taiwan is an independent, sovereign state and expressing its strong opposition to "communist China's attempt to swallow Taiwan."

Yeh said the alliance will seek the support of all major domestic political parties and elected representatives at various levels for its cause. "We'll also push the Ministry of National Defense and the Ministry of Foreign Affairs to collect latest information about mainland China's military buildup and developments in Washington-Beijing engagement," she said, adding she believes Beijing is unlikely to renounce the use of force against Taiwan before cross-strait issues are resolved.

DOC.HEADLINE: TWENTY-FIVE CHILDREN DIE OF COMPLICATIONS CAUSED BY ENTEROVIRUS

TEXT.P: A total of 25 babies and children have died of complications caused by a virulent type of enterovirus, with another 100 in critical condition due to complications caused by the virus since an epidemic broke out in the middle of last month, the Department of Health (DOH) reported on Tuesday.

Wu Tsung-neng, director of the National Quarantine Service under the DOH, said the complications include encephalitis, meningitis and acute myocarditis, and noted that several of the deaths have been confirmed as resulting from enterovirus type 71.

He said most of the fatalities have been reported from the Changhua Christian Hospital in Changhua, central Taiwan, and from the Linkou branch of the Chang Gung Hospital in Taoyuan, northern Taiwan, which suggests that the virus is more rampant among children in Taoyuan, Hsinchu, Miaoli, Taichung and Changhua counties.

The Changhua Christian Hospital has so far reported nine deaths, the Chang Gung Hospital has reported seven deaths, the Taipei Veterans General Hospital has reported three, the National Cheng Kung University Hospital in the southern city of Tainan has reported two, while the Tri-services Hospital and the Kaohsiung Chang Gung Hospital have each reported one.

Wu estimated that so far, an estimated 200,000-300,000 infants and children have fallen victim to the epidemic, caused mainly by the enterovirus, along with the similar coxsackievirus. He noted that this type of virus is usually very active during the summer months, but added that this year, it has caused more fatalities than usual.

He said that so long as infected children develop only hand-foot-and-mouth disease and herpangina, the most common symptoms of the infection, parents should not worry too much. But he warned that if infected children also suffer from unrelieved high fever, nausea, headache, rapid breathing, and lack of appetite, parents should take them to a hospital.

Saying that there is no vaccine for the enterovirus, Wu called on parents not to take their children to public places, and to make sure their children wash their hands more often. If necessary, parents should keep their children away from day-care centers and kindergartens for a short period.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOEA CONFIDENT OF ECONOMIC GROWTH

TEXT.P: Despite falling exports and a depreciating new Taiwan dollar, investment willingness at home remains bullish and the local economy will continue to grow, Economic Affairs Minister Wang Chih-kang said on Tuesday.

Wang said investment in the domestic market is expected to increase by 16 percent to 17 percent for 1998, as a number of large-scale investment projects worth about US$800 million-US$1 billion in the biochemical and aviation industries are set to be carried out this year.

The economics minister made the remarks while answering questions from reporters after attending a seminar sponsored by Tamkang University on management strategies for the small business sector in the transition into the new millennium.
Although export performance is a major indicator of a country's business condition, Wang said investment willingness is another leading indicator.

Taiwan's exports dropped by 6.7 percent in the first quarter of this year compared to the same period of last year, and estimates for the second quarter are not expected to post an increase, although the Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) has been attempting to boost outbound shipments to the United States and Europe to maintain the island's export growth.

The Committee of Economic Research and Development under the MOEA said a weaker local currency will help sharpen export competitiveness, while the bearish sentiments prevailing in the local bourse are just a short-term phenomenon. Local market demand remains strong and Taiwan's economic growth rate should be able to reach the 6 percent target, it added.

MOEA statistics show that Taiwan charted a considerable 22 percent annual increase in capital investment in the first four months of the year, an indication that private sector investment interest remains high.

The MOEA predicts that the export sector will regain momentum in the second half of the year because of the government measures to boost exports, and because Southeast Asia is expected to begin a recovery from the current financial storm.

DOC.HEADLINE: NT DOLLAR CONTINUES SLIDE

TEXT.P: Affected by the strong greenback, the new Taiwan dollar continued its downward slide on the Taipei foreign exchange market on Tuesday, dropping NT$0.109 to close at 34.339.
The currency opened at the day's high of 34.23 and experienced a low of 34.395.
Interbank trading reached US$387 million.

DOC.HEADLINE: SIEW MEETS WITH VISITING PANAMA CITY MAYOR

TEXT.P: Premier Vincent Siew on Tuesday told visiting Panama City Mayor Mayin Correa that the Republic of China values its friendship with Panama.
Siew also expressed gratitude for the support the government and people of the Central American country has extended to the ROC's efforts to expand its presence in the international community.

The premier told Correa that he visited Panama City several years ago, and offered his personal comments on possible directions for the further development of the Panamanian capital. He suggested that the city could be developed into a regional financial, transportation, information, tourism, and product display center for the entire Latin American area.

Siew also lauded Correa for her strong sense of justice and high popularity ratings, saying that with a politician like her, the outlook for Panama's economic and political reforms are sure to be bright.

He pointed out the ROC's willingness to share its "Taiwan experience" with its Panamanian friends and expressed the hope that no matter which posts Correa will occupy in the future, she will continue to strengthen Panama-ROC relations.

DOC.HEADLINE: GOV'T URGED TO REGULATE SALE OF CABLE TV DECODERS

TEXT.P: The Television-Culture Research Committee on Tuesday urged the government to speed up the legislation of a cable television law to properly regulate scrambled programs and sales of decoding devices for such programs.

The committee also called for amendments to the existing children's welfare law to strictly ban sales of decoders to underage persons. The current law doesn't prescribe penalties for those who sell or provide decoders to the underage.
The committee said it conducted a field survey of nine night marketplaces in the greater Taipei area last month. The survey found that decoder sales to teens are rampant.

A committee spokeswoman quoted shopkeepers and street vendors interviewed as saying that junior and senior high school students form the bulk of underage customers of decoding devices for scrambled TV programs.

According to a recent telephone poll of 975 adult residents in Taipei City and Taipei County, conducted by CNA on behalf of the committee, 48.6 percent of the respondents said they have purchased decoders from street vendors, sales booths at night markets, or shops, while 42.9 percent said they have bought such devices from cable TV operators.

Another recent survey conducted by the committee itself also found that homes are the main place for adolescents to access scrambled programs. Fifty-two percent of teenage respondents said they have watched scrambled programs at home, while 44 percent said they have accessed such programs at the homes of their classmates or friends.

Meanwhile, more than half of their parents interviewed admitted that they have fixed decoders on TV sets. "Such a practice has offered youngsters easy access to scrambled programs," the spokeswoman warned.
About 38 percent said they would equip their TV sets with decoders only when they want to watch scrambled programs.

As scrambled programs mostly feature themes related to rape, sexual abuse and incest, the committee urged decoder importers and retailors to exercise self-discipline and decline sales of such devices to the underage.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN BUSINESS TYCOON INTERVIEWED BY JAPANESE NEWSPAPER
DOC.DATELINE: Tokyo, May 2 (CNA) (By Mike Chang and Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: If mainland China really wants to woo more investment from Taiwan, it should openly "renounce the use of force" against the island, Jeffrey Koo, chairman of the Taiwan-based Chinese Federal Association of Industry & Commerce, said on Tuesday.
In an interview with the Nihon Keizai Shimbun, Koo said that if Beijing unequivocally renounces the use of force against Taiwan, then Taiwan investment in the mainland will increase immediately.
Addressing the effect of the Asian financial crisis on Taiwan, Koo said that Taiwan's exports to Southeast Asia have decreased, describing the situation as worrisome.

He said that the development of Asian economies in general will hinge on the exchange rate of the Japanese yen, adding that if the yen is stable, then the Asian economies will gradually take a turn for the better.

However, he pointed out that if the yen continues to slide and hover at between 140 and 150 against the US dollar, then the South Korean won and the new Taiwan dollar will suffer. In that situation, mainland China will have no reason to prop up the renminbi, and will have a good excuse for devaluing its currency.

Looking to the future, the Southeast Asian financial crisis is a great investment opportunity, Koo said, noting that Thailand, Malaysia and Indonesia will have more financial liberalization, and that their land prices will also be cut dramatically.

The business tycoon said that Taiwan investment in the mainland has decreased following President Lee Teng-hui's August, 1996 advice to Taiwan businessmen to be more cautious when investing in the mainland -- the oft-touted "no haste, be patient" policy.

He also said that the cross-strait economy is inseparably intertwined, pointing out that Taiwan has an ample pool of managerial talent, while the mainland has vast labor resources. If both sides of the Taiwan Strait were to engage in agricultural cooperation, then agricultural production would increase three or four times.

Koo said that both sides of the Taiwan Strait should put aside their differences on the concept of "one China," maintain the status quo for the time being, and push for cooperation and economic exchanges.

DOC.HEADLINE: MND WELCOMES US SALES OF F-16 RADARS TO TAIWAN

TEXT.P: The Ministry of National Defense said on Tuesday it welcomes any US move that will contribute to peace and stability in the Taiwan Strait.

Military spokesman Gen. Kung Fan-ding made the statement in response to reports that the US Defense Department has agreed to sell advanced radar systems for use on Taiwan's newly acquired F-16 jetfighters.

Pending congressional approval, the proposed deal involves the provision of 28 sets of pathfinder/sharpshooter navigation and targeting pods, their integration with the F-16 fighters, training, maintenance and relevant support, the Pentagon said in a press notice released on Monday.
The deal will cost an estimated US$160 million.
This marks the first time that the United States has agreed to sell the sophisticated nighttime combat equipment to Taiwan since the two countries struck a deal in 1992 for the sale of 150 F-16s.

The new equipment will help Taiwan's F-16 pilots navigate at low altitudes and allow them to target weapons more accurately. The deal will also give 28 of Taiwan's F-16s the capability to combat at night.
Commenting on the reports, the Ministry of Foreign Affairs said it will be pleased if the deal becomes a reality.

DOC.HEADLINE: ASIAN CRISIS AFFECTING CONSUMER SPENDING IN AUSTRALIA

TEXT.P: Many Australians have tightened their belts as regards consumer spending due to the Asian financial crisis, and local manufacturers are bracing for production cuts to cope with rising stock surpluses, according to the Australian Bureau of Statistics.
The ABS figures show that retail turnover rose by only 0.2 percent to A$11.3 (US$7.5) billion in seasonally adjusted terms in April, well below market expectations.

Analysts said the sluggish consumer demand resulted in a largely unwanted 2.9 percent seasonally adjusted build-up in stocks in the first quarter of 1998 -- the biggest increase in the 13-year history of the official figures.
ABS officials said the figures mean that Australian companies will have to wind back their production significantly over the rest of 1998 to get rid of the unwanted stock.
The figures have prompted private economists to revise their forecast for Australia's gross domestic product growth in the first quarter of 1998.
They also believe that the Asian crisis will not fully affect the Australian economy until the second quarter of 1998 and that the effect on the first quarter is only the beginning of the impact.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN'S AGRICULTURAL OUTPUT INDEX DROPS 1.55 PERCENT

TEXT.P: The Council of Agriculture under the Executive Yuan announced on Tuesday that Taiwan's agricultural production index stood at 98.45 in 1997, a decline of 1.55 percent from the previous year.

The COA attributed the reduction to measures enacted to boost Taiwan's chances of being accepted into the World Trade Organization and last year's outbreak of foot-and-mouth disease, which decimated the island's hog population.
The livestock industry's production index for 1997 stood at 92.4, a drop of 7.6 over one year earlier, according to COA statistics.

The forestry industry's production index, however, gained ground, moving up 12.49 percent. Meanwhile, the fishing and agrobusiness industries' production indexes advanced 2.09 and 1.05 percent, respectively.

Rice field acreage grew also. Last year the island had 364,212 hectares of rice fields, an increase of 4.73 percent over the previous year. Some 2.04 million tons of brown rice were produced during the island's two growing seasons last year.

Soybean production, however, nose-dived, dropping 51.28 percent compared to the previous year, while green bean production fell 35.85 percent. The reductions stem from reduced tariffs on agricultural imports, which have made both crops less profitable for domestic producers.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC PRESIDENT CONGRATULATES PHILIPPINES PRESIDENT-ELECT

TEXT.P: President Lee Teng-hui has cabled his congratulations to President-elect Joseph Estrada and Vice President-elect Gloria Macapagal-Arroyo of the Republic of the Philippines.
Similar congratulatory messages were sent by Vice President Lien Chan, Premier Vincent Siew, and Foreign Minister Jason Hu.
The Philippines Congress announced on May 29 that Estrada and Macapagal-Arroyo had been elected 13th president and vice president, respectively, of the Southeast Asian nation.

According to a press release from the ROC Ministry of Foreign Affairs, the term of office of President Fidel V. Ramos will end on June 30, when the new leadership will take over the administration and form a new government.

Based on the principles of mutual benefit and reciprocity, the ROC is willing to continue to enhance bilateral relations with the new government based on the current friendly and close relationship, the release said.

DOC.HEADLINE: AIDS AND DRUG ABUSE TO BE ON NATIONAL ANTI-DRUG CONFERENCE AGENDA

TEXT.P: AIDS and drug abuse are two subjects on the agenda of the upcoming National Anti-drug Conference, which will open in Taipei on Wednesday.

The supervisor in narcotics administration for the Department of Health, Li Jih-heng, said the island's rising drug abuse problem is causing concern about a possible increase in AIDS infections among drug addicts who use intravenous needles.

Taiwan's current AIDS infection rate among addicts of drugs taken intravenously posts 3.6 percent, Li said. This compares to infection rates of 42 percent in Argentina, 33 percent Uruguay, 26 percent in Brazil and 11 percent in Paraguay.
Despite the relatively low infection rate, Li said more must be done to prevent the island's growing drug abuse problem from developing into a public health hazard.

DOC.HEADLINE: MORE PEOPLE GOING ONLINE IN TAIWAN AND HONG KONG

TEXT.P: There are now 1.75 million people online in Taiwan and Hong Kong, and the number is increasing day by day, according to a story which appeared in the Los Angeles Times business edition on Monday.

It began when three Stanford graduate students created a website with information from Taiwan in Chinese three years ago. It was so popular, would-be users jammed the bandwidth, crashing the university's server.
"We got kicked off," said one of the culprits, Hurst Lin, "but we realized we were on to something."

That "something" became Sinanet.com, one of the Web's most popular Chinese-language sites, with an estimated 1.2 million page views, or hits, per day. The guide was like a beacon in one of the Internet's last frontiers, where finding specific Web pages in Chinese was largely a matter of guesswork, word-of-mouth, and luck.

Last month, after several years of jumping technical and political hurdles, Sinanet added a Chinese search engine, and on Wednesday will unveil a partnership with Excite, another search engine, that will allow users to comb one million Chinese Web pages for information.

Previously, creating a special system to navigate the Chinese portion of the Web didn't seem possible or profitable. In mainland China, fewer than 10 percent of the population have their own telephones, much less computers. Access to the Internet was expensive and tightly restricted, Chinese Web sites were sparse, and Internet advertisers nonexistent.

But since the Beijing regime has begun to officially encourage Internet use for research and business, providing computers for universities and state-owned companies, user numbers have surged from 60,000 to nearly 600,000 in just over a year, according to information industry sources.
Another 1.75 million people are online in Taiwan and Hong Kong, putting the region on track to be the world's largest market after the US by 2001.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC MINISTER LAUDS TAIWAN'S ECONOMY
DOC.DATELINE: Ottawa, June 1 (CNA) (By S.C. Chang and Fang Wen-hung)

TEXT.P: The Republic of China has weathered the Asian financial crisis because its economy possesses key characteristics lacking in less economically stable Asian countries, said ROC Minister without Portfolio Shirley Kuo.

Addressing the 12th meeting of the Canada-Taiwan Business Association, which opened in Ottawa on Monday, Kuo compared the economic characteristics of Asia's hardest-hit countries to those of Taiwan. Although Taiwan has been affected somewhat by the crisis, she said, overall it has performed well.

Kuo cited Taiwan's 1997 economic growth rate of 6.8 percent, an increase of 15.6 percent in private sector investments, an increase in consumer prices of only 0.9 percent and an unemployment rate of 2.75 percent as indications of Taiwan's economic health.
Countries such as South Korea and members of the Association of Southeast Asian Nations (ASEAN), however, face sharply lower economic growth rates, in some cases negative growth, Kuo said.

Analyzing the economies of South Korea, Indonesia, Malaysia, the Philippines and Thailand, Kuo cited numerous factors that contributed to those countries' financial crises: private investments far exceeding long-term savings, massive levels of foreign debt -- particularly in the form of short-term loans -- and a tendency for companies with low capitalizations to borrow excessive sums all led to weak financial infrastructures, she said.

In Taiwan, on the other hand, savings have exceeded investments for years, enabling domestic savings to support investments in the public and private sectors, which has lessened the need for foreign funds.
In addition, Taiwan has huge foreign exchange reserves, whereas crisis-stricken countries have accumulated huge trade deficits made worse by overvalued currencies.

Taiwan spent 15 years in a gradual process of economic and financial liberalization that included lowering tariffs, opening the island up to imports and speeding up manufacturing advancements. The crisis-stricken countries, meanwhile, were liberalized their economies more slowly.

Besides calling for mutual cooperation among all Asian countries, Kuo said that greater cooperation between Canada and Taiwan, in areas such as commerce, investment, finance and technology, could help promote regional prosperity.

DOC.HEADLINE: MND CONFIRMS UNIDENTIFIED UNDERWATER OBJECT AS PLA SUBMARINE

TEXT.P: The Ministry of National Defense (MND) on Tuesday confirmed that one of two unidentified underwater objects discovered by the ROC military last Thursday was a communist Chinese submarine.

The diesel-powered People's Liberation Army submarine was first spotted by the navy near Hsiyu, a small islet in the Penghu (Pescadore) island group in the Taiwan Strait, according to MND spokesman Kung Fan-ting.
An S2T anti-submarine aircraft was then mobilized by the air force to jointly monitor the still-unidentified target.
The submarine went into silent mode when it discovered it was being monitored, before escaping amid bad weather that caused turbulent waves and poor visibility, Kung said.
The navy and air force have been continuing with a search-and-rescue operation since March 20 when a brand-new F-16 jet fighter disappeared during a routine training flight, Kung noted.

The other unidentified underwater object, an old sunken ship, was not positively identified until Monday, when a special undersea probe was sent to the seabed, Kung said, adding that the two confirmed identifications dashed earlier hopes that one of the objects was the missing plane.

The ill-fated F-16, serial number 6828, was on a training flight in the skies about 50 kilometers southwest of Makung, capital of offshore Penghu County, when it lost contact with military air controllers at around 2:30 p.m.
A full-scale search has since been underway, but all efforts to find the plane or its two-man crew of pilot and instructor have so far proved futile.

Under its 10-year military modernization plan, the ROC struck a deal with the United States in 1992 to purchase 150 of the advanced F-16 fighters, at a reported cost of more than US$20 million each. To date, 44 have been delivered, and the first squadron of the new planes was formed last October. A second squadron was commissioned earlier this year.

DOC.HEADLINE: AFRICAN COUNTRIES URGED TO DEVELOP NUCLEAR ARMS

TEXT.P: African countries should follow the examples of India and Pakistan to develop nuclear arms, a leader of South Africa's Pan Africanist Congress said here Monday.

Motsoko Rheko, who is a leader of the political party, said African countries, such as South Africa and Nigeria, should develop nuclear arms for self-defense, if advanced countries do not give up their nuclear arms.
African peoples were colonized before because they did not have weapons to defend themselves, he said, adding that similar things may happen again.
He also said that South Africa should refuse to sell uranium ore to other countries for producing nuclear arms.

DOC.HEADLINE: WANG DAN: BEIJING CAN NOT RESIST TREND OF DEMOCRACY

TEXT.P: Free publication of newspapers, free elections, freedom of expression, and other features of democracy may come to mainland China in a decade, a well-known mainland Chinese dissident said Tuesday.
Wang Dan, who was released from prison on a medical parole in April, said this is because "the trend of historical development is irresistible."
However, it may take a longer period of time for the democratic system in mainland China to take root, he added.

Wang, 29, was arrested in July 1989 and sentenced to four years in prison for his part in the Tiananmen incident, which took place one month earlier. He was arrested again in October 1996 and sentenced to 11 years in prison for advocating democracy.
He said in a telephone interview with the Hong Kong Radio Station that he still hopes mainland China will become a democratic country.

Wang, who is living in exile in the United States, said that last week's Legislative Council election in Hong Kong has indicated that people there are very enthusiastic about democracy. Voter turnout in the election was extraordinarily high. On this basis Hong Kong will have "a very good influence" on mainland China, he added.

Hong Kong can serve as a window, through which mainland Chinese can watch the outside world and can also see the benefits of implementing democracy in Hong Kong, he said, adding that Hong Kong's role in catalyzing the democratization of mainland China is irreplaceable.
He expressed the hope that President Bill Clinton will urge Beijing leaders to release more political prisoners, when he visits the Chinese mainland later this month.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHINA STEEL GROUP TARGETS ANNUAL TURNOVER OF US$4.4 B.

TEXT.P: The China Steel Group, established recently by China Steel Corp. in cooperation with 13 other related companies, is targeting an annual turnover of NT$150 billion (US$4.4 billion) by the turn of the century, CSC Chairman Wang Chung-yu said on Tuesday.

Of the companies involved in the partnership, CSC and China Steel Structure are now listed companies, while China Steel Carbon is expected to become a listed company at the end of this year, Wang added.
Formerly a state-run enterprise, CSC has strived to diversify its operations and expand operations overseas since it was privatized nearly two years ago.

The group is currently in discussions with Vietnam's state-owned steel corporation and several other companies on a possible joint-venture steel mill in Vietnam, Wang said. An agreement on the investment project, aiming at the production of 210,000 metric tons of stainless steel plate in coils annually, is expected before year's end.

Among its diversification initiatives, the group is planning a line to develop up-stream materials for making silicon wafers, as well as lines for producing integrated circuit chips and other high-tech products, Wang said.
By diversifying its operations, the group's turnover is expected to top US$5.88 billion annually by 2005, Wang said.

DOC.HEADLINE: CLINTON ADMINISTRATION SEEKS DELAY IN MFN VOTE

TEXT.P: The Clinton administration is seeking to delay an annual vote on Beijing's trade status that could embarrass the President before he leaves for a summit in Beijing on June 24.

President Clinton has until June 3 to renew mainland China's Most Favored Nation trade status. The yearly renewal process often ends up a review of the mainland's human rights record, proliferation of weapo2s and trade practices.
After the President renews a country's MFN status, Congress has 90 days to override the decision. No Congress, however, has yet overturned a presidential decision to award mainland China MFN status.

Although renewal is ultimately expected, this year's debate will be saddled by allegations that mainland China donated money to the Democratic Party, according to reports from the World Trade Organization. The administration has come under heavy criticism over the allegations.

Congress is expected to agree to delay the vote, but observers believe attacks on the administration will only be deferred until after the summit. "This way Republicans get to rain on any positive publicity the President gets out of the trip," the WTO report said.

The mainland's MFN status imposes the same low-level tariffs on mainland Chinese goods as that apply to imports from most US trading partners. The US business community launches intense lobbying efforts whenever mainland China's MFN status appears in jeopardy.

The administration, meanwhile, is trying to head off two controversies. First, some of the money donated to the Democratic Party by California businessman Johnny Chung appears to have come from Liu Chaoying, the daughter of mainland China's most powerful military official. These revelations put Liu at the center of a Justice Department investigation into alleged attempts by mainland China to influence the 1996 congressional and presidential elections.

The administration is also under fire for allowing a US satellite to be launched atop a mainland Chinese rocket. The satellite was built by Space Systems Loral, whose chairman had made large contributions to the Democratic Party. At the time the license was granted, the company was reported to be under investigation by the Justice Department for passing sensitive information to mainland Chinese.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHINESE TAIPEI PARTICIPATES IN WORLD CUP TAEKWONDO 1998

TEXT.P: The Chinese Taipei Amateur Taekwondo Association has selected 16 participants for its World Cup Taekwondo 1998 team.
The competition will take place in Sindelingen, Germany, from June 5 to 7.

The competition will be divided into eight weight divisions: fin, fly, bantam, feather, light, welter, middle and heavy. The Chinese Taipei team will compete in all eight divisions in both men's and women's competitions.

Eighteen countries -- Australia, Chinese Taipei, Korea, the Philippines, mainland China, Croatia, France, Germany, Italy, Spain, Turkey, Argentina, Brazil, Canada, Mexico, the United States, Egypt and Lesotho are participating in both men's and women's events.

Chinese Taipei team members include gold and silver medal winners in past year's World Cup and World University contests. Team member Tang Hui-wen won gold medals in the World Cup's women's bantam division from 1993 to 1996. In last year's World Cup competition current Chinese Taipei team members Huang Chiu-chin and Hung Chia-chun won gold medals in the women's feather division and men's fin division, respectively.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT MAY CANCEL TAIPEI MAYORAL PRIMARY

TEXT.P: Kuomintang Taipei City Committee Chief Chan Chun-po said on Tuesday his committee will suggest that the KMT Central Committee cancel the party's Taipei mayoral primary.
Former Justice Minister Ma Ying-jeou unexpectedly announced on Saturday his candidacy in the primary. His announcement has prompted other candidates to pull out of the race.

Noting the importance of "promoting unity and harmony within the party," Foreign Minister Jason Hu and former Yunlin County Government Chief Liao Chuan-yu withdrew their registrations on Tuesday, leaving Ma the only candidate.

Accompanied by Su Wen-hsiung, current chief of Yunlin County Government, and Juan Kang-meng, chief of Changhua County Government, Liao arrived at the KMT Taipei City Committee to cancel his registration.
Chen Chien-chih, speaker of the Taipei City Council, revoked Hu's registration on the foreign minister's behalf.
At a news conference, Ma, an associate professor at Chengchi University, expressed his appreciation of Hu and Liao's support.
Wu Po-hsiung, a senior advisor to the President, praised Ma at the same conference as a candidate for all parties and ethnic and age groups.

Meanwhile, Taipei City Legislator Lin Jui-tu from the opposition Democratic Progressive Party revealed on Tuesday that he is willing to quit the DPP and help Ma in his mayoral bid. He suggested, however, that Ma first discuss the matter with him personally.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN INITIATES GLOBAL TRADE PROMOTION CAMPAIGN

TEXT.P: Taiwan's economic authorities recently mapped out strategies to boost sagging exports of the island, according to the Board of Foreign Trade (BOFT), which helped draft the plan package.

The package comprises 15 plans that include measures to create surveys to assess the island's foreign trade and domestic business performance, to assist private traders in expanding overseas markets, to create business and investment workshops and to help build new trade channels.

Falling exports and local currency declines suggest Asia's financial storm is approaching Taiwan's shores. The island had previously been regarded as a crisis-free haven for investors, said the BOFT officials.
Taiwan can no longer ignore the regional financial meltdown, which is slowly eating away at its economy, they said.
The officials indicated Taiwan must work to preserve its share of the market in Japan, South Korea, Thailand, Indonesia, Malaysia and the Philippines.
Meanwhile, efforts must be made to open markets in developing countries, such as India and Turkey and nations in Latin America the Middle East and eastern Europe, officials said.

DOC.HEADLINE: KOO CHEN-FU HOPES TO VISIT MAINLAND BEFORE WINTER

TEXT.P: Koo Chen-fu, Taiwan's top negotiator with mainland China, said on Tuesday that he hopes to visit the mainland before winter.

Koo, who chairs the Straits Exchange Foundation, an intermediary body authorized to handle cross-strait exchanges in the absence of official contacts with mainland China, said he hopes issues relating to the property and personal safety of Taiwan business people in the mainland will top the agenda of cross-strait dialogue once it resumes.

In May the SEF invited the Beijing-based Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait (ARATS) to send a deputy secretary-general to visit Taipei at the end of the month for talks on the prospect of Koo visiting Beijing.
In a reply dated June 1, the ARATS turned down the SEF invitation, saying only that it welcomes a Beijing visit by Koo.
But Koo said he will not go until SEF officials complete preparatory talks with their ARATS counterparts.

DOC.HEADLINE: KAOHSIUNG MAYOR SAYS PUBLIC PROMPTED HIM TO SEEK REELECTION

TEXT.P: Calls from grassroots supporters rather than requests from the leaders of ruling Kuomintang are the main reason Kaohsiung City Mayor Wu Den-yih has decided to seek reelection, he said on Tuesday.
Wu had been considering entering the legislative race, but he said the public has persuaded him to seek a third four-year term as mayor.

He was further encouraged to run by former Justice Minister Ma Ying-jeou, who unexpectedly announced that he would enter the KMT's Taipei mayoral primary. Wu had encouraged Ma to run for the post, and Ma's decision, in some respects, threw down the gauntlet before Wu.

Looking back over his seven year's at the helm of the city, Wu said Kaohsiung has developed quickly, but added that its development has been hampered by problems in recent years, problems that made him reluctant to seek another term.
But the central government has responded positively to Wu's demands that it address these problems, he said at a press conference in which he announced his reelection bid.

Although initial reports indicated Wu would not seek another term, he denied reversing his decision. Wu said that despite pressure from party authorities, he never revealed -- let alone reversed -- his decision on running again.

DOC.HEADLINE: INDONESIAN UNREST SCARING AWAY TAIWAN INVESTMENT

TEXT.P: A survey in the wake of the recent Indonesian unrest has found that a majority of Taiwan businessmen believe the turmoil will dampen Taiwan's investment in Southeast Asia.

The poll, commissioned by Lai Shih-pao, a National Assembly member belonging to the opposition New Party, found that 49.4 percent of the small- and medium-sized enterprises interviewed think the government should review it's "go south" policy which encourages local firms to invest in Southeast Asia rather than mainland China.

Among the respondents, 61.5 percent said the Indonesian upheaval has discouraged them from investing there, while 75 percent think the government should review its "no haste, be patient" policy regarding investment in mainland China.

Nearly half, or 48.7 percent of the respondents, said the ROC government has not provided them with sufficient assistance, and named the following areas, in order of priority, in which they would most like to see improved government help: the conclusion of investment-protection pacts; the provision of information or consulting services; comprehensive evacuation plans in cases of emergency; help for investors claiming compensation for damages; and better loan services.

Of a total of 1,023 questionnaires distributed in the survey conducted between May 21-26, only 165 replies were considered valid, 43 percent of which approved President Lee Teng-hui's policies regarding business.

The survey results were released at a public hearing on the relative merits of the government's "go south" policy compared with the opposition Democratic Progressive Party's "go west" policy, which encourages businessmen to put their money into mainland China.

Chou Tien, a professor at Chung Yuan Christian University, criticized the government's policy of countering market forces by trying to divert the island's capital flow from the lucrative mainland China market to the turmoil-besieged Southeast Asian markets for political reasons.

This policy has been largely successful, partly because Beijing has never renounced the use of force against the island, but Chou urged the government to strike a balance between national security and economic development.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN IMPORTERS REFUSE GUARANTEES ISSUED BY PAKISTAN BANKS
DOC.DATELINE: Bangkok, June 3 (CNA) (By F. C. Kuo and Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: After Pakistan's sixth nuclear test, exporters in many East Asian countries, including Taiwan, have refused to accept letters of credit issued by Pakistani banks due to increased risks of doing business with Pakistani firms.

According to a recent report in the Islamabad-based Business Recorder newspaper, exporters in many Asian countries, such as Taiwan and South Korea, have informed their Pakistani business partners that they would not accept letters of credit of 120 days or 180 days issued by Pakistani banks. Exporters are instead asking for guarantee letters issued by foreign banks.

The report cited the country's recent nuclear tests for the decision, which led to international investment and consulting companies such as Moody's Investors Service to downgrade the highest level for the country's offshore debt from B2 to B3.

The move, coupled with a recent freeze by Pakistan's national bank on business dealings in foreign currencies, has significantly increased risks for foreign companies doing business with Pakistani firms, the report said.

Many Pakistani firms said they are troubled by foreign business demands that they be paid immediately upon receiving their letters of credit and that they provide stand-by letters of credit issued by foreign banks.
