DOC.HEADLINE: NARCOTICS-RELATED CRIME ON THE RISE

TEXT.P: Narcotics-related crime has risen over the past year and drug abuse among adolescents has also become more prevalent, a senior law enforcement officer reported on Wednesday.

Wu Ying, director of the anti-narcotics center under the Ministry of Justice Investigation Bureau (MJIB), issued the warning at a national anti-drug meeting held at the Veterans General Hospital in suburban Taipei.

Wu said drug-related crime increased last year, reversing a downward trend that began in 1993 when the government launched a war on drugs aimed at eradicating illegal narcotics trafficking and abuse on the island.

Quoting official tallies, Wu said law enforcement authorities handled more than 45,000 new narcotics-related criminal cases in 1997, up 24 percent from the year-earlier level. Meanwhile, 2,900 kilograms of contraband drugs were seized last year, up 40 percent on the 1996 figure.

"All these figures indicate that drug crime surged again in 1997 after declining steadily for four years," Wu noted, adding that mainland China remained the largest source of narcotics smuggled into Taiwan last year.
Speaking on the same occasion, Liu Wei-chung, a prosecutor with the Taiwan High Court, said the number of repeat drug offenders has also risen steeply in recent years.

Repeat offenders accounted for 31 percent of narcotics-related convictions in 1993. This percentage rose to 41 percent in 1994, 47 percent in 1995, 52 percent in 1996 and 62 percent in 1997, according to government statistics.
Liu attributed this rise mainly to the high profits to be made in the drug trade and the difficulties involved in overcoming drug addiction.

Meanwhile, Liu said, drug abuse among teens and young adults has also become more rampant, with the number of convicted juvenile drug offenders picking up 3.09 percent in 1997 compared with the year-earlier level.
His claim was illustrated by official tallies which show that the number of convicted drug abusers aged between 14 and 24 made up 24 percent of total offenders in 1995, rising to 26 percent in 1996.

The national anti-narcotics meeting was part of a series of activities held to mark the June 3 Opium Suppression Movement Day, which has been observed since 1930 in commemoration of the 1839 burning of imported opium in China during the Opium War against Britain.

Vice President Lien Chan delivered a keynote speech at the opening ceremony of the meeting, in which he reaffirmed the government's determination to continue its all-out anti-narcotics campaign for the nation's well-being.

Lien said that as Taiwan sits on a convenient geographical location and has a liberal, booming economy, many international drug rings try to use the island as a narcotics transshipping and money laundering center.

"Against this backdrop, we must step up cooperation with other countries and mainland China in thwarting such attempts," Lien said, adding that Taiwan must also establish a comprehensive legal system to fight all narcotics-related crime.
Lien said relevant government agencies should also join forces with private social groups to help drug addicts quit their habits.

DOC.HEADLINE: COSTS FOR SYDNEY'S OLYMPIC GAMES SKYROCKET TO US$4 BILLION

TEXT.P: The cost of hosting the 2000 Olympic Games in Sydney has ballooned to A$6 billion (US$4 billion) from the original estimate of A$2.3 billion (US$1.5 billion), according to New South Wales (NSW) Treasurer Michael Egan.
In submitting the 1998-99 budget at the NSW parliament yesterday, Egan said the total cost of hosting the Olympic Games in Sydney would exceed US$4 billion.

When Sydney defeated Beijing in a bid to host the event in 1993, its proposal did not take into account the costs for items such as police security, waterway maintenance, transport and health services.

The Sydney Organizing Committee of Olympic Games' (SOCOG) updated estimate has NSW government spending on construction of venues and other infrastructure at A$2.2 billion (US$1.47 billion), private sector spending at A$1.1 billion (US$730 million), and an additional A$617 million (US$411 million) in government spending.
The Olympic Games will be held in September 2000, in Sydney with more than 10,000 athletes from at least 100 countries expected to compete in various events.

DOC.HEADLINE: SHARE PRICES UP ON TAIEX

TEXT.P: Share prices opened high and closed even higher on the Taipei Stock Exchange (TAIEX) on Wednesday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, increasing 77.56 points to close at 7,643.2.
The bourse opened at 7,631.98, and experienced a high of 7,699.48 and a low of 7,598.16.

Dealers said that although the market rebounded, buyers were still lacking confidence, with large fluctuations in the middle session and the movement of foreign investors continuing to draw attention.
Gainers outnumbered losers by 323 to 105, with 56 issues remaining unchanged.

A total of 1.73 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$92.79 billion, decreasing from the previous trading session which saw 1.89 billion stocks change hands on a market turnover of NT$105.96 billion.

All eight major categories gained ground, with foodstuff stocks moving up the most at 2.0 percent, followed by bank and finance shares at 1.8 percent, pulp and paper issues at 1.7 percent, textile stocks at 1.2 percent, cement shares at 0.9 percent, plastics and chemical issues at 0.3 percent, electrical stocks at 0.2 percent, and construction shares at 0.1 percent.

The 10 listed companies enjoying the largest turnovers in Wednesday's trading were: Ever Fortune Industries; China Steel; ASE; Macronix International; Picvue Electronics; ACER; Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing; Liton Electronic; Siliconware Precision Industries Co.; and Winbond Electronics Corp.

DOC.HEADLINE: US LEADS WORLD IN INTERNET USAGE, ROC RANKS 5TH, M'LAND 10TH

TEXT.P: The United States leads the world in Internet usage with almost 40 percent of its total population having gone online. Taiwan ranks fifth ahead of Japan, the United Kingdom, South Korea, mainland China and France, according to a poll conducted by Intel.

During his visit to Tokyo, Intel Chairman Andy Grove said Japan was lagging behind the US in information technology (IT) investment and warned that if this trend continued, Japan could fall behind in its global competitiveness.
Japanese investment in IT is running at two percent of gross domestic product compared with four percent in the US.
The primary driver of growth in the IT industry was the Internet, Grove said. In Japan, only 23 percent of all businesses were connected to the Internet compared with 50 percent in the US.
He added that the Internet business market in the US is growing dramatically, and at last count was worth 1.25 trillion Japanese yen compared with only 81.8 billion yen in Japan.
Japanese companies are the world's dominant suppliers of hardware in this digital age, but the country is reliant on American companies for operating systems and for microprocessor units.
Grove said it would take more than a year for Japan and other Asian countries to catch up to the US in Internet usage.

The Intel survey results ranked Malaysia second in the usage of the Internet, followed by Australia and Germany. Taiwan ranked fifth, followed by the UK, Japan, Korea, France, mainland China, Thailand, the Philippines and Russia.

DOC.HEADLINE: SENIOR APEC OFFICIALS AGREE ON AGENDA FOR TELMIN3

TEXT.P: Senior officials of the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation (APEC) set the agenda for the Third APEC Ministerial Meeting on the Telecommunications and Information Industry (TELMIN3), which is slated to start Wednesday in Singapore.
The two-day senior officials' meeting proceeded smoothly with representatives from the 18 APEC economies reaching an agreement on several significant areas of cooperation.
They agreed to push forward a pro-active agenda on electronic-commerce (e-commerce). To do so, they defined a constructive APEC telecommunications reference framework for action which will:
1. promote e-commerce for use by businesses and consumers;
2. contribute to the harmonization of the region's e-commerce policies;
3. promote the development of e-commerce infrastructure, services and applications in ways relevant to the needs of users in the region; and
4. facilitate the electronic delivery of government services.
These initiatives will enhance the capabilities of APEC economies to harness available information technologies to function effectively in an increasingly digital economy.
Recognizing the importance of the private sector in this field, officials have recommended an enhanced partnership with the private sector to ensure the success of these efforts.

The officials also expressed their commitment to work cooperatively with other APEC forums that have also undertaken e-commerce activity, in particular the APEC Electronic Commerce Task Force. Both Singapore and Australia are co-chairs of this task force.
Senior APEC officials also finalized details of the world's first multilateral Mutual Recognition Arrangement (MRA) covering telecommunications equipment.

The MRA will reduce technical barriers to trade in telecommunications equipment by allowing equipment to be tested in the exporting economy in accordance with the importing economy's standards. Telecommunications equipment can then be accepted in the importing economy with minimal additional regulatory action, thereby reducing the time it takes for a product to appear on the market.
Negotiations on the MRA were concluded in the short space of nine months with the majority of APEC economies indicating on Wednesday their willingness to commit to dates for their participation.
Ministers are expected to endorse this landmark agreement when they meet on Thursday, conference sources said.
Senior APEC officials also identified a key impediment to economies' transition into the digital economy, that is, access to basic telecommunications infrastructure.

The senior officials will seek the ministerial endorsement of a list of Universal Access Principles which will provide guidance on how APEC economies should address this task in a manner consistent with existing legal and regulatory environments of each economy.
TELMIN3 sources said the APEC task force on e-commerce was set up in response to a call by APEC leaders last November for a coordinated APEC-wide work plan on e-commerce.

DOC.HEADLINE: ITC TO INVESTIGATE TAIWAN COMPANY FOR PATENT INFRINGEMENT

TEXT.P: The US International Trade Commission (ITC) voted Tuesday to investigate patent infringement charges against 12 companies, including one from Taiwan's Hsinchu Industrial Science Park.

Mitsubishi Chemical Corporation of Tokyo, Japan, and Mitsubishi Chemical America, Inc. of New York, filed the complaint on April 30, 1998. The items in question are certain organic photoconductor drums and other similar products.

Under the Tariff Act of 1930, section 337, it is illegal to import to the United States, sell for importation, or to sell within the United States after the importation, items and products which have been patented in the US.

Mitsubishi, the patent owner for the organic photoconductor drums identified the following companies in its complaint: Sinonar Corp. of Hsinchu, Taiwan; AEG Elektrofotografie GmbH, of Warstein, Germany; AEG Photoconductor Corp., of Hamilton, Ohio; Dainippon Ink & Chemicals, Inc., of Tokyo, Japan; DIC Trading (USA), Inc., of Fort Lee, New Jersey; Fuji Electric Co., Ltd., of Tokyo, Japan; Fuji Denki of Hong Kong; US Fuji Electric, Inc., of Piscataway, New Jersey; Shindengen Electric Manufacturing Co., Ltd., of Tokyo, Japan; Lumphun Shindengen Co., Ltd., of Lumphum, Thailand; Shindengen America, Inc., of Westlake Village, California; and Yamanashi Electronics Co., Ltd., of Kofu, Japan.

By instituting an investigation, the ITC has not yet decided on the merits of the case, the commission said in a press release. Within 45 days after instituting the investigation, the ITC will set a target date for completing the investigation.
The administrative law judge will make an initial determination as to whether there was a violation of section 337, and that initial determination is subject to review by the commission.
The products at issue in the investigation are coated cylinders that are the central components in laser printers, copier machines, facsimile machines, and other electrophotographic machines.

DOC.HEADLINE: NT DOLLAR UP

TEXT.P: The New Taiwan dollar on Wednesday rebounded on the Taipei foreign exchange market, moving up NT$0.153 to close at 34.186.
The local currency opened at 34.199 against the greenback and was traded between 34.16 and 34.285.
The interbank trading reached US$439 million.

DOC.HEADLINE: NEW ARMS SALE UNRELATED TO BEIJING SUMMIT: ROC DEFENSE MINISTER

TEXT.P: The proposed sale of an advanced radar system for the Republic of China's newly acquired F-16 jet fighters "seems not at all related" to the upcoming summit in June between US President Bill Clinton and mainland Chinese President Jiang Zemin, Chiang Chung-ling, the ROC's minister of national defense said on Wednesday.

Monday's announcement by the US Department of Defense that it is willing to provide Taiwan with 28 Pathfinder/Sharpshooter navigation and targeting pods just weeks before the Beijing summit appeared to indicate the US' commitment to continued defensive arms sales to the ROC military.

However, Chiang ruled out the possibility that this second major weapons deal between the US and Taiwan so far this year "bears any relations to the Beijing summit," and has no "special meaning" in this respect.
Chiang stressed that established US policy was followed in the proposed US$160 million deal, the main purpose of which is to improve the navigation and targeting abilities of some of the F-16s.

The Pentagon said the Pathfinder/Sharpshooter pods allow the F-16 to navigate at low altitudes and find targets more accurately. According to defense industry sources, the new equipment also greatly improves night flight safety.
The Pentagon has informed the US Congress of the planned arms sales to Taiwan. Congress has 60 days to object to the deal, otherwise the sale will go forward.

Taiwan has taken delivery of 80 F-16s since the two countries struck a deal in 1992 for the sale of 150 F-16s, with another 20 still in the US, where they are being used at US air bases to train ROC pilots.

DOC.HEADLINE: FPC MAY SIGN INVESTMENT AGREEMENT WITH MAINLAND CHINA: REPORT

TEXT.P: Wang Yung-ching, chairman of the board of the Formosa Plastics Corporation (FPC), is likely to sign an investment agreement with mainland China's Fujian Province, according to an unconfirmed report.

Officials of the Investment Commission under the Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) stressed that an investment agreement is just an expression of intention, rather than an actual investment, and thus does not violate regulations laid down by the government of the Republic of China.

However, as a leader in Taiwan's petrochemical industry, FPC's intentions are of great concern to the government, and although Wang's current trip to the mainland is a personal affair, MOEA officials said it is under close scrutiny.

Wang is scheduled to meet with Fujian provincial government officials during his trip, said the report, which also disclosed that Wang has paid visits to several "important ports" in the province, in addition to continuing his commitment to construct a power plant in Zhangzhou, also in Fujian.

The report said Wang is likely to sign an investment agreement with Fujian Province, which will probably be connected with FPC's intention to play a future leading role in the petrochemical and energy resource industries on both sides of the Taiwan Strait.
The MOEA officials said that it is still uncertain whether an investment agreement will be signed, but added that they are monitoring developments in the matter very carefully.

DOC.HEADLINE: CANADA, TAIWAN UPBEAT ON BILATERAL TRADE RELATIONS
DOC.DATELINE: Ottawa, June 2 (CNA) (By S.C. Chang and Fang Wen-hung)

TEXT.P: Representatives from Canada and the Republic of China announced the signing of a joint communique on developing bilateral trade relations at the 12th joint meeting of the Canada-Taiwan Business Association (CTBA), which ended Tuesday.

The communique was signed and read by Tom Appleton, chairman of the CTBA, and Theodore Cheng, chairman of the Canadian Committee of the Chinese National Association of Industry and Commerce. They both noted that the optimistic atmosphere surrounding the two-day meeting was further enhanced by the lively discussions and the continued prosperity of Canada and Taiwan's economies.

The importance both governments placed on the conference was evident in the attendance and speeches of Sergio Marchi, Canada's minister of international trade; John Manley, Canada's minister of industry; Shirley Kuo, ROC's Cabinet minister without portfolio and George S.Y. Chen, ROC's executive vice minister of transportation and communications.

Marchi lauded Taiwan for being a dynamic economy which "has weathered the region's pressures better than most. Its resilience is a clear testimony both to its internal strengths and its international reputation."

Marchi said bilateral relations should be based on non-discriminatory and mutually beneficial agreements. He said he hoped Taiwan could accomplish this to ensure its early entry into the World Trade Organization. He also urged both sides to speed up negotiations over an agreement to avoid double taxation.

Manley indicated that the potential for the two economies to become partners was great, and cited the signing of a memorandum of understanding for cooperation in communications and information technologies on Monday as an example. In addition, he suggested aviation safety and environmental technology as other ideal areas for cooperation.

The next joint meeting of the CTBA is scheduled to be held in Taipei next year. Doug Young, a heavyweight in Canada's Liberal Party, replaced Appleton as chairman of the association on Tuesday, and Keith Pope, vice president of Canadian Airlines International became the new vice chairman. They pledged continued efforts to improve Canada-ROC economic relations.

DOC.HEADLINE: TSMC CHAIRMAN OPTIMISTIC ABOUT SEMICONDUCTOR SECTOR'S FUTURE

TEXT.P: Morris Chang, a heavyweight in Taiwan's semiconductor industry, said on Wednesday that he sees "no dark clouds" over the semiconductor industry, despite its current setback in the island's stock market resulting from the regional financial crisis.
The Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Corp. (TSMC) chairman made the optimistic remarks in a speech on the future development of Taiwan's semiconductor industry at Computex Taipei '98 on Wednesday.
The massive five-day exhibition opened on Tuesday at the Taipei World Trade Center, with 892 local and foreign businesses displaying their latest information technology products.

Chang said that Taiwan is enjoying a similar experience to that of Japan in developing its high-tech sector, explaining that like Japan, Taiwan holds a precious resource -- professional personnel full of creative energy, who have created in a relatively short period a semiconductor sector able to compete in the international market.
Chang pointed out that the semiconductor industry did not start to take root on Taiwan until 1976, when the government began trying to introduce new technologies to the island from the United States.
In less than two decades, the semiconductor sector has grown into one of Taiwan's leading industries, with a current production value of around NT$247.9 billion (US$7.29 billion), he said.
Chang added that the island is home to 60 design companies, three manufacturers of silicon wafer materials, 20 silicon wafer makers, 23 packing factories and 11 companies for product tests.

The chairman said that he is very optimistic of the sector's future development, noting that although a number of semiconductor stocks have been seen significant declines recently, this merely reflects periodical sluggishness.

However, Chang indicated that Taiwan's semiconductor industry is now suffering from insufficient innovation, which is expected to be the sector's largest obstacle to business expansion and development. He suggested that domestic enterprises and educational institutes should spare no effort to cultivate innovation resources that are able to contribute to the sector's continued competitiveness.

DOC.HEADLINE: SEF CHAIRMAN LIKELY TO VISIT MAINLAND CHINA IN OCTOBER

TEXT.P: Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) Chairman Koo Chen-fu, Taiwan's top negotiator with mainland China, is unlikely to pay a visit to the mainland before October, ranking officials in charge of mainland affairs said on Wednesday.

The mainland authorities are not expected to agree to resume cross-strait negotiations before the meeting between US President Bill Clinton and mainland Chinese President Jiang Zemin later this month, said the officials from the Mainland Affairs Council (MAC), the Cabinet-level agency which charts Taiwan's policy toward the mainland.

The officials said the mainland Chinese side will not reopen talks with Taiwan before the Clinton-Jiang meeting, slated to begin on June 28 and wrap up on July 1, making it unlikely that Koo will visit the mainland prior to the event. They opined that the SEF chairman will probably realize his mainland trip in late September or, more likely, early October.

During the interim period, the mainland authorities will make gestures showing that they would welcome a visit by Koo, while at the same time seeking to damage Taiwan's international image with moves such as the recent spying allegations against several Taiwan businessmen, in a bid to push the United States into compromising on the "Taiwan issue," the MAC analysts said.

After an impasse of almost three years, cross-strait relations began showing signs of improvement in late April after the SEF and its mainland counterpart -- the Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait (ARATS) -- reached consensus on arranging a meeting between Koo and his ARATS counterpart Wang Daohan within this year.
But bilateral relations again hit a low ebb after the ARATS turned down an SEF invitation on May 12 inviting an ARATS vice secretary-general to visit Taiwan in late May.

Turning to the possible Koo-Wang meeting, the MAC officials warned the government of Beijing's intention to use the occasion to make the US believe that the two sides of the Taiwan Strait have agreed to end their state of hostility, thus backing their demands that Washington stop arms sales to Taiwan.
The SEF and ARATS are semiofficial organizations set up to represent Taipei and Beijing in bilateral exchanges in the absence of formal contacts between the two sides.
Regular SEF-ARATS talks were unilaterally cut by Beijing in 1995 after President Lee Teng-hui paid a visit to the United States earlier that year.

DOC.HEADLINE: CIB TO HELP ABDUCTED GIRL SEEK HER BIRTH PARENTS

TEXT.P: The Criminal Investigation Bureau (CIB) said on Wednesday it will help a Taiwan girl who was sold to an Australian couple by a criminal ring in March 1981 to find her biological parents.

CBI Deputy Director Lin Kuo-tung said the girl, whose Chinese name is Lin Mei-li, was one of 64 Taiwan babies sold to couples in several Western countries by the Chu Li-ching white slavery ring in the late 1970s and early 1980s.
According to Lin, the girl was sold to an Australian couple residing in Melbourne for US$3,000 - US$4,000 when she was six months old.
"With the CBI's assistance, Mei-li, now 17, will fly to Taiwan on June 9 for a homecoming visit in the company of her adoptive parents," Lin said.
Lin Mei-li, who was named Kartja Elizabeth Wunderle by her adoptive parents, will hold a news conference to plead for public assistance in seeking her real parents.
Lin said the CBI will collect DNA samples from Mei-li to facilitate the identification of her biological parents.
Lin further said CBI officers have already questioned Chu Li-ching, the mastermind behind the white slavery ring, and her accomplices, about Mei-li's birth parents.

"However, none of them knows who Lin Mei-li's parents are," Lin said, adding that if her parents come forward, the CBI will arrange for them to meet their daughter in private to protect their privacy.
Lin said the CBI still doesn't know whether Mei-li was born out of wedlock and deserted by her parents or whether the baby girl was stolen by the ring.
Chu's white slaving ring was busted in 1982, by which time it had sold 64 babies for adoption in the United States, Australia, Germany and Switzerland.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT LEE RECEIVES KIWANIS GOVERNOR

TEXT.P: President Lee Teng-hui on Wednesday received Walter G. Sellers, governor of Kiwanis International, and lauded the local chapter of the international organization for its contributions to society in the Republic of China.

Accompanied by Chang Hsiao-yen, secretary-general of the ruling Kuomintang (KMT) Central Committee, Lee Pen-jen, director of the KMT's Social Affairs Department, and Wu Chih-chung, governor of the ROC District Kiwanis International, Sellers and his wife paid the president a courtesy call at the Presidential Office.
President Lee told his guests that the ROC District Kiwanis International has a long-standing performance record for its social services work and the many public welfare activities it has held.

He pointed out that the Kiwanis International, which is aimed at serving and helping others, conforms with his own idea of social and moral reformation, both of which share the goal of improving social behavior and public morality in order to create a harmonious society.

Sellers also praised the good performance of the ROC District Kiwanis International and predicted success for the 1999 Kiwanis Asia-Pacific annual meeting and the 2001 Kiwanis world annual meeting, both of which will be held in Taipei.

DOC.HEADLINE: LEE URGES NHIB TO ENCOURAGE RESOURCE CONSERVATION

TEXT.P: President and Kuomintang Chairman Lee Teng-hui on Wednesday urged the National Health Insurance Bureau to adopt differential insurance rates in its national health program to encourage the public not to squander government medical resources.

He called on the NHIB to partially refund insurance deductions or reduce insurance rates for people who do not use their insurance cards for an entire year. Each card entitles a person to six visits to hospitals or clinics.

Lee also requested that the bureau consider subsidizing three special groups -- laborers without permanent employers, handicapped people and aborigines. He also suggested the bureau amend the scope of its coverage to include enterovirus, which in recent weeks has afflicted more than 200,000 children and killed 26 newborn babies across the island.
Lee made the remarks while hearing a report from the NHIB at a meeting of the KMT's Central Standing Committee on the national insurance program. The plan was first implemented three years ago.
His comments came after Taiwan Provincial Governor James Soong suggested last month that the program cover social minority groups.
Meanwhile, NHIB Vice Director Liu Chien-hsian said the bureau must conduct financial assessments before deciding whether Lee's suggestions can be adopted.

DOC.HEADLINE: RESIDENTS NEAR FORMER RCA PLANT TO BE GIVEN FREE PHYSICAL CHECKUPS

TEXT.P: Following a controversy over a contaminated tract of land in Taoyuan, northern Taiwan, the Taiwan Provincial Assembly has decided to give local residents free physical checkups.
The Taiwan Provincial Assembly will also ask the Taiwan Provincial Government to compensate the former workers of the now defunct RCA factory and their relatives.

Peng Tien-fu of the opposition Democratic Progressive Party said in the Taiwan Provincial Assembly on Wednesday that the victims of the contaminated land are not limited to former workers at the factory, but also include local residents who consumed well water contaminated by the factory.
Peng demanded that the provincial government's Department of Health provide local residents with free physical checkups, and that tap water be supplied to the whole area.
He said that the Department of Labor Affairs should compensate the former workers according to labor vocational damage regulations, and provide help for the families of workers who have already died.
At Peng's request, the national assembly passed a resolution to convene a meeting of environmental officials, labor representatives and related agencies, to discuss the problem as soon as possible.

The Environmental Quality Protection Foundation, a non-profit group, said recently that as many as 43 former RCA workers contracted cancer due to water contaminated by the factory. Nearby residents have also reported cancer cases. For many years, RCA provided the contaminated ground water for the workers to drink because tap water was not available at the site at that time.

RCA established a production facility for the manufacture of electronics and electric home appliances on the 23.71-acre plot in 1970. The US-based General Electric Co. took over the plant's operations in 1986, and two years later, the operation went to French-based Thomson Corp. The factory was closed several years ago.
The land now belongs to two local companies -- Hong Yi and Chang Chung -- which reportedly purchased it for some NT$1.6 billion (US$48.8 million).

The two companies first applied to rezone the industrial land for commercial and residential use shortly after the purchase, but the application was put on hold in 1994 when reports emerged that RCA had dumped toxic waste into wells on the land for nearly two decades, seriously contaminating the whole area.

At the request of the two companies, GE and Thomson launched a six-month clean-up project late last year to get rid of the contaminated ground water, and the Environmental Protection Administration (EPA) has now been informed that the clean-up is complete.

The EPA is scheduled to examine the site later this month, and if the project is found to have been unsuccessful, the site will be declared "permanently contaminated" and banned from commercial and residential use.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN URGED TO PROTECT STRAY DOGS

TEXT.P: International animal rights activists staged cross-border demonstrations on Wednesday to push Taiwan to give better protection to tens of thousands of stray dogs on the island.
The Taipei-based Life Conservationist Association (LCA) said the demonstrations were jointly organized by overseas Chinese groups and several international animal rights organizations.
An LCA spokesman said the moves were aimed at urging the Republic of China government to improve its treatment of stray dogs and to better protect all animals.

"The animal rights activists will demonstrate in front of the ROC's representative offices in more than 10 major cities around the world, including Washington, D.C., New York, Los Angeles, Paris, London and Hamburg, from 11:30 a.m through 1:30 p.m. on Wednesday (local time)," the spokesman said.
He quoted a study by the US-based People for the Ethical Treatment of Animals as saying that Taiwan has an estimated 1.5 million stray dogs.

"The organization said the ROC government has failed to treat stray dogs in a humanitarian manner," the spokesman said, adding that the Legislative Yuan should pass the animal protection bill as soon as possible to imporve treatment of stray dogs and other animals.

The spokesman further said the most effective way to resolve stray dogs problems is to regulate trade in dogs and their reproduction. "Equally important is to train animal welfare officers," he noted.

The spokesman also suggested that government authorities use high dosages of anesthetics, such as pentobarbital, to kill ailing stray dogs instead of using such inhumane methods as electrocution, poisoning and drowning.

Quoting a recent LCA field survey, the spokesman said Keelung. Ilan and Miaoli county governments have improved their treatment of stray dogs. Nevertheless, he said, there is still ample room for many county governments to improve protection for stray dogs.

TEXT.P: International animal rights activists staged cross-border demonstrations on Wednesday to push Taiwan to give better protection to tens of thousands of stray dogs on the island.
The Taipei-based Life Conservationist Association (LCA) said the demonstrations were jointly organized by overseas Chinese groups and several international animal rights organizations.

"The animal rights activists will demonstrate in front of the ROC's representative offices in more than 10 major cities in six countries, including Washington, D.C., New York, Los Angeles, Paris, London and Hamburg, from 11:30 a.m through 1:30 p.m. on Wednesday (local time)," the spokesman said.
He quoted a study by the US-based People for the Ethical Treatment of Animals as saying that Taiwan has an estimated 1.5 million stray dogs.

"The organization said the ROC government has failed to treat stray dogs in a humanitarian manner," the spokesman said, adding that the organization will urge Premier Vincent Siew to push the Legislative Yuan to pass the animal protection bill as soon as possible to imporve treatment of stray dogs and other animals.

The spokesman also suggested that government authorities use high dosages of anesthetics, such as pentobarbital, to kill ailing stray dogs instead of using such inhumane methods as electrocution, poisoning and drowning.

Quoting a recent LCA field survey, the spokesman said Keelung. Ilan and Miaoli county governments have improved their treatment of stray dogs. Nevertheless, he said, there is still ample room for many county governments to improve protection for stray dogs.

Meanwhile, a CNA report from Washington quoted Stephen Chen, the de factor ROC ambassador to the US, as saying that his office has received many letters from American citizens criticizing Taiwan's alleged inhumane treatment of stray dogs.

"We have written to all those people, explaining our government's efforts to improve protection for stray dogs. We have also conveyed some constructive suggestions presented by them to relevant government agencies for reference," Chen said.

DOC.HEADLINE: AUSTRALIA CONTINUES TO SEEK N-TEST BAN

TEXT.P: Australia will continue to promote nuclear test bans and address the global security implications of the recent nuclear tests by India and Pakistan following the condemnation of the two countries by a disarmament conference in Geneva.

In a statement faxed to the CNA on Wednesday, Foreign Minister Alexander Downer said: "International condemnation of India's and Pakistan's nuclear testing has been powerfully reinforced at a special session of the Conference on Disarmament (in Geneva on June 2)."

The statement went on: "Indicative of the strength of international feeling on this issue, 47 countries, including the five nuclear weapon states, co-sponsored an Australia-New Zealand statement at the special session condemning the (nuclear) tests."

It said the nuclear tests by India and Pakistan blatantly challenged the international regime of non-proliferation of nuclear weapons and threatened the process of disarmament and the goal of eliminating nuclear weapons altogether.

The statement called on "both India and Pakistan to sign and ratify without condition the Comprehensive Nuclear Test Ban Treaty, to accede to the Non-Proliferation Treaty and to engage in negotiations to conclude a ban on the production of fissile material for weapons purposes."

It concluded: "Australia will continue to take the lead in regional and multilateral fora to promote urgent considerations of means to address the global security implications of India's and Pakistan's actions."

DOC.HEADLINE: LEE TENG-HUI ASKS KMT MEMBERS TO HELP THEIR OWN

TEXT.P: Kuomintang Chairman Lee-Teng-hui on Wednesday requested that senior KMT members help candidates fielded by the ruling party win in year-end elections.

Lee made the request at a KMT central policy guiding committee meeting in which he urged senior party members to do their utmost to help party candidates win mayoral, city council and legislative elections on December 5.

Lee said the elections will be vital if the party is to maintain its political power at the central and local levels. Assistance from senior party members will help the KMT consolidate its power base.
The KMT chairman also asked the committee and other KMT agencies to prepare for the General Assembly, which will hold its plenary session in July.
Lee likened the National Assembly and the Legislative Yuan to the two wings of a bird and suggested they coordinate with each other to jointly carry out the ruling party's policies.

Commenting on the "government reformation project" proposed by the Executive Yuan, Lee said he hopes all legislators will understand that the project is an important administrative reform that will increase government efficiency.

DOC.HEADLINE: CROSS-STRAIT TRADE UP SLIGHTLY

TEXT.P: Two-way indirect trade between Taiwan and mainland China totaled US$5.3 billion for this year's first quarter, an increase of 1.3 percent over the same period last year, according to government statistics.

The Cabinet-level Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics said in its report that Taiwan exported US$4.3 billion worth of goods to the mainland during the three-month period, down 1.9 percent over a year ago, while imports from the mainland increased 17.9 percent to US$1 billion.

Taiwan's exports of mechanical equipment to the mainland increased 19.2 percent. Exports of industrial-use textiles, meanwhile, fell 18 percent, while plastic product and synthetic fiber exports dropped 4.7 and 9.6 percent, respectively.

Cross-strait trade accounted for 9.8 percent of Taiwan's total trade during the first quarter. The island's trade surplus with the mainland amounted to US$3.3 billion, down 6.8 percent from year-earlier levels.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC'S COMPETITIVENESS RANKED SIXTH BY SWISS THINK TANK

TEXT.P: Taiwan was ranked the world's sixth most competitive economy, up two from last year's eighth-place standing, by a Swiss economic think tank, the Cabinet-level Council for Economic Planning and Development said on Wednesday.
The sixth-place ranking is the highest the island has ever received in the Global Competitiveness Report, published annually by the Geneva-based World Economic Forum (WEF).

Despite Asia's financial turmoil, Singapore and Hong Kong retained their respective first- and second-place rankings from last year. The United States was ranked third, followed by Britain and Canada. Rounding out the top ten were the Netherlands at number seven, followed by Switzerland, Norway and Luxembourg.

Taiwan's competitiveness rating also rose in rankings published by another Swiss economic institution, the International Institute for Management Development (IMD). Taiwan advanced from 18th 1997 to 16th this year.

The discrepancy in rankings resulted from different sets of criteria being used to gauge economic competitiveness. Whereas the IMD places heavy emphasis on an economy's ability to generate income, the WEF report measures various economies' efficiency and pace in creating income.
Despite Taiwan's advances in both sets of rankings, Minister of Economic Affairs Wang Chih-kang warned the island against complacency on Wednesday.

DOC.HEADLINE: SINGAPORE HOSTS APEC MEETING ON TELECOM, IT

TEXT.P: The Third APEC Ministerial Meeting for Telecommunications and Information Industry officially opened at Singapore's Ritz Carlton Hotel Wednesday morning with more than 700 delegates and industry leaders from APEC's 18 member economies attending.

Speaking at the opening ceremony, Singapore Prime Minister Goh Chok Tong said the Asian economic crisis was partly due to globalization and revolutionary changes in telecommunications and information technology.

"Our world has shrunk in distance and time," he said. "Financial decisions and the transfer of funds can be made at the click of a mouse, far away from the place where their impact is felt. This is the global village we are living in."

He said the meeting's theme "Realizing the Asia-Pacific Information Society: Reaping the benefits of convergence for the Asia-Pacific's new role in the Global Information Society" is appropriate and timely.
The creation of an Asia-Pacific information society will shape not only the development of telecommunications and information technology but also future society, he said.
The prime minister warned against countries in the region being diverted from developing their information infrastructures by the current economic crisis.

"The financial crisis has shown how crucial it is for us to deal with the challenges of an increasingly interdependent and networked global environment," he said. "Our markets have become so interlinked that the difficulties one economy faces invariably affect other economies."
In response to these challenges, several APEC economies, including Singapore, are constructing national information infrastructures and implementing national IT plans, he said.

Last year, he said, Singapore launched its pilot national multimedia broad-band network, Singapore ONE. By the end of this year, Singapore ONE will be available not only to all homes and businesses but also to schools, libraries and community centers.
He said Singapore will link its information superhighway with all APEC economies. So far, Singapore ONE has broad-band connections to Canada, Japan and the United States, he said.

Besides the ministerial meeting, ministers and delegates held separate dialogues with telecommunication and IT industry leaders on ways of further promoting coordination and cooperation between government organizations and the private sector.

DOC.HEADLINE: TSINGHUA RATED BEST UNIVERSITY IN TAIWAN

TEXT.P: National Tsinghua University was rated the best university in Taiwan, while National Taiwan University (NTU) ranked second and National Chiao Tung University came in third, according to a public opinion survey released by the GlobalView monthly magazine on Wednesday.

The rating was based on the opinions expressed by senior administrators, department chiefs and professors at 55 universities on the island, as well as by high school students, those who intend to take part in the annual joint college entrance exmaination again this year and senior executives at major local enterprises. The magazine sent out a total of 3,500 copies of questionnaires.

Survey results show that Tsinghua was reputed to have the best curriculum and faculty, while its students' overall performance ranked second among the 55 universities studied. National Taiwan University trailed behind Tsinghua in curriculum and faculty, but its students' performance was rated the best.
Overall, Tsinghua received an average score of 4.31 points, slightly higher than NTU's 4.27 points.

The survey also found that National Taiwan University remains the top "dream" school for high school students, while senior business executives most like to employ graduates of National Cheng Kung University.
Meanwhile, Yuan Ze University was reputed to be the school with the greatest development potential.

DOC.HEADLINE: PECC PUTS TAIWAN'S GROWTH RATE AT 6.3 PERCENT IN 1998
DOC.DATELINE: Hong Kong, June 3 (CNA) (By H. S. Wu and Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: Taiwan's growth rates for the next two years are expected to fall only slightly short of its 6.8 percent growth in 1997, according to a forecast by the Pacific Economic Cooperation Council (PECC).
The PECC forecasts growth of 6.3 percent in 1998 and 6.4 percent in 1999.

While Taiwan's economic growth may slow slightly over the next two years, its private investment outlook during the period is expected to brighten. With the opening of new international air transport routes, increased investment is expected in cargo-carrying aircraft. Ongoing, large-scale construction projects will bring in further investment as well.

Taiwan's government is expected to continue removing investment obstacles and promoting the build-operate-transfer model being followed in the construction of its high-speed rail project. The establishment of the Tainan Science-based Industrial Park is also expected to induce more domestic and foreign direct investment in electronics, the report said.

Based on these factors, private investment is expect to grow about 14 percent in 1998-1999. This is Taiwan's highest growth rate in the past seven years. The continuing privatization of state-owned enterprises, however, means investment in publicly owned enterprises will register negative growth.
Meanwhile, Taiwan's real growth of exports and imports in 1998 is expected to amount to 7.6 percent and 7.2 percent, respectively.
The PECC further forecast a three percent rise in the consumer price index and a five percent rise in the wholesale price index in 1998.
Although Taiwan has weathered the region's economic turmoil, owing to its healthy economic fundamentals, the local currency has dropped more than 15 percent since last October.
But Taiwan should be able to cope with the turmoil and continue its robust economic performance over the long term, according to the report.

DOC.HEADLINE: MA SAYS HE IS RUNNING FOR WELFARE OF TAIPEI'S RESIDENTS

TEXT.P: Former Minister of Justice Ma Ying-jeou said on Wednesday that his decision to run in the Taipei mayoral race is aimed at bettering the welfare of Taipei's residents rather than beating incumbent mayor Chen Shui-bian.
Ma made the remarks while visiting the Kuomintang (KMT) caucus of Taipei Council. The KMT mayoral hopeful said the election should be a battle among gentlemen.
Because of his lack of experience in local government administration, Ma called on the councilors to provide him with information on how the city's government can be improved.
The KMT councilors not only welcomed Ma's return to the party but also said they would establish a strategic task force to back up him in the election campaign.

Ma noted that while serving as justice minister, he received support not only from the KMT but also from both opposition parties. As a result, he is confident that he can help mend relations between the Taipei government and the council, which have been tense since Chen was elected mayor.

In related news, Taipei Mayor Chen Shui-bian on Wednesday said his performance while in office guarantees he will win the election. Chen also reiterated his determination to improve the city's administration in the six months that remain before he faces the city's voters.

Wang Chien-shien, the New Party's nominee in the Taipei mayoral race, on Wednesday continued his attack on Ma's credibility. Wang chided Ma for entering the race after saying more than 200 times he would not run.

The former Minister of Finance, however, stressed that his election campaign will not focus on criticizing Ma or Chen. He added that while he may have had an incentive to team up with Ma in the past -- their common goal being Chen's removal from Taipei's helm -- he said that now there is only a slim chance of cooperation between the two men.

DOC.HEADLINE: UNI AIRLINES TO MERGE WITH GREAT CHINA, TAIWAN AIRLINES

TEXT.P: UNI Airlines, Great China Airlines and Taiwan Airlines have been given the green light to merge into a single company, which will also operate under the name UNI Airlines, an UNI official said on Wednesday.

Lin Hung-chih, president of UNI Airlines, said that the augmented UNI Airlines, with a combined staff of nearly 2,000 employees, will devote itself to both domestic and regional routes, including flights to Phuket, Palau and Rangoon.
After the merger is completed, the company will have a fleet of 32 planes and will serve cities throughout Taiwan, as well as offshore islands.
Lin said that the new company hopes to build a close-knit network, so that wherever there are airfields, "there are UNI Airline planes."
UNI Airlines is an offshoot of EVA Airways.

Lin said that in the past year, Taiwan's domestic air industry has undergone drastic changes. All airlines need to provide better service, improve their reputations and maintain decent flight safety records to distinguish themselves from competing airlines, he said.
A spate of air disasters earlier this year prompted a review of flight safety records and suggestions that some of the island's smaller airlines merge.

DOC.HEADLINE: SEMICONDUCTOR GIANT CALLS FOR TAIWAN TO BECOME THE WORLD'S PC CENTER

TEXT.P: With an infrastructure favorable to the development of the information technology industry, Taiwan should make itself into the world's personal computer center, said Brian L. Halla, president of US-based National Semiconductor on Wednesday.
Speaking during "Computex Taipei 1998," Halla said at a press conference that cheap and user-friendly computers are fueling the booming IT industry.
To lower the cost of a PC, while substantially enhancing its power, Halla said his company is trying to incorporate all the major functions of a PC onto a single chip by 1999.
Halla is the second semiconductor industry giant to visit Taiwan in recent weeks, following Intel's Andrew Grove.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN WINS US SUPPORT IN MRA ENDORSEMENT
DOC.DATELINE: Singapore, June 3 (CNA) (By Elizabeth Hsu & Conrad Lu)

TEXT.P: Taiwan's Ministry of Transportation and Communications (MOTC) has won US endorsement of the island's signing of the multilateral Mutual Recognition Agreement (MRA) for telecommunication equipment.

The agreement was reached during a bilateral meeting between Lin Feng-cheng and representatives of the US delegation to the upcoming ministerial-level telecommunications meeting of the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation (APEC) forum, which opened on Wednesday in Singapore.
A discussion on the MRA, which was initiated to help lift trade barriers and facilitate the opening of APEC markets to telecommunication products, is on the agenda of the three-day conference.

The Taiwan delegation at the APEC conference is headed by Minister of Transportation and Communications Lin Fong-cheng, who held three separate bilateral meetings with representatives of the APEC delegations of the United States, Australia and Canada on Tuesday to exchange views on telecommunication cooperation.

The US side has expressed its wish that Taiwan can make more efforts to development its Internet business, while communication officials from Australia showed interest in investing in Taiwan's telecommunication and information technology sectors, said Lin.
He added that the Australian officials also said they are willing to share with Taiwan their expertise and experience in privatization of state-run businesses and trade liberalization.
Lin and his delegation are scheduled to return to Taipei on Saturday.

DOC.HEADLINE: BIOTECHNOLOGY SEEN BOOSTING FOOD PRODUCTION

TEXT.P: Farmers will have to increasingly rely on genetic engineering to produce enough food to feed the world's growing population in the next 30 years, according to reports from the Geneva-based World Trade Organization (WTO) Wednesday.

"People must realize that these GMO or genetically modified organisms are going to be part and parcel of agriculture production," Graham Blight, president of the International Federation of Agricultural Producers, said in the WTO report.
"There's something like US$18 billion worth of crops grown ... now in the world from genetically engineered products. It will be far greater than what we have seen in the past 15 years," he stated.
Blight said it will be possible to develop every single vegetable variety through genetic engineering in the next five to 10 years.
Aside from better quality products and higher yields, biotechnology may also be the answer to shrinking farmlands and water resources.
"(Biotechnology) is going to increase productivity," Bob Frieson, second vice president of the Canadian Federation of Agriculture, was quoted as saying.

Farmers said they would need more land and water sources if they continue to rely on traditional farming. However, Frieson warned farmers that they should also address growing fears over the safety of genetically modified products.
"Once (that message is communicated), then I believe that the markets and consumers will be ready for it," the WTO report quoted Frieson as saying.

DOC.HEADLINE: BOEING TO CLOSE TORONTO PLANT

TEXT.P: Boeing Canada will close its Toronto plant, which employs more than 2,000 people, as production of the MD-11 jetliner will be phased out, representatives announced Wednesday.

The closure will affect 600 employees currently building wings for the MD-11 and follows a previous decision by Boeing to stop production of the MD-80 and MD-90, affecting sub-contracts at the Toronto plant.
Boeing Canada President George Capern said once the last sets of wings for the MD-11 are completed by the end of 1999, "the plant will be phased out -- unless something dramatic happens."
Boeing took over McDonnell Douglas last year. In November, it announced it would phase out production of the MD-80 and MD-90 models, while retaining the MD-95, now called the Boeing 717.
Boeing has other facilities in Winnipeg and Arnprior, west of Ottawa, which Capern said will not be affected by the closure.

DOC.HEADLINE: AUSTRALIA'S HOWARD AND SENIOR MINISTERS LAMBASTE HANSON

TEXT.P: Australian Prime Minister John Howard and his senior ministers for the first time criticized Member of Parliament Pauline Hanson' remarks.
Howard told Parliament Wednesday that Hanson's speech on the floor this week was fanning racism and verged on "deranged."
It was the first time Howard has spoken out against Hanson since she made her first parliamentary speech on September 10, 1996, which contained anti-Asian immigration and anti-Aborigine sentiments.
Howard's comments were followed by those of Deputy Prime Minister Tim Fischer, who ridiculed Hanson's absence from two-thirds of the 148 legislative votes during her time as an MP.
Federal Treasurer Peter Costello took part in the criticism.

"Social Hansonism starts from the wrong values. Economic Hansonism is just a variant on the notion that if you seal Australia's borders, somehow you will make us rich, but you will make us poor," he said.

Public opinion polls show that Hanson could win a re-election bid in the general elections slated for later this year, and her One Nation Party candidates could win between two to four seats in the Queensland elections on June 13.

DOC.HEADLINE: US DISEASE CONTROL EXPERTS TO HELP TAIWAN ERADICATE ENTEROVIRUS

TEXT.P: Two specialists from the US' Center for Disease Control & Prevention (CDC) are due to arrive in Taiwan to help arrest the spread of enterovirus, which has killed 29 infants in nearly one month, sources from the Department of Health (DOH) said Thursday.
The US epidemiologists are expected to visit major medical centers in Taiwan to discuss enterovirus cases and to conduct laboratory diagnostic tests.

According to reports as of Wednesday night, a total of 29 babies and children have died of complications caused by enterovirus infections, particularly enterovirus 71, since an epidemic broke out early last month.

Ten more young patients were admitted into hospitals in critical condition on Wednesday, increasing the number of hospitalized cases of those affected by enterovirus to 132. Conditions of some of those are extremely critical, and chances of survival are slim.
Meanwhile, the reported number of infected children who visited hospitals for treatment totaled 9,047 islandwide as of Thursday morning.
Gravely concerned about the epidemic, Premier Vincent Siew on Thursday ordered the establishment of a crisis prevention task force to accelerate the effective handling of this disease.

DOH Director-General Chan Chi-shean visited the Changhua Christian General Hospital in central Taiwan, where the most number of fatalities were reported, to gain a better understanding of the epidemic.

Doctors remain undecided as to what has led the virus to kill, and whether the victims died of heart, lung or brain failure. To determine the cause of death, an autopsy must be performed, but so far no parent has agreed to permit such an operation on their child.
While DOH officials say the number of reported enterovirus cases is beginning to subside, some doctors believe the epidemic has not yet reached its peak.
According to Dr. Lee Ching-yun from the Pediatrics Department of National Taiwan University Hospital, some 200,000 to 300,000 infants and children have fallen victim to the epidemic islandwide.

As the group of enteroviruses, including type 71 and coxsackievirus reported earlier in April, are usually more active during the summer, they are expected to affect more young children before September, Lee said. He estimated that the number of infected children may top 500,000 islandwide over the next four months.

Many of the infected children develop hand-foot-and-mouth disease and herpangina, the most common symptoms of the enterovirus infections. But if victims also suffer from unrelieved high fever, nausea, headaches, rapid breathing and lack of appetite, parents should take them to the hospital, Lee said.

Although the epidemic is found to be more rampant among children in central and northern counties of Taichung, Changhua, Miaoli, Hsinchu and Taoyuan, similar cases were also reported in Tainan, Kaohsiung and Pingtung Counties in southern Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC RANKS SIXTH IN WORLD COMPETITIVE RANKINGS

TEXT.P: The Republic of China moved up to sixth place in the Swiss-based World Economic Forum's (WEF) 1998 global competitive rankings. Taiwan ranked eighth in last year's survey.
The WEF placed Singapore on top of its list again this year while Hong Kong and the United States retained their second- and third-place positions in the new rankings list released Wednesday.
Despite the economic turmoil affecting the Asian region, the WEF said recent data indicated that Singapore would continue to enjoy good conditions for growth over the next five to 10 years.
Singapore and Hong Kong performed well in all eight factors used to compile the rankings; they were openness, government, finance, infrastructure, technology, management, labor and institutions.

Other Asian manufacturing economies -- the ROC, Japan, mainland China, South Korea, Malaysia, Thailand, Indonesia and the Philippines -- scored well on government and labor markets. However, low scores in technology, management and institutions led to lower rankings.
The WEF study, which ranks 53 countries and areas, showed that some of the economies worst hit by the Asian financial crisis saw an erosion of competitive levels.

In this year's global rankings, Indonesia ranked 31st, down 16 places; Malaysia ranked 17th, down eight; and Thailand was 17th, down three. South Korea was ranked 19th, up two rungs while China was placed 28th, up one notch.

The United States owed its third-place position to high scores in finance, infrastructure, and especially technology and management, the WEF said. It emerged from the world's most competitive large countries with populations of more than 50 million. Britain was second and Japan was in 12th place.
The study noted that entrepot economies -- Hong Kong, Luxembourg, Singapore and Switzerland -- were easily the most competitive nations in the world.
"This group of small, highly open economies has the highest scores on all of the factors except technology and institutions, where the Anglo-Saxon countries rank first," the WEF said.
The top 10 economies in the WEF's 1998 global competitiveness rankings are as follows:
Rank Country (area) Competitiveness
1 1 Singapore 2.16
2 2 Hong Kong 1.91
3 3 United States 1.41
4 7 Britain 1.29
5 4 Canada 1.27
7 12 Netherlands 1.13
8 6 Switzerland 1.10
9 10 Norway 1.09
10 11 Luxembourg 1.05

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC LAWMAKERS TO VISIT US TO EXPRESS STANCE ON CLINTON-JIANG SUMMIT

TEXT.P: A 25-member parliamentary delegation will leave for the United States on June 14 to express the Republic of China's stance prior to US President Bill Clinton's departure for a state visit to mainland China.

"The nonpartisan delegation will meet with American officials to express our country's opposition to the so-called 'new three no's' policy," Jao Ying-chi, a Kuomintang legislator who will head the group, told the press on Thursday.

Jao said Beijing has been pushing the Clinton administration to spell out in more detail its commitment to the "one China" principle, which is against the creation of two Chinas or one Taiwan, one China, and is against the independence of Taiwan and its joining the United Nations or any other organizations involving sovereign states.

"We hope the United States will not just respond to Beijing's new three no's demand. It should also listen to our position," Jao said, adding that his mission will urge the Clinton administration to push Beijing to promise not to use force against Taiwan, not to suppress Taiwan's presence in the international community and not to coerce Taiwan into accepting its "one China" definition.

During his visit to the mainland from June 25 to July 3, Clinton will hold a summit meeting with his mainland counterpart, Jiang Zemin. Jiang said in an interview with AFP Chairman Jean Miot on Wednesday that the Taiwan issue will certainly be high on the agenda.
Jao said the delegation will remind Clinton not to sacrifice Taiwan's rights and interests in his talks with Jiang.
"We'll express our rejection at becoming a sacrifice of the Clinton-Jiang summit," he stressed.

The delegation, composed of legislators and National Assembly deputies from different political parties, will meet with senior Clinton administration officials and congressional members as well as give interviews to major American media during its 10-day US visit. The mission is scheduled to return to Taipei on June 24.
