DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN'S FIRST COMMERCIAL SATELLITE TO BE LAUNCHED THIS YEAR
DOC.DATELINE: Singapore, June 4 (CNA) (By Conrad Lu & Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: A communications satellite, as part of a joint project agreement between Taiwan's Chunghwa Telecom Corp. and Singapore's Singapore Telecommunications Corp., is expected to be launched some time in the second half of this year.
The announcement was made during the Asia Communication '98 show in Singapore by the head of Arianespace Group, the company contracted to send the satellite into geostationary orbit.
Jean-Marie Luton said the optimum place for the launch will be Ecuador in South America, but the exact time has yet to be determined due to a glitch in the details.
Meanwhile, Arianespace Group's chief consultant Claude Sanchez said the commercial satellite, called ST-1, will be launched into space in mid-August at the earliest.
Preparations for the launch can be finished within two months of ST-1's completion, Luton added.
The French Matra M-Space company, one of the world's four largest satellite manufacturers, has been commissioned to build Taiwan's first communications satellite.

Under the terms of the agreement between Chunghwa Telecom and Singapore Telecommunications, the two sides will each erect a control station and each will own seven C-band and eight Ku-band transponders.

Chunghwa Telecom will take advantage of the 15 transponders to provide technically advanced television, telephone and digital telecommunications services to a huge market encompassing Taiwan and its outlying islands, Japan, South Korea, as well as the entire Asia-Pacific region and most of mainland China.

DOC.HEADLINE: NTU RATED ASIA'S SEVENTH-BEST UNIVERSITY

TEXT.P: Asiaweek magazine recently ranked National Taiwan University as Asia's seventh-best university, up one place from a similar poll conducted last year.
The survey, completed in May, included 95 leading multi-disciplinary universities and 41 science and technology institutes in Asia.

Results indicated that most of Asia's top universities are located in affluent countries, such as Japan. Meanwhile, four of the top 10 schools come from so-called Chinese communities -- Taiwan, Singapore and Hong Kong.

All mainland Chinese universities were forced to withdraw from this year's survey by mainland authorities. Authorities were protesting the inclusion of schools from Taiwan with the word "national" in their names in the survey. Last year, Beijing University was ranked seventh.
Meanwhile, Japan's Tohoku University and South Korea's Seoul National University, both of which refused to participate in last year's survey, were ranked second and sixth, respectively, this year.
The survey's ratings were based on the schools' scores in the following areas: academic reputation, student selectivity, financial resources, faculty, and research achievements.

Asia's top 10 multi-disciplinary universities were, in descending order: the University of Tokyo, Tohoku University (Japan), Kyoto University, the University of Hong Kong, National University of Singapore, Seoul National University, National Taiwan University, Chinese University of Hong Kong, the University of Melbourne and the University of New South Wales.

The region's top five science and technology schools were, in descending order: Pohang University of Science & Tech., Indian Institute of Technology, Delhi, Indian Institute of Technology, Madras, Nanyang Technological University (Singapore), and Science University of Tokyo, according to Asiaweek.

DOC.HEADLINE: POLICEMAN WHO ATTEMPTED MURDER-SUICIDE BELONGS TO HIGH-RISK GROUP

TEXT.P: The policeman that shot his girlfriend and then turned his gun on himself last Thursday falls into the group of police officers with the highest risk of committing suicide, the National Police Administration said on Thursday.

Wu Fu-nien, 28, the officer who committed the shootings was a low-ranking officer who was both young and unmarried. On average, police officers between the ages of 20 and 29 are the most likely to kill themselves, while officers in that group who are low ranking, young and unmarried are most at risk.
Thursday Wu went to Hsin Kong Hospital at around 7 a.m. to seek out his girlfriend, Shen Hui-jung, 29, a medical examiner at the hospital.

Wu shot Shen once in the head and once in the breast. He then shot himself in the head. Both of them remain in critical condition. Wu used his pistol in the shootings, and the NPA is still trying to determine how Wu managed to take his gun with him after going off duty Wednesday.

The NAP, in analyzing more than 70 police suicides over the past decade, said broken relationships accounted for about 30 percent of the deaths, while problems with families, jobs and health were also causes.

NPA statistics indicate the number of suicides per year among policemen peaked at 15 in 1991. Though the number has since declined, the NPA is alarmed that the suicide rate among policemen is still higher than that of the general public.
NPA officials said that the ratio of policemen committing suicide was 1.09 per 10,000 officers in 1996, while the rate among the general public was 0.86 per 10,000 people.

DOC.HEADLINE: NT DOLLAR DOWN

TEXT.P: The New Taiwan dollar slid NT$0.052 against the greenback on the local foreign exchange market Thursday, closing at 34.238.
The Taiwan currency opened at the day's high of 34.17 and had a low of 34.279 during the trading.
The interbank US dollar trading reached US$330 million.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIEX SHARES SUFFER PLUNGE

TEXT.P: Share prices opened low and closed even lower on the Taipei Stock Exchange (TAIEX) on Thursday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, dropping sharply by 217.24 points to close at 7,425.96.
The bourse opened at the day's high of 7,563.63 and fell to 7,398.49 before recovering slightly.
Dealers said the entire market was affected by a decline in electronics stocks, causing the index to drop below 7,500, its lowest level since Jan. 14.
Losers outnumbered gainers 400 to 54, with 25 issues remaining unchanged.

A total of 1.90 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$93.75 billion, an increase from the previous session, which saw 1.73 billion stocks change hands on a market turnover of NT$92.79 billion.

All of the eight major categories lost ground, with electrical stocks falling the most at 5.4 percent, followed by construction shares at 2.2 percent, plastics and chemical stocks at 1.9 percent, pulp and paper issues at 1.8 percent, cement shares at 1.6 percent, foodstuff issues and bank and insurance stocks both at 1.5 percent and textile issues at 1.2 percent.

The 10 listed companies with the largest turnovers in Thursday's trading were United Micro Electronics, China Steel, China Synthetic Rubber, ACER, Ever Fortune Industries, ASE, Picvue Electronics, Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing, Macronix International and Winbond Electronics Corp.

DOC.HEADLINE: NYC MAYOR ANNOUNCES SUPPORT FOR CHINESE DEMOCRACY
DOC.DATELINE: New York, June 3 (CNA) (By Huang Kuang-chun and Fang Wen-hung)

TEXT.P: On the eve of the ninth anniversary of the Tiananmen Square massacre, New York City Mayor Rudolph Giuliani proclaimed June 4, 1998 as "New York City Supports Chinese Democracy Day" in memory of those who died for democracy and freedom.
In his proclamation, Giuliani remembered Chinese supporters of democracy who lost their lives or faced long-term imprisonment in the wake of Beijing's military crack down on June 4, 1989.

Fifty years after the United Nations announced its Universal Declaration of Human Rights, New York City seeks to affirm the efforts of those who have made sacrifices for democracy and freedom around the world, particularly the pro-democracy activists in mainland China, Giuliani said.

The groups and individuals in mainland China and their pursuit of political, religious and labor reforms have awakened the American people, allowing them to understand that millions of people in the world are still living under oppressive policies, Giuliani added.

A long-time supporter of the pro-democracy movement in mainland China, Giuliani openly expressed his disgust for Beijing's autocracy and oppression of human rights by snubbing mainland Chinese President Jiang Zemin during his visit to the United States last October.

Giuliani refused to receive Jiang when he visited New York because of Beijing's dismal human rights record. However, he received renowned mainland Chinese dissident Wei Jingsheng shortly afterward and gave Wei a "Key to the City" to express his welcome.
When Beijing released pro-democracy dissident Wang Dan on medical parole in April, Giuliani met with him and welcomed him to settle in New York.

On the day of the ninth anniversary of the Tiananmen massacre, mainland China democracy movement organizations and ethnic Chinese living in New York will stage a protest in front of the mainland Chinese embassy in New York. Giuliani's proclamation will be recited as a part of the activities.

After weeks of protests in Beijing's Tiananmen Square, thousands of students and workers who were calling for political reforms were killed or injured on June 4, 1989 in a bloody military crack down. Hundreds of others were also arrested.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAC URGES BEIJING TO CARRY OUT POLITICAL REFORM

TEXT.P: Chang King-yuh, chairman of the ROC's Cabinet-level Mainland Affairs Council, said on Thursday that mainland China's most urgent need at present is political reform.
This will lay the groundwork for the implementation of its goal of "fundamental modernization," he said.
Chang made the remarks while speaking at the invitation of the Taipei Rotary Club at a dinner party.

With the conclusion of mainland China's First Session of the Ninth National People's Congress in March, Beijing has completed the reshuffling of its leadership and decided on its policy direction for the next five years, Chang said. Beijing is now ready to enter into a new era of construction and development.

While discussing cross-strait relations, Chang said Taipei has promoted good relations by gradually lifting restrictions on private-sector exchanges and creating bodies such as the National Unification Council, the MAC and the Straits Exchange Foundation.

Competition between Taipei and Beijing, stressed Chang, should not be based on diplomatic or military rivalry, nor should it be rooted as a national or cultural competition. Instead it should been viewed as a race between different systems, and all Chinese people should have the right to choose their own way of living, he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: RUSSIAN STATE DUMA SPEAKER BLOCKS REVIEW OF TAIWAN RELATIONS BILL

TEXT.P: In a surprise move, the speaker of the Russian State Duma, Gennady Seleznev, arbitrarily decided on Tuesday to remove a Taiwan Relations Bill from the agenda for the parliament's Wednesday plenary session.

Seleznev, a Communist Party member, personally chaired an impromptu meeting of the Rules Committee Tuesday afternoon during which time he said the State Duma need not review the Taiwan Relations Bill because it doesn't comply with Russia's "one China" policy.

Under the "one China" policy, Seleznev said, Russia recognizes the People's Republic of China as the only legitimate government of China and that Taiwan is part of China. Against this background, he said, the State Duma has no reason to screen a Taiwan Relations Bill.

Seleznev's remarks drew strong protests from Alex Mitrofanov, chairman of the Committee of Geopoliticis, who stressed that the bill is simply designed to regulate trade and economic relations between Taiwan and Russia, and has nothing to do with any third country.

Moreover, Mitrofanov said the bill was formally listed on the agenda for the June 3 plenary session when the Rules Committee held its last procedural meeting on May 22. "At an impromptu meeting, only the order of agenda topics can be changed and decisions to drop bills from the agenda cannot be made," he asserted.
As the Communist Party now dominates the State Duma, protests from Mitrofanov and other pro-Taiwan parliamentarians turned out to be futile.
Vladimir Zhirinovsky, chairman of the Liberal Democratic Party, said he will continue seeking to have the bill discussed at the legislative floor in the future.
The unexpected development has drawn much media attention. Many major Russian newspapers gave prominent reports on the Seleznev's arbitrary decision to "kill" the bill.

The bill, patterned after the United States' Taiwan Relations Act, was initiated last year by Mitrofanov and other pro-Taiwan parliamentarians in consideration of Taiwan's increasing economic clout in the Asia-Pacific region.
Since April 1997, Mitrofanov and his colleagues had pushed for its reading in the State Duma, hoping the enactment of the bill will lay a legal framework to facilitate Taiwan-Russian exchanges.

The initiative, however, had met strong opposition from the Russian executive branch, particularly the Ministry of Foreign Affairs, on the grounds that an administrative decree issued by President Boris Yeltsin in 1992 is sufficient to take care of Russian-Taiwan ties.

Acknowledging that the chances for the bill to smoothly pass the State Duma in three readings in the near future are slim, pro-Taiwan Russian parliamentarians said they originally hoped that discussions on the bill in the parliamentary floor would help increase Russian public's awareness of Taiwan.
They said Beijing has exerted strong pressure on the Russian foreign ministry to prevent the State Duma from discussing the bill. (by Sofia Wu)

DOC.HEADLINE: HEAVY RAINS IN KAUHSIUNG COUNTY DAMAGE CROPS

TEXT.P: The Kaohsiung County Government's Bureau of Agriculture said on Thursday that flooding resulting from heavy rains over the past few days has damaged more than NT$46 million worth of food crops in the county.

According to a survey by the bureau, a total of 68 hectares of rice paddies in Meinung, Chishan, Sanlin and Chihkuan villages were flooded, while 28 percent of all rice stocks grown on paddies in those villages have collapsed.

In addition, vegetable and melon production in Chihkuan, Kangshan, Fengshan, Mito, Taliao, Chiaotou and Linyuan villages were also affected, with crop damage levels ranging from 20 percent to 53 percent.

DOC.HEADLINE: CISCO AND TAIWAN FORGE TECHNOLOGY ALLIANCE

TEXT.P: Cisco Systems Inc., a leading provider of computer networking equipment, on Thursday signed an agreement with Taiwan's Institute for Information Industry to provide the island ADSL technology.

Six Taiwan companies -- Askey Computer, DB Networks, GVC Corp., Sun Moon Star, Tecom and Zyxel Communication Corp. -- expressed interest in joining the ADSL development project, which is aimed at accelerating the adoption of ADSL technology and production of ADSL equipment by the island's manufacturers of communications equipment.

ADSL, which stands for Asymmetric Digital Subscriber Line, is a communications technology that transmit data at up to six megabits per second -- a speed more than 125 times faster than that of a 56Kbps modem. And unlike other high-speed data communications technologies, ADSL operates over existing copper telephone wires.
The agreement was signed by III President Kuo Yun and Cisco Vice Chairman for Global Operations Gray Daichendt in Taipei in the presence of Vice Economics Minister Chang Chang-pang.

The global output of Internet-related products, said Kuo, currently totals US$40 billion a year, but Taiwan's output amounts to only US$1.6 billion a year. Cooperating with industry leaders is one way for Taiwan companies to push further into this market, he said.
There are currently more than 2 million Internet users in Taiwan, with 3 million expected by 2000.
Cisco's turnover for the first half of this year amounted to US$3.89 billion, up 28 percent from its year-earlier level, according to the company.

DOC.HEADLINE: FIRST BATCH OF LOCALLY NURTURED AIRCRAFT ENGINEERS GRADUATING

TEXT.P: Some 91 students at the National Huwei Institute of Technology in southern Taiwan graduated on Thursday, making them Taiwan's first batch of locally nurtured aircraft maintenance technicians.

The graduates are part of the government's efforts to develop much-needed aircraft maintenance talent to help improve flight safety in Taiwan and to turn the island into a regional aircraft maintenance center.

Jack Tang, deputy director of the Committee for Aviation and Space Industry Development (AIDC) under the Ministry of Economic Affairs, said at the commencement ceremony that nurturing aircraft engineering talent is crucial to improving flight safety.
He estimated that by 2004, the production value of Taiwan's aircraft maintenance industry will reach US$2.3 billion, and the industry will require a workforce of 20,000.

The AIDC and the Ministry of Education channeled nearly US$50 million to help National Huwei Institute establish an aircraft engineering department three years ago and has invited Pratt & Whitney Aircraft and the US-based Pittsburgh Institute of Aeronautics to provide lecturers and training courses.

National Huwei Institute will be Taiwan's first institute to cooperate with foreign aircraft maintenance schools and engine companies and will be the first school in Asia to be certified by the US Federal Aviation Administration.
National Huwei Institute President Yu Cheng-kuang said the institute plans to recruit more students to meet the ever-growing need for engineering technicians.
Taiwan airlines rely heavily on personnel trained in the air force for aircraft maintenance.

DOC.HEADLINE: COMMUNIST PARTIES OF JAPAN, CHINA TO IMPROVE TIES

TEXT.P: A three-member delegation of the Japan Communist Party (JCP) will leave for Beijing Sunday at the invitation of the Communist Party of China (CPC) for talks on the resumption of formal relations.

Hikaru Nishiguchi, chief of the International Affairs Division of JCP, and his Chinese counterpart Dai Bingguo, head of the International Liaison Department of the CPC Central Committee, will meet Monday for the talks.

The relations between the two communist parties began to deteriorate in 1966, when they had bitter ideological disputes. They were disrupted in 1967, when Red Guards roughed up JCP officials in the Beijing Airport at the height of the Cultural Revolution.
Representatives of the two communist parties held talks in 1985 for the resumption of relations, but in vain.

The relations began to warm up in December 1997 when Dai said in an article published in the People's Daily that it was possible for the two parties to resume formal relations. JCP's organ newspaper Akahata, or Red Flag, established a branch office in Beijing in February.
The communist parties of the two countries are expected to "normalize" their relations before mainland Chinese president Jiang Zemin visits Japan in September, analysts said.

DOC.HEADLINE: ONE MAN ARRESTED IN CONNECTION WITH FORGED IDS

TEXT.P: A police investigation into a criminal smuggling ring has resulted in the arrest of a suspect, the Criminal Investigation Bureau said on Thursday.

Police accuse Peng Yu-ming, 52, of giving local travel agents false IDs and household registries forged by Peng and then asking them to apply to the Ministry of Foreign Affairs for ROC passports. Peng then used the passports to obtain visas to the United States, Canada and Japan, police said.
Peng later delivered the passports to Hong Kong and Macau, where he sold them to a mainland smuggling ring for US$10,000 each, police claim.
CIB police said they were alerted by counterparts in the United States, Canada and Japan about mainlanders entering the countries with suspicious passports.

Peng traveled to Hong Kong and Macau on Monday with four ROC passports that he intended to deliver to the smuggling ring. He returned Wednesday with dozens of photos of mainland Chinese for use in additional passports.
At Peng's residence in Hsintien, Taipei County, police discovered scores of forged IDs, along with copy machines and tools used in the forgeries.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC FOREIGN MINISTER PRESIDES OVER ENVOYS MEETING IN EUROPE

TEXT.P: Foreign Minister Jason Hu presided over a meeting of Taiwan envoys to European countries this week, according to a statement issued by the ministry on Thursday.

The meeting brought together ROC envoys and representatives, as well as the Republic of China's diplomatic staff to some 27 European countries, according to the statement. The meeting took place on June 1 and 2, although the meeting's location was not disclosed for fear of provoking a reaction from Beijing.
Meeting participants resolved to beef up exchanges with their respective host countries in the fields of economy, culture, science and technology.
The group also voiced plans to promote contacts among various ROC offices in Europe to further advance Taiwan's presence in the region.
The statement did not disclose the whereabouts of Hu, who is outside Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT MAYORAL CANDIDATE REFUTES ANTI-DEMOCRACY ALLEGATIONS

TEXT.P: Kuomintang (KMT) Taipei mayoral candidate Ma Ying-jeou on Thursday rebuffed criticism by Taipei Deputy Mayor Lin Chia-cheng that he is not open-minded and has not contributed anything to Taiwan's democratization.

Ma announced his decision to run in the year-end mayoral election for Taiwan's largest city last week, giving a shot in the arm to the KMT, which has found it difficult to find a candidate strong enough to challenge the incumbent, Chen Shui-bian of the opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP).

Lin blasted Ma, a former minister of justice and currently an associate professor of law at National Chengchi University, for serving a conservative regime, advocating an outdated indirect presidential election system, and supporting the National Security Law, which Lin said limits the freedom of the people.
Ma, who is considered the KMT's best hope for winning the mayoral race, resigned as minister without portfolio last year, saying at the time that he would not join the race on the KMT ticket.

He said Lin's lack of understanding of past events has led him to a misguided conclusion, pointing out that before the National Assembly amended the Constitution in 1994 to allow direct presidential elections, the KMT had already weighed the possibilities for both the direct and indirect systems.

Turning to the National Security Law, Ma said that it was at his insistence that articles limiting the people's freedom of speech were dropped from the draft law which was later enacted by the legislature.

Ma also lauded Mayor Chen for playing an important role in past opposition movements and contributing to the democratization of Taiwan, but he said the KMT, not the opposition parties, have pushed forward with Taiwan's democratization, adding that he himself is responsible for many of the reform programs of the past decade.

DOC.HEADLINE: RECORD NUMBER OF VISA CARDS ISSUED IN APRIL

TEXT.P: VISA International Service Association issued a single-month high of 300,000 VISA cards in April in Taiwan, the international credit card organization announced on Thursday.

A total of 7.16 million VISA cards had been issued in Taiwan as of the end of April, making the card the most popular credit card in Taiwan, according to the organization, which added that aggregate spending by VISA cardholders in the first four months of the year broke the NT$100 billion (US$2.9 billion) mark for the first time.
A VISA executive in charge of the Taiwan area attributed the popularity of the card to the organization's high-quality services and its innovation in marketing new products.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAC HEAD URGES BEIJING TO AVOID RECURRENCE OF JUNE 4TH TRAGEDY

TEXT.P: Taiwan's top official in charge of mainland Chinese policies on Thursday urged authorities in Beijing to accelerate political and social reform in the mainland to avoid a recurrence of the "June 4th" tragedy.

In a short statement marking the ninth anniversary of the 1989 Tiananmen Square crackdown on pro-democracy activities, Chang King-yuh, chairman of the Cabinet-level Mainland Affairs Council, said that in addition to continued efforts to promote economic development, Beijing should also come up with effective plans for political and social reform.

Chang said that although it has been nine years since the crackdown, he does not see significant changes in mainland China's political environment, particularly in the areas of human rights, personal protection and justice.

Only after Beijing makes large-scale changes to its political structure and builds new economic, social, military and administrative orders, can mainland China lay the foundation for its goal of modernization, Chang stressed.
Hundred if not thousands were killed and thousands more arrested during the crackdown.

DOC.HEADLINE: AUSTRALIA'S ECONOMY SEEN AS SLOWING AFTER GROWTH OF 4.9 PERCENT

TEXT.P: Australia's economy is expected to decline sharply in the second quarter of this year as the full force of the Asian economic meltdown hits the country, economists predict.
This comes after surprisingly strong growth of 4.9 percent between April 1997 and March 1998.
The Australian Bureau of Statistics released economic figures showing the country's gross domestic product rose a solid 1.3 percent in the first quarter of 1998.
"Australia is probably the fastest growing country in the industrialized world and certainly the strong economy of the Asian region," said Federal Treasurer Peter Costello.

Private economists, however are skeptical about the ABS figures. They said Australia's robust growth was largely the result of an unintended build-up of unsold goods by manufacturers and retailers with private consumption flattening and exports falling.

They said manufacturers will be forced to reduce their production significantly over the second quarter of this year to clear their shelves as consumer spending is expected to remain weak -- reflecting the impact of the Asian crisis on consumer confidence, which will slow the country's economy.
The economists said the latest figures could represent the economy's peak growth period. Growth will certainly slow in the coming months, they said, as the full force of the Asian crisis hits.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAINLAND CHINA INTRUDED INTO INDIA TWICE IN 1997

TEXT.P: Mainland China troops intruded into Indian territory in Arunchal Pradesh twice in 1997, a New-Delhi-based English-language newspaper reported on Thursday.
The Hindustan Times said that Indian Defense Minister George Fernandes told the Rajya Sabha on Wednesday that the intrusion was later discussed at a Border Personnel Meeting and Export Group Meeting.
However, the minister said that so far in 1998 there have been no border violations by the Chinese communist army.
Referring to the India-Pakistan border in Jammu and Kashmir, Fernandes said that 859 shooting incidents were reported from November 1997 to April 1998.

DOC.HEADLINE: CLINTON URGED TO DEMAND BEIJING NOT TO DO '3 THINGS' AGAINST ROC

TEXT.P: A senior diplomatic official on Thursday urged US President Bill Clinton to take advantage of his upcoming state visit to mainland China to demand Beijing not to do "three things" against Taiwan.

"We look forward to seeing Clinton ask Beijing not to use force against Taiwan, not to suppress Taiwan's presence in the international community and not to force Taiwan into accepting its 'one China' definition," said Lyu-shun Shen, director of the MOFA's North American Affairs Department.

Shen made the appeal while meeting with a group of legislators who will leave for the United States on June 14 to express the Republic of China's basic stance on relations across the Taiwan Strait prior to Clinton's departure for his two-week mainland visit later this month.
Shen said the ROC hopes the Clinton administration will not just respond to the Beijing-proposed "three no's" overture. "The United States should take into account our new three no's."
He went on to urge Clinton not to issue any unilateral or joint statement concerning Beijing's "three no's" overture. "Such moves are very unfriendly," Shen noted.

Beijing's "three no's" overture is against the creation of two Chinas or one China, one Taiwan, and is also against the independence of Taiwan and its joining the United Nations or any other organizations involving sovereign states.

Shen said the ROC also hopes Clinton will not issue any public statement hinting that the "one country, two systems" formula Beijing has used to take over Hong Kong may be applicable to Taiwan. Clinton will make a stop in Hong Kong during his two-week mainland visit from June 25 through July 3.

Shen further urged the United States to faithfully implement the Taiwan Relations Act of 1979, its "six guarantees" to Taiwan issued in 1982 and its 1994 review of policy toward Taiwan. All these documents require the US to imporve substantive ties with Taiwan and provide the island with defensive weapons to ensure security and stability in the Taiwan Strait.
Meanwhile, Mainland Affairs Council Chairman Chang King-yuh said Clinton should not discuss Taipei-Washington relations with his mainland Chinese counterpart, Jiang Zemin, during his Beijing visit.

While Beijing has consistently intended to discuss what it calls the "Taiwan issue" with Washington, Chang said there is no such issue. "What exists is how the two sides of the Taiwan Strait will treat each other," Chang stressed.

DOC.HEADLINE: NEW LESOTHO CABINET SWORN IN

TEXT.P: Lesotho's new cabinet was sworn in by Chief Justice Joseph Kheola in the presence of King Letsie III at the royal palace in Maseru on Thursday morning.
In the new cabinet, Prime Minister Pakalitha Mosisili also holds two other portfolios, namely minister of defense and minister of public service.
Former Prime Minister Ntsu Mokhehle's special advisor, Tom Thabane, was named foreign minister.
Among the 14 members of the new cabinet, Minister of the Environment, Women and Youth Affairs Mamshebi Kabi is the only female member.
Mosisili said a deputy prime minister has not yet been appointed.
Lesotho held a general election on May 23, in which the Lesotho Congress of Democracy won 78 out of 80 seats contested.

DOC.HEADLINE: SECURITIES TRANSACTION TAX REVENUE IN MAY DROPS TO NT$6.8 BILLION

TEXT.P: The revenue from securities transaction taxes in May is expected to drop to NT$6.8 billion (US$198.83 million) from April's NT$9.3 billion (US$271.93 million) due to dwindling turnover in the stock market, the Ministry of Finance (MOF) said on Thursday.

Hsu Kuo-chung, director of the Department of Accounting under the MOF, said however that the accumulated securities transaction tax revenue for fiscal 1998, which ends in June, will reach a record high, as the revenue collected since the beginning of last July has reached NT$111 billion (US$3.25 billion).

Hsu said that the turnover in the stock exchange and over-the-counter market in May amounted to NT$2.266 trillion (US$66.26 billion) and is expected to bring tax revenue of some NT$6.8 billion (US$198.83 million). Over the 22 transaction days in May, daily turnover averaged NT$103.03 billion (US$3.01 billion), he added.

He indicated that if daily turnover in June can be maintained at NT$95 billion (US$2.78 billion) on average, the total securities transaction tax revenue for fiscal 1998 will surpass NT$117 billion (US$3.42 billion), giving a record high.

The annual securities transaction revenue target of NT$57.2 billion (US$1.67 billion) for fiscal 1998 was reached as long ago as Dec. 9 last year, when the daily market turnover for that day surged to NT$219.25 billion (US$6.41 billion).
The share prices on Taiwan stock exchange dropped 217.24 points on Thursday to close at 7425.96 on a market turnover of NT$92.97 billion (US$2.71 billion).

DOC.HEADLINE: MOFA APPRECIATES BACKING OF RUSSIAN LAWMAKERS

TEXT.P: Roy Wu, spokesman for the Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA), on Thursday expressed his ministry's appreciation for the support from 77 Russian lawmakers for Taiwan, although a bill they raised on bilateral cooperation was vetoed on Wednesday in the 450-seat State Duma, the lower house of the Russian parliament.
Expressing gratitude to the 77 lawmakers who voted in favor of the proposal, Wu said the Republic of China government will continue boosting two-way relations based on existing ties.

Foreign wire services reported on Wednesday that the Russian parliament had rejected the bill, with parliament speaker Gennady Seleznyov explaining that "the State Duma is unaware of the existence of such a country."
After verification by the ROC representative office in Moscow, Wu said that what Seleznyov meant is that "there is no country called `Taiwan' in the charter of the United Nations."
Wu lamented the failure of the bill's passage, saying that it would have helped further increase a wide range of exchanges between the two countries.
Bilateral exchanges between Taiwan and Russia entered a new era when the ROC established a representative office in Moscow in 1993. Russia also opened a representative office in Taiwan in 1996.

According to the MOFA spokesman, two-way trade totaled US$1.5 billion in 1997, and the figure for 1998, which has already reached US$430 million for the first four months of the year, is expected to hit US$1.8 billion.

Taiwan travelers made a total of more than 8,000 visits to Russia last year, and local colleges, including National Chengchi University and Tamkang University, have signed a number of cooperative ventures with their Russian counterparts in recent years to strengthen technology exchanges.

In January, a 48-member Russian delegation, led by a former prime minister, participated in the second technology meeting of the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation forum in Taipei, and more recently, a Russian delegation composed of five constitutional court judges took part in the World Capitals Forum sponsored by the Taipei City Government late last month.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN CULTURAL CENTER TO BE SET UP IN VLADIVOSTOK

TEXT.P: An agreement was reached on Thursday between Fo Kuang University and Vladivostok's Far East University for the establishment of a Taiwan cultural, economic and trade center in the Russian university.
The agreement was signed by Kurilov, president of Far East University, and Kung Peng-cheng, president of Fo Kuang University, at the Nanhua Management College, part of the Chiayi County university.
Under the terms of the agreement, Fo Kuang University will invest US$4 million, and the Far East University will provide a plot of land on the university campus for the construction of the center.
Kung said after the signing ceremony that the cooperative project will be conducive to enhancing academic exchanges, as well as economic and trade relations, between the two countries.

His Russian counterpart pointed out that his university is an important research institute for East Asian studies in Russia. Kurilov said he expects great progress in the promotion of exchanges between the both sides after the set-up of the cultural, economic and trade center, which has been heavily promoted by Wu Jen-fu, chairman of the Asia Pacific Cultural and Academic Exchange Foundation.
The two universities, which forged sisterhood ties on January 7 this year, have drafted various academic plans, including exchanges of students and professors.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT TO NOMINATE 114 CANDIDATES TO RUN IN LEGISLATIVE ELECTION

TEXT.P: The ruling Kuomintang (KMT) has decided to nominate no more than 114 candidates to run in the year-end legislative election, and predicts that the party will capture at least 93 out of the 164 Legislative Yuan seats to be contested.
The party is expected to complete the final part of its list of nominees next week, after which it will be submitted for approval by the party's central standing committee on June 10.

The ruling party had previously planned to field a total of 112 candidates, until it saw its morale boosted by the fact that Ma Ying-jeou and Wu Deng-yih are set to represent the party in the Taipei and Kaohsiung mayoral elections, prompting it to add to its nominees.

The spotlight of the KMT nomination is currently on whether former Provincial Government Spokesman Hwang Yi-chiao will be nominated to run in Taichung City, in central Taiwan. A high-ranking KMT official has excluded this possibility on the grounds that Hwang did not register as a candidate and that the nomination list is already full. He also denied that Taiwan Provincial Governor James Soong will be given a say in deciding whether Hwang should be nominated.

In the last legislative election in 1995, the KMT captured 85 of the 164 seats, its worst performance ever, and that the party's overall share of the vote dwindled to 46.1 percent. The main opposition Democratic Progressive Party won 54 seats, with 33.2 percent of the vote, while the New Party, with 13 percent of the vote, captured 21 seats.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC VOWS TO BUILD SAFEST HIGH-SPEED RAILWAY

TEXT.P: The high-speed train crash in Germany is not expected to affect Taiwan's cooperation with Germany in building a high-speed rail system on the island, a senior official with the Ministry of Transportation and Communications (MOTC) said on Thursday.
MOTC Vice Minister Chang Chia-chu said the cause of Wednesday's high-speed train crash in the northern German city of Eschede, some 50 kilometers north of Hanover, is still being investigated.

"If thorough investigations show that the crash has anything to do with mechanical failures or troubles, we'll demand the main German contractor to make necessary improvement and provide us with the safest machine and equipment," Chang said, adding that safety is the government's top concern.

Taiwan High-Speed Railway Consortium, which has won the priority right to negotiate with the MOTC for building the island's first high-speed rail system under a BOT (build-operate-transfer) formula, has tentatively decided to introduce Germany's ICE locomotives and France's TGV double-deck railway cars to Taiwan's high-speed rail system.

A spokesman for the multinational consortium said it has yet to sign formal purchase contracts for either locomotives or railway cars. "In case the German high-speed train crash is really caused by mechanical problems, we still have room to make adjustments," he added.

Basically, the spokesman said, Taiwan's high-speed rail system will be much safer than Germany's. "We'll build a brand new railway exclusively for use of high-speed trains, while some sections of the German high-speed system use conventional railway," he explained.
The consortium, composed of several major Taiwan business groups, Siemens AG of Germany and GEC Alsthom SA of France, has yet to sign a formal agreement with the MOTC.
The 345 km high-speed ralway, which will stretch from Taipei in the north to Kaohsiung in the south, is scheduled to become operational by 2003.
At least 100 people were killed in Germany's high-speed train crash, the worst tragedy in that country's railway history since World War II.

DOC.HEADLINE: SINGAPORE UNVEILS HUMAN RESOURCE TRAINING PROGRAM FOR APEC

TEXT.P: Singapore on Thursday unveiled an integrated Human Resource Development (HRD) training program in broadband technologies and multimedia applications for Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation (APEC) economies.

The program aims to address the skills development gap within APEC in the broadband multimedia area. It was presented during the plenary session of the Third APEC Ministerial Meeting on the Telecommunications and Information Industry (TELMIN3) being held in Singapore.
The training program provides generic training in areas such as broadband technology, infrastructure planning, applications development and end-user online training, and regulatory policy planning.

In the longer term, Singapore hopes its program can complement schemes offered by other APEC economies and that these initiatives will become integrated with one another so as to eventually create a virtual network of broadband multimedia training opportunities for APEC economies.

The goal is that eventually APEC member economies will be able to conduct and receive virtual training and education for multimedia broadband networking and applications. These skills will equip them to live, do business and interact with one another in the "Asia-Pacific Information Society."

DOC.HEADLINE: ECONOMIC PUBLICATION FORECASTS TAIWAN'S ECONOMY WILL GROW BY 6%

TEXT.P: Taiwan is expected to meet its goal of 6 percent economic growth this year, and to stay at that level in 1999, according to the Hong Kong-based Far Eastern Economic Review.
In its latest issue, the weekly forecast 2 percent negative growth for Hong Kong and 15 percent negative growth for Indonesia during the same period.
The magazine also said mainland China's economy will grow by 9 percent, while Malaysia and the Philippines will each see 2.5 percent growth.

As for 1999, the publication predicts a growth rate of 8.6 percent for mainland China, 4 percent for the Philippines, 3 percent for Malaysia, 2.4 percent for Hong Kong, and minus 0.6 percent for Indonesia.

DOC.HEADLINE: THAI OFFICIAL TO COURT INVESTMENT FROM TAIWAN

TEXT.P: In an effort to lure investment from Taiwan in the wake of the Asian financial crisis, a Thai official will visit Taiwan soon to introduce his country's investment environment to the local business community.
Stapom Kavitanon, secretary-general of Thailand's Bureau of Investment, is scheduled to preside personally over a presentation on June 18 in Taipei of his country's business environment.

Although still beset by financial woes, Thailand is steadfastly on the road to recovery following a restructuring of its financial system at the demand of the International Monetary Fund, and cuts in the government's budget, the MOEA officials said.

Thailand's political stability and the absence of anti-Chinese sentiment there are also favorable factors to potential Taiwan investors, especially those who were forced to flee Indonesia when the social unrest and financial crisis ruined that country's economy, said the officials.

DOC.HEADLINE: TASK FORCE PLANNED TO IMPROVE TREATMENT OF STRAY DOGS

TEXT.P: A central government-level task force will be set up to help local governments improve their treatment of stray dogs, the Cabinet-level Council for Agriculture (COA) announced on Thursday.

In conjunction with the Environmental Protection Administration (EPA), the COA said it will raise funds to subsidize local governments in order to allow them to improve their measures for handling the stray dog problem.

The COA said that it has drafted an "animal protection bill," pending the approval of the Legislative Yuan, and that it will also take effective measures to carry out a sterilization program for stray dogs before the bill passes the legislative floor, in an efforts to reduce the number of stray dogs on Taiwan's streets.

The COA said about 310,000 stray dogs were spayed or neutered last year, adding that it has also helped the National Pingtung University of Science and Technology in southern Taiwan to establish a "halfway house and training center" for stray dogs, in a bid to set an example of how to protect and regulate homeless animals.

The COA's remarks came after international animal protection groups staged protests at ROC overseas outposts in six cities around the world on Wednesday. They demanded that the ROC government provide humane treatment for street animals or face a boycott campaign against Taiwan products and travel to Taiwan.

Meanwhile, local animal conservation groups have accused the government of inadequate measures for the handling of street dogs, blaming both the government's legislative and administrative branches for the delayed passage of the animal protection law, and criticizing the barbaric methods currently employed to destroy homeless dogs.

DOC.HEADLINE: GOVERNMENT TO LAY OFF 20,000 EMPLOYEES BY 2000

TEXT.P: About 20,000 civil servants will be laid off by 2000 under a government reengineering program, according to a senior government official on Thursday.

Most of the redundancies will be in the state-run enterprises which are slated for privatization under the government program, said Wei Chi-lin, director-general of the Central Personnel Administration (CPA) under the Executive Yuan.

Premier Vincent Siew has urged the CPA, as well as the Council for Economic Planning and Development, and the Research, Development and Evaluation Commission, to draw up plans to allow the government to shed personnel which are no longer needed, said Wei.

DOC.HEADLINE: 1998 A HARD YEAR FOR LOCAL EXPORTERS: MOEA

TEXT.P: This will be the hardest year in a decade for Taiwan's export sector, as many Asian countries are still seriously entrenched in financial troubles and the pace of growth of the US economy has began to slow down, the Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) said on Thursday.

Based on estimates made by the Washington Economic Forecast Association (WEFA), the MOEA said local exporters will face their hardest year in ten years due to the economic situations in Asian countries and the US, adding that outbound shipments for the whole year are expected to chart only moderate growth.

The WEFA forecast that the world economy will grow by 2.6 percent and 2.9 percent for 1998 and 1999, respectively, as a result of the Asian financial plague which broke out in the middle of last year.

Global economies, except those of European countries, have not shown signs of improvement in the first half of this year, and the root problem is that the impact of the financial crisis is not yet over, the WEFA was cited as saying.

As demand from the US market has also slowed this year, the MOEA warned that Taiwan exports will be affected markedly, noting that overseas orders from the US has charted negative growth in recent months.
The US has always been one of the major outlets for Taiwan exports.

DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER ASKS FINANCE MINISTRY TO STABILIZE TAIEX

TEXT.P: Premier Vincent Siew on Thursday instructed the Ministry of Finance (MOF) to take immediate measures necessary to maintain the normal operation of the Taipei Stock Exchange (TAIEX).
Siew issued the directive after hearing a briefing by Finance Minister Paul C.H. Chiu on the current stock market situation.
Share prices opened low and closed even lower on the TAIEX on Thursday, with the index dropping sharply by 217.24 points to close at 7,425.96, its lowest level since January 14 of this year.

Chiu said in his report that the MOF has asked the Security and Exchange Commission to speed up its checking of funds, adding that an estimated NT$100 billion will be put into the stock market this month, with about NT$35.8 billion entering the market this week alone.
After hearing Chiu's report, the premier made the following observations:

-- The Council for Economic Planning and Development (CEPD) has predicted that the economic situation, which has remained good during the first and second quarters, will improve in the third quarter. The CEPD has also estimated that economic growth will reach its predicted target;

-- In order to increase domestic demand and maintain economic growth, a meeting of related government agencies on Thursday decided to promote reconstruction of housing units for military dependents, with first-stage construction involving about NT$60 billion, which is expected to help related industries; and

-- The stock market has a big influence on economic development, and public interests, and although the TAIEX drop on Thursday was affected by an overall decline in the international stock market, the MOF should make further study of the domestic stock market situation and immediately take the necessary measures to maintain normal operation of the stock market.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN'S ECONOMIC GROWTH OUTPACES OTHER ASIAN COUNTRIES

TEXT.P: Vice President Lien Chan on Thursday said that despite the Asian financial crisis, Taiwan's economic growth for last year reached as high as 6.81 percent, signaling the sound economic fundamentals enjoyed by the country.

Lien told a group of business leaders at a dinner party hosted by the Council for Industrial and Commercial Development that Taiwan's economic growth for last year was its highest since 1992, adding that with economic growth of nearly 6 percent for the first quarter of this year, the overall growth for this year is expected to reach 6.02 percent, the world's sixth-highest.

Lien went on to say that South Korea's economic growth posted 3.8 percent negative growth for the first quarter of the year, the poorest quarterly record in 18 years. Hong Kong and Malaysia have reported minus 2 percent and minus 1.8 percent growth, respectively, for the first three months of the year, their first quarterly stumbles in 13 years. As for Indonesia and Thailand, they are likely to suffer double-digit negative economic growth for 1998.

The vice president also said that according to a survey conducted by the Far Eastern Economic Review, nearly 30 percent of business leaders interviewed in 10 Asian countries cited Taiwan as the most powerful economy in Asia.

However, he pointed out that Taiwan has already encountered difficulties in economic expansion as the effect of the Asian financial turmoil has been felt in its reduced exports to Asian countries, and he called on the island's corporate leaders to diversify their export outlets and upgrade their competitiveness.
Lien also said that as a member of the global village, Taiwan has to make sure its industrial development meets world wide environmental protection standards.

He cited the Kyoto global climate agreement, which is aimed at helping save the earth from catastrophic global warming, as a good example of this, pointing out that the Taiwan government has worked out plans to cut greenhouse gas emissions and exhorting the industrial sector to comply with government policy.

DOC.HEADLINE: THREE CHILDREN MISSING PER DAY IN TAIWAN

TEXT.P: Some 1,325 children under the age of 12, or more than three per day, were reported missing in Taiwan last year, National Police Administration (NPA) officials said on Saturday.
The officials said that the number represents a 50-fold increase on the corresponding figure of a decade ago.
They said that among the 31,000-plus missing person cases reported last year, 557 concerned pre-school children under the age of seven, and 768 were between seven and 12 years old.
The total number of 1,325 of missing children under 12 compares with only 26 reported cases in 1988.

An analysis by the Child Welfare Legal Foundation, a non-profit group, said that in addition to getting lost or running away from home, 16 percent of these children were abducted by non-family members, while 24 percent went missing for undetermined reasons.
Some of the children may have been sold, and will probably never be reunited with their biological parents, according to the group.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN'S HIGH-SPEED TRAIN WILL DIFFER FROM GERMAN CRASH MODEL
DOC.DATELINE: Paris, June 6 (CNA) (By M.J. Tsou & Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: The high speed railway that the Eurotrain Consortium is going to build for Taiwan will be completely different to the one which crashed on Wednesday in the German town of Eschede, consortium spokesman Ernest Thompson said on Friday.

Although the precise model to be developed for Taiwan has yet to be decided, Thompson said, it will be an integrated one which is completely different to the first-generation Intercity Express (ICE) train involved in Wednesday's accident.

During an interview with the CNA in the wake of the worst rail disaster in Germany's post-war history that has left at least 96 dead and 42 seriously injured, Thompson said the Taiwan model, to be jointly developed by Germany's Siemens AG and France's GEC Alsthom companies, which comprise the Eurotrain Consortium, will be much more advanced, in terms of both building technology and design concept, than the ICE.
No official explanation has yet been given for why the ICE Munich-Hamburg train slammed into an overpass pylon at 200 kilometers per hour near the northern German town.

However, one hypothesis suggests that a faulty wheel casing may have caused one of the carriages, very likely the first carriage immediately behind the locomotive, to jump the tracks, propelling two other carriages into the concrete pillar, and in turn dragging the other carriages off the rails, according to German news reports.

In a test ride conducted in northern Germany on May 3, the Eurotrain Consortium conducted a successful demonstration of the integrated high speed train system that is likely to be built for Taiwan, which was witnessed by its Taiwan partners and an 80-member delegation including the ROC representatives in Germany and France, Director-General of the Bureau of Taiwan High Speed Rail Liao Ching-lung, and representatives of the Taiwan High Speed Rail Consortium (THSRC).
During the test ride, the Taiwan delegation experienced the Eurotrain system which uses German-built locomotives and French double-deck carriages.

In January 1998, the THSRC was selected by the ROC government as the "preferred bidder" for Taiwan's planned high speed rail system. An initial concession agreement between the THSRC and the ROC government was approved in February this year.
If everything goes smoothly, the THSRC and the Eurotrain Consortium are expected to sign a formal contract in July and construction will begin later this year.
With a total budget of US$17 billion, the 345-kilometer high speed rail line is one of the world's largest transportation infrastructure projects currently under development.

The project includes a variety of civic work elements, including viaducts, tunnels and environmental protection features. At a design speed of 300 kilometers per hour, travel time between Taipei and the southern port city of Kaohsiung will be 90 minutes with a three-minute stop in Taichung, central Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: SEMICONDUCTOR WORKERS PRONE TO HF POISONING

TEXT.P: Semiconductor workers who use hydrofluoric (HF) acid to etch chips and remove corrosion are likely to develop symptoms of HF acid poisoning, a doctor at the Veterans General Hospital in Taipei reported on Saturday.

Deng Chao-fang, director of Clinical Toxicology at the hospital, said that the hospital received 90 cases of HF acid poisoning between 1985 and 1997. Among them, about 60 were contracted in the workplace, with semiconductor workers accounting for 56 cases.
Deng said that HF acid is an inorganic acid widely used in the semiconductor industry for chip etching and corrosion removal.

The toxicology expert said that careless handling of the acid can lead to painful skin inflammation, and necrosis, or skin death, in severe cases, while high doses can even lead to death from hypocalcemia, or low levels of calcium in the blood.

In terms of industry sectors, Deng said that workers in the semiconductor sector accounted for 78 percent of HF acid poisoning cases, followed by the chemical engineering sector at 9.7 percent, and the cleaning sector at 6.9 percent.
Housewives using the acid to remove corrosion in the home also accounted for 5.6 percent of the cases, he said.
In view of the rapid development of the semiconductor industry in Taiwan, Deng urged the sector to make sure they train their workers and take precautionary measures against acid contamination.

He advised workers who splash HF acid onto their skin to wash for 20 to 30 minutes using copious amounts of water, and then to apply calcium gluconate cream or solution before getting to a hospital as quickly as possible.

Statistics released by the Industrial Technology Research Institute show that the production value of Taiwan's semiconductor industry soared to US$10.01 billion in 1997, up from just US$1.57 billion in 1990.

Meanwhile, the Industrial Development Bureau also reported that HF acid usage increased to 1,433 metric tons last year from 600 metric tons in 1994, showing that while the island's semiconductor sector is developing fast, the hazard of HF acid poisoning is also increasing.
