DOC.HEADLINE: AGRICULTURE LOSSES EXCEED NT$170 MILLION AS FLOODS CONTINUE
DOC.DATELINE: Pingtung, southern Taiwan, June 6 (CNA) (By Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: Losses and damage to Taiwan's agricultural sector had exceeded NT$175 million (US$5.1 million) as of Saturday noon as heavy rains which have battered southern Taiwan over the last five days were reported to be moving toward the north.
Traveling at the head of a seven-member Cabinet mission, Premier Vincent Siew flew to Taiwan's southernmost Pingtung County on Saturday to inspect flood-stricken areas there.

The predominantly agricultural county has been hardest-hit by a cold front which has brought heavy downpours, resulting in serious flooding and landslides to southern Taiwan since Monday. Flooding has affected extensive areas of farmland in the county, causing losses worth NT$31.7 million in farm produce. The rains have also blocked roads, left one aquaculturist drowned, and washed away several farmhouses in the county.

In addition to promising timely salvage assistance to farmers, Siew also guaranteed that each hectare of damaged farmland will be compensated to the tune of NT$6,000 to help the affected farmers get back on their feet.

In Pingtung County, several schools were forced to close on Friday, and firefighters had to be dispatched to rescue students trapped by rising water. Over 10,000 households in the county suffered blackouts.

Meanwhile, the Taiwan Provincial Government announced that flood damage to the island's agricultural industry as a whole had exceeded NT$175 million as of Saturday noon, with cropland bearing the brunt of the heavy rains, incurring losses totaling NT$173 million (US$5 million) in that sector alone.
The worst-affected farmland, totaling 4,338 hectares, was in Kaohsiung, Pingtung, and Tainan counties in southern Taiwan, and in central Taiwan's Yunlin, Changhua and Miaoli counties.
Weathermen have forecast that the front will move north on Saturday, threatening the central and northern parts of the island with similar disastrous conditions.

DOC.HEADLINE: TUNG CHEE-HWA: CHINA WANTS HK TO SUCCEED FOR TAIWAN'S SAKE

TEXT.P: China is giving full support to Hong Kong so that its "one country, two systems" model can work and will be applied for the sake of reunifying Taiwan -- a bigger fish -- in the future, according to Tung Chee-hwa, Hong Kong's chief executive.
In an exclusive interview with the mass-circulation newspaper The Australian published Saturday, Tung said, "China is supportive of Hong Kong and it wants 'one country, two systems' to succeed."
Moreover, the mainland is allowing Hong Kong to run itself: "China really stays out of Hong Kong," he said.

Despite the recent election victories of Hong Kong's Democratic Party, Tung said his government will not increase the pace of democratization in Hong Kong. Instead his main priority is to restore Hong Kong's economic growth.
Hong Kong's economy fell two percent in the first quarter of 1998, its first drop in 13 years.
"The outlook is for a painful adjustment brought about principally by the very high cost of doing business, property values, high inflation and high wages," Tung said.

Although Hong Kong's condition is being made worse by the region's financial turmoil, Tung said its ample reserves, young labor force, high level of savings, desire to succeed and acceptance of technology will enable the territory to rebound.
Tung said the Hong Kong dollar will continue to be pegged to the US dollar. He said he would "absolutely" keep the peg.
He said Hong Kong's strengths are its position as a financial center for China and a service provider for the region and its ability to remake itself.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAC URGES BEIJING TO LET FAMILIES VISIT DETAINED TAIWAN BUSINESSMEN

TEXT.P: Johnnason Liu, director of the Legal Affairs Department of the Mainland Affairs Council under the Executive Yuan, on Saturday urged the Beijing authorities to allow families escorted by Straits Exchange Foundation personnel to visit the four Taiwan businessmen who were detained recently in the Chinese mainland on charges of espionage.

The call was issued because there has been no response from the Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait -- the mainland's quasi-official body authorized to handle civil contacts with Taiwan -- to a similar request from the SEF.
The SEF sent a letter to its counterpart, ARATS, on June 2, expressing its hope that the ARATS could arrange visits between the detainees and their families and SEF personnel.

Families of the four detainees have told the SEF that the businessmen have been involved in mainland investment activities for several years and could not possibly be guilty of spying, the families claim.

As the mainland has not yet responded to requests from Taipei, Liu remarked an interview Saturday that the authorities in Beijing need to understand Taipei's concerns, adding that he hopes the detainees' families, accompanied by SEF personnel, will be permitted by Beijing to visit their relatives soon.

DOC.HEADLINE: HOUSE COMMITTEE DEMANDS BEIJING TO RENOUNCE USE OF FORCE AGAINST ROC
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, June 5 (CNA) (By Jay Chen and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: A US House of Representatives committee passed a concurrent resolution on Friday, demanding Beijing to renounce the use of force against democratic Taiwan.

The House Committee on International Relations adopted the concurrent resolution with a unanimous verbal vote, which is mainly aimed at acknowledging Taiwan's desire to play a positive role in the current Asian financial crisis and affirming the support of the American people for peace and stability in the Taiwan Strait and security for Taiwan's democracy.

The resolution demanded President Bill Clinton seek, at the June summit meeting this year in Beijing, a public renunciation by mainland China of any use of force, or threat to use force, against democratic Taiwan.
It also demanded the United States abide by all previous understandings of a "one China" policy and its abiding interest in a peaceful resolution of Taiwan Strait issues.
The resolution, introduced by Rep. Gerald Solomon (R-NY) on April 30, will be referred to the House floor for approval next week.

Although the resolution is not binding to the executive branch, it expresses the sense of the Congress. The executive branch usually would pay due attention to non-bidnding resolutions unanimously adopted by the House and the Senate.

During Friday's discussion, Rep. Doug Bereuter (R-NE), chairman of the Subcommittee on Asia and the Pacific, said the concurrent resolution will convey the Congress' high respect for the people of Taiwan and its firm conviction that issues related to Taiwan's future should be resolved by peaceful means.

Rep. Benjamin Gilman (R-NY), chairman of the Committee on International Relations said he is pleased to see the passage of the resolution prior to Clinton's mainland visit from June 25 through July 3.
In the past, the US government had demanded Beijing renounce the use of force against Taiwan. Beijing, however, had consistently rejected such demand.

DOC.HEADLINE: CANADA'S EXPORTS TO ASIA DOWN

TEXT.P: A Canadian think tank said on Friday that Canada's exports to Asia have dropped by almost a quarter since last July, a result of the Asian financial crisis.
In a report on the world economic outlook, the Conference Board of Canada said Asia's problems will affect growth within the G-7 countries during the next two years.

It noted that exporters to the region will be particularly hard hit. Exports to Japan alone -- Canada's second-largest trading partner -- are down 28 percent since July and down 52 percent to Southeast Asian countries.

Although there have been signs of improvement in Asia since March, the board said the crisis is far from over. The region's fragile financial system and massive overcapacity will stymie quick recovery, it predicted.

Peter Lok, the author of the study, said there is a real danger of a second round in the Asian crisis. "The sharp deceleration in economic growth in China and the plunging Japanese yen are particularly worrying," he said.

Asia accounts for about 10 percent of Canada's exports. However, the United States, which accounts for 80 percent of the country's exports, may already be showing some signs of an Asian slowdown and that will eventually hurt Canada.

DOC.HEADLINE: MANDELA WARNS AGAINST POLITICAL CRIMINALS

TEXT.P: South African President Nelson Mandela on Friday urged political parties not to give sanctuary to "scoundrels" seeking to endanger state security, and said the government is ready to deal with any threat.

In a statement on the recent arms and ammunition heists, which have been linked to alleged right-wingers in the defense force, he said the government is aware of maneuvers by criminal elements to cultivate political justification for their illegal activities.
Mandela appealed to leaders of political parties not to even unwittingly give political sanctuary to "scoundrels who are manipulating the insecurity of innocent people."
He said those still contemplating any kind of action amounting to a breach of state security should abandon their fruitless efforts.

He called for party leaders to stop misleading members of the public by creating the false impression that they can achieve by other means what they have failed to attain democratically and peacefully.
"They are exposing gullible people to danger and destroying the future of young people whose preoccupation should be raising their children and giving comfort to their families," he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: WANG DAN SUPPORTS CLINTON VISIT TO MAINLAND CHINA

TEXT.P: Mainland Chinese dissident Wang Dan said on Friday he supports US President Bill Clinton's visit to mainland China.
Wang was in Toronto to promote a memorial service commemorating the June 4, 1989 Tiananmen massacre.

Wang also visited Ottawa, where he spoke with Foreign Affairs Department officials and handed over a list of political prisoners he hopes the Canadian government will pressure mainland China to release.

He said that there is no benefit in isolating mainland China. "I think to improve human rights conditions in China, we need to maintain a dialogue and relationship with the government of China," he commented.
Other exiled Chinese dissidents and American politicians have condemned Clinton's June 25-July 3 visit, the first by a US leader since the bloody crackdown.
Wang's recent release from a Chinese jail on medical parole was widely seen as a goodwill gesture toward the US.
"I also hope that when President Clinton visits China, he will not avoid the human rights question," Wang said.
He added: "I hope that during his dialogue, he asks for further releases of political prisoners."
Wang was arrested in July 1989 and sentenced in 1991 to a four-year prison term. In October 1996, he was sentenced to a further 11 years in jail for crimes of "sedition and counterrevolution."
The 29-year-old was granted medical parole in April and exiled to the United States, where he now lives.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT CONFIDENT OF WINNING YEAR-END ELECTIONS

TEXT.P: The ruling Kuomintang (KMT) has been gaining momentum and is confident of winning the year-end elections, KMT Secretary-General John Chang said here on Saturday.
Chang said he believes the party's election candidates will win back voters who might have lost faith in the grand old party.

Asked whether former Justice Minister Ma Ying-jeou's entry into the Taipei City mayoral race last week has boosted the KMT's sagging morale after the long and anguished search for a candidate strong enough to race against the popular incumbent Chen Shui-bian of the opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP), Chang said it is evident that the KMT is gaining momentum daily.
He added that party solidarity will have a positive effect on the year-end legislative election and the election for Taipei and Kaohsiung city mayors and councilmen.
Chang met with party heavyweights on Saturday morning to discuss the strategy for Ma's campaign support.

Meanwhile, although Wang Chien-hsien, the opposition New Party (NP)'s candidate for Taipei City Mayor, was placed in an awkward position following Ma's last-minute entry into the race, NP officials vowed on Saturday to throw their full weigh behind him, saying that they will not consider a proposal to join hands with Ma to crush the popular incumbent.

Chou Yang-shan, convenor of the NP's National Election and Reform Committee, said that his party will present its best candidate to the voters, and will not resort to personal attacks or vilification strategies in the campaign.
Jaw Shau-kang, manager of the NP's national campaign, also revealed that "high-ranking" KMT officials approached the NT in April about the possibility of cooperating to wrest power from Mayor Chen.

He said the NP agreed not to present a candidate for the Taipei City mayoral race on certain conditions, including a promise that President Lee Teng-hui, in his capacity as KMT chairman, would lift the ban on the three "noes" -- no direct trade, no direct postal links, no direct transportation links -- suspend the "go slow" policy toward investing in mainland China, and recognize NP policies on foreign policy, environmental protection, and social order.
However, the KMT refused to accept these conditions and the cooperation proposal fell through, according to Jaw.

DOC.HEADLINE: ENTEROVIRAL MUTANT DISCOVERED

TEXT.P: One more infant appears to have fallen victim to an enteroviral epidemic that has claimed 26 lives in Taiwan in less than two months.
In at least one of those cases, the victim succumbed to a mutation of enterovirus type-71.

The most recent death was that of a seven-month-old female who died Saturday morning at Taichung Veterans General Hospital in central Taiwan. She had been in critical condition since being admitted on Tuesday, said a pediatrician in charge of the infant's care.
The baby, however, did not develop symptoms typical of an enteroviral infection, such as blisters or a rash on the skin, the doctor said, which led him to wonder whether the virus had mutated.

That same day, researchers at Taipei-based Veterans General Hospital confirmed the existence of a mutation. Medical researcher Wu Yu-chi said the mutation was discovered in tissue samples taken from a child who recently died of an enterovirus infection at the same Taichung hospital as the latest victim.

There are two main subtypes of enterovirus type-71, and the newly discovered mutation demonstrates characteristics of both, researchers said. One subtype results in encephalitis and myocardistis, while the other results in hand-foot-and-mouth disease.
Parents of the most recent victim have agreed to allow an autopsy to be performed. Results from the autopsy are expected to shed light on the cause of the viral epidemic.

Hsu Kuo-shiung, a counselor for the Department of Health (DOH), on Saturday said the enterovirus epidemic seems to have cooled down somewhat. He cited a latest medical report that indicated throughout Taiwan, only two enterovirus cases were reported to the DOH over the past two days.
However, the DOH official warned that the new viral hybrid could lead to more deaths.
He urged people in Taiwan to pay greater attention to personal hygiene, noting that the virus breeds most easily during the warm and damp summer season.

DOC.HEADLINE: VETERAN TYCOON RETURNS AFTER LOW-PROFILE MAINLAND VISIT

TEXT.P: Formosa Plastics Group (FPG) Chairman Y. C. Wang returned to Taipei on Saturday following a weeklong low-profile visit to mainland China.
Wang would not make any comment on his mainland visit at Chiang Kai-shek International Airport. The veteran industrial mogul just said he would meet the press at his office later.

Wang, accompanied by his wife, quietly left Taipei for the southeastern mainland province of Fujian on May 30 and traveled to Beijing on June 2 in the company of a senior Fujian communist party official.
Major mainland news media gave prominent reports on Wang's mainland trip in an apparent attempt to signify the importance Beijing authorities attached to the petrochemical industry baron's visit.

During his stay in Fujian, Wang reportedly had toured several major infrastructure construction projects in the province, s stronghold of Taiwan-funded companies. Wang also inspected the FPG-invested ventures in the region.

According to a Hong Kong newspaper, Wang met with National People's Congress Chairman Li Peng, a former mainland premier, on Wednesday. During the meeting, Li reportedly had inquired Wang about his opinions on a set of mainland regulations aimed at protecting Taiwan investments on the mainland.

The report further said Wang was originally scheduled to meet new mainland Chinese Premier Zhu Rongji to seek his understanding of the reasons behind the FPG's decision to transfer its stake in a multibillion-dollar thermal power plant project in Zhangzhou, Fujian to a foreign business group. However, Zhu didn't meet Wang because of his busy schedule, the report said.

The FPG's three flagship companies -- Formosa Plastics Corp., Nan Ya Plastics Corp. and Formosa Chemical and Fiber Corp. -- originally planned to each hold a 20 percent stake in the US$3 billion Zhangzhou power plant project. However, the FPG, Taiwan's largest private manufacturing enterprise, was forced to transfer its stake to a foreign partner earlier this year to avoid violating Taiwan's "no haste, be patient" mainland investment policy. Under the terms of the contract with its partner, the FPG will be able to buy back the stake in the Zhangzhou power plant when Taiwan's cross-strait investment policy is eased.

President Lee Teng-hui ordered a review of the policy on mainland-bound investment in late 1996 as Beijing stepped up its efforts to isolate Taiwan in the international community. Under the tightened restrictions, local companies are banned from investing in any mainland infrastructure project worth more than US$50 million as well as in high-tech industries.

The "no haste, be patient" mainland investment policy is also aimed at protecting this country from becoming too reliant on the mainland market as Beijing has never renounced its attempt to use force against Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: LINCOLN AMERICAN SCHOOL FOUND WITH THREE TAIWAN NATIONALS ENROLLED

TEXT.P: In an investigation of six foreign schools in Taiwan, only Taichung's Lincoln American School in central Taiwan was found to have violated regulations, officials of the Department of Education under the Taiwan Provincial Government said on Saturday.
Officials ordered the investigation after a controversy erupted last month surrounding Lincoln American School, founded and headed by Anna Lee, daughter of ROC President Lee Teng-hui.

Officials said that among Lincoln American School's 184 students, three Taiwan nationals were found enrolled in the school's kindergarten. The school offers a total of 15 classes, from kindergarten to 12th grade.

The other five foreign schools, located in Hsinchu, Taichung and Kaohsiung, were found to be operating in line with regulations that stipulate only foreign students or Taiwan students with dual citizenship can be accepted as students.
The officials said that they would ask Lincoln American School to help its three Taiwan nationals transfer to other local schools.
Lincoln American School first made news when it was discovered that it had relocated to a residential area in Taichung without first obtaining proper approval.

DOC.HEADLINE: CONFUSION AND LAYOFFS AS MAINLAND CHINA RESTRUCTURES

TEXT.P: Mainland China is facing widespread confusion and rising unemployment as Premier Zhu Rongji moves to restructure his central government by laying off up to 4 million public servants by year's end, according to The Sydney Morning Herald.
Zhu plans to reduce the number of ministries in mainland China from 40 to 29, and the reduction program is creating confusion and being met with resistance, according to the paper.

In a dispatch from Beijing, the daily's correspondent David Lague quoted foreign diplomats as saying that some key sections of the Beijing bureaucracy are now in disarray as Zhu continues to prune the number of government ministries in the biggest public service upheaval since the Cultural Revolution.

"I think he (Zhu) has probably overreached himself this time. People are worrying about whether they will have a job next week rather than concentrating on their work," an unnamed foreign diplomat said.

Diplomats and businessmen in Beijing said Zhu had been hailed both within the mainland and abroad for his economic acumen. However, mainland China's mounting economic difficulties are now too much for any leader to overcome, they said.

The Chinese government has mounted a major propaganda blitz to encourage workers shed from collapsing state-owned companies to find new jobs, but an urban unemployment rate that has reached about 20 percent makes this nearly impossible.
Chinese labor activist and political dissident Han Donfang, who works in Hong Kong for Radio Free Asia, said Beijing appears to have no answer to its unemployment problem.
"As a result, the countdown to an explosion of anger has already begun," he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHINESE TAIPEI STRIKES GOLD ON FIRST DAY OF TAEKWONDO WORLD CUP

TEXT.P: Chinese-Taipei came away with three medals, including one gold, on Friday, the first day of the Taekwondo World Cup in Sindelfingen, Germany.

Tang Hui-wen of the women's bantam class won the gold, while two teammates, Yeh Chiao-ling of the women's fly class and Huang Chia-ching of the women's fin class, took the bronze. Both Tang and Huang have won medals in past international competitions.
Chinese-Taipei is competing in all eight tournament divisions in both men's and women's events.

Participating in the three-day competition are teams from Australia, Taiwan, Korea, the Philippines, Vietnam, Iran, Kuwait, Croatia, France, Germany, Italy, Spain, Turkey, Greece, Russia, Turkey, Yugoslavia, Denmark, Sweden, Argentina, Brazil, Canada, Mexico, Venezuela, the United States, Cuba, Egypt, Lesotho, South Africa and Morocco.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN DEVOTED TO PROMOTING TELECOM LIBERALIZATION
DOC.DATELINE: Singapore, June 6 (CNA) (By Conrad Lu & Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: The transportation and communications authority of the Republic of China said Taiwan's efforts in promoting trade liberalization in the telecommunications market has been recognized by other member-economies of the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation (APEC) forum.

Transportation and Communications Minister Lin Feng-cheng made the remarks during an interview with CNA after APEC's three-day ministerial-level information and telecommunications conference concluded Friday in Singapore.
Taiwan is one of 18 members of APEC.
Lin, who led a delegation aiming to boost electronic commerce and promote free trade in telecommunications products, spoke of Taiwan's measures to open its market.

He said in 1997 Taiwan's telecommunications authorities allowed private businesses to provide cellular phones services, and recently a decision to open satellite and Internet communication markets was made.

Meanwhile, with the worldwide expansion of the Internet and electronic commerce, his ministry is also constructing high-quality communications networks islandwide to facilitate Taiwan's development of the modern businesses, Lin said.
He added Taiwan can learn a great deal from Singapore ONE, the network being built to connect every home in Singapore to the Internet.

As to Taiwan's effort in developing electronic commerce, Lin said the authorities are currently considering reforms to its electronic commerce regulations. In addition, he mentioned Taiwan is working to develop IC cards that will serve as a combined identity, health insurance and bank ATM card.
Lin and his delegation visited with administrators and operators of Singapore's Changi International Airport, one of the world's most modern, on Saturday before returning to Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC WELCOMES US CONGRESSIONAL RESOLUTION

TEXT.P: The Republic of China welcomes a US congressional resolution urging President Bill Clinton to demand Beijing renounce the use of force against Taiwan, Foreign Ministry spokesman Roy Wu said on Saturday.

The House Committee on International Relations on Friday passed a resolution calling on Clinton to seek from mainland authorities, at the summit meeting in Beijing later this month, a public renunciation of the use of force or the threat of the use of force against Taiwan.
"We welcome this resolution and appreciate all the support the American lawmakers have extended to us," Wu said at a press conference.
Wu said the resolution, adopted with a unanimous voice vote, indicates that the US Congress hopes to restrict Beijing's threat to use force against Taiwan.
"It also signifies American lawmakers' concerns about peace and stability in the Taiwan Strait," Wu noted.
The non-binding resolution notes Taiwan's desire to play a positive role in resolving Asia's current financial crisis and affirms the support of the American people for Taiwan's security.
The resolution demands the United States honor its previous commitments to its "one China" policy and maintain its interest in a peaceful resolution to the "Taiwan Strait issue."

It further said the American people desire strong relations with people on both sides of the Taiwan Strait and that the US government should take all necessary actions to ensure peace and stability in the Taiwan Strait, while continuing mutually beneficial trade relations with Taiwan's vibrant economy.
The resolution, introduced by Rep. Gerald Solomon (R-NY) on April 30 and passed by the Subcommittee on Asia and the Pacific on May 21, will be referred to the House floor for approval next week.

DOC.HEADLINE: KINMEN DESALINATION PLANT EXPECTED TO BE COMPLETED NEXT JANUARY

TEXT.P: Kinmen Magistrate Chen Shui-tsai on Saturday presided over the first meeting called to discuss the status of a pilot desalination plant on Kinmen, the ROC's major frontline island outpost, located off the mainland coastal province of Fujian.
Chen and officials from the Kinmen Water Department heard a briefing offered by a Montgomery Watson Taiwan affiliate on the plant's development.

Construction on the plant, designed by Montgomery Watson and being built by an engineering operation under the Cabinet-level Vocational Assistance Commission for Retired Servicemen, began last April and is scheduled to be completed next January.
The desalination plant, once fully operational, is expected to supply some 2,000 metric tons of water daily.
Chen said he expects the plant will help ease Kinmen's persistent water shortages. In Kinmen rain water is scare and running water is limited, he added.

The plant is expected to alleviate the more serious shortages that occur each summer when the island is swarmed by tourists from Taiwan, who visit the island for its natural beauty and historical attractions, Chen said.
Since the ROC government lifted restrictions on tourists traveling to Kinmen nearly five years ago, about 600,000 Taiwan tourists visit the island each year.

On Kinmen, about 20,000 members of the ROC military and an unknown number of civilians, rely on a combination of running water and water obtained from reservoirs and storm-water collection ponds. About 50,000 civilians are registered residents of Kinmen, but it is not known how many actually live on the island.

Fujian Province, aware of Kinmen's persistent water shortages, has offered to provide Kinmen water, since the island is located closer to Fujian than Taiwan. ROC authorities, however, have been reluctant to accept the mainland's offer.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC FRIENDSHIP FLOTILLA RETURNS TO HOME BASE

TEXT.P: A friendship flotilla of the Republic of China Navy returned to its home base in southern Taiwan Saturday after completing an 11,000-nautical mile training voyage for graduating cadets of the Navy Academy.
Composed of two missile frigates and one supply ship, the flotilla visited Nauru, Solomon Island, Indonesia, Singapore, and Malaysia during the 39-day journey.
The cadets took part in various drills during the voyage, which began on April 28.

DOC.HEADLINE: KARTYA SEEKS CIB ASSISTANCE IN SEEKING TRUE PARENTS

TEXT.P: A Taiwan girl who was sold to an Australian couple by a white slavery ring in March 1981 paid a visit to the Criminal Investigation Bureau (CIB) on Saturday to seek its assistance in finding her birth parents.
Kartya Elizabeth Wunderle, now 17, returned to Taiwan from her Melbourne home for the first time Friday night in the company of her adoptive mother Nola.

During her meeting with CIB Director Yang Tzu-ching, Kartya expressed her strong desire to know her true identity. "I look forward to meeting my biological parents, and your assistance will be deeply appreciated," she told Yang.
Kartya had her blood samples taken at the CIB laboratory for DNA tests to facilitate the identification of her true parents.
Kartya, whose Chinese name was Lin Mei-li, is scheduled to meet the press on Monday afternoon.

CIB officials said they have received phone calls from some 10 counples in the past few days claiming themselves as Kartya's true parents, but none of them would come forward or reveal their identities.
The CIB unveiled its phone numbers (27678305 and 27670588) and Kartya's fax number in Australia -- 00261393183523 -- to facilitate contact by Kartya's Taiwan parents.

Kartya was one of the 64 abducted Taiwan babies sold to couples in the United States, Australia, Switzerland and Germany by the Chu Li-ching white slavery ring in the late 1970s and early 1980s for up to US$5,000 each.

The ring was busted in 1982. Its mastermind, Chu Li-ching also known as Julie Chu, was convicted in 1982 and had been freed after serving a seven-year jail term. Some 30 others, including doctors and midwives who issued false birth certificates as well as people who posed as parents and signed false adoption agreements, were also given jail terms ranging from four months to several years.

DOC.HEADLINE: GRASSROOTS ELECTION CAMPAIGN OFFICIALLY LAUNCHED

TEXT.P: Taiwan's grassroots election campaign was officially launched Sunday as voters islandwide are scheduled to go to the polls on June 13.
Election officials said 19,602 candidates are vying for 8,755 wardenships in three administrative districts which are Taiwan Province, Taipei and Kaohsiung cities.
There are an additional 6,901 candidates who are competing for 3,727 seats in councils of rural and urban townships as well as cities in Taiwan province.

The competition for wardenships in Taipei city is particularly fierce, with 1,231 candidates vying for 435 posts. This is in part due to the recent increase in the salary for wardens which is about NT$45,000 (US$1,323), significantly higher than their counterparts in Taiwan Province and Kaohsiung. Only 66 candidates are running without rival.
There are 1,136 persons in competition for 664 wardens in Kaohsiung and 17,235 persons for 7,656 wardens in Taiwan Province.
Although campaigning was not supposed to begin until Sunday, some candidates began stumping on Friday, according to local papers.

Other reports of illicit maneuvering include changing the registered residence of supporters to special constituencies, violence and four incidents of gunshots aimed at scaring rivals out of the race.

However, there were no reported evidence of attempts at vote-buying. It has been common practice for candidates to hand out monetary gifts to garner voters. The mass-circulated United Daily News reported Sunday that some candidates are offering between NT$200 to NT$3,000 in exchange for voter support.

The elections, widely believed to be a harbinger of the year-end elections for legislators and mayors of Taipei and Kaohsiung, have taken on new importance since the ruling Kuomintang lost its strong grip on power in the city and county chief elections in 1997.

DOC.HEADLINE: RE-VOTE FOR DPP CHAIRMAN HELD IN KAOHSIUNG

TEXT.P: A re-vote for the election of the Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) chairman was held on Sunday in Kaohsiung after violence and vandalism marred the original election on May 26.
Voting in the southern Taiwan city will complete the process in which the party will select its next chairman from six candidates.
In an effort to prevent cheating or a repeat of the violence, the DPP leadership kept security tight during the event.
Kaohsiung has approximately 16,000 DPP members eligible to vote in the chairmanship election while the number of party members across the island stands at around 96,000.

Polling stations are scheduled to close at 4 p.m. which will be followed by the counting of Kaohsiung ballots as well as those 40,000 votes which had been sealed and placed at DPP headquarters since the original elections.

The counting of votes is expected to be completed by 9 p.m. and the DPP will hold a news conference at 9:30 to announce the results of the election. Although the race is being contested by six candidates, the party's top adviser, Lin Yi-shiung, and Legislator-at-large Chang Chun-hung are seen as the top favorites.

Other contestants are Taoyuan County Magistrate Annette Lu, former DPP spokesperson Sisy Chen, Legislator Yen Chin-fu and Huang Fu, president of a radical pro-Taiwan independence faction within the DPP.

The DPP held its election for party chairmanship on May 26. However, voting in Kaohsiung had to be suspended after a group of men stormed into the city's only polling station in Chungshan Stadium and destroyed tables, chairs and cameras. They also overturned several ballot boxes ruining hundreds of ballots.

After the incident, the DPP decided to hold a re-vote in Kaohsiung while the remaining 30 ballot boxes across the island were sealed and transferred to party headquarters in Taipei to await a simultaneous counting of votes with those from Kaohsiung.

DOC.HEADLINE: IMPORT OF FOREIGN WORKERS NEARS QUOTA

TEXT.P: The number of foreign workers imported to Taiwan is reaching the government's limit of 260,000 Council of Labor Affairs Chairman Chan Hou-sheng said on Saturday. There are currently about 251,000 foreign labors working in Taiwan.
Due to the limited room for further importation of foreign workers, the need from local construction and manufacturing sectors will be considered on a case-by-case basis, he said.
Chen made the comments during a speech at a seminar sponsored by the Commercial Times on the improvement of competitiveness and management-labor relations.

In a bid to help carry out major public construction projects around the island, Chan said he is in favor of importing workers from overseas for large-scale plans worth NT$200 million or more on a case-by-case basis. However, he added that the maximum number of foreign employees working on such projects cannot exceed 30 percent of its total labor force.

DOC.HEADLINE: UIGHURS SAID WAITING FOR OPPORTUNITY TO RISE UP IN XINJIANG

TEXT.P: The Uighurs in Xinjiang would rise up against their communist rulers if mainland China took military actions against Taiwan, a leader of Uighur dissidents living in exile in Turkey said here Saturday.

The leader, who declined to be named, said in an interview with CNA that, judging from Taiwan's defense capability, he believes it would take mainland China a lot of troops and a long period of time to conquer Taiwan. The military action would therefore give Uighurs in Xinjiang a good opportunity to revolt against communist China in order to solve "the problem of Xinjiang," he added.

If mainland China took military actions in Tibet, the Uighurs would also take the opportunity to revolt, he said, adding that Beijing's persistent refusal to solve the problem of Tibet through peaceful negotiation with Tibetan spiritual leader the Dalai Lama has undermined young Uighurs' confidence in the Beijing regime. There are 18 million Uighurs in Xinjiang, according to a 1990 census. They would mobilize for a popular uprising whenever the country is in disorder, he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICE WAR BETWEEN LOCAL AIRLINERS EXPECTED

TEXT.P: A price war between local airliners that operate Taipei-Kaohsiung flights is expected to break out on Monday when six carriers call an end to their joint operation cooperation on flights between the two cities.

Six local airlines -- China Airlines (CAL), EVA Airways, Far East Air Transport Corp., TransAsia Airways, UNI Airlines and Formosa Airlines -- reached an agreement on joint operation on Taipei-Kaohsiung flights last February.
U-Land Airlines, one of the seven airliners that ply Taipei-Kaohsiung flight, was the only company at that time which did not join the agreement as it targets a different segment of the market.

The agreement allowed passengers who held tickets from any one of the six companies to take flights offered by those carriers in the pact. Airliners benefited from not having to compete so fiercely with their pricing strategies. The cost of a one-way ticket rose from NT$600-700 to NT$1,100 as a result.

However, a series of aviation disasters, including CAL's crash on Feb. 16 which killed 202 people and Formosa Airlines' crash on March 18 which claimed 13 lives, resulted in a decrease of passenger load capacities.
In the face of fewer passengers, airline companies have launched a variety of promotional offers to woo back customers, leading to the end of the joint operation cooperation.

CAL and Formosa Airlines announced they were withdrawing from the pact in late March. One-way ticket fares have been cut to NT$999 for those approaching the airport counter and to NT$760 for those purchasing tickets via local travel agents.

Far East Air Transport Corp. is offering one-way tickets at NT$980 to students, soldiers and policemen. If passengers take flights between Monday and Thursday with VIP cards issued by the airliner, they can get an additional NT$200 discount coupon for their next flight.

Meanwhile, TransAsia Airways offers customers a 15 percent discount on all flights if they pay by credit card. In addition, the airliner gives out convenience store coupons with every ticket purchase on the Taipei-Kaohsiung route.
The street market price of a Taipei-Kaohsiung one-way ticket is known to be as low as NT$650, lower than the fare of train ticket for the highest class.

Aviation authorities are currently taking a hands-off approach to the price war. They may however change their policy, but before they do, local travelers will benefit from the keen competition between local airlines given that aviation security is not a concern.

DOC.HEADLINE: SUN YUN-SUAN TO HELP MA YING-JEOU TO RUN FOR TAIPEI MAYOR

TEXT.P: A former premier of the Republic of China and a current senior advisor to the president announced Sunday he would help campaign for KMT candidate for Taipei mayor Ma Ying-jeou.

Sun Yun-suan made the announcement while attending the opening ceremony of a Yushan conservation exhibition at the National Taiwan University in Taipei. He expressed his personal support for "my good friend" and wished the former justice minister success in his mayoral bid.

Ma, an associate professor at the National Chengchi University, lauded Sun as a premier who had won a great deal of respect from the public. He expressed his appreciation for Sun's support and hoped the senior leader would give him more encouragement and advice in the future.

In regards to the exhibit, Ma said during his term as a minister without portfolio, he visited many areas damaged by typhoons and has discovered that Taiwan's ecology has been seriously damaged. Illegal mining of sand and stone at river beds have been particularly bad, he said.
He criticized government officials for being lazy and called for the people to be more vigilant in supervising their efforts.

The exhibition, jointly sponsored by the Yushan National Park Headquarters, China Youth Corps, and other public and private organizations, is promoting national parks through photos and audio-visual presentations. The mobile exhibition will be held on various campuses over eight days.

DOC.HEADLINE: MA YING-JEOU LEADS CHEN SHUI-BIAN IN OPINION POLL

TEXT.P: Taipei Mayor Chen Shui-bian is lagging behind former Minister of Justice Ma Ying-jeou in a popularity poll conducted by the mass-circulation newspaper the United Daily.

The poll showed that 46 percent of the respondents said they support Ma, the Kuomintang's (KMT) candidate in the contest for Taipei city mayor, while only 30 percent said they would vote for the Democratic Progressive Party's (DPP) Chen.

According to the survey results, support for Ma has mounted since he unexpectedly announced his candidacy for the post last week. In a similar poll at that time, Ma secured 42 percent of support compared with Chen's 32 percent.
The support rate of New Party candidate Wang Chien-shien remained stable at approximately 5 percent in both surveys.

However, when asked who had a better chance of winning the year-end mayoral election, 36 percent of those polled named Ma, while 34 percent picked up Chen. Only one percent said that Wang had the greatest chance among the three.

The survey also suggests the gap between Ma's and Chen's support rates would expand 16 percentage points to 22 percentage points with Ma gaining 51 percent approval and Chen 29 percent if Wang decides not to run in the race.

Asked if they thought Ma's credibility should be questioned because he refused to run in the mayoral race until the last minute, 25 percent answered yes, while 22 gave a negative response. Thirty percent felt that Ma's candidacy has nothing to do with his credibility, while 20 percent had no comment on the issue.
Even among those who said Ma lacked credibility, as high as 32 percent still believe that Ma is the best candidate for Taipei mayor compared to 54 percent in that group who said no.
The poll was based on telephone interviews of 1,056 Taipei residents held between June 4 and 6.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHINESE-TAIPEI WINS ONE GOLD, ONE BRONZE

TEXT.P: The Chinese-Taipei team won a gold and a bronze metal on the second day of the World Cup Taekwondo championships being held in Sindelfingen, Germany.
Hung Chia-chun won a gold medal in the women's feather-weight class while Hsu Feng-chih of the men's light-weight class beat competitors from Kuwait and Lesotho, but yielded to Iran.
Hsu's bronze is so far the first medal won by the Chinese-Taipei men's team in the three-day contest.

The Chinese-Taipei women's team have won two golds and two bronzes in the first two days of the competition. Coaches expect the team to win the women's group championship if the two competitors in the middle- and heavy-weight classes perform equally well on Sunday.
In addition to the two women's divisions, three of the men's divisions, namely fly-, bantam- and welter-weight classes, will have compete on the last day of the events.

Coaches said it was not surprising for the Chinese-Taipei team to win more medals in the women's divisions. Taiwan athletes have been winning medals in taekwondo for years and are recognized internationally as accomplished competitors in the sport.

In the past, Chinese taekwondo athletes have won more than 200 medals, among which are some one hundred gold medals, in international competitions. As taekwondo will become an official event in the 2000 Olympic Games, taekwondo athletes from Taiwan are considered medal contenders.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT MAY FIELD MA YING-JEOU FOR MAYORAL RACE ON WEDNESDAY

TEXT.P: Kuomintang Secretary General Chang Hsiao-yen said Sunday Ma Ying-jeou will hopefully be named KMT candidate in the Taipei mayoral race during the KMT Central Standing Committee meeting to be held on Wednesday.
The KMT Taipei City Committee has suggested that since only Ma has registered for the KMT primary for candidates in the Taipei mayoral race, there would be no point in holding a primary.
Chang said the KMT screening committee will meet on Monday and Tuesday to decide the namelist of the third batch of candidates for the year-end legislative elections.
KMT Chairman Lee Teng-hui is expected to formally support the fielding of Ma for the mayoral race at the meeting on Wednesday as there is no other KMT candidate up for the post.
As for the KMT primary for Kaohsiung mayoral candidates, Chang said results will be submitted to the KMT Central Standing Committee to decide on the candidates after the completion of the primary.

Commenting on cooperation between the ruling party with the opposition New Party in the mayoral race in Taipei, Chang stressed that at present, there was no possibility of cooperation between the two parties, as for future development, it will depend on the situation by that time.

Chang also denied allegations made by New Party leader Jaw Shau-kong that the KMT has sent people to speak with New Party members on possibility of cooperation between the two parties. He said the KMT is very careful with its strategy, and any cooperation between Ma and New Party candidate Wang Chien-shien may incite a strong reaction from voters.

DOC.HEADLINE: TURKEY TO GIVE UIGHURS PERMANENT RESIDENCE STATUS

TEXT.P: The Turkish government will soon grant permanent residence status to the Uighurs newly-arrived from Xinjiang, an informed source said Saturday.
Some 1,000 Uighurs from Xinjiang in northwest China will receive the status, he said, adding that there are about 50,000 Uighurs living in exile in Turkey.
With the permanent residence status, they will be able to legally live and work in Turkey, but they can not serve in the armed forces or work in government organizations.

The Turkish parliament passed a bill in February to grant permanent residence status to newcomers from Xinjiang and northern Iraq, he said, adding that it is the Turkish government's policy to give a helping hand to other people who also speak the Turkic language.

The informed source said Uighurs in Turkey, who regard the permanent residence status as a certificate for "second-class citizens," hope to go back to their homeland after the collapse of the Chinese communist regime in Beijing.

DOC.HEADLINE: ACADEMICS, OPINION LEADERS APPEAL FOR RELEASE OF BUSINESSMEN

TEXT.P: Academics and political opinion leaders attending a Sunday seminar urged the government to seek the release of Taiwan businessmen detained by mainland authorities through political means.

Quasi-officials in charge of dealing with mainland China responded to the calls by saying the only way to protect Taiwan business interests in the mainland was to sign an investment guarantee accord with mainland China.

Liu Yih-chun, a research fellow at Academia Sinica, Taiwan's highest-level research institution, said the most important issue now was whether the basic human rights of the Taiwan businessmen currently under arrest in the mainland are fully protected.
Beijing announced late last month that four Taiwan businessmen were arrested by mainland state security authorities in March on espionage charges.

Liu called on the mainland authorities to make public evidence which justifies their arrest, noting that the incident will serve as a benchmark on whether Taipei and Beijing will be able to move toward cooperation instead of confrontation.

Central Police University (CPU) Vice President Liu Shih-lin said Beijing's intention is to use the incident to pressure Taiwan to go to the negotiating table, and serve as a warning to others conducting business in the mainland. Similar cases will re-occur in the future, he warned.

CPU Professor Huang Yen-tung called on the people of Taiwan to write a letter to mainland Chinese President Jiang Zemin to protest against the Taiwan citizens' arrest as Jiang prepares to meet with US President Bill Clinton later this month.

National Chengchi University Professor Chang Tai-lin said the two sides should begin talks on a joint effort to crack down on criminal activities, and to find out whether there is evidence showing that the Taiwan businessmen had really engaged in illegal activities.

If the mainland authorities fail to respond positively to Taiwan's call, then Taiwan residents can consider launching a boycott against investments and travel to mainland China, he said. Taiwan should also consider lodging complaints with international human rights groups as well, he added.

National Assembly Deputy Wu Mao-hsiung said the case cannot be resolved through legal means and pointed out that holding political negotiations is the only possible way of finding a solution to the problem.

Echoing Wu's view, National Assembly Deputy Tsai Chih-hung said the motive behind Beijing's arrest of Taiwan citizens, which took place just before the ninth anniversary of the June 4 massacre and the Clinton-Jiang meeting, is "not simple."

Beijing might use the case to make the United States believe Taiwan is at fault for strained cross-strait relations, and for refusing to begin cross-strait talks, Tsai said. He added that mainland China might be issuing a warning to political dissidents in the mainland with the arrests.

He forecast that Beijing would announce a verdict on the detained Taiwan businessmen and repatriate them back to Taiwan before Clinton's planned visit to mainland China in a bid to underscore its efforts in building friendly ties with Taiwan.

An official of the Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF), Taiwan's semi-official organization in charge of negotiating with mainland China in the absence of official relations between the two sides, revealed that the SEF and a group of legal experts are studying feasible ways to rescue the Taiwan businessmen.

Since 1991, there have been around 460 trade disputes across the Taiwan Strait, according to the official. And 184 of them were criminal cases against the personal safety of Taiwan investors, such as killing, kidnapping, detentions and robberies.

Chou Chang-hsiang, brother of Chou Chang-ming, one of the four Taiwan businessmen who were arrested by the mainland authorities, said families of the four men are very worried about their personal safety in the mainland.

Expressing the desire that the four be properly treated in accordance with mainland laws and set free as soon as possible, Chou called on the government to take a moderate and low-profile approach to deal with Beijing authorities in the case.
He said they prefer to take a low-key strategy to prevent exacerbating cross-strait relations and to ensure the safety of their family members in the mainland.

DOC.HEADLINE: ACTING HEAD OF INVESTIGATIVE BUREAU ACCUSED OF RAPE

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Justice announced Sunday it would investigate charges that acting head of the ministry's Investigation Bureau Cheng Chuan had attempted to rape the daughter of a friend.

The charges, which Cheng has denied, were made by Democratic Progressive Party National Assembly Deputy Lai Ching-lin at a news conference Saturday. Lai said Cheng attempted to rape the daughter of Yang Wan-shou on Sept. 13, 1996 in Paris.
Lai said Cheng, who studied in France between 1974 and 1977, was in Paris for a reunion with his acquaintances and friends there.
He allegedly attempted to sexually assault Yang's daughter, then 19, when they were left alone in a hotel room. Cheng stopped when Yang's wife Chiou Pai-lien entered the room, Lai said.

Yang filed complaints with French police and Taiwan authorities but to no avail because Cheng use his status as deputy director of the Ministry of Justice Investigation Bureau (MJIB) to block the investigation, said Lai.
Lai added that the victim was so shocked and traumatized by the assault that she almost collapsed and continues to require psychological counseling and medical treatment.
The assembly deputy lambasted Cheng for "biting the hand that feeds him" because Yang and his wife helped Cheng financially while he was studying in Paris.
Lai claims that Cheng also assaulted several other women while he was a student in France.
Cheng denied the accusations and dismissed it as a plot to dampen his chance to head the MJIB.

Cheng, who has been the MJIB deputy director for over 10 years, began doubling as director four months ago when the former bureau head Wang Rong-jou was named deputy finance minister. He has been hoping to fill the vacancy officially.

To support his claim of innocence, Cheng ordered his bureau to disclose his schedule during his stopover in Paris between Sept. 11 and 14, 1996 which was filled with visits and social events with friends and Taipei diplomats posted there.
Cheng admitted to having visited Yang at his Paris home, but on Sept. 12 and not Sept. 13, the date of the alleged incident. He added that he was accompanied by his entourage during the whole visit.

Lai, in a news conference on Sunday, called Cheng a liar, and asked Cheng to reveal his whereabouts on Sept 13, when the victim claims to have been assaulted by Cheng in a hotel room where he was staying.
Lai also produced documents of the original complaint the victim filed with the French police.
Cheng refused to reply Lai's accusation on Sunday saying that he is consulting with lawyers and could take legal steps to defend his reputation.
Meanwhile the Minister of Justice Liao Cheng-hao, who is Cheng's immediate superior, decided after an emergency meeting Sunday to convene a panel to probe the allegations.

Noting that the ministry was informed of Yang's complaints by the office of president in March 1997, Liao said that he ordered the then director Wang Rong-jou to look into the case. In a brief issued in September 1997, Wang said there was no evidence to support the claim.
Liao promised to reopen the investigation by setting up an ad hoc panel consisting of senior justice officials to get to the bottom of the case.

DOC.HEADLINE: PAKISTAN PM VISITS SAUDI ARABIA

TEXT.P: Pakistan Prime Minister Mohammed Nawaz Sharif began a two-day visit to the Kingdom of Saudi Arabia on Saturday.
It is Sharif's first visit abroad after his country conducted nuclear tests last month.

Pakistan Ambassador to Saudi Arabia Khalid Mahmood said the visit comes in the framework of the two countries mutual consultations on matters of common interest. The delegation accompanying Sharif include economic experts and high officials of the Pakistan government.
Mahmood was received by King Fahd on May 29, a day after Pakistan conducted its first nuclear tests, to explain why Pakistan had held its tests.
The tests were hailed by Muslim countries as the Pakistan tests were seen as a champion of the Muslim cause.

DOC.HEADLINE: INDIA CUTS DUTY TO BOOST IMPORT OF COMPUTER PARTS

TEXT.P: Computer and computer-related manufacturing companies with operations in India should benefit from import duty reductions announced by the Finance Ministry in the national budget for fiscal 1999 through March 31.

The impact of duty reductions, which are substantial in some cases, would have been even more significant if it were not countered by the 8 percent special customs duty slapped on almost all imports, the Economic Intelligence Unit (EIU) said Saturday.

Computer use in India is still very limited, with a ratio of about two PCs for every 1,000 persons. This means India has tremendous growth potential, which also makes it a large market for exports of information technology products. The United States is a major exporter of both hardware and software to India.

Prime Minister Atal Behari Vajpayee has announced that it wants to make India a computer software powerhouse in 10 years. A government-appointed task force has been established to draw up a national policy to achieve this objective.

India was committed to abolishing the import duty on information technology products under the Informational Technology Agreement. The duty cuts and nationalizations announced by India's Finance Ministry will make imports of components and parts significantly cheaper than fully built units, the EIU said.

The duty on floppy, hard and CD-ROM drives has been reduced to 5 percent from 12 percent. Duty on computer parts excluding printed circuit boards will come down to 22 percent from 25 percent. Cathode ray tubes for color monitors will have a duty of 5 percent against 15 percent, and the duty on deflection components for such monitors will be 5 percent versus 25 percent.

Duty on software for telecommunications -- a major growth area in India -- has been cut to 30 percent from 40 percent. Import duty on telecommunication equipment parts will be 20 percent, the EIU added.

DOC.HEADLINE: AUSTRALIAN DOLLAR SEEN CONTINUING TO FALL

TEXT.P: The Australian dollar, once regarded as a stable currency, is expected to continue its slide in coming weeks as a result of external factors, including weakening commodity prices, deepening regional problems and Australia's higher foreign debt.
The Australian dollar hit a 12-year low of 60.55 US cents on Friday, down from 61.07 US cents on Thursday.

Market economists predicted the currency could trade below 60 US cents in the coming days or weeks and move toward 55 US cents when the full effect of Asia's deepening economic crisis hits. The currency's previous low was 57.10 US cents in July 1986 when Australia's economy was suffering.
Analysts said the Reserve Bank of Australia (RBA) had failed to prop up the value of the Australian dollar above 61 US cents even after spending about A$3 (US$2) billion on Thursday and Friday.
They believed the RBA will continue to buy more Australian dollars if the currency, which is one of the 10 most active currencies, depreciates further.
The RBA is not strong enough to keep the currency from sliding further because Australia holds only around A$24 billion (US$16 billion) in both gold and foreign exchange reserves, they said.
This week's slide of the Australian currency was caused by massive selling by US investors, including Merrill Lynch, Citibank and George Soros.
"Most people in the world are bearish on the Australian dollar because of Asia which is in a mess and will only be getting worse," Rory Robertson of the Bankers Trust Australia in Sydney said.
Economists believe speculators could further bring down the value of the Australian dollar because the currency no longer appears to be the safe haven it was during the Gulf War in 1991.

They attributed the plunge of the dollar, which was still at 76 US in June 1997, to weakening commodity prices in the world market, falling Australian exports, surging net foreign debt of A$225 billion (US$150 billion) in April and above all the impact of the Asian economic meltdown.

"There is a risk that in the next three months the currency will be sufficiently weak to force the RBA to raise (interest) rates. The trouble is they have a limited number of reserves and the Australian dollar is not going to rise anytime soon," Robertson said.

He and other economists believed the RBA could be forced to raise interest rates because of growing fears of the inflationary pressure as a result of the falling Australian currency, which causes imports to be more expensive.

RBA Governor Ian Macfarlane, who is currently on visit to London, has ruled out any possibility of further interest rate cuts because of fears of a higher inflation rate. He described the rate cut as "unlikely."

Australia's inflation, measured by the Consumer Price Index, is now hovering between 1.5 and two percent despite five consecutive interest rate cuts between July 1996 to July 1997, which brought down the official rate to five percent from 7.5 percent.
On two-way trade, Australia has long-suffered trade deficits due to rising imports to its exports.

Australia's exports, including gold, metals, coal, iron ore, wheat, seafood and other agricultural products, have dropped due to slackening demand in Asia, which accounts for about 60 percent of Australia's total exports.
Other exports, including education, and tourism, also experienced declines due to the economic meltdown in Asia.
But there could be a silver lining for Australian exporters to North America, Europe, the Middle East and Latin America because their products are more competitive in these markets.
Economists believe the US operators of hedge funds will continue selling the Australian dollar because it is a currency in Asia with enough liquidity.
"There is still some selling to be done by US hedge funds because they are short US dollar and long Asian currencies," Mark O'Leary of the Macquarie Bank in Sydney said.
He and other economists believed the RBA will continue to intervene in the foreign exchange markets to slow down the depreciation of the Australian dollar.
"But the intervention will only have some effect on the Australian dollar because the RBA has only limited power to substantially prop up the value of the currency," one economist said.

DOC.HEADLINE: DISNEY NAMES EXECUTIVE TO OVERSEE MAINLAND CHINA OPERATIONS

TEXT.P: Walt Disney Co. named John Feenie as its executive vice president for mainland China affairs, as the world's second largest entertainment company prepares to expand into the world's largest market.

Feenie, 49, has been president of Walt Disney Consumer Products Asia/Pacific since 1994. It is the first time Disney has appointed an executive to deal directly with Beijing, and it comes after controversy earlier this year over its film "Kundun." The picture, about Tibet, was criticized by Beijing authorities for its anti-Chinese sentiments.
Disney is in a race with other multi-media firms such as News Corp. and Time Warner Inc. to provide the world's most populous nation with news, television shows and films.

John Feenie, a native of Australia, has worked for Disney in Asia for a decade. In his new role, he will also oversee DisneyFest, a new mobile attraction that combines shopping with a mini-theme park and will travel to cities around the world.

DOC.HEADLINE: OPPOSITION ELECTS PARTY ADVISER TO BE NEW CHAIRMAN

TEXT.P: Taiwan's major opposition Democratic Progressive Party elected its top adviser Lin Yi-shiung as its new chairman for a two-years term.
Lin beat fellow front-runner Chang Chun-hung with a total of 31,674 ballots, while Chang garnered 14,923 votes. The remaining votes went to the other four runners.
A total of 51,030 ballots were cast out of 92,504 eligible party members, representating a turnout of about 55 percent.
DPP Chairman Hsu Hsin-liang announced the outcome at a press conference on Sunday night.
Newly-elected DPP chairman Lin called for party unity at the press conference, and vowed to lead the DPP to win the yearend elections of legislators and city heads of Taipei and Kaohsiung.
The ballot counting was delayed for two weeks after the Kaohsiung polling station was vandalized by disgruntled party members on May 24.
The party condemned the vandalism and staged a re-vote in Kaohsiung and suspended ballot counting islandwide until Sunday.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHINESE OFFER RELIEF TO POOR AND REFUGEES IN PARAGUAY AND BRAZIL

TEXT.P: Chinese communities in Paraguay and Brazil have widened their yearly charity efforts and donated over US$50,000 in relief aid as well as food to those suffering from the harsh winter conditions and drought.
The disadvantaged in Ciudad del Este and of the City of Foz have received US$46,000 so far, and refugees of a drought in North East Brazil received more than ten thousand US dollars.
A severe drought in northeast Brazil led Chinese residents in Sao Paulo to form an ad hoc committee to collect and offer aid in the form of 10,000 kg of food in late May.

Unwilling to let their fellow countrymen in Brazil outdo them, the Chinese community in Paraguay offered 1,200 bags of food as relief for the poor of Foz, a Brazilian frontier city with Paraguay, in late May. They also donated 50 bags of food to refugees in drought-stricken northeastern Brazil.
On June 5, Chinese residents in the Ciudad del Este offered 2,000 bags of food and a similar quantity of cotton quilts for the poor of the city, adding to the previously donated 50 wheelchairs.

Ciudad del Este Mayor Juan Carlos Barreto told the CNA that the citizens of the Ciudad del Este appreciate the kindness of Chinese citizens very much. The Chinese community is one of the only foreign communities in the city to provide relief for the poor and their benevolent actions are increasing. Last year, they offered 1,200 bags of food and this year, it was 2,000.

Each bag of food includes five kg of rice, five kg of flour, two kg of noodles, 900 ml of soybean oil, one kg of bean, 500 gm of tomato ketchup, two kg of sugar, one kg of salt, 500 gm of powdered chocolate, one kg of powdered corn, and 500 gm of biscuit.
Pedro Juan Caballero, another gathering place for Chinese in Paraguay, will also launch relief efforts on June 7.

DOC.HEADLINE: EVERGREEN FOUNDER INVITED TO BE PHILIPPINE PRESIDENTIAL ADVISER

TEXT.P: Evergreen Group Chairman Chang Yung-fa, who maintains interests in shipbuilding, construction and airlines worldwide, has been invited to be an economics adviser to Philippine President-elect Joseph Estrada, company sources reported Monday.
Chang founded Evergreen Marine Corp. in Taiwan with one second-hand vessel in 1968 and steered the company into becoming the world's largest container ship operator 17 years later.
He visited Manila shortly after May 29 when the Philippine Congress proclaimed Estrada the winner of the May 11 presidential elections at the invitation of the president-elect.

During their meeting, Estrada invited Chang to be an economics adviser to the presidential office, and Chang accepted, the sources said. Chang was also invited to attend Estrada's inauguration slated for June 30 in Manila.
Estrada and Chang, who have been long-time associates since Estrada served as vice president to the Philippines, met again on Sunday to discuss business and trade issues as well as national policies.
After the meeting, Estrada hinted that he would seek constitutional changes to spur investment in the Philippines.
Estrada told reporters that he urged Chang to invest in Philippine seaports but that Chang was apprehensive due to a constitutional limit on foreign ownership of most businesses at 40 percent.

Many foreign investors have gotten around the limit by using Filipino dummy companies, Estrada said, adding that Chang told him that foreign businessmen in the Philippines are leery of such an arrangement because dummy firms sometimes break under-the-table agreements designed to get around the investment law.

This will be Chang's second such appointment by a foreign government. He was named a presidential adviser to Panama and an honorable consul-general of the Republic of Panama in the Republic of China on Taiwan.
Under Chang's leadership, Evergreen expanded its operations in 1989 to aviation by establishing EVA Airways, Taiwan's second airline serving international flights.

DOC.HEADLINE: UNIVERSITY STUDENTS CONFIDENT IN CHEN'S REELECTION BID: POLL

TEXT.P: More than half of university students around the island would like to see incumbent Taipei Mayor Chen Shui-bian reelected in the year-end mayoral election, according to a survey conducted by a National Chengchi University student paper.
The paper sent 811 copies of questionnaires to students at 20 selected universities around the island on June 1-2. It managed to collect 771 valid replies as of June 6.
Survey results show that 55 percent of the respondents threw their support behind Chen, a heavyweight in the main opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP).
About 35 percent said they would vote for former Justice Minister Ma Ying-jeou, a Kuomintang (KMT) stalwart who, in a surprise move, announced late last month his candidacy for the mayoral contest.
The poll also found that the support rate for Wang Chien-hsien, the New Party's candidate for the race, is only about 3 percent.
Meanwhile, as many as 66 percent of the respondents said they believe Chen will be able to win his reelection bid.

The same survey further found that only 25 percent of the total respondents are eligible to vote in the Taipei mayoral election. More than half of these eligible voters said they would vote for Chen if the election were to take place the following day, while 30 percent would opt for Ma.

According to the survey, most of Chen's supporters admire his guts, decisiveness and efficiency in carrying out administrative reforms and major municipal development projects, while Ma's supporters recognize his passion for social services and constant concern about the well-being of the underprivileged.
As for the motivations behind Ma's decision to enter the Taipei mayoral race, most respondents said they think that Ma mainly wants to help sustain the KMT's dominance in Taiwan politics.
Many respondents further said they think Ma's integrity is questionable because he had rejected calls for his candidacy until the last minute.

DOC.HEADLINE: HEAVY RAINS CAUSE NT$570 MILLION IN AGRICULTURAL LOSSES

TEXT.P: Losses in agriculture from the recent torrential rains have reached about NT$570 million, the Taiwan Provincial Department of Agriculture and Forestry said on Sunday.
Yunlin County in central Taiwan suffered the biggest losses totaling NT$293 million, followed by Kaohsiung County in southern Taiwan with about NT$74 million, the department said.

The department said affected farmers can apply for low-interest government loans and subsidiaries and that it has released 4,000 metric tons of frozen vegetables to ease local market demand. It also said it will begun helping farmers resume operations.
Rainfall is expected to continue across Taiwan and the department has called on farmers to take preventative measures to protect their crops.

The aquacultural husbandry industry located in coastal areas in central and southern Taiwan has been blamed for the heavy flooding as its overuse of underground water sources has lead to the sinking of soil, officials said. The government has encouraged local aquacultural husbandry cultivators to shift to other sectors or relocate their operations to Southeast Asian countries.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP CHAIRMAN LEAVES FOR NORTHERN EUROPE

TEXT.P: In his last overseas trip as Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) chairman, Hsu Hsin-liang left for northern Europe Monday.
The chairman is expected to step down from his post as leader of Taiwan's largest opposition party in July.
He will first visit Riga, Latvia before going to Helsinki, Finland, where he is scheduled to meet parliamentarians, and think tanks on Wednesday.
Hsu will then proceed to Stockholm, Sweden on Saturday and is scheduled to call on political party members, and social welfare groups before returning home June 17.
Members of Hsu's delegation include DPP Secretary-General Chiu Yi-jen, Legislator Liu Chin-hsing and Hsiao Mei-ching, DPP director of Department of Culture & Information.

Since the DPP won a resounding victory in islandwide county and city chief elections late last year, Hsu has made a series of foreign trips which included the United States, South Korea, Japan and Australia.
The trips have increased the DPP's exchanges with parties of other nations, and greatly boosted Hsu's profile in the international community.

DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER SIEW TO VISIT SOUTH PACIFIC

TEXT.P: Premier Vincent Siew is scheduled to visit Republic of China allies Tonga and Solomon Islands in the South Pacific early in July, Government Information Office Director-General Chen Chien-jen said.

The trip, the first by an ROC premier to that part of the world, may also take Siew to Fiji which has no formal diplomatic ties with the ROC but maintains cordial relations with Taiwan, the government spokesman said.

Siew will attend the celebrations marking the 80th birthday of King Taufa'ahau Tupou IV of the Kingdom of Tonga, and will be one of the Solomon Islands' honorable guests at galas marking the country's 40th founding anniversary, according to the Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA).
King Tupou, who turns 80 on July 4, paid a four-day state visit to the ROC in August last year.
Before proceeding to the South Pacific, MOFA officials said, Siew will likely fly to Manila to attend the inauguration of Philippine President-elect Joseph Estrada slated for June 30.
From Manila, officials hope Siew may stop-over in Australia, from where he will then proceed to Tonga. Relevant contacts are being made to secure the possibility of the stop-over, they said.
If the stop-over approval materializes, Siew will be the highest-ranking ROC official to set foot in Australia, they noted.
Tonga and Solomon Islands are two of the ROC's four diplomatic allies in the South Pacific, which also include Nauru and Tuvalu.
Fiji opened its representative office in Taipei late last year. President Kamisese Mara traveled to Taipei and personally presided over the opening of the office on Dec. 15, 1997.

Siew will be accompanied by Peng Tso-kwei, chairman of the Cabinet-level Council of Agriculture, Minister without Portfolio Yang Shih-chien and a number of other government officials during the forthcoming trip.
He may also make a transit stop in Hawaii during his return trip, MOFA officials said.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHINESE-TAIPEI WINS TWO GOLDS, FIVE BRONZES IN TAEKWONDO COMPETITION

TEXT.P: The Chinese-Taipei taekwondo team won two gold and five bronze medals in the World Cup Taekwondo 1998 competition in Sindelfingen, Germany. The women's team also received a third-prize trophy for group performance.

The women's team takes home two golds and three bronzes. Bantamweight Tang Hui-wen and featherweight Hung Chia-chun each won the gold, while fineweight Huang Chiu-chin, flyweight Yeh Chiao-ling and middleweight Tsai Pei-shan each took the bronze.
Lightweight Hsu Feng-chih and welterweight Kao Ming-chien from the men's team each won the bronze in their categories.

The Chinese-Taipei team participated in all 16 divisions in both the men's and women's competitions. Many of those on the team have experience in international meets as over 200 medals have been won by Chinese taekwondo athletes from Taiwan in previous years.

Coaches were optimistic that the Chinese-Taipei team will do well in the 2000 Olympic Games when taekwondo becomes an official medal event. Members of the Chinese-Taipei team are currently in their teens and 20s, making them potential medal contenders.

Taekwondo has become increasingly popular not only in Asia, but also in Europe and American. In the three-day competition in Sindelfingen, athletes from Africa and the Middle East put on impressive performances.

Coaches of the Chinese-Taipei team emphasized that the Chinese competitors need more experience in international contests. So far, the World Cup and Asian Cup are the most important meets for Chinese taekwondo competitors.

DOC.HEADLINE: COMMITTEE OF 100 URGES CHINA AND TAIWAN RAPPORT

TEXT.P: As US President Bill Clinton prepares for his visit to mainland China on June 25, the Committee of 100, an influential Chinese-American group, urged the administration to encourage greater rapport between Beijing and Taipei.

At its 7th annual conference, the Committee of 100 presented a paper on Clinton's coming visit to China titled "Seeking Common Ground, While Respecting Differences: Essentials of a Winning China Policy."
In pursuit of peace in the Taiwan Strait, the committee offered suggestions for Clinton to propose while on his visit to China for both Beijing and Taipei to agree upon. They are as follows:
-- refrain from any political and military provocation that would increase tension and escalate conflict across the Taiwan Strait;
-- to establish the three currently banned direct links between the mainland and Taiwan (shipping, trade and mail),
-- set, as early as possible, a more concrete agenda for the leadership of both sides to meet and begin a constructive dialogue;
-- encourage further economic cooperation;
-- initiate more artistic, athletic, cultural and educational exchanges;

-- hold frequent joint conferences, seminars and study groups attended by non-government experts, scholars, and business executives from both sides of the Taiwan Strait to study the question of peaceful reunification.

Among the 10-point recommendation to President Clinton, the committee said the US should encourage direct dialogue between mainland China and Taiwan so that both sides may peacefully settle cross-strait issues according to their own terms, continue to make clear that the US will not interfere or take sides, and reaffirm a "One China" policy.

Chinese ambassador to the US Li Zhaoxing had earlier told the conference that the Taiwan issue is the most sensitive one between the US and China. However, he does not expect the Clinton visit to produce any "fourth communique" on the issue.
As long as both countries can fully implement the words and spirit of the existing three joint communiques, the Sino-American relations will be very good, said Li.
ROC Representative to the US Steven Chen has been invited to address the conference on Sunday.

DOC.HEADLINE: OFFSHORE ASSETS REPORTING LAW JUSTIFIED: CANADA

TEXT.P: An authority in the Canadian government says the proposed offshore assets-reporting law is justified because a growing number of Canadians are hiding assets overseas to avoid paying taxes.
Canada's Auditor General Denis Desautels said Friday he reached that conclusion after completing an in-depth review of the controversial law.
"Canadians, increasingly, are investing offshore and there are signs that some are not reporting their foreign income to Revenue Canada," he said. "Therefore, they are not paying tax on this income.

"This violates the basic principle that residents in Canada are taxed on their worldwide income. It is also unfair to taxpayers who are reporting 100 percent of their income and who must shoulder a greater portion of the tax burden."
Desautels was asked by the government last December to review the law. He concluded it is "justified and appropriate because there is a potentially serious erosion" of Canada's tax base.

The conclusion strengthens the federal government's hand to put the law, which would require Canadians to report their overseas assets, into effect. This comes in spite of strong opposition from rich immigrants from Hong Kong, Taiwan and other countries.

Critics of the legislation disagree with Desautels' findings and predict the Canadian economy will lose more than it gains because the law will drive out many immigrant families and discourage others from coming here. Some have already left Canada in protest, and more prospective wealthy immigrants are hesitating to come, they said.
The assets-reporting law has caused a furor in the business community, particularly in British Columbia, when the federal government first introduced it in the 1995 spring budget.

The legislation was passed last spring but implementation has been postponed until April 1999. It requires Canadian residents to disclose all assets held outside the country if their original cost exceeds C$100,000. Exempted are property used exclusively in an active business, and residences for personal use.
Critics complained the reporting rules are an invasion of privacy, are difficult to comply with, and may be a precursor to a wealth tax.

Opponents said while they recognized Ottawa's main aim is to stop the flow of billions of dollars each year from large Canadian corporations into offshore tax havens, many middle-class individuals will end up being caught by the low C$100,000 threshold.

DOC.HEADLINE: JAPAN AT THE ROOT OF ASIA'S PROBLEMS
