TEXT.P: Japan is at the root of Asia's financial problems and because it accounts for two-thirds of the region's GDP, there is no easy cure for Asia's ailing economies, the Financial Post of Canada reported Saturday.

It has been almost a year since Asia's economy slammed into a wall and provided the rest of the world with an ugly lesson in the consequences of speculative investing, the Post's editor Diane Francis wrote.

In a column which is also carried by The Ottawa Sun, Francis said Japan's desperate and insolvent banks never confessed to, or dealt with, the problems that hit them in 1989 with the collapse of the Japanese stock and real estate markets.
"To make up for these losses they engaged in ill-considered lending practices with their neighbors, thus creating speculative bubbles in real estate and stocks and currencies," she pointed out.
Between 1996 and 1997, the adverse shift in net private capital flow was US$109 billion, roughly equivalent to 10 percent of their combined GNPs before the crisis, she noted.

As business and government scandals have undermined Japan's confidence, and the government is pushing down interest rates to encourage spending, she believes Japan "faces a daunting long-term problem."
She pointed to Japan's need to increase investment to fund the medical and pension needs of its aging population.
On the other hand, the failure of Japan to ignite spending or to deal with its fat cat bankers' mistakes impedes the recovery in all of Asia, Francis said.

She observed that if Japan's banks offer debt relief to other Asian countries, they can emerge as economically healthy, democratic societies. "Not GNP growth based on speculative bubbles," she stressed.

DOC.HEADLINE: TRADE SURPLUS HIT US$570 MILLION IN MAY

TEXT.P: Taiwan recorded a trade surplus of US$570 million in May, the highest single-month level since December, the Ministry of Finance statistics showed Monday.
Taiwan exported US$9.39 billion worth of products and services in May while imports amounted to US$8.82 billion, according to the tallies.
Although the May trade surplus figure registered a decrease of US$1.3 billion from the same period last year, it was the highest month's total in six months.
The May export value was down 7.5 percent from the same period in 1997, while the import value was up 3.1 percent on an annual basis, the statistics indicated.

A Finance Ministry official attributed the fall in outbound shipments last month to plummeting exports to Japan and Association of Southeast Asian Nations member states, which were down 22.5 percent and 28.2 percent, respectively, from a year ago. Exports to Hong Kong fell by 5.4 percent, he added.

The growth in May imports is a result of increased inbound shipments of machinery equipment, which rose by about 23 percent from the same month a year ago, an indication that investment sentiments remain bullish at home, the official said.

DOC.HEADLINE: TRADE DEFICIT WITH JAPAN SHRINKING

TEXT.P: Taiwan's trade deficit with Japan fell to US$1.39 billion in May, Ministry of Finance officials said on Monday.
The figure compares with US$1.8 billion in February, US$1.81 billion in March and US$1.52 billion in April.
But officials noted that exports to Japan have continued to decline by 20 percent in the first five months of the year compared to the same period last year.
If the trends continues, the trade deficit with Japan this year could exceed the record figure of US$17.3 billion reported in 1997, they stated.
They also indicated if Japan's economy rebounds and if Taiwan can increase its exports to Japan, then the island would still be able to cut its trade deficit with Japan.

If the Taiwan dollar continues to slide against the greenback, officials said it would be difficult to predict the effect of the depreciated New Taiwan dollar. It could boost Taiwan exports but it could also lead to inflation due to higher prices on imports, they said.

DOC.HEADLINE: BEIJING MIGHT AGREE TO CROSS-STRAIT SUMMIT IN INT'L SETTING

TEXT.P: Mainland China might ask US President Bill Clinton to help arrange for the top leaders from the two sides of the Taiwan Strait to meet in an international setting before the end of this year, an opposition lawmaker said on Monday.
Legislator Trong Chai from the pro-independence opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) made the revelation in a written interpellation to the Cabinet.
Chai said Beijing has furnished the Clinton administration with a report detailing the issues that communist authorities want to discuss with Clinton when he visits the mainland later this month.

Chai quoted the report as saying that if Clinton is willing to conduct an in-depth discussion on Taiwan-related issues during his June 25-July 3 mainland visit, Beijing would not mind letting the US help arrange a cross-strait summit meeting in an international setting before year's end.

According to Chai's report, Beijing is also demanding that the US reaffirm its commitments to the so-called "one China" principle, which is against the formulas of "two Chinas, or one China, one Taiwan," and is also against independence for Taiwan or its membership of the United Nations and other international organizations involving sovereign states.

Chai further said Beijing will produce a timetable for resolving cross-strait issues and will seek Clinton's support for its proposal. "The two sides are almost certain to issue a joint statement at the end of Clinton's summit with his mainland counterpart, Jiang Zemin," he added.

Nevertheless, Chai said, Washington and Beijing have yet to come to terms on the content of this joint statement, as the Clinton administration still doesn't want to include the so-called "Taiwan issue" in the statement.

Meanwhile, Chai reminded the government here of the possibility of Beijing taking politically motivated action in the run-up to Clinton's visit, either to highlight its claim over Taiwan or to justify the urgency with which it wants to tackle what it calls the "Taiwan problem."

Chai urged the government to keep a close watch on developments surrounding the upcoming summit in order to prevent Taiwan from becoming a sacrificial lamb on the altar of Beijing-Washington rapprochement.

He also suggested that the government step up its lobbying of the US Congress to push American lawmakers to firm up their support for Taiwan and pressure Clinton not to reach an easy compromise with Beijing at Taipei's expense.

DOC.HEADLINE: MA YING-JEOU ELECTION CAMPAIGN OFFICE TO BE ESTABLISHED

TEXT.P: Kuomintang Taipei mayoral candidate Ma Ying-jeou will establish his election campaign office this week, and plans to hold weekly public appearances to listen to constituents' concerns, said Chen Hsueh-sheng, a KMT Taipei city councilor.

According to Chen, Ma's campaign team will be formed in a few days and will consist primarily of professors from National Taiwan University and National Chengchi University, where Ma is currently an associate professor of law.

Ma's campaign team plans to select a native Taiwanese scholar who is thoroughly familiar with city politics as its campaign spokesman. Chen said Ma will no longer personally respond to criticisms against him as the campaign office, once established, will handle them.
Chen also revealed that Ma will meet with KMT Taipei city councilors to better understand civic concerns and political opinions.
Ma also plans to visit city councilor Lin Jui-tu of the opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP). Lin has said he is willing to drop out of the DPP to help Ma run for Taipei mayor.

DOC.HEADLINE: MILITARY TO HOLD ANNUAL PERFORMANCE REVIEW

TEXT.P: The Republic of China's 1998 armed forces performance review meeting will be held Tuesday to evaluate the military's overall performance and to help improve military strength.

Chief of the General Staff Tang Fei will preside over the meeting which will focus on ways of improving troop management, preventing incidents that may endanger public safety and the first stage results of the ongoing streamlining of the military aimed at establishing an elite deterrent force.

Flight and maritime safety, logistics performance, enlistment and personnel selection, development in military information database systems, and anti-corruption measures will also be reviewed at the meeting.

Minister of National Defense Chiang Chung-ling will preside over the opening ceremony, while President Lee Teng-hui will address the 500 senior military officials and advisers at the closing ceremony.
The military spokesman's office explained that the meeting will be closed to the public and the media as it is a routine internal performance review.

DOC.HEADLINE: NEWLY ELECTED PARTY CHAIRMAN MEETS WITH DPP OFFICIALS

TEXT.P: One day after winning the election for party chairman of the main opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP), Lin Yi-hsiung met on Monday with several DPP heavyweights.
Lin, who won 62.07 percent of the vote, beat his closest rival, Chang Chun-hung, by a wide margin in Sunday's election. Chang managed to garner only 29.24 percent of the vote.
Lin met with incumbent DPP chief Hsu Hsin-liang, and DPP secretary-general Chiu Yi-jen over lunch on Monday to learn about their experiences in leading the country's largest opposition party.

Addressing the issue of personnel arrangements, Lin said that he will not bring in any faces from a foundation headed by him, but will focus instead on ability and character when choosing his right-hand men.

Asked about the intercommunication between the DPP and the ruling Kuomintang (KMT), Lin said that both parties should "join hands to do what is best for the people," with regard to matters such as national health insurance and constitutional reform.
He stressed that all political parties should take the welfare of the people as their first priority.

On the year-end elections, he said his party will work with and coordinate among its various candidates, saying that the party will combine the benefits of its policy studies, campaign strategies and its clean image, in the election race.

He expressed the belief that whatever the elections -- be they the race for the mayorships of Taipei and Kaohsiung cities, the election of city councilmen, or the legislative election -- DPP candidates will have to woo voters through legitimate means, adding that only if the DPP can win the mandate of the voters will it be able to win political power.

The advocate of Taiwan independence also said that Taiwan's position as an independent sovereignty is an historical fact. He lamented that this is still not recognized by most nations in the international community, or even by some local people, and vowed that the DPP will step up moves to solicit support for the idea.

DOC.HEADLINE: MALAYSIA BECOMING KEY DESTINATION FOR TAIWAN INVESTMENT
DOC.DATELINE: Kuala Lumpur, June 8 (CNA) (By Chen Yi-ping and Fang Wen-hung)

TEXT.P: Taiwan enterprises have invested NT$20 billion (US$580 million) to establish the Southeast Asia Holding Co. and plan to invest mainly in Malaysia, according to Representative Paul J.K. Tso of the Taipei Economic and Cultural Office in Malaysia.

The Southeast Asia Holding Co., which is headed by Liu Tai-ying, chairman of the China Development Corporation, plans to invest in manufacturing-oriented projects as well as stock markets in Southeast Asia, and Malaysia in particular, Tso said.

Taiwan investment delegations have visited various post-financial crisis Southeast Asian countries over the last few weeks, and have agreed that Malaysia has the best investment environment. Looking at the long-term situation, Taiwan businesses investing there can make a profit while bringing much-needed capital and technology to Malaysia -- a situation Tso described as "win-win."
He also revealed that one of the strategies being adopted by the Taiwan enterprises is to first invest in Malaysia, while observing the situations as they develop in other countries.
Approximately 1,500 Taiwan businesses currently have investment interests in Malaysia worth a total of US$8.3 billion, and annual Taiwan-Malaysia bilateral trade hits as high as US$6.5 billion.

DOC.HEADLINE: US NEWSPAPER INTERVIEWS ACER CHAIRMAN

TEXT.P: "The Taiwan economy's blend of government backing and small-company verve has helped it weather the Asian financial crisis better than other countries, and is seen as a model for the rest of Asia," Stan Shih, Chairman of Taiwan's Acer Group, was quoted as saying.
So said James Flanigan, the Los Angeles Time's senior economic editor in a report on Taiwan's successful experience in coping with the Asian financial crisis.

Stan Shih, an electrical engineer who founded Acer group 20 years ago, said in a an inteview with James Flanigan, the Los Angeles Time's senior economic editor that the crisis signals once and for all that the region's reliance on high-volume manufacturing is ending.

"Labor-intensive manufacturing of hardware is not sustainable for any country in Asia," Shih said in the report entitled "Asian Miracle", adding "Automation and new materials change the product, and even-cost producers are left behind.
"That is why every country now must move forward to knowledge, education, management skills -- the elements of intellectual property that now define world industry," he was quoted as saying.

Americans will find such musings familiar, but Shih is making an important point for Asia. The rise of Asian economies in the last 50 years, even that of mighty Japan, has been based on the skilled manufacturing of goods. Cars, televisions, industrial machinery -- turned out with great precision -- won world markets because of high quality and reasonable prices.

The quality is still there; the price is even cheaper now. But something has changed: The skilled manufacturing of Asia has been devalued. New car plants in South Korea aren't worth what it cost to build them, not only because the Korean currency, the won, is devalued but because cars are in surplus everywhere. A plant by itself has no great value unless it's linked with good customer relations, a distribution system, and a hard-won brand image, according to the report.
Shih's own company, and indeed Taiwan, illustrate these trends. Shih and a few associates founded Acer in 1976 as a low-priced manufacturer of computer hardware for other companies, IBM among them.

It still makes computers for IBM and many others, but Acer has become a worldwide giant in its own right, with US$6.5 billion in sales of computers, software and networking systems. In addition to Taiwan, it manufactures in the Netherlands, Texas, the Philippines, Malaysia and mainland China, where it is starting a computer software development center in Shanghai.

With a lead from Acer, Taiwan has become a leading manufacturer of computer systems through entrepreneurial companies working in government-backed high-tech industrial parks. The work is a big step forward in sophistication from turning out low-cost home appliances, Taiwan's chief activity just 10 years ago.
Shih offered a provocative judgment:
"One cause of the Asian crisis is that America has moved into the information age while Japan has remained tinkering with automation and mass production.

"The greatest value in business from now on will be in intangible property. Customers will pay more for knowledge and information," Shih said. "Look at the profit of automobile companies -- hardware earns maybe 5 percent on sales. But software earns 30 percent to 40 percent on each dollar of sales -- look at Microsoft."

In simpler terms, according to the report, Shih was saying that service industries will spur the growth of Asia's economies when they recover. To be sure, Asia's manufacturers will still turn out quality goods. But in country after country, labor costs and shortages are forcing a shift of such manufacturing work. Malaysia, for example, has labor shortages. And manufacturers are leaving mainland China's coastal cities for lower-wage towns in its vast interior.

In the future, the report said, look for service industries -- finance, marketing, medical care and business services -- to provide the bulk of urban employment, as they do in the US and other developed economies, the report concluded.

DOC.HEADLINE: AIRSPACE, AIRPORTS RANKED FOR SAFETY

TEXT.P: Hong Kong, Wellington, San Francisco, Nice, Suva, Buenos Aires, Nauru and Lagos are among the 15 "black-star" airports in the world, and the airspaces of mainland China, Africa, South America and the North Sea are listed as the most treacherous, according to the International Federation of Air Line Pilots Association (IFALPA) in Montreal.

The IFALPA said the 15 blacklisted airports, which also include Kabul in Afghanistan, Rio Negro and San Andres in Colombia, Maiquetia in Venezuela and Oslo in Norway, are the most dangerous airports in the world, according to mass-circulation newspaper The Australian.

The IFALPA report also identified airspaces considered to be the most treacherous in the world -- thousands of square kilometers in Africa, mainland China and South America. The North Sea between Britain and Scandinavia is also given a black star for airspace below 10,000 feet because of the vast amount of civil and military traffic there.

"If airports and airspaces are listed, it means they have serious deficiencies, not that they are unsafe," said the executive director of the association, which represents 115,000 pilots throughout the world.
"They are potential dangers, but there are potential dangers when you get into any plane," he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: `ORGASM PILL' FOR WOMEN UNDER TEST BY THREE COMPANIES

TEXT.P: The pharmaceutical giant Pfizer and two other firms are conducting a series of tests in a bid to produce what has been dubbed and "orgasm pill" for women after the astounding success of "Viagra" -- a drug for increasing sexual capability in men.
Pfizer, which has had huge success in the United States with the recent release of Viagra, has been conducting secret clinical trials on an "orgasm drug" aimed at women.

In a dispatch from London, the Australian Associated Press reported that Pfizer is investigating three different formulations of an active ingredient of Viagra in trials among 500 women throughout Europe.
In at least one trial, women reported an increase in the number of times they made love to their husbands.
Two other drug companies -- Zonagen of Europe and Abbot Laboratories of the US -- are also conducting trials on similar drugs for women.

DOC.HEADLINE: SHARE PRICES DOWN ON TAIEX

TEXT.P: Share prices opened low and closed even lower on the Taipei Stock Market (TAIEX) on Monday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, decreasing 45.46 points to close at 7,591.27.
The bourse opened at 7,601.31, and experienced a low of 7,574.49 and a high of 7,645.39.
Dealers said the market was affected by the depreciation of both the Japanese yen and the new Taiwan dollar, causing heavy selling pressure.
Losers outnumbered gainers by 281 to 158, with 50 issues remaining unchanged.
A total of 1.93 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$98.91 billion.

All of the eight major categories lost ground, with construction stocks moving down the most at 1.5 percent, followed by bank and insurance shares at 1.4 percent, both pulp and paper issues and plastics and chemical stocks at 0.6 percent, foodstuff shares at 0.5 percent, textile issues at 0.4 percent, and both cement stocks and electrical shares at 0.1 percent.

The 10 listed companies enjoying the largest turnovers in Monday's session were: Ever Fortune Industries; ASE; China Manmade Fibers; Kinpo Electronics; Picvue Electronics; Mosel Vitelic Inc.; Liton Electronic; Orient Semiconductor Electronics; Chuntex Electronic Co., Ltd.; and Mitac International Corp.

DOC.HEADLINE: JAPAN RESUMES VISA-FREE PRIVILEGES FOR ROC TRANSIT VISITORS

TEXT.P: Under the terms of newly revised immigration laws, Japan on Monday resumed 72-hour visa-free privileges for Republic of China nationals intending to visit a third country via Japan.

The Taipei office of the Japanese Interchange Association (JIA), which represents Japanese interests in Taiwan in the absence of diplomatic ties between the two countries, said the privileges are applicable only to those travelers whose destination is a third country.
Meanwhile, the JIA also began printing Japanese visa stamps directly into ROC passports, a move seen as recognition by Japan of the ROC passport as an official document.

Since switching diplomatic recognition from Taipei to Beijing in 1972, Japan had been issuing separate entry permits to prospective ROC visitors instead of printing visa stamps directly into their passports.
This practice had increased the workload for JIA staff, and with the rapid increase in the number of Taiwan visitors to Japan in recent years, this workload had reached an intolerable level.
In April this year, thanks to strenuous efforts by pro-Taiwan Japanese lawmakers, the Japanese Diet finally passed amendments to Japan's visa regulations.
Under the revised law, Japan now recognizes the validity of ROC passports and authorizes its representative office in Taipei to print visa stamps directly into the passports of ROC applicants.

Since the JIA usually takes only one working day to process visa applications by prospective visitors from Taiwan, the first ROC passports bearing official Japanese visa stamps will be picked up from the JIA office on Tuesday.
More than 800,000 ROC nationals visited Japan in 1997, up nearly 10 percent from a year ago.

DOC.HEADLINE: ANOTHER INFANT SUCCUMBS TO ENTEROVIRUS EPIDEMIC
DOC.DATELINE: Taichung, central Taiwan, June 8 (CNA) (By Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: A seven-month-old baby boy died in the Taichung Veterans General Hospital on Monday, increasing to at least 30 the number of babies and young children to have fallen victim to the enteroviral epidemic currently sweeping Taiwan.
The child, who had remained in a coma since being admitted to the hospital on May 18, died of massive organ failure and other symptoms of enterovirus infection, hospital staff said.

On Saturday, a seven-month-old baby girl also succumbed to the infection and died in the same hospital, although pediatricians suspected that this baby was killed by an enteroviral mutant not previously seen during the current epidemic, because she did not develop the symptoms typical of an enteroviral infection, such as blisters or a skin rash.

In Taipei County, where the situation up till now has been less serious than in the counties of central Taiwan, a public kindergarten in Yungho City on Monday announced a week-long closure of its classes for children aged 2-4 after seven children were found to have been infected.

With some 130 children currently under intensive hospital monitoring in critical condition, the reported number of infected children visiting hospitals for treatment was nearing 10,000 as of Monday, although it is estimated that as many as 200,000-300,000 infants and children have been infected by the epidemic islandwide.

As the group of enteroviruses -- including type 71 and coxsackievirus -- responsible for the epidemic are usually more active during the summer months, they are expected to affect more children aged under three before September.

Amid rising panic islandwide among families with babies and young children, three epidemiologists from the US Center for Disease Control & Prevention arrived in Taiwan on Saturday at the invitation of the ROC government to help try to arrest the spread of the epidemic.

DOC.HEADLINE: NT DOLLAR PLUNGES

TEXT.P: The new Taiwan dollar plunged NT$0.281 on Monday, the largest single-day drop since January, to close at 34.697 on the Taipei foreign exchange market.

The figure, a new record low for the past 11 years, was attributed to the Japanese yen's collapse through the 140 barrier against the US dollar, Taiwan's continuing export decline, and unusually strong demand for the greenback in Monday's trading session, dealers said.
The local currency opened at the day's high of 34.416, and had a low of 34.75, showing a violent 0.33 fluctuation.
Interbank US dollar trading reached US$476 million.

Regarding the fierce depreciation, Central Bank of China Governor Peng Fai-nan said the bank is drawing up urgent measures to arrest the fall. However, he added that it will not interfere unless trading proceeds "abnormally."

DOC.HEADLINE: TASK FORCE TO VISIT FRANCE TO INVESTIGATE RAPE ALLEGATIONS

TEXT.P: A task force set up by the Ministry of Justice to probe rape allegations against acting Director of the Investigation Bureau Cheng Chuan, will send a team of officials to France to probe the case further, Vice Justice Minister Chiang Hao said on Monday.

In order to avoid violating the jurisdiction of the host country, Chiang, head of the task force, said the bureau will send a number of anti-corruption and personnel officials to investigate the alleged incident, rather than dispatching a team of police officials.

Meanwhile, National Assembly Deputy Lai Ching-lin of the opposition Democratic Progressive Party, who called a news conference to raise the allegations against Cheng on Saturday, released the contents of a tape as further evidence to back his charges.
In the tape, Lai's friend, surnamed Yang, accused Cheng of attempting to rape his daughter, then 20, on Sept. 13, 1996 at a Paris hotel where he was staying while on official business.

Yang's wife and daughter were visiting Cheng, a former family friend, at his hotel, when Cheng made an excuse in order to induce the mother to leave the hotel on an errand. While she was gone, he attempted to rape the daughter, and was only stopped when Yang's wife returned unexpectedly.
The girl has been reported to have suffered mental problems since the alleged offense occurred.

Yang went on to say that he immediately reported the case to French police later on the same day and has since stopped all contact with Cheng. He expressed the hope that Lai will help him seek justice for his daughter and said that "scum" like Cheng does not deserve his official position.

Over the past two days, Lai has produced a medical checkup certificate for the girl issued by a French hospital, and the complaint form filed at the time with French police, as well as letters of petition sent by the victim to the Presidential Office, the Executive Yuan, and the Control Yuan in search of justice.

Cheng has so far declined to make any comment regarding the incident, saying only that he will wait for the task force to bring its findings back from France and that he is willing to be summoned by the Justice Ministry for questioning.

DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER SIEW CALLS LUNCH MEETING ON CURRENCY, STOCK ISSUES

TEXT.P: Premier Vincent Siew called a special lunch meeting on Monday to review the latest situation in the domestic currency and stock markets.
Siew was concerned about recent slumps in the local stock prices and the value of the New Taiwan dollar against the US greenback.
The premier exchanged views with relevant officials on feasible ways to restore investor confidence and stabilize the local bourse and the foreign exchange market.

The officials present at the lunch meeting included Central Bank of China (CBC) Governor Peng Hui-nan, Finance Minister Paul Chiu, Economics Minister Wang Chih-kang and P. K. Chiang, chairman of the Council for Economic Planning and Development.
After the meeting, CBC Governor Peng said the central bank will intervene if the domestic foreign exchange market shows signs of abnormal fluctuations.

The NT dollar faced strong selling pressure on Monday because of a further weakening of the Japanese yen. The NT dollar sank below NT$34.5 against the greenback level soon after market opening and closed at an 11-year low of NT$34.697.

As part of its efforts to stabilize the domestic financial market, the central bank funneled NT$25 billion in postal savings funds on Monday into the capital market through open market operations in an attempt to local interest rates within its target ranges.

Meanwhile, CBC officials called on local people to remain calm and not to feel panic over the temporary market fluctuation. The officials stressed that they see no reasons other than psychological factors for the NT dollar to drop along with the Japanese yen since Taiwan's financial and economic fundamentals are healthier than Japan's.

Economics Ministry officials also said the central bank should intervene to bolster the value of the NT dollar. Some fianncial analysts, however, predicted that the NT dollar will remain weak until the yen stabilizes.

DOC.HEADLINE: EVA PLANE FORCED TO MAKE EMERGENCY LANDING IN MANILA
DOC.DATELINE: Manila, June 8 (CNA) (By Sun Ting-wu & Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: A passenger jet belonging to Taiwan's EVA Airways was forced to make an emergency landing at Manila's Ninoy International Airport on Monday, shortly after taking off from there on a flight to Taipei.
The emergency occurred 20 minutes into flight BR-272 when fire broke out in one of the engines of the Boeing 747 aircraft which was carrying 276 passengers and crew. No casualties were reported.
According to an EVA Airways spokesperson, another aircraft was dispatched to take over the Monday flight service, and was scheduled to take off for Taipei at 7:30 p.m.
Eva Airways currently operates a daily Taipei-Manila flight schedule.

DOC.HEADLINE: MND MUM ABOUT PLANNED JOINT US-MAINLAND CHINA MILITARY DRILL

TEXT.P: The Ministry of National Defense (MND) on Monday declined comments on reports that the United States will conduct joint naval exercises with mainland China for the first time next year.
A military spokesman said the ministry is checking details about the reports. However, he would not elaborate.

MND sources said senior American and mainland military officers have exchanged visits more frequently in recent years. The sources said the US has increased such exchanges mainly because it wants to push mainland China to increase its military transparency and contribute to regional peace and stability.

In fact, the sources said, the United States has conducted joint military exercises with five major Southeast Asian countries in the South Pacific annually. In the past few years, the US has invited mainland military brass to observe such joint military drills.
By so doing, the sources said, the US hopes mainland China will understand its strong military force and deter the Chinese communists from lightly provoking a war in the region.

DOC.HEADLINE: ACTIVISTS TRYING TO LAND ON TIAOYUTAI ISLETS AGAIN

TEXT.P: Chinese Activists from the United States, Hong Kong, and Taiwan are planning to go to Tiaoyutai islets by small fishing boats later this month to proclaim sovereignty over the disputed islets.
Tiaoyutai islets are a group of small uninhabitable islands some 200 kilometers northeast of Taiwan. The small islets in the East China Sea are claimed by Japan, mainland China, and Taiwan.

Disputes over the islets by Japanese and Chinese activists made headlines after Japanese activists built a lighthouse on one of the islets in 1996. Chinese activists from Hong Kong, Taiwan, and the United States landed and put national flags on one of the islets later that year. They were turned back by Japanese maritime patrol boats when they were sailing to the islets on fishing boats last summer.

The activists are planning to sail to the islets again on June 24 to claim sovereignty over them, one of the activists said, adding that they will tear up a wooden Japanese national flag on one of the islets, if they can land on the islet successfully.
To ensure a successful landing, some of the activists practiced landing on a small islet off northern Taiwan coast Monday.

DOC.HEADLINE: YANG SHIH-CHIEN CALLS FOR BIOTECHNOLOGY DEVELOPMENT

TEXT.P: Minister of State Yang Shih-chien on Monday urged Taiwan's major business enterprises to set up investment funds to help promote the biotechnology industry, considered one of the 21st century's most promising high-tech industries.

Yang, who will preside over the second Steering Review Board meeting on biotechnology development strategies on Tuesday, said the Executive Yuan has drafted a plan to promote the industry, and NT$20 billion will be invested in the industry over the next 5 years.

Government promotion measures include development funds from the Council for Economic Planning and Development and the Ministry of Economic Affairs' Medium and Small Business Administration, in addition to funding from the Executive Yuan. Funding from all three groups will provide long-term loans to spur product development within the industry.

In addition to encouraging the private sector to invest in the biotechnology industry, the government is attempting to persuade state-run companies, such as the Taiwan Tobacco & Wine Monopoly Bureau, the Chinese Petroleum Corp. and the Taiwan Sugar Corp. to develop biotechnological products.
The development of a new industry cannot rely solely on governmental planning and promotion; the private business sector's participation will play an important role, said Yang.

The five-day Steering Review Board meeting, to be held at the National Central Library, will focus on such topics as the continued development of Chinese medicine, the establishment of mechanisms to turn biotechnology research into commercial products and the introduction of state-sponsored research projects.

In addition, a round-table meeting will be held in which overseas biotechnology experts and scholars and government officials will meet. Subjects to be discussed include gene research, agricultural biotechnology, biotechnological intellectual property rights and cooperation within the biotechnological industry.

Meeting participants will include such US experts as S. Leslie Microck, an expert in biotechnological intellectual property; Noubar Afeyan, president of Perseptive; Frank Lee, a leading scientist at Millennium; Michael Su, a senior researcher at Vertex; and Lee Shih-hsiung, technical director at Merck.
In addition, a group of Academia Sinica members, including Wang Yi-jiau, Cheng Yung-chi and Wu Tuan, will attend the meeting.
The meeting will end on June 12. Vice Premier Liu Chao-shuan will preside over the closing ceremony.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT TROVOADA OF SAO TOME AND PRINCIPE TO VISIT TAIPEI

TEXT.P: President Miguel Trovoada of Sao Tome and Principe is scheduled to arrive in Taipei on June 16 for a week-long visit.
He will be accompanied during the visit by Foreign Minister Homero Salvaterra and other officials of the country, which is in the Gulf of Guinea in Africa.
While here, Trovoada and other officials of the country will meet with President Lee Teng-hui and other government leaders, and visit cultural and economic establishments.

Foreign Minister Jason Hu visited Trovoada, Salvaterra, and other government leaders of Sao Tome and Principe in February on his trip to Africa. The two countries established diplomatic relations a year ago.

DOC.HEADLINE: AUSTRALIAN GIRL ASKS PUBLIC'S ASSISTANCE IN FINDING BIRTH PARENTS

TEXT.P: An Australian girl of Taiwanese origin on Monday held a press conference to solicit public assistance in locating her birth parents, whom she has not seen since she was 7 months old.
Kartya Elizabeth Wunderie, 17, expressed her strong desire to find her birth parents, saying she has been thinking about them for the past 17 years.

Kartya is believed to be one of 64 Taiwan babies abducted by a criminal ring that operated in Taiwan in the late 1970s and early 1980s. The babies were sold to couples in the United States, Australia, Switzerland and Germany for up to US$5,000 each. The group was broken up in 1982 and its ringleader, Chu Li-ching, was imprisoned.

Accompanied at the conference by her adoptive mother, Nola, Kartya, whose Chinese name is Lin Mei-li, said that if she had been abducted by the ring, her birth parents must have wondered what became of her.
Saying that she dearly loves her adoptive parents, who have raised her as their own, Kartya thanked them for supporting her efforts to find her birth parents.

Nola Wunderie said she and her husband had no idea Kartya had been abducted when they adopted her. Since she was little, though, Kartya has asked who her birth parents were and why she had been given up. The questions have caused Kartya "distress and many problems," her adoptive mother said.
The pair arrived in Taipei Friday and visited the Criminal Investigation Bureau on Saturday to seek its assistance. Blood samples were taken from Kartya at the bureau's laboratory for DNA testing.

After Kartya's story was revealed by the media, prior to her arrival in Taiwan, the bureau received phone calls from some 12 women who say they may be Kartya's birth mothers. So far, however, only three people have come forward and undergone DNA testing, the results of which are still unknown.
Nola and her husband have two biological sons and two adopted daughters.

DOC.HEADLINE: YEAR-END ELECTIONS A PLAY-OFF BETWEEN KMT, DPP: HSU

TEXT.P: The three elections slated for the end of this year will be a play-off between the Kuomintang and the main opposition Democratic Progressive Party, said outgoing DPP Chairman Hsu Hsin-liang on Monday.

"Especially, the results of Taipei and Kaohsiung mayoral elections will be an index indicating which party will be at the helm of the central government," Hsu said at a press conference before he left for a visit to northern Europe.
Hsu's tenure as DPP chairman expires next month. In his last overseas trip as DPP chairman, Hsu is scheduled to visit Riga, Latvia and Helsinki, Finland.

Regarding the elections as "a war of defending its ruling status," the KMT is fielding Professor Ma Ying-jeou, former justice minister and minister without portfolio, as its candidate for Taipei mayor.
Ma has long been considered the KMT's best hope of challenging incumbent Mayor Chen Shui-bian, a member of the DPP.

Neither the KMT nor the DPP is capable of capturing half the seats being contested in the upcoming Legislative Yuan elections, making cooperation between the two parties necessary to avoid political instability, Hsu said.

"If that's the case, then the New Party will be marginalized, as it will no longer be a checking power," Hsu said. The New Party, now Taiwan's second-largest opposition party, was founded by a group of KMT mavericks.

Should the DPP win both the Taipei and Kaohsiung mayoral elections, it will signal "the age of the DPP as Taiwan's ruling party," Hsu said. The party currently controls 12 of Taiwan's 23 county and city governments.
Besides mayoral and legislative elections, elections for Taipei and Kaohsiung city councils will be held on Dec. 5.
Hsu was jailed in 1989 on treason charges but was granted amnesty and released the following year. He was elected DPP chairman in 1990 and again in 1996.
Hsu said that he will speed up preparations for contesting the 2000 presidential election after he steps down as DPP chairman.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHINESE HERBAL MEDICINE EXTRACT FOUND TO SHRINK CANCEROUS TUMORS

TEXT.P: A new drug extracted from Chinese herbal medicine shows promise in battling cancerous tumors and will undergo clinical tests later this year, according to the Ministry of Economic Affairs' Industrial Development Bureau.

The drug, known as Extract U-995, starved tumors in laboratory mice by plugging the capillaries that carry nutrients and oxygen to the tumors. Surrounding healthy cells, however, were not affected by the drug -- a quality unmatched by existing anti-cancer drugs, said IDB officials.

Kuochang Pharmacy developed the drug under the IDB's sponsorship and, with the approval of the Department of Health, tested it on 30 cancer patients who volunteered to take the drug. The patients' tumors shrank significantly after taking the medicine for 10 days, doctors found.
Its effects were particularly noticeable on liver tumors, which are widespread among people in Taiwan, said a Kuochang spokesperson.
Extract U-995 is expected to hit the market in two years, said the IDB.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN'S COMPETITIVENESS NOT WEAKENED BY CURRENCY DECLINES

TEXT.P: Acer Chairman Stan Shih on Monday said the New Taiwan dollar's recent declines will not affect Taiwan's business competitiveness.

Psychological anxiety over the currency's depreciation, rather than fears that Taiwan's economy is in crisis, caused the NT dollar to fall to an 11-year low of 34.697 to the US dollar on Monday, he said.
Declining foreign trade, regarded by local observers as the culprit behind the NT dollar's decline, merely means the island is being impacted by the region's financial meltdown, Shih said.

Shih stressed Taiwan's computer sector has enjoyed a strong competitive edge in international markets, which has contributed to the island's vigorous economic development. This edge will help Taiwan weather the regional crisis, he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN, MALAYSIA VIRAL EPIDEMIC MAY BE RELATED

TEXT.P: The viral epidemic currently sweeping through Taiwan may be related to a contagion that attacked Malaysia last year, US epidemiologists who came to Taiwan to help stop the epidemic's spread said on Monday.

The experts from the US Center for Disease Control and Prevention said that the two waves of epidemic in the two countries have somthings in common including the range of ages of the infected with the virus, the symptoms of the infection and the sudden death of the infected. However, they said that they are still not certain of this.

Enterovirus type-71 has claimed the lives of 30 infants and young children in Taiwan in recent weeks. All the victims developed a fever and a rash with ulcers on their hands, feet and mouths. They died from complications from the virus, including meningitis and encephalitis, shortly after being admitted into hospitals.

It is not known whether this same viral strain was responsible for a viral outbreak in Malaysia last year, as researchers had trouble obtaining bodies for autopsies to determine the exact cause of death.

The epidemiologists -- Anthony Mounts, Umesh Parashar and Hsieh Wen-ju -- warned that mainland China, Indonesia and other Southeast Asian countries may experience similar epidemics in the near future. They did not exclude the possibility that the epidemic may have already spread to those countries without being detected.
The experts, who arrived on Saturday, will remain in Taiwan for up to four weeks. More time is needed for the investigation, they said, especailly since only one child's body was donated for autopsy.

Although ROC health officials have claimed the virus, which typically strikes children under 5 years old, has already reached its peak, they warn that the virus is usually most active during the summer. Recent flooding, brought about by torrential rainfall, could further spread the disease, they said.
As there is no vaccine for the virus, health officials suggest parents keep their children away from public places and make sure the children wash their hands often to reduce the risk of infection.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIEX MOST STABLE IN ASIA

TEXT.P: Taiwan's stock market, or TAIEX, is Asia's most stable market, while South Korea's is the one fluctuating the most, according to reports compiled by the Stock Exchange Hong Kong.

SEHK's report for the month of May shows the TAIEX shed 3.28 percent in May. This is the third-best performance in the region after the Shanghai "A" stock market, which gained 12.51 percent, and the Shenzhen the "A" stock market, which gained 5.16 percent.
The Shanghai and Shenzhen "B" markets, meanwhile, plunged 47.03 percent and 39.51 percent, respectively.
In mainland China, "A" stocks are open exclusively to locals while foreign investors can only buy "B" stocks.

The report also shows that in the past 12 months, the South Korean stock market has declined in value by 56.13 percent, while Kuala Lumpur's market followed closely behind, losing 51.28 percent of its value.
Other loses by Asian markets include Thailand, which lost 43.51 percent; Jakarta, 39.59 percent; Hong Kong, 39.46 percent; Singapore, 39.24 percent; Manila, 28.40 percent; and Tokyo, 21.91 percent.
Australia and New Zealand turned in a mixed performance, with Australia's market rising 4.03 percent and New Zealand's falling 7.42 percent.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN OLYMPIC COMMITTEE CHIEF MEETS IOC PRESIDENT
DOC.DATELINE: Lausanne, Switzerland, June 8 (CNA) (By Wei Su & Lin Wen-fen)

TEXT.P: A visiting official in charge of Olympic affairs in Taiwan met with Juan Antonio Samaranch, president of the International Olympic Committee on Monday.

Huang Da-chou, chairman of the Chinese-Taipei Olympic Committee, reported to Samaranch on his committee's progress. He also told the IOC chief that Taiwan will send a team comprising 141 athletes to take part in the first international youth games in Moscow in June and that a team of more than 200 athletes will compete in the year-end Asia Olympic Games.
Saying he was glad that Taiwan can send so many athletes to attend international games, Samaranch hopes Taiwan will fare well in the competitions.
Samaranch also expressed concern over gymnastics exchanges between Taiwan and mainland China, adding that he is willing to help promote cross-strait gymnastics exchanges.
Huang invited the IOC head to visit Taiwan again, and Samaranch said that, time permitting, he would like to visit the island by year's end.

DOC.HEADLINE: SHARE PRICES DOWN ON TAIEX

TEXT.P: Share prices stumbled on the Taiwan Stock Exchange Tuesday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, dropping 135.64 points to finish at 7455.63.
The bourse opened at the day's high of 7607.58 and closed at the day's low of 7455.63.
Losers outnumbered gainers 390 to 72, with 28 remaining unchanged. In all, 1.80 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$95.64 billion (US$2.77 billion).

Financial shares dropped the most at 2.4 percent, followed by plastic and chemical shares at 2.3 percent; textile issues at 1.9 percent; both paper and stock stocks and electrical engineering shares at 1.6 percent; foodstuff shares at 0.2 percent; ant cement stocks at 0.8 percent.

DOC.HEADLINE: WOMEN NEED LOVE, NOT AN ORGASM PILL

TEXT.P: Love is what women need -- not an orgasm pill, the New York Daily News reported Monday.
That was the consensus Sunday as women reacted to word that the makers of Viagra, the male anti-impotency pill, and their rivals were racing to perfect a pill that would help women climax.
"I mean, if you're not in love, you're not in the mood," said 18-year-old Elizabeth Jose of Manhattan.
"If you need a pill to have an orgasm, then maybe you shouldn't be doing it," added her sister Keyla, 20.
Li-Mai Cooper, 24, of Plainfield, N.J., wondered whether the proposed pill would make men obsolete as she paused from wheeling her year-old son, Kai-san.
"I still don't understand how it could work if a woman isn't into it," Cooper said.
But 22-year-old Mari Potter of Kew Gardens, Queens, said she had no objections to an orgasm pill, hastening to add, "I don't have that problem."
"But if a woman ... does, why not take something to help make her sex life better?" Potter said.
Her husband of five years, Eric, 26, agreed. "A person whose sex life is not spicy wouldn't be romantic anyway," he said.
Fortysomething Jill of Vancouver begged to differ.
"A man would say that," Jill said as she shopped with her girlfriends. "You need the love and romance first."

Jill's 31-year-old pal, who asked not to be named, said "sex should be natural.... You shouldn't have to take a pill for that." The shyest member of the group said she'll leave the chemical climaxing to the Americans.
"We're from Canada," she said. "We're not into that."

Viagra works by increasing blood flow to the erectile tissues allowing previously impotent men to have an erection. Pfizer Inc., the makers of the drug, believe a variation of what is good for the gander may be good for the goose.
Pfizer is already conducting trials in Europe and has been encouraged by early results.

DOC.HEADLINE: EIGHT SOUTHEAST EUROPEAN COUNTRIES MEET IN ISTANBUL

TEXT.P: Foreign ministers and deputy ministers from eight southeast European countries gathered for a two-day meeting in Istanbul, Turkey on Monday.
The eight represented countries are Albania, Bulgaria, Greece, Bosnia-Herzegovina, Croatia, Macedonia, Romania and the Federal Republic of Yugoslavia.
The meeting, hosted by Turkey's Foreign Minister Ismail Cem, will touch on issues which include regional cooperation initiatives and the enhancement of political cooperation.

The topic of main concern was the unfolding tragedy currently taking place in Kosovo where residents of this Albanian province are fleeing in fear for their lives, Turkish Foreign Ministry officials said.

Foreign Minister Cem said in his opening statement that the countries of Europe should have all drawn appropriate lessons from the bitter experience of Bosnia to help prevent the recurrence of such a large-scale tragedy. Yet leaders are allowing such violence against humanity to happen and continue.

Cem called for enhanced cooperation and integration mechanisms in southeastern Europe as soon as possible to find a "durable and effective solution" to the problems which have persisted among the countries of the region.

DOC.HEADLINE: SINGAPORE TO FOSTER COMPETITION IN FINANCIAL SECTOR

TEXT.P: Singapore aims to concurrently open up its financial sector to greater foreign competition and strengthen its local banks, Singapore's Deputy Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong said Monday.
He made the statement in a keynote address as chairman of the Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) at the 25th anniversary dinner of the Association of Banks in Singapore (ABS).
Lee outlined five areas where the MAS will be taking action over the next few months.
Firstly, he said, the MAS will raise Singapore's bank disclosure norms to international standards.

Local banks should stop the current practice of maintaining hidden reserves. They should disclose the market value of their investments and the level of their non-performing loans, as well as past and future provisions.
These new accounting practices are consistent with international standards and the global trend toward greater transparency in both the banking and corporate sectors.

As Singapore banks are well-capitalized and financially strong, clearer disclosure should strengthen market confidence in them, Lee said. Better disclosure and market scrutiny will also put banks under pressure to operate efficiently and deploy resources to uses which yield the highest risk-adjusted returns. This discipline will sharpen their competitive edge.
Secondly, the MAS will adopt a risk-focused approach to its examination of banks. It will inspect the banks more frequently and regularly, ideally at least once every two years, he said.

More frequent inspections will enable the MAS to distinguish stronger banks with well-developed systems of internal control from weaker ones. The MAS can then give more flexibility to the stronger banks while maintaining stricter controls on the weaker ones.
The MAS will start to implement this new approach to bank inspection this year, he said.

Thirdly, the MAS will lower banks' minimum cash balance (MCB) from 6 percent to 3 percent. This is part of the MAS' effort to align its prudential stipulations with the best of international practice.

Banks in Singapore have been required to maintain an MCB with the MAS of 6 percent of their liabilities base with their domestic banking units, and minimum liquid assets (MLA) of 18 percent of their liabilities base. The purpose is to ensure that banks maintain adequate cash and liquid reserves to meet any sudden withdrawals by depositors.

Fourth, the MAS will progressively open up Singapore's financial sector to greater foreign competition. It will create a more level playing field for local and foreign institutions in the banking, securities and insurance sectors.
Lee said the fifth policy is to develop strong local banks. "While we open up the financial sector to greater competition, we should also build up our domestic institutions," he said.
Lee pointed out that a more competitive environment is critical to Singapore's further development as an international financial center.

Greater participation by strong foreign financial institutions can bring new technology, management expertise and financial innovation; attract more international investors; and help local institutions upgrade their services and become more efficient.
Lee said the ferment in the global banking industry brings fresh surprises almost daily. The end game is impossible to forecast.
"But one thing is certain, our banks will face ever-growing competitive pressures," he said.
"Now is the time -- when we are in a position of strength and have the luxury of choice -- to start thinking and preparing how to meet this competitive challenge.
"If we do this right, we will be well-positioned to become the premier banking center in Asia," he concluded.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC TO SEEK MAI OBSERVER STATUS: MINISTER

TEXT.P: Taiwan will apply to join the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development's (OECD) Multilateral Agreement on Investment (MAI) as an observer, Economic Affairs Minister Wang Chih-kang said on Wednesday.

It is hoped that by joining the MAI, touted as an agreement which will open doors around the world for investors, Taiwan will solicit more foreign investment into the island and acquire sufficient protection for its overseas investment as well as business and trade interests abroad, Wang noted.
The MAI was initiated in 1996, but is only this year expected to come into effect as major OECD member-states have been divided on some key points.

Relevant officials from the Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) who have studied and evaluated the MAI's possible impact on Taiwan's future financial and economic development, said Taiwan will benefit more by joining the MAI than not.

By signing the MAI, Taiwan will directly declare itself a liberalized and globalized economy which is conducive to attracting more foreign investment to the island. This will accelerate the adjustment of the domestic economic structure and raise Taiwan's international competitiveness, the officials noted.
According to the latest United Nations World Investment Atlas, as of the end of 1996, Taiwan is the world's 17th largest capital source in terms of overseas investments.
If Taiwan joins the MAI, the officials continued, local businessmen can take advantage of the agreement's international arbitration body to settle disputes for those with investments abroad.
Taiwan will also be entitled to equal treatment as other signatory members and the privileges of the most-favored treatment if it joins the MAI, they added.

The 29-member OECD, also known as "the rich men's club," acts as a think tank for rich industrial nations. Its recommendations are not binding but can play a role in shaping its members' economic policies. Taiwan became an OECD dialogue partner a few years ago.

DOC.HEADLINE: PENTAGON DENIES REPORT OF US-PRC NAVAL DRILL
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, June 9 (CNA) (By Jay Chen and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: The US Department of Defense on Tuesday denied a Hong Kong newspaper report that the United States will hold a joint naval exercise with communist China next year.

Nevertheless, the Pentagon confirmed that Beijing has accepted a US invitation to send observers to a Pacific Rim naval drill in Hawaii and an air superiority exercise in Alaska to be held this summer.
The Hong Kong Standard reported on Monday that the United States and mainland China will for the first time conduct a joint naval drill in 1999.
"Hong Kong press reports on this issue are spurious," a Pentagon official said in a telephone press briefing.
In the past, the official said, the United States and Hong Kong conducted joint search and rescue exercises, call SAREX.

The most recent SAREX was after Hong Kong's reversion to Beijing and was held on Dec. 2-5, 1997, the official said, adding that the Hong Kong Civil Aviation Department and US Air Force and Coast Guard personnel from the Joint Rescue Coordination Center in Honolulu took part in that drill in Hong Kong.
"Another SAREX is scheduled to take place in December this year," the official added.
As to the reported joint exercise with mainland China, the official said the Pentagon does not have any such plan at the moment.
Meanwhile, the official said the commander-in-chief of the US Pacific Fleet has invited mainland military brass to observe Exercise Rim of the Pacific (RIMPAC) '98 in Hawaii.
RIMPAC '98 is a joint naval exercise involving eight countries, including the US and Japan, the official explained.

The commander of the US Pacific Air Forces has also invited Beijing to send observers to Cooperative Cope Thunder '98, an air superiority exercise to be held in Alaska, the official said, adding that the invitations are a gesture designed to upgrade military transparency of the two countries.
With relations between Washington and Beijing improving, the official said, the Pentagon looks forward to increasing exchanges or engagements with mainland military.

"By so doing, we hope to boost mutual understanding and minimize the risk of any military conflict in the Asia-Pacific region," he noted, adding Beijing's consent to send observers to the two exercises indicates that the Pentagon's efforts have paid off.

DOC.HEADLINE: CAA REJECTS CAL'S APPLICATION FOR NEW FLIGHTS

TEXT.P: The Civil Aeronautics Administration (CAA) recently rejected China Airlines' (CAL) application to ply two new flight routes on the basis of flight safety.
CAA Acting Director-General Chang Chia-chu said CAL will not be granted permission to expand its fleets or fly new routes until an improvement is seen in its current efforts to boost flight safety.
Chang stressed CAL's current priority is flight safety.
CAL had planned to launch flight service between Taipei and Hanoi, Vietnam, as well as a domestic flight from Hsinchu in northern Taiwan to the island's southern city of Kaohsiung.

CAL, the Republic of China's former flag-carrier, was widely criticized for its operations particularly after an Airbus A300 crashed in a failed landing attempt at Chiang Kai-shek International Airport on Feb. 16, killing all 196 people onboard and six others on the ground.
The disaster was the second for CAL in less than four years. Another A300 crashed at Japan's Nagoya airport on April 26, 1994, killing 264 of the 271 aboard.

Meanwhile, the CAA has drafted a bill which would impose penalties on airlines if they are found at fault in a serious air accident causing death. These include a year-long ban on new international passenger flight service, Chang said.

DOC.HEADLINE: CROSS-STRAIT TALKS MAY TAKE PLACE NEXT SPRING

TEXT.P: Taiwan's top negotiator with mainland China said on Wednesday that it is reasonable to assess that both sides of the Taiwan Strait could resume talks next spring.

But C.F. Koo, chairman of the semi-official Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF), did not rule out a visit to the mainland sometime this year for talks with his counterpart, Wang Daohan, chairman of the Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait (ARATS).
Koo was responding to a recent letter from the ARATS which reaffirmed its welcome to a visit to the mainland by Koo.

The landmark Koo-Wang talks which took place in Singapore in 1993 established a framework for regular dialogue between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait, but this dialogue was disrupted in 1995 after President Lee Teng-hui's visit to the United States in June of that year. Beijing believes that the trip was a veiled attempt to solicit support for Taiwan independence.
Koo said that the timing of his trip will have to wait for reaffirmation by Shi Hwei-yow, the SEF secretary-general.

He also said that the SEF has invited an ARATS deputy secretary-general to visit Taiwan to exchange views on a resumption of talks. Should this official decline to come, the SEF will not rule out inviting Tang Shubei, ARATS vice chairman, to come to Taiwan to discuss the matter, he added.

Noting that the SEF and ARATS reached some consensus in preparatory talks in April, Shi said the SEF will arrange for groups to visit the mainland to step up exchanges, following the visit to Beijing in late June by US President Bill Clinton, and in advance of the Koo-Wang talks.
He said that these groups will comprise senior reporters, Taiwan businessmen, notaries, and crime crackdown specialists, and that they will travel to the mainland in July or August.

Following the recent arrest of four Taiwan businessmen on charges of espionage in the mainland, Shi said that personal safety and the rights of Taiwan investors will be given top priority in the cross-strait dialogue.

DOC.HEADLINE: CLINTON DEFENDS PLAN TO APPEAR IN TIANANMEN SQUARE WELCOMING CEREMONY
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, June 9 (CNA) (By Nelson Chung & Eva Chen)

TEXT.P: US President Bill Clinton insisted on Tuesday that observing mainland China's diplomatic etiquette and accepting a welcoming ceremony that Beijing authorities plan to hold in Tiananmen Square will not ruin his ability to promote the principles that the American people cherish most.

Clinton said that as he is visiting mainland China at the invitation of Beijing, it is Beijing's responsibility to arrange a welcoming ceremony, and it would not be proper to propose his own conditions for such a ceremony. Clinton made the remarks at a joint news conference with South Korean President Kim Dae-Jung.

In view of the recent Asian financial turmoil and the nuclear testing on the Indian subcontinent, it is more crucial than ever for the US to establish a constructive, positive relationship with mainland China, added Clinton.

Beijing also wants to improve this relationship, Clinton said, which is why the Beijing authorities are being far more tolerant of different political opinions than before. He pointed out that several dissidents have been released since mainland Chinese president Jiang Zemin visited the US last year, but he stressed that his trip to the mainland will give him the opportunity to express categorically the views of the American people regarding human rights.

DOC.HEADLINE: ACTIVISTS TO LAUNCH ANOTHER ATTEMPT TO LAND ON DISPUTED ISLANDS

TEXT.P: Several activists said on Wednesday that they will make another attempt later this month to land on the disputed Tiaoyutai islands in the East China Sea to highlight the Republic of China's claims to the islands.

Taipei County Councilor Chin Chieh-shou made the remarks when he and the group of activists went to the suburban residence of Shintaro Yamashita, Taipei's director of the Japan's Interchange Association, the de facto Japanese embassy here.

Yamashita had already left for work and the activists did not meet him, but Chin, convenor of Taiwan's task force to protect the Tiaoyutais, said that he had already faxed a statement to the association's Taipei office.
Chin said that wanted to inform Yamashita that Chinese around the world will launch another attempt to land on the Tiaoyutais, known in Japan as the Senkaku islands, on June 21.
Chin urged the Japanese side to impose "self-restraint," warning that the task force will adopt "necessary measures" in order to avoid potential grave consequences.

Chin also said that the Tiaoyutais are ROC territory, and pointed out that the Japanese government's claim to the islands, its dispersal of Taiwan fishing boats, and its beating of fishermen, have led to resentment among Taiwan fishermen.
To avoid clashes between the two nations, Chin expressed the hope that the Japanese government will stop taking improper action against Taiwan fishing boats and fishermen.

The disputed islands lie about 200 kilometers northeast of Taiwan and 300 kilometers west of the Japanese island of Okinawa. Japan was given control of the islands in 1972 by the United States, which had administered the islands along with Okinawa since the end of World War II.

DOC.HEADLINE: HEART DRUG WITHDRAWN FROM MARKET

TEXT.P: Less than a year after it was approved by the US Food and Drug Administration (FDA), the heart drug Posicor was taken off the market in 38 countries Monday amid mounting evidence that it is dangerous and possibly lethal when used in combination with other drugs.

According to The New York Times Tuesday, the drug, made by Roche Laboratories of Nutley, N.J., is used to treat high blood pressure and the chest pains known as angina, particularly among the elderly. It has been used by 400,000 people worldwide, including 200,000 in the United States.

FDA officials have long known that the drug did not mix well with certain other medications. However, over the last few months, the list of drugs that cause toxic interactions with Posicor grew so long officials asked Roche, a subsidiary of Roche Holdings, to withdraw it from the market.
The list of drugs, 26 in all, includes such common medication such as antihistamines, antibiotics, cholesterol-lowering drugs and the cancer-fighting drug tamoxifen.
Both the FDA and Roche urged patients who are taking Posicor not to stop taking the drug but rather to consult their doctors to find an alternative therapy.
It is extremely rare for the FDA, which is widely regarded as being extremely safety-conscious, to withdraw a drug once it has been approved, the Times said.

Posicor, which is part of a class of medications known as calcium channel-blockers, inhibits certain liver enzymes that enable the body to eliminate other drugs. When the enzyme is not active, those other drugs can build to toxic levels.

The FDA has been monitoring Posicor since it went on the market last July and has received dozens of reports of adverse side effects when it is taken in combination with other drugs. Symptoms include dangerously low heart rate, irregular heart beat and a breakdown of muscle that can cause permanent damage to the kidneys.

There have been 24 reported deaths of patients taking Posicor, but it is unknown whether they were caused by the drug. FDA officials believe two or three deaths could be directly attributed to the drug taken in combination with other medication.

DOC.HEADLINE: BEER OEM BIDDING REQUIREMENTS TO BE ANNOUNCED

TEXT.P: The Taiwan Tobacco and Wine Monopoly Bureau will announce in a few days the bidding requirements for foreign beer companies interested in producing their beer locally at the bureau's Chunghsin plant, Bureau Deputy Director Chen Wen-kai said Tuesday.

The bureau has already drawn up the bidding requirements for the original equipment manufacturing (OEM) of a foreign beer product, he said, adding that several companies have contacted the bureau expressing interest in the cooperative project.

The government-run enterprise is looking for a beer company that is both well-known abroad and well-established in Taiwan, with a proven domestic sales record and leading market share, Chen said. The final choice for a partner will be decided by a bureau task force according to established standards and requirements.

Domestic food companies interested in the venture cannot be accepted as valid bidders because according to a draft law currently under deliberation, only manufacturers are valid bidders. Since the bureau has a monopoly over beer manufacturing in Taiwan, only foreign companies are eligible, Chen said.

Explaining that beer is 90 percent water and freshness is vital to the product's quality, Chen said that local production will help guarantee product freshness and reduce shipping costs normally involved with imported beer -- incentives for the foreign companies to take advantage of this cooperative arrangement.

A stipulation attached to the offer is that the foreign company cannot continue to import the beer it will be manufacturing in Taiwan. To simplify the process, the company will also provide its own raw materials, and the bureau will be responsible for only production, not sales.

Chen pointed out that the beer market is open, and no one product will be able to dominate the entire market. By producing beer for another company, the bureau is mainly interested in fully utilizing its current manufacturing capacity and in promoting constructive competition among foreign manufacturers, he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: SHARE PRICES PLUNGE ON TAIEX

TEXT.P: Share prices plunged 3.1 percent on the local stock market in Wednesday's trading following the continuing fall of the local currency to an 11-year low.
The Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) weighted price index, the market's key barometer, moved down sharply by 232.5 points, to close at the day's low of 7,223.13.
"Quiet, weak buying is dominating the market, as no incentive has been offered to boost trading," stock analyzers said.
Most heavyweight shares in the industrial sectors suffered heavy losses during the three-hour session, they added.
The bourse opened at 7,377.05 and reached the day's high of 7,422.65 before falling again to the day's low of 7,223.13.
Losers overwhelmed gainers 407 to 46, with 35 shares remaining unchanged.
In all, 2.1 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$103.27 billion (US$2.96 billion), up from the NT$95.57 billion turnover of the previous day's trading session.
All eight major stock categories fell, with plastic and chemical shares plunging 4.5 percent, the heaviest loss of the day.

Textile issues fell 3.8 percent, followed by technology stocks at 3.6 percent, financial shares at 3.1 percent, paper-making stocks at 2.9 percent, cement issues at 2.5 percent, construction shares at 1.2 percent, and foodstuff stocks at 0.4 percent.
The New Taiwan dollar devalued to an 11-year low of 34.887 against the greenback in the morning session, a 0.5 percent fall in comparison with the previous session's close at 34.715.

DOC.HEADLINE: TIBETAN BUDDHISTS PLEA FOR RELEASE OF THEIR PANCHEN LAMA

TEXT.P: Tibetan Buddhist leaders in India and abroad have launched a worldwide campaign to pressure Beijing into releasing the reincarnation of the 10th Panchen Lama who is being held somewhere in the mainland.

The "Free Gedhun Campaign" refers to Gedhun Choekyi Nyima who was declared the 11th Panchen Lama by the Dalai Lama on May 14, 1996. Shortly afterward, Beijing declared another boy was the "official" Panchen Lama and has held Gedhun in custody since then.

The campaign is gaining momentum in Southeast Asia as well as the US, Europe, Canada and Australia, officials from the Dalai Lama's official headquarters in Himachal Pradesh told the Daily News, a Sri Lanka-based English daily.

As a part of the campaign, world bodies such as the United Nations are being asked to demand the release of the eight-year old boy, and to allow him to function as the 11th Panchen Lama of the Tibetan Order.
As an indication that the campaign has gained international support, the Brussels-based European Parliament launched a massive signature collection drive to pressure Beijing into releasing Gedhun.

Born on April 25, 1989, Gedhun is considered the true reincarnation of Panchen Rimpoche who was the 10th Panchen Lama of Tibet. After the death of Panchen Rimpoche, the Dalai Lama received 30 names of possible reincarnations of Panchen Rimpoche from Tibet and other parts of the world. In 1991, a divination was performed by the Dalai Lama followed by another in 1993.

Subsequently, a team of lamas traveled Tibet and the world to search for and identify the reincarnated Panchen Rimpoche. The search ended in January 1995 when Gedhun Choekyi Nyima was picked as the reincarnated Panchen Rimpoche.

After Gedhun was crowned as the 11th Panchen Lama, the Dalai Lama asked Beijing to recognize him as the "true and only religious leader of Tibetan Buddhists." Beijing instead named their own Panchen Lama and asked Tibetans to accept their nominee, Gyalsen, as the true Panchen Lama.
Beijing, bowing to UN pressure, recently disclosed that Gedhun was "safe and in its custody".

DOC.HEADLINE: NT DOLLAR DOWN

TEXT.P: The New Taiwan dollar sharply fell NT$0.181 against the greenback on Wednesday, closing at NT$34.896.
The local currency opened at 34.703, and once moved down through the 35 barrier to the lowest 35.149 of the day before climbing up. It had a high of 34.681.
The interbank US dollar trading reached 548 million.

DOC.HEADLINE: US HOUSE DEMANDS BEIJING TO RENOUNCE USE OF FORCE AGAINST TAIWAN
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, June 9 (CNA) (By Jay Chen and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: The US House of Representatives passed a concurrent resolution with a unanimous 411-0 vote on Friday, demanding Beijing to renounce the use of force against Taiwan.
The resolution acknowledges Taiwan's desire to play a positive role in the current Asian financial crisis and reaffirms the support of the American people for Taiwan's security.

It also expresses the sense of the Congress that President Bill Clinton should seek from mainland authorities, at the summit meeting in Beijing later this month, a public renunciation of the use of force or the threat of the use of force against Taiwan.

The non-binding resolution further demands the US government abide by all previous understandings of a "one China" policy and maintain its interest in a peaceful resolution of the Taiwan Strait issue.

Before the resolution was put to the vote, Chairman Benjamin Gilman (R-NY) of the House Committee on International Relations said Taiwan has played a pivotal role in regional prosperity and stability.

"But this prosperity and stability can be threatened. We need only to look back to the ominous period in the spring of '96, when Chinese M-9 missiles flew across the Strait of Taiwan into international air and sea lanes in a heavy-handed attempt by Beijing to threaten the first democratic elections in 5000 years of Chinese history," Gilman said.

That sort of missile diplomacy on the part of communist China is unacceptable and it is appropriate that the Congress calls on Beijing to renounce the use of force in settling the Taiwan Strait issue, the influential congressional leader stressed.

Gilman further said: "I want to state my firm belief that the issue of one China must be settled peacefully and first and foremost by the Chinese people on both sides of the Strait of Taiwan, not by one side dictating terms to the other through missile diplomacy or otherwise..."

Speaking on the same occasion, Rep. Gerald Solomon (R-NY), who introduced the resolution on April 30, said: "As the author of this simple resolution, let me just say that it is necessary because of the continuing belligerent attitude of the Communist Chinese toward our great friends, the people of Taiwan, our strongest allies in the history of this nation."

Solomon pointed out that Communist China has repeatedly and brazenly refused to renounce the potential use of military force to resolve its dispute with Taiwan."And it has shown on more than one occasion that it is willing to intimidate Taiwan with military force."

Meanwhile, Rep. Doug Bereuter (R-NE), chairman of the Subcommittee on Asia and the Pacific, said while it is true only the Chinese on both sides of the Taiwan Strait can determine their future, "the United States must continue to play a role in ensuring the peace and stability of the region."

The resolution notes that Clinton will visit mainland China on June 25-July 3 to discuss the common interests of the two countries and that the American people desire strong relations with the people on both sides of the Taiwan Strait.

The resolution also affirms that it is an established US policy to take all necessary action to ensure peace and stability on the Taiwan Strait, while continuing mutually beneficial trade relations with Taiwan's vibrant economy.

DOC.HEADLINE: AUSTRALIA THREATENS ACTION OVER JAPAN'S FISHING PROGRAM

TEXT.P: Australia may take Japan to the International Court of Justice over its experimental tuna fishing program, which contravenes an international agreement, if Japan goes ahead with the program.
Resources and Energy Minister Warwick Parer said the Australian government "is resigned to the fact that Japan will carry out an experimental fishing program," but remains opposed the action.
Australia will maintain a ban on Japanese vessels from using Australian ports until an agreement on quotas is reached in the Commission for the Conservation of Southern Bluefin Tuna (CCSBT).
Japan, Australia and New Zealand are the only three members of the CCSBT, the international management body for the southern bluefin fishery.

CCSBT negotiations are now underway over Japan's demand for an increase in its quota of 6,065 tons. Japan wants to catch an additional 1,400 tons of bluefin tuna for its experimental program in international waters, but both Australia and New Zealand are opposed to that figure.
Greenpeace of Australia has asked Canberra to take the issue to international court because Japan is in breach of an international agreement with its request for an increased quota.

DOC.HEADLINE: SOUTH KOREA ECONOMY SEEN WORSENING

TEXT.P: Thomson Bankwatch, the world's largest bank rating company, has downgraded South Korea's BBB sovereign risk rating outlook from stable to negative as the country's economic outlook appears to be worsening.

The bank rating agency said in a report released Tuesday the impact of the financial crisis on South Korea's real economy is deeper than previously anticipated. The timetable for a turnaround is therefore likely to be further delayed.
Recently released figures of the gross domestic product for the first quarter of this year show that the country's economy contracted by 3.8 percent, more sharply than most forecasts.

The downturn has been made worse by the occurrence of stagflation, as inflation looks set to overtake previous estimates of 6.7 percent, reaching levels of 10 percent or higher by the end of this year, the report added.
The export growth of the country slowed for the first time in five months in May, as Korean exporters started to feel the effects of a steadily weakening Japanese yen and a domestic credit crunch.

Interest rates have been kept high to defend the external value of the Korean won, hampering the ability of local firms to repay their obligations. The report added that the problem has been exacerbated by the high debt-to-equity ratios of Korean firms.
An estimated 20 trillion won (US$14.28 billion) worth of bonds mature during this month alone, the report said.

The country's short-term domestic obligations have been rolled over, but banks are unlikely to put up with this situation for long given their own precarious situation. The government's efforts to recapitalize banks have so far been inadequate.

Reflecting the worsening outlook, the Kospi stock market index fell to a 11-year low during the last week of May. Foreigners are still reluctant to enter Korean markets as it appears likely that the economic downturn will continue through the second and third quarters of this year.

In the midst of the generally depressed economic picture, however, there have been some encouraging developments. South Korea's foreign reserves have steadily risen, quadrupling from US$8.9 billion at the end of last year to US$38.76 billion at the end of May, the report stated.

DOC.HEADLINE: HK, TAIWAN HAVE FREEST MEDIA: POLL
DOC.DATELINE: Hong Kong, June 10 (CNA) (By Stanley Cheung & Deborah Kuo)
