TEXT.P: Taiwan and Hong Kong are the two areas in Asia where journalistic freedom is respected the most among the economies of the region, according to the results released on Wednesday of a public opinion poll of Western business people working in Asia.
The respondents think that among the 11 Asian economies, only Hong Kong, Taiwan, the Philippines and Thailand enjoy journalistic freedom, the poll found.
The poll, conducted by the Hong Kong-based Political and Economic Risk Consultancy Ltd. (PERC), canvassed opinions on media freedom, censorship and quality in countries and areas throughout Asia.
The poll found that according to the respondents, six countries in the region have stepped up news censorship, while only four others have relaxed their press restrictions.

However, the PERC researchers said the respondents' opinions might be biased due to their personal partiality for certain countries or areas. For example, they said, the finding that Taiwan was considered in the survey to have greater press freedom than Japan is probably controversial.

In the survey, the respondents said Hong Kong has the highest-quality mass media workers among all the economies in the region, while Taiwan's media personnel are just mediocre, although they have potential for improvement.

Taking the Asian economic turmoil as an example, the PERC researchers said, the Taiwan media and other Asian media have carried far fewer reports than their Hong Kong counterparts on regional impact and regional points of view.
This insufficient coverage could be one of the major factors in the failure by most countries and areas in the region to cope with the regional crisis, they pointed out.

DOC.HEADLINE: CAA TO ALLOW FOREIGN MECHANICAL ENGINEERS TO WORK HERE

TEXT.P: Foreign aeronautic mechanical and maintenance personnel will soon be able to work in Taiwan under a draft passed on Wednesday by the Civil Aeronautics Administration (CAA).
CAA officials said that the passing of the draft is expected to relieve the problem of a serious shortage of ground mechanics and maintenance personnel for local airlines.

Noting that local airlines are currently bound by law to employ only local people to work as ground mechanics and maintenance workers, they said that if serious personnel shortages occur, the airlines will now be able to employ foreigners to fill the vacancies.
But they said that the total number of foreign employees should not exceed one-fifth of the local employees.

The officials said that the foreign personnel should have good English communication abilities, should possess valid qualifications from their own countries, and should have at least five years of related work experience.
Under the draft, foreign mechanics could work for up to three years in Taiwan, and if necessary could extend their stay for two more years.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAJOR JAPANESE FIRMS SHUN BATTERED AUSSIE DOLLAR

TEXT.P: Major Japanese insurance companies, including Nippon Life, have temporarily stopped investing in Australian-dollar denominated assets such as bonds and stocks despite efforts of senior Australian officials to calm foreign investors.

In a survey conducted by The Australian Financial Review in Tokyo, Nippon Life, Dai-Ichi Mutual, Meiji Mutual, Mitsui Mutual and Sumotomo Mutual have all expressed concern about the foreign exchange rate risks of Australian investment due to depreciation in the country's currency.

The Japanese companies said they are rethinking their Australian portfolio investment strategies because the Australian dollar appears to be continuing to slide against the US dollar and other major currencies, including the German deutsche mark.

The daily quoted Meiji Mutual as saying, "We consider the current situation a phase of global disinflation, and we take a deliberate stance against investment in Australian dollar assets as it is closely linked with the commodities market."

Australia Treasurer Peter Costello and his senior colleagues on Tuesday talked up the Australian dollar, saying the country's economic fundamentals remained good. They also indicated that the Australian dollar was undervalued at its current state.

"Obviously there has been a lot of interest in the Australian dollar over recent weeks and there has been quite a deal of speculation in relation to its levels," Costello said, adding "Quite a lot of that is based on commentary which is not well based. The important thing about the Australian dollar and the Australian economy are the fundamentals, and it's the fundamentals which are going to determine the overall levels of the dollar over the long term as people put aside ill-informed commentary."
Deputy Prime Minister and Trade Minister Tim Fischer said, "In the broader context, I emphasize that we are holding up and weathering the storms out of Asia extraordinarily well."
In a speech in New York, Foreign Minister Alexander Downer said, "It clearly important that in New York, there is an understanding of the strengths of the Australian economy, and I think there is."

The tough comments bolstered the value of the Australian dollar to 60.08 US cents at one stage Tuesday, but it soon dropped to close at 59.87 US cents. The dollar was trading at one point during the day at 59.63 US cents, the lowest level since it fell to 57.10 US cents in July 1986.

Investors were apparently not convinced of the politicians' remarks particularly after seeing the Japanese yen plunge to a seven-year low of 141.25 against the greenback. Japan is Australia's largest trading partner.
The Herald's survey shows Japanese institutions were net sellers of the Australian-dollar denominated securities for eight of the nine months up to March 1998.
Up to March 31 this year, Japanese insurance firms sold 3.9 trillion (US$30.7 billion) Australian securities compared with their purchases of 3.5 trillion, leaving net sales of 372 billion yen.
The Japanese institutions attributed their sales of the Australian securities to lower economic growth and a riskier foreign exchange market down under as a result of the Asian crisis.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT CHAIRMAN CONSIDERS MA BEST CHOICE FOR TAIPEI MAYOR

TEXT.P: The ruling Kuomintang (KMT) on Wednesday formally decided on Ma Ying-jeou, an associate professor at National Chengchi University, as its candidate for the year-end mayoral election in Taipei City.
The decision was made at a KMT Central Standing Committee meeting which approved a suggestion by a KMT election nominees screening committee.

KMT Chairman Lee Teng-hui lauded Ma for his contributions to the upgrading of administrative quality during his terms of office as KMT vice secretary-general, vice chairman of the Research, Development and Evaluation Commission, and vice chairman of the Mainland Affairs Council, as well as his term as justice minister.
According to Lee, Ma is the best candidate for the mayorship of Taipei City, and he urged all party members to render their assistance to help Ma win the election.
KMT Vice Chairman Lien Chan also praised Ma for his education background, ability and public image, and called for all party members to unite and fully support him.

Wu Poh-hsiung, a member of the KMT Central Standing Committee, said the KMT party spirits have been given a hearty boost by Ma's candidacy. He added that he believes that with party support, Ma will win the election.
Chen Chien-chih, speaker of the Taipei City Council, also expressed his confidence that Ma will become mayor of Taipei. He suggested that Ma should start work immediately to court grassroots voters.

The KMT Central Standing Committee meeting also approved the third batch of candidates for the year-end legislative elections, including the names of candidates for Ilan and Taichung counties, and for Taichung, Tainan, and Kaohsiung cities.

The first and second batches of candidates were announced on April 15 and 29, respectively. The KMT has to date fielded a total of 104 candidates to run in 29 election areas, and is expected to name its candidates for Chiayi and Taitung counties in the near future.
The fourth national election to the legislature will be held on December 5 in a total of 31 election districts, in which a total of 176 legislators will be elected.

DOC.HEADLINE: KINMEN COMMAND DENIES CONSULTATION ROLE IN MINE-CLEARING EFFORTS

TEXT.P: A high-level official of the Republic of China's Kinmen Defense Command (KDC) on Wednesday denied being consulted by mainland China before its navy carried out underwater mine-clearing operations in nearby Amoy Bay.

Mainland China announced at the end of April that its navy had completed clearing underwater mines left in Amoy Bay in the wake of the eight-year War of Resistance against Japan which ended with the surrender of Japan in 1945.

Mainland China further stated that the KDC was consulted through the mainland's Red Cross Society and Amoy's Taiwan Affairs Office before the operation began, but the Kinmen official stressed that the claim was "pure fiction."

The Red Cross never contacted the KDC over the mine-clearing operation, the official stated adamantly, adding that in any case, the command was not in a position to make any decisions regarding the issue.

The official pointed out that mine-sweeping is not an offensive military mission, so if mainland China wanted to conduct these operations in its waters, it can "take care of its own business" without having to seek permission from the KDC.

The Kinmen islands, consist of 12 ROC-controlled islets off the southeastern coast of mainland China's Fujian Province, located in a key position in the Taiwan Strait. The shortest distance from the main island of Kinmen to mainland China is only 2,310 meters.

DOC.HEADLINE: HOUSE RESOLUTION TO DETER CLINTON FROM SACRIFICING TAIWAN
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, June 9 (CNA) (By Jay Chen and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: The US House of Representatives' unanimous vote for a concurrent resolution demanding Beijing to renounce the use of force against Taiwan is expected to deter President Bill Clinton from sacrificing Taiwan's interests during his upcoming visit to mainland China, political observers said on Tuesday.

The House passed the non-binding resolution with a unanimous 411-0 vote on Tuesday evening to express the Congress' opinion that Clinton should seek from mainland authorities "a public renunciation of the use of force, or the threat of the use of force, against democratic Taiwan" at the summit meeting in Beijing later this month.

Political analysts said the move not only signifies the Congress' sympathy toward Taiwan, it also indicates that Clinton's June 25-July 3 mainland visit will not lead to any unexpected developments in the Taiwan Strait issue.

Rep. Gerald Solomon (R-NY), the chief architect of the resolution, said on the floor of the House that the resolution is aimed at reminding the Clinton administration not to engage Beijing at Taiwan's expense.

Solomon said the resolution is necessary not only because of Beijing's continuing belligerent attitude toward Taiwan but also because of disturbing trends in the Clinton administration's policy regarding the two sides of the Taiwan Strait.
"President Clinton has had in place a policy of unmitigated appeasement toward communist China for five years now..." Solomon noted.

Even before the House adopted the resolution, political observers said, Taiwan's friends in the US Congress had taken many steps to prevent Clinton from reaching any easy compromise with Beijing over the Taiwan Strait issue.

For instance, the Congress in May invited Stanley Roth, assistant secretary of state for East Asian and Pacific affairs, and several other Clinton administration officials, to testify on Taiwan-related issues. These officials made many promises in favor of Taiwan, including that Clinton will neither sacrifice Taiwan's interests during his summit meeting with mainland President Jiang Zemin in June, nor sign any new joint communique concerning Taiwan.
They also reaffirmed commitments to providing Taiwan with adequate defensive arms and to supporting peaceful resolution of the Taiwan Strait issue.

DOC.HEADLINE: ASIAN TELECOMMUNICATIONS CONFERENCE OPENS IN MANILA

TEXT.P: Some 42 major telecommunications companies, Internet service providers (ISPs) and multimedia software and equipment developers from 10 Asian countries converged on Wednesday at a Manila hotel for a two-day international multimedia conference.

In a speech read for her by Undersecretary Arturo Valdez, Philippine Transportation and Communications Secretary Josefina Lichauco noted that by promoting multimedia awareness among Asians, the forum can help create business opportunities for many Asians.
Lichauco said the launch of several telecommunication satellites in the Asia-Pacific region indicates the region's resolve in developing multimedia in the region.

She said the satellites will enhance many services, such as the Internet, distance learning, and entertainment, into an affordable and accessible method of communication via national global networks, which will have a significant impact on the lives of Asians.
Jun-Icho Miyazu, President of the Asian Multimedia Forum (AMF) welcomed the participants, which include officials and experts from telecommunications companies from all over the region.
During the two-day forum, technical experts will present various state-of-the-art multimedia applications and systems that have been developed for possible commercialization in Asia.
Among the other highlights of the two-day conference and exhibition will be a demonstration of a multimedia link featuring video, audio and data transmission between Tokyo and Manila.

DOC.HEADLINE: CENTRAL BANK GOVERNOR CALLS ON CONTROL YUAN PRESIDENT

TEXT.P: Peng Fai-nan, governor of the Central Bank of China (CBC), on Wednesday paid a courtesy call on Wang Tso-yung, president of the Control Yuan, the ROC government's watchdog body.
Wang had suggested a day earlier that the government should intervene in the foreign exchange market "at the proper time" to restrain speculation, instead of trying to boost the stock market.
He said he supported the measure taken by the CBC to ban corporate trading in non-deliverable forward funds, saying that the move has closed a channel for speculation.
Wang's remarks drew many analyses by the country's ranking economic and financial officials.
Peng is one of Wang's former students from the time when Wang worked as a professor at National Taiwan University.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC WARSHIP COLLIDES WITH PANAMA CARGO SHIP

TEXT.P: An ROC Navy warship had a minor collision with a Panama-registered freight vessel near Kaohsiung Harbor in southern Taiwan on Wednesday.
No casualties were reported, according to navy sources.
The sources said the warship "Huiyang" suffered damage to its bow, while the cargo ship "Hokushin," which was on its way to Japan from Kaohsiung, was virtually unscathed.
The collision took place at 8:04 a.m. local time (00:04 GMT) in heavy seas about 5 nautical miles west northwest of the Tsoying naval base, according to the navy.
Both ships sailed into Kaohsiung Harbor after the accident pending an investigation by the harbor authorities, the sources said.

DOC.HEADLINE: TENTH FOREIGN SCHOOL TO OPEN IN TAIPEI

TEXT.P: The Grace Christian Academy, Taipei's tenth foreign school, is scheduled to open here in August.

The new American school, founded by the Nangang Baptist Bible Church in eastern Taipei, is planning to enroll 120 students, ranging from three kindergarten classes to a class each from first grade to sixth grade. In addition to English, the new school will also offer a 90-minute daily Chinese class to its students.

According to a church spokesman, it was decided to establish a new American school in Taipei due to increased demand from the growing number of American businessmen and missionaries residing in Taiwan.

The church's Taiwan congregation had also expressed the desire for such a school, because some local parents wishing to send their children to study overseas are afraid that their offspring will have difficulty adapting to living abroad, the spokesman added.

The Grace Christian Academy will be the tenth international school in Taipei. The nine other foreign schools, including the Taipei American School, the Taipei English School, the Deutsche Schule Taipei, and the Taipei Japanese School, were all founded years ago.
The announcement of the opening came a day after Premier Vincent Siew attended the inauguration of the Swire European Campus in Yangmingshan, suburban Taipei.
The German, French and British schools, which have all moved to the brand new site, will share the campus, teaching and housing facilities, while retaining their own national curricula.
Addressing the inauguration ceremony, Siew said the event marked a giant step for Taipei in its efforts to develop itself into an international commercial, financial and cultural hub.

The premier also expressed the hope that the European campus will boost exchanges with local schools in a bid to lay the groundwork for greater peace and prosperity for the entire world in the future.

DOC.HEADLINE: WTO URGED TO EXPAND TRADING RULES

TEXT.P: Singapore has urged the World Trade Organization (WTO) to expand its rules to cover new forms of trade, such as cross-border electronic commerce, which have the potential to be worth more than US$300 billion by 2002, according to reports from the Geneva-based WTO on Wednesday.

From the WTO perspective, electronic commerce has significant implications for the traditional notions of cross-border trade, Lee Yock Suan, Singapore's Minister for Trade and Industry, was quoted by the WTO report as saying.

"As national borders disappear in cyberspace, the relevance of existing rules on cross-border trade comes into question. The WTO has to address such issues in order to keep abreast of the changes in the world trading system," the report quoted Lee as saying.

"The WTO's future work program should adapt to technological advances which affect trade. A prime example of such advances is the emergence of new forms of trading activities such as electronic commerce, which has captured the imagination of governments, businesses, and consumers alike for its potential to enhance trade," he was quoted as saying.

DOC.HEADLINE: NO NEED TO PANIC OVER STOCK PRICES: FINANCE MINISTER

TEXT.P: The panic selling on the Taipei stock market triggered by heavy drops in both the Japanese and Hong Kong stock markets and their currencies seems to indicate that local investors are overreacting to those foreign setbacks, Finance Minister Paul C.H. Chiu said on Wednesday.

Chiu told the CNA that Taiwan enjoys a firmer financial system than either of those two economies and it also has sound economic fundamentals, so there's no need to worry about a possible financial collapse for Taiwan.
Taiwan's share prices dropped 3.1 percent on Wednesday following the local currency's further depreciation due to the Japanese yen's fall through 141 against the greenback.
The "abnormal" performance in both the stock and foreign exchange markets prompted mounting calls for the government to implement effective measures to halt the crisis.

Wang You-theng and Koo Chen-fu, two commercial and industry heavyweights, were reported to have called on Premier Vincent Siew in the wake of the stock market and NT dollar drops, to voice their worry about the inflation which will hit the island after the serious currency devaluation.

Wang, chairman of the General Chamber of Commerce of the Republic of China, said a "reasonable" value of the NT dollar is around 32-33 against the greenback. "It is not right" that the unit has been devalued to under 34, he said.

Wang noted that he and Koo, honorary chairman of the Chinese National Association of Industry and Commerce, have both suggested that Siew pay close attention to investors' expectations of a further weakening of the NT dollar. "Such expectations might also cause an inflation crisis," Wang stressed.

According to statistics from the Central Bank of China (CBC), the NT dollar has suffered a 19.88 percent decline since the end of last June. The value of the currency moved down to 34.715 to the US dollar on Tuesday from the 27.812 level of June 30, 1997, which was described by CBC officials as "over-depreciation."

DOC.HEADLINE: AUSTRALIAN DOLLAR, BOURSE DIP AMID INTEREST RATE HIKE RUMORS

TEXT.P: The Australian dollar fell to 58.48 US cents in Wednesday morning trade, its lowest level in 12 years, while the stock market continued sliding amid nervous trading, market analysts said.
The All Ordinaries dipped 19.6 points from Tuesday's close of 2,623.9.

Analysts said reports of big Japanese insurance companies, such as Nippon Life, selling Australian dollar-denominated assets, including securities and bonds, unnerved investors, who rushed to sell Australian currency and shares.
Speculation that the Reserve Bank of Australia would raise interest rates to prop up the currency's value caused further nervousness, especially among businessmen and home buyers, analysts said.
Analysts warn that if the Australian dollar falls as low as 55 US cents -- which they say is indeed possible -- the country will become "a banana republic."
Businessmen are worried that a rise in interest rates would blunt their competitive edge in world markets because of higher production costs.

Likewise, tens of thousands of Australian home buyers are worried that higher interest rates would cause heavier financial burdens for them, while the construction association said the hike would have a dampening effect on the A$23 (US$15) billion industry.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC WELCOMES US HOUSE RESOLUTION

TEXT.P: Foreign Minister Jason Hu on Wednesday expressed welcome to a US House of Representatives resolution urging President Bill Clinton to demand Beijing renounce the use of force against Taiwan during his upcoming state visit to mainland China.
"We welcome the resolution and appreciate all the support the American congressmen have extended to us," said Hu, who just returned from a visit to Europe and Africa.

The US House passed the non-binding concurrent resolution with a unanimous 411-0 vote on Tuesday to express the Congress' opinion that Clinton should seek from mainland authorities "a public renunciation of the use of force, or the threat of the use of force, against democratic Taiwan" at his summit meeting with mainland President Jiang Zemin in Beijing late this month.

The resolution acknowledges Taiwan's desire to play a positive role in the current Asian financial crisis and affirms the support of the American people for peace and stability on the Taiwan Strait and security for Taiwan.
It also demands the US government abides by all previous understandings of the "one China" policy and maintain its interest in a peaceful resolution of the Taiwan Strait issue.
Hu said the resolution complies with the Republic of China's basic stance that cross-strait issues should be resolved peacefully by the Chinese people on both sides of the Taiwan Strait.
The minister said although the House resolution is not binding to the executive branch, the Clinton administration is not expected to ignore such unanimous congressional opinion.

Touching on Clinton's June 25-July 3 mainland visit, Hu said the ROC government hopes that the United States will not take the initiative to make the Taiwan Strait issue a centerpiece of the agenda for the Clinton-Jiang summit meeting.
"We also hope the US will not sign any documents with mainland China concerning the Taiwan Strait issue," Hu said.

Barring unexpected developments, Hu said, the topics or directions of the upcoming meeting will not be very different from that of the first Clinton-Jiang summit meeting held in Washington, D.C. last year.
"The United States looks forward to seeing its engagements with Beijing benefit the delicate Taipei-Washington-Beijing relations. We think this US stance has remained unchanged," Hu noted.
He went on to say that both Taipei and Washington hopes to see the triangular Taipei-Washington-Beijing relations move on a stable, peaceful direction.
Nevertheless, Hu said the government has always remained cautious in watching developments in Beijing-Washington engagements. "We must keep alert in order to protect our national interests."

Hu further said although the US and mainland China have agreed to increase exchanges of military information and personnel, they are still far away from exchanging weaponry systems because of differences in vaules and military concepts.

DOC.HEADLINE: AUSTRALIAN PAPER REPORTS TAIWAN TO REMAIN A SAFE HARBOR AMID A STORM

TEXT.P: Taiwan will remain an economic haven in Asia despite the beating its currency has taken in the wake of a weakening Japanese yen, said Chen Chien-jen, director general of the Government Information Office.

In a story published in The Sydney Morning Herald, Australia's oldest mass-circulation newspaper, Chen also was quoted as saying ROC President Lee Teng-hui is prepared to consider visiting Beijing, "but definitely not as head of a provincial government. No way. He would like to go as president of the ROC."

Chen said that despite regional turmoil, Taiwan's economy remains robust, with inflation of about 2 percent and low unemployment. He predicted economic growth of 6 percent this year compared to 6.8 percent last year.
"In the first quarter we were not able to achieve 6 percent, but I believe in the second half of this year we are going to do somewhat better than in the first half," Chen said.

In that same story, Mainland Affairs Council Chairman Chang King-yuh, was quoted as saying that China's "one country, two systems" formula cannot be applied to Taiwan because the model "was irrelevant to Taiwan, which was not a colony."
More than 80 percent of the people of Taiwan reject the notion that "one country, two systems" is applicable to the Republic of China, he said.
Whether the Chinese formula on Hong Kong will work or not remains to be seen not in the first year, but over 50 years, Chang said.

Talks on the reunification of Taiwan and China could happen only after Beijing agrees to "further modernize, emphasize the rule of law and evolve into an open and pluralist society and, eventually, a functioning democracy," he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC, VIETNAM INK TRADE ACCORD

TEXT.P: The Republic of China and Vietnam recently signed an agreement to eliminate double taxation and tax evasion, the Republic of China Ministry of Finance announced on Wednesday.

C. H. Yang, deputy director of the ministry's Department of Taxation, said C.C. Hu, representative of the Taipei Economic and Cultural Office in Hanoi, and Dang Dinh Luu, representative of the Vietnam Economic and Cultural Office in Taipei, inked the accord in Hanoi days earlier.
Yang said the accord will help protect Taiwan business interests in Vietnam and boost bilateral trade and investment opportunities. Taiwan is Vietnam's largest foreign investor.

Vietnam is the eighth country to sign such a comprehensive, cross-sector trade agreement with Taiwan, according to Yang. Australia, Indonesia, Malaysia, New Zealand, Paraguay, Singapore and South Africa, have all signed similar pacts.

Canada, Japan, Germany, Holland, Luxembourg, Norway, South Korea, the United States and Sweden, meanwhile, have signed agreements with Taiwan to eliminate double taxation, but the agreements apply only to the marine and aviation transport sectors.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAC CHIEF OUTLINES NEW DIRECTIONS FOR CROSS-STRAIT TALKS

TEXT.P: Future consultations between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait should focus on promoting peaceful development and national unification under a democratic system, a senior mainland affairs official said on Wednesday.
Chang King-yuh, chairman of the Cabinet-level Mainland Affairs Council (MAC), made the statement at an interministerial mainland affairs working meeting.

The chief mainland policy architect also said Taiwan must exercise flexibility and pragmatism in engaging mainland China in order to avoid falling into the Beijing-proposed 'one China' predicament or being troubled by squabbling over whether cross-strait talks should first deal with political issues or focus on technical and practical issues.

Meanwhile, Chang stressed the importance of resuming normal operations of institutionalized cross-strait dialogue channel, noting that maintaining a healthy consultative mechanism is essential to ensure long-term harmony and stability in cross-strait relations.

Since mainland China unilaterally suspended regular cross-strait dialogue in mid-1995, Chang said the Republic of China has never stopped its efforts to push for early resumption of institutionalized cross-strait consultations. "Our stance is always coherent and consistent."
Chang went on to say that future cross-strait relations will face a new climate in the future and that many new interactions will also emerge.

"We must keep confidence in our national goals and work hand-in-hand to promote cross-strait rapprochement in line with the National Unification Guildelines," Chang said. "By so doing, we'll be able to reduce unnecessary suspicion and increase mutual understanding with mainland China."
Chang also reminded government officials in charge of mainland affairs that Beijing will intensify its "united front" tactics to court Taiwan investors or business people.

"Mainland China held a Taiwan affairs meeting in mid-May, during which time communist officials vowed to seek headway in cross-strait economic cooperation and to push for direct trade, transport and postal links," Chang recalled.

Against this background, Chang said, Taiwan must maintain its "no hast, be patient" mainland investment policy in order to protect the island from becoming very vulnerable to mainland China's economic and political clout.

"We must regulate cross-strait economic exchanges from an omnibus perspective to sustain Taiwan's domestic economic growth," Chang said, adding that the government will further imporve information services and offer more assistance to Taiwan companies with interests on the mainland.

DOC.HEADLINE: MA PLEDGES TO LISTEN TO TAIPEI RESIDENTS

TEXT.P: Ma Ying-jeou, the ruling Kuomintang's Taipei mayoral candidate, said on Wednesday a good mayor must learn from and listen to city residents.

Ma, who was formally named by the KMT Central Central Committee as the party's candidate on Wednesday morning, said at a press conference that he will combine human resources from commerce, industry and academic and administrative fields to engage in a dignified election campaign.

Commenting on his motives for entering the race, Ma said that before making his decision, he had been caught in a tug of war between responsibility and sincerity. In the end, however, he decided not to be a bystander anymore.

Ma said that although he is, at present, less knowledgeable about city administration than Taipei's present mayor, he will solicit views and opinions from the city's residents and officials, as well as from experts and scholars, before formulating his policies.

The former justice minister's campaign team will comprise leaders of industry and commerce, administrators and academics. The team will be organized by the KMT's city committee, and Wu Poh-hsiung, senior adviser to the President, will lead a supplemental support team.

Ma stressed that he intends to set an example and run an honorable race, adding that he will, if elected, seek out the assistance of people from different political parties, using each person according to his talents and abilities.
Noted painter Yeh Tsui-pai presented a painting depicting horses to Ma at the conference and wished him success in the year-end election.

Also attending the conference were Taipei City Council Speaker Chen Chien-chih; KMT legislative candidates Chin Hui-chu, Lee Ching-an and Chen Hsueh-seng; and representatives of women's, youth and labor organizations.

DOC.HEADLINE: FM TOUTS BENEFITS OF HIS PRESENCE AT OAU MEETING

TEXT.P: Foreign Minister Jason Hu hailed his presence at a recent conference of the Organization of African Unity as a valuable opportunity to enhance Taiwan's visibility on the international stage.

On returning Wednesday from Ouagadougou, Burkina Faso, where the OAU held its 34th annual conference, Hu told reporters that the Republic of China will not forgo any opportunity to "be seen, be heard and be felt" in the international community. The OAU conference provided a forum for the island to increase its presence in Africa, he said.
On the meeting's sidelines, diplomats from many African states approached Hu and expressed a willingness to tighten ties with Taipei, he said.

Although not an OAU member and despite the absence of diplomatic relations with Burkina Faso, Beijing dispatched a four-member delegation to the conference, an indication of Beijing's eagerness to woo African states, said Hu.

Noting that the Republic Of China places importance on international conferences hosted by its allies, Hu said the island looks forward to more opportunities to attend meetings of regional economic and trade forums. However he brushed aside questions on whether Taiwan will attend the OAU event regularly.
Hu declined to elaborate on his African trip itinerary, saying that presenting a laundry list of his initiatives could jeopardize their future harvests.

Hu attended the OAU meeting, which took place from June 6 to 10, at the invitation of Ablasse Ouedraogo, foreign minister of Burkina Faso. He arrived without advance announcement after concluding a meeting in Europe with ROC envoys to 27 states on June 1-2.

The Foreign Ministry issued a statement regarding Hu's European trip after the envoys' meeting but remained tight-lipped as to the meeting's location, saying only that it was held in a European state that does not maintain official ties with Taipei.
Moreover, the ministry did not disclose Hu's presence at the OAU meeting until the meeting had nearly drawn to a close.
The OAU, founded in 1963, is an association of African nations that aim to promote unity among African peoples. It comprises 52 countries.

DOC.HEADLINE: WASHINGTON URGED NOT TO HAMSTRING TAIWAN WITH CLOSER BEIJING TIES

TEXT.P: Although ROC Premier Vincent Siew does not expect any surprises will come out of the upcoming summit between US President Bill Clinton and his Beijing counterpart, Jiang Zemin, he urged Washington on Wednesday not to improve ties with Beijing to Taipei's detriment.

Reiterating Taiwan's official position that Washington's ties with Taipei and Beijing are separate and that close Washington-Beijing ties are in the interests of regional stability and peaceful relations across the Taiwan Strait, Siew told a group of Beijing-and-Hong Kong-based journalists for Western mass media outlets that Taiwan does not stand in the way of the United States' relationship with Beijing.

Although taking at face value Washington's assurances that the United States' engagement with Beijing will not affect its policy toward Taiwan, Taipei will closely monitor the summit, scheduled during Clinton's trip to mainland China between June 25 and July 3, said Siew.
Siew also reiterated his willingness to meet with mainland Chinese Prime Minister, Zhu Rongji, provided the two can meet on equal footing.
Sixteen journalist met with Siew, including correspondents from the British Broadcasting Corporation, Voice of America, The International Herald Tribune and the German weekly Die Spiegel.

DOC.HEADLINE: ANOTHER DISPUTE BETWEEN CENTRAL, PROVINCIAL GOVERNMENTS

TEXT.P: The cabinet issued a strongly-worded rebuttal late Tuesday afternoon to criticism made by Taiwan Provincial Governor James Soong against the central government regarding recent flooding in central and southern Taiwan.

Calling Soong's remarks "totally groundless and unacceptable" at an emergency news conference, government spokesman Chen Chien-jen said the central government must make clear its position and called on Soong to discuss with the central government.

Chen made the statement after Soong harshly criticized the central government earlier in the day for failing to cooperate with provincial authorities in their efforts to improve long-standing problems with flooding in central and southern Taiwan.

During an inspection of Chiayi City and Huko township in Yunlin County, both of which have seen widespread flooding from recent torrential rains, Soong was questioned by local chiefs on why he failed to keep his promise to help the two localities prevent future floods from occurring.

Emphasizing that the provincial government has done its best to achieve that goal, an angry Soong accused the central government of attempting to write off the provincial government's flood-control efforts by freezing funds allocated for fiscal 1999. He also accused the central government of "devoting itself to eliminating the provincial government and ignoring the welfare of the people."
Rebutting Soong's comments, Chen called them "irrational and totally groundless," adding that the central government would not tolerate such accusations.

Stressing that the central government is deeply concerned about the welfare of people throughout the island, Chen said as much as NT$49.2 billion (US$1.2 billion) has been allocated over the past five years to help the provincial government combat flooding. It is now time to examine the results of the provincial government's flood-control efforts, he said.
Soong and central authorities have been at odds since the central government decided to reduce the size and scope of the provincial government in late 1996.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC SWIMMING TEAM TO CROSS ITALIAN CHANNEL

TEXT.P: A channel-crossing team from the Republic of China is set to swim the Circeo Channel in Italy later this month, team leader Wang Han announced on Thursday.
Wang said the crossing of the channel, located about 100 kilometers south of Rome, will take place as originally scheduled between June 22 and 24.
The team, which consists of seven men and women long-distance swimmers, will leave for Italy on Friday and will train for at least four days prior to the attempt.
Wang has swam across 11 channels over the past 13 years. He started his cross-channel swimming career in 1986 when he became the first ROC swimmer to cross the Strait of Gibraltar.
He told reporters that the team wants to prove once again that the Chinese from Taiwan possess physical strength and sportsmanship.
On behalf of the ROC sports sector, Chinese Taipei Sports Federation Chairman Chang Wan-li presented the national flag to the team on Thursday, and encouraged the swimmers to do their best.

With regards to the attempt, Wang said the water temperature in the Circeo Channel ranges between 18- and 20-degrees Celsius during this time of the year. Five team members and an Italian swimmer will take part in the 45-km crossing. It will take an estimated 12 to 15 hours to complete the crossing.

The team had previously applied to cross the Strait of Messina which separates Sicily and Italy, and the Strait of Bonifacio which separates the islands of Corsica and Sardinia, but the applications were turned down for security reasons. The team then settled for the Circeo Channel.
The Circeo crossing will be the team's last attempt before they take on the crossing of the Taiwan Strait by 2000, Wang said.

Since 1985, Wang's team has successfully swam the Gibraltar Channel, English Channel, the Bosporus Strait, which separates Europe from Asia, Hawaii's Maui Channel, Cape of Good Hope, Canada's Juan de Fuca Channel, Japan's Tsugaru Channel, Australia's Platypus Channel, New Zealand's Cook Strait, and the San Pedro Channel in the United States.

DOC.HEADLINE: US STAINLESS STEEL INDUSTRY FILES COMPLAINT AGAINST TAIWAN
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, June 10 (CNA) (By Herman Pan and Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: The United States stainless steel industry has filed a complaint against three Taiwan companies, accusing them of dumping stainless steel sheet and strip in coil at below fair market price.

Identified in the complaint were the Yieh United Steel Co., Tang Eng Iron Works Co., and Tung Mung Development Co. The industry has asked the US government to impose anti-dumping taxes ranging from 8.23 percent to 77.08 percent on these three Taiwanese companies.

The Department of Commerce is looking into the matter and will decide whether a formal investigation is warranted by the end of the month. Under normal procedures, the International Trade Commission will give an initial verdict on the damage incurred by the alleged dumping practices on July 24.

The complaint against Taiwan was part of a larger complaint against Taiwan, Japan, South Korea, Germany, France, Mexico, Britain and Italy. The stainless steel industry has asked the US government to impose anti-dumping tax on these countries.

The industry also accused South Korea, France and Italy of improving their competitiveness by dumping goods which were subsidized by their governments, and asked the US government to impose a tax to compensate for the lower prices on products from these three nations.

DOC.HEADLINE: AUSTRALIA MILITARY GETS TOUGH ON SEXUAL HARASSMENT

TEXT.P: The Australian Defense Force will introduce tough new rules to eliminate sexual harassment against female cadets at its military academy.

The new measures follow a damning report on the elite Australian Defense Force Academy -- the top military training institution in Australia -- which reveals a practice of crude and offensive behavior, mainly directed at women.

The report says harassment has become a "pervasive and public feature of the environment -- part of the day-to-day social life of cadets." However, the number of women who reported being harassed was not revealed in the report.

Chief of the Defense Force General John Baker said the "vast majority of cadets" were impressive people but he was "very surprised at the extent and the depth" of the culture of harassment at the academy.
He said it was "not a great pleasure" to release the report, but it was necessary to reassure the public that the Defense Force was committed to the highest standards of propriety and behavior.
Baker said although the report focused on the defense academy, it had wide applications and many of its recommendations would be implemented throughout the defense force.

DOC.HEADLINE: CEPD OPTIMISTIC ON TAIWAN'S ECONOMIC DEVELOPMENT

TEXT.P: Taiwan's economic performance research authority expressed optimism over the island's economy despite the overall bearish sentiment in the stock and currency markets.

Thomas M.F. Yeh, director of economic research in the Council for Economic Planning and Development (CEPD), said that Taiwan's imports posted small but positive growth during the first five months of this year.

There was a significant increase of imported capital goods, the value of which reached more than NT$10 billion (US$287.36 million), up 22.9 percent from the same five-month period last year, Yeh said. He added the growth indicate the willingness to invest in the island did not dissipate due to the recent drop in value of the NT dollar.

Yeh's observation was supported by CEPD's Vice Chairman K.C. Lee, who said that although most leading indices for the island's economic performance convey a downward trend, he thought domestic interaction between demand and supply remains vibrant.
"Economic activities did not cool down ... (there is) no need to worry about recession," Lee said.

The CEPD on Wednesday released statistics on foreign trade in the first five months of 1998. The figures show Taiwan exported US$45.38 billion worth of products in the five-month period, down 6.9 percent from the same period in 1997. Meanwhile, imports totaled US$44.63 billion, which were down 2 percent.
Trade surpluses posted a 79.6 percent plunge during the January-May period compared to the amount that the island earned from foreign trading a year ago, the statistics showed.

DOC.HEADLINE: NATURE OF FATHERHOOD CHANGING WITH SURGING DIVORCE RATES

TEXT.P: Surging divorce rates in Australia and the United States have changed the nature not only of marriages but also of fatherhood, according to experts.

Speaking at the Men and Family Relationships Forum in Canberra Wednesday, Professor Paul Amato of the University of Nebraska said more than 40 percent of first marriages in Australia end in divorce. "Because most divorces involve children and because most children reside with their mothers following divorce, large numbers of men ... are discovering that fatherhood means being a non-resident father. Non-resident fatherhood is, in fact, a new type of fatherhood, which we are just beginning to understand," Amato told participants of the meeting.
He said there was little evidence to support the notion that frequent contact between non-resident fathers and their children is good for children.
A better predictor of a child's future academic success was financial support as opposed to the number of contact hours with the father, he said.

"Studies consistently find that fathers' payment of child support improves not only children's standard of living, but also their health, educational attainment and general sense of well-being. Overall, the social science research appears to indicate that non-resident fathers are important for their money, but for very little else," Amato said.

According to the research, fathers' relationships with their children were primarily recreational in nature. Fathers generally did not provide authoritative parenting which involves warmth, responsiveness, everyday assistance and instruction.

DOC.HEADLINE: AEROSPACE COOPERATION MAY HELP NARROW TAIWAN-JAPAN TRADE GAP

TEXT.P: Industrial cooperation between Japan's leading corporations and their Taiwan counterparts might be an effective initiative to help correct Taiwan's chronic trade imbalance with Japan, officials from the Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) said on Thursday.

Working toward that goal, Vice Minister of Economic Affairs Yin Chi-ming led a Taiwan business and investment delegation to Japan in April this year. During the visit, ROC officials met with executives from Fuji Heavy Industries Co. and other leading Japanese industrial conglomerates for talks on cooperation.
The visit began to pay off this month when a fact-finding mission from Fuji visited Taiwan last week in a bid to tap the feasibility of cooperating with the domestic aerospace industry.

Fuji, after its officials visited five Taiwan aerospace companies over the last week, has initially decided to co-produce parts and components with Taiwan partners. The five Taiwan companies were Chenfeng Machinery & Enterprise, Fong Sou Machinery, Jui Li Enterprise, Taiwan Aerospace Co., and the state-run Aerospace Industrial Development Corp.
According to the MOEA officials, Fuji has taken part in similar cooperation with manufacturers in mainland China, India and Singapore, but none of the efforts produced satisfactory results.

If the initial cooperation with Taiwan proves successful, Fuji officials said, the Japanese company will consider expanding the cooperation to other lines including the assembly of major aircraft parts and development of advanced materials for aircraft.

Fuji Heavy Industries Co., which maintains five major operations in Subaru automobiles, industrial equipment, household goods, rail cars, and aerospace industry, posted an annual turnover of 856 billion Japanese yen in 1997 with a workforce of 15,400.
Taiwan's trade deficit with Japan reached a record high of US$17.3 billion in 1997, which was a stunning increase of 25.2 percent over the previous year.
In 1997, Taiwan imported US$29 billion worth of goods from Japan, up 5.6 percent from 1996, mainly because of increased imports of capital goods as domestic investment rose, MOEA officials said.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAC OFFICIAL SPEAKS ON PROBLEMS OF INVITING MAINLAND PROFESSIONALS

TEXT.P: The problems arising from having mainland Chinese professionals visit Taiwan need to be addressed, a high-ranking official of the Cabinet-level Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) said Thursday.

MAC Vice Chairman Wu An-chia made the remarks at a seminar about the situation and development of cross-strait cultural and social exchanges. The MAC is in charge of mapping the nation's policy toward the mainland.

Wu said some of the private groups in Taiwan inviting mainland professionals to the island did not have an adequate knowledge of the goals behind allowing such visits. These groups were either trying to establish communication with the mainland or seek profits from the visits.
Another problem Wu cited was that some of these mainland visitors made improper remarks that ran counter to the current policies of the Republic of China.

Some visitors had defamed Taiwan or advocated establishing the three currently banned direct links between the island and the mainland (which are trade, postal, and transport), or promoted the "one country, two systems" formula for reunification.
Some visitors have even criticized the government and the leaders of the ROC, Wu said.

A number of mainland professionals, after coming to Taiwan, have engaged in activities incompatible to their original purpose of coming to Taiwan, including working, sight-seeing, giving commercial performances or trying to woo Taiwan investors.
Such activities have badly affected the results of good-will exchanges across the strait, Wu stressed.
