DOC.HEADLINE: SINGAPORE OFFICE VOWS TO HELP TAIWAN INVESTORS

TEXT.P: Singapore's representative office in Taipei on Thursday agreed to extend a helping hand to a group of Taiwan investors who allegedly have been swindled money by a multinational investment company whose Asia-Pacific headquarters is located in Singapore.

The Singapore Trade Office made the promise after 50-plus Taiwan investors, headed by New Party Taipei City Councilor Chu Mei-feng, appealed for its assistance in freezing Global International Investors Trading Limited's (GIITL) assets in the Southeast Asian city-state.

Chu told Pang Te Cheng, deputy head of the de facto Singapore embassy here, that many Taiwan investors had invested in the GIITL's Global Managed Equity Portfolio partly because its regional operations were based in Singapore which Chu said is the envy of Taiwan people for its low crime rate and good business reputation.

Chu said scores of Taiwan investors traveled to Singapore last week to file lawsuits against GIITL's Asia-Pacific affiliate, SCLA Creation Ltd. However, Singaporean lawyers told them that only judicial authorities of the country where the crime took place can handle the case.
Chu said Taiwan investors hope the Singapore government will help probe the whereabouts of GIITL SCLA Chairman James Cheng and immediately put a freeze on all of his assets.

In response, Pang said his office would contact Singapore's foreign ministry, commercial crime investigation department and other related law enforcement authorities and push them to help probe the alleged fraudulent case.
Pang said he will also urge his country's law enforcement authorities to cooperate with their Taiwan counterparts in investigating where the GIITL's capital has flowed.

GIITL opened branch offices in major Taiwan cities last year to sell a financial product, named Global Managed Equity Portfolio, to investors around the island. They lured investors with guarantees of high profit rates, ranging between 30 percent and 40 percent.

Its Taiwan branches even claimed that their prduct was backed by the Standard Chartered Bank. However, the British bank's Taipei office issued a statement last Friday, insisting that it has never been the trust supervising bank or guarantor in connection with the GIITL product.
According to local press reports, GIITL had illegally collected about NT$5 billion (US$143.68 million) from local investors, many of whom were retired government employees or office workers.

The Ministry of Justice Investigation Bureau (MJIB) has launched a probe into the case. Top executives of the company's Taiwan branches, including Huang Po-ching and Chen Chin-wen, have not been seen in public since late last month. MJIB sources said they might have fled abroad with the money they had collected here.

DOC.HEADLINE: CLINTON TO DEFEND HIS BEIJING TRIP AND ENGAGEMENT POLICY
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, June 10 (CNA) (By Nelson Chung & Eva Chen)

TEXT.P: US President Bill Clinton is to deliver a speech on Thursday in which he will defend his "constructive engagement" policy toward Beijing and upcoming trip to mainland China.

Clinton is to address the National Geographic Association Thursday morning, where he "will directly answer those critics that suggest that it would be better at this point in human history to isolate the billions of people who live in China and treat that nation as a rogue nation," said White House spokesman Michael McCurry in a press briefing Wednesday.
Clinton will be the first US president to visit mainland China since its army crushed pro-democracy demonstrations in 1989.

A human rights alliance has written to Clinton urging him to avoid Tiananmen Square, the site of the massacre. Nine years after the slaughter, the Beijing authorities have showed no repentance at all, said the alliance.
Clinton is also expected to defend his controversial decision to approve the transfer of satellite technology to mainland China.

Washington observers, however, say Clinton will have a tough time winning over critics, especially after a House International Relations subcommittee watched a video on forced abortions in mainland China and held hearings that included testimony accusing Beijing of continuing its policy of practicing forced abortions.
During the hearings, one former mainland Chinese official testified that he personally witnessed an abortion performed on a woman who was nine month's pregnant.

"I witnessed the mouth of the fetus was moving, and so did its hands and feet. A doctor injected poison into its brain and cast the baby into a garbage can after its death," said the former Chinese official.
McCurry did not dismiss the allegations, but he insisted that the best way to handle this issue, as well as others, is to take them up with authorities in Beijing directly.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN SHARE PRICES DOWN

TEXT.P: Share prices slid a mere 0.2 percent on Thursday in Taipei, as the government propped up the market with funds aimed at stemming panic selling triggered by bearish sentiments in Japan and Hong Kong.

In the wake of Wednesday's 232.5-point plunge, the Taiwan Stock Exchange's weighted price index, the market's key barometer, slipped 12.39 points to close at 7,210.74, with the index fluctuating between 7,073.22 and 7,238.92.

The bourse dropped nearly 150 points after opening amid investors undertaking margin sales. Dealers said the release of government funds helped bolster buyer sentiment. In addition, several companies began to buy back their shares to prevent further price declines.
A total of 2.01 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$98.32 billion (US$2.83 billion) during the three-hour session.
Losers outnumbered gainers 247 to 176, with 63 stock remaining unchanged.
Of the TAIEX's eight major categories, only two -- foodstuffs and financial issues -- gained ground, while paper and pulp shares lost the most, falling 1 percent.

DOC.HEADLINE: BAD MANNERS TOP TOURISTS LIST OF GRIPES ABOUT TOUR LEADERS

TEXT.P: Most complaints from Taiwan tourists last year centered on the poor manners of tour group leaders and travel agency officials with whom tourists were involved in disputes, the Consumers' Foundation said on Thursday.

The foundation received 285 complaints last year, with 30 focusing on the poor manners of tour group leaders and agency officials and another 24 noting the improper handling of tourists' travel documents.

Changes to tour itineraries were the subject of 22 complaints, while another 15 bemoaned the fact that agencies had not confirmed accommodation or vehicle reservations and, consequently, had to make last-minute alterations. Dissatisfaction over shopping and entertainment facilities, as well as the quality of accommodations, accounted for another 14 complaints.

Lee Feng-hsiang, secretary-general of the foundation, said that the tour group leaders are crucial to the quality of the tourism industry, adding that some group leaders do not meet professional standards.

Chen Yi-chuan, secretary-general of Tourism Quality Protection Association, said that leaders and guides play different roles in handling tour groups. The statistics released by the foundation seem to have confused the two, he said.

Chen said most tourists' complaints about group leaders' manners stem from unhappiness over compulsory trips or shopping expeditions or rigid tour itineraries. The leaders, however, are acting in accordance with their agencies' policies and should not take all the blame, he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: NT DOLLAR UP

TEXT.P: The New Taiwan dollar rebounded NT$0.029 to close at 34.867 on Thursday in Taipei following Wednesday's plunge to its 11-year low.
The local currency opened at 34.887, and was traded between 34.51 and 35.05.
The interbank US dollar trading reached US$544 million.

DOC.HEADLINE: HANDICAPPED MAN THANKS COMPUTERS FOR OPENING A WINDOW OF HOPE
DOC.DATELINE: Chiayi, Southern Taiwan, June 11 (CNA) (By Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: Born without hands and with a distorted right leg and foot, Li Chih-chiang hails the computer, which he operates by tapping keys with his left foot, as his savior.

Li, 24, was a top academic performer during his five years of study at Chiayi's Tatung College of Commerce. After graduating, Li was hired by the school as a data processor. He was later promoted to director of the college's online business.
Computers have opened a window of hope for Li, he said.
A diligent student following programs with the Open University, Li said he is aiming at graduate school for higher study on information technology after he obtains a diploma with the Open University.
In addition to computers, Li professes his gratitude for classmate Yu Wei-chun, who was Li's constant companion during college. "I owe him more than I can say," Li said.

DOC.HEADLINE: OPPOSITION URGE EMERGENCY LEGISLATIVE MEETING TO SAVE STOCK MARKET

TEXT.P: With no end in sight for the local stock market's current slide, opposition party lawmakers urged the Legislative Yuan to hold an emergency meeting to save the market by passing two amendments to the securities exchange law.

Democratic Progressive Party Legislator Lin Wen-lang and New Party Legislator Tsai Cheng-yang jointly urged the legislature to reconvene in an emergency meeting to pass the amendments, which are currently awaiting second readings.
Both amendments, which deal with treasury stocks, are substantially beneficial to stimulating the stock market, Lin said, adding that they are the only measures that can halt the market's plunge.
Lin pointed out that the "deplorable" stock market's "never-ending stumbles" have already caused a domestic financial crisis.
Although the Ministry of Finance has already put forth three major measures to reverse the Taiwan Stock Exchange's downward motion, they have not been effective, he said.
Lin said investors should turn to the Legislative Yuan for a solution rather than hope for too much from the Executive Yuan's ministry-level policies.

Regarding divided opinion over whether the government should first rescue the stock market or the currency, Lin said that stabilizing the exchange rate would require the use of hard-earned foreign exchange reserves, a move that will adversely affect Taiwan's financial foundations.
Instead of paying so high a price, the government should start by stabilizing the stock market, Lin said.

Lin stressed that delaying action until the next legislative session opens in September would be too late; only by holding an emergency meeting to examine the proposed amendments can benefits be brought to Taiwan's stock market and its economy, he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: 1998 TAIPEI FOOD FESTIVAL OPENS

TEXT.P: The 1998 Taipei International Food Festival opened on Thursday with an array of eye-catching, tummy-tempting foods.
More than 400 exhibitors from more than 30 countries will participate in the four-day festival, which is expected to attract thousands of domestic and foreign visitors from the foodstuffs industry.

Besides promotions, product samplings and taste tests, workshops on introducing new products and trade and investment opportunities will be held during the show, which is taking place at the Taipei World Trade Center.
The festival will not be open to the general public until Saturday and will conclude Sunday.

DOC.HEADLINE: WESTERN MANAGERS FEEL MOST COMFORTABLE IN SINGAPORE, MALAYSIA, TAIWAN

TEXT.P: Western managers living in Asia tend to find Singapore, Malaysia and Taiwan the most comfortable locations in which to live, according to a survey conducted by the Political and Economic Risk Consultancy in Hong Kong.

The survey was administered to some 400 selected European and American managers living in Asia to determine how satisfied they were with their host countries. A report on the results was published in the German weekly "Wirtschaftswoche."
Singapore topped the list, followed by Malaysia, Taiwan, Japan, Honk Kong, Thailand, the Philippines, Indonesia, mainland China, Vietnam and South Korea.

Evaluations were based on such criteria as the quality of medical care, kindergarten and elementary schools, higher education systems for foreigners, housing, sports facilities, entertainment and personal security, as well as the degree of cultural adaptation that can be attained.

Singapore's medical care and schooling facilities received high marks, as did Malaysia's housing, sports facilities and entertainment offerings. Taiwan, meanwhile, was noted for its good schools and also received above-average scores for medical care, personal security, night life and cultural adaptation ability.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT MAY NAME CANDIDATE FOR KAOHSIUNG MAYORAL RACE BY JUNE 17

TEXT.P: Kuomintang Secretary-General Chang Hsiao-yen said on Thursday the ruling party would name its candidate for Kaohsiung mayor through coordination, and hopefully the KMT Central Standing Committee would approve the nomination on June 17.
Incumbent Kaohsiung Mayor Wu Den-yi has announced he will seek reelection. The announcement has angered other KMT competitors who insisted not to take part in a KMT primary.

KMT Vice Chairman Lien Chan on Wednesday invited three candidates who had intended to enter the race, Wang Chih-hsiung, Chang Rei-teh and Su Nan-cheng, for talks in an attempt to calm down their emotion.
The party is expected to name its candidate through coordination since Wang, Chang and Su all refused to take part in a party primary.

Chang confirmed Thursday morning that coordination would likely be the means by which a nominee will be chosen, but he stressed that although the ruling party would name its candidate by coordination, however, it will still go through proper procedures and the namelist of potential nominees will be submitted to the party's screening committee and then to the KMT Central Standing Committee for final approval.

DOC.HEADLINE: BEIJING MAY BECOME MORE FLEXIBLE AFTER CLINTON-JIANG SUMMIT: MAC

TEXT.P: A senior mainland affairs official predicted on Thursday that mainland China may become more active and more flexible in promoting relations across the Taiwan Strait after US President Bill Clinton's state visit to the mainland later this month.
Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) Chairman Chang King-yuh made the forecast at a weekly Cabinet meeting.

Chang said Clinton will hold summit talks with his mainland counterpart, Jiang Zemin, during his June 25-July 3 mainland visit. This will be the third Clinton-Jiang meeting in eight months, and Beijing authorities have made it clear that the Taiwan Strait issue will be on the agenda.

Noting that basic US stances on cross-strait issues are closer to Taiwan's than to mainland China's, Chang said he doesn't think the Clinton administration will deviate from its existing stances following the Beijing summit.
Nevertheless, Chang said he expects mainland China to become more active and more flexible in promoting cross-strait relations after the Clinton-Jiang meeting.
"Beijing may take the initiative to press for the opening of cross-strait political talks and adopt more flexible strategies and tactics in dealing with cross-strait affairs," Chang predicted.

In related news, Vice Chairman Wu An-chia suggested at an interministerial mainland affairs meeting that the two sides of the Taiwan Strait sign an agreement to institutionalize bilateral information and news exchanges.
Wu said cross-strait journalistic and information exchanges have been unbalanced because of gaps in political systems and attitudes toward news events.

Against this background, Wu said, it is necessary for the two sides to seal a formal accord on the establishment of institutionalized channels to facilitate cross-strait information exchanges and boost mutual understanding.

Wu said Taiwan's newspapers and magazines have consistently run detailed reports on major mainland news events. Local publishing houses have also published many books authored by mainland writers and scholars, and television companies have presented many mainland China-originated programs.

"Through all these media, local people can understand recents developments or trends in mainland China," Wu said, adding that the increasing popularity of Internet services have offered even easier access to information about mainland China.

On the other hand, Wu said mainland media have seldom reported on Taiwan-related news stories. "Worse yet, mainland media often offered distorted or misleading reports on Taiwan-related issues. Mainland authorities have also imposed many restrictions on Taiwan journalists concerning news coverage," Wu said.

In addition, Wu said, mainland China has lowered the quota of offshore programs to be aired on its TV channels since 1990 for fear of cultural invasion from Hong Kong, Taiwan and other free countries and areas. Mainland authorities have also imposed strict restrictions on Internet surfing and linkup, he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: LATVIA WILLING TO BOOST TIES WITH TAIWAN: DPP CHIEF
DOC.DATELINE: Paris, June 10 (CNA) (By M. J. Chou and Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: Outgoing Democratic Progressive Party Chairman Hsu Hsin-liang said on Thursday that both Latvia's ruling and opposition parties gave high praise to Taiwan's political and economic achievements and are willing to enhance bilateral ties with Taiwan.
Hsu made the remarks en route to Finland after concluding a two-day visit to Latvia.

The DPP chairman said the main purpose of his Latvian visit is to gain an understanding of the country's democratization progress after gaining independence from the former Soviet Union in August 1991.
Hsu said he visited government officials and political party leaders during his stay and held a seminar with a pro-Taiwan parliamentary group.

Claiming that both Latvia's ruling and opposition parties are friendly to Taiwan and that both have expressed a desire to strengthen two-way relations, the DPP chairman said the Latvian government and private sector welcome Taiwan businesses to invest in the country.

Located near the Baltic Sea, the Latvian capital of Riga was an important port for the former East European bloc, Hsu said. Taiwan companies can take advantage of the city's strategic location and its proximity to the vast markets of the Commonwealth of Independent States, he added.
Hsu will proceed to Stockholm from Helsinki before returning home on Wednesday.
Hsu is expected to step down from his post in July, making this his last overseas trip as party chairman.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC TOPS LIST OF ARMS IMPORTERS IN 1997

TEXT.P: The Republic of China topped a list of the world's 15 biggest importers of weapons in 1997, according to the Stockholm International Peace Research Institute (SIPRI).
Figures released by the institute in its authoritative annual report on world arms sales show that the ROC spent US$4 billion on arms last year compared to US$1.5 billion in 1996.
Saudi Arabia is second on the list, having spent US$2.3 billion on arms in 1997. Mainland China is third, with US$1.8 billion.

The ROC has been relatively untouched by the Asian economic crisis which hit the region in July last year, while the worst affected countries -- Indonesia, Thailand, South Korea and Malaysia -- have canceled major arms orders.

Among its large weapons contracts with Western countries were orders for 150 F-16 combat aircraft, Patriot air defense missiles and helicopters from the United States, as well as six La Fayette-class frigates and 60 Mirage 2000-5 combat aircraft from France.
Economic crisis notwithstanding, Asia stayed the No. 1 arms buyer, with a 49 percent share of global imports, up from 31 percent in 1988, according to the SIPRI report.
Out of the 15 top arms importing countries, eight of them are Asian.
On the supply side, the market remains dominated by six export countries, led last year by the US, with a 43 percent market share, followed by Russia and France.
The three countries, along with Britain, mainland China and Germany, supplied 84 percent of global sales last year, selling to Asian and Middle Eastern buyers.
Notable is the dramatic drop in mainland Chinese arms sales, which plummeted by 75 percent last year compared to 1996 figures.
The top 15 arms-importing countries in 1997 were:
1. ROC -- US$4,049 million
2. Saudi Arabia -- US$2,370 million
3. Mainland China -- US$1,816 million
4. Malaysia -- US$1,346 million
5. Turkey -- US$1,276 million
6. India -- US$1,085 million
7. South Korea -- US$1,077 million
8. Thailand -- US$1,031 million
9. Egypt -- US$867 million
10. United Arab Emirates -- US$808 million
11. Greece -- US$715 million
12. United States -- US$656 million
13. Japan -- US$584 million
14. Pakistan -- US$572 million
15. Italy -- US$552 million

DOC.HEADLINE: KOREAN FISHERMEN PROTEST AGAINST CHINESE PIRACY

TEXT.P: Some 50 representatives of South Korean fishery organizations Thursday staged a demonstration at the embassy of mainland China in Seoul against mainland Chinese piracy and illegal fishing in the Yellow Sea and the East China Sea.

An organizer of the demonstration said that since the two countries established diplomatic relations in 1992, mainland Chinese fishermen have robbed and illegally fished in South Korean waters more and more often. They accused the Beijing government of ignoring the problem.

He said the mainland Chinese pirates are reminiscent of the "Jap pirates," who ravaged the coastlines of China several hundred years ago. South Korean fishery organizations set up a "countermeasure committee" Thursday to help resolve the problem, he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAINLAND CHINA MAJOR SOURCE OF ILLEGAL DRUGS IN TAIWAN

TEXT.P: Mainland China constitutes a grave threat to Taiwan's social order, as 64 percent of the narcotics seized by local law enforcement authorities in 1997 originated there, according to figures compiled by the Cabinet-level Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics (DGBAS).
Taiwan law enforcement authorities intercepted a total of 2,900 kilograms of drugs in 1997, up 827 kilograms from the 1996 figure, 64 percent of which came from the mainland, the DGBAS tallies show.
According to the DGBAS, a total of 37,901 people involved in 45,935 drug-related cases were charged by prosecutors across Taiwan in 1997, up 14.4 percent and 24 percent, respectively, from 1996.

However, the DGBAS also said that drug-related crime seems to have declined this year, as only 9,431 people involved in 13,536 drug-related crimes were prosecuted in the first four months of the year, down 29.6 percent and 24.2 percent, respectively, from the same period of last year.
Nearly half of those sentenced to jail terms for narcotic-related crimes were educated to only junior high school level, the DGBAS noted.

DOC.HEADLINE: DOH CHANGES PERSONNEL AMID VIRAL OUTBREAK

TEXT.P: The Department of Health (DOH) announced a personnel change on Thursday amid a viral outbreak that has infected thousands of children around the island and claimed the lives of more than 30 babies and toddlers.
DOH Director-General Chan Chi-shean said he has approved the resignation of Wang Li-hsin from his position as director of the Bureau of Communicable Disease Control (BCDC).
Chan said Hsu Kuo-hsiung, a DOH adviser, will serve as acting BCDC director for the time being, while Wang will take up the post of deputy director of the National Institute of Preventive Medicine.
Wang tendered his resignation last week amid rising criticism of the DOH's slow response to the enterovirus 71 outbreak and its failure to come up with contingency counter-measures.

Usually spread by physical contact, the virus has been plaguing central and southern Taiwan where most of the deaths were found. However, Lee Ching-yun, a noted pediatrician with National Taiwan University Hospital, warned on Thursday that the disease would intensify in the northern part of the island.
On Wednesday, a one-year-old baby girl believed to be infected with the enterovirus died in a Taipei hospital.
"The outbreak will gradually reach its peak in northern Taiwan," Lee warned, adding that there is an urgent need to develop a vaccine to curb the further spread of the disease.

Quoting extensive tests at major hospitals in Taipei, Taichung, Tainan and Changhua, Lee said there are at least two types of enterovirus that are attacking children here and that the type 71 is the most virulent.

Lee said the virus might have spread from Malaysia to Taiwan as an enterovirus epidemic outbroke in that country last year. "Now the virus may spread from Taiwan to Hong Kong, mainland China, and Southeast Asia," he forecast.

Concerned about the virus, Japan has decided to send two experts to Taiwan to inspect and learn more about the epidemic. The Japanese experts are scheduled to arrive in a few days, according to DOH sources.

Meanwhile, the three American epidemiologists from the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention invited by the DOH to help in the investigation of the viral outbreak suggested that the DOH set up a diagnostic center to centralize viral tests.

The enterovirus usually attacks children below five years old. The virus breaks down immunity and can leave infants susceptible to encephalitis, meningitis, and acute inflamation of the heart muscle. Early symptoms are similar to the flu, including fever, headache and vomiting. The death rate of the viral infection is low if the patients are offered timely and proper medical treatment.
Doctors urged local parents to take precautions, such as avoiding crowded places and observing a high standard of hygiene, to protect their children from contracting the virus.

DOC.HEADLINE: TRADE MISSION CHALKS UP NEW BUSINESS IN JAPAN
DOC.DATELINE: Tokyo, June 11 (CNA) (By Mike Chang and Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: A large-scale trade delegation composed of 170 representatives from 99 Taiwan electronics and machinery companies has chalked up at least US$300 million-worth of new business after concluding the first two days of a promotion campaign in Tokyo and Osaka.

The promotion activity held on Thursday in Tokyo at a local hotel drew more than 1,200 Japanese businessmen, who brokered around US$200 million-worth of business on the spot with their Taiwan counterparts.
An earlier promotion fair held on Tuesday in Osaka attracted some 700 representatives from Japanese companies, who reached agreements on US$100 million-worth of business with the Taiwan delegation.
Liu Wei-te, chairman of the Taiwan-Japan Economic and Trade Foundation and leader of the trade mission, told the CNA that he is very satisfied with the results of the campaign so far.

The large number of Japanese visitors is an indication that Taiwan-made electronics and machinery products are popular in Japan, he said, predicting that Japan's investment in Taiwan this year is expected to exceed the record high level of US$850 million posted last year.

Pointing out that business conditions in Japan are sluggish at the moment, S.C. Lee, secretary-general of the delegation, expressed surprise at the US$300 million-worth of business and the some 80 joint cooperative ventures they have arranged with Japanese firms.
He said the delegation's current visit to Japan, the 11th of its kind, has helped the two countries establish a solid channel of communication and exchange for the future.
The trade-promotion mission is scheduled to conclude its weeklong visit to Japan on Sunday.

DOC.HEADLINE: RUSSIAN SOLONS TO CONTINUE PROMOTING TAIWAN RELATIONS BILL
DOC.DATELINE: Moscow, June 11 (CNA) (By Chang Hung-kuang & Ben Wu)

TEXT.P: Alex Mitrofanov, chairman of the Committee of Geopolitics of the Russian State Duma, said on Wednesday that he will continue his efforts to promote a Taiwan Relations Bill in the next session of parliament.
He made the remarks while receiving a Republic of China National Assembly mission led by Chen Chuan, secretary-general of the National Assembly.
In addition, Mitrofanov said he and his colleagues will work through the Moscow City Council to draft investment laws to protect businessmen from Taiwan and to promote bilateral relations.

Chen expressed his appreciation for Mitrofanov and his colleagues' efforts to promote the Taiwan Relations Bill. However, he reminded his Russian friends that when promoting the related bills, they should keep in mind the principles of fairness and reciprocity.

Mitrofanov said that since April, 1997, he and his fellow parliamentarians have pushed for a reading of the bill in the State Duma, in the hope that its enactment will lay a legal framework to facilitate Taiwan-Russian exchanges.
In a surprise move, Gennady Seleznev, speaker of the Russian State Duma, decided arbitrarily on June 2 to remove the bill from the agenda for the parliament's June 3 plenary session.

According to Mitrofanov, although Valdimir Zhirinovsky, chairman of the Liberal Democratic Party, suggested on June 3 the bill be reentered into the agenda, a suggestion which gained 77 supporting votes, it still failed to achieve a majority.

Mitrofanov told Chen that he and other Russian parliamentarians will submit a revised bill at the next parliamentary plenary session to be held in September. In addition, he pointed out that the Moscow City Council also plans to draft an investment law to attract more Taiwan businessmen.

Chang Wen-chung of the Representative Office in Moscow for the Taipei-Moscow Economic & Cultural Coordination Commission, hosted a dinner party in honor of the Russian and ROC parliamentarians on Wednesday evening, where Chen said that at the next National Assembly meeting in July, he will suggest the establishment of a Sino-Russian friendship group to help promote bilateral relations.

DOC.HEADLINE: EVA AIR INAUGURATES KAOHSIUNG-LOS ANGELES ROUTE

TEXT.P: A brand new Boeing 747-400 passenger jet belonging to the EVA Airways Corp., carrying a full complement of 342 passengers, took off from the Kaohsiung International Airport on Thursday night for Los Angeles, becoming the first trans-Pacific flight to depart from this port city in southern Taiwan.

A dozen central and local government officials, including Transportation and Communications Minister Lin Feng-cheng and Kaohsiung Mayor Wu Den-yih, attended a ribbon-cutting ceremony to mark the maiden flight.

Lin gave high praise to EVA AIR's opening of the Kaohsiung-Los Angeles route, which he said will facilitate travel by southern Taiwan passengers to the United States and help create business opportunities in Kaohsiung, the largest city in southern Taiwan.

Wu, who has served as the mayor of Kaohsiung for almost eight years, said the city has witnessed a rapid increase in its international air traffic in recent years. Eight years ago, Kaohsiung had only two international routes, but this number has grown to 18 today, he pointed out. He suggested that Lin should improve facilities at all the island's domestic airports to provide travelers with more convenient flight arrangements.
EVA AIR, Taiwan's second-largest carrier, said it will use only brand-new Boeing 747-400s to operate the new route.
The inaugural flight even attracted passengers from the northern city of Taipei, and several who were in transit from Vietnam's Ho Chi Minh City.

DOC.HEADLINE: SCHOLARS PRIME LOCAL BUSINESSMEN FOR EURO

TEXT.P: The launch of a single European currency, the euro, on Jan. 1, 1999, will serve to further integrate the European markets and provide an extra opportunity for local businessman to explore business opportunities there, local scholars said on Thursday.

In a symposium organized by the local Euro-Asia Trade Organization on Thursday to prime local businessmen for the introduction of the euro, Shen Hsuan-chih, a researcher at Academia Sinica, said the introduction of the euro is favorable to Taiwan-manufactured goods which are competitive in Europe because it will reduce the losses and inconvenience incurred by having to repeatedly exchange various European national currencies and thus will lower business operational costs.
Exploring the new European market will also lessen the island's dependence on the markets of the United States and mainland China for its exports, said Shen.

However, he said he regretted that Taiwan's investment in the 11 European Union member states currently totals only US$133 million, and focuses on wholesale\retail and international trade, which don't take full advantage of the benefits of a single currency.

He urged local businessmen who trade with or invest in European states to conduct market surveys and beef up their collection of commercial information to weather the fierce competition which is expected after the inauguration of the single European currency.

Huang Teh-feng, an associate professor at Tamkang University, predicted that the emergence of the euro will challenge the dominance of the US dollar in international trade and change the foreign exchange portfolio of governments around the world.
He called on both the authorities and private businessmen to watch closely the interaction between the US dollar and the euro and to be prepared for possible impact on the greenback.

DOC.HEADLINE: TORRENTIAL RAIN CAUSES NT$1.57 BILLION-WORTH OF AGRICULTURAL DAMAGE

TEXT.P: Heavy rain over the last few days has caused damage worth up to NT$1.57 billion (US$44.85 million) to Taiwan's agriculture sector, according to a statement released on Thursday by the Council of Agriculture.
Crops have borne the brunt of the devastation, with 43,348 hectares of rice, vegetables and peanuts destroyed, accounting for losses of about NT$1.37 billion (US$39.14 million), said the council.
The relentless rain has caused further damage of about NT$145 million in soil erosion around the island.
About 22 hectares of land has even been totally lost to the floodwater, with damage estimated at about NT$19.55 million.

Livestock has also suffered, with 200 hogs, 2,000 geese, 123,000 chickens, and 12,000 ducks, with a combined market value of NT$10.5 million, either drowned in floods or killed by collapsing pens and shelters.

Forestry and fisheries have suffered damage of about NT$2.4 million and NT$24.1 million, respectively, due to landslides in mountain areas and the flooding of 420 hectares of fish farms in Yunlin and Tainan counties, both in southern Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: CLINTON TO ENCOURAGE CROSS-TAIWAN STRAIT DIALOGUE
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, June 11 (CNA) (By Nelson Chung & Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: US President Bill Clinton said Thursday he plans to ask mainland Chinese President Jiang Zemin to continue cross-strait talks with Taiwan when he visits mainland China later this month.
"I will encourage President Jiang to pursue the cross-strait discussion the PRC recently resumed with Taiwan, and where we have already seen a reduction in tensions," he said.
Clinton, in a speech made at the National Geographic Society, was defending his China policy and his planned visit.

He said he would participate in welcoming ceremonies at the Great Hall of the People across from Tiananmen Square according to Beijing's arrangements because "that is where the Chinese government receives visiting heads of state and government."
"Protocol and honoring a nation's traditional practices should not be confused with principle," Clinton said.
"A stable, open, prosperous China that assumes its responsibilities for building a more peaceful world is clearly and profoundly in our interests," the president added.
He described his administration's choice to take this course of action in dealing with communist China as "both principled and pragmatic."

Discounting opinions that the US should try to isolate and contain China because of its undemocratic system and human rights violations, Clinton said "seeking to isolate China is clearly unworkable .... We would succeed instead in isolating ourselves and our own policy."
"Working with China is the best way to advance our interests," he noted.

Clinton is scheduled to visit mainland China between June 25 and July 3, making him the first American president to visit Beijing since the military violently crushed pro-democracy demonstrations in Tiananmen Square in 1989.

DOC.HEADLINE: TYPHOID FEVER WARNING ISSUED IN PHILIPPINES

TEXT.P: Manila and four other areas in Metro Manila were declared "hotspots" for typhoid fever, a water-borne disease which can be fatal, the Philippine Department of Health (DOH) said Wednesday
The other areas considered "hotspots" are Caloocan, Malabon, Navotas and Valenzuela.

There were 157 confirmed reports of typhoid fever patients, including four who have succumbed to the disease, between Jan. 1 to May 23, said Dr. Eric Tayag, San Lazaro Hospital (SLH) chief of epidemiology.
Tayag said the youngest typhoid victim was a 9-month-old baby while the eldest was 65 years old, although most of the patients fell between 22 and 24 years.
Ninety-four percent of the admissions were from Metro Manila and half of the Metro's cases came from Manila, he said.
As the number of patients with typhoid fever began to grow since January, the SLH opened two 65-bed ward to accommodate victims, Tayag said.
"We also reserved an additional 130 beds after noting no change in the trend," the doctor said.
If the number of typhoid cases continues to grow, the total number of such admissions could surpass last year's figure by a wide margin, he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: YELLOW FEVER EMERGING AS SERIOUS THREAT IN AFRICA

TEXT.P: Yellow fever is re-emerging as a serious health threat in 34 sub-Saharan African countries despite there being a vaccination to cure it, according to British Airways Travel Clinic Thursday.
Spokesman for the travel clinic Dr. Andrew Jamieson said the re-emergence of yellow fever has occurred because of a disruption in national vaccination programs.
Jamieson said the clinic had received reports of two tourists who recently died of yellow fever after a visit to the Amazon region in South America.
"Yellow fever immunization is often regarded as a bureaucratic nuisance by travelers to endemic areas," he said.
"This infection is so easily prevented by a simple vaccination that it is criminal that people are still dying from it," he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: FOREIGN MINISTRY OPTIMISTIC OVER CLINTON'S SPEECH

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Foreign Affairs on Friday expressed optimism over US President Bill Clinton's latest speech on the Taiwan Strait issue.

In his first major China policy address in eight months, Clinton said Thursday that during his upcoming visit to Beijing, he will encourage mainland President Jiang Zemin to "pursue the cross-strait discussion the PRC recently resumed with Taiwan, and where we have already seen a reduction in tensions."
Commenting on Clinton's speech which was delivered at the National Geography Society, Foreign Ministry spokesman Roy Wu said, "We feel positive about it."

Noting that the Republic of China has advocated the resolution of disputes and problems across the strait through rational, peaceful dialogue, Wu said Clinton's speech reaffirms the established US policy and also complies with Taipei's position.

Wu said since Beijing unilaterally suspended regular cross-strait dialogue in July 1995, the ROC leadership had on 114 occasions called for an early resumption of bilateral consultations as of February this year.
"This indicates that we look forward to resolving cross-strait problems in a peaceful, rational manner," Wu stressed.

He added that the ROC already made a public renunciation of the use of force against the mainland by terminating the Period of National Mobilization for Suppression of the Communist Rebellion in May 1991.

DOC.HEADLINE: ASIAN CRISIS A SERIOUS BLOW TO AUSTRALIA'S TOURISM INDUSTRY

TEXT.P: The Asian economic meltdown has dealt a serious blow to Australia's tourism industry with the number of visitors expected to drop by 345,000 and revenue losses estimated at A$1.4 billion (US$830 million) in 1998, according to the Australian Tourism Commission (ATC).

In a statement faxed to the CNA Friday, the ATC said the fallout from the crisis in Australia's tourism industry has occurred quicker than expected. Many would-be tourists in cash-strapped countries are tightening their belts by staying at home.

Australia suffered its first decline in tourist arrivals between April 1997 and March 1998 with numbers totaling 4.21 million, down 0.4 percent from the same period in the previous year, ATC figures showed.
Tourists from Asia, excluding Japan, dropped by 7.7 percent to 1.2 million for the year ending March 1998, according to the ATC.

Between April 1997 and March 1998, tourists from Singapore to Australia rose 8.6 percent to 242,597; the figure for the Philippines rose 6.7 percent to 38,976; mainland China was up 22.7 percent to 70,361; and Indian tourist arrivals rose 15.6 percent to 26,500, all compared to the previous year.
Australia's largest market for tourism is Japan, and the number of tourists dropped 10 percent, or 795,725, between April 1997 and March 1998.
Tourists from Taiwan, South Korea, Hong Kong, Thailand, Indonesia and Malaysia all registered declines ranging from one to 32 percent, the ATC report indicated.
ATC officials believe Australia could only attract 3.97 million foreign tourists in calendar 1998, down eight percent from the 1997 level.

Both domestic and inbound tourism contributed about A$63 billion (US$48 billion) to the Australian economy in 1995-96. This amounted to 7.4 percent of Australia's gross domestic product, the ATC said.
In 1995-96, the tourism industry employed about 694,000 people, which accounted for 8.4 percent of Australia's total workforce, the ATC said.

Tourism is Australia's single largest export industry. It generates A$16.5 billion (US$12.7 billion) of earnings, representing 13.2 percent of Australia's total export earnings and 66.1 percent of its service exports in fiscal 1995-96. Figures for 1997 were not available.
Tourism promoters said Australia's tourism industry would experience a serious blow in 1998.

They added that tourism is expected to grow in 1999 with an estimated increase of 5.4 percent and total tourist numbers expected to rise to 4.6 million by the year 2000 as Sydney hosts the Olympic Summer Games. However, the newly revised figure of 4.6 million is far below the original target of more than seven million.

DOC.HEADLINE: AUSTRALIA'S STOCK MARKET SUFFERS HEAVY LOSSES

TEXT.P: The Australian stock market is expected to fall further in coming days following eight consecutive days of losses which have so far wiped out about A$52 billion (US$31 billion) from the market capitalization, brokers said Friday.
The All Ordinaries Index plunged 34.2 points to close at 2,558.7 on Thursday. It fell another 18 points in morning trade today, brokers said.

The stock market is expected to continue to fall in coming days because of the lingering impact on major stock markets in Asia and the speculation that the Reserve Bank of Australia could raise official interest rates, analysts said.
In addition, the unemployment rate in Australia could rise slightly as more people may lose their jobs as a result of a drop in exports to Asian countries.
Yesterday's decline was also caused by a 78 point fall on Wall Street, brokers said.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN RANKS 27TH ON US' FOREIGN INVESTMENT LIST
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, June 11 (CNA) (By Herman Pan & Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: Taiwan ranked 27th on a list of US foreign investment recipients in 1997, the latest statistics released by the US Department of Commerce showed.
According to figures, American investors poured US$116.56 billion into foreign economies in 1997, up 36 percent from the previous year.
Of the total amount, US$59.96 billion, or 51 percent, went to Europe, with Britain the largest recipient of direct US investment in 1997.

Hong Kong, despite being handed over to Beijing in July 1997, won the most amount of direct American capital in Asia last year. The former British colony obtained US$4.46 billion or a sum 2.4 times greater than that of Japan, the statistics show.

Taiwan attracted US$594 million of US investment dollars last year, lagging behind Hong Kong, Singapore (US$2.96 billion), Japan (US$1.86 billion), Australia (US$1.66 billion), mainland China (US$969 million), South Korea (US$774 million), and Indonesia (US$677 million) in the Asia-Pacific area, according the statistics.
The 10 largest markets of American direct foreign investment were Britain, Holland, Canada, Brazil, Mexico, Switzerland, Hong Kong, Germany, Ireland, and the British Caribbean Islands.

DOC.HEADLINE: CBC INTERVENES IN CURRENCY TRADING; NT DOLLAR UP

TEXT.P: The Taiwan currency took a roller coaster ride in morning foreign exchange trading Friday caused by the Japanese yen's unstoppable decline and intervention by the Central Bank of China (CBC).
The New Taiwan dollar plunged to its 35 resistance level to the US dollar soon after opening at the previous close of 34.867.
The setback led to intervention by the CBC which dumped some US$250 million into the market, trying to reverse the falling trend of the currency, dealers said.
The CBC's efforts seemed to pay off as the NT dollar rose 0.001 to close at 34.866 in morning trading.
However, a prestigious professor in banking in National Chengchi University said the CBC's intervention was not necessary.

Yin Nai-ping said during a national conference on currency issues in Taipei Friday morning that the CBC should not intervene during such a strong market trend which is like going against a stream's current.

He agreed that the CBC should intervene, but he warned that intervention at an improper time could cost a great deal. Yin added under present conditions, it is difficult to predict how much the NT dollar should be valued against the greenback.
CBC Governor Perng Fai-nan personally ordered the bank to defend the NT dollar.
Deputy Governor Shea Jia-dong reiterated that the CBC would take action against "unreasonable" foreign exchange trade. "Now it is the time," he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: HONG KONG THINK TANK SEES GREATER RISK FOR TAIWAN
DOC.DATELINE: Hong Kong, June 12 (CNA) (By Stanley Cheung & Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: Political uncertainty and economic instability have heightened, although slightly, the Republic of China on Taiwan's overall national risks, the Political and Economic Risk Consultancy Ltd. (PERC) reported on Friday.
In its most recent assessment of national risk among economies in the Asia-Pacific region, the PERC assigned Taiwan a score of 4.52 points, on a scale in which 0 is the best and 10 the worst.

Taiwan's June score was up slightly from its March score of 4.43. The score is still significantly lower, however, than the 5.6 rating it received in February 1996, at which time mainland China was conducting missile tests off the Taiwan Strait.

In its assessment, the Hong Kong-based economic and political think tank based its ratings of economies in the Asia-Pacific region on their perceived levels of various types of risk, including internal political, social unrest and external.

The PERC attributes Taiwan's higher score to three factors: political uncertainty, resulting from the growing strength of Taiwan's opposition Democratic Progressive Party; economic instability, the result of region-wide turmoil that has hurt Taiwan's exports; and a worrisome US policy toward mainland China that could compromise Taiwan's national interests.

DOC.HEADLINE: AIRLINES CUT FLIGHTS, PRICES TO FIGHT RECESSION

TEXT.P: Major airlines have taken steps to cope with a travel market slowdown resulting from the recent sharp depreciation of the New Taiwan dollar against the greenback and a worldwide economic downturn, industry sources said on Friday.
Quoting flight ticket reservation records, the sources said the travel market really has been hit hard by the lingering Asian financial crisis.
Against this backdrop, the sources said, several carriers have reduced the number of flights on some routes while many others have offered unprecedented low prices to attract travelers.

For instance, a dramatic fall in the number of Taiwan tourists to the Subic Bay has prompted Far East Air Transport Corp. to cut its flights to the new Philippine commercial hub. The airline now operates only four flights between Taiwan and the Subic Bay per week, with two each from Chiang Kai-shek International Airport in northern Taiwan and the Kaoshiung airport in the south.

Far East has also decided to postpone indefinitely the inauguration of direct flights to Guam in view of continued stagnation in the travel market. The company originally planned to open the new service in late June.

Canadian Airlines International Ltd. is offering especially low prices for its Taipei-Vancouver-US West Coast flights to lure customers. This is the first time in many years that a carrier has offered discount prices on such a hot route during the summer vacation boom season.

Meanwhile, China Airlines said it's not bad that the Civil Aeronautics Administration had rejected its applications for opening Taipei-Hanoi and Hsinchu-Kaohsiung routes, which were filed last year. In view of the recent market slowdown, the airlines said it is not interested in inaugurating such new services at the moment.

Airline sources said although an economic recession will discourage overseas pleasure trips, the number of business travelers is not expected to be affected. Major carriers said they now focus their promotional efforts on courting business travelers.

DOC.HEADLINE: BEIJING HOPES TO MAKE PROGRESS ON TAIWAN ISSUE IN CLINTON-JIANG TALKS
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, June 11 (CNA) (By Jay Chen and Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: The Taiwan issue and the lifting of US sanctions are two areas where Beijing hopes to make progress when US President Bill Clinton and mainland President Jiang Zemin meet later this month, a scholar said here Thursday.

But Harry Harding of the George Washington University, speaking in a seminar sponsored by Heritage Foundation, said Beijing already knows it will not have its wishes fulfilled on several requests concerning Taiwan.

Concerning the lifting of remaining sanctions the US imposed on the mainland after the 1989 crackdown of pro-democracy demonstrators in Tiananmen Square, Harding predicted that progress would be limited.
He said Beijing could expect some symbolic gains from the Clinton-Jiang meeting, the establishment of a framework for strategic relations and progress in substantive issues.

Beijing had originally wanted the US to explicitly state that China must be unified, stop providing arms to Taiwan, not provide missile defense protection, and to bar all Taiwan leaders from visiting the US, Harding said.

The scholar, who briefed Clinton prior to Jiang's visit to the US last October, said he did not believe mainland China will have its wishes fulfilled, and equally important, mainland leaders also know this.

Harding said Beijing will instead persuade the US to officially state the three "no's," meaning that the US will not support Taiwan independence, not support "one Taiwan, one China" or "two Chinas," and not support Taiwan's efforts to join international organizations which require statehood as a prerequisite for membership.

He noted that the level of US officials who have stated the "three no's" are increasingly higher, citing an examples remarks by Susan Shirk, deputy assistant secretary for East Asia and Pacific Affairs, and Secretary of State Madeleine Albright recently.

The question now is whether President Clinton will openly state such position during his visit to the mainalnd and whether it will be mentioned in a statement after Clinton-Jiang meeting, Harding said.
Beijing's wish for the US to lift remaining sanctions against it is "impractical," Harding said, because the effects of the tragedy are not fully gone.
However, the US may agree to measures such as the resumption of guarantee for export financing to the mainland to facilitate trade and investment, he said.
The US is also unlikely to lift an arms embargo against Beijing.

Harding said Beijing will reap its biggest gains on a symbolic level. He noted that Beijing is satisfied that President Clinton is willing to go to the mainland now instead of waiting until November when he will attend the Asia Pacific Economic Cooperation (APEC) forum summit meeting in Malaysia.

Beijing may think the first visit of a US president after the 1989 tragedy signifies official relations between Beijing and Washington are "back on track," Harding stated. But he said Beijing's belief that the summit will diminish the Tiananmen tragedy is obviously mistaken and "impractical.

On the framework of strategic relations between Beijing and Washington, Beijing would like to listen to US views on such relations, including US opinion on the issue of China unification, and how such views could be integrated into bilateral strategic relations.

DOC.HEADLINE: NT DOLLAR DOWN AT CLOSE

TEXT.P: The New Taiwan dollar slid NT$0.025 on the local foreign exchange market on Friday, closing at 34.892.
The local currency opened at 34.865 and had dropped to the lowest 35.5 of the day before the government's intervention.

With intervention of the Central Bank of China, the NT dollar once rose to the day's high of 34.823. However, the effort was then overpowered by heavy buying for the greenback due to an overall pessimistic sentiment amid the Japanese yen's unstoppable plunge.
The interbank US dollar trading reached US$580 million.

DOC.HEADLINE: FOREIGN SPOUSES TO BE COVERED BY NATIONAL HEALTH INSURANCE PROGRAM

TEXT.P: Starting July 1, foreign spouses of Taiwan nationals can join Taiwan's national health insurance program, a Bureau of National Health Insurance official said on Friday.

Lu Ying-wu, general manager of BMHI's Department of Underwriting and Eligibility, said that to be eligible, foreign spouses must have documented proof they are living in Taiwan legally. Also, spouses must have lived in Taiwan for more than four consecutive months to qualify.
Spouses can submit photocopies of documents proving their legal status to the insurance program's underwriting agencies, Lu said.

Another change to the program concerns premium payments for people from low-income households. Under the current system, heads and dependents of low-income households who are members of professional associations, farmers or fishermen or employees of certain companies must pay a portion of their premiums themselves.
Starting July 1, however, the government will pay the full premium of anyone coming from a low-income household, no matter how or by whom he is employed.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAC DEFENDS MOE'S EXTENSION OF MAINLAND SCHOOL RECOGNITION STUDY

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Education's decision to extend indefinitely the period of study for a proposal to recognize academic degrees conferred by mainland Chinese educational institutions is not an about-face, said Mainland Affairs Council Vice Chairman Sheu Ke-sheng on Friday.
The MOE's decision to extend indefinitely the period of study for the proposal is supported by the MAC, Sheu said.
On Thursday the MOE announced the extension, basing it on the grounds that mainland Chinese authorities are still hostile toward Taiwan.
An unconfirmed report on Friday suggested, however, that Taiwan may simply reduce the number of mainland Chinese educational institutions whose degrees it will recognize from 73 to 30.

Former Education Minister Wu Jin, known for his resourcefulness and pragmatism toward educational reform, opened the door to academic exchanges across the Taiwan Strait by proposing mutual recognition of academic degrees conferred by schools from either side.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAINLAND CHINESE SHOP ASSISTANTS PROTEST IN WUHAN

TEXT.P: Some 200 mainland Chinese shop assistants of a state-run market in Wuhan staged a demonstration Tuesday to protest against corruption and unfair treatment to them.

A news release from the Hong Kong-based Information Center of Human Rights and Democratic Movement in China said the peaceful demonstration, which took place at a crossroads in the Qingshan district of Wuhan in central China, drew some 1,000 bystanders and many public security officers. A police helicopter was flying around the area during the demonstration.

The demonstrators said that their monthly salary should increase from 350 yuan (about US$42) to 600 yuan (US$72), since the salaries of middle-level officials of the state-run market have increased to more than 2,000 yuan per month. They also complained about the corruption of their managing officials.
The state-run market, which was established four decades ago, has 1,300 shop assistants and other low-pay workers, according to the news release.

DOC.HEADLINE: OPINION DIVIDED OVER WHETHER CBC INTERVENTION IS WISE

TEXT.P: Economists and investors are divided as to whether the Central Bank of China's aggressive defense of the New Taiwan Dollar on Thursday and Friday was wise.
Strong intervention by the CBC demonstrated its seriousness in defending the NT dollar, said Wang Heh-song, senior vice president and chief economist of the International Commercial Bank of China.

With the support of its board of directors, the CBC sold US$200 million in foreign reserves on Thursday and another US$250 million on Friday to shore up the NT dollar, which has been chasing after a falling Japanese yen.
As of noon Friday, the local currency held at NT$34.866 to the greenback, compared to Thursday's close of NT$34.867.
Yin Nai-ping, a professor of banking at National Chengchi University, said the CBC should follow the market and intervene through currency trading rather than swim "against the current."

The CBC will have to pay a heavy price if its intervention is improperly executed, Yin said, citing last year's "agonizing" experience when the CBC finally allowed the NT dollar to depreciate on October 17 after spending huge amounts of its foreign reserves to prop up the currency.

Investor Liu Tsung-sheng said that a government's policy to defend its currency is no match for international market forces, citing as an example Thailand's failed attempts to defend the baht last year at the onset of the Asian financial crisis.
Liu said government intervention aimed at stabilizing exchange rates will be a wasted effort. The markets alone should determine a currency's exchange rate, he said.
Chiu Yi, a researcher at the Chung-Hua Institution for Economic Research, disagreed, saying Taiwan's government should defend the NT dollar.

Meanwhile, one of Chiu's colleagues, Guo Wen-cheng, said investors should not be overly pessimistic about the market since Taiwan's fundamentals are in good shape. However, he said the government should still pursue reasonable economic policies to direct market trends.

Luo Ping-chang, chairman of the National Development Cultural Foundation, noted that both foreign financial reports and domestic financial statistics indicate Taiwan's economy is still strongly competitive.
He urged investors not to "scare themselves" into underestimating the strength of the local economy, thereby weakening the currency and the market.

DOC.HEADLINE: BEIJING URGED TO PAY ATTENTION TO US HOUSE RESOLUTION

TEXT.P: The Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) on Friday urged communist China to attach importance to a newly passed US congressional resolution pushing President Bill Clinton to demand Beijing renounce the use of force against Taiwan during his upcoming mainland visit.

The US House of Representatives passed a concurrent resolution with a unanimous 411-0 vote on Tuesday asking Clinton to secure a "public renunciation by the People's Republic of China of any use of force, or threat to use force, against Taiwan" when he meets mainland President Jiang Zemin in Beijing later this month.
MAC Vice Chairman Sheu Ke-sheng said the rare unanimous vote indicates that the Americans hope to see the two sides of the Taiwan Strait peacefully resolve their problems or disputes.

"While non-binding to the executive branch, the resolution is expected to exert some pressure on the the Clinton administration because it has the unanimous backing of the Democratic and Republic parties," Sheu said, adding that Clinton may convey the congressional opinion to Beijing leaders during his June 25-July 3 mainalnd visit.

Sheu went on to say it is the Republic of China's established policy to resolve cross-strait issues through peaceful, rational consultations. "We already made a public renunciation of the use of force against mainland China by terminating the Period of National Mobilization for Suppression of the Communist Rebellion in May 1991," he noted.
Sheu also hailed Clinton's major China policy speech delivered on Thursday, saying it complies with the ROC's basic position.

Clinton said when he travels to the mainland, he will encourage Jiang to "pursue the cross-strait discussion the PRC recently resumed with Taiwan, and where we have already seen a reduction in tensions."

Sheu said exchanges and consultations form the cornerstone of Taiwan's current policy toward the mainland. "We have never stopped promoting cross-strait exchanges and look forward to resuming regular dialogue with the mainland as soon as possible."

The MAC spokesman also expressed the hope that a long-stalled second Koo-Wang meeting can be held in the near future. The first meeting between C. F. Koo, chairman of Taipei's Straits Exchange Foundation, and Wang Daohan, chairman of the Beijing-based Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait (ARATS), was held in Singapore in April 1993, during which time the two sides agreed to hold regular meetings to discuss matters of mutual concern.
However, Beijing unilaterally put a halt on a planned second Koo-Wang meeting in mid-1995.
The SEF and ARATS are semi-official bodies authorized by their respective governments to handle cross-strait exchanges in the absence of official ties.

DOC.HEADLINE: FORMER CBC GOVERNOR URGES BANK TO SHOW RESTRAINT

TEXT.P: Former Central Bank of China governor Samuel C. Shieh on Friday urged the bank's administration to be "carefully deliberate" in its efforts to maintain the New Taiwan dollar's stability.

Shieh made the remarks after sharp drops in the NT dollar's value in the wake of a Japanese yen that has fallen to 144 to the US dollar. The CBC, he advised, should watch more, listen more and talk less.
The global economy is filled with uncertainty, he said, adding that turbulence in one economy can affect others. This makes it difficult to maintain a currency at a certain level, Shieh said.

The CBC must permit the NT dollar to fluctuate, Shieh said. Moreover, the bank should make investors aware that the currency's value should be expected to change as it follows international market trends.

DOC.HEADLINE: GAMBLING TAKES FLIGHT ON SINGAPORE AIRLINES

TEXT.P: Singapore Airlines introduced this month gambling on board its jumbo jets with games such as blackjack and poker, as well as electronic slot machines, for passengers on routes to such cities as Tokyo, Taipei and Hong Kong, said Rick Clements, the airline's senior public affairs manager.
The system will be extended over the next few years to all SIA's Boeing 747-400s and 777s and its Airbus 340s, Clements said.

The games have been incorporated into SIA's Krisworld in-flight entertainment system and are available in first, business and economy classes. Each seat has its own telephone handset, which also allows passengers to choose among movie, game and music entertainment channels.

Gamblers play against the system rather than fellow passengers. To begin playing, passengers swipe their MasterCard, Visa, American Express or JCB credit cards through slots in their handsets. After selecting the gaming option from the entertainment system, another swipe of the card sets the game in action.
Bets ranging from US 25 cents to US$3 can be made. Winnings are limited to US$3,500 and are credited to players' credit cards, while losses are debited from them.
SIA is the third airline to offer on-board gaming. Swissair launched its system early last year, while Lauda Air introduced its system last March.

DOC.HEADLINE: INDONESIAN SITUATION MAY AFFECT GREATER CHINA ECONOMIES
DOC.DATELINE: Hong Kong, June 12 (CNA) (By Stanley Cheung and Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: The three economies of the "greater China economic sphere" -- Taiwan, Hong Kong, and mainland China, will be affected if the situation in Indonesia continues to deteriorate, the United States-based consulting firm Morgan Stanley said in its latest analysis.
But the report stressed that the impact on the three economies will be limited. Taiwan and Hong Kong have invested about US$3.4 billion and US$6.6 billion, respectively, in Indonesia.
Meanwhile, the report forecast that Taiwan's economic growth rate will reach 5.7 percent for 1998.

Although Taiwan's exports fell in April and there is concern in some quarters that Taiwan's economy will grow by just 5.7 percent this year, lower than the 6.8 percent recorded in 1997, Morgan Stanley said Taiwan's "terms of trade" have actually increased by 6 percent.
Comparing the island's import and export sectors, prices for the former have contracted more than for the latter, the report pointed out, adding that this will benefit a country's economy.
According to the report, Taiwan's export sector is now facing strong competition from South Korean firms which have slashed prices to boost export volume.

Despite the fact that Taiwan exports to the United States have dropped in recent months, the report praised Taiwan's export sector as demonstrating responsibility for not engaging in a price war with South Korean firms, saying that this approach will help Taiwan companies to chalk up greater profits.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN TRADE DEFICIT WITH JAPAN EXPANDING

TEXT.P: Minister of Economic Affairs Wang Chih-kang said on Friday that Taiwan's trade deficit with Japan is expanding as exports to Japan dwindle amid the ongoing depreciation of the Japanese yen.

Wang said that Taiwan's trade deficit with Japan totaled 17.3 billion last year, adding that this year's figure is expected to widen further, as exports to Japan slumped 23 percent for the first three months of the year.

He pointed out that the economic slowdown in Japan triggered by the Asian financial turmoil has cut the purchasing ability of the Japanese. In addition, the depreciation of Taiwan's currency has been relatively moderate compared to the Japanese yen, which has raised the price of imported raw materials, causing Taiwan to lose its competitiveness.

To improve the trade imbalance with Japan, Wang said that his ministry has been carrying out action programs regarding Japan, including upgrading product quality, enhancing research and development capabilities, and introducing Japanese capital and technology into Taiwan.

He added that Taiwan at the same time should promote its trade with Europe and the United States, since exports to Japan and other Asian countries have declined more than 20 percent since the breakout of the financial crisis last June.

Officials from the Board of Foreign Trade (BOFT) said that a number of other countries have also fared poorly in trade with Japan, pointing out that US exports to Japan between January and March dropped 5 percent, German exports to Japan tumbled 22.5 percent, British exports slipped 11 percent, Hong Kong exports fell 18 percent, and mainland Chinese exports moved down 1.7 percent.

DOC.HEADLINE: SHARE PRICES PLUNGE FOR FIFTH CONSECUTIVE SESSION

TEXT.P: Share prices on the Taipei stock market plunged for the fifth consecutive session on Friday, with the weighted stock price index, the market's key barometer, declining 93.63 points to close at 7117.11.

The setback was caused mainly by the weakness against the US dollar of the Japanese yen, which fell further to below the 144 level, and the Central Bank of China's intervention in the exchange rate between the new Taiwan dollar and the greenback, as well as selling pressure stemming from individual investors in a bid to repay loans used to buy stocks.
The market opened low and maintained a downward trend throughout the session. The weighted price index fluctuated between 7199.48 and 7099.54.
A total of 2.016 billion shares changed hands on a turnover of NT$98.586 billion.
Losers outnumbered gainers 307-104, while 47 shares closed flat.

DOC.HEADLINE: BUSINESS TYCOON MAKES DONATION TO CHENG KUNG UNIVERSITY

TEXT.P: A business tycoon who is also an adviser to President Lee Teng-hui on Friday donated NT$150 million (US$4.32 million) to National Cheng Kung University in Tainan, southern Taiwan, to help construct a new building for the college of literature.

Wu Hsiou-chi, patriarch of the Tainan-based President Group, also presented a miniature of the proposed new building to the university's president, Wong Cheng-yi, during the donation ceremony. His generous contribution was hailed by the faculty and students of the renowned national university present at the ceremony.

While expressing gratitude for Wu's generous act, Wong said that he believes the new building, when finished, will provide the students with a better environment to learn foreign languages and literature. He added that construction of the building will start in the near future.

DOC.HEADLINE: AUSTRALIA TO ALLOW ROC PREMIER TO MAKE STOPOVER

TEXT.P: Australia will allow Republic of China Premier Vincent Siew to make a transit stopover when he travels to ROC allies in the South Pacific, Australia's Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade said on Friday.

In an interview with the CNA, a spokesman for Foreign Minister Alexander Downer said the Australian government has no reason to refuse an ordinary transit to Siew if he and his delegation stop over in Australia on their way to the South Pacific.
He said the department had acknowledged a news report by Australian media on Siew's possible transit.

Taiwan and Australia have no diplomatic relations since Canberra switched its recognition to Beijing from Taipei in 1972, but both countries have maintained close economic and trade ties, and two-way trade was worth well over US$4.5 billion in 1997.
The media report said Australia's ties with mainland China will come under pressure if Siew goes ahead with his plans to stop over in Australia next month on his way to a South Pacific tour.
The report said Beijing is almost certain to object to the Siew visit because Taipei can be expected to extract maximum diplomatic mileage from his presence on Australian soil.

If Siew stops over in Australia, he will become the most senior official from Taiwan to visit. Siew was the first senior official from Taiwan to visit Australia when he was economics minister in the early 1990s. He visited Australia at least twice before becoming premier.

The Foreign Ministry spokesman said the Taiwan authorities are looking at a number of options for a transit stop en route to the South Pacific, but added that no final details have been conveyed by Taiwan to Australia.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT MAYORAL HOPEFULS UNITED AGAINST PARTY FAVORITE

TEXT.P: Three contenders for the ruling Kuomintang's (KMT's) nomination as candidate in the election of Kaohsiung City Mayor united on Friday against the party's intended nominee, incumbent Mayor Wu Den-yi.

In a joint press conference on Friday afternoon, Legislator Wang Chih-hsiung, National Assembly Deputy Su Nan-cheng, and City Councilman Chang Jui-teh, denied that they had agreed to withdrew from the party primary and declared their opposition to Wu's candidacy.

Although Vice President Lien Chan, who also serves as the deputy chairman of the KMT, met with them separately early Friday, they angrily denied that they had backed away from their intentions to run.
Claiming that Wu's candidacy will ruin the party's chances of winning the year-end mayoral election, the three vowed to stay in the race even if denied the opportunity to represent the party.
However, if any one of them is chosen as the party's standard bearer, the other two will throw their weight behind him, they promised at the press conference.

Wang, whose family exercises great political influence in Kaohsiung, said that he and his father, Wang Yu-yun , National Policy Adviser to the President , drummed up more than 20,000 votes for Wu four years ago, but Wu never expressed thanks to them after winning the election.

Saying they agreed with the party's decision to halt the primary and choose the candidate through inner-party consultations instead, Wang said that this does not mean they will automatically support anyone picked by the party.

Four people had registered to enter the party primary in Kaohsiung before the widely perceived favorite Wu declared at the last minute his willingness to run for reelection, prompting the party to halt the primary.
The decision angered the three would-be mayors, who vowed to boycott Wu's candidacy despite attempts by the party old guard, including Lien Chan, to persuade them to back down.

They lambasted Chen Chiung-tsan, the KMT director for organizational affairs, for allegedly leaning on the local court to dismiss their motion to have Wu's registration for the primary revoked, and warned the KMT to gear up for all the negative consequences if it sticks to its decision to have Wu run on the party ticket.
Privately, Su and Chang said they would fall in behind Wang, who is the most serious of the three contenders, to avoid splitting the anti-Wu camp, which they claimed outnumbers Wu's supporters.

Although political analysts do not believe any of the three contestants is a match for Wu, they could spoil Wu's chances of reelection by dividing KMT supporters, thus playing into the hands of the opposition Democratic Progressive Party.

DOC.HEADLINE: BEIJING CALLS FOR EARLY WTO ENTRY

TEXT.P: Mainland China's trade officials are calling on the international community to let Beijing join the Geneva-based World Trade Organization (WTO) "as soon as possible," according to reports from the WTO on Friday.

Addressing a seminar on the Asian financial crisis in Beijing, Vice Minister of Foreign Trade and Economic Cooperation Sun Zhenyu said the crisis has posed a serious challenge to mainland China's foreign trade, the WTO report said.

However, he added, to stabilize the Southeast Asian economy and global economy, the mainland Chinese government has solemnly committed itself to maintaining a stable renminbi and has paid a high price for it.

"The responsible behavior of China has met with high acclaim from the international community, and the best return of the international community to China is to let China join the WTO as soon as possible," the WTO report quoted Sun as saying.

"Without the participation of China, the WTO will not be complete, he noted. It's early entry into the WTO would benefit the country's opening and reform process and its long-term development, and would also help China contribute more to the world in the future," Sun was quoted as saying.

The negative impact of the Southeast Asian financial crisis cannot be underestimated, and the delayed consequences on mainland China's foreign trade sector will continue to show for some time to come, he said.
"China needs two critical conditions to meet these challenges: one is domestic stability, the other is international sympathy and support."

Mainland China's Central Bank Governor Dai Xianlong vowed recently to keep the renminbi stable despite the sharp weakening of the Japanese yen which has worsened the knock-on effects of the Asian financial crisis.

The Japanese yen has fallen below 141 to the dollar for the first time in seven years, and currency dealers cautioned that the drop has put more pressure on the renminbi in "gray-market" forward trading.

Concern is growing that mainland China's export-driven economy won't be able to meet government targets of 8 percent growth unless it devalues its currency to gain competitiveness against Japan and other nations such as Malaysia and Thailand, whose currencies have depreciated sharply.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN HOLDS GRASSROOTS ELECTION

TEXT.P: Taiwan holds its grassroots election on Saturday, with 19,602 candidates vying for 8,755 precinct chief positions in Taiwan Province, and Taipei and Kaohsiung cities.
An additional 6,901 candidates are competing for 3,727 council seats in rural and urban townships, as well as in cities throughout Taiwan Province.
This year's election campaign appears to be particularly fierce, with colorful campaign flags prominently displayed in streets and alleys, and vote-buying described as rampant by local newspapers.

The election is also seen as an important indicator of the strength of the various parties on the island and is thus widely believed to be a litmus test for the year-end legislative election and the Taipei and Kaohsiung mayoral elections.

A record high number of candidates are competing in Taipei City -- 1,231 hopefuls for 435 city precincts. The NT$45,000 monthly stipend which the post carries is seen as the main reason so many people are running.
In Kaohsiung City, 1,136 people are in competition for 664 precincts, while 17,235 are vying for 7,656 precincts in Taiwan Province.

The Central Election Committee of Taiwan Province on Friday issued a statement to show the provincial government's determination to host a fair, open, and just grassroots election. It also called for all parties, candidates, and the public to support a clean, non-violent and non-corrupt election.
The KMT on Friday predicted that the KMT and pro-KMT candidates will grab 70-80 percent of the seats contested islandwide, a support rate similar to that of the last such election four years ago.

DOC.HEADLINE: US UNIVERSITY OPENS TAIPEI CONFERENCE ON ASIAN ECONOMY

TEXT.P: A conference on the Asian economy, organized by the US' renowned Wharton School, opened in Taipei on Friday.

The two-day conference entitled "Innovation & Evolution: Asia's Economic Emergence," will address the region's financial challenges, corporate development, and new technology in the current business environment.

C.Y. Lee, chairman of the Taiwan Stock Exchange, Morris Chang, chairman and president of Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Co., and Dr. Samuel C. Shieh, former governor of the Central Bank of China, will deliver speeches at the gathering.

Wharton School, one of the most highly regarded business schools in the US, has extensive links to Asia. It conducts extensive undergraduate and graduate "global immersion" programs and faculty exchanges with Asian universities, and conducts annual executive education programs throughout the region.

DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER STRESSES MARKET SYSTEM AND ORDER

TEXT.P: Premier Vincent Siew said on Friday that while liberalization and globalization are the approaches taken by the government in its pursuit of economic growth, they should not take precedence over market system and order.
Siew made the remarks at a luncheon meeting with reporters after making an inspection tour of the Tainan Industrial Park in southern Taiwan.

Speaking of the recent slides in the local stock and foreign exchange markets, Siew said liberalization and globalization are the course the country must follow. But he pointed out that they are just the approaches adopted by the government and that they should not be allowed to destroy the market's system and order.

Regarding the dispute over whether or not the government should intervene in the stock and currency markets, the premier said no country in the world, including the United States, can afford to totally open its markets and allow completely free flow of foreign capital without any restrictions.
