Although liberalization and globalization are the world trends and policies formally adopted by the government, Siew noted that the situation in each country is different and that each government will draw up a policy which most benefits its country.

Citing the recent Asian financial storm which has hit several Southeast Asian countries, Siew described it as the result of too much liberty. In his view, those affected countries forgot to maintain market regulations and a system, in their pursuit of market liberalization and globalization.

Meanwhile, in a self-penned press release, Central Bank of China (CBC) Deputy Governor Jia-dong Shea attributed the recent plummets in the local bourse and the value of the new Taiwan dollar to a lack of public confidence.

Responding to questions from reporters on whether foreign speculators are targeting Taiwan, Shea admitted that some of them have been active, but pointed out that a lack of public confidence is far more dangerous than international speculators.

The CBC deputy governor called on the public to have confidence in the government, because "the central bank alone cannot win the battle against international speculators without public support." At the same time, he said the CBC will fight the foreign speculators should they ever return.

Compared to neighboring countries, Taiwan's fundamentals are healthy and sound, Shea said, although he admitted that the local unit has depreciated well below a reasonable level against the US dollar, and urged the public to stop panic purchases of the greenback, in order to help prop up the local currency.

Turning to the local stock market, the ranking CBC official said foreign capital accounts for only 3 percent in the local bourse and that the market should soon stabilize if public confidence is restored.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOEA MAPS OUT MEASURES TO COPE WITH JAPANESE TRADE DEFICIT

TEXT.P: Officials of the Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) met on Friday to discuss measures to narrow the nation's increasing trade deficit with Japan.
According to statistics released by the MOEA, the Republic of China's trade deficit with Japan totaled US$17.32 billion in 1997, an increase of 25.2 percent compared with the previous year.

Of the country's exports to Japan, electric and electronic components for automatic data processors and monitors comprised the bulk, but these exports have been decreasing due to a drop in demand from Japan and the weakness of the Japanese yen.

Major items imported from Japan included electric equipment, machinery, precision optical instruments, chemicals, steel and iron. However, due to the restructuring of certain industries, imports from Japan of electrical equipment for labor-intensive industries have decreased.

At the same time, the MOEA's preliminary analysis indicates, the restructuring of many of the nation's industries from labor-intensive to technology-and-capital-intensive, and the implementation of major investment projects, has generated an urgent need for crucial component imports.
Taking advantage of its geographical proximity to the ROC and its current competitiveness, Japan has therefore become the main source of these components.

DOC.HEADLINE: THAI LABORERS ADVISED TO CUT DRINKING

TEXT.P: A campaign to persuade Thai laborers to cut down on alcohol intake is currently underway in a bid to spruce up their image in the eyes of their Taiwan employers.
The campaign was launched after some local employers complained that they are tired of having to deal with rowdy Thai laborers who have had too much to drink.

Local human resource agencies pointed out that the laborers, with their mild temperaments and willingness to accommodate the wishes of their employers, have long been favored by local employers. But the employers often later find them difficult to manage when they have had a few too many.
The problem is so prevalent that many employers have now turned to other countries for the laborers they need, the agencies added.
Officials at the Thailand Trade & Economic Office in Taipei also have voiced concern about the trend.

They said that at a time when the jobless rate in Thailand has hit 2 million, and the Thai government is actively seeking overseas job opportunities for their nationals, the number of Thai laborers here has declined.
Only about 130,000 Thai laborers are currently working in Taiwan, down 25,000 from the peak period in 1996.

The officials said that in order to spruce up the image of the laborers, the office has been working with Taiwan's human resources agencies and several broadcasting stations that carry Thai-language programs to sponsor a campaign to persuade them to cut down on drinking.
Thai laborers are welcome to either mail letters or call to give their opinions on resolving the drinking problem, or they can promise to refrain from drinking during their working period in Taiwan.

The officials said that the office will broadcast messages during Thai-language programs to remind the Thais to think about their own health and their families at home, and ask them to prepare for a better life when they return to Thailand.

DOC.HEADLINE: TIME REPORTS ON ROC'S STANCE BEFORE CLINTON'S BEIJING VISIT
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, June 12 (CNA) (By Nelson Chung and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: Time Magazine will carry a special report on the Republic of China's basic stance and attitude toward relations across the Taiwan Strait, about 10 days before US President Bill Clinton makes a state visit to mainland China.

The report, which features interviews with President Lee Teng-hui and other senior ROC officials, appears in the latest issue of the magazine's American and Asian editions, which will hit newsstands next Monday.

The prestigious weekly sent a team of journalists to Taipei earlier this month in an effort to give balanced coverage of the Taiwan Strait issue ahead of Clinton's arrival in Beijing, which will undoubtedly bring mainland China into the international limelight.
Senior mainland officials have said on many occasions that the Taiwan Strait issue will be high on the agenda of Clinton's summit meeting with mainland President Jiang Zemin later this month.

The team was headed by Bruce Nelan, Time's senior editorial writer based in Washington, D.C., and its members included the magazine's Asia managing editor Donald Morrison, Hong Kong bureau chief Terry McCarthy, Asia correspondent Sandra Burton and reporter in Taipei Donald Shapiro.
Nelan is one of Time's most senior editorial writers. He has covered news in Hong Kong, Bonn and Moscow, and often traveled to Taipei for news coverage when he worked in Hong Kong some 10 years ago.

Nelan told the CNA that he was impressed by Taiwan's progress in economic development and political democratization in recent years. After learning that Clinton will visit mainland China from June 25 through July 3, Nelan said he had taken the initiative to make a report on Taiwan.
He then contacted Yao Shuang, the information division chief at the ROC's representative office in Washington, asking him th help arrange for the team to interview several senior ROC leaders.

Yao said it is rare for Time to simultaneously carry in-depth reports on Taiwan in both its Asian and American domestic editions. "The move indicates the importance the newsmagazine attaches to Taiwan," he noted.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN-BORN CANDIDATE RUNS FOR QUEENSLAND LEGISLATIVE ASSEMBLY

TEXT.P: Taiwan-born Steven Huang, the youngest among the candidates competing for a seat in the Queensland Legislative Assembly today, is the only Liberal Party member brave enough to battle the popular One Nation Party in Brisbane.

The 22-year-old Huang has defied his Liberal colleagues, including Premier Rob Borbidge, to put the One Nation candidate last in his preference vote, making him the only Liberal Party member to confront the growing influence of Independent Member of Parliament Pauline Hanson's party.
Altogether more than 300 candidates in Brisbane and other cities and towns in Queensland will compete for 89 seats in the legislature.
Huang, who was born in Taiwan and emigrated to Australia with his parents more than 11 years ago, is one of two candidates of Chinese ancestry in the parliamentary race.
He graduated from the University of Queensland in Brisbane, majoring in politics and is now pursuing post-graduate study in public administration at the same school.
The other Chinese candidate, Hong Kong emigrant Dr. Anthony Lee, is a member of the Democrats Party.

DOC.HEADLINE: ENVIRONMENTAL GROUPS REAFFIRM OPPOSITION TO PINGNAN PROJECT

TEXT.P: The biggest problem posed by the proposed development of a new industrial zone in southern Taiwan lies in its potentially excessive water consumption, an alliance composed of various environmental groups said on Saturday.

A spokesman for the alliance, National Taiwan University Professor Hsieh Chih-cheng, said that the development of Pingnan Industrial Zone, to be located in southern Taiwan's Tainan County, is expected to use an estimated 300,000 tons of water per day, which is roughly equivalent to the daily requirements of 1 million people.

The proposed NT$400 billion (US$11.62 billion) zone, which would be the island's largest single investment project, will house the island's 7th naphtha cracker, a steel mill, and its own harbor, if construction goes ahead.

The staunch environmentalist said that the two reservoirs near the zone, Nanhua and Wushantou, could supply 810,000 tons of water per day, but pointed out that even the Water Resources Bureau under the Ministry of Economic Affairs now has mixed views about the Pingnan Industrial Zone's estimated heavy consumption.

He noted that the bureau originally said that the water supply would pose few problems, but later changed its stance, announcing instead that a new reservoir would be built to meet the demand after questions from environmentalists about the water supply for the zone.
At the same time, Hsieh said, water consumption problems in the agricultural sector have long been overlooked.
Some argue that cultivated land is expected to decrease after Taiwan's entry into the World Trade Organization (WTO), leading to a decline in demand for water from this sector.

But he pointed out that in fact, water for farmland has already been decreasing in the past few years, mainly because of draughts, and because of farmers allowing their land to lie fallow in order to plant more profitable crops in the future. In addition, irrigation water has long been diverted for non-agricultural uses.
Hsieh said that if construction of the Pingnan Industrial Zone takes place as scheduled, it could compound the water shortage problem in southern Taiwan.

Kao Cheng-yen, convener of the Green Party, described the industrial zone as a high energy-consumption project, and said that the government should immediately call a halt to its development in order to protect the environment.

Meanwhile, alliance officials said that they will mobilize people from southern Taiwan on Monday to stage a protest in front of the Environmental Protection Administration (EPA) headquarters in Taipei.

The EPA is responsible for the assessment of water consumption and its effect at the Tainan Science-based Industrial Zone, another large infrastructure project in southern Taiwan which is already under construction.

DOC.HEADLINE: SHANGHAI DISSIDENTS HOPING TO MEET CLINTON
DOC.DATELINE: New York, June 12 (CNA) (By David Wang & Eva Chen)

TEXT.P: Six mainland Chinese dissidents from Shanghai on Thursday entrusted the Hong Kong-based Information Center for Human Rights and the Democratic Movement in China with an open letter to US President Bill Clinton, in which they express their desire to meet with him during his upcoming visit to the city of Shanghai and to exchange views with him about human rights.

The letter discloses that during Clinton's Shanghai visit, the six dissidents will try their best to greet the US president, and that if they are prevented from doing so and detained by the public security authorities, they will stage a hunger strike in protest, according to a news release faxed to New York news media by the information center on Friday.

The dissidents said that while Clinton is concerned about trade and economic relations between Washington and Beijing, about the functions Beijing could provide in Asia, and about the Taiwan and Tibet issues, he should be even more concerned about the democratic movement and human rights in mainland China, as well as the thousands of prisoners of conscience still being deprived of their basic human rights by the Beijing regime.
The letter expresses the dissidents' hope that Clinton will listen to different points of view regarding the situation in mainland China, and make more effort to address the human rights issue there.

Although Shanghai's economic growth has enjoyed great success in recent years, the human rights situation has deteriorated more than in most of the other provinces and cities of the mainland, with many dissidents arrested and sentenced to "re-education through labor," the information center's press release stressed, adding that human rights in mainland China as a whole have also started to regress.

DOC.HEADLINE: CAMPAIGN AGAINST SEX AND VIOLENCE IN MEDIA BEARS FRUIT

TEXT.P: A campaign against pornography and violence in the media is said to have borne fruit one month after it was launched by the Government Information Office, GIO officials said on Saturday.

The officials have fined cable TV stations and shops that rent videocassettes and have reprimanded newspaper publishers for violating regulations regarding the publication of periodicals or the airing of programs that contain pornography, graphic violence or other violations of decency. Officials have also referred publishers of pornographic material to the courts.
Theaters showing pornographic movies also have been fined and have been targeted for future observation, they said.
Officials said the campaign has gained widespread support from the news media, citing the media's heavy coverage of the campaign.
The public has also responded enthusiastically, by reporting claims of violations to the GIO through telephone calls, letters and e-mail messages.

DOC.HEADLINE: DEATH TOLL OF ENTEROVIRAL EPIDEMIC REACHES 36

TEXT.P: An enteroviral outbreak has claimed the lives of 36 babies and toddlers in Taiwan over the past four months, the Department of Health (DOH) reported on Saturday.

The department has finished an extensive study of the medical history of 200 patients who were suspected of contracting enterovirus 71 and hospitalized at 23 large teaching hospitals around the island from Feb. 15 through June 12.
"Among the cases, 36 patients have died," said Hsu Kuo-hsiung, acting director of the DOH's Bureau of Communicable Disease Control.
Quoting the study, Hsu said the viral epidemic peaked at the end of May and has since started to decline.
"Suspected cases of enterovirus infections began to surface sporadically in mid-February, and the situation gradually aggravated and climaxed in late May," Hsu reported.
Some 20 cases of the disease were reported during the week of May 10, with 30 new cases reported the following week and an additional 50 cases reported during the week of May 24.
The number of new cases then started to decline with 40 cases reported during the week of May 31 and a single-digit figure reported for the first four days of the following week, Hsu said.
The northern part of the island accounted for the largest number of cases of enteroviral infections, Hsu said, followed by Taiwan's central, southern and eastern parts, in that order.
"As of Friday, 38 confirmed enteroviral cases had been reported in metropolitan Taipei, 32 in Taipei County, 21 in Taichung County, and 19 each in Taoyuan and Changhua counties," Hsu said.
The study also found that 94 percent of the 36 deceased patients had developed a high fever and 89 percent had suffered breathing difficulties, Hsu said.
Moreover, more than 90 percent of patients who have already been discharged from the hospital or are still being hospitalized suffered from fever.

Hsu said further study is required to determine which symptoms are most dangerous. "The result is expected to come out next week, when a detailed report on mutated hybrid forms of the virus detected in the bodies of the victims will also be available."
Hsu also stressed that no dults have so far been infected with the enterovirus-caused hand-mouth-foot disease.
Meanwhile, the China Medical College Hospital in Taichung said it has discovered evidence of enterovirus attacking brain stem of the patients.
"The finding will help doctors to more effectively treat or control the disease," said Shen Wu-chung, director of the hospital's X-ray examination department.
To date, doctors still did not know for sure whether the enterovirus-related deaths were caused by heart failures or brain death.
"MRI tests clearly show that the medulla, mid-brain and pons cerebelli of several seriously ailing patients were all infected and became swollen," Shen noted.

Shen said the hospital has treated more than 1,690 babies and young children infected with the enterovirus since May. Most of them have recovered after receiving treatment. Only three of them who have developed meningitis are still staying in the intensive care ward.

The enterovirus usually attacks children below five years old. It breaks down immunity and can leave infants susceptible to encephalitis, meningitis and acute inflamation of the heart muscle. Early symptoms are similar to the flu, including fever, headache and vomiting. The death rate is low if the patients are offered timely and proper treatment.
Parents are advised not to take young children out in crowded places, and be sure children changed clothes and washed their hands frequently.

DOC.HEADLINE: GERMANY DAILY PRAISES TAIWAN'S ECONOMY

TEXT.P: Taiwan's economy has weathered Asia's economic crisis better than many other economies in the region, reports the Germany daily Handelsblatt.

Taiwan's first-quarter economic growth amounted to 5.9 percent, lower than the government's projection of 6.9 percent, but still significantly higher than that of Hong Kong or Japan. Taiwan is predicting gross domestic product growth of between 5.5 percent and 6 percent for 1998.

As have most Asian currencies, however, the New Taiwan dollar has fallen since the onset of the crisis. Currently the NT dollar is trading at an 11-year low. Taiwan is finally feeling the impact of the crisis, although it withstood the first wave better than its Asian neighbors, the report said.

The report lauds Taiwan's private sector for strong investments that have lessened the effects of a drop in exports. Praise is also given for Taiwan's emphasis on promoting high-tech industries and for its investments in education, training and management.

Taiwan's economy, which comprises a large number of small- and medium-sized companies, has proven more durable than the economies of South Korea or Japan, both of which contain many conglomerates, according to the report.

DOC.HEADLINE: NT NEED NOT FLUCTUATE WITH JAPANESE YEN

TEXT.P: The New Taiwan dollar does not need to fluctuate with the Japanese yen because the two countries' economic fundamentals are different, a senior official said on Saturday.
Minister-without-Portfolio Shirley Kuo, who once served as finance minister and deputy governor of the Central Bank of China, made the remarks at an international seminar on monetary policy.
Kuo said it is erroneous to think the NT dollar's exchange rate against the yen should be maintained at a 1-to-4 ratio.
For one thing, Kuo said, Taiwan's economic fundamentals are healthier than Japan's.
Moreover, Kuo said, the government has pegged its currency exchange rate policy mainly to the value of the US greenback, not the yen.
Against this background, Kuo said, the NT dollar does not need to depreciate in tandem with the yen.
The NT dollar has depreciated by nearly 50 cents against the greenback over the past five days mainly because of a weakening Japanese currency.
Many local and foreign scholars present at Saturday's seminar echoed Kuo's views, saying the NT dollar should not fluctuate with the yen.
They said the NT dollar's recent depreciation was triggered primarily by psychological factors.

Philip Turner, a senior banker from Switzerland, said Taiwan people seem to have forgetten that their country's economy is in a far better shape than many other Asian economies, including Japan and South Korea.
"When many Asian countries raise their interest rates, Taiwan is the only one that has not done so. This indicates that the NT dollar remains stronger than many other Asian currencies," Turner noted.

Ronald W. Anderson, a university professor from Belgium, said the Japanese yen's steep fall should be a temporary phenomenon as the Japanese government is unlikely to sit idle and let its financial crisis deteriorate further.
"I'm convinced that Japan will adjust its monetary policy soon to tackle its economic woes," Anderson said.
The seminar was co-sponsored by the central bank and Academia Sinica, Taiwan's highest academic body.

DOC.HEADLINE: COMMUNIST PARTIES OF JAPAN, CHINA NEEDS EACH OTHER

TEXT.P: The normalization of relations between the Japan Communist Party (JCP) and the Communist Party of China (CPC) after 31 years of estrangement was prompted by their need for each other, observers here said Saturday.

Nishiguchi Hikaru, chief of the International Affairs Division of JCP, and his Chinese counterpart Dai Bingguo, head of the International Liaison Department of the CPC Central Committee, announced the normalization of relations between the two parties Thursday in Beijing. JCP Chairman Tetsuzo Fuwa is scheduled to hold talks with CPC General Secretary Jiang Zemin next month in Beijing.

The relations between the two communist parties began to deteriorate in 1966, when they had bitter ideological disputes. CPC Chairman Mao Zedong said in July 1966 that the United States, the Soviet Union, the then ruling Liberal Democratic Party of Japan, and the JCP were four "major enemies of the Cultural Revolution."

The relations were severed in August 1966, when Red Guards roughed up a JCP official in the Beijing Airport at the height of the Cultural Revolution. Representatives of the two communist parties held talks in 1985 over the possibility of resuming relations, but produced no results.

The relations began to warm up suddenly in December 1997, when Dai said in an article published in the People's Daily that it was possible for the two parties to resume formal relations. JCP's organ newspaper Akahata, or Red Flag, established a branch office in Beijing in February.
Observers in Tokyo said the two communist parties chose to normalize their relations now, because they found they need to reconcile with each other for mutual benefits.

In recent years Japan's major opposition Social Democratic Party and Democratic Party have been falling in strength, while the JCP has been growing steadily. The JCP now controls 26 seats in the House of Representatives and 14 seats in the House of Councilors.

The observers said it is apparent that the CPC needs the help of JCP at a time when Beijing is very concerned about the new guidelines for US-Japan defense cooperation and about Japan's position on the issue of whether Taiwan is included in the sphere of the defense cooperation.
The JCP is known for its long-standing opposition to US-Japan defense cooperation.

Fuwa said at a press conference earlier this week that he will exchange views with Jiang on a wide range of issues, including the problems concerning the sphere of US-Japan defense cooperation, when he visits Beijing next month.

There is a strong correlation between the reconciliation of the two parties and the changing political situations in Japan, the observers said, adding that the CPC wants to use the JCP as a "diplomatic channel" in Japan and as a leverage against the Japanese government.

The reconciliation is also in the interest of the JCP, the observers said, because it can improve its image as an "open party" and thus make it more popular with a large number of "independent" voters.

The normalization of relations with the CPC may not only help the JCP's policy of increasing its visibility in the international arena, but also help Fuwa's hope to build up his prestige as the new leader of the party, the observers said. (BY Chang Fang-min/eh)

DOC.HEADLINE: NEW PARTY CALLS FOR CHANGE OF PREMIER

TEXT.P: The right-wing opposition New Party on Saturday urged the Legislative Yuan to immediately call an extraordinary meeting to decide whether Premier Vincent Siew should step down in the wake of a recent series of natural and man-made disasters.

New Party Secretary-General Yok Mu-ming, himself a legislator, said he hopes Taiwan Governor James Soong will replace Siew as the premier with a view to reducing frictions between the central and provincial governments.

Yok said Soong recently lasked out at the central government for failing to financially support anti-flooding construction projects in several counties, which Soong said was the culprit for recent flooding in central and southern Taiwan. Soong's criticism drew immediate denial by Siew's Cabinet, dismissing Soong's accusations as "irrational" and "unacceptable."

Caliming that the incident indicated Siew can neither control floods nor clarify the responsibility of recent flooding, Yok said he thinks Siew should step down and let a more compentent person take up the post to lead the country to a brighter future.

Yok further said the recent domestic fianncial turmoil has promoted several senior advisers to President Lee Teng-hui to criticize the government's monetary and stock market policies. "This is another indication of Siew's inability to address many challenges and problems faced by our country."
Against this backdrop, Yok said, Siew should show his political wisdom by leaving his post.

Chen Yi-hsin, New Party whip in the Legislative Yuan, said he will meet with the speaker and deputy speaker of the legislature and heavyweights of other major political parties in the next few days to seek their support for convening a special legislative meeting to discuss the proposal.

A spokesman for the main opposition Democratic Progressive Party's legislative caucus said he doesn't think the New Party's proposal can win the majority support in the legislature. "Even if Siew steps down, I don't think President Lee would name Soong to succeed him," the spokesman added.
Meanwhile, none of Soong's close aides would comment on the New Party's proposal.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT MAKES A STRONG SHOW IN TOWNSHIP, NEIGHBORHOOD ELECTIONS

TEXT.P: The ruling Kuomintang (KMT) made a strong show Saturday in nation-wide elections of township council deputies and neighborhood chiefs by winning more than 45 percent of the seats contested.
Taiwan voters Saturday elected 3,726 township council deputies out of 6,805 candidates, and 7,752 neighborhood chiefs out of 19,601 candidates.

In the elections of township council deputies, the KMT captured 1,684 seats, or 45.21 percent, while the major opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) won 149 seats, or 4 percent. The New Party got 20 seats, or 0.54 percent. Candidates of no party affiliation and candidates of other minor opposition parties garnered a total of 1,872 seats, or 50.26 percent.

In the contests of neighborhood chiefs, the KMT won 3,520 seats, or 45.54 percent, while the DPP captured 117 and the New Party received 6. Candidates of no party affiliation and candidates of other minor opposition parties got a total of 4,086 seats, or 52.87 percent.
The successful candidates will swear in for a four-year term on August 1.

The KMT, DPP, and other political parties campaigned vigorously for their candidates in the past week, because they believed the election results will have considerable impact on the elections of Legislative Yuan members and mayors of Taipei and Kaohsiung in December.

Voter turnout in Saturday's elections was 39.1 percent in Taipei city, 57.11 percent in Kaohsiung city, 64.58 percent in other parts of Taiwan, and 65.97 percent on the offshore islands of Kinmen and Matsu.

The results of elections for one township council deputy and 22 neighborhood chiefs have not been decided, mostly because the contending candidates received equal vote. The results of these elections will be decided Monday by drawing lots.

DOC.HEADLINE: LEGISLATORS LEAVE FOR US TO EXPRESS STANCE ON CLINTON-JIANG TALKS

TEXT.P: A legislative mission left for the United States over the weekend to convey the Republic of China's stance on US President Bill Clinton's state visit to mainland China later this month.
Legislator Jao Ying-chi, head of the 24-member mission, said Saturday the ROC is unwilling to see the US develop relations with mainland China at the expense of the ROC's interests.
Jao said the non-partisan delegation will firmly express the ROC's stance and the aspirations of 21 million people on Taiwan who want safety and dignity.
The veteran legislator of the ruling Kuomintang earlier said the delegation would express the ROC's opposition to the "new three no's" policy in meetings with American officials.

Jao said Beijing has been pushing the Clinton administration to spell out in more detail its commitment to the "one China" principle, which runs against the creation of two Chinas or one Taiwan, one China. Beijing is also against the independence of Taiwan and its joining the United Nations or any other organizations involving sovereign states.
Jao said he hopes the US will not just respond to Beijing's new three no's demand, and should also listen to the ROC's position.

He said his mission is to urge the Clinton administration to convince Beijing to renounce the use of force against Taiwan, not to stifle Taiwan's presence in the international community and not to force Taiwan into accepting its "one China" definition.
During his visit to the mainland from June 25 to July 3, Clinton will hold a summit meeting with mainland Chinese President Jiang Zemin and the Taiwan issue is expected to be high on the agenda.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN IS HONG KONG'S SECOND LARGEST SOURCE OF TOURISM
DOC.DATELINE: Hong Kong, June 13 (CNA) (By Jorge Liu and Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: Taiwan was the second largest source of tourism to Hong Kong in the first three months of this year, statistics from the Hong Kong Tourism Association showed.
More than 420,000 Taiwan visitors, or about 20 percent of the 2.18 million foreign tourist arrivals, traveled to Hong Kong from January to March in 1998.
Statistics indicated that tourist arrivals dropped by nearly 25 percent from the same period in 1997.

Mainland China was Hong Kong's largest source of tourism with 595,000 visitors traveling to the former British territory. Japan and the United States were third and fourth with 204,000 and 174,000 visitors, respectively.

Hard hit by a recession, hotel occupancy rates averaged only 70 percent in the first quarter, down from 86 percent a year ago. The figure for March stood around 73 percent, down from 90 percent from the same month in 1997.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAJOR PARTIES SATISFIED WITH OUTCOME OF GRASSROOTS ELECTIONS

TEXT.P: All three major political parties expressed satisfaction with their performances in Saturday's island-wide grassroots elections.

Although the ruling Kuomintang's grip on this level of politics appears to be diminishing somewhat after decreasing its share of seats by about 4 percent to 45 percent, Chen Chiung-tsan, Director-General of the KMT Organization Affairs Department said it was "a natural reflection of the current political reality."

That figure is well above the major opposition Democratic Progressive Party's share of 1.5 percent, and with support from its allies among independent members -- which grabbed the lion's share of seats with 53 percent -- the KMT is still confident in its dominance in the island's grassroots politics, Chen said.

He was especially satisfied with the performance of party candidates in Taipei City, where the number of KMT precinct chiefs was trimmed by only 6 percent despite the fact the city is ruled by DPP's Mayor Chen Shui-bian.

The DPP's 1.5 percent share in the elections does not compare to over half of the island's seats for city or county heads, nor is the figure close to the nearly 30 percent of legislative seats the party holds. However, Kao Hsing-hsuei, acting director of the DPP Organization Department, still takes comfort in the party's slight gain of 0.5 percent.
Kao attributed the party's gain to voters being fed up with the KMT's corruptive ways at the grassroots level. He said the DPP is beginning to expand its power base to the level of community.
New Party candidates won 26 of the 99 seats they were contending, a performance party Convenor Chou Yang-sun called not good enough, but acceptable.
He urged victorious party candidates to honor their campaign promises and to maintain fair year-end legislative elections and mayoral races in both Taipei and Kaohsiung.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN WOMEN FACE DIFFICULTY IN REENTERING WORKFORCE

TEXT.P: About one-third of Taiwan women must leave their jobs after becoming pregnant and they invariably face difficulty when they try to reenter the workforce, participants in a seminar said here on Sunday.
They made the remarks at a two-day seminar on women employment and labor policy sponsored by the Council of Labor Affairs.

Professor Hsieh Hsiu-feng of Soochow University said the traditional role of women calls for them to stay home to take care of the family. When work runs counter to their role as a mother, many women give their top priority to their family.
Hsieh cited statistics released by the Directorate General of Budget, Accounting & Statistics which showed about one-third of women in Taiwan leave their jobs after becoming pregnant.
She said the statistics showed household chores and child rearing were the primary issues which affected women's willingness to participate in the workforce.
When their children grew older, women often found their chances of finding jobs were limited either because of age restrictions or because they found the work schedule difficult to accommodate.

Hsieh conducted a survey which showed that as many as 86.4 percent of women interviewed said it was hard for them to find a job which took into consideration their interests, specialty and the needs of their families.
Some women surveyed said it was difficult to find appropriate work because a long hiatus from the job market diminished their competitiveness, she said.
Only the establishment of more nurseries and a sound social security system will help solve the problem, she said.
Chen Ma-li, director for a women's employment promotion center in Taipei, said there is a huge gap between the supply and demand for women seeking second employment.
She said short-term job opportunities supplied by businesses usually attaches no strings to age, education level or specialty, but they tend to offer lower wages and are less attractive to women.
Those jobs that are more attractive to women will almost invariably require certain qualifications, the most common being good computer and language skills.
Chen also said for women seeking to reenter the workforce, they will have to address the problem of taking care of the young and old of the family.

She suggested that the government and private sector work together to establish more nurseries and retirement homes so women, like men, will not have to worry about their families when they accept work.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN GOVERNOR URGES PUBLIC TO HELP MAINTAIN LAW AND ORDER

TEXT.P: Taiwan Provincial Governor James Soong on Sunday asked the public to help the police maintain law and order to improve public security in the society.

The governor made the remarks during a celebration marking Police Day, which falls on Monday. He also asked the police to enhance their professional training to improve their crime-fighting skills so they can be a real protector of the people.

Soong expressed his appreciation to both the police force and their families for their devotion in maintaining public security. He presented awards to model policemen and model police families, as well as 21 students who were selected provincial "public order angels" at the meeting.
The governor also presented a certificate to Hong Kong movie star Jackie Chan, who was recently elected a Taiwan provincial police ambassador.

On hand to extend their congratulations at the occasion were Deputy Governor Lai In-jaw, Deputy Speaker Yang Weng-hsin of Taiwan Provincial Assembly, Mayor Chang Wen-ying of Taichung Municipal Government, Speaker K.C. Chang-liao of Taichung Municipal Council, Legislator Tsai Ming-hsien, and Tsai Ling-lan, member of the National Assembly.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOEA TARGETS EUROPE TO PROMOTE TRADE

TEXT.P: Worried about Taiwan's declining exports in recent months, economic officials are scheduled to visit Europe to promote trade, the Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) said on Sunday.
Minister of Economic Affairs Wang Chih-kang will lead a delegation to Belgium next month to hold meetings with the European Union on trade and economic cooperation, officials said.

Bilateral trade between Taiwan and Europe has continued to rise since 1986, registering an annual increase of 7.9 percent. Europe has now become Taiwan's third largest trading partner, next only to the United States and Japan.
In view of Taiwan's declining exports following Asia's financial turmoil, officials said promotional efforts in Europe will center on increased exports or a cut in the trade imbalance.

With the economic situation in Japan spiraling down, it would not be a surprise if Taiwan's trade imbalance with Japan hit US$20 billion this year, officials noted. In comparison, the economic situation in Europe will continue to be strong, especially after the introduction of Europe's single currency next year.
The MOEA is urging Taiwan manufacturers to take the opportunity to step up promotional efforts to cut the trade deficit with Europe.
Taiwan's exports to Europe totaled US$18.4 billion while imports from Europe recorded US$21.6 billion last year. Taiwan suffered a trade deficit of US$3.2 billion.

To promote trade, Wang will meet with leaders of the EU in Brussels, Belgium in July to discuss trade and investment problems in electronics, machinery, aeronautics, automobile, and biochemical sectors, as well as proposals on industrial cooperation.
Meanwhile, Chen Juei-lung, director general of the Bureau of Foreign Trade, will also lead a delegation to visit Latvia, Lithuania and Russia in September.
Chen will call on trade officials and meet with businessmen in the three countries to help promote substantial economic relations with them.
He said the depreciation in the Taiwan dollar against European currencies in recent months has made Taiwan's information technology and other industrial products more competitive.
The EU's scrapping of preferential tariffs on products from Hong Kong, South Korea, and Singapore will also benefit the export of Taiwan's products.
Central and East European countries have adopted more open markets and liberal trade rules to facilitate their bids to enter the EU, a trend which Chen said will help Taiwan in promoting trade.

DOC.HEADLINE: THREE DEFENSE CONTRACTORS DETAINED IN MILITARY SCANDAL

TEXT.P: Three defense contractors were recently detained by prosecutors on suspicion of defrauding the air forces in a NT$300 million (US$8.82 million) construction project, a local daily reported on Sunday.

Tung Liang, the husband of Kaohsiung City Councilor Yang Se-yu and owner of the Huatsou Construction Company, was accused of allowing Ou Wei-liang and Wang Kuang-han to illegally bid and win a public contest for the contract under the company name of Huatsou. All three were detained by Kaohsiung District Court prosecutors, according to the China Times.

Investigators from the Ministry of Justice's Investigation Bureau said the alleged scandal took place between 1992 and 1993. Ou and Wang not only took part in the public bidding under the name of Huatsou, but also arranged for another six firms controlled by Tung's father-in-law, Yang Jui-tung, to also put in bids to make the bid appear above board.

The men reportedly bribed air force officers to turn a blind eye to their illegal maneuvering and conspired with them to alter the contract specifications to favor the contractor's profits, the China Times reported.
Tung, Yang and Ou were summoned by investigators on June 8 for interrogation. Tung admitted lending the company's name and credentials to Ou and Wang and distanced himself from the alleged bribery.
Meanwhile, Yang said he was the silent owner of the six companies, and he did not have a hand at running the daily operations. He was released after questioning.
Tung and Ou also denied any wrongdoing. They were referred to the prosecutors and put in custody after questioning.
Wang, accompanied by a legislator from Kaohsiung, surrendered himself on June 11, and was arrested.
A former colonel who retired after the bidding was completed is also reportedly involved in the scandal. Investigators refused to identify him, but said they have a subpoena issued against him.

The construction project targeted in the probe is part of the air force's Chiashan project which is aimed at stationing the country's valuable jet-fighters in a base in Hualien, eastern Taiwan. It is considered less vulnerable to a possible air attack by Beijing than western Taiwan.
The scandal was exposed when investigators delved into another scandal last year involving the armed force's contract for jet-fighter's anti-bombing bunkers.
Several military officers, including a lieutenant general and a major general as well as contractors were detained in that case pending prosecution.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT URGES GRADUATES TO CONTRIBUTE TO THE SOCIETY

TEXT.P: President Lee Teng-hui on Sunday urged graduates of Shih Chien University to contribute their share to help accomplish the common vision of the society.

In his speech at the graduation ceremony, Lee expressed his respect and appreciation to the university for its outstanding contributions to the cultivation and training of talent in the nation for many years.
He added that in a complex social network, each person is a member who cannot be substituted. He expressed hope that all members of the society understand the importance of their own existence.

The president also suggested that all members of the society use self-affirmation and respect for others as a starting point to this end. He urged the students to contribute their abilities and intellect to accomplish the common vision of the society.

Meanwhile, Vice President Lien Chan attended the graduation ceremony at the Tunghai University in Taichung where over 3,600 students graduated. His presence at the graduation ceremony Sunday came as a great surprise to most of the graduates and their parents.

Lien said in his speech that young people should not only dare to say "no," but also be brave enough to affirm matters which are right. He stressed that in an environment of democracy, the younger generation should bear the responsibility of rationality and innate knowledge of intellectuals.

According to Lien, with the coming of the 21st century and as the nation is still changing, the efforts of young intellectuals are needed in raising national competitiveness and creating a new state of affairs.

DOC.HEADLINE: NO PROGRESS IN TAIWAN ISSUE EXPECTED IN SUMMIT
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, June 14 (CNA) (By Jay Chen and Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: Although Taiwan is a sensitive core issue between the United States and mainland China, the two sides are not expected to achieve a major breakthrough on the issue when the leaders from both countries meet, political observers said.
US President Bill Clinton is scheduled to meet with mainland Chinese President Jiang Zemin during his visit to the mainland from June 25 to July 3.

As relations among Washington, Taipei, and Beijing are complicated and sensitive, political analysts said Clinton would not want to spend much time discussing Taiwan. However, Jiang will undoubtedly raise the issue during their second meeting.

US State Department officials recently said discussions will touch on weaponry proliferation, human rights, political and security talks, military exchanges, legal and law enforcement cooperation, economic growth, energy and environmental protection and technology development.

The White House declared in official documents following the first Clinton-Jiang meeting last October that the United States and mainland China had made noticeable progress in the above mentioned issues.

Stanley Roth, assistant secretary of state for East Asian and Pacific affairs, said in May during testimony to the Senate that Washington will not sign any new communique on Taiwan with Beijing and that Taiwan interests will not be sacrificed in the June Clinton-Jiang meeting.

Stephen Chen, representative of the Republic of China to the Untied States, also said the US has reassured the ROC representative office that "there will no surprise regarding the Taiwan issue during the coming summit."

Most important, Chen said, is that Washington has realized Beijing would exercise far greater pressure on it regarding the Taiwan problem if Clinton were to sign a formal agreement committing to the "three no's."

As Clinton will be the first US president to visit mainland China since the 1989 military crackdown on democratic demonstrators at the Tiananmen Square, his mainland trip carries a great deal of symbolic importance in the international community, US China experts said.

Beijing will achieve the last step in its efforts to return to international society, even though Clinton is just to shake hands with Beijing leaders at the airport and immediately return to the United States, they pointed out.

Although Clinton's China policy and visit to the mainland have been widely criticized in the United States and little progress is expected to be made, some analysts urge Taipei to closely monitor the situation.
Richard D. Fisher, a senior China expert with the conservative think tank Heritage Foundation, has warned Taiwan not to let down its guard because there will always be another summit in the future.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN-BORN CANDIDATES LOSES IN QUEENSLAND ELECTION

TEXT.P: Taiwan-born Steven Huang, the youngest candidate in Queensland's polls on Saturday, lost in his first Legislative Assembly election mainly because of strategic mistakes by his own Liberal Party.
Another ethnic Chinese candidate, Dr. Anthony Lee, also lost in the election. Lee, a migrant from Hong Kong, represented the Democrats Party in Southbank, Brisbane. He was not available for comment.
In an interview with the CNA Sunday, Huang said the strategy to put the One Nation Party first ahead of the Australian Labor Party was "a terrible mistake for the Liberal Party."
In addition, this year's elections focused not on good policies, but more on sensational issues propagated by the One Nation Party, which dominated Australian media during the elections, he said.
"This year's elections were much different from the previous ones," Huang noted.
In the Sunnybank electorate, four candidates from four parties -- Labor, One Nation, Liberal and Democrats -- competed but the Labor Party candidate emerged as a winner, Huang said.
He said he finished second, but could not get the precise figure because it would take a day or two to finalize the official counting of the ballots.
"This year's election will offer a valuable experience for me and I hope to have another chance to take part in the next election three years from now," he said.

Huang noted preliminary figures showed he lost only about 7 percent of the ballots to his opponents in his electorate compared to an average loss of about 18 percent by his Liberal Party colleagues in other electorates in Brisbane, other cities and towns throughout Queensland.
"I failed to get elected this time, but I had tried my best to give a good fight during the election. This will serve a good lesson for me in future elections," he said.
The 22-year-old Huang was the youngest candidate among over 300 candidates from different parties competing for 89 seats at the Queensland Legislative Assembly.
Huang said he was still young and could afford to take the time to gain more experience and become a better, more skilled opponent in future elections.
He plans to finish his post-graduate study at the University of Queensland as he has spent much time and effort to launch his election campaign in the past months.
"I will return and hope to succeed in future elections," he said. By Peter Chen

DOC.HEADLINE: AUSTRALIAN PM SEEN CHANGING STRATEGY AFTER ONE NATION'S STUNNING WIN

TEXT.P: The sweeping political debut of the One Nation Party in Saturday's Queensland Legislative Assembly elections may lead a stunned Prime Minister John Howard to change his federal election strategy, analysts predicted.

Howard's plans to announce the double dissolution election in August may be put on hold after the massive show of support for Independent Member of Federal Parliament Pauline Hanson and her party candidates in the Queensland elections.
He was expected to make the announcement to his Cabinet on Monday in Melbourne.
The strong showing by the One Nation Party in Saturday's elections, unprecedented for a new party, virtually guarantees it will win seats in the Senate in the next federal election, analysts said.

According to preliminary estimates, the One Nation Party is expected to win up to 10 seats from Saturday's elections. The figure is much higher than the earlier forecast of two to four seats for the One Nation Party.
Official counting of the total ballots is expected to be finalized in a day or two.

Analysts predicted One Nation candidates would win at least two Senate seats in Queensland if Howard were to announce a double dissolution soon, and two to four more seats in Western Australian and New South Wales.

They believe Howard and his senior ministers are expected to discuss shelving the original plan for a federal election in August. Instead, the date may be postponed to October, November or even early next year.
They said One Nation's unexpectedly high voter support across Queensland will pose a dilemma of massive proportions for Howard and his Liberal Party in the next federal election.

Howard must now decide whether to risk losing further control of the Senate in a double dissolution election triggered by the failed native title land bill or lose credibility in the National Party's heartland by holding a half-Senate election and further delaying a resolution of the native title issue.

Analysts said minor parties such as the One Nation Party have a greater chance of winning with a double dissolution because all the 78 Senate seats are up for grabs, reducing the quota of votes needed for each.
They said the One Nation Party could cash in on the victory of the Queensland election to score wins for Senate seats.

Observers believe the Cabinet's moderate ministers are expected to further pressure Howard to re-think his earlier refusal to direct the Liberal Party's state branches to place the Labor Party below the One Nation Party on their federal how-to-vote cards.
These ministers would argue that the success of the One Nation Party in Queensland elections came off the back of the National and Liberal Party preferences to Hanson's party.

The One Nation's success came at the expense of an unprecedented collapse in the National Party vote in regional Queensland. The National Party is the only party that forms the coalition government with the Liberal Party in Canberra.

Analysts believe the Queensland elections would send the Labor Party back to power because initial figures show the Labor Party winning 46 seats out of the 89 seats at the Legislative Assembly, accounting for more than 50 percent of the total seats needed to form the state government. By Peter Chen

DOC.HEADLINE: SINGAPORE TO FURTHER WIDEN ITS INDUSTRIAL SECTOR

TEXT.P: Singapore will further widen its industrial sector by strengthening manufacturing services under an "Industry 21" program, a trade minister said Saturday.
The program, mapped out by the Singapore Economic Development Board (EDB), was announced by Singapore's Second Minister for Trade and Industry Yeo Yong Bon.

The program aims to push Singapore up the value chain, to ensure that the manufacturing sector remains a key pillar of the Singapore economy. Planners hope it will create more highly-skilled jobs and workers, making Singapore a global hub for knowledge-driven activities.

The manufacturing services to be added to Singapore's industrial sector include: research and development, product design, product development, process engineering, testing services and market research.

"Our focus must widen from manufacturing alone to manufacturing as part of the value added in an industry," Yeo said. He was speaking at the official opening of the new Siemens Matsushita Components plant in Singapore.

The plant is the firm's only surface acoustic wave (SAW) filter manufacturing plant outside Germany. SAW devices are key components in such machines as television sets, video recorders and mobile phones.
Yeo, who is also minister for information and the arts, pointed out that Singapore's commitment to manufacturing had enabled the economy to diversify internationally.
It also prevented the country from being hit as hard by the regional financial crisis "as it would have if we were predominantly a service economy," he added.
Industry 21 program will encompass both manufacturing and manufacturing services, and other exportable services like health care and education, Yeo said.

The program will make sure that manufacturing's share of the Gross Domestic Product (GDP) remains at 25 percent, as targeted by the previous EDB program M2000, which was mapped out in 1993. And it aims to double the share of manufacturing services in the GDP from 3 percent in 1997 to 6 percent by 2010.
About 15,000 jobs are expected to be created each year under the Industry 21 program, and at least two-thirds of them should be for knowledge and skilled workers, Yeo added.

The targets of M2000 -- that the manufacturing sector contributed at least 25 percent to the GDP and maintained an employment share of 20 percent -- have been largely met. Manufacturing now contributes about 23 percent to the GDP and it has an employment share of around 23 percent.
To position Singapore for the future, Industry 21 has been drawn up to replace M2000.

"For Industry 21 to succeed, Singapore cannot be an island. We have to treat the whole world as our market place and talent pool. Our instinct must be to scour the world for capital, knowledge, ideas, talents and inspiration," Yeo said. By Conrad Lu

DOC.HEADLINE: BIG APPLE GETS BIG BASH FOR ITS 100TH

TEXT.P: New York City, the city that never sleeps, will be partying even more than usual next weekend when it kicks off its 100th birthday bash with a host of events highlighting the spirit and diversity of its five boroughs.

The centennial weekend is set to begin Friday with a virtual journey through time at the Children's Museum of Manhattan. A fireworks show the next day is billed as the "widest geographic pyrotechnic display ever," visible from vantage points in each borough.
The weekend will include cultural programs in Brooklyn, dance performances in the Bronx, poetry readings in Queens and history lessons at museums on Staten Island.

Although the city dates its founding to 1625, the five boroughs were not born until 1898, when the rival metropolises of Manhattan and Brooklyn -- newly linked by the Brooklyn Bridge -- were merged with more than 40 individual municipal governments in Staten Island, the Bronx and Queens.
"Centennial weekend is intended to kick off an entire season of celebrating New York City's history, its creativity and is diversity," said Mayor Rudolph Giuliani Friday.

Among the summer highlights will be a July 10 Central Park concert featuring three major city orchestras on the same stage for the first time: The New York Philharmonic Orchestra, the Lincoln Center Jazz Orchestra and the New York Pops.

DOC.HEADLINE: GOVERNMENTS SHOW SUPPORT FOR NEW PHILIPPINE ADMINISTRATION

TEXT.P: Philippine President Fidel Ramos was assured Saturday by high-ranking officials from 14 countries and the United Nations that their respective governments will continue to support the modernization and economic development of the Philippines under the administration of President-elect Joseph Estrada.

At the same time, the dignitaries urged Ramos to be actively involved in international affairs even after he steps down from office on June 30 by sharing his thoughts on the many developments taking place in various parts of the world.
Among those countries that vowed support were Japan, South Korea, Singapore, Russia, New Zealand, mainland China, other Arab countries.
Meanwhile, US President Bill Clinton extended his "special congratulations" to Ramos and the Filipino people on the country's Centennial of Philippine Independence Friday.

In a letter addressed to Ramos, Clinton said he was pleased the celebration of such an auspicious occasion were being complemented by events throughout the United States which highlight the significance of the contributions Filipino American have made to America's heritage.
"I know this National Day is of special significance to you as it comes just before you leave office," Clinton said.

He also said that since General Emilio Aguinaldo first laid out his vision of an independent Philippines on June 12, 1898, the country "has grown into a respected, active, and valued member of the family nations." By Timothy Sun

DOC.HEADLINE: LABOR AFFAIRS COUNCIL CAPS FOREIGN WORKFORCE AT 300,000

TEXT.P: No more than 300,000 foreign laborers will be allowed to work in Taiwan, Taiwan's top labor affairs official said on Monday.

Currently 250,000 foreign laborers are working in Taiwan, while an additional 50,000 have received work permits but have not yet arrived, said Chan Huo-sheng, chairman of the Cabinet-level Council of Labor Affairs.
In the future, Taiwan will allow even fewer foreign workers as the government pursues a policy of promoting the interests of Taiwan's aborigines, Chan said.

Additional foreign laborers, however, may be brought in for major investment or construction projects that exceed NT$200 million (US$5.7 million) in value. Applications to bring in additional foreign laborers will be evaluated on a case-by-case basis, Chan added.
Addressing claims that foreign laborers steal jobs from the island's aborigines, Chan admitted the unemployment rate among aborigines is 6 percent, higher than Taiwan's overall average of 3 percent.

Chan said the relatively high jobless rate among aborigines is not simply due to the government's introduction of foreign laborers into Taiwan. Traditional, cultural and educational factors also contribute to the group's high unemployment, he added.
Of Taiwan's estimated 340,000 aborigines, some 140,000 are either too young or too old to work. Of the remaining 200,000 people, some 12,000 are currently jobless, Chan said.

To help alleviate the aborigines' long-standing unemployment problems, the CLA has put into effect regulations that require construction companies to employ a certain number of aborigines, relative to the number of foreign laborers that are hired, Chan said.

Meanwhile, the CLA has recently begun to survey aboriginal people's willingness to receive vocational training and be employed, Chan said. The government should raise the living standards of Taiwan's native inhabitants by "giving them a fishing net rather than fish," he added.
For several years, foreign workers have outnumbered aborigines in Taiwan, according to unconfirmed reports.

Since the government opened up the labor market to foreign workers eight years ago, some 360,000 foreign laborers have worked in Taiwan. If illegal foreign and mainland laborers are factored in, that figure could be closer to 450,000, according to the reports.

DOC.HEADLINE: BILL GATES TO HELP PROMOTE HIGH-END TAIWAN PRODUCTS

TEXT.P: Microsoft Chairman Bill Gates will help promote Taiwan-made, high-end products, the semi-official China External Trade Development Council reported on Monday.
"Gates has agreed to appear in a videotape promoting high-end Taiwan products when he makes a whirlwind visit to Taipei later this week," said a CETRA spokesperson.
This will be the first time the world-renowned computer software titan has ever spoken on behalf of products from any single country, the spokesperson said.
Gates is scheduled to arrive in Taipei this Friday and will deliver a speech on the competitive niche for the 21st century -- digital nerve system -- at the Taipei International Convention Center.
As Gates will stay in Taiwan for only about eight hours, CETRA will set up a makeshift studio at the convention center to facilitate the shooting of Gates' video presentation.
The CETRA spokesperson said Stan Shih, chairman of Acer Group, Taiwan's leading personal computer maker, helped persuade Gates to star in the film to promote Taiwan products.

Economics Minister Wang Chih-kang will oversee the film's production and present a gift to Gates to express his gratitude for the American tycoon's assistance in promoting locally made products in world markets.
"The video will be shown in future overseas trade fairs and other similar occasions," the spokesperson said.

This is the second time CETRA has invited an internationally respected business magnate to star in its "Symbol of Excellence" series of video programs, which are aimed at improving the image of Taiwan products and boosting their sales around the globe.
Andrew Grove, chairman of the world's top microchip firm Intel, also appeared in a CETRA-produced video to promote Taiwan's high-tech products when he visited Taipei in May.
