DOC.HEADLINE: US SAID TO BE BEHIND MAINLAND CHINA'S WTO IMPASSE

TEXT.P: The United States must bear its share of responsibility for the "cruel refusal" of the World Trade Organization to admit mainland China, Zhou Shijian, vice-chairman of mainland China's Chamber of Commerce, was quoted as saying in a report by the Geneva-based World Trade Organization.
Mainland China's protracted bid for entry to the WTO will dominate the summit between the United States and mainland China in late June.
"The United States must shoulder part of the blame for the organization's cruel refusal over the past 10 years to mainland China's repeated requests for membership," Zhou was quoted as saying.

The US government has exaggerated its trade deficit with mainland China by underestimating its exports while inflating imports, the report quoted Zhou as saying. Zhou noted that last year, the US government recorded a US$49.7 billion deficit with mainland China, while the mainland's tally of the deficit amounted to only US$16.4 billion.
Resolving issues involving the trade deficit "will be high on Clinton's agenda" during his visit, the WTO report added.

DOC.HEADLINE: LEGISLATIVE DELEGATION SEEKS US PROMISE ON TAIWAN ISSUE
DOC.DATELINE: New York, June 14 (CNA) (By David Wang and Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: Republic of China lawmaker Rau Yin-chi of the ruling Kuomintang said on Sunday that the ROC government and people are strongly opposed to any talks or agreements between Washington and Beijing that could hurt Taiwan's interests and security.
Rau, who is heading a 19-member, non-partisan legislative delegation, made the remarks to New York's Chinese-language press after arriving on Saturday.

The major aim of the delegation's visit to the United States before US President Bill Clinton's upcoming trip to mainland China, Rau said, is to make known the Taiwan people's unanimous opposition to any pact regarding Taiwan that may be made between Washington and Beijing. He stressed that the Republic of China is an independent sovereignty and that its future cannot be decided by other countries.
Clinton is scheduled to meet with mainland Chinese President Jiang Zemin during a visit to mainland China from June 25 to July 3.

Rau urged the United States not to sign any accord with Beijing committing it to the so-called "three noes" -- no support for a "two Chinas" or "one China, one Taiwan" policy, no support for an independent Taiwan and no support for Taiwan's bid to join the United Nations. He also called on the United States to continue to sell defensive weapons to Taiwan and help Taiwan join international organizations.

Hseng Fu-hsiung, a lawmaker with the pro-independence Democratic Progressive Party said they have come to the United States to defend Taiwan's sovereignty, while Legislator Chien Ta of the pro-unification New Party said disputes between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait should be resolved by Chinese people.
The delegation will travel to Washington, D. C., on Monday and will meet with US congressmen, think tanks and media during its visit.

DOC.HEADLINE: AUSTRALIAN FOREIGN MINISTER SAYS ONE NATION SUPPORT SPELLS ISOLATION

TEXT.P: Australia's Foreign Minister Alexander Downer has condemned support for Independent Member of Parliament Pauline Hanson's One Nation Party because it means isolation for Australia from the rest of the world, especially Asia.

In an interview with the Australian Broadcasting Corporation, Downer, who is currently visiting the Egyptian capital of Cairo, strongly condemned support for Hanson's party because the party is anti-Asian immigration, anti-aboriginal people, anti-native land titles and anti-multiculturalism, he said.

Downer also said the party opposes the privatization of government enterprises and advocates protectionist measures for the country's farming and industrial sectors. It is also against foreign investment.
The One Nation Party is expected to win between nine and 12 seats in the Queensland Legislative Assembly, which may give the party the balance of power in the state government.
Final counting of Saturday's ballots will take a few more days, according to the Electorate Commission in Queensland.

One Nation's strong showing could serve as a catapult for the new political party to gain seats in the Senate or possibly in the House of Representatives when the next round of federal elections are held.

DOC.HEADLINE: ONE NATION PUTS PRESSURE ON AUSTRALIAN DOLLAR AND BOURSE

TEXT.P: The plight of the Australian dollar and stock market will continue after the stunning election victory of the One Nation Party, which is regarded by foreign investors as protectionist and against foreign investment and Asian immigration.
The Australian dollar dropped to 58.79 US cents in early morning trade on Monday from last Friday's close of 58.88 US cents, market economists said.
The All Ordinaries Index also fell 3.9 points in early trade Monday from last Friday's close of 2,571.7.

Economists said the One Nation Party, established in April 1997 by Independent Member of Parliament Pauline Hanson, has negatively affected both Australia's currency and stock markets with its impressive showing in Saturday's state elections.
The markets have been battered recently by a weakening Japanese yen and a drop in the prices of Australia's commodities and gold, economists said. The Hanson effect is only fueling the fire.
Economist said many investors were now taking a wait-and-see attitude toward investing in Australia.

Citibank said One Nation's economic platform of greater industry protection, subsidies, foreign aid cuts, import bans and curtailing foreign investment and immigration would drive international investors away.

"If support for One Nation in Queensland is matched in other states, concerns about the shape of the Federal Parliament after the next election will warrant bearishness for the A$, bonds and stocks," said Stephen Koukoulas, Citibank's chief economist.
"I think this will cause some short-term pain for the dollar as international investors start to get very nervous about the (Australian) politics," Bankers Trust's economist Dirk Morris said.

Meanwhile, National Australia Bank's chief economist Alan Oster said, "I think certainly if I was sitting offshore, I'd start to wonder what actually is going on and it would be another uncertainty that basically the dollar does not need."

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT LEE MEETS JAPANESE DIETMAN YAMANAKA

TEXT.P: President Lee Teng-hui on Monday met with Sadanori Yamanaka, a member of the House of Representatives of Japan's Diet, or parliament, and praised Yamanaka for the long-standing support and friendship he has shown the Republic of China in the past.

Yamanaka is currently president of the non-partisan Alliance for Japan-ROC Friendship in the Japanese Diet, which was instrumental in bringing about Tokyo's resumption of 72-hour visa-free travel privileges for ROC nationals.

Another change under Japan's revised visa regulations, Japan now recognizes the validity of ROC passports and has authorized its representative office in Taipei to print visa stamps directly into the passports of ROC applicants.

Since switching diplomatic recognition from Taipei to Beijing in 1972, Japan had been issuing separate entry permits to prospective ROC visitors instead of printing visa stamps directly into their passports, a move considered unfriendly to Taiwan visitors.
This increased the workload for the Taipei office of the Japanese Interchange Association (JIA), which represents Japanese interests in Taiwan in the absence of formal ties between the two countries.
With the rapid increase in the number of Taiwan visitors to Japan in recent years, the increased workload became intolerable, JIA officials have said.
The association reported that more than 800,000 ROC nationals visited Japan in 1997, up nearly 10 percent from the previous year.

Yamanaka, a long-time friend to the Republic Of China, once taught at a primary school in Taiwan's southern-most county of Pingtung. A veteran politician, he has been elected 15 times to the Diet's lower house, also known as the House of Representatives.
Yamanaka has also held important government positions, including that of minister of international trade and industry, and has headed the Defense Agency and the Environment Agency.

During his audience with Lee, Yamanaka was accompanied by Lin Chin-ching, former ROC representative to Japan, and president of Taipei's Association of East Asian Relations, a quasi-official organization authorized to handle civilian exchanges between Taiwan and Japan in the absence of diplomatic ties between the two countries.
Yamanaka presented President Lee a calligraphic work by Lee Hung-chang (1823-1901), a prime minister in the late Ching Dynasty, as a token of respect.
During his stay in Taiwan, Yamanaka will also receive an honorary doctorate in economics from Chinese Culture University, located in the Taipei suburb of Yangmingshan.

DOC.HEADLINE: FALLEN NT DOLLAR CUTS DOWN TAIWAN TOURISM TO US
DOC.DATELINE: San Francisco, June 15 (CNA) (By Neil Lu & Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: The depreciated New Taiwan dollar is being blamed for the lower number of Taiwan tourists heading to the United States, dealing a heavy blow to tourism and related businesses in San Francisco, a favorite spot among the island's tour groups.

Since February this year, when the NT dollar fell to a then low of NT$32 to the US dollar, the number of Taiwan tour groups bound for the westcoast of the United States was cut by half, tourism sources in San Francisco reported.

As the Taiwan currency fell further to an 11-year low of NT$35 at the middle of June, tourism sources said the westcoast should brace for a cold summer this year with much fewer Taiwan holiday makers. The number of Taiwan tourists usually reaches its height during summer vacation.
Taiwan tourists appear to have turned to Southeast Asia and East Asia where costs were comparatively much lower for leisure travel, the sources noted.

High-end restaurants in the San Francisco Bay area which had in the past seen many Japanese and Chinese customers, are experiencing a slowdown in business as a result of the greenback's slaughter of the Japanese yen and NT dollar in recent months.
The problem that most worries the US' westcoast tourism sector is that they don't have a clue as to how long this Asian slump will last, the sources said.

DOC.HEADLINE: GOVERNMENT SHOULD HIRE, PROMOTE MORE WOMEN TO HIGHER RANKS: SIEW

TEXT.P: To better serve the people of Taiwan, the government should understand and satisfy the needs of 10 million women and facilitate their entry into core decision-making ranks through various channels, Premier Vincent Siew said Monday.
Addressing the first Women Leaders Workshop, Siew pointed out that traditional patriarchal societies mainly rely on men while neglecting women.

From an economic standpoint, a 10-million-strong workforce is being overlooked. From a national development standpoint, the resulting loss is immense, Siew said, adding that more women should be cultivated to join the ranks of the island's decision-makers.

In recent years, the government began employing more women than men, but at the mid- to high-level ranks, female government employees are still noticeably outnumbered by their male counterparts, Siew said.

Fifty-nine percent of those who passed Taiwan's national civil service examination last year were women, according to government statistics. However, of the 138 political appointees in the Executive Yuan, only 15 are female, and women comprise only 10.59 percent of the total number of high-ranking civil servants.

An American group seeking to protect a merit-based system in the hiring and promotion of employees conducted a recent study. The findings suggested that the "invisible barriers" to the advancement of women in government departments should be overcome by policy tools.
These findings prompted the inception of the Women Leaders Workshop, which is aimed at cultivating female leaders with vision, Siew said.

Workshop director Wei Chi-lin expressed high hopes and aspirations for this "first class in history." Wei, who is also the director general of the Central Personnel Administration, pointed out that the workshop is only the beginning of Siew's plan to instruct the government to cultivate more female senior-level officials.
Wei said his administration will carry out the task of promoting outstanding talented women and develop more channels to cultivate such individuals.

The Women Leaders Workshop is open to high-ranking female employees, aged 50 or younger, working for the central, provincial or municipal governments, or other state-affiliated organizations. Each class has 40 openings, with 14 reserved for women in the academia, enterprise sector and television stations for the inaugurating class.

Four weeks of classes will include national development policies, cross-strait relations, matters related to Taiwan's bid to enter the World Trade Organization, the establishment of Taiwan as a culture and technology island, gender equality policies and seminars such as "how to use female leadership charisma."

DOC.HEADLINE: SHARE PRICES SURGE ON TAIEX

TEXT.P: Share prices opened high and closed higher on the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) on Monday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, surging 166.72 points to close at 7,283.83.
The bourse opened at 7,166.96, and experienced a low of 7,111.76 and a high of 7,283.83 at the closing.
Dealers said the market rebounded under support from the Central Bank of China with electronic stocks and textile issues surging up sharply.
Gainers outnumbered losers by 383 to 50, with 42 issues remaining unchanged.
A total of 1.81 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$89.95 billion.

All eight major categories gained ground, with both electrical stocks and textile issues moving up the most at 3.2 percent, followed by plastics and chemical shares at 2.7 percent, bank and insurance stocks at 1.9 percent, construction shares at 1.4 percent, foodstuff issues at 1.3 percent, cement stocks at 1.2 percent, and pulp and paper issues at 1.0 percent.

DOC.HEADLINE: NT DOLLAR UP

TEXT.P: The New Taiwan dollar slightly moved up NT$0.002 against the greenback on the Taipei foreign exchange market on Monday, closing at 34.872.
The local currency opened at 34.8 and was traded between 34.4 and 34.98.
The interbank US dollar trading reached US$324.5 million.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAINLAND DISSIDENTS WANT TO MEET CLINTON
DOC.DATELINE: New York, June 14 (CNA) (By David Wang and Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: Mainland Chinese dissidents have asked to meet US President Bill Clinton when he visits mainland China from June 27 to July 3, a Hong Kong-based human rights organization revealed on Sunday.

According to a news release by the "China Human Rights Message Center" in Hong Kong, a Shanghai-based dissident sent a letter on June 10 asking the city's public security bureau to allow him to meet Clinton when the president visits Shanghai.
Han Lifa was released by mainland security authorities in April after serving a three-year sentence in a labor camp.

In his letter, he wrote the freedom of assembly is a right guaranteed by the constitution of the people. He said his application to the bureau, in accordance with the constitution and relevant regulations, was for a permit to organize a welcome ceremony for Clinton.

According to the human rights group, Han will provide the bureau with a specific date and location for the gathering and the letter is simply aimed at learning the bureau's intent. However, Han has not yet received a response from the bureau.

Han, in conjunction with five other dissidents based in Shanghai, also wrote a letter to Clinton on June 11, asking to meet him during his visit to Shanghai for discussions on human rights, the group said. The group added that the dissidents threatened to stage a hunger strike if authorities were to detain them again.
Authorities are not only closely monitoring dissidents and pro-democracy activists in Shanghai, but also in other provinces, the group pointed out.
Citing Liu Lianjun in Shandong Province as an example, it said Liu has already been questioned three times and dissidents in Xian say their telephones both at home and work were eavesdropped.

Some mainland activists have complained that Clinton's upcoming visit has not improved their situation, but has instead led to increased scrutiny and a great deal of inconvenience to their work and lives, the rights group said.

DOC.HEADLINE: CLINTON TO TALK TOUGH ON CHINESE HUMAN RIGHTS: ALBRIGHT
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, June 14 (CNA) (By Jay Chen & Eva Chen)

TEXT.P: US Secretary of State Madeleine Albright said on Sunday that President Bill Clinton will talk tough with mainland Chinese leaders about Beijing's human rights policy during his upcoming state visit to mainland China.

Albright was speaking to the Cable News Network in defense of Clinton's decision to be received by Chinese leaders in Tiananmen Square. She said Clinton's appearance in the square was not an affirmation of Beijing's human rights policy, adding that engagement is by no means an affirmation.

In response to criticism from Chinese human rights activists that Clinton will be received at the sight of the deadly crackdown of pro-democracy demonstrators in 1989, Albright said Clinton will make clear to Beijing authorities that "they are on the wrong side of history" as far as the human rights issue is concerned.

"President Clinton will not mince words," said Albright, adding that the president will explain precisely Washington's human rights policy, and will express his hope to see an improvement of human rights conditions in mainland China.
The only way to convince mainland China to improve its human rights record is through trade and diplomatic ties with the Beijing authorities, said the Secretary of State.
"We believe that by engaging with mainland China, that we have a better chance of really pushing them on the human rights policy," she said.

Albright repeated comments Clinton made in his speech last week titled "US-China Relations in the 21st Century," saying that "protocol is not policy," and that Tiananmen Square is where the Beijing authorities greet their visitors. What really matters is what President Clinton says when he gets there, she added.

Clinton is scheduled to arrive at Xian City, Shaanxi Province, on June 25, as the first leg of his trip. He will leave for Beijing in the afternoon of June 26; and will attend a military welcoming ceremony in the morning next day. Clinton will not give an address during the welcoming ceremony, according to Beijing's tradition.

"He plans to make very clear that our relationship with China will never be totally normal until they improve their human rights policy and until they get on the right side of history," pointed out Albright.

President Clinton's mainland China policy, his decision to move up his mainland China journey and to receive a welcoming ceremony in Tiananmen Square, all invited harsh censure from human rights groups and US lawmakers.
Utah Senator Oaring Hatch, who is also chairman of Senate Judiciary Committee, strongly rebuffed arguments made by Clinton and the White House officials.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT LEE OPTIMISTIC ABOUT CLINTON'S MAINLAND VISIT
DOC.DATELINE: New York, June 14 (CNA) (By J. J. Huang and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: Republic of China President Lee Teng-hui has expressed optimism over US President Bill Clinton's upcoming visit to mainland China.
In an interview carried in the latest issue of Time magazine, Lee said Taiwan is too important to US interests in Asia for Washington to weaken its support for the island.

"Although Beijing will surely try to bargain very hard, I don't believe the United States will make any concessions with regard to Taiwan because it is so important to the US," Lee said in the interview with a group of Time journalists earlier this month.

For one thing, Lee said, the US is trying to maintain international order in East Asia. In addition, the US wants to see economic development sustained in the region while trying to enlarge democracy and human rights.
"Our efforts are consistent with US interests in maintaining civility in this part of the world, and also with American values and ideals," Lee noted.

Asked whether he is concerned that Washington might pressure Taiwan to move from talks with Beijing on technical issues to political issues like unification, Lee said it is impossible to distinguish between political issues and functional issues.

"It is not necessary to make that distinction. Our attitude toward dialogue is quite open," Lee stressed, adding he hopes Beijing would show the same type of pragmatism on its relations with Taiwan as it has exercised on its economic reform policy.
"Today their economic policy is based more on pragmatism than before. Unfortunately, this has not extended to cross-strait relations," the president said.

Asked what he thinks Beijing will do if Taiwan's pro-independence opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) gains power, Lee said he has noticed that Beijing is paying close attention to this issue.

Nevertheless, Lee said, mainland China is wrong in its approach. "Its leaders' focus should be directed not to the DPP, but to the people in Taiwan. If they keep trying to intimidate us and equate everything we do with so-called Taiwan independence -- including foreign travel by our leadership and our participation in international relations -- then our people will be alienated. That will lead to a great desire for independence."
Lee went on to say mainland China will find it very difficult in 25 years to maintain the nationalism and hegemonism that it relies on now for its rule.
"Society on the mainland will become more pluralized. In that case, cross-strait relations will grow closer than at present," the president predicted optimistically.

Three weeks before Clinton leaves for mainland China for a state visit, Time magazine sent a team of journalists to Taipei to interview President Lee and other senior ROC officials in an effort to give more balanced coverage of the Taiwan Strait issue.
The team was headed by Time's senior editorial writer Bruce W. Nelan.
Nelan said in an article, carried in Time's June 22 issue, that Clinton is expected to reaffirm his support for the concept of "one China" during his June 25-July 3 mainland visit.
"But he will probably refuse to put that in writing, and he will not agree to stop selling modern weaponry to the Republic of China on Taiwan," Nelan wrote.

In his article titled "Will We Have To Go To War for Taiwan?" Nelan also said that in many ways, Taiwan has been America's star pupil. Under US tutelage Taiwan has has modernized its economy, built a thriving democracy and opened up a free press.

"It is one of the world's leading trading nations and one of the most prosperous. And yet, by succeeding, Taiwan has become a problem for Washington," Nelan observed. "Taipei's dynamic de facto independence may one day trigger a Chinese ultimatum: blockade or attack. It will then be up to the US to decide whether Taiwan's status quo has a future."

DOC.HEADLINE: EPA CONDUCTS INITIAL REVIEW ON PINNAN PROJECT AMID PROTESTS

TEXT.P: More than 100 people gathered in Taipei Monday to protest against the proposed development of an industrial zone project in southern Taiwan in front of the Environmental Protection Administration (EPA).
The protesters, traveling from Kaohsiung, Tainan and Pintung in southern Taiwan, wanted to express their strenuous opposition to the development of Pinnan Industrial Zone in Tainan County.
Some 150 police were on hand to maintain order. No clashes were reported as the protest was generally peaceful.

The EPA was conducting its first meeting to review reports on projected water consumption, water sewage plans of the Pinnan Industrial Zone and its effect on the Tainan Science-based Industrial Park, which is already under construction.

During the meeting, Professor Hsieh Chih-cheng of the National Taiwan University said developers of the project have turned a deaf ear to requests that they submit additional documents to back up their claim that they meet environmental requirements.
The EPA should reject the application for development outright, Hsieh said.

He added that water shortage has been a long-standing problem in southern Taiwan, adding that the Tainan Science-based Industrial Park has already consumed a portion of water originally designated for farmland.

Legislator Su Huan-chih said developers have only submitted a water consumption scheme, but failed to mention its water supply plan. If they are given a green light for the development and later find it difficult to get water, they will be able to ask for national compensation.
The NT$400 billion (US$11.52 billion) development project, to be developed by Yieh Loong Group and Tuntex Group, will be the largest investment project in Taiwan.
The project will house the island's seventh naphtha cracker, a steel mill, and its own harbor, if construction goes ahead.
The EPA will have to hold at least two more meetings on the project before a decision is made.

DOC.HEADLINE: SALARIES OF PRESIDENT, VICE PRESIDENT TO REMAIN UNCHANGED

TEXT.P: The salaries of the president and vice president will remain unchanged despite reports that they could get a pay raise in the next fiscal year, officials from the Presidential Office said on Monday.

The officials were responding to local reports that the two would receive a pay increase of three percent starting July 1 when the new fiscal year starts, the same as civil servants across the island.
They noted that President Lee Teng-hui has repeatedly said he did not want a pay raise and the nation has been paying him generously.
Currently, the monthly salary for President Lee is NT$822,000 (US$23,688) and NT$616,700 (US$17,772) for Vice President Lien Chan.

DOC.HEADLINE: GOV'T SPEEDS UP PROJECTS TO IMPROVE ECONOMIC FUNDAMENTALS: CEPD

TEXT.P: The government will speed up infrastructure projects in the second half of the year to improve Taiwan's fundamental economic potential, said P. K. Chiang, chairman of the Council for Economic Planning and Development (CEPD) on Monday.

Regarding the recent fluctuation in the local stock and currency markets, Chiang said only increased efforts to carry out domestic infrastructure projects, BOT (build, operate, transfer) projects, and military dependent housing reconstruction projects can improve Taiwan's economic fundamentals and promote economic growth.

Addressing the Chinese National Association of Industry and Commerce, Chiang urged the public not lose confidence in domestic economic development in the face of the crisis situations in Japan and Southeast Asia.
Chiang stressed that Taiwan's economic fundamentals are still very strong, and that the New Taiwan Dollar's exchange rate has no reason to follow the continued devaluation of the Japanese yen.

DOC.HEADLINE: CROSS-STRAIT CULTURAL EXCHANGES HELP BOOST UNDERSTANDING

TEXT.P: Through cultural exchanges, both sides of the Taiwan Strait have an increased understanding of each other, Chang King-yuh, Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) chairman,said Monday. The MAC is in charge of formulating Taipei's mainland China policy.

Speaking at a seminar, Chang said since the start of cultural exchanges in 1989, Taiwan travelers have made more than 12 million visits to the mainland while mainland travelers made 32,846 visits to Taiwan. Among those visitors, academic figures accounted for 16,078 visits and performers 8,016 visits.

In terms of groups, 243 mainland cultural and educational groups visited Taiwan as of the end of last year. Among them, performing groups accounted for 146, or about 60 percent of the groups, followed by 41 student groups, and 29 athletic groups.
Cultural exchanges across the Taiwan Strait have helped narrow the gap of understanding between the two sides, Chang said.

He cited surveys saying that half of those polled believed cultural exchanges have boosted bilateral understanding. Meanwhile, mainlanders visiting Taiwan said they were able to gain a deeper understanding of Taiwan after traveling to the island.

DOC.HEADLINE: HK WILL BE THE FIRST TO REBOUND: TUNG CHEE-HWA

TEXT.P: Hong Kong's Chief Executive Tung Chee-hwa pledged Sunday that Hong Kong would be the first to rebound from the economic turmoil now affecting the region as Hong Kong continues to peg its currency to the US dollar.
Tung also said competitiveness was the key to recovery. He was speaking while on his first visit to Australia since he assumed the executive post last July.
Hong Kong's economic growth dropped two percent in the first quarter of this year, which shocked the Special Administrative Region's business sector and community.
Tung said Hong Kong must prove to itself, to China, East Asia and the world that the new phase of its history which began last July with the handover to China marks rejuvenation, not a decline.
In an exclusive interview with the mass circulation newspaper The Australian Sunday, Tung said, "The outlook is for a difficult and painful adjustment."
He admitted that Hong Kong's economy was overheated and overpriced. He blamed "the very high cost of doing business in Hong Kong (on) property values, high inflation and high wages."

A series of measures designed to stimulate the economy and property market have been announced, he said, adding that the Hong Kong dollar will continue to be pegged to the US dollar despite higher interest rates.
Tung said he believes "China wants (the) 'one country, two systems' (formula) to work and that long-term interests of Hong Kong and China are the same."

However, he said he would not accelerate the timetable for the implementation of a full democracy for Hong Kong even though 60 percent of the popular vote went to pro-democracy candidates in recent elections.
During his one-week visit, Tung is expected to meet Prime Minister John Howard and senior Australian ministers to discuss bilateral trade, economic cooperation and other issues of mutual concern.

DOC.HEADLINE: NOBEL LAUREATE DR. ROBERT MERTON ARRIVES FOR VISIT

TEXT.P: Dr. Robert C. Merton, 1997 Nobel laureate in economics, said Monday if Taiwan can successfully handle both the economic and non-economic factors affecting the fluctuating foreign exchange rates, rates will go down and the impact on investors will be reduced.

Merton, who arrived on Monday, was invited by the National Sun Yat-sen University. He called on Perng Fai-nan, governor of the Central Bank of China (CBC) in the morning and paid a courtesy call on President Lee Teng-hui in the afternoon.
The Japanese yen's decline to 145 to the US dollar on Monday has put very heavy pressure on the exchange rate for the New Taiwan dollar.

The Harvard professor refused to comment on the future trend of the Japanese yen or the NT dollar, claiming that his expertise is risk management, not exchange rates. He added that as this was his first tour of Asia, he was not very clear about Taiwan exchange rates.

However, he said in principle there are many ways which Taiwan businessmen can avoid the risk of foreign exchange rate fluctuation. If the government can control both economic and non-economic factors, the fluctuation will decrease, reducing the impact on investors.

Commenting on risk management, Merton said Taiwan has put too much emphasis on trade and has ignored the importance of risk management. He suggested that Taiwan establish a risk management system as soon as possible.
Merton also suggested that Taiwan, through international exchanges, cooperate with other countries on such industries as electronics and automobiles, to turn the risk abroad.
At present, he said, there are quite a few such risk exchange plans in the United States, and Taiwan should follow the move as soon as possible. His idea has won support from the CBC governor.

DOC.HEADLINE: STUDENTS DISCOURAGED FROM STUDYING IN MAINLAND CHINA

TEXT.P: Education Minister Lin Ching-jiang said Monday that the government will not encourage Taiwan students to study in mainland China as the current stage of cross-strait ties remains at a low ebb.

Lin said political motives are not behind the ministry's refusal to recognize degrees issued by mainland Chinese universities and higher-educational institutions. He denied there was a turnaround in the ministry's policy due to the present state of relations between the two sides.

"There has not been a so-called 'policy turnaround' on the issue," said Lin, pointing out that "it is a far-reaching issue and relevant government agencies, such as the Mainland Affairs Council, still wants to further discuss the issue with the Education Ministry."

The education minister made the remarks after attending the opening of a cross-strait seminar on family education at the National Taiwan Normal University. The seminar was attended by Mainland Affairs Council Chairman Chang King-yuh and mainland Chinese academics from Beijing, Shandong, Shanghai, Shanxi, Henan and Heilongjiang.
During the three-day seminar, experts and representatives from both sides of the Taiwan Strait will give keynote speeches and make public their research studies to boost two-way exchanges.

DOC.HEADLINE: DISCONTENT RUNNING HIGH IN POLICE FORCE: POLL

TEXT.P: Nearly 80 percent of Taiwan's police officers would like to change their jobs, according to the results of an opinion poll released on Monday to mark the nation's 20th Police Day.

The survey was conducted by the newly formed Republic of China Police Association with a view to understanding grassroots policemen's opinions about their profession and the general social order here.
The association sent out more than 10,000 questionnaires between April 1 and June 10 to low- and middle-ranking police officers around the island, and collected 6,155 valid responses.
The survey results show that 78 percent of the respondents would switch to other jobs if given the opportunity.
Only 46 percent said they feel proud or honored to be a police officer, while 24 percent said they are afraid to divulge their profession to other people.
Ironically, more than 30 percent said they are dissatisfied with the current state of domestic public order. Moreover, 34 percent said they feel law and order on the island is deteriorating.

Nearly 60 percent attributed the worsening social order to the fact that police officers are required to do too many "side jobs," or official duties unrelated to police work, while 20 percent blamed either improper policies or unhealthy systems for administering the police force.

More than 80 percent complained about the current reward and discipline systems, saying that rewards usually come too slow, while punishments come too fast and are often too severe. They also said the number of promotion channels is disproportionate to the workload.

The survey also found that many respondents hope the National Police Administration will adopt a more humane personnel administrative system, improve the work review system, open more channels for filing complaints or appeals, rennovate all crime-fighting equipment, standardize welfare services in all counties and cities, and build additional dormitories for police families.

Meanwhile, a telephone poll of 1,039 adult residents around the island, conducted by the Modern Women's Foundation on June 9-11, found that local people are most concerned about the work ethics, discipline and service attitude of the country's police force.
According to the survey, breaking of criminal cases is not the most urgent work to improve the image of police force.
The majority of respondents also attributed worsening social order primarily to family and social factors, not police's inability to fulfill their duties.

DOC.HEADLINE: MORE CHILDREN IN TAIWAN DIE OF INTESTINAL VIRUS

TEXT.P: The Department of Health (DOH) of the Executive Yuan confirmed Monday that 38 children in Taiwan have died of enterovirus 71, a deadly intestinal virus, since it struck last month.

Hsu Kuo-hsiung, acting director of DOH Communicable Disease Control Bureau, said his bureau is checking to see whether the death of four other children was also caused by the virus. All of the 38 children who have died of the virus were under the age of six, he added.
Since the virus struck, 205 victims have been hospitalized, Hsu said, adding that 66 of them have recovered from the disease.

The virus, whose early symptoms are similar to those of influenza, has made many parents with little children nervous. More than 200 children suspected of having contracted the virus were rushed to Chang Gung Memorial Hospital Monday for diagnosis, a doctor of the hospital in Taipei said.

DOC.HEADLINE: RUSSIA COULD JOINT WTO BY 2000

TEXT.P: Russia could join the Geneva-based World Trade Organization (WTO) by 2000 but first needs to overhaul its antiquated tax system and improve the legal environment for business, reports from the organization said Monday.

Moscow will also need to improve the investment climate in Russia to attract foreign investors who were scared off by the recent turmoil in financial markets amid concern over a government fiscal crisis, the WTO report said.
Weak shareholder rights, ambiguous property laws and an outdated and punitive tax system are regularly cited by western businessmen as key reasons for their reluctance to invest in Russia.

Top European Union officials in Russia refused to comment on Russia's chances of joining the EU, noting the country was still going through a difficult transition to a market economy. However, they said the union favored broadening cooperation, the WTO report said.

Analysts say WTO membership would secure Russia access to the markets of the 132 member states and, by requiring Russia to conform to WTO rules, provide a powerful lever for further reform of the Russian economy.
But Russia nationalists warn membership could make domestic industry vulnerable to a flood of foreign imports by forcing Moscow to lift tariff barriers, the WTO report added.

DOC.HEADLINE: SAN TOME AND PRINCIPE PRESIDENT WELCOMED WITH FULL MILITARY HONORS

TEXT.P: Visiting President of the Republic of San Tome and Principe, Miguel A.C.L. Trovoada, was welcomed on Monday with full military honors, complete with a 21-gun salute, at a ceremony presided over by ROC President Lee Teng-hui at the Chiang Kai-shek Memorial Hall complex in downtown Taipei.
Trovoada, accompanied by an 11-member entourage, arrived in Taipei early on Monday afternoon for a five-day state visit, his first trip to Taiwan.

In an address at the ceremony, President Lee, on behalf of the government and people of the Republic of China, extended a sincere welcome to Trovoada and his group on a visit which has been anticipated since the two countries established diplomatic relations on May 6 last year.

Lee lauded Trovoada as an outstanding leader who has managed to achieve great progress in improving the welfare of his people, carrying out democratic as well as economic reforms, and expanding foreign relations since assuming the presidency in 1991. The president also expressed his personal admiration for the West African leader.

Lee said that he and Trovoada will exchange views on the current international situation and discuss issues of mutual concern during their talks. He also said he hopes that the visit will allow the West African country to better understand the latest developments in the ROC and thus contribute to the expansion of bilateral cooperation in various fields.
Responding to Lee's address, Trovoada said he is delighted to be making an official visit to the ROC, and thanked the government and people for the warm welcome.

Trovoada pointed out that the aim of his visit is to strengthen friendly ties between the two countries, to expand bilateral cooperation, and to promote mutual understanding between the people of the two countries.

He said that Taiwan's experience in economic development can serve as a model for his country to follow, adding that he believes that he and his entourage will draw inspiration from Taiwan's experience during the visit, which is expected to help his country make structural changes to its economy.

The San Tome and Principe president also expressed belief that based on the mutual desire for peace, freedom, and justice, the two countries will maintain their friendly ties and be able to work together to create a beautiful future.

During the welcoming ceremony, Deputy Taipei Mayor Lin Chai-chen presented Trovoada with the keys to the city, as a gesture of respect and welcome. Vice President Lien Chan, Premier Vincent Siew and other high-ranking officials were present at the ceremony.

Lee and Trovoada will hold formal talks on Tuesday, after which the visiting president will be decorated in recognition of his contribution to the promotion of bilateral relations. In the evening, a banquet will be held in Trovoada's honor.
Meanwhile, visiting Foreign Minister Homero J. Salvaterra will sign a medical cooperation agreement with his ROC counterpart Jason Hu.
Trovoada is scheduled to leave Taipei on June 19. Prior to his departure, a joint communique is expected to be signed between the two leaders.

DOC.HEADLINE: EXPORT PROCESSING ZONE SURPLUSES DOWN

TEXT.P: The Export Processing Zone (EPZ) Administration under the Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) announced on Monday that during the first five months of this year, its trade surplus amounted to just over US$850 million, a drop of 23 percent in comparison with the same period of last year.
According to administration statistics, exports from January to May this year totaled US$3,083.63 million, while imports amounted to US$2,229.31 million, resulting in a surplus of US$854.32 million.

Despite the decline, the administration described the performance at the country's three EPZs as "exceptionally commendable" when compared with the overall national trade surplus, which stood at US$750 million during the same period.
In May alone, the zones exported US$570.6 million-worth of products, a decrease of 9.8 percent from the year-earlier level, while imports amounted to US$434.59 million, an increase of 3.1 percent.

However, the three zones suffered large deficits in trade with Japan, with the total figure plummeting to US$227.19 million during the first five months of this year, an increase of 51.61 percent compared with the same period of last year.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI MAYOR CHEN SHUI-BIAN TALKS ABOUT FUTURE OF TAIWAN

TEXT.P: Taipei Mayor Chen Shui-bian Sunday told more than 2,000 Taiwanese Americans in Los Angeles that he believed Taiwan should go independent for its own future.

Chen, who is a leader of Taiwan's major opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP), also said that, "With its current economic strength, Taiwan should join the United Nations as early as possible."

In his hour-long speech, Chen said Taiwan will absolutely not accept communist Chinese rule. He said in Taiwanese that "Taiwan, China; one country on either side." He said that Taiwan should not be annexed by communist China, and that the people of Taiwan should not become "international orphans." They should become citizens of Taiwan, he added.
Chen, who arrived in Los Angeles Friday for a two-day visit, made the speech at a meeting sponsored by 38 Taiwanese American organizations in southern California.

DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER VOWS TO SPEED UP REFORM OF POLICE ADMINISTRATION

TEXT.P: Premier Vincent Siew on Monday singled out police administrative reform as the priority task for upgrading the morale of the country's police force and improve social order.

Speaking at a ceremony marking the nation's 20th Police Day at the Central Police College in Taipei, Siew said the government will offer a variety of counseling services to help grassroots police officers cope with work-related stress and improve their work ethic.

"We must also establish a comprehensive crime-fighting system and continue cracking down on organized cirme to meet the public expectaitons for a safe, harmonious and peaceful living environment," Siew added.

Noting that the government has felt the urgency to overhaul police administration, Siew said he has ordered the Ministry of the Interior to refer to the police personnel management systems adopted by Japan, Germany and other countries known for their low-crime rates.
Siew also encouraged police authorities to cooperate more closely with other law enforcement agencies and joinforces with private social groups in establishing an effective crime-fighting network.

After the ceremony, Siew went to a hospital in Panchiao, Taipei County to express his concern for a police officer who has been partially paralyzed after sustaining gunwounds in a shootout with several drug traffickers last October.
Interior Minister Huang Chu-wen paid visits to the bereaved families of several police officers who were killed last year while performing their official duties.

According to a study by professor Huang Fu-yuan at the Central Police College, the number of police officers who committed suicide in the past five years was twice that who lost their lives while performing official duties.
Meanwhile, the result of an opinion poll released on Monday shows that discontent runs high in the island's police force.
Nearly 80 percent of police officers surveyed said they would like to change their jobs, and few of them take pride in their profession.

The survey was conducted by the newly formed Republic of China Police Association with a view to understanding grassroots policemen's opinions about their profession and the general social order here.
The association sent out more than 10,000 questionnaires between April 1 and June 10 to low- and middle-ranking police officers around the island, and collected 6,155 valid responses.
The survey results show that 78 percent of the respondents would switch to other jobs if given the opportunity.
Only 46 percent said they feel proud or honored to be a police officer, while 24 percent said they are afraid to divulge their profession to other people.
Ironically, more than 30 percent said they are dissatisfied with the current state of domestic public order. Moreover, 34 percent said they feel law and order on the island is deteriorating.

Nearly 60 percent attributed the worsening social order to the fact that police officers are required to do too many "side jobs," or official duties unrelated to police work, while 20 percent blamed either improper policies or unhealthy systems for administering the police force.

More than 80 percent complained about the current reward and discipline systems, saying that rewards usually come too slow, while punishments come too fast and are often too severe. They also said the number of promotion channels is disproportionate to the workload.

The survey also found that many respondents hope the National Police Administration will adopt a more humane personnel administrative system, improve the work review system, open more channels for filing complaints or appeals, rennovate all crime-fighting equipment, standardize welfare services in all counties and cities, and build additional dormitories for police families.

A telephone poll of 1,039 adult residents around the island, conducted by the Modern Women's Foundation on June 9-11, found that local people are most concerned about the work ethics, discipline and service attitude of the country's police force.
According to the survey, breaking of criminal cases is not the most urgent work to improve the image of police force.

DOC.HEADLINE: 3 PERCENT PAY INCREASE FOR STATE SECTOR EMPLOYEES

TEXT.P: Government employees islandwide will be granted a 3 percent pay raise on July 1, the beginning of fiscal 1999, Wei Chi-lin, director-general of the Central Personnel Administration under the Executive Yuan, announced on Monday.

The salary adjustment will cover more than one million public servants with the exception of the president and vice president, both of whom have expressed their willingness to decline the raise, Wei said.
He noted that the president's salary will remain at its current level of NT$822,000 (about US$23,573) per month, while that of the vice president will stay at NT$616,500.

Meanwhile, in light of the fact that military personnel, teachers in public primary and high schools will be deprived of their tax-free privileges next year, resulting in income reductions, they will enjoy an additional compensatory 0.3 percent salary raise, Wei added.
The adjustment will cost the government approximately NT$20.27 billion (US$581.3 million), he pointed out.

The 1.075 million government employees around the country include 453,000 military personnel, 220,000 teachers and workers in educational institutes, 16,900 workers in state-run firms and 86,000 police personnel.

DOC.HEADLINE: WEI JINGSHENG INVITED TO VISIT TAIWAN
DOC.DATELINE: Los Angeles, June 14 (CNA) (By Chu Ju-sheng & Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: Republic of China Overseas Chinese Affairs Commission Minister Chiao Jen-ho met on Sunday with mainland Chinese dissident Wei Jingsheng in Los Angeles, and extended to him an invitation to visit Taiwan.
Chiao also presented Wei with a crystal eagle, chosen to represent the world's most prominent political dissident's spirit in pursuing democracy and freedom.
During the meeting, Chiao explained the ROC's efforts to promote democracy, and encouraged Wei to continue trying to foster the democratic spirit in mainland China.

Wei, now a visiting scholar at New York's Columbia University, spent 18 years in mainland Chinese prisons before being released on medical parole in November, 1997. He arrived in Los Angeles from New York on Sunday to attend a luncheon hosted by the California branch of the US Human Rights Association, during which he was presented with an award for his work as a fighter for democracy.
Chiao left for Taiwan later that evening after concluding a series of visits to Chinese organizations around the United States.

DOC.HEADLINE: PEACE PRESERVATION CORPS RENAMED MARINE POLICE BUREAU

TEXT.P: In a ceremony held at coastal Tamsui, Taipei County on Monday, the Seventh Preservation Peace Corps under the National Police Administration was renamed the Maritime Police Bureau, covering the same jurisdiction.

The ceremony, presided over by Minister of the Interior Huang Chu-weng, featured the unveiling of a new official nameplate and the promotion of the corps' commander Chung Tung-sheng to director of the new bureau.

Speaking at the ceremony, Huang took note of last year's record haul of contraband by the corps, including more than 1,000 handguns, about 4,000 rounds of ammunition, 20 kilograms of heroin and more than 200 kilograms of amphetamine.

Stemming the influx of contraband at sea is easier than tracking it down once it arrives on land, and makes it easier to maintain the island's law and order, which is why the government made the decision to enlarge the corps into a bureau, Huang said.

The new status of the marine police will provide them with more resources to fight smuggling and poaching, he added, while urging the marine police to improve their professional skills as well as their knowledge of the law in order to remain capable of carrying out their duties.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN'S FIRST QUARTER EXPORTS TRAIL OTHER ASIAN DRAGONS

TEXT.P: The falling value of the new Taiwan dollar is biting into the island's economy, with exports falling behind its "Asian dragon" counterparts, according to statistics released on Monday.

The figures prepared by the Ministry of Economic Affairs show that Taiwan's exports declined by 6.7 percent in the first quarter of this year, compared to a 6.5 percent gain for Singapore, 8.2 percent growth for South Korea, and a 3 percent decline for Hong Kong.
Economic officials attributed the decline to the devaluation of the local currency which has driven up the cost of raw material imports and blunted the island's competitive edge.

Many of the island's exports are manufactured from imported raw materials or components, and the rising price of these imports has seriously damaged the competitiveness of the country's exports on international markets, the officials said.

The new Taiwan dollar depreciated from 28 against the US dollar last year to more than 34 against the greenback in early June, much less than the devaluation of the South Korean but more than the Hong Kong and Singapore currencies.

DOC.HEADLINE: EXPORTS TO JAPAN DWINDLING AMID YEN DEPRECIATION

TEXT.P: Exports to Japan have dwindled in recent months because of the ongoing depreciation of the Japanese yen, leading to a larger trade deficit between Taiwan and Japan, the Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) said on Monday.

According to statistics released by the China External Trade and Development Council (CETRA), the export items to Japan that have suffered the most significant drops are computers and component parts, Integrated Circuits (ICs), frozen fish, furniture, sporting goods, and transistors.

Officials from the Board of Foreign Trade (BOFT) under the MOEA attributed the decline of exports mainly to Japan's economic slowdown and the depreciation of the yen. They pointed out that the economic sluggishness triggered by the Asian financial turmoil has cut the purchasing ability of many Japanese, while the yen's heavy depreciation, compared to the modest slide of the new Taiwan dollar, has made Taiwan's products lose the competitiveness they used to enjoy.

In order to promote Taiwan's exports to Japan, the BOFT has scheduled 26 promotion missions to attend a variety of exhibitions in Japan in the second half of the year and the beginning of next year. In addition, the BOFT is also pushing for a number of strategic cooperation alliances in various fields between the industries of the two countries.

Faced with a 23 percent plunge in exports to Japan for the first three months of the year, BOFT officials said that Taiwan must continue to upgrade product quality, enhance research and development capabilities, and make efforts to usher in Japanese capital and technology.

DOC.HEADLINE: NEW ZEALAND COURTING TAIWAN INVESTMENT IN BIOTECHNOLOGY DEVELOPMENT

TEXT.P: Visiting New Zealand Trade Minister Lockwood Smith on Monday explored the opportunities for the pharmaceutical sectors of the Republic of China and New Zealand to cooperate in biotechnological development.

At a seminar sponsored by the Ministry of Economic Affairs, Smith, visiting at the head of a mission comprising a number of New Zealand pharmaceutical company officials, made a case for why Taiwan pharmaceutical companies should invest in his country.

At the beginning of the seminar, Smith introduced his country's investment environment to a group of local pharmaceutical company representatives, saying that New Zealand has made great progress in biotechnological development during the past decade and that his government encourages foreigners to invest in the high-tech industry by offering low tariff incentives.

The local representatives at the seminar showed keen interest in Smith's proposal, and agreed to conduct a fact-finding trip to New Zealand in September to gain a better understanding of the country's investment environment.
Taiwan's government has been pushing for biotechnological development, and has plans to invest NT$20 billion over five years to help the local pharmaceutical industry.

DOC.HEADLINE: PROBLEM OF MOTORCYCLE MANAGEMENT TO BE ADDRESSED

TEXT.P: With over 10 million motorcycles in Taiwan, an average of one for every two persons, the Ministry of Transportation and Communications said it is important to address the needs of motorcycle riders and have a sound management policy.
The ministry's Institute of Transportation has been instructed to map out a policy in the next three months. It will include the planning of exclusive lanes, and parking for motorcycles.

Ministry officials noted that after Taipei designated separate lanes for buses, the traffic situation showed a marked improvement. The success of this program has led other cities and counties to consider following suit.

However, the right to set up exclusive lanes for motorcycles lie with the local city government, officials said, adding the ministry can only help establish exclusive lanes and parking lots if required.
They said nearly half of Taiwan residents ride motorcycles, and the management for the huge amount of motorcycles has become a problem for traffic management.
Statistics showed that most of motorcycle riders are under 40 years old and are high school graduates. They ride on average 5.3 days a week and 9.2 kilometers per day.

DOC.HEADLINE: LEGISLATIVE MISSION VISITS US CAPITAL
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, June 15 (CNA) (By K. C. Huang and Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: A non-partisan legislative mission from the Republic of China arrived here Monday to seek a US promise not to compromise Taiwan's interests when US President Bill Clinton meets mainland Chinese President Jiang Zemin later this month.

Rau Yin-chi, a ruling Kuomintang lawmaker and leader of the 19-member delegation, will first be briefed by the ROC representative office here. He will then visit major think thanks on Tuesday and on Wednesday, the delegation will meet US congressmen and officials to relay the ROC government's stance on the Clinton-Jiang meeting.

Stephen Chen, ROC representative to the United States, said Washington has reassured Taipei there will be no surprise development on the Taiwan issue when Clinton and Jiang meet on June 27. US officials have also repeatedly said that Washington will not improve its relations with Beijing at the cost of Taiwan's interest, Chen said.

Before arriving in Washington, the delegation made a one-day stopover in New York where they met with senior editors of Newsweek and Business Week as well as US foreign policy experts Monday morning. They exchanged their opinions on the relations among Taipei, Washington and Beijing.

Rau told representatives of the two leading magazines and academics in attendance that the ROC has no intention of interfering in the US' foreign policy, but is strongly opposed to any engagement with mainland China at the expense of Taiwan.

Expressing appreciation for the US' long-term support for Taiwan in the past, the KMT legislator said Taipei will never accept any deal between Washington and Beijing which could damage Taiwan's sovereignty and security.
He called on the US to demand that Beijing renounce its threat of military force against Taiwan and help the island to join international organizations.
