DOC.HEADLINE: FOREIGN MINISTRY MUM ON FREEMAN'S OVERTURE

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) on Tuesday kept mum on a former American official's call for a review of US arms sales to Taiwan.

Chas W. Freeman Jr., a former diplomat who served as deputy chief of the US Embassy in Beijing from 1981 to 1984, said in an article in the latest issue of Foreign Affairs bimonthly that the United States should reevaluate its arms sales policy to Taiwan in accordance with the 1982 Washington-Beijing joint communique.

Freeman said US arms sales to Taiwan no longer boost the island's confidence that it can work out its differences with Beijing. Instead, he claimed such sales would only enhance pro-independence sentiments in Taiwan.
In response to press inquiries, MOFA officials said they would not respond to Freeman's comments now that he is a private citizen and no longer holds any government position.

Freeman, who also once served as an assistant secretary of defense and is currently co-chair of the United States-(mainland) China Policy Foundation, asserted in his article that the US sale of 150 F-16 fighters to Taiwan in 1992 and some subsequent deals do not comply with the 1982 communique.
In that communique, Beijing pledged to "strive for a peaceful solution to the Taiwan question," and in return the US promised to cap the quantity and sophistication of its arms sales to Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI CITY MAYOR CHEN SHUI-BIAN CONFIDENT OF ANOTHER MANDATE

TEXT.P: Taipei City Mayor Chen Shui-bian said Tuesday he is confident that he will be given another mandate in the year-end mayoral election.
Chen, who returned from a whirlwind visit of the US early on Tuesday, made the remarks during a weekly meeting of the Taipei City Government.
He said his performance over the past three years has won support and recognition from Taipei city residents and overseas compatriots.
Chen was invited by National Taiwan University alumni associations located on the west coast of the US. He left for Los Angeles Saturday.
No official activities were arranged for Chen due to his short stay in the US. Instead, he gave two speeches to the alumni associations.
Chen said the support he has gained is not a result of his efforts alone, as it has not come without extensive teamwork.
He stressed that the year-end election will be a new challenge to the Taipei City Government, and will be a chance to review the administration's works in the past three years.

He reminded department heads on hand to listen to public criticism and try to improve in these areas if they are valid. He also asked that they clarify false accusations so the city government's image is not tarnished.
Chen would not elaborate on the remarks he made in Los Angeles that he would "serve to the full term of Taipei City mayor" if he is reelected.
The popular Taipei city mayor of the opposition Democratic Progressive Party is widely tipped to represent the party in the presidential election slated for 2000.

DOC.HEADLINE: US-MAINLAND TIES TO IMPROVE WITHOUT HURTING TAIWAN: NEW DPP CHIEF

TEXT.P: The chairman-elect of the Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) Lin Yih-hsiung said Tuesday the United States and mainland China should improve their bilateral relations without hurting Taiwan's interests.
Stressing that Taiwan is an independent sovereign state, Lin said the promotion of relations between the United States and the mainland should not be made at Taiwan's expense.
If Beijing and Washington leaders strike any deals running counter to Taiwan's interests in the upcoming summit in Beijing in late June, the two countries' national images will be seriously damaged.

Lin said he believes the increasing engagement between the United States and the mainland will prompt Beijing to assume larger responsibility in the international community, which will in turn serve global interests.

Although Taiwan is not widely recognized as a sovereign state among countries in the international community, the island should continue to play the role of a responsible and constructive global member in hopes to win more international support, he noted.

The DPP chairman-elect said he is optimistic Taiwan's efforts will lead the world and mainland authorities to realize there is no need to use force against Taiwan and that such an act would not be justified.

DOC.HEADLINE: SOAS AT LONDON UNIVERSITY ESTABLISHES CHAIR FOR TAIWAN STUDIES

TEXT.P: The School of Oriental and African Studies (SOAS) at the University of London on Monday signed an agreement with a Taiwan representative to establish a chair for Taiwan Studies.

In signing the agreement, Sir Tim Lankester, director of the SOAS, said the study of Taiwan has long been a feature of SOAS academic activities and an increasingly important one in its China programs.

In the United Kingdom, he said, there has been a strong interest in Taiwan's democratic process, its impressive economic achievements, its relations with mainland China and its role in the Asia Pacific region.
Companies from Taiwan are major investors in the UK and their growing presence is having a greater impact on the communities in which they are active, added Sir Tim.

It is with this understanding that despite its fine existing body of China scholars, an enhancement of academic staff in contemporary Taiwan studies is required to address this growing interest, he stated.

According to the agreement signed by Sir Tim and Louis Tzen, representative of the Taipei Representative Office in the UK, Taipei is to set up a fund of 300,000 pounds sterling in three years. The project will focus on subjects ranging from economic development in Taiwan and the status of Taiwan in international law to relations between Taiwan and mainland China.
Tzen said the agreement opens up a new chapter of academic cooperation between the two sides.
He expressed the hope that the SOAS will add its rich resources and insight to Taiwan studies.

The chair for Taiwan studies at the SOAS is a continuation of the long friendship between the institution and the people of Taiwan. Currently, there are more than two dozen Taiwan students in SOAS, and it has more than 100 alumni from Taiwan, he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: TUNG CHEE-HWA TALKS ABOUT AUSSIE SUCCESS IN ASIA

TEXT.P: Tung Chee-Hwa, chief executive of the Hong Kong Special Administrative Region, talked about Australia's success in Asia Monday in Canberra.
When asked about the impact of the strong electoral showing of the One Nation Party, Tung on Monday said he could only comment within diplomatic constraints because he was a guest in Australia.

In a clear reference to the One Nation's advocacy of economic and social isolationism, he said: "I know many of you in Australia are having a debate about what you are and who you are. From the Hong Kong perspective, you are a very important member of the Asia-Pacific region."

"You have a unique position. You understand the cultures and religions of your neighbors and you are able to understand them even when they are very different to your own. Because of that, you have been very effective facilitators in the region.
"Let me say this. Australia has been successful because it has been very tolerant and multicultural. Your strength is here and I can't imagine Australia moving away from that," he said
About the One Nation's impact on Hong Kong students, Tung said, "I understand the One Nation Party had 23 percent of the vote; so the other 77 percent must be saying something else."
He praised the 30,000 Australian citizens currently residing in Hong Kong, and said the relationship between those residents and the Hong Kong population would not likely change.
He added that there was a tremendous two-way traffic of investment, trade and people between Australia and Hong Kong.

Tung, who is making his first visit to Australia since taking his present job in July 1997, is expected to give another speech in Melbourne Tuesday and meet Victoria Premier Jeff Kennett and other officials.

DOC.HEADLINE: AUSTRALIA'S TOURISM TO SUFFER LOSSES FROM ONE NATION VICTORY

TEXT.P: The unprecedented election victory of the One Nation Party has contributed to the worry that Asian tourists will avoid visiting Australia, tourism sources said.

Tourism officials and promoters have asked the federal government to reject what they called racist policies of the One Nation Party in a bid to prevent further damage to Australia's tourism, which has already suffered a substantial decline in the number of arrivals and revenue.
Earlier forecasts show the number of tourist arrivals in Australia in 1998 will fall about 8 percent to more than 3.97 million from the 1997 level.
Tourism promoters said they expect the earlier forecast will be revised to a lower figure as a result of the strong showing of the One Nation Party in Queensland elections on June 13.

In the past two years, the tourism industry has experienced a 25 percent drop in tourist arrivals from Taiwan, Hong Kong, Singapore, and Malaysia, which accounted for about 10 percent of tourism's annual foreign earnings of A$16 billion (US$10 billion).
"There will be some impact on tourism numbers on top of what we have already suffered. It does not fill us with a lot of hope," Len Taylor of the Tourism Organization of Australia told reporters.

DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER SIEW URGES TECHNOLOGICAL INNOVATIONS, IMPROVED MANAGEMENT

TEXT.P: To maintain its national competitiveness, Taiwan should continue to develop technology-intensive industries and efficient resource management techniques as it makes its way to being a wealthy and powerful "technology island," Premier Vincent Siew said.

Addressing a seminar on industrial technology research and development management, Siew said Taiwan should develop its electronic, information and biotechnology industries in coordination with plans to develop the island as an Asia Pacific regional operations center.

He expressed hope that by 2010, technology-intensive industries will make up 50 percent of all Taiwan industries, and research and development budgets will make up 3 percent of the gross domestic product.

Due to the island's limited natural and human resources, Siew stressed it is particularly important that Taiwan be more efficient. Therefore, in addition to continued innovations in technology, it is vital that R&D strategic, structural and procedural management produce the maximum results, he said.

Improper management is worse than the lack of investment, Siew said, noting only effective management and commercialization can produce market value for technology -- the modern source of national competitiveness.

Siew urged local enterprises to improve their overall technology base and management abilities, vowing that the government will carry out its duty of providing them with an excellent development environment.

Pointing out that industrial technology is the driving force behind economic development, the premier said the Ministry of Economic Affairs allocates a sizable budget to promote it every year, and the gradual effects can now be seen.

Siew expressed his satisfaction over the results of a 1998 Swiss report on global competitiveness where Taiwan's ranking surged to 16th place from last year's 23rd, and a World Economic Forum rating of 6th, up from last year's 8th ranking.

He noted, however, that the domestic industrial structure is facing major adjustments. Whereas economic developments in the past were largely credited to labor-intensive industries, their difficulty in adapting to new competitive situations necessitates the development of technology-intensive, high value-added industries.

The best alternative for Taiwan, which lacks natural resources and sufficient domestic demands, is to concentrate on the electronics, semi-conductor, information and biotechnology industries, Siew said.
Nurturing talent needed by medium and small enterprises and developing new technological innovations through effective R&D management are both important tasks ahead, Siew concluded.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN SEEN STEAMING AHEAD OF TITANIC CHINA IN CRISIS

TEXT.P: Taiwan, described as a modest freighter, is sailing ahead of its Titanic neighbors -- mainland China and Hong Kong -- in the Asian crisis storm, according to a leading Australian business newspaper.
Australian Financial Review correspondent Rowan Callick wrote a story on Tuesday from Taipei headlined "Taiwan steams ahead of its Titanic neighbors."

He said if Hong Kong is considered a first class cabin on the Titanic and mainland China is a vast container vessel whose captain is still grappling with its massive steering wheel to turn it around, then Taiwan is a modest freighter steaming toward its destination.

Callick wrote that Taiwan's future is not in the hands of party-owned property magnates, but in those of the 5,000 high-tech companies that have settled in Asia's version of Silicon Valley between Taipei and Hsinchu, southwest of the capital.

According to the report, Taiwan's performance can be attributed to three elements: the plurality of decision-making centers with its flexible economic core comprising small- and medium-sized businesses; its greater margin for monetary maneuvering, free from the defenses of the Chinese and Hong Kong currencies which will probably meet their doom next year; and Taiwan's diversified trading relations.
While Hong Kong's economy has experienced negative growth of 2 percent in the first quarter of 1998 and China has faced a 1.5 percent fall in its exports and stagnant foreign investment, Taiwan's

DOC.HEADLINE: TALKING DOWN US DOLLAR IS RISKY: LEE KUAN YEW

TEXT.P: The United States and Japan must work together to prevent the Japanese yen from further tumbling while at the same time avoid a sudden slide in the value of the US dollar, said Singapore Senior Minister Lee Kuan Yew.

Attempts to talk down the US dollar might affect the New York stock exchange and lead to even greater problems, he cautioned in an interview with Newsweek last week. The interview was published in the latest issue of the American news magazine.
Describing this as a "very difficult situation," Lee said, "The opposite side of the coin to a weak yen is a strong US dollar.

"The US dollar is appreciating against all currencies. How do you bring it down? If you talk the US dollar down, you might bring the New York stock market down, and that would lead to great troubles for everyone.
"Somehow this has to be unwound but without causing a sudden slide," he added.
In the wide-ranging interview on the economic and political changes sweeping the region, Lee was also asked if the recent financial crisis had changed the political landscape.
"The political landscape has changed and will continue to change, but it is not going to be a straightforward line to democracy," he said.

Lee did not see for example, the Indonesian people voting directly for a president because they remembered too well the chaotic 1950s when there were many political parties and weak coalition governments that each lasted only a few months.
Instead, he said, the country would have to decide on the number of parties that would enter elections for national assembly members, who would then choose a president.
Lee also rejected the notion that President Suharto's stepping down was the result of a "people-power revolution."
"This was a controlled exercise. Right up until the shooting of the six students, the government, army and police were in complete control.
"They allowed the demonstrations to carry on in a controlled way.
"Then somebody did something not in the script, and that triggered it off," he said.
The student demonstrations, he added, were calling not for democracy but for an end to corruption, cronyism and nepotism.

Lee was also asked if he agreed with Malaysian Prime Minister Mahathir Mohamad's view that Asians might have to fight a guerrilla war against westerners for control of their economies in the wake of the present economic turmoil.
"A leader who sends out such signals must expect foreign investors to be stout-hearted enough to engage in counter insurgency actions before they invest in local companies," he responded

DOC.HEADLINE: CROSS-STRAIT FISHERY MEETING OPENS IN TAIPEI

TEXT.P: A senior mainland Chinese fishery official suggested here on Tuesday that the two sides of the Taiwan Strait commission private insurance companies or maritime appraisal firms to help resolve frequent cross-strait fishing disputes.

Lin Yi, a department chief at the Taiwan Affairs Office of the mainland China's State Council, made the overture during a seminar on sustainable use of fishery resources in the Taiwan Strait, which separate Taiwan from the mainland.
Lin said there are currently no propoer channels to handle nagging cross-strait fishing disputes, leading to deterioration of such issues.
"I think the two sides of the strait can commission private insurance or maritime accidents appraisal firms to help settle those problems," said Lin.
Zhuo Youzhan, director of the Administration of Fishery and Ports under mainland China's Ministry of Agriculture, also underscored the urgency of addressing cross-strait fishing disputes.
Zhuo said the two sides should jointly work out a mutually acceptable format to enable those who have suffered losses or damage in cross-strait fishing incidents to acquire reasonable compensation.

Speaking on the same occasion, professor Lee Kuo-tien of National Taiwan Ocean University, called attention to rapid dwindling of fishery resources in the continental shelves beneath the Taiwan Strait.

Lee said waters surrounding Taiwan, including the Taiwan Strait, the southern part of the East China Sea and the northern part of the South China Sea, used to be a rich fishing ground, with abundant benthic fish.
"Such fishery resources, however, have gradually declined because of sloppy management and decades of exploitation by Taiwan and mainland fishermen," Lee said.

According to Lee, Taiwan fishermen could caught 180 kilograms of fish per hour in the 1970s. The hourly fish catach dropped to 150 kgs in the early 1980s, and by the end of the decade, the catch slid to 80 kgs.

Noting that maritime fishing resources can be reproduced, Lee said Taiwan and mainland China should attach importance to the issue and craft out a joint management system to ensure sustainable use of those resources.
The seminar was sponsored by the ROC Marine Industry Association, with the participation of fishery officials and scholars from both sides of the Taiwan Strait.

The mainland delegation is composed of scores of department chiefs and deputy chiefs from the Ministry of Agriculture and the Taiwan Affairs Office. Mainland delegates also include Qin Zhilin, president of the Academy of Marine Science, and Chen Xuyezhang, president of the East China Sea Research Institute.
The Taiwan delegation comprises officials from the Cabinet-level Council of Agriculture and the semi-official Straits Exchange Foundation.

DOC.HEADLINE: BEIJING PLANS TO CUT INTEREST RATE TO COUNTER SINKING YEN: REPORT
DOC.DATELINE: Hong Kong, June 16 (CNA) (By Stanley Cheung & Eva Chen)

TEXT.P: Beijing may cut interest rates to relieve pressure on the mainland Chinese renminbi in the wake of a sinking Japanese yen, said the Hong Kong Economic Times on Tuesday.

The Economic Times cited informed sources as saying that People's Bank of China will soon announce the cut, the fifth such cut since 1996. The cut would be aimed at stimulating domestic demand to help mainland China achieve its target economic growth rate of 8 percent this year.

Mainland Chinese exports, as well as its currency, have been badly affected by Asia's financial crisis, said the sources. Experts from the research department of People's Bank of China and the Chinese Academy of Social Sciences have been examining the possibility of devaluing the renminbi, or yuan, as well as the impact of a falling yen on the mainland's economy.

High-ranking mainland Chinese economic officials believe that, given the current situation, a devaluation of the renminbi will not offset the negative impact of the region's economic turmoil. It would instead trigger another round of currency devaluations throughout the region, the officials said.

DOC.HEADLINE: NT DOLLAR UP

TEXT.P: The New Taiwan dollar rose NT$0.053 against the greenback in Taipei on Tuesday, closing at NT$34.819.
The local currency opened at the day's high of 34.61, and had a low of 34.852.
The interbank US dollar trading reached US$318 million.

DOC.HEADLINE: SHARE PRICES UP AGAIN ON TAIEX

TEXT.P: Share prices opened low but closed higher on the Taipei Stock Exchange on Tuesday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, climbing 120.44 points to close at 7,404.27.
The bourse opened at the day's low of 7,174.73 and rose as high as 7,444.06.

Dealers said the market was given a boost by the appreciation of both the New Taiwan dollar and the Japanese yen, which spurred strong buying sentiment among investors. Many issues, most notably electronics stocks, posted gains in Tuesday's trading, following a surge on Monday as well.
Gainers outnumbered losers 325 to 107, with 58 issues remaining unchanged.

A total of 2.42 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$119.03 billion, up from the previous session which saw 1.81 billion stocks change hands on a market turnover of NT$ 89.95 billion.

All eight major categories gained ground, with electrical stocks moving up the most at 3.0 percent, followed by pulp and paper issues at 2.0 percent, foodstuff shares and textile issues both at 1.6 percent, plastics and chemical stocks and cement shares both at 1.0 percent, construction issues at 0.9 percent and banking and insurance shares at 0.6 percent.

The 10 listed companies with the largest turnover on Tuesday's trading were United Micro Electronics, Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing, Siliconware Precision Industries Co., Mitac International Corp., Kinpo Electronics, ASE, Silicon Integrated Systems Corp., Chuntex Electronic Co. Ltd., Liton Electronic and Taitung Business Bank.

DOC.HEADLINE: US URGED TO FOLLOW APPROACH USED IN NORTHERN IRELAND TALKS

TEXT.P: In the run-up to the meeting between US President Bill Clinton and his mainland Chinese counterpart, Jiang Zemin, slated for later this month, local pro-independence forces attending a Tuesday seminar urged Washington to help forge peace across the Taiwan Strait a la its role in Northern Ireland's peace negotiations.

The Taiwan Independence Alliance, sponsor of the symposium, issued a statement welcoming Clinton to play the role of mediator between Taiwan and mainland China and suggested he might win the Nobel peace prize for such efforts.

The group suggested Beijing take a page from the Northern Ireland peace agreement and demonstrate greater flexibility in its position toward Taiwan. Mainland China should treat Taiwan, which maintains close cultural, language and ethnic links with the mainland, with greater open-mindedness, the group said.

Huang Erh-hsuan, a lawmaker with the pro-independence Democratic Progressive Party and a member of the alliance, called on the United States to respect the Taiwan people's yearning for independence and help resolve the issue peacefully.

Noting that Washington is not expected to change its basic stance toward Taiwan during the upcoming summit, Huang urged the people of Taiwan to have confidence in their country and not succumb to mainland China's military threats.

A senior official with the alliance said the United States would do best at present to maintain peace in the Taiwan Strait and the West Pacific. That means the United States should insist mainland China not resort to force in its dealings with Taiwan, while the United States will not support Taiwan independence, he noted.

Taiwan should pay more attention to US efforts to build a strategic partnership with mainland China because any move by Washington, such as the signing of a fourth communique, may lead to a misunderstanding between Taiwan and the mainland, causing further instability, he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT LEE RECEIVES FOREIGN AGRICULTURE EXPERTS

TEXT.P: Effective adjustments to the government's agricultural policies are one of the main reasons Taiwan's agricultural development has been so successful, President Lee Teng-hui said Tuesday.

Lee, while meeting a group of foreign experts and scholars who were in Taipei for a symposium on agricultural policies, explained that over the past 100 years of agricultural development in Taiwan, the government has pursued policies appropriate to the situation.

From the earliest construction of irrigation facilities and improvements to rice strains to land reform and the current opening of Taiwan's agricultural market to internationalization and liberalization, Taiwan's policies have led to its agricultural success, Lee said.

Compared to farmers elsewhere, Taiwan's farmers are well-versed in the business aspects of agricultural production and are able to concentrate on different crops to meet changing market needs. This has allowed Taiwan's agricultural production to maintain flexibility and competitiveness, Lee added.

To help domestic farmers who may suffer losses from market internationalization and liberalization, Lee said the government has established a NT$100 billion (US$2.9 billion) agricultural relief fund to help them through the transition.

Lee received guests from Australia, Canada, England, Japan, South Korea, and the United States, including Donald MacLaren, Mr. and Mrs. David R. Harvey, Ken Ash, Hiroshi Tsujil, Sang-woo Park, Thomas I. Wahl, Luther G. Tweeten and Mr. and Mrs. M. Boyd Buxeton.

DOC.HEADLINE: ENTEROVIRUS TYPE-71 CONFIRMED RESPONSIBLE FOR EPIDEMIC

TEXT.P: Government health officials on Tuesday confirmed that enterovirus type-71 is behind a viral epidemic that has claimed the lives of 38 infants and children in Taiwan.

Hsu Kuo-hsiung, acting director of Bureau of Communicable Disease Control under the Department of Health, said that the confirmation was based on an autopsy performed at Linkuo Chang Gung Memorial Hospital on an 8-year-old female who had a viral infection. The autopsy revealed the presence of enterovirus type-71 in the girl's spinal cord and medulla.

That discovery has led officials to believe that enterovirus type-71 first attacks a person's central nervous system, causing a rise in blood pressure and cerebral pressure, Hsu said. As the infection worsens, the victim falls into coma and dies from complications of the infection, such as edema pulmonary, meningitis or encephalitis.
Children under the age of 5 are most at risk of being infected, and common symptoms of an infection include a fever and rash with ulcers on the hands, feet and mouth, Hsu said.

Hsu said news of the discovery has been passed on to three experts from the US Centers for Disease Control who are currently in Taiwan studying the outbreak, adding that the Department of Heath will invite the doctors to recommend appropriate treatment for those infected.

As there is no vaccine for the virus, Hsu repeated the suggestion that parents keep their children away from public places and make sure that children wash their hands often to reduce the risk of infection.

DOC.HEADLINE: HOWARD NOT SWAYED BY ONE NATION'S ELECTION GAINS

TEXT.P: The One Nation Party, buoyed by its stunning success in the June 13 Queensland elections, has vowed to field candidates for each of the 148 lower house seats that will be contested in the next federal election, while Prime Minister John Howard is expected to go ahead with plans for early elections.
Howard is expected to follow his original game plan, despite the unprecedented beating his Liberal Party and the National Party took in the Queensland state elections last Saturday.
Howard will announce his tax program in July and call for federal elections either in August or September, as earlier planned, political analysts said.
The prime minister is worried that a delay in calling elections would generate friction between the Liberal and National parties, which form the country's coalition government, they said.

A number of National Party members of Parliament have asked Howard to abandon plans for a goods and services tax and not to complete the privatization of Australia's telecommunications giant Telstra, to increase the party's chances of winning in the next federal election.
But Howard is said to be unwilling to alter his plans, despite the possible election-day consequences for the Liberal and National parties.

State branches of the One Nation Party in New South Wales, Victoria, South Australia, Western Australia, Tasmania and Northern Territory are expected to draw strength from the party's victory in Queensland and achieve even greater success by winning seats in the lower house.

Branch directors of the party said inquiries on how to become party members have increased since the Queensland election, from which the party is expected to grab between nine and 12 seats in the state assembly.
The final tally is not expected until later this week.
By calling the federal elections earlier than required, Howard must announce a double-dissolution, which will dissolve both the Senate and the House of Representatives.

DOC.HEADLINE: GERMAN DAILY REPORTS ON PRESSURE CLINTON FACES OVER M'LAND TRIP

TEXT.P: US President Bill Clinton is facing pressure over his upcoming trip to mainland China from within the United States, from mainland China and from the media, reported the German daily "Die Welt" on Tuesday.

The report cites the controversy surrounding Clinton's welcoming ceremony, which will take place in front of the Great Hall of the People in Tiananmen Square, the site of a bloody crackdown against pro-democracy protests in 1989.

The intensity of the criticism within the United States of Clinton's trip and of mainland China was not expected by the Beijing leadership. The report quotes an informed source in Beijing as saying mainland Chinese President Jiang Zemin believed he had impressed the US public during his state visit last October.

Starting Monday Beijing will begin showing a 60-minute propaganda film entitled "Over the Pacific," which depicts Jiang's US visit, according the report. Neither the demonstrations that dogged Jiang throughout his trip nor questions put to him at press conferences and at US universities where he spoke will be included in the film.

DOC.HEADLINE: LARGE COUNTERFEITING RING BUSTED

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Justice Investigation Bureau (MJIB) announced on Tuesday it has busted a large counterfeiting ring in the central county of Taichung and confiscated more than 12,000 pieces of counterfeit brand-named fashion goods, ranging from Chanel leatherware to Versace ready-to-wear collection.
This was the fourth time that the MJIB's Taichung outpost has successfully seized spurious fashion goods over the past three months.

MJIB investigators said the newly seized products were all exquisitely made, including handbags, belts, garments and accessories, and sunglasses. The products had been sold throughout the island. "If they were genuine goods, they could fetch more than NT$200 million (US$5.75 million)," said an investigator.
He further said the MJIB had tracked a wholesaler of the fake goods for two years. "But we had been unable to locate his supply source until early this month."
On June 12, investigators raided a retail outlet in the southern port city of Kaohsiung, a distribution center in Taichung City and a production facility in Shalu, Taichung County.

In addition to confiscate large quantities of counterfeit goods and production equipment at the three places, the investigators also managed to nab the wholesaler, identified only by his family name Hung, and several of his accomplices.
Investigators said they will continue to probe the case in order to check whether there are other accomplices at large.

The MJIB has launched a new crackdown on commercial piracy since the beginning of this year, with an aim to eradicate such illegal business practices and rid Taiwan of the infamous name of "island of counterfeiting."
On April 15, the MJIB Taichung outpost seized more than 300 pieces of counterfeit Rolex watches and Chanel handbags at a retail shop in Taichung City, worth about NT$16 million in market value.

It again confiscated 160 Rolex watches in Taiping, Taichung County on May 8 and raided a factory specializing in counterfeiting brand-named goods in Tainan on June 8 and seized more than 8,600 bogus fashion goods.
MJIB officials said Chanel Co. of France sent a letter to the MJIB headquarters in Taipei recently to express its gratitude for Taiwan's anti-counterfeiting efforts.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHEMICAL-FILLED TANKER RAMS GRAVEL BOAT IN KEELUNG

TEXT.P: A Taiwan gravel boat docked at the port of Keelung, northern Taiwan, sank after being rammed by a Malaysian-registered tanker filled with chemicals on Tuesday.
The accident also resulted in an oil slick. Keelung port authorities are working to stop its spread.

The 18,000-ton Malaysian tanker Tan-Jung was approaching the Keelung port when it rammed the Yi Fang No. 1, tearing a hole into the Yi Fang's hull. The 2,948-ton Yi Fang took on water and sank with full gravel and a crane still on board. No casualties were reported.

A member of the gravel boat's crew told port police that the tanker was approaching so quickly that, even with the two anchors it has cast, it could not help but ram the boat, adding that with 4,000 tons of gravel on board, the boat sank quickly. A dock worker also said the Malaysian tanker was speeding at the time of the accident.

DOC.HEADLINE: UNEMPLOYMENT IN MAINLAND CHINA RISES ABOVE WARNING LINE

TEXT.P: The Beijing-based China Economic Times reported Tuesday that, if workers laid off by state-run enterprises are included, the jobless rate of the urban areas in mainland China has risen above the warning line of eight percent to 9.36 percent.

Quoting a survey report by the Development Research Center of the State Council, the front-page news story said that the jobless rate must be kept under eight percent, because various kinds of social problems will emerge if the jobless rate is over 10 percent. The "registered unemployment rate" will rise "slowly" in the next two years, it added.

In order to keep the jobless rate under eight percent, the government must keep the number of people laid off by state-run enterprises under seven million, and the number must be reduced by two million in 1998 and 1999, the report said.

DOC.HEADLINE: NOBEL LAUREATE DR. ROBERT MERTON CALLS ON FINANCE MINISTER

TEXT.P: Dr. Robert C. Merton, 1997 Nobel laureate in economics, on Tuesday paid a courtesy call on Finance Minister Paul C.H. Chiu at his office.
They exchanged views on a range of issues such as dealing in futures and derivative financial products.

Chiu said later that according to Merton, futures dealing and trading in derivative financial goods can not only help spread a country's economic risk but can also benefit its economic development and capital-raising abilities.
The finance minister told the visiting Harvard professor that Taiwan will formally allow dealing in stock index futures next month, to which Merton replied that the move is on the right course.
Chiu said he did not discuss the recent depreciation of the Japanese yen or the Asian financial turmoil with Merton.

DOC.HEADLINE: HEALTH OFFICIAL TOUTS TAIWAN'S NATIONAL HEALTH INSURANCE PROGRAM

TEXT.P: The public approval rating of Taiwan's National Health Insurance Program has risen from 33 percent at the time of its inception 3 years ago to 70 percent now, proof that its quality matches that of similar systems in developed countries, said Chan Chi-hsien, director-general of the Department of Health.

In an article published by the ruling Kuomintang's "Policy Monthly," Chan said 96 percent of Taiwan's population is now covered by the program, compared to 43 percent when the program was established.
About 360,000 patients with serious ailments or injuries -- about 1.8 percent of the total number insured -- have accounted for 16.7 percent of total expenditures under the program.
Chan vowed to work to achieve the program's ultimate goal of providing universal coverage.

DOC.HEADLINE: AUSTRALIAN GIRL MEETS TAIWANESE BIRTH MOTHER

TEXT.P: Eleven days after her arrival in Taiwan, an Australian teenager of Taiwanese origin was finally reunited with her birth mother on Tuesday after DNA testing established their relationship.
Kartya Wunderle of Melbourne said at a news conference she felt "more at ease" to meet face to face with her biological mother and older sister, whose identities were withheld at their request.
Kartya, who was sold as an infant and adopted into an Australian family 17 years ago, met her long lost natural mother at 4 a.m. at the Chungho branch office of the Taipei County Police Bureau.
One police officer who witnessed the event told the press that the reunion was "heart-rending."
"They hugged each other, cried and asked about each other's life," said the officer with the Criminal Investigation Bureau, which had helped arrange the reunion.

Kartya later said at a press conference that she didn't call her natural mother "Mama", but she added: "Hopefully I can build a relationship with my biological mother in the future. I'll stay here for two months."
The 17-year-old further said she doesn't hate her birth father who, according to police authorities, sold his baby daughter to an adoption broker for NT$36,000 (about US$1,035).
Speaking on the same occasion, Nola Wunderle, Kartya's adoptive mother, said discovery of her daughter's birth mother is an "overwhelming emotional experience," ending an eight-year search.
"We knew straight away by looking at them that they are Kartya's family," Wunderle said.
Kartya's adoptive father is scheduled to arrive in Taipei on Wednesday to meet his daughter's birth mother, identified as "Mrs. Chin."
According to police authorities, Kartya's natural father never married her mother, and already died several years ago.

Kartya was adopted by the Wunderles in 1981. The adoption was arranged by a white slavery ring headed by Chu Li-ching, also known as Julie Chu, who was convicted in 1982 for selling 64 babies to prospective parents in the United States, Australia, Germany and Switzerland for up to US$5,000 each, according to police.

DOC.HEADLINE: CAA DRAFTS GUIDELINES ON FLIGHT DELAYS

TEXT.P: Taiwan's Civil Aeronautics Administration (CAA) has drafted a set of guidelines relating to the handling of flight delays, but civil airlines cannot seem to agree on the sections concerning their responsibilities regarding compensation to inconvenienced passengers.
CAA mapped out the guidelines following a spate of sit-in protests by Taiwan passengers in recent years over flight delays.

Under the draft guidelines, if the airlines know that their planes will be delayed by more than 15 minutes on domestic routes or by over 30 minutes on international routes, they will have to inform passengers immediately of the reason, and of measures being taken to deal with the delay.
Any changes in flight routes or of take-off points or destinations will have to follow the same procedures.

If a flight delay affects the rights and interests of passengers, airlines will have to provide complimentary telecommunication services, meals and accommodation, and any transportation to transfer points which may be necessary.
If there are practical reasons as to why airlines cannot provide these services, they are required to fully explain the situation to the passengers.
CAA officials said that the gist of the guidelines is to push the airlines into paying closer attention to flight punctuality.

But the airlines have different views on the proposed guidelines, pointing out that the most controversial parts lie in the CAA's proposal to list the responsibilities of the airlines and set the standards for judging the inconvenience to passengers.

The Board of Airline Representatives (BOAR), comprised of local and foreign airlines operating international routes, said that the CAA has overstepped its bounds to an unacceptable extent, claiming that the proposed guidelines stipulate that airlines will be obliged to compensate passengers for any delays, even those caused by circumstances outwith the airlines' control.

The board pointed out that delays are often caused by poor weather conditions, or problems on the part of the airports, citing as an example a previous incident involving a breakdown of ground operations at the Chiang Kai-shek International Airport caused by a power blackout.
The BOAR officials said that European and American airliners have questioned CAA guidelines through the American Chamber of Commerce in Taipei and through the European Council of Commerce and Trade.

They also said that if the CAA succeeds in making the airlines take all the blame for delays, disputes between airlines and passengers will probably increase, and operational costs will also rise, leading to higher ticket prices.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC STRIVING TO STREAMLINE MILITARY

TEXT.P: The Republic of China Army is striving to streamline its hierarchy while beefing up its combat strength, military spokesman Gen. Kung Fan-ding said on Tuesday.
Under a sweeping troop reduction plan, Kung said, army divisions will be trimmed to brigades in an effort to develop a stripped-down but elite fighting force.
By the time the plan is complete, the Army force will have been trimmed by 15 percent, but combat capability will have been raised by 13 percent, Kung noted.

The plan, to be implemented in three stages between July 1997 and June 2001, calls for a general restructuring, including streamlining of the chain of command, consolidation of basic structures, acquisition of sophisticated weaponry, reduction of the number of men in uniform, and raising of combat readiness, according to Army planning chief Gen. Pang Yu-tung.
The plan will see the slashing of up to 1,700 higher-ranked personnel, including generals and other officers.
To beef up the Army's contingency command capabilities, a "Warfare Headquarters" has been established to monitor potential threats and the readiness of the various levels of the army, Pang noted.
Under the Warfare Headquarters, there is also a procurement department, which has so far carried out 1,441 procurement projects worth about NT$2 billion (US$57 million).

The streamlining of the basic Army structures will result in smaller brigades, including infantry, motorized infantry, armored infantry and air cavalry, to replace the existing army divisions. Brigade strength ranges from 2,000 to 4,000 men, compared with over 10,000 in a division.
In addition, the Army is to establish a "combined battalion system," in which soldiers from the above-mentioned brigades will be mobilized to enhance the army's overall combat capability.

DOC.HEADLINE: CETRA TO SET UP ONLINE TRADE MARKET

TEXT.P: The Taipei-based China External Trade Development Council (CETRA) is building a "virtual trade market" on the Internet, an executive from Taiwan's foremost non-profit trade promotion organization revealed on Tuesday.

The market is to be located on the planned "Cetra Net" website that CETRA is setting up to expand its online trade-related services for domestic and foreign business communities, said Chan Fu-hsiung, CETRA's chief of information services.

The "virtual market" is expected to become one of CETRA's most innovative and powerful services for creating trade opportunities. "Approximately 4,500 items of product-related data provided by 3,000 businesses will be recorded in the planned market, making it the world's largest online trading site," Chan said.

He indicated that from July 8, local and foreign businesses from around the world will be able to point their browsers at "http://www.cetra.org.tw" to enter the "market," where they can look for buyers or sellers.

In addition to the "virtual trade market," Chan noted that the planned website will also provide information resources via an extensive databank, up-to-date news reporting, and an on-line library, which will be available for a fee.

The CETRA official estimated that at least 3 million people around the globe are expected to visit Cetra Net when it goes online. In order to take full advantage of the Internet's limitless power in communication, CETRA is also planning to cooperate with the Yahoo! search engine to expand its online services, he noted.

DOC.HEADLINE: LABOR LEADER HAILS TAIWAN'S HUMAN RESOURCE TRAINING

TEXT.P: Chan Hou-sheng, chairman of the Cabinet-level Council of Labor Affairs (CLA) under the Executive Yuan, said on Tuesday that from 1965, the government has implemented a series of four-year plans for human resource training.
Chan made the remarks at the 18th Asia Pacific Economic Cooperation (APEC) forum working group meeting on human resource development which was held in Taipei on Tuesday morning.

He said the Asian financial crisis has created a heavy impact on some APEC economies in Southeast Asia, resulting not only in the depreciation of their currencies, but also in the closing of many businesses and factories, creating large-scale unemployment. These job losses have in turn caused social unrest, as well as economic recession.

However, Chan said, Taiwan has managed to come out of the financial crisis relatively unscathed due to its excellent human resource development policy. He pointed out that Taiwan has long placed emphasis on human resource education and training.

According to Chan, the series of four-year development projects on human resources have helped build Taiwan into a prosperous society. He noted that Taiwan's current goal is to raise education levels in order to meet the needs of the high-technology sector and the development of the service industry.

In addition, Chan said, Taiwan also places great emphasis on retraining and lifelong study projects. He also expressed his hope that Taiwan's experience in human resource development can be used to help the APEC economies.

The APEC human resource working group meeting, the second of its kind to be held this year, has set up an ad hoc committee on crisis management to discuss ways and means of coping with the Asian financial firestorm.

DOC.HEADLINE: SOUTH AFRICA DESTROYS CHEMICAL, BIOLOGICAL WEAPONS

TEXT.P: The Republic of South Africa's chemical and biological weapons program has been terminated, and all material which could have been used for offensive purposes destroyed, according to government spokesman Joel Netshitenzhe.
Netshitenzhe said material produced under the program has been destroyed in cooperation with countries that have the necessary expertise for the task, and in terms of international conventions.

The South African government was responding to revelations last week at the Truth and Reconciliation Commission's hearings into the chemical and biological weapons program initiated during the apartheid years.

Netshitenzhe said the South African government practices a foreign policy based on "friendly, human and peaceful engagement" with other nations and has no interest in developing weapons of mass destruction.

"The government is also committed to ensuring that the knowledge and expertise gathered in this area should, under no circumstances, become available to any other country, individual or company," he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: ASIAN AMERICANS EXPECTED TO DOUBLE BY 2010

TEXT.P: Chinese Americans, estimated to make up 2,268,000 of the US population, are the most populous Asian Americans in that country, according to a recent report.
The report, titled "Asian Americans: Diverse and Growing," indicates that in 1997, of the total 9,568,000 Asian Americans, 24 percent are of Chinese origin, followed by Filipinos at 21 percent.
The estimated total of Asian Americans, about 4 percent of the US population, is expected to double by 2010, the report said.

"This rapid expansion has been characterized by a similarly rapid growth in their ethnic diversity," noted the report's author, Sharon Lee, who will join the sociology department at Portland State University later this year as an associate professor after nearly 10 years at the University of Richmond.

Noting that in 1970, 96 percent of Asian Americans were Japanese, Chinese, or Filipino, Lee said that today, the three groups make up just over 50 percent of the total. Asian Americans now include Koreans, Vietnamese, Indians, Cambodians, Pakistanis, and Thais.

Despite this remarkable pace of growth, Lee's report said, Asian Americans will remain a small proportion of the US population, but their influence on American institutions and culture will expand, largely because of their high average educational levels and increasing interaction with non-Asians.

DOC.HEADLINE: FORMER US DIPLOMAT'S REMARKS ABSURD, SAYS FOREIGN MINISTER

TEXT.P: Foreign Affairs Minister Jason Hu on Tuesday ridiculed former US diplomat Chas Freeman's recent remarks that US arms sales to Taiwan no longer boost the island's confidence that it can work out its differences with Beijing as "extremely absurd."

Although Hu admitted that he had not yet read the full context of Freeman's article, carried in the latest issue of Foreign Affairs, a bimonthly journal, he said it is not the first time he has heard such nonsense. Such allegations are in complete contradiction to the facts, he added.

Freeman, a former diplomat who served as deputy chief of the US embassy in Beijing between 1981 and 1984, said in the article that US arms sales to Taiwan no longer boost the island's confidence that it can work out its differences with Beijing. Instead, he asserted, such sales only enhance pro-independence sentiments in Taiwan.
"The United States should reevaluate its arms sales policy to Taiwan in accordance with the 1982 joint communique," he claimed.

Freeman also asserted in his article that the US sale of 150 F-16 fighters to Taiwan in 1992, and certain subsequent deals, do not comply with the 1982 communique that Washington and Beijing forged primarily to limit US arms sales to Taiwan.

"Beijing is now wavering in its determination to stick with a policy of peaceful resolution of its differences with Taipei. How much of this wavering is due to US noncompliance with the 1982 communique, and how much is Taipei's new opposition to reunification, is unclear," he added.
Hu said that today, the cause of Taiwan people's deep repugnance toward mainland China is Beijing's persistent and unceasing attempts to isolate Taiwan in the international community.
Discounting Freeman's remarks about the arms sales, Hu said Taiwan's strenuous arms acquisition efforts and America's arms sales to Taiwan serve only one purpose -- to safeguard peace.
"Our acquisition of defensive arms is only for defending peace, and has nothing to do with whether or not we want independence," he said.

Hu stressed that Freeman's remarks represent only the isolated views of a few people. "We don't think such views, which are definitely not the mainstream views of the American academic sector, but relatively close to the views of the Beijing authorities, will spread throughout America," he said.
Hu also said he does not think Freeman's remarks are relevant to the upcoming Clinton-Jiang summit, or that they will have any impact on the meeting.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAC DEFENDS `NO HASTE, BE PATIENT' MAINLAND CHINA INVESTMENT POLICY

TEXT.P: Taiwan's Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) said on Tuesday that it is necessary for the government to continue following its "no haste, be patient" mainland China investment strategy.

This is because political motives have always been behind Beijing's move to conduct trade and economic exchanges with Taiwan, according to an MAC report on the policy initiated by President Lee Teng-hui.

The report claimed that as Beijing's hostility toward Taiwan remains, an unlimited increase in Taiwan investment in the mainland will eventually undermine national security, citing remarks made by ranking Beijing officials on several occasions to support its conclusion.

Former mainland Chinese President Yang Shangkun, for example, said in 1987 that "Taiwan would not be able to run away (from the mainland) if we can control its lifeline by persuading the island's top 20 enterprises (to invest in the mainland)."

More recently, according to the report, the director of the Taiwan Affairs Office of Beijing's State Council, Chen Yunlin, said: "Warmer cross-strait trade and economic relations will be in the greater interest of China's unification."

The report said that the Beijing leadership has gradually come to understand that resorting to force would not be a good way of pursuing China's unification, and that the best course of action would be by way of trade and economic exchanges.

The report also said that critics of the cautious policy, who claim that "politics should be separate from economic affairs," are being impractical, as Beijing has always regarded cross-strait trade and economic exchanges as political issues.

It is also impossible that the mainland will be able to maintain its high annual economic growth of around 10 percent, the report went on, and once its economic growth slows down, political and social crises are likely to be triggered, putting Taiwan's mainland investments at great risk.

In fact, the report said, the results of several public polls have shown that only a minority of the general public are against the strategy, compared to the nearly 50 percent of the people who favor even stricter limits on mainland investment.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT TO NOMINATE WU DEN-YIH AS KAOHSIUNG MAYORAL CANDIDATE

TEXT.P: The ruling Kuomintang (KMT) is likely to nominate incumbent Kaohsiung Mayor Wu Den-yih as its candidate for the year-end mayoral election in Kaohsiung, KMT party sources reported on Tuesday.

In a meeting that day presided over by Vice President and KMT Vice Chairman Lien Chan, the nine-member KMT Nomination Screening Task Force suggested that during a Wednesday meeting of the KMT Central Standing Committee, Wu be nominated as the KMT candidate to seek reelection in the southern metropolis of Kaohsiung.

The task force, which includes KMT Vice Chairman Li Yuan-zu and such other party heavyweights as Premier Vincent Siew, President of the Examination Yuan Hsu Shui-teh and Presidential Secretary-General Huang Kun-huei, also suggested that the party make special efforts to soothe the anger of three other KMT hopefuls who have vowed to run for the Kaohsiung mayorship.
One of the three contenders, Su Nan-cheng, a National Assembly member and former Kaohsiung mayor, claimed that he will never back down from his intention to run.

Su later added that he may even join Chang Jui-teh, deputy speaker of the Kaohsiung City Council, who also announced his intention to run, in support of Legislator Wang Chih-hsiung, the third of the three contenders, in a potentially vote-splitting race with Wu for the mayorship.

DOC.HEADLINE: ANTI-CRIME CZAR QUESTIONED OVER MOLESTATION ALLEGATIONS

TEXT.P: Acting Director of the Investigation Bureau Cheng Chuan turned up at the Ministry of Justice on Tuesday to answer questions before a special panel over allegations that he molested the daughter of a friend two years ago in a Paris hotel room.
At a hastily called press conference after one-and-a-half hours of questioning, Cheng denied any wrongdoing and offered to undertake a polygraph test to clear his name.

Cheng said that the French authorities would never have let him leave France if he had really done what his accusers complained of, which was that he raped a friend's daughter during a private trip to Paris between Sept. 8 and 13, 1996.

Opposition Democratic Progressive Party National Assemblyman Lai Ching-lin, a personal friend of the girl's family, said he was asked by the girl's father, Yang Wan-shou, to expose Cheng's crime after Taipei authorities stonewalled over Yang's calls for a probe. He urged the Ministry of Justice to investigate the case thoroughly.

Cheng did not immediately respond to Lai's allegations, but his office denied the accusations, claiming that his three-day schedule in Paris did not include any meeting with Yang. His aides dismissed the rumor as a plot to block Cheng's chances of taking the helm at the Investigation Bureau.

However, Cheng confessed to the bureau's internal investigators on Sept. 11 that he had seen Yang and his daughter in Paris and had applied Chikung, a Chinese martial art with medical effects, on the daughter.

Three days later, a local newspaper published a telephone interview with Yang's wife Chou Pai-lien, in which she claimed that Cheng molested her daughter under the pretext of administering Chikung in Cheng's Paris hotel room.

Chou said in the interview that she and her daughter called on Cheng on Sept. 13 at his hotel room, where Cheng touched her daughter's breast and private parts under the excuse of curing her with Chikung, after Chou left the room for about 40 minutes.
Cheng told reporters on Tuesday that Yang's daughter, then 19, suffered from anorexia nervosa and that he tried to cure her with Chikung on Sept. 12 in the presence of her parents.
The next day, Chou and her daughter called on Cheng at his hotel and asked him to perform the treatment again because the daughter felt better after the treatment of the previous day.
Cheng said Chou left the hotel room during the treatment but he denied touching Chou's daughter indecently, saying that he only asked her to take off her outer coat and touched her back.
Cheng said he would not step down now that a special panel has been set up by the Ministry of Justice to probe the case, for fear that his quitting would be interpreted as an admission of guilt.
He said he kept silent when the allegations surfaced because he believed the investigation would clear his name.
Cheng said Yang and he are old friends who met in Paris many years ago when Cheng was studying there, that he cares for Yang's daughter as an elder, and that he did nothing wrong.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI & SAO TOME PLEDGE TO PROMOTE PEOPLE'S WELFARE

TEXT.P: The presidents of the Republic of China and the Democratic Republic of Sao Tome and Principe on Tuesday jointly reiterated that their two nations will promote the welfare of the people of their countries, based on a common stance of mutual trust and benefit.
President Lee Teng-hui and his Sao Tome and Principe counterpart Miguel Trovoada made the remarks during a state banquet hosted by Lee and his wife on Tuesday evening at the Presidential Office.
Trovoada, accompanied by an 11-member entourage, arrived on the island on Monday for a five-day state visit.

Before the banquet, Lee and Trovoada exchanged views on bilateral cooperation, the current international situation, and a range of other issues of mutual concern. Following the talks, Lee conferred on Trovoada the Order of Brilliant Jade, the ROC's highest civil award, to mark his remarkable contributions to promoting friendly ties and cooperation between the two countries.
Trovoada described the award as not only the highest honor he has ever received, but also a representation of the close friendship and cooperation between Taipei and Sao Tome.
He also said he expects the two governments to engage in more cooperative projects, and that the friendship between the two peoples will be further enhanced.
Taipei and Sao Tome forged diplomatic relations last May.

Meanwhile, in related news, ROC Foreign Minister Jason Hu and his visiting Sao Tome and Principe counterpart Homero Salvaterra signed a medical cooperation agreement in Taipei on Tuesday afternoon. Under the pact, Taiwan will dispatch a five-member mission to the West African country to join in medical treatment and disease control activities.

DOC.HEADLINE: NEW ZEALAND SEEKS WTO 'DOWN PAYMENT' FROM TAIWAN

TEXT.P: New Zealand has sent its top trade official to Taiwan in a bid to further crack open the island's agricultural markets.
Lockwood Smith, New Zealand's minister of international trade who is also minister of agriculture and forestry, met with ROC Economic Affairs Minister Wang Chih-kang Tuesday.

Smith hopes to convince Taiwan to partially open its agricultural market as a "down payment" for entry to the World Trade Organization (WTO) following a similar agreement Taiwan made with the United States.
Smith's visit to the island represents the first time Wellington has sent a ministerial-level official to Taiwan for WTO-related talks.
As part of the agreement Smith is seeking to strike with Taiwan, he asked that the island open its meat market to New Zealand exports to the tune of 5,000 tons of beef chops and offal annually.

He is also asking Taiwan to increase its annual apple quota for New Zealand by 4,000 tons, and allow imports of pear, persimmon and citrus fruits from New Zealand. Taiwan now permits the import of 8,000 tons of apple from New Zealand annually.

Wang, meanwhile, stressed that the trade, investment, immigration and education ties between the two sides are increasing. However, Wang kept mum on Taiwan's promises of "down payment" to New Zealand. He only said he and Smith exchanged views on the issue.

In February this year, Taiwan agreed to partially open its agricultural market to US imports as a "down payment" for entry to the Geneva-based WTO. Taiwan agreed to open its pork market to US exports to the tune of 12,500 tons of pork products immediately upon WTO accession.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN TRADE GAP WITH JAPAN EXPECTED TO HIT US$20 BILLION
DOC.DATELINE: Tokyo, June 16 (CNA) (By Mike Chang and Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: Due to declining exports to Japan since the beginning of this year, Taiwan may post a record-high trade deficit of US$20 billion with Japan for 1998, a trade promotion official predicted Tuesday.

If the downward trend continues, Taiwan's trade imbalance with Japan may exceed the US$20 billion mark for the whole of 1998, said Ricky Y.S. Kao, secretary-general of the quasi-official China External Trade Development Council (CETRA).

Taiwan exports to Japan plummeted by 22.5 percent in the first five months of 1998 compared to the same period last year, while its combined trade surplus from January to May only reached US$750 million, a decrease of 77 percent.
As the Asian financial storm takes its toll on Taiwan's economy, Kao said relevant government agencies have taken measures to explore outbound shipments.

Of the government's 106 packages aimed to boost export, 26 are targeted at the Japanese market, Kao said. He added that CETRA is considering a name change for its Tokyo office -- the Far East Trade Service Center in Tokyo -- to further enhance its operations and services.
He urged Japan to take more efficient steps to stabilize its financial sector and stimulate its economy to help prevent another bout of turmoil in Asia's financial markets.
Kao, who arrived in Tokyo for a six-day visit Monday from the United States, was speaking at a meeting with reporters

In addition to visiting Japanese trade promotion organizations for discussions on bilateral cooperation, Kao will also meet with CETRA personnel stationed in Japan and hold seminars with investors and representatives of banking institutions from Taiwan.
