DOC.HEADLINE: MOEA APPROVES 29 SECTORS TO SET UP LIAISON OFFICES IN MAINLAND

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) on Wednesday gave the green light to 29 types of businesses in Taiwan to establish liaison offices in mainland China to help gain greater understanding of business practices and trade developments there.

The businesses included stocks and securities firms, construction, tourism and trade organizations. The more sensitive businesses of banking and insurance, however, were not included in the "go-ahead" list, MOEA sources said.
The 29 businesses are only allowed to set up liaison offices in the mainland and are not permitted to make investment in mainland China, MOEA officials noted.

Stock firms for example will only be able to collect relevant information about the mainland's operations, the officials said. In other words, these firms will be barred from buying, investing or speculating in mainland China's stock markets.

The 29 businesses given "go-ahead" signals include: international trade, construction, maritime transport, shipping agent, marine cargo brokerage, ship leasing, seaport, container distribution centers, warehouse, air cargo brokerage, air cargo distribution centers, civilian air transport, telecommunications, travel, hostel, tourist hotel, amusement park, stocks, futures, securities, mutual funds, radio broadcasting, wireless television, motion picture production, film publishing, and cable television.

DOC.HEADLINE: PAL'S RANK-AND-FILE WORKERS OBSERVES SLOWDOWN

TEXT.P: The strike-hit Philippine Airlines (PAL) suffered another setback as union rank-and-file members said they would observe a work slowdown which began at noon on Tuesday.
The management dismissed the effects of the threat and said the company had already downsized its operations by retrenching 50 percent of its employees which number 14,000.

An official of the Philippine Airlines Employees Association (PALEA) said, "Starting at noon (Tuesday), we will reduce terminal operations (check-in counters), ground handling services, and aircraft maintenance services."
This work slowdown will affect services at Ninoy Aquino International Airport and Manila's domestic airport.
"We are practically paralyzed by operating at only 20 percent, so what is there to slow down?" a PAL official said in reaction to the PALEA statement.

Also, a top airport official from PAL on Tuesday told reporters the extent of the retrenchment involved firing 518 pilots from the 620-strong members of the Airlines Pilots Association of the Philippines after an illegal strike was called on June 5.
The PAL official claimed that since the strike, the company has lost more than 2 billion pesos.
The official said PAL now has 78 pilots, including 22 from pilot management who were ready for flight operations.

DOC.HEADLINE: SINGAPORE TO REVISE GROWTH FORECAST FOR 1998

TEXT.P: Singapore is revising its full-year growth forecast of 2.5 percent to 4.5 percent and may announce other new figures within two weeks, a senior official from the Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) said Tuesday.
The revised gross domestic product (GDP) growth numbers for 1998 will be at the lower end of the official forecasts, said Khor Hoe Ee, director of MAS' economics department.
Off-budget measures to alleviate conditions for businesses are also likely to be announced once an inter-agency review involving the Ministry of Trade and Industry and the MAS is completed, he added.
Khor declined to specify the measures the government would take but said they would be aimed at helping industries adjust to difficulties straight away.
"The effect of these measures on the Singapore economy should be fairly immediate," he said.

Off-budget measures are tools governments use to tackle economic emergencies that may arise after an annual budget has been announced. They could include tax rebates, infrastructure spending or tax cuts.
Deputy Prime Minister Tan Keng Yam said last month that off-budget measures could be introduced by the end of June if second-quarter growth figures show a further slowdown.
Finance Minister Hu Tsu Dow also told Parliament this month that the government could initiate off-budget measures if preliminary second-quarter data point to an economic slowdown.
He said Singapore's non-oil domestic exports fell 6 percent in May, after a 1.6 percent decline in April.
The Singapore economy grew 5.6 percent in the first quarter of this year compared to the first quarter of 1997, but declined 1.4 per cent compared to the final quarter of last year.

DOC.HEADLINE: CONGRESSMAN PRESSES FOR MORE ARMS SALES TO TAIWAN

TEXT.P: The United States should abide by the Taiwan Relations Act and continue to sell arms to Taiwan, US Congressman Robert Smith (R-OR) said in the House of Representatives Tuesday. He added that Beijing should declare it will not use force against Taiwan "now or in the future."
Smith was speaking in a statement welcoming the visit of 19 ROC legislators to Capitol Hill.

The delegation, led by KMT Legislator Rau Yin-chi, is visiting the US voice Taipei's concerns as US President Bill Clinton prepares to meet with mainland Chinese President Jiang Zemin during his visit to mainland China from June 25 to July 3.
Smith said while the PRC is vital to US interests, "it is equally important that we not ignore the interests of our ally and trading partner: the Republic of China on Taiwan."

Smith, chairman of the House Agriculture Committee, told his colleagues that the legislators represent all major political parties in Taiwan: the ruling Kuomintang, the Democratic Progressive Party, the New Party and non-aligned parties. This delegation fully demonstrates how democracy has worked in the ROC, he said.
In 10 years, Taiwan has evolved from a one-party state to multi-political parties of different ideologies. The growth of elective politics has been very healthy for Taiwan, he added.
"Taiwan is setting a good example of elective democracy for other developing nations, especially China," the congressman noted.
For years, Taiwan has been buying American agricultural products worth billions of dollars and cooperating with the US on all major issues affecting the two countries, he said.
"I therefore share the many concerns of our Taiwan friends who are visiting us here on the hill today," said Smith.

"Let us abide by the Taiwan Relations Act and continue our arms sales to Taiwan. It is also my hope that both Taiwan and the People's Republic of China will work toward eventual reunification when both sides reach similar levels of freedom and democracy," he added.

In the meantime, both sides across the Taiwan Strait should communicate on all issues "as equal partners." Moreover, Smith stressed, the PRC should declare that it will not use force against Taiwan now or in the future.

DOC.HEADLINE: SHARE PRICES UP ON TAIEX

TEXT.P: Share prices opened high but closed lower on the Taipei Stock Exchange on Wednesday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, increasing 62.11 points to close at 7,466.38.
The bourse opened at 7,486.54, and experienced a low of 7,451.68 and a high of 7,548.0.

Dealers said the market was affected by price increases at the New York Stock Exchange, and surged at the opening. However, selling pressure later caused fluctuations, especially for electronics shares.
Gainers outnumbered losers by 308 to 129, with 56 issues remaining unchanged.

A total of 2.56 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$129.17 billion, increasing from the previous trading session which saw 2.42 billion stocks change hands on a market turnover of NT$119.03 billion.

Seven of the eight major categories gained ground, with foodstuff stocks moving up the most at 3.1 percent, followed by pulp and paper issues at 2.3 percent, both electrical shares and cement stocks at 1.2 percent, plastics and chemical shares at 1.1 percent, construction stocks at 1.0 percent, and textile issues at 0.7 percent.
Meanwhile, only the bank and insurance category registered a loss, moving down at 0.3 percent.

The 10 listed companies enjoying the largest turnovers on Wednesday's trading were: United Micro Electronics; ASE; Mitac International Corp.; ACER; Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing; Silicon Integrated Systems Corp.; Chuntex Electronics Co.; Kinpo Electronics; Siliconware Precision Industries Co.; and Liton Electronic.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT NOMINATES WU DEN-YIH AS KAOHSIUNG MAYORAL CANDIDATE

TEXT.P: The ruling Kuomintang (KMT) officially nominated incumbent Kaohsiung Mayor Wu Den-yih as its candidate for the year-end Kaohsiung mayoral election at Wednesday's KMT Central Standing Committee meeting.

As words of support flooded in, the three other KMT hopefuls who angrily vowed to continue with their bids for the Kaohsiung mayorship following Wu's last-minute decision to seek reelection, all said they would have to wait and see before making further decisions regarding their part in the race.
Following his official nomination, Wu said that he will "boldly step forward and spare no effort" in his bid for reelection.

He also said he would speak with those in the party who held different opinions of him with sincerity. However, the mayor did not say he plans to meet with the three other KMT mayoral hopefuls in the near future.

Meanwhile, as the KMT's mayoral candidates for both Taipei and Kaohsiung became official, a delighted President and KMT Chairman Lee Teng-hui said he felt "as if the dark clouds in the sky have scattered, leaving pleasant feelings inside."

Lee lauded Wu as an outstanding senior member of the KMT with abundant administrative experience and incorruptible integrity, and described him as a most fitting and difficult-to-find candidate for Kaohsiung mayor.
During his eight years as mayor, Wu planned numerous major infrastructure projects and laid down a solid foundation for Kaohsiung's future development, Lee said.

Wu also visited all levels of his administration diligently, greatly raising the standard and effectiveness of the city government's service for the people, bringing about prosperity and progress for the city, Lee added.

Vice President and KMT Vice Chairman Lien Chan also noted Wu's outstanding qualifications. In addition, he urged the party to express more concern for the other three KMT contenders. He said he hoped these members can also support the party's decision.
President of the Examination Yuan Hsu Shui-teh, a former Kaohsiung city mayor, said he believed Wu would win the support of Kaohsiung residents because of his numerous contributions.
C.K. Wu, director of Kaohsiung's Department of Information, said the nomination is a major benefit to the citizens of the southern metropolis.
Wu Den-yih is a capable candidate with integrity who has sought out several major construction projects from the central government for the long-term development of his city, C.K. Wu said.
He added that if the mayor can continue to guide municipal affairs at critical moments in the future, he can accomplish even more to improve the welfare of the residents of Kaohsiung.

Thursday will mark Wu's eighth anniversary in office. He was appointed to the Kaohsiung mayorship on June 18, 1990 and was popularly elected at the end of 1994 in the first Kaohsiung municipal election.
If Wu's bid for reelection this year is successful, he will be the longest serving mayor of Kaohsiung when he completes his 12 and a half years in office.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI COURT IMPOUNDS AIRPORT MRT LINE DOCUMENTS

TEXT.P: The Taipei District Court has impounded large quantities of documents concerning a bid for building a mass rapid transit system (MRT) linking Chiang Kai-shek International Airport in Taoyuan County to metropolitan Taipei.

Judge Lai Ying-hua led a team of court officials to the Engineering Office of the Highspeed Rail under the Ministry of Transportation and Communications (MOTC) on Tuesday evening and took away all related documents.
Lai told the press on Wednesday that the court action was taken in response to an application by BES Engineering Corp. to have the documents impounded to use as evidence.

Noting that the move is only one stage of civil court procedures aimed at the perpetuation of evidence, Lai said the impoundment is unbiased and does not imply any moral or legal judgment on any party involved.

BES, which lost to Chang Sheng International Development Co. in bidding for priority rights to negotiate a contract for building the new 34.5-km MRT line, said it had applied for the perpetuation of evidence because it might sue the MOTC for what it called mishandling of the bidding.

"In case we finally decide to file a lawsuit, we'll need all these documents to back our claims," a BES spokesman said, adding that the company is afraid the documents may be destroyed, lost, or otherwise made difficult to be produced for use in court.
He further said the company will apply for the right to read the impounded documents to ascertain whether there were any irregularities in the bidding process.

"Our action is a legal remedy and is not expected to hinder normal operations of the Engineering Office of Highspeed Rail because all the documents impounded are duplicated copies," the spokesman added.

The documents taken by the court include the winning contractor's full investment plan, reports detailing opinions of all relevant government agencies, a comprehensive evaluation report on all competing bids, reports concerning all technical problems, minutes of all screening meetings, and many other related data.

The BES action has drawn concern from President Lee Teng-hui and stern criticism from senior MOTC officials. President Lee summoned MOTC Minister Lin Feng-cheng Wednesday morning for questioning about the MRT line bidding process. During their half-hour talks, Lin briefed the president on details about the incident.

Lin later told the press that the impoundment is unnecessary and nonsensical. "The ministry had handled the bidding in an open, fair and just manner. The process was impeccable. I feel regret over BES' actions and allegations," he stated.

Stressing that preserving official documents is an unshirkable duty for public functionaries, Lin further said it is unlikely that any of the airport MRT line-related documents will be destroyed or lost.

Liao Ching-lung, director of the Engineering Office of Highspeed Rail, said the BES action has seriously undermined the government's reputation and credibility, and has even dealt a severe blow to the morale of all civil servants.
Liao also denied any irregularities or defects in the bidding for construction of the new MRT line under a BOT (build-operate-transfer) formula. The system is expected to become operational by 2003.

A total of five business groups tendered bids for the NT$50 billion project. Chang Sheng International Development Co., an affiliate of the Taichung-based Ever Fortune Group, won the priority right to negotiate a contract with the highspeed rail office within 45 days.
BES and Shang Ching MRT Co. were named as second and third alternatives in case Chang Sheng fails to strike a deal with the highspeed rail office during the specified period of time.

Since the MOTC announced the results of the bidding on May 26, the four losing bidders have lodged protests with relevant government agencies and have appealed to the watchdog Control Yuan over alleged irregularities and unfairness in the bidding process. One of them, the Tailien consortium, already filed a lawsuit with the Taipei District Court on May 28.

The airport MRT line is Taiwan's second infrastructure project to be built under the BOT scheme. The first such project is a high-speed railway which will stretch from Taipei in the north to Kaohsiung in the south.

DOC.HEADLINE: DEMENTIA DOESN'T ALWAYS AFFECT DRIVING SKILLS

TEXT.P: Although previous studies have shown people suffering from Alzheimer's disease have an increased risk of getting into an automobile accident, not all individuals with mild dementia exhibit poor driving skills.
Investigators at Washington University School of Medicine in St. Louis have identified specific aspects of attention that may help in determining whether a demented individual can drive safely.

"A demented older adult's attention capacity can sometimes be quite reduced, which makes it much more difficult for that person to deal with the complex environment that driving creates," said Janet Duchek, assistant professor of occupational therapy and lead author of a paper published in the latest issue of Journal of Gerontology.
John C. Morris, the Harvey A. and Dorismai Friedman Professor of Neurology, headed the research team while the National Institute on Aging funded the study.
Alzheimer's affects about 4 million Americans, many of whom continue to drive throughout the early stages of the disease.

A 1997 study of Alzheimer's affects on driving skills conducted by the same research team showed that 59 percent of individuals with mild dementia and 81 percent with very mild dementia passed their driving tests and appeared to retain relatively safe driving skills.
In the recent study, researchers investigated aspects of attention to predict which individuals with Alzheimer's were still safe on the road.
The study involved 136 participants recruited from the Washington University Alzheimer's Disease Research Center, which Morris co-directs.
These individuals were still driving at the time of the study, had a valid driver's license, at least 10 years of driving experience and corrected visual acuity of at least 20/50.
Each participant was screened and rated according to the Clinical Dementia Rating scale. Some participants were healthy controls, while others had very mild or mild dementia.
Morris said although Alzheimer's patients may drive safely for a while, every person with the disease eventually will become an unsafe driver.

"We do not wish to limit driving -- and hence an individual's independence -- too soon," he said. "The trick is to identify problems and intervene before a dangerous situation or actual crash occurs."

DOC.HEADLINE: JAPAN'S SOVEREIGN RISK RATING REMAINS STABLE

TEXT.P: Thomson Bankwatch, the world's largest bank rating agency, maintains its current Sovereign Risk Rating outlook for Japan at AAA stable.

Betty Starkey, director of sovereign risk at Thomson Bankwatch, said in a report to be released Wednesday that although the economic outlook continues to worsen in Asia, as the world's largest creditor nation, Japan has foreign exchange reserves of around US$200 billion, a substantial current account surplus, and deep institutionalized savings.
These resources should be more than sufficient to preserve the country's overall credit-worthiness, she said.
However, recently released economic data indicated that Japan's economy is in worse shape than previously anticipated, Starkey pointed out.
According to Japan's economic planning agency, the country's economy contracted by 1.3 percent in the first quarter of this year, or by an annualized rate of 5.3 percent.
Since a 0.4 percent contraction was reported in the fourth quarter of the last year, Japan is now technically in a recession, Starkey noted.
The recessive environment makes it highly unlikely that interest rates will be raised to defend the Japanese yen which has fallen sharply in recent days, the report said.

Japanese policy makers said they may intervene in the markets to stem the yen's decline. The effectiveness of government intervention is likely to be limited given market perceptions of continuing divergence between the sluggishness in Japan and the strength of the US economy, it continued.

The icy wind blowing out of Japan will dampen prospects for the rest of Asia, the report indicated, adding that currency and stock markets continue to tumble across the region over concerns that the yen's slide is turning out to be more rapid than expected.
As a result, Starkey concluded, the timetable for recovery in the rest of Asia has now been pushed back even further.

DOC.HEADLINE: SUMMIT SAID NOT TO HURT TAIWAN

TEXT.P: The United States has repeatedly assured the Republic of China that the upcoming meeting between US President Bill Clinton and mainland Chinese President Jiang Zemin will not hurt Taiwan's interests, and so far there have been no signs to indicate any such possibility, Foreign Affairs Minister Jason Hu said on Wednesday.

Hu said that from a personal point of view, he would like to trust the US promises made during recent US-ROC exchanges of opinion on the summit. The US side has repeatedly vowed that no surprise developments regarding Taiwan will be produced at the summit, slated for later this month in Beijing.

Speculating on the possible agenda of the Clinton-Jiang summit, the foreign minister forecast that trade and financial issues might take precedence because of the recent sharp depreciation of the Japanese yen and the impact of the Asian financial turmoil.
Hu made the remarks in a keynote speech to a meeting sponsored by a journalists' club.

Although Clinton may make a gesture to show US support for the "three noes," -- no Taiwan independence, no "two Chinas" or "one China, one Taiwan," and no United Nations membership for Taiwan -- at the summit, Hu said he does not believe that Washington will shift its basic stance toward Taiwan.
On the post-summit relations between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait, the foreign minister said his ministry would be delighted to see any improvement in bilateral ties.

The Cabinet-level Mainland Affairs Council has been actively pushing for a resumption of regular cross-strait talks, arranging a meeting between Koo Chen-fu, chairman of the semi-official Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF), and his mainland Chinese counterpart, Wang Daohan, chairman of the Beijing-based Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait (ARATS), by the end of this year, Hu pointed out.
Koo and Wang are the top negotiators representing Taipei and Beijing, respectively, to deal with two-way exchanges in the absence of formal contacts between the two sides.

Regular SEF and ARATS talks were suspended unilaterally by Beijing in 1995 after President Lee Teng-hui paid a landmark visit to the US that same year. Beijing viewed the trip as a covert move to promote Taiwan independence.

DOC.HEADLINE: AUSTRALIAN BUSINESS CONFIDENCE HITS SEVEN-YEAR LOW

TEXT.P: Business confidence in Australia has hit a seven-year low as a result of the lingering Asian crisis and the latest financial slump in Japan, Australia's largest trading partner.

In its latest joint survey by the Australian Chamber of Commerce and Industry (ACCI) and Westpac Banking Corporation, one of Australia's four leading banks, the country's gross domestic product in fiscal 1998-99 will only grow at 2.25 percent, lower than the government's forecast of 3 percent.
In fiscal 1997-98, Australia GDP is expected to grow at 3.75 percent.
Westpac now believes the Australian dollar, which has been battered by the weaker Japanese yen, the Asian crisis and falling commodity prices, will further drop to 55 US cents in the near term.
The currency closed Tuesday at 58.68 US cents.

Westpac's general manager for economics, Bill Evans, said Australia's inflation, measured by the Consumer Price Index, is expected to increase to about 3 percent from the current rate of below 2 percent.
"The results of the latest survey highlight clearly the dangers of raising interest rates in the current environment," he said.
He said many Australian businessmen have now either stopped new investment plans or have put them on hold.

Evans said Westpac has downgraded its forecast for GDP growth in 1998-99 from 2.5 percent to 2.25 percent. This is well below the federal government's forecast of 3 percent economic growth for 1998-99.

He said the Westpac-ACCI survey showed production and new orders have fallen dramatically over the past three months with capacity utilization also down sharply over the same period. He did not give figures.
"The drag in growth from falling exports has clearly grown and is now more than negating any strength in domestic sales," Evans said.

ACCI chief executive Mark Paterson said the disappointing survey results confirmed the need for more reform despite the backlash against change being exploited by Independent Member of Parliament Pauline Hanson's One Nation Party, which scored a stunning victory in the Queensland state election on June 13.
Shadow Treasurer Gareth Evans said the survey finally dispelled the myth that the coalition government under Prime Minister John Howard had "fireproofed" the Australian economy from the Asian crisis.

"Australians now face an economic horror story: falling exports, falling output, falling business investment, a falling dollar, falling employment -- but rising home mortgage rates and rising unemployment," Gareth Evans told reporters yesterday.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN IS CALIFORNIA'S FOURTH-LARGEST EXPORT OUTLET
DOC.DATELINE: Los Angeles, June 16 (CNA) (By Chu Lusheng & Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: Taiwan is California's fourth-largest export market, while Hong Kong is the 10th-largest and mainland China, the 14th, according to the latest tallies from the US state's Trade and Commerce Agency (TCA).
Taiwan imported US$1.68 billion-worth of goods from California in the first quarter of this year, up 18 percent from the year-earlier level, making it the golden state's fourth-largest export outlet.
In 1996, Taiwan was California's sixth-largest overseas market, behind Japan, Canada, South Korea, Mexico and Singapore.

John C. Lungren Jr., international marketing director for the TCA, said it is amazing that an island as small as Taiwan has turned out to be the fourth-largest market for Californian goods, especially when compared to mainland China's 14th position, with its population 58 times that of Taiwan's, and its area 250 times larger than Taiwan.
The TCA's trade figures in the first quarter of this year show Japan still to be California's largest overseas market.

This position, however, is threatened by the so-called "Chinese communities" -- Taiwan, Hong Kong and mainland China -- whose combined trade volume with California approached that of Japan's in the first three months of the year.
TCA officials estimated that Japan may soon be outperformed by the three "Chinese communities," as the Japanese government has declared that its economy has entered a recession.

California, the hub of America's computer, aerospace, biochemical, environmental protection and technology industries, has seen increased exports to Taiwan in recent years, and an increased number of companies in the above-mentioned sectors have invested in Taiwan, the officials noted.

In a visit to Taipei in February this year, Los Angeles Mayor Richard Riordan struck cooperation agreements with Evergreen Marine Corp. and Yangming Marine Transport, two leading Taiwan shipping companies. These agreements are expected to further help expand business cooperation between Taiwan and California.

Describing California as the US in miniature, the officials said that in 1996, Taiwan was the US' sixth-largest import source, the seventh-largest export market, and the eighth-largest trading partner.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN SUGAR TO SHIFT AUSSIE OFFICE DUE TO 'ONE NATION' WIN

TEXT.P: Taiwan Sugar Corp. of Taiwan will move its regional head office to New South Wales (NSW) from Queensland as a result of the One Nation Party victory in state elections on June 13, according to the Taiwan-Australia Business Association (TABA) in Brisbane.
Chinese business authorities in Shanghai have also raised concerns over the investment climate in Queensland due to the anti-Asian policies advocated by the One Nation Party.

TABA President Jim Sheu told The Australian newspaper Tuesday that Taiwan Sugar would base itself in NSW because Queensland would not be an appropriate place for its regional office after the One Nation Party won an unprecedented victory.

The party, often called racist, anti-Asian and anti-multiculturalism, is expected to win between nine and 12 seats at the Queensland Legislative Assembly. The victory could put the One Nation Party, set up by Independent Member of Parliament Pauline Hanson, in the balance of power in the Queensland government.
"Taiwan Sugar is looking for multiple investment opportunities, and A$20 million (US$12.5 million) is just small potatoes," he added.

In an interview with business authorities in Shanghai, the Australian Broadcasting Corporation's correspondent Jane Hutcheon reported that Chinese investment in Queensland is likely to change following the victory of the One Nation Party.
The Australian Chamber of Commerce and Industry (ACCI) said the victory for the One Nation Party resulted in major concern among foreign businessmen and their investments in Australia.
"Clearly it is a major concern not just from Taiwan not to invest in Australia, but any investment from overseas is certain to have the same view," ACCI chief executive Mark Paterson said.
At a news conference Wednesday morning, Prime Minister John Howard said foreign investors are looking for a stable environment when they make their investment overseas.
"If we don't welcome them to invest in Australia, they will certainly go elsewhere," he warned.

Tourism Minister Andrew Thomson said the One Nation's parliamentary team had a "big cannon" aimed at Queensland's A$8 billion (US$5 billion) tourism industry and the state must now reassure skittish Asian markets.
He warned of potential havoc from the new political force as tangible signs of damage to Queensland business began flowing from the One Nation's popularity.

Taiwan's investment in Australia, mainly in shopping malls, a steel mill and a joint venture in salt, eels and prawn cultivation, is estimated at well over A$1 billion (US$625 million) in recent years.
Trade officials from both Taiwan and Australia believe Taiwanese investment in Australia is expected to increase in coming years.
Two-way trade between the two countries rose 12 percent in 1997 to A$6.7 billion (US$4.5 billion) from the 1996 level.

They said there is more room for both countries to increase trade and investment because Australia and Taiwan are complimentary. Australia has rich natural resources while Taiwan is awash with capital, good in marketing and strong in the manufacturing sector.

DOC.HEADLINE: NO PRICE FIXING FOUND ON COPYRIGHTED IMPORTS

TEXT.P: Taiwan's Fair Trade Commission (FTC) on Wednesday released a report on the increased market prices of several copyrighted import products, but found no evidence of a concerted effort at price fixing.
In April, prices from 223 related businesses in Taipei, Taichung and Kaohsiung were compared with those from May of last year.

The study revealed that cable channel fees registered the highest price hike, at 24.19 percent on average, mainly due to increases in copyright royalties, which increased average broadcasting costs by 31.44 percent.
Computer software cost 15.2 percent more than last year, mainly because of major fluctuations in the new Taiwan dollar and subsequent price adjustments by traders.
Magazine prices also went up by 12.06 percent, because of changes in the currency exchange rate coupled with an increased cost of pulp in the international market.
Compact discs went up in price by 10.74 percent, while video game cartridges registered a price drop of 15.34 percent and laser discs fell 5.36 percent.

FTC member Cheng Yiu said the commission did not find any evidence of companies involved in price fixing, but stressed that the commission will continue to monitor the behavior of the companies involved.

DOC.HEADLINE: AN OVERVIEW OF IMPACT OF FINANCIAL TURMOIL ON HONG KONG

TEXT.P: The Asian regional financial turmoil which began last summer is still exerting an impact on Hong Kong, with no end in sight.

Its impact on Hong Kong's economy was first reflected on the stock market and the slump in real estate prices. Speculators carried out successful hit and run operations in South East Asian money markets before making an onslaught on Hong Kong's currency in August, 1997. In order to counter this speculation and in defense of its exchange system pegging the Hong Kong dollar to the US dollar, the Hong Kong government chose a high interest rate policy at that time.

Although the policy defeated the speculators and kept the HK dollar stable, the measure delivered a serious blow to Hong Kong's stock market, resulting in a plummet in securities which saw the Hang Seng equity index falling to the 10,000 level by the end of 1997 from 16,800 last August.

In addition to the fall in the stock market, the price of real estate also dropped drastically. In response to the inflationary spiral of real estate at the end of l997, the Hong Kong government announced measures to curtail the trend. One of the important measures was to build 85,000 housing units in the hope of keeping a reasonable balance between demand and supply.

However, just as the Asian financial crisis began to bite, the well-intentioned housing policy was censured acrimoniously as a negative factor which was accelerating the fall of Hong Kong's real estate prices.

At the end of May, the government announced negative growth of 2 percent for first-quarter 1998 exports, while unemployment rose to 3.9 percent in February through April. In mid-June, unemployment rose further to 4.2 percent in the period from March to May, the highest rate in 15 years.
All in all, economic prospects for Hong Kong are bleak.

Tung Chee Hwa, chief executive of the Hong Kong Special Administrative Region, has admitted that the economy is going down, and anticipated recently that Hong Kong's economy will deteriorate even more in the next few quarters.
These factors leave us in no doubt that Hong Kong's economy is entering into a recession.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC'S MAINLAND CHINA POLICY AIMED AT BUILDING FREE CHINA

TEXT.P: Republic of China President Lee Teng-hui said on Tuesday that his government will be glad to see US engagement with mainland China as long as it is helpful in maintaining peace and stability in the Asia-Pacific region.

Lee made the remarks in a meeting with visiting scholars from the US at the Presidential Office in Taipei. The scholars, most of whom are China experts, were attending the two-day "27th Sino-American Conference on Contemporary China" which opened here on Monday.

They were accompanied on their visit to the Presidential Office by Shaw Yu-ming, director of the Institute of International Relations under National Chengchi University, which sponsored the conference.

During the meeting, Lee told his visitors that his government has been pursuing a mainland China policy based on the spirit of "peace, equality, rationality and goodness," which will eventually establish a China under freedom, democracy and equal distribution of wealth.
The policy includes promoting mutual understanding by means of exchanges, and trying to eliminate hostility between Taiwan and mainland China by forming mutually beneficial relations, Lee said.

The president also said that the ROC expects interaction between Washington and Beijing to be beneficial to the peace and stability of the Asia-Pacific region, and expressed his optimism toward ROC-US ties.
Lee said he believes US President Bill Clinton, who is due to take a mainland China trip in late June, should be aware of the ROC's stance on the China issue.
As to the trilateral interaction among Taiwan, mainland China and the United States, Lee expressed the hope of developing peaceful and mutually beneficial relations.

His visitors included former US Ambassador to Beijing James Lilley; Arthur Waldron, professor in history at the University of Pennsylvania; Lin Nan, director of Duke University's Institute for Asian Studies; Wang Shaoguang, assistant professor in politics at Yale University; and Michael Y.M. Kau, professor in politics at Brown University.

DOC.HEADLINE: NT DOLLAR UP

TEXT.P: The New Taiwan dollar soared NT$0.138 against the greenback on Wednesday in Taipei, closing at 34.681.
The local currency opened at 34.487 and was traded between 34.48 and 34.839.
The interbank US dollar trading reached US$238.5 million.

DOC.HEADLINE: FORD LIO HO CONSIDERS PRICE INCREASE ON IMPORTED CARS

TEXT.P: Taiwan's Ford Lio Ho Motor Company Ltd. may increase prices for its imported cars in July due to the increased differential between Taiwan's falling currency exchange rate and Ford's reported import exchange rate, Ford Lio Ho spokesman Hsu Guo-Cheng said on Wednesday.

Hsu pointed out that a major round of devaluation in the local currency in the second half of last year caused Ford Lio Ho to adjust its reported import exchange rate from NT$27 to NT$31 to the greenback to reflect the differential, which led to an upward adjustment in its prices for imported cars.

Now that that NT dollar has further devalued to NT$34 to the greenback, the pressure on Ford Lio Ho has increased again, but the company is worried that adjusting the price will only give consumers cold feet and adversely affect sales, Hsu said.
Consequently, the major car importers are currently observing the situation, with none wanting to be the first to raise prices, Hsu said, adding that Ford Lio Ho will not be the first.

The US Ford Group takes care of all maneuvers related to shielding its global dealerships from exchange rate risk, Hsu said. This gives Ford Lio Ho strong support so that it can afford to take the pressure of the exchange rate differential better than others in the industry.

DOC.HEADLINE: BILL GATES TO VISIT TAIWAN

TEXT.P: Bill Gates, chairman & CEO of Microsoft, will arrive here on Friday for a one-day visit, Microsoft Taiwan Corp. officials said on Wednesday.

During his whirlwind trip, Gates is expected to promote his company's new Windows 98 and meet local leaders in the software industry. He is also likely to meet with President Lee Teng-hui, the officials said.
Gates will deliver a speech on the "digital nervous system" at the Taipei International Convention Center, according to the officials.
At the invitation of the semi-official China External Trade Development Council (CETRA), Gates will also shoot a videotape to promote Taiwan high-end products.
This will be the first time the world-renowned computer software titan has ever spoken on behalf of products from any single country, CETRA officials said.
It will be his seventh visit to Taiwan. The last time he visited was in June 1996, when he attended the 20th anniversary of the founding of Taiwan-based ACER.

DOC.HEADLINE: DISSIDENTS WARNED OUT OF MAINLAND CHINA CITIES DURING CLINTON VISIT
DOC.DATELINE: Hong Kong, June 17 (CNA) (By Sherman Wu and Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: Mainland Chinese dissidents have been warned by public security officials not to go to the cities of Beijing, Shanghai or Xian during the visit to mainland China by US President Bill Clinton from June 27 to July 3, a Hong Kong-based human rights organization said on Wednesday.

A spokesman for the organization said the warning came after a dissident from Qingdao in northern Shandong Province was sent back to Qingdao on Wednesday morning after being detained for a night in the capital by Beijing public security officials.

Mou Chuanheng, who went to Beijing last week to visit friends, was taken from his hotel on Monday night by local public security forces, the spokesman said, adding that Mou was told that ranking authorities had ordered that "sensitive elements" like him are not allowed to stay in Beijing because of Clinton's upcoming visit to the capital.

As speculation is mounting that Clinton plans to talk to people on the street while visiting Beijing, the spokesman pleaded with the US president not to do so, saying that such action could bring mainland dissidents under even heavier state scrutiny and control.

Although it would be a well-intentioned gesture on the part of the US president, the spokesman said, it could deprive the dissidents of the freedom to visit friends or travel during the period of Clinton's stay in mainland China.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAOYUAN COUNTY CHIEF MEETS CLINTON ON TAIWAN STRAIT ISSUE

TEXT.P: Taoyuan County Magistrate Annette Lu said on Wednesday that she has asked US President Bill Clinton not to impair Taiwan's interests during his upcoming visit to mainland China.
Lu, a former legislator from the opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP), told the press that she met Clinton during an evening party in San Francisco last Friday.

"I took advantage of the occasion to present to Clinton a letter signed by 10 Taiwan city mayors and county magistrates, which urged Clinton not to make Taiwan a sacrifice of his summit meeting with mainland Chinese President Jiang Zemin," Lu said.

"After reading the letter, Clinton assured me that he fully understands Taiwan's stance and will not do anything harmful to its interests or dangerous to its security," the outspoken former political prisoner added.
The 10 local government chiefs, including Lu herself, said in the letter that they are basic levels of elected officials and are in constant touch with grassroots public opinion.

"All of our people appreciate your sending two aircraft carrier battle groups to help maintain peace in the Taiwan Strait in March 1996 when communist China were conducting missile tests and live-fire war games in the strait to intimidate us in the run-up to Taiwan's first direct presidential election," the letter said.

Nevertheless, it added, the majority of Taiwan people think that the US "one China" policy, which acknowledges there is only one China and that Taiwan is part of China, is erroneous and dangerous. "We hope the United States will revise its position based on the reality."
The letter further said all Taiwan people are concerned about the forthcoming Clinton-Jiang summit meeting in Beijing, whose agenda is certain to include the Taiwan Strait issue.
It reminded Clinton not to throw his support behind Beijing's overture to use a "one country, two systems" scheme to unify Taiwan.
"Although Beijing has used the formula to take over Hong Kong from Britain, the format is not applicable to Taiwan. Taiwan is not Hong Kong, which used to be a colony," the letter stressed.
It went on to say Taiwan is more than willing to maintain friendly, reciprocal relations with mainland China and all other countries around the world on an equal footing.
The letter called on Clinton to help push for peaceful co-existence of the two sides of the Taiwan Strait. "And you are welcome to visit Taiwan at your pleasure."

Except Lu, the nine other local government chiefs who signed the letter were Hsinchu County Magistrate Lin Kuang-hua, Kaohsiung County Magistrate Yu Cheng-hsien, Taichung County Magistrate Liao Yung-lai, Ilan County Magistrate Liu Shou-cheng, Hsinchu City Mayor Tsai Jen-chien, Pingtung County Magistrate Su Chia-chuan, Tainan County Magistrate Chen Tang-shan, Chiayi City Mayor Chang Po-ya and Nantou County Magistrate Peng Pai-hsien.
Because of her busy schedule, Lu said she couldn't have asked other mayors and county chiefs to sign the letter.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC LEGISLATORS STATE TAIWAN'S POSITION ON CLINTON SUMMIT

TEXT.P: A delegation of 19 Republic of China legislators told a Washington press conference on Tuesday that they were in the US to state the position of the 21 million people of Taiwan that the rights and interests of Taiwan should not be affected by President Bill Clinton's upcoming visit to mainland China and his summit talks with mainland Chinese President Jiang Zemin.
Legislator Rau Yin-chi, the delegation leader, noted in a joint statement that the basic consensus and position of the people of Taiwan are:

-- "We firmly oppose any bilateral negotiations between the US and the PRC regarding our country's affairs, and under no circumstances will we accept any stipulations and/or agreements concerning Taiwan reached by the US and the PRC;

-- "Since peace and stability in the Taiwan Strait is not only of critical importance to Taiwan's future but also affects vital American strategic interests, we hope that the US will urge the PRC to renounce the use of force against the ROC on Taiwan;

-- "With Taiwan's strong economic power, it should be able to contribute even more to the international community. We therefore would like to join more international organizations and play a more active role in them; and

-- "We hope the US will exercise its influence to prevent the Asian financial crisis from spreading to other parts of the region and affecting the stability, prosperity, and order of the world economy."

Yao added their hopes that the summit will help build stability in the Taiwan Strait and the Asia-Pacific region as a whole. However, he added: "It is imperative that any improvement in the relationship between the United States and the PRC should not be made at the cost of Taiwan's interests, nor should it negatively affect our relations with the United States.

"The ROC Legislative Yuan appreciates the long-term support and assistance from the United States and especially House Resolution 270, which the House of Representatives passed by an overwhelming majority of 411 votes to zero, suggesting that President Clinton urge Beijing to publicly renounce the use of force against Taiwan.
"This resolution shows that the people of both the US and the ROC agree that problems between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait should be resolved in a peaceful manner," the ROC legislator noted.

DOC.HEADLINE: NEW PARTY LEADER SUGGESTS LEE-CHEN PRESIDENTIAL TICKET

TEXT.P: It is possible that current ROC President Lee Teng-hui and Taipei Mayor Chen Shui-bian will run together in the 2000 presidential election, said Jaw Shau-kong, general campaign manager of the opposition New Party, on Wednesday.

Jaw made the remarks in a press conference at the Legislative Yuan Wednesday morning. He suggested that Lee, chairman of the ruling Kuomintang, and Chen, a member of the opposition Democratic Progressive Party, could forge an alliance.
"Politics is an art of possibility, and there is nothing impossible," said Jaw, a former legislator who once headed the Environmental Protection Administration and ran for Taipei mayor.

Jaw predicted President Lee will seek re-election and said that even if Chen is re-elected mayor of Taipei, no law prohibits a vice president of the Republic of China from serving concurrently as a mayor of a municipality under the central government.
Although Lee and Chen belong to different political parties, both wield considerable influence. A Lee-Chen ticket stands a good chance of winning the election, Jaw said.
Jaw said both men are friendly toward each other. Moreover, he said he doubts Lee's support for Ma Ying-jeou's bid for Taipei mayor.
If Lee and Chen were to run together in the next election and Chen were elected vice president, the next step for Chen would be a presidential bid in the 2004 election, Jaw said.

DOC.HEADLINE: US WORRIED ABOUT COMMUNIST CHINA'S PRESENCE IN PANAMA
DOC.DATELINE: Panama City, Panama, June 16 (CNA) (By Edward Chen)

TEXT.P: Richard Delgaudio, chairman of the Center of National Security of the United States has confirmed that the US is concerned about the presence of the Chinese communists in Panama.

Delgaudio, who headed a delegation on a week-long visit to Panama, told a news conference on Monday that Washington is worried about the transition of the Panama Canal. As the United States prepares to pull out of Panama, it appears that Chinese communists are beginning to infiltrate the country, he added.

"This event has not only (caused worry among) Americans but also Panamanians. The economics and the security of both (the US and Panama) are tied to the correct administration and the security of the Panama Canal," he said.

After he and his delegation conducted investigations, Delgaudio confirmed that the Chinese communists have been attempting to control the Panama Canal through the Hong Kong-based Hutchison group. Panama conceded the administration of the Balboa and Cristobal ports to Hutchison for 22 years with a 10-year option.
"The Chinese communists are infiltrating Panama by means of Hutchison while the US interests are pulling out," he pointed out.

Delgaudio, the author of book entitled "The Death Knell of the Panama Canal," said American interests in the Panama Canal have not only not been protected but also been sold to the Chinese communists by Perez Balladares' administration.
"Only the presence of the United States in military bases and ports of the Panama Canal can guarantee a promising future which complete all expectations.
"The transition of the canal, the presence of Chinese communists and stability of workers had been demonstrated to both Americans and Panamanians as a great uncertainty," he concluded.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAZDA GIVES TAIWAN DEALERSHIP TO FORD LIO HO

TEXT.P: Japan's Mazda Co. on Wednesday announced that it is transferring the Taiwan dealership for Mazda automobiles, with the exception of its T-series of vans, from Taiwan Mazda to Ford Lio Ho Motor Company, one of the largest car traders on the island.
Bunzo Suzuki, senior project manager for the overseas sales division of Mazda Co., made the announcement at a press conference in Taipei, accompanied by representatives from all three companies.

He explained that the decision for the move which will go into effect on Oct. 1 was made because Mazda is facing ever-stronger business competition in Taiwan, and this competition is expected to increase even more once the island enters the World Trade Organization.

More importantly, Suzuki said, his company wishes to increase its market share by taking advantage of Ford Lio Ho's complete sales network covering the island and its excellent marketing capabilities.

Under the new arrangement, Mazda Taiwan will remain in charge of the T-series van dealership on the island, and maintain its role as a district distributor of Mazda cars in key areas of Taiwan such as Taipei, Mazda Taiwan President Wang Chung-ho said.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHENG HOLDS ONTO HIS JOB -- FOR NOW

TEXT.P: The Executive Yuan is not considering a job transfer for Cheng Chuan, acting director of the Investigation Bureau, despite the fact that he is currently in hot water over a rape allegation, an Executive Yuan official said on Wednesday.
Chang You-hui, secretary-general of the Executive Yuan, said that Cheng will remain in his job pending the result of an independent investigation into the allegation.

However, he added that if the investigation substantiates the accusation that Cheng sexually molested a friend's daughter in Paris, then the Executive Yuan will begin to consider whether to keep Cheng, and who to appoint as his likely successor if he steps down.
Cheng openly gave his side of the story when he finally appeared on Tuesday before a four-member team, headed by Vice Justice Minister Chiang Hao, which was formed to get to the bottom of the matter.
He defended his reputation, saying that he was only trying to cure the daughter of his friend Yang Wan-shou with Chikung, a traditional martial art which is believed to have curative powers.

He denied categorically any wrongdoing with the girl, then 19 and suffering from anorexia nervosa, countering claims by her parents that he touched her breast and private parts under the pretext of helping to cure her in his Paris hotel room.
Cheng said he will step down after the investigation is closed, pointing out that if he leaves now, it might be seen as a tacit admission of guilt.

But many questions remain unanswered as the drama develops into a "Rashomon-style" scenario, with the accuser and the accused each giving their own conflicting accounts of the events surrounding the case, as in the famous movie of that name by Japanese director Akira Kurosawa.
The Ministry of Justice has even considered sending officials to Paris to collect information relating to the case in order to help find answers to the outstanding questions.
Although speculation has been rampant about the removal of Cheng from his post, and about his likely successor, the Executive Yuan has been cautious about commenting on the case.

The case first surfaced when Lai Ching-lin, a National Assemblyman of the opposition Democratic Progressive Party, accused Cheng of molesting the daughter of a friend during a trip to the French capital between Sept. 9 and 13, 1996.
Lai claimed that he was asked to come forward to expose Cheng after the government allegedly failed to respond to Yang's repeated demands for an investigation.

DOC.HEADLINE: VIRAL OUTBREAK CLAIMS ANOTHER LIFE

TEXT.P: The enterovirus epidemic that has swept Taiwan since mid-February claimed the life of another young child on Wednesday, bringing the death toll to 41 babies and toddlers around the island, health officials said.

The latest victim was a three-year-old girl who died at the Changhua Christian Hospital in central Taiwan early in the morning. Doctors said the girl first received treatment for high fever at the hospital four days ago and was hospitalized again on Tuesday evening. Despite intensive care, the girl still failed to regain consciousness and died at 2 a.m. Wednesday.
Meanwhile, a pediatrician at the Chung Shan Medical and Dental College Hospital said immunoglobulin has proved to be an effective pharmaceutical to treat enteroviral infection.

Shen Ke-huan, director of the Chung Shan hospital's pediatrics department, said the conditions of seven seriously ill enteroviral patients have imrpoved significantly after receiving injections of immunoglobulin.

Parents of those children, however, said the drug is too expensive. The current National Health Insurance Program does not offer coverage to immunoglobulin. Some city and county health offices offer financial subsidies to newborn babies who have to receive injections of the drug. Nevertheless, the privilege is only extended to babies younger than one month.

Chan Chi-hsien, director of the Department of Health (DOH), made an inspection tour of the Bureau of Health under the Taipei City Government on Wednesday to show his concern about the city's measures to cope with the enteroviral outbreak.

Chan said the DOH will encourage all local hospitals to help monitor the outbreak of any epidemic. "Reports on major epidemics will be listed as one of factors to measure the performance of local hospitals in the future," he added.

The country's top health official further said the DOH is considering developing a vaccine to help curb the spread of the epidemic now that a complete pathological autopsy has confirmed that enterovirus type-71 is the culprit of the recent wave of contagion.
Nevertheless, Chan said there are still many problems to be addressed before making a decision on whether to develop such a vaccine.
"First and foremost, we must consider the safety of the vaccine. Secondly, we must further study the tendency of the enteroviral outbreak," Chan noted.

Tu Hsin-tze, director of the Taipei municipal Bureau of Health, said a total of 2,641 cases of entervirus infections were discovered in the city from June 5 through June 16. Among those patients, 267 were hospitalized. "About half of these patients were Taipei residents, while the remaining half came from other cities or counties to receive treatment," he said, adding that the death toll in Taipei stood at four so far.
Tu further said the peak of the epidemic was already over in Taipei. "The number of patients has gradually declined in recent days," he added.
Meanwhile, some medical doctors predicted that the current viral epidemic probably will continue until August or September.
Children under five years of age are most susceptible to enterovirus, and common symptoms of an infection include a fever and rash with ulcers on the hands, feet and mouth.

The death rate of the infection is not high if patients receive timely proper treatment. To protect their children from infection, parents are advised to keep their children away from crowded public places, and make sure that children change clothes and wash hands frequently.

DOC.HEADLINE: 'ONE COUNTRY, TWO SYSTEMS' MODEL SAID UNSUITABLE FOR TAIWAN

TEXT.P: Whatever the results of the "one country, two systems" model being applied to Hong Kong, most people in Taiwan believe the model is unsuitable for Taiwan, according to a series of surveys conducted by the Mainland Affairs Council over the past year.
William Li, director of MAC's Department of Hong Kong and Macao Affairs, said local people are still suspicious of the "one country, two systems" model.
In every survey, 77 percent to 88 percent of Taiwan respondents rejected the model for Taiwan, while as much as 55 percent of Hong Kong respondents expressed a similar view.

Li stressed that Taiwan respondents agreed in principle with several points advocated by Beijing: that Hong Kong people will run the former British colony, that Hong Kong will be given a substantial degree of autonomy and that its status will remain unchanged for 50 years.
Taiwan respondents also hope Hong Kong can become a freer and more democratic and prosperous society, Li said.

DOC.HEADLINE: TRADE AND INDUSTRY ASSOCIATION OPPOSE NATIONAL PENSION SYSTEM

TEXT.P: Local trade and industry organizations on Wednesday issued a joint statement, protesting a possible increase in the business tax rate to support a proposed national pension system.

By increasing the business tax rate from 5 percent to 6 percent, the consumer price index will rise 0.65 percent, while economic growth will be reduced by 0.2 percent, according to the statement. The increase will seriously affect the island's industrial development, the statement said.

The General Chamber of Commerce of the Republic Of China, the Chinese National Federation of Industries and the Chinese National Association of Industry and Commerce suggested in the statement that the government reduce spending, impose additional taxes on tobacco and wine or create a national lottery to generate funds for the pension plan, slated to go into effect by the end of 1999.

The statement further criticized the government for ushering in the plan fast on the heels of the national health insurance program, which was introduced in 1995. The experience of developed countries shows the introduction of such systems should be spaced at least 10 years apart, according to the statement. Moreover, people do not have a clear enough picture of the contents of the pension plan, similar to some countries' social security programs.

The system will apply to people who are not covered by existing pension programs for servicemen, government employees and the workforce, according to the Executive Yuan task force in charge of devising the plan. Ultimately, all current pension plans will be absorbed into the proposed national plan after such a plan is approved by the Legislative Yuan. The bill stipulates regulations governing the national pension system will be sent to the legislators for approval in the first half of next year.

If the system takes effect in 1999 as proposed, monthly premiums for that year will be NT$910 per person. The government will provide subsidies of NT$182 for workers, NT$655 for government employees and NT$364 for people who are unemployed. Employers will be required to contribute NT$582 for each employee, while workers must pay NT$146 each. Government employee, meanwhile, must pay NT$255.

The government must come up with nearly NT$44 billion in its 1999 budget to fund the plan, although the proposed increase in the business tax rate would generate an estimated NT$32.5 billion of that amount.

Monthly pension payments will amount to NT$9,100 per person, provided that person has contributed to the fund for a period of 40 years. Others will be paid amounts relative to the amount of time they have been paying into the fund.

Under the plan people begin contributing to the fund at the age of 25 and cannot withdraw a pension until they reach 65. However, they can, at that point, continue paying into the fund and receive larger payments at a later date.

Anyone seriously injured or killed during the time he is contributing to the fund or receiving pension payments from it is entitled to a compensation payment. In the case of death, the payment will be made to the family of the deceased.
Once the plan is introduced, anyone over 65 years old who has never received a pension payment under another system will be entitled to a monthly stipend of some NT$2,000.

DOC.HEADLINE: SLICK FROM SUNKEN SHIP SPREADS ACROSS KEELUNG HARBOR

TEXT.P: A gravel ship rammed by a tanker Tuesday in Keelung Harbor continues to leak oil, fueling a slick that is spreading across the harbor.
With its keel resting on the sea bed, the Yi Fang No. 1 is poking part-way out of the water, surrounded by the thick black slick, which has confounded workers' attempts to contain it.

Workers sprayed more than 1,300 gallons of detergent to clean the water and tried to capture the fuel with sponges and scoops. Only six barrels of fuel had been collected as of Wednesday evening, dampening worker's hopes that the slick could be removed within three days, as originally thought.
Now workers are unsure how long it will take to remove the spill.
The Yi Fang No. 1 and its cargo, 4,000 tons of gravel, sank within 20 minutes of being rammed by a Malaysian-flagged ship, the Tan-Jung. No casualties were reported, however.
The cause of the accident is still under investigation.

DOC.HEADLINE: FISHERMEN OPPOSE CUTTING TARIFFS FOR FISHERY PRODUCTS

TEXT.P: Scores of representatives from the fishery industry went to the Ministry of Economic Affairs Wednesday to express their discontent over possible reductions in tariffs on fishery products.

The representatives, led by Legislator Shih Tai-sheng of the ruling Kuomintang, met with Board of Foreign Trade Director-General Chen Juei-lung Wednesday. The group said they will call a press conference soon to highlight their opposition to the possible reductions.

The protest comes before a trade ministerial meeting of Asia Pacific Economic Cooperation forum in Kuching, Malaysia from June 21 to 23. A Taiwan delegation, led by Economics Minister Wang Chih-kang, will leave Saturday to attend the meeting.

The meeting will center on voluntary liberalization measures in nine areas: environmental protection, energy, forestry, toys, jewelry, medical equipment, telecommunications, chemicals and fishery products.
APEC members will discuss a goal of cutting tariffs on more than 3,000 products in the aforementioned categories to zero or nearly zero by 2005.
BOFT officials have said Taiwan supports the liberalization measures in principle, though it is less committed to an early tariff reductions in the sensitive area of fishery products.

The Council of Agriculture, meanwhile, has said Taiwan will cut the average tariffs on fishery products from the current level of 27.9 percent to 20.5 percent within the first year of Taiwan's entry to the World Trade Organization, with further annual reductions to follow.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC PREMIER TO VISIT TONGA, SOLOMON ISLANDS AND FIJI IN JULY

TEXT.P: Premier Vincent Siew will visit two of the Republic of China's South Pacific allies, Tonga and Solomon Islands, as well as Fiji, which does not maintain official ties with Taiwan, the Ministry of Foreign Affairs announced Wednesday.

Minister of Economic Affairs Wang Chih-kang, Council of Agriculture Chairman Peng Chuo-kui, Director-General of the Government Information Office Chen Chien-jen and Vice Foreign Minister David Tawei Lee will accompany Siew and his wife on the trip.
The group will use a chartered plane, as commercial flights from Taiwan to those countries are so infrequent, and will transit in either Australia or New Zealand.

This will be Siew's forth trip overseas but his first to ROC allies since taking office as premier last September. Siew will attend celebrations marking the 80th birthday of the King of Tonga, Taufaahau Tupou IV, as well as commemorations of the 20th anniversary of the Solomon Islands' independence, said the MOFA.

DOC.HEADLINE: VICE PRESIDENT MEETS WITH 1997 NOBEL ECONOMICS LAUREATE

TEXT.P: Vice President Lien Chan welcomed on Wednesday last year's Nobel winner in economics, Dr. Robert C. Merton, at Lien's office.

Lien told the visiting Nobel laureate that in line with a worldwide trend toward economic liberalization and globalization, Taiwan has been building the island into a regional operations hub that includes manufacturing, ocean transportation, air freight, financial, telecommunications and mass media centers.

The vice president said Taiwan's efforts to join the World Trade Organization have made great progress, as Taiwan has reached agreements on entry terms with almost all of the WTO members that requested trade talks with Taiwan.
Lin stressed that Taiwan aims to make itself into a unique financial center in Asia-Pacific region, saying it will not merely follow in the footsteps of Hong Kong and Singapore.
Merton said that the aim of his trip was to gain a better understanding of Taiwan's economic situation and to learn more about how Taiwan is coping with Asia's financial turmoil.
Later in the day, Premier Vincent Siew also met with Merton. During the meeting, they exchanged views on Asia's financial crisis and the current economic situation in Taiwan.
Siew said that he believes that with sound economic fundamentals, Taiwan will weather the financial turmoil. He added that Taiwan will stimulate economic growth by boosting domestic demand.

DOC.HEADLINE: PAL SCALES BACK OPERATIONS

TEXT.P: To save Philippine Airlines, the country's flagship carrier, from total bankruptcy, its management announced the implementation of the company's "Plan 14" contingency plan.

The airline will retain only 14 aircraft, returning 16 others to the foreign leasing companies from which they came, said Avenilo Zapanta, PAL's senior vice president for marketing. Eight Fokker F-50s, two Boeing 747-200s, four Airbus A-340s and two Airbus A300s will be returned.
PAL will also reduce the number of destinations it serves to seven: Hong Kong, Narita, Fukuoka, Singapore, Taipei, Los Angeles and San Francisco.
Daily domestic flights will be reduced from 54 to 22, he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: A SURE BET: SINGAPOREANS GAMBLING HABITS NOT DAMPENED BY TURMOIL

TEXT.P: Singaporeans spent a record S$5.5 billion (about US$3.4 billion) on gambling and sweepstakes in the last fiscal year, and regional economic turmoil has not dampened their enthusiasm for gambling so far this year.

Both Singapore Pools Co. and the Singapore Turf Club reported strong first quarter earnings. The Turf Club had one of its strongest quarters ever in the first three months of this year, with horse racing and the 4-D lottery taking in a combined S$626 million.
The last fiscal year has been the best to date for legal gambling in Singapore. Figures did not include bets placed with illegal gambling syndicates and in casinos around the region.
Singapore's favorite game of chance is still 4-D, which drew in more than S$3 billion in the last fiscal year. Horse racing came in second with S$1.37 billion, up from $1.26 billion in 1996.

Next came slot machines, which collected S$561 million, about S$56 million more than the year before. There are about 1,700 slot machines in more than 100 private clubs, associations and societies across the island.
For the Turf Club, of the S$2.39 billion it collected last year from horse racing and 4-D, S$1.78 billion was paid out in winnings.

DOC.HEADLINE: TIMES URGES BEIJING NOT TO DEVALUE ITS CURRENCY

TEXT.P: The latest threat to the currencies of Asia comes not from a political crisis or a faltering International Monetary Fund program but from Japan.
"The fall of the yen against the dollar is prompting speculation that China, which so far has been firm against the crisis, may devalue the renminbi," an influential European newspaper said.

Recent statements by mainland Chinese officials have fueled this fear by appearing to soften the country's no-devaluation line. But mainland China is well aware of the dangers of devaluing its currency, the Financial Times said.
Mainland China is suffering from the fallout of the Asian crisis. Exports dropped by 1.5 percent year-on-year in May, threatening the government's economic growth target of 8 percent.

"But a devaluation now could be economically and politically disastrous. With markets still in a fragile state, it could easily knock the Hong Kong dollar from its peg, and spark a new round of devaluations," the Financial Times said.

Mainland Chinese Premier Zhou Rongji has called currency stability a main pillar of his economic policy; a devaluation would undermine his authority and hold up the reform process. Also at risk would be the enhanced international influence that mainland China's currency policy has generated.

A devaluation may not even be necessary, though. Mainland China remains the second-cheapest place to manufacture in Asia. The weakness of the yen may deter investment from Japan into mainland China. But its effects on trade should be limited, as the countries have very different export patterns, the Financial Times said.

"China's policy has so far helped to prevent a serious worsening of the crisis, and has brought the country further into the international fold. A devaluation would reverse this, and would damage the long-term stability of the region," according to The Times.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAISUGAR NOT SHIFTING AUSTRALIAN OPERATIONS DUE TO 'ONE NATION' WIN

TEXT.P: Taiwan Sugar Corp. (Taisugar) has never considered relocating its investment in Australia from one province to another because of possible victory by the One Nation Party, Taisugar Chairman Chien Ping-tsai said on Thursday.
Chien said there is no reason for Taisugar to move its investments in Queensland to New South Wales (NSW) even if the One Nation Party wins in the Australian state elections in August.

The One Nation Party, often called racist, anti-Asian and anti-multiculturalism, is expected to win between nine and 12 seats at the Queensland Legislative Assembly. The victory could give the party, headed by independent member of Parliament Pauline Hanson, the balance of power in Queensland, political observers said.
Chien said Taisugar maintains its investment operations in both Queensland and NSW, and new investment projects are underway in the two provinces.

Investment in NSW consists mainly of a beef company, with joint investment from Taisugar, Taiwan Pineapple Corp., and a number of Australian corporations. Taisugar holds 45 percent of the company shares, according to Chien.
Investments in Queensland include a hog farm, slaughterhouse and a feed and pharmaceutical plant, he added.
Chien's remarks come amid reports from Australia that a possible victory by the One Nation Party may affect investments and businesses financed by people from Taiwan, Hong Kong and mainland China.

"Clearly it is a major concern not just from Taiwan not to invest in Australia, but any investment from overseas is certain to have the same view," Mark Peterson, chief executive of the Australian Chamber of Commerce and Industry recently said in Australia.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC CONCERNED ABOUT RISE OF ONE NATION PARTY IN AUSTRALIA

TEXT.P: The Republic of China is concerned about the rise of the anti-Asian One Nation Party in Australia, a senior Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) official said on Thursday.
"We are concerned about the success of the anti-immigration, protectionist One Nation Party in last Saturday's Queensland state parliamentary election," MOFA spokesman Roy Wu told the press.

Noting that the ministry is paying close attention to the developments in Australia, Wu said the ROC would not like to see Australian local politics, national policy or platforms of any of its political parties affect the interests and safety of Taiwan nationals who have traveled Down Under for business, investment, sightseeing or study.

Wu said the ROC has maintained close, mutually beneficial relations with Australia despite the absence of formal diplomatic ties. The ROC is currently Australia's seventh largest trading partner. In 1997, two-way trade between the two countries reached US$5 billion, with Australia posting a more than US$1.3 billion trade surplus.
Meanwhile, Wu said, there are some 20,000 ROC expatriates in Australia, including more than 2,100 youths studying there. Direct Taiwan investment in Australia well exceeds US$300 million.

The One Nation Party's showing sent shock waves through Australian politics after it won a quarter of the seats in the 89-member Queensland state parliament, much of it taken from Prime Minister John Howard's conservative coalition parties.
The maverick party opposes immigration and special welfare benefits for aborigines, and advocates protectionist economic policies.
Wu said although the One Nation Party's positions reflect views of some Queensland residents, they neither represent Australia's general public opinion nor its government policy.
"In our view, the party's platform violates the prevailing world trend," Wu said, adding that in the post-Cold War era, the internationally accepted norms are democracy, freedom and human rights.
"Nowadays, nearly all countries are pursuing multicultural, pluralistic developments and working hard to promote harmony and cooperation among different racial groups," Wu noted.
