DOC.HEADLINE: ROYAL HOLLOWAY UNIVERSITY OFFERS SCHOLARSHIPS TO TAIWAN STUDENTS

TEXT.P: Royal Holloway University of London announced Wednesday that it will establish a new scholarship fund for students from Taiwan.
College Principal Professor Norman Gowar made the announcement in a meeting with Louis Tzen, head of the Taipei Representative Office in the UK.
Scholarships, each worth 4,000 pounds sterling, will be awarded to outstanding Taiwanese undergraduate or postgraduate candidates who choose to study at Royal Holloway in 1998-99.
The Cultural Division of the Taipei representative office will be asked to provide advice on the scholarship selection process.

During a tour of the college campus at Egham, Surrey, Tzen and four of his colleagues from the Taipei representative office also visited Royal Holloway's internationally renowned Information Security Group for a presentation by Professor Chris Mitchell.

There are currently 90 Taiwan students at the college, comprising the third largest group of international students at the college. Royal Holloway enjoys long-standing links with a number of universities in Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: AUSTRALIA'S ANZ BANK TO EXPAND OPERATIONS IN TAIWAN, 5 OTHER NATIONS

TEXT.P: The ANZ Bank, one of Australia's four leading banks, is set to expand its operations in Taiwan, Malaysia, the Philippines, Indonesia, Thailand and Singapore through acquisitions and the purchase of stakes within a year.

In a speech at the Australia Summit in Melbourne Wednesday, ANZ Chief Executive John McFarlane reaffirmed the bank's six priority countries for expansion despite the current slowdown caused by Asia's financial turmoil.
He said ANZ shareholders have offered strong support for Asian expansion in a recent global roadshow.
"Basically, they do see the downside of the present situation but they also see the long-range benefit of moving into Asia," he said.
ANZ Bank is the biggest Australian presence in Asia with offices in Taipei, Hong Kong and other major Asian cities.

The bank has reduced its regional exposure by almost 40 percent in the six months to March 1998, but McFarlane believes once the tide turns in Asia's economic crisis, there will be outstanding opportunities.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAC REITERATES OPPOSITION TO 'ONE COUNTRY, TWO SYSTEMS' FORMULA

TEXT.P: The Cabinet-level Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) on Thursday released a position paper to reiterate the Republic of China's opposition to Beijing's "one country, two system" proposal on reunification.

The MAC, Taiwan's top agency in charge of formulating policies on mainland China, said in the paper the "one country, two systems" formula imposed by Beijing on Hong Kong cannot be applied to Taiwan because the ROC on Taiwan is a sovereign state, not a former colony like Hong Kong.
The ROC government maintains sovereign diplomacy in the international community and its own national defensive systems at home, while Hong Kong did not, the statement said.
The ROC is a democratic nation, with its people deciding the future of the country. Comparatively, the Hong Kong people cannot decide their own future, the position paper said.

It said China should be reunified under a democratic system in the future. Only under a democratic system can both sides of the Taiwan Strait strictly adhere to the agreements of reunification reached between them, it stressed.
Only under a democratic system can Taiwan, Macao, Hong Kong and mainland China peacefully reunify avoiding the formation of an alliance which could threaten security and peace in Asia, it said.
The "one country, two systems" formula devised by Beijing has three characteristics -- it is contradictory, it is transitional, and it is suppressive, the statement concluded.

DOC.HEADLINE: WHITE HOUSE SAYS CLINTON WON'T MEET WITH DISSIDENTS DURING TRIP
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, June 17 (CNA) (By Jay Chen & Eva Chen)

TEXT.P: US President Bill Clinton has decided not to meet with dissidents or their families during his upcoming trip to mainland China, according to a story that appeared in Wednesday's Washington Times, which cited White House officials.

Such meetings would irritate the mainland Chinese leadership and frustrate efforts aimed at improving human rights conditions within the country, said two White House officials who are responsible for handling the arrangements of Clinton's nine-day visit.

Clinton does plan to meet with those who have contributed to the development of a "new China," including students, lawyers, doctors, businessmen and other non-government officials, White House officials said.
Clinton's decision will likely draw fire from human rights groups as well as from people already critical of the trip, reported the paper.

The news story quoted Abigail Abrash, chief of a human rights organization named in honor of Robert Kennedy, as saying that Clinton's China trip will be the most tightly controlled state visit any White House official has ever seen.
The Beijing authorities have guaranteed that Clinton will not be embarrassed during his trip, said Abrash.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN CAPITAL FLOWS TO NON-TAX OR LOW-TAX AREAS

TEXT.P: An increasing number of local businesses are investing in countries which impose no or relatively low taxes on foreign investments, a survey released Thursday by the Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) showed.

A total of 333 overseas investment applications were approved by the authorities in the first five months of this year, with the total value of investments reaching US$1.24 billion, up 45 percent from the same period last year, the survey results indicate.
Almost 66 percent of investments went to the Central America's British Virgin Islands and Cayman Islands, while 14.53 percent went to the United States.

The survey results confirm that under a global trend of financial liberalization, local capital tends to flow out toward areas where tax privileges are granted to investors, as is the case in Central America, the survey said.

According to the tallies, 84.76 percent of the approved overseas investments were launched in the following sectors: financial assurance, electric and electronic applications, basic metal manufacturing, retail and wholesale business, as well as foreign trade.
In addition to the previously mentioned areas, Vietnam and Thailand are also attracting Taiwan investments, the survey showed.

As to other Southeast Asian countries, such as Indonesia, the Philippines and Malaysia, which had been ideal investing spots of Taiwanese businesses, the figures indicate these countries have lost their appeal for investors because of the regional financial crisis.
Registered investments in those three nations from Taiwan plunged by over 70 percent in the first five months of 1998.
Meanwhile, in May, the MOEA approved 73 applications for overseas investments valued at over US$261 million, the statistics indicated.

Tycoons Group Enterprise has applied to invest some US$67 million in the British Cayman Islands and Ho Tung Chemical applied to invest US$19 million in Vietnam. These two cases were the largest investment plans on record.

DOC.HEADLINE: MICROSOFT'S GATES TO BE IN FILM PROMOTING TAIWAN PRODUCTS

TEXT.P: Microsoft Chairman Bill Gates will appear in a film promoting high-end Taiwan products, sources from the China External Trade Development Council (CETRA) said on Thursday.

Gates, founder and CEO of the world's most powerful software company, will take time out of his eight-hour whirlwind visit to Taipei Friday to star in a video that will be part of the CETRA-sponsored "Symbol of Excellence" program series.
This will be Gates' seventh visit to Taiwan in the nine years since Microsoft established a Taiwan branch office.

Microsoft's Taiwan turnover has increased steadily over the past several years. Its turnover for fiscal 1998, which ends June 30, is expected to exceed last year's figure by a whopping 70 percent, according to sources from Microsoft Taiwan.

Gates will be the second internationally known business magnate, following Intel Chairman Andy Grove, to star in the "Symbol of Excellence" series, which is aimed at improving the image and boosting sales of Taiwan-made products.
The 10-minute video will be shown at major international trade fairs and on other similar occasions, according to a CETRA spokesperson.

ROC Economic Affairs Minister Wang Chih-kang will meet with Gates at the Taipei International Convention Center, where Gates will deliver a speech on the competitive niche for the 21st century -- digital nerve system.
Wang will also oversee the shooting of Gates' video and present him with a gift to thank him for his efforts.

DOC.HEADLINE: NT DOLLAR TO APPRECIATE WITH STABLE YEN: SCHOLAR

TEXT.P: The New Taiwan dollar will likely continue its rebound to between NT$32 and NT$33 to the greenback following Wednesday's Japan-US joint intervention to shore up the yen, said Yin Nai-ping, a professor of banking at National Chengchi University.

The intervention does not imply that Japan's economic problems are over, however. Yin said the move can only buy more time for Japan to reform its financial and economic systems and temporarily prevent the economic situation in other Southeast Asian countries from worsening.

Wire services reported that the joint intervention agreement between US President Bill Clinton and Japanese Prime Minister Ryutaro Hashimoto helped boost the yen to the 137-level. The NT dollar reacted favorably to the news and continued its rebound.

The Central Bank of China's intervention in the Taiwan currency exchange market in the past few days has helped stabilize the NT dollar to around the NT$35 psychological support level, Yin said. He predicted this combined with the Japan-US joint intervention in the yen would give the NT dollar a lift.
Furthermore, Yin noted that if the CBC takes the opportunity to give the NT dollar another boost, the local currency may quickly return to between NT$32 and NT$33.

Yin explained that the continued devaluation of the yen is a major threat to the United States in the world market. The United States has been relying on its strong domestic economy while it waits for Tokyo to come up with effective measures to reinvigorate the Japanese economy.

Washington had taken the opportunity to urge Tokyo to accelerate its pace in opening up its markets, Yin said. Now that Japan has made some concessions, the Japan-US joint intervention was made possible, he added.
Yin estimated the US government spent approximately US$2 billion to US$3 billion in the intervention, noting that the United States is waiting for Japan to carry out further economic reforms.

Substantial effects of any Japanese economic reform packages will not be obvious for another six months, and whether signs of recovery will continue to appear in the short term remains to be seen, Yin said.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIEX CLIMBS FOR FOURTH STRAIGHT DAY

TEXT.P: Share prices opened high and closed even higher on the Taipei Stock Exchange Thursday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, surging 301.93 points to close at 7,768.31, the market's fourth straight gain.
The bourse opened at 7,658.35, peaked at 7,771.76 and fell to 7,633.72.
Dealers said the market was given a boost by a higher New Taiwan dollar and Japanese yen, as well as by market gains in Hong Kong, Japan and the United States.
Gainers outnumbered losers 308 to 129, with 56 issues remaining unchanged.

A total of 2.96 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$149.12 billion, an increase from the previous session, which saw 2.56 billion stocks change hands on a turnover of NT$129.17 billion.

All eight major categories gained ground, with electrical issues moving up the most at 5.4 percent, followed by plastics and chemical stocks at 4.3 percent, bank and insurance shares at 3.7 percent, textile issues at 3.6 percent, cement stocks and pulp and paper issues both at 3.5 percent, construction shares at 2.9 percent and foodstuff stocks at 2.4 percent.

The 10 listed companies with the largest turnovers during Thursday's trading were United Micro Electronics, ASE, Ever Fortune Industries, Clevo, Chang Hwa Bank, Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing, Mitac International Corp., ACER, Hualon Teijran and CIS Technology.

DOC.HEADLINE: MA WOULD RATHER LOSE THAN RESORT TO DIRTY TRICKS: SUPPORTER

TEXT.P: Taipei mayoral candidate Ma Ying-jeou is capable of running a campaign in which he would rather lose than resort to disreputable tactics, said Wu Poh-hsiung, chairman of Ma's campaign support committee on Thursday.

Ma would rather lose in the year-end election than give away gifts or host free, open-air banquets to win votes for the Kuomintang, Wu said. Moreover, all candidates should refrain from smear campaigns or provocations aimed at sowing discord in rival camps, he said.

Ma is willing to play a critical role at a critical moment and face criticism regarding the sincerity of his election bid, Wu said, adding that Ma has already apologized for reneging on earlier vows not to run.

Responding to questions on whether the lack of a meeting between Ma and ROC President and KMT Chairman Lee Teng-hui indicates a troubled relationship between them, Wu said Ma's winning the election is more important than whether Lee and Ma meet.

DOC.HEADLINE: NT DOLLAR REBOUNDS

TEXT.P: The New Taiwan dollar skyrocketed NT0.58 against the greenback on Thursday in Taipei, closing at 34.101.

The local currency opened at the day's low of 34.446. Prompted by a stronger yen as a result of joint US-Japan intervention overnight, the Taiwan unit has once soared to the day's high of 33.951 during the trading.
The interbank US dollar trading reached US$518.5 million.

DOC.HEADLINE: WINBOND OPENS 4TH SILICON WAFER MANUFACTURING FACILITY

TEXT.P: Taiwan's third-largest maker of integrated circuits, Winbond Electronics Corp., on Thursday marked the opening of its fourth silicon wafer manufacturing plant in Hsinchu's Science-based Industrial Park.

Vice President Lien Chan visited the facility and congratulated Winbond on the plant's opening. Chan said he is pleased to see that cooperation between Winbond and Japan's Toshiba has contributed to Taiwan's technological advancement.

The factory cost Winbond more than NT$25 billion (US$735 million) and will be used to produce 64-megabyte Dynamic Random Access Memory modules as small as 0.35 and 0.25 microns. A single micron is about one-one hundredth the width of an average human hair.

Initially the plant will turn out 8,000 0.25 micron wafers per month, said a Winbond spokesperson. By year's end, the facility's production capacity is expected to more than double to 15,000 wafers per month.
The spokesperson added that Winbond will develop at its new plant advanced wafers measuring only 0.2 microns. Silicon wafers increase in efficiency as they shrink in size.
Winbond, which first partnered itself with Toshiba several years ago, sells 90 percent of its DRAM modules to the Japanese company.
Winbond's 1997 revenue totaled NT$12.7 billion (US$374 million), while after-tax profits amounted to NT$4.03 billion, according to the company.
Taiwan's largest IC chip manufacturer is Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing, followed by United Micro Electronics.

DOC.HEADLINE: MILITARY EXERCISES SUSPENDED UNTIL JULY

TEXT.P: The Ministry of National Defense announced on Thursday that all the ROC armed forces' large-scale military exercises and live-fire training drills will be suspended until early July.

The suspension has nothing to do with the upcoming summit between US President Bill Clinton and mainland Chinese President Jiang Zemin later this month, said a spokesperson with the Military Spokesman Office. The official called on the public not to speculate on the reason for the suspension.
The move is part of the ministry's efforts to adjust its training program for the second half of this year, according to the office. That program is scheduled to begin on July 1.
An annual military exercise on the Republic of China's frontline Penghu Island, originally scheduled to take place sometime between June and August, has been shelved by the ministry.

DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER CALLS FOR CONTROL OF DEADLY INTESTINAL VIRUS EPIDEMIC

TEXT.P: Premier Vincent Siew on Thursday ordered health officials to step up efforts to contain the spread of a deadly intestinal viral epidemic that has claimed the lives of 43 young children throughout the island in recent weeks.
Siew gave the directive after hearing a report on the enterovirus outbreak by Chan Chi-hsien, director-general of the Department of Health (DOH), at a weekly Cabinet meeting.

Noting that the killer epidemic has caused great suffering for parents whose children had died from enterovirus-triggered complications, Siew urged health agnecies at central and local levels to join forces and mobilize all medical resources to control the contagion and minimize its damage.

"Thanks to concerted efforts of the DOH and the medical community, we have managed to detect the culprit of the contagion. As the epidemic has not yet been controlled, we must continue keeping high alert and studying the root cause of the outbreak," Siew said.

The premier further said health authorities should develop an effective epidemic reporting, prevention and treatment system in order to allay fears of the general public and create a hygienic, wholesome living environment.

Siew also urged the DOH to launch a publicity campaign in cooperation the Government Information Office and the Ministry of Education to remind local parents to take precautionary measures to protect their children from being infected by the intestinal virus.
Meanwhile, Shieh Wun-ju, a Chinese-American epidemiologist with the US Center for Disease Control (CDC), said the viral epidemic is not over since casualties are still rising.
Shieh further said the probability for the current epidemic to infect adults is very low because most adults have been exposed to the virus and have developed antibodies.

Shieh also suggested that all local hospitals be required to report any finding of viral outbreaks to the DOH instead of disclosing related information to the press on their own to avoid causing unnecessary panic or misunderstanding among the general public.

Hsu Kuo-hsiung, acting director of the DOH's Bureau of Communicable Disease Control, said the latest enterovirus-related deaths involved girls aged nine and 12, indicating that the virus could also attack older children. All other deaths involved children younger than six.
Among those afflicted, Hsu said, 174 children had developed serious complications but had recovered or are recovering.

A pathological autopsy on an eight-year-old girl has confirmed that enterovirus type-71 was the culprit of her death. "Autopsies on five other children suspected to have died of similar intestinal viral infections have also been completed. One of them was apparently not killed by the deadly virus. We are still examining whether the virus had anything to do with the death of the remaining four," Hsu reported.

He further said no case of enterovirus infection has so far been reported in several Taiwan-held offshore islands. Unconfirm reports said a child suspected to contract the intestinal virus was sent from the frontline island of Matsu to Taiwan for medical treatment on Thursday.

Infants and young children are most susceptible to enterovirus. Early symptoms of the infection resemble the flu, with fever, headache and vomiting. Ulcers or blisters in the mouth and a rash on the palms and feet can also develop. Later, possible deadly complications include encephalitis, meningitis and acute inflammation of the hear muscle. Parents are advised to keep their children away from public places, and make sure that their children change clothes and wash hands frequently.

DOC.HEADLINE: COASTAL PATROL VESSEL LAUNCHED IN KAOHSIUNG

TEXT.P: The Dann-Jiang, the first of 11 new coastal patrol craft being built for the ROC navy, was launched at the southern port city of Kaohsiung on Thursday.
Navy Commander in Chief Admiral Wu Shih-wen, and Yu Chen-nan, chairman of the state-owned China Shipbuilding Corp. (CSC), presided over the launch at CSC's Kaohsiung shipyard.

The missile patrol boat will be fitted with weaponry including Hsiung-Feng missiles, and 20 mm and 40 mm guns, before undergoing a series of performance tests to ensure that it meets quality and specification requirements.

The vessel, which is based on the Chinchiang, a prototype designed and built by the CSC, is part of the navy's plan to upgrade its combat readiness. The rest of the order is scheduled for completion by May, 2000.
The Dann-Jiang is 61.4 meters long, has a beam of 9.5 meters, and a displacement of 540 tons. It will be able to travel at a speed of 25 knots.

The new vessels will be responsible for patrolling Taiwan's coastal waters and for conducting patrol and protection missions in certain other maritime areas as required. In times of war, they will be equipped with additional weapons systems and deployed on combat operations with the navy's much larger warships.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAINLAND STATE-RUN ENTERPRISES SUFFER GREATER LOSS

TEXT.P: The Beijing-based "Economic Daily" reported Thursday that the state-run enterprises of mainland China suffered a total loss of 41.7 billion renminbi (yuan) in the first four months of this year.
Large and medium-sized state enterprises lost 32 billion yuan during the period, or 77 percent of the total loss. One US dollar is equal to 8.280 yuan.
The loss of state-run industrial enterprises in the four-month period amounted to 8.87 billion yuan, a jump of 31.6 percent over a year earlier, the report said.

The increase of their loss is attributable to the Asian financial crisis, which has weakened the ability of many Asian countries to import from mainland China, and to the devaluation of many Asian currencies, which has sharpened the competition edge of these countries in the mainland Chinese market.

Meanwhile, the Hong Kong-based Ming Pao Daily News Thursday quoted a mainland Chinese financial official as predicting that the interest rates of renminbi bank deposits will soon be lowered in order to reduce the financial burden of enterprises in the country, and to stimulate the economy.
The interest rate of American dollar deposits in mainland China has just been lowered to 4.875 percent as a prelude, the official pointed out.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT LEE TENG-HUI HONORS 48 ENVIRONMENTAL CRUSADERS

TEXT.P: President Lee Teng-hui hosted an annual tea party on Thursday morning in honor of 48 people who have helped promote environmental protection in Taiwan.

The group was accompanied to the party by Interior Minister Huang Chu-wen, Vice Education Minister Lee Chien-shin and Tsai Hsung-hsiung, administrator of the Environmental Protection Administration under the Executive Yuan.

The world's rapid population growth and economic development have quickly depleted natural resources and caused substantial environmental damage, Lee said, adding that the resource depletion and environmental degradation are affecting people's quality of life.

This had made environmental protection an important topic for the international community, Lee said. Multinational cooperation has resulted in concrete measures being taken to protect the environment, he said.

The Republic of China has not only included environmental protection as a basic national policy in its constitution but has also drafted a "State Environmental Protection Plan" that will bring Taiwan into the 21st century.

Lee expressed his respect and admiration to the party's honorees, including school teachers, community representatives, volunteer workers, members of government ageincies and activists, for their efforts to promote environmental protection. They serve as an example to society, he said.

Effective environmental protection is an indication of a nation's efforts to modernize itself, Lee said. Government agencies, however, cannot do the work alone; public support and participation is required as well, he said.
Huang Kun-huei, secretary-general to the president, also attended the party.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC HOPES TO SEE STABLE, PROSPEROUS HONG KONG

TEXT.P: The Republic of China would like to see Hong Kong remain stable and prosperous, an official of the Cabinet-level Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) said on Thursday.
MAC Vice Chairman Lin Chung-ping made the remarks to coincide with the first anniversary of Hong Kong's return to Chinese sovereignty under the "one country, two systems" formula.
Lin said that not only is Hong Kong an important trade partner of Taiwan, it has also played a major role as an intermediary in cross-Taiwan Strait exchanges.
He expressed the hope that the mainland authorities will make good on their promises to allow Hong Kong people to run Hong Kong, and to give the people of Hong Kong a high degree of autonomy.

He stressed that a politically democratic, economically liberal and legally sound Hong Kong, will not only help promote the development of Hong Kong and the welfare of the Hong Kong people, it will also help the growth and stability of the entire region, including Taiwan.

He pointed out that although Hong Kong has in general fared well over the past year, some problems have surfaced, including a slight decline in government efficiency, especially as it relates to crisis management.

Economically, he said that as a result of the financial turmoil in the region, Hong Kong has seen its stock market and real estate market slump. Trade and investment, as well as tourism, have also been hit severely.
Hong Kong suffered negative economic growth in the first quarter of this year, for the first time in 13 years.

The international community has given generally favorable reviews of Hong Kong since its reversion to Chinese rule on July 1, 1997, but there is a perceived potential risk regarding the maintenance of freedom, democracy and rule of law.

Lin said it remains to be seen whether Beijing will go through with its "one country, two systems" policy, and whether it will keep its promise to allow Hong Kong to retain its status unchanged for fifty years.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP HEAD TERMS EUROPEAN TRIP `FRUITFUL'

TEXT.P: Hsu Hsin-liang, chairman of the opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP), described his just-concluded tour of three European nations as "fruitful" when he returned home on Thursday.
Hsu said that during his visit to Latvia, Finland, and Sweden, he met with party leaders and academics, and observed their political and social systems at work.
He noted that Latvia, which gained its independence after the collapse of the former Soviet Union in 1991, is worthy of the DPP's attention.

The party chairman also pointed out that Finland has always been bordered by giant neighbors, and that the DPP can learn from that country's experience of living peacefully with its neighbors without serious incidents.

Turning to the achievements of Sweden, Hsu noted that the Scandinavian country is one of the first nations to have implemented a social welfare system, but has not lost its national competitiveness, despite huge expenditure on social welfare programs.
Asked to comment on Taipei City Mayor Chen Shui-bian's remarks that he will serve a full mayoral term if he is reelected at the end of the year, Hsu said that it would be an admirable decision.
The popular mayor has been widely tipped to be the DPP candidate for the presidential election in 2000.

DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER URGES LOCAL INSURANCE COMPANIES TO GLOBALIZE

TEXT.P: Premier Vincent Siew on Thursday encouraged local insurance companies to expand their services around the world, describing the some 30 million overseas Chinese and 200,000 overseas Taiwan businessmen as the insurance industry's biggest assets in achieving the goal of globalization.

During a ceremony to mark the establishment of an ROC insurance companies' association, Siew called on local insurance firms to cultivate an international professional elite, to embrace information technology, and to provide first-class services, in order to penetrate the international market.

Siew said that according to statistics compiled in 1995, Asia was the world's largest insurance market, with total premiums in the region surpassing those of North America and the European Union. Taiwan was the 14th-largest insurance market in the world, Siew pointed out, adding that despite the Asian financial crisis, the insurance business in Asia is expected to continue to grow this year.

The premier said that for the government, maintaining discipline and promoting sound development of the insurance market are of equal importance when it comes to a further opening of Taiwan's insurance market. He added that the government should ensure that insurance companies have the ability to liquidate their debts, in order to protect the rights of their policyholders.

He described the insurance business as an important sector of the financial service industry which is inextricably linked with national development, and stressed that local insurance companies must upgrade their competitiveness if they are to be successful in the international market.

DOC.HEADLINE: CAL EXPECTED TO SOON RECOVER FROM SLUGGISH PERFORMANCE

TEXT.P: China Airlines, Taiwan's largest carrier, is expected to recover from a period of sluggish business, as the airline, hard hit by a major crash in February, is quickly wooing back customers, according to a report carried by the Economic Daily News in its Thursday edition.

Citing statistics made public by the Civil Aeronautics Administration, the daily reported that of the 685,700 departures from Chiang Kai-shek International Airport in May, 195,100 passengers, or 28.5 percent of the total, were traveling aboard CAL flights.

The ratio, which is very near the pre-February level of about 30 percent, is the highest level for the carrier since the mid-February CAL crash which killed a total of 202 people, according to the report. The tragedy was Taiwan's worst-ever air disaster.

Industry sources attributed the noticeable surge in the company's passenger load to the carrier's strategy of cutting prices. In March, CAL round-trip tickets for destinations in Northeast and Southeast Asian countries were selling at just NT$6,000 (about US$180), prompting other aviation companies to follow suit.
With the approach of the summer vacation period, however, the company has begun to adjust ticket prices for most of its popular routes.
The sources said the carrier is expected to record a brilliant performance in the July-August high season, thus greatly boosting its profits for the entire year.

DOC.HEADLINE: AUSTRALIA SAYS ONE NATION PARTY NO THREAT TO TAIWAN, ASIAN INVESTORS

TEXT.P: Australian Deputy Prime Minister Tim Fischer urged Taiwanese businessmen not to avoid Queensland or Australia in the wake of gains made by the One Nation Party in state elections last week.
"I would urge Taiwanese not to avoid Queensland and the Australian economy," said Fischer, who also serves as trade minister.
"There are positive job-creating aspects associated with sensible Taiwanese investment, more jobs in Queensland, more jobs in New South Wales," he said.
Fischer said Australia remains "a great place to do business."
Asian investors, meanwhile, are monitoring the party's support at the federal level in the run-up to fresh federal elections, which will likely take placs next August or September.

Jim Sheu, head of the Taiwan-Australia Business Association (TABA) in Brisbane, told the press earlier this week that Taiwan Sugar Corp. (Taisugar) has decided to move its regional office from Queesland to New South Wales because of concerns over the increased strength of the One Nation Party, which is regarded as anti-multiculturalism, anti-Asian, anti-Aboriginal rights and anti-foreign investment.

One Nation, founded last year by Independent Member of Parliament Pauline Hanson, is expected to win between nine and 12 seats in the Queensland Legislative Assembly. A final tally is expected later this week.
In addition to Taisugar, 10 other Taiwanese investment projects are being put on hold at least until the next federal elections.
Sheu's claims that Taisugar is relocating its headquarters were denied by Taisugar officials.
Asian trade offices in Australia are worried that One Nation's anti-Asian investment policies could erode investor confidence and local demand for Asian products, analysts said.
"Many Korean companies already based in Sydney are very concerned about their business future," said Chung Young, trade commissioner at the Korea Trade Center in Sydney.

The Japanese Chamber of Commerce and Industry has also voiced its concern, and the Australian Chamber of Commerce in Hong Kong issued a statement reassuring Hong Kong companies that "the vast majority of Australians are appalled by the minority views of One Nation."

Ethnic Chinese businessman Chuck Hong placed an advertisement in Wednesday's Sydney Morning Herald in which he called for Asian businesses to boycott products from Queensland, and to avoid visiting or investing there.

DOC.HEADLINE: BERGER REAFFIRMS NO SECRET DEAL ON TAIWAN ISSUE
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, June 17 (CNA) (By Nelson Chung and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: A senior White House official confirmed on Thursday that the US policy of selling arms to Taiwan in accordance with the Taiwan Relations Act remains unchanged.
National Security Adviser Sandy Berger also reiterated that President Bill Clinton, during his upcoming visit to mainland China, will not take any action that may undermine Taiwan.

Berger was responding to inquiries from CNA at a special news briefing whether the Clinton administration has changed its policy on arms sales to Taiwan or whether Clinton will strike any secret deal with Beijing leaders during his June 25-July 3 state visit to the mainland.

"No. No secret deal. No change; the same. And we will -- our policy with respect to arms sales to Taiwan, are dictated by the Taiwan Relations Act, by the communiques. And we will not take any action, during this trip, that will undermine Taiwan," Berger said.
He went on to say that Clinton's mainland visit is part of his efforts to build up stronger ties with Asia, particularly mainland China.

Berger pointed out that forging constructive ties with mainland China is very important because its development direction in the next 10 to 20 years will have a fundamental and profound impact on US interests, Asian stability and world peace.

DOC.HEADLINE: NATIONAL ASSEMBLY TO CONVENE ON JULY 21

TEXT.P: President Lee Teng-hui is expected to issue a decree in the next two days for the convening of a meeting of the National Assembly on July 21.
In the meeting, members of the National Assembly will hear President Lee Teng-hui's "State of the Nation" address, and exercise their power of consent in the selection of new Control Yuan members.
The new members of the Control Yuan will be sworn in on February 1 for a six-year term.

DOC.HEADLINE: WOMAN SETS TWO-YEAR RECORD FOR EMERGENCY CALLS

TEXT.P: A 62-year-old woman weighing nearly 100 kilograms has called the 119 emergency fire department service center telephone number for help 23 times over the past two years, setting an unusual record in the Taipei Fire Department.

On Thursday morning, the woman, surnamed Hsieh, once again felt severe chest pains and asked her husband to call 119 for help. Upon receiving the call, an ambulance manned by four strong paramedics rushed to the by now-familiar address and took the woman to a nearby hospital, where her condition was described as stable.

The woman and her husband live in a shabby apartment in Taipei with a social welfare program their only source of income. In recent years, the woman has been suffering from obesity-related heart problems.

An official at the 119 emergency service center said that Hsieh has logged the highest number of calls on record from a single individual. He stressed, however, that although Hsieh's weight presents difficulties for the paramedics, they are always delighted to offer the necessary help.

DOC.HEADLINE: JAPANESE PM OUTLINES PLANS TO BEAT RECESSION

TEXT.P: Japanese Prime Minister Ryutaro Hashimoto told a press conference on Thursday that he will do his best to restore Japan's sagging economy, with emphasis on tackling the problem of heavy bad debts in domestic financial institutions.
Directly after the end of the 158-day 142nd ordinary session of the Diet, Hashimoto held a press conference to outline the problems that he will handle from now on.
He said that to regain the confidence of the Japanese people in the country's economy, problems concerning heavy bad debts, insecure economic systems, and economic regulations, have to be redressed.
While a 30 trillion-yen package has recently been set to bail out failing Japanese financial institutions and write off bad debts, its effectiveness is still in doubt.

Hashimoto said an extraordinary Diet session will be convened shortly after the July 12 election of the House of Councilors to deliberate on laws to help develop a smoother way of handling the problem of bad debts.
He added that corporate taxes will be reduced on a par with international levels in less than three years, and that income tax reductions will be thoroughly discussed.
Asked about the possibility of a cabinet reshuffle, Hashimoto declined to comment, saying that the current economic problems have occupied all his thoughts.

DOC.HEADLINE: ASEAN MEETING TO FOCUS ON FOREST FIRES, HAZE IN SE ASIA

TEXT.P: Environmental ministers of the Association of Southeast Asian Nations will meet in Singapore Friday to discuss problems caused by forest fires and haze in the region.
The meeting will be the ministers' fourth since late last year and will be chaired by Yeow Chiu Tong, Singapore's Minister for the Environment.
The meeting was to have been held in Jakarta last month, but was postponed because of political unrest in the country.
During the meeting, Singapore, Malaysia and Indonesia will offer progress reports on their efforts to put into place a plan to prevent, monitor and fight forest fires in Indonesia and Malaysia.

The meeting is also expected to touch on assistance being coordinated by the United Nations Environment Program. It had been hoped that US$10 million could be raised to buy fire-fighting equipment, but few international donors have been found.
It has been reported that heavy rains have put out fires in East Kalimantan, which had been blazing out of control and blanketing large parts of Borneo in a thick haze only weeks ago.
Over the past several days, however, satellite pictures have revealed several hot-spots and haze-stricken areas in central Sumatra.

DOC.HEADLINE: HK HOPES FOR INSTITUTIONALIZED TIES WITH TAIWAN: POLL
DOC.DATELINE: Hong Kong, June 18 (CNA) (By Stanley Cheung and Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: Most of Hong Kong's citizens hope for an institutionalized relationship between Taiwan and the former British colony, a recent survey has found.

According to the survey carried out by the Hong Kong Center for Studies on Relations Across the Taiwan Straits, 79 percent of the respondents agreed that Taiwan and Hong Kong should exchange representative offices. Only 8.7 percent voiced opposition to the idea.

The poll found that Hong Kong people are extremely vague on Beijing's policy regarding Hong Kong-Taiwan ties, with 85 percent saying they do not know of the "seven-point statement" released by former mainland Chinese Foreign Minister Qian Qichen on the subject.

Around 35 percent of Hong Kong residents said they think current Hong Kong-Taiwan ties are looser than they were before the territory's return to Beijing rule last July, while 32 percent said they have seen few changes in bilateral relations, according to the survey.
However, nearly 50 percent said they remain optimistic about future prospects of two-way exchanges with Taiwan.

Regarding Beijing's "one country, two systems" formula, 57 percent of the respondents said the scheme should also be implemented in Taiwan if the practice works well in the territory, in contrast to 19 percent who do not think so, the survey pointed out.

Some 35 percent opined that Taiwan and mainland China should maintain the status-quo before the two sides of the Taiwan Strait achieve eventual unification, while 12 percent expressed the wish for an immediate unification of the two sides. A mere 1.9 percent said they support Taiwan independence.
Citing the results of the survey, the center said most of the people of Hong Kong consider both themselves and the people of Taiwan to be Chinese.
The survey was carried out on May 11-13 among 1,004 Hong Kong citizens.

DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER GIVES DIRECTIVES ON BOT PROMOTIONS

TEXT.P: Premier Vincent Siew on Thursday instructed the Council for Economic Planning and Development (CEPD) to draft rules and standards of operation for build-operate-transfer (BOT) projects as soon as possible.

He issued the directive after hearing a briefing by C.L. Liao, director-general of the Engineering Office of Highspeed Rail, and a report from Minister of Transportation and Communications Lin Feng-cheng at a meeting at the Executive Yuan.
Other speakers at the meeting included Finance Minister Paul C.H. Chiu, and ministers without portfolio Yang Shih-chien, Huang Ta-chou, Chao Shou-po and Shirley W.Y. Kuo.

After listening to their views, Siew lauded the Engineering Office of Highspeed Rail under the Ministry of Transportation and Communications for its efforts in actively promoting open bidding for the Chiang Kai-shek Airport Rapid Transit Systems project.

Commenting on the future operation of the BOT system, the premier stressed that BOT is a vital strategy for the country. He said its future operation requires further review and discussion, and its rules, screening process, and operating standards, should be drafted.
He also said that before these standards are drafted by the CEPD, other BOT cases should be put temporarily on hold.

DOC.HEADLINE: BEIJING ACTS TO SUSTAIN EXPORTS

TEXT.P: Fresh signs that Beijing's export growth may slow sharply later this year are prompting the authorities to consider measures to reinvigorate one of the main growth engines in the national economy.

One ominous sign, according to reports from the Geneva-based World Trade Organization (WTO) on Thursday, is that new export contracts rose by only 1.18 percent in the first four months of this year, compared with the same period of a year ago.
This is significantly lower than the 11.6 percent climb in total exports, which itself was 15.3 percentage points lower than during the first four months of 1997.

Statistics on new contracts are not as faithful an indicator as actual orders, but they nevertheless serve as a guide to future demand. It takes several months for contracts to be translated into export sales.
The slowing growth in contracts was partly the result of keen competition from Asian exporters who are starting to capitalize on the sharp devaluation in their currencies, the WTO report said.

Devaluation of mainland China's renminbi has been ruled out by Beijing's senior leadership, so authorities are intensifying efforts to find other ways to stimulate exports, which last year contributed about 20 percent of gross domestic product.

Mainland China appears in need of a robust export performance as the wider economy slows. Gross domestic product growth was 7.2 percent in the first quarter, down from 8.8 percent for the whole of 1997.

The government's greatest fear is that slowing growth will trigger social unrest as unemployment surges and pensions are withheld from millions of retired people. Recent official statistics show that by the end of March, 2.8 million pensioners were owed a total US$562 million in pensions. Many have not received any welfare for six months, the WTO report added.

DOC.HEADLINE: AUSTRALIAN GIRL APPEARS IN PUBLIC WITH BIRTH MOTHER

TEXT.P: An Australian teenager of Taiwanese origin appeared in public with her long lost biological mother at the Criminal Investigation Bureau (CIB) on Thursday.
Kartya Wunderle of Melbourne was accompanied by her adoptive parents when she met with her birth mother, identified as Mrs. Hsu, and older sister at the office of CIB Director Yang Tzu-ching.
Kartya, who was adopted into the Wunderle family 17 years ago, met her birth mother and sister for the first time on Tuesday after DNA testing established their relationship.
Their first meeting was shrouded in secrecy at Mrs. Hsu's request. Encouraged by her current husband, Mrs. finally decided to appear in public with her long lost second daughter.
Both Mrs. Hsu and Kartya's adoptive parents thanked the CIB for its assistance in making the happy reunion possible.

Kartya was sold as an infant to an adoption broker by her birth father for NT$36,000. Her biological parents were not married and already had another daughter. Her birth father already died several years ago.
The baby girl was adopted by Orthma and Nola Wunderle in Melbourne in 1981 through a Taiwanese agency, which was later found to be an illegal ring selling young children abroad.
Accompanied by her adoptive mother, Kartya arrived in Taiwan earlier this month to seek her roots because she has long suffered an "identity crisis."
Her adoptive father, who arrived in Taipei on Wednesday to meet Kartya's Taiwanese family, said he is delighted to see his daughter's eight-year search for real mother has come to a happy ending.
Wunderle further said he would not oppose if his daughter wants to stay in Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESTIGIOUS UK COLLEGE ANNOUNCES SCHOLARSHIPS FOR TAIWAN STUDENTS

TEXT.P: Royal Holloway College of the University of London, announced on Wednesday that it will establish a new scholarship fund for students from Taiwan.

College Principal Professor Norman Gowar made the announcement at a meeting with Louis Tzen of the Taipei Representative Office in the UK. Scholarships, each worth 4,000 pounds, will be awarded to outstanding undergraduate or postgraduate candidates from Taiwan who opt to study at Royal Holloway in 1998-99.
The Cultural Division of the Taipei Representative Office will be asked to provide advice on the scholarship selection process.

There are currently 90 students from Taiwan attending the college, making them the third-largest group of international students there. Royal Holloway enjoys long-standing links with a number of prestigious universities in Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: NEW TARIFF SYSTEM TO TAKE EFFECT ON FRIDAY

TEXT.P: A new list of lower duties on imports will take effect on Friday, which will lighten the government coffers by about NT$4.4 billion (US$129.41 million) per year, according to Taiwan customs officials.
However, the new tariff system will boost the development of local industry and raise people's income, which will more than compensate for the decrease in revenue, the officials pointed out.

The new list is the result of two amendments to the current tariff system, one in 1996, the other in 1997. Although presented to the legislature one year apart, the two amendments were ratified together in May.

The 1996 amendment, which resulted from negotiations with Australia, Norway, and New Zealand on Taiwan's bid to enter the World Trade Organization (WTO), proposed to cut duty on 350 agricultural products and 780 industrial products, reducing the average nominal tariffs from 17.18 percent to 14.64 percent.

The 1997 amendment, worked out in line with the WTO declaration on the free flow of information industry products, lowers tariffs on 289 computer-related products with the aim of cutting duty in this sector from the current 4.69 percent to zero under a four-phase program.

The Ministry of Finance estimates that the 1996 proposal will prune the government's income from tariffs by NT$2.67 billion (US$78.52 million), while the 1997 proposal will scale it down by about NT$1.8 billion (US$52.94 million).
However, the officials noted that since the two amendments overlap each other in some respects, the actual amount of revenue reduction will be less than the two estimates combined.

DOC.HEADLINE: ECONOMICS MINISTER HEADING FOR MALAYSIA APEC MEETING

TEXT.P: Minister of Economic Affairs Wang Chih-kang will leave on Friday for Kuching, Malaysia, to attend a ministerial meeting of the Asia Pacific Economic Cooperation (APEC) forum.

He is expected to exchange views with his APEC counterparts on advancing the APEC trade liberalization program, and on individual states' action programs, during the June 21-23 conference, according to economic officials.
Lin Yi-fu, vice minister of economic affairs, and Chen Ruey-long, director-general of the Board of Foreign Trade, will accompany Wang on his trip.

He will also have a lunch meeting with Taiwan businessmen in Singapore on Saturday during a one-day stopover there on his way to Kuching, and will attend a seminar with Taiwan businessman in Kuala Lumpur on June 24 before returning to Taiwan later that day, the officials said.

DOC.HEADLINE: ELIMINATION OF TARIFFS ON TVS, VIDEO CAMERAS OPPOSED BY TAIWAN

TEXT.P: Taiwan is opposed to the elimination of tariffs on TV sets, video cameras, coaxial cables and printed circuit boards (PCBs) by 2002, which, along with another 178 items, have been targeted by the World Trade Organization (WTO) in the next round of market liberalization, the Ministry of Finance (MOF) said on Thursday.

The Information Technology Agreement (ITA) committee under the WTO will conduct a meeting in which ITA signatories will discuss the elimination of tariffs on consumer electronic items and other products, following its success in achieving tariff reductions by 2000 on 289 other information technology (IT) items.

Taiwan was admitted as the 39th signatory of the ITA committee last March, when the ROC government agreed to gradually cut tariffs on 274 IT items to zero in four stages by 2000, beginning from July 1, 1998. Tariffs on another 15 items will not be completely removed until 2002.

As the ITA members hope to further promote the free flow of information, electronics and other related products, a total of 15 signatories have proposed 400 more products to the ITA committee that they wish to be declared tariff-free. Taiwan has suggested 13 items to be included in the next round of tariff eliminations.

The ITA committee has conducted a number of technology meetings between February and June, during which they reached consensus that tariffs on 182 items, including chemical products, consumer electronics products, communications products, and PCB manufacturing equipment, will be eliminated by 2002. The list will be presented for further discussion by the ITA signatories at a meeting in late June.

Liu Rong-chu, director of the Customs Administration Department under the MOF, said that Taiwan will demand at the upcoming meeting that TV sets, video cameras, coaxial cables and PCBs be excluded from the proposed list, or at least that the timetable for the four items should be extended to 2007.
Liu said that in general, Taiwan supports the proposal that tariffs on the rest of the items on the list be gradually cut to zero by Jan. 1, 2002 in four stages, beginning from Jan. 1, 1999.

According to Liu, the ITA members have differing opinions regarding the elimination of tariffs on consumer electronic products. The European Union and many developing countries are opposed, while the attitude of the United States is still unknown.

DOC.HEADLINE: LOCAL CARMAKER TARGETS FINLAND

TEXT.P: Taching Motors Co., Ltd., a local carmaker based in the southern Taiwan city of Pingtung, announced on Thursday that it plans to export compact cars to Finland and other northern European countries.
Taching Chairman C.K. Wang said his company is planning to export its Impreza model in both 1,600 c.c. and 1,800 c.c. engine capacities by the end of this year.

According to Wang, Taching is also considering an expansion of its export network to cover Central and South America, with Venezuela as the company's focus in the region. The Impreza will also be the major model for exports to the vast Latin American market, he noted.

An executive in charge of overseas operations with Japan's Fuji Heavy Industries Co., which controls 45 percent of Taching's shares, said the Japanese industry titan has already begun discussions with its Finnish partners on remodeling the Impreza to take account of the northern hemisphere's frigid zone.
He added that his company's Japanese headquarters will provide Taching with technological assistance for the car exports.

DOC.HEADLINE: AUSTRALIAN CURRENCY AND BOURSE SURGE AFTER US YEN BAILOUT

TEXT.P: The Australian currency and stockmarket, buoyed by rising currencies and stockmarkets in major markets, surged sharply on Thursday after the US government came to the rescue of the beleaguered Japanese yen.
The Australian dollar finished at 60.88 US cents, up from Wednesday's close of 59.34 US cents, dealers said.
The All Ordinaries Index surged 58.9 points to close at 2,608.2 compared with the previous day's close of 2,549.3.

Economists attributed the surges to an unexpected agreement between US President Bill Clinton and Japanese Prime Minister Ryutaro Hashimoto, who promised to turn his country's stricken economy around.
Economists said the temporary relief in the currency and stock markets will ease the pressure on the Reserve Bank of Australia to raise official interest rates and combat inflationary pressure.

DOC.HEADLINE: US DEFICIT WITH TIGERS GROWS IN LEAPS AND BOUNDS
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, June 18 (CNA) (By Herman Pan & Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: The Asian financial crisis has not only deflated US exports this year but also raised US deficits with the four "Asian tigers" by a factor of 20, results of the latest Commerce Department tallies showed.

The Asian financial crisis, which began to loom large in the second half of last year, has pushed down US sales to the region by 10.5 percent for the first four months of this year. With most Asian currencies depreciating, the United States overall trade deficit shot up to US$48.7 billion for the period, 38.4 percent higher than its year-earlier level.
Deficits with Taiwan, Singapore, Hong Kong and South Korea totaled a whopping US$6.39 billion, 20.8 times the combined deficits' year-earlier levels, according to the Commerce Department report.

Among the four tigers, the United States witnessed a roller-coaster rise and fall in trade with South Korea -- its US$1.9 billion surplus during the first fourth months of 1997 turning into a deficit of US$2.6 billion during the same period one year later.

The United States deficit with Singapore, meanwhile, soared 78 percent, while its deficit with Taiwan rose 10.2 percent. Deficits with Japan and mainland China, the United States' two largest deficit sources, rose 13.3 percent and 19.8 percent, respectively.
In April alone, the United States' goods and services deficit posted a single-month record high of US$14.5 billion, mainly because of sluggish exports to Asia.
The Clinton administration has grown concerned that consumer confidence could be rattled if the Asian crisis spreads outside the region and begins to drag down the high-flying US stock market.

In an effort to contain the crisis, President Bill Clinton has recently authorized the sale of dollars in currency markets to stem a free-fall in the value of the Japanese yen, a slide that threatened to prompt a second round of currency devaluations.
As of the end of April, the United States' top 10 trading partners around the world were Canada, Japan, Mexico, Germany, Britain, mainland China, Taiwan, France, South Korea and Italy, in that order.
