DOC.HEADLINE: MAC REITERATES ROC SHOULD NOT BE PUT AT RISK

TEXT.P: The Mainland Affairs Council reiterated on Friday Taiwan's opposition to any deals that might be made during the upcoming meeting between US President Bill Clinton and mainland Chinese President Jiang Zemin that could put the Republic of China at risk.

Sheu Ke-sheng, spokesman and vice chairman of the Cabinet-level MAC, which formulates Taiwan's policies on mainland China, said Clinton and Jiang should not discuss the so-called "three noes," -- no Taiwan independence, no "two Chinas" or "one China, one Taiwan" and no United Nations membership for Taiwan -- at the summit, nor should they produce any written agreements or understandings on the matter.

Responding to speculation that Beijing may ask the United States to cease arms sales to Taiwan, Sheu said Washington has repeatedly assured Taipei that the summit will not produce any surprises to Taiwan or changes in US policy toward Taiwan.

The ROC's termination of the Period of National Mobilization for Suppression of the Communist Rebellion in 1991 signifies the ROC government's determination not to use force to settle differences across the Taiwan Strait, Sheu said.
Unfortunately, Sheu added, the Beijing authorities have not likewise renounced the use of force against Taiwan.

Taiwan is entitled to defensive weapons to safeguard its security, Sheu said, since mainland China continues to pose a military threat to the island and because it has stepped up efforts to isolate Taiwan diplomatically.

DOC.HEADLINE: FORMER EBRD PRESIDENT DE LAROSIERE HONORED BY ROC

TEXT.P: Jacques de Larosiere, former president of the European Bank for Reconstruction and Development, received the ROC's Order of Brilliant Star with Grand Cordon on Thursday.
The award was conferred upon de Larosiere by Louis Wen-hua Tzen, Taipei's representative to the United Kingdom, on behalf of the ROC government.
De Larosiere served as EBRD president from September 1993 to January 1998 and has also served as managing director of the International Monetary Fund.

Tzen said de Larosiere's friendship to the Republic of China was unfailing during his tenure as IMF director and during his EBRD presidency. As EBRD president, de Larosiere enabled Taipei to enter into meaningful cooperation with the London-based bank, Tzen said.
Tzen reaffirmed Taipei's commitment to the bank, saying it will continue to play a positive role through EBRD's programs for the development of countries in Eastern Europe and Central Asia.

As part of its commitment, the ROC recently agreed to contribute an additional US$5 million to a joint Taipei-EBRD technical assistance fund to which Taipei had already contributed US$15 million. The agreement was signed during EBRD's annual conference this year in the Ukrainian capital of Kiev.
Taipei has also contributed another US$20 million to a fund designed for small- and medium-sized enterprises in Belorussia and to a special investment fund.

Although Taipei attended the annual EBRD conference as an observer, de Larosiere called Taiwan the bank's best non-member. The bank was established in 1991 to help Eastern European and Central Asian countries transform their economies from planned to market ones.

Taipei has been extremely helpful in contributing to the joint technical assistance fund, de Larosiere said. In fact, Taipei has helped EBRD more than EBRD has helped Taipei, de Larosiere said after receiving the ROC honor.

DOC.HEADLINE: DESIGNER WANTS SYDNEY OPERA HOUSE LISTED WITH WORLD HERITAGE

TEXT.P: The Danish designer of Sydney's best-known international landmark, its opera house, has urged the Australian government to place his masterpiece on the list of World Heritage-protected buildings.

Joern Utzon, who designed the Sydney Opera House, made the plea to an Australian documentary film team at his home in Hellebaek, Denmark. The government must act quickly to meet the June 30 deadline for listing the building with World Heritage, Utzon said.
"Please listen to me, Canberra," Utzon was quoted as saying in a story in the mass-circulation The Australian on Friday.

"This is an Australian building that should be cared for, at this important time in Australian history when your country is at the end of the colony of Australia and at the beginning of the Republic of Australia," he said.

"The spirit of this building is independent of anything anywhere. It is 100 percent Australian. This (the listing) and the year 2000 fit beautifully together. Then you can hear beautiful music all the time in the future from a clean, beautifully kept building," he said, adding "Please tell them in Canberra -- help."

Utzon was being filmed for a documentary titled "The Edge of the Possible," in which he tells the story behind the opera house's design and construction, as well as his departure from the project in 1966, years before the building was completed.
The documentary will be screened by the Australian Broadcasting Corporation in October.
The Sydney Opera House is popular not only among residents of Sydney, New South Wales and other Australian states but also among foreign guests and travelers who have visited Sydney.

DOC.HEADLINE: AUSTRALIA TO OVERHAUL ITS INTELLIGENCE FORCE

TEXT.P: Australia will overhaul its intelligence services to improve its spy training and the way information is presented to the government and military.

The mass-circulation newspaper The Australian on Friday quoted sources as revealing that the shake-up was prompted by concerns that timely defense intelligence information and analysis had failed to reach decision-makers.
One example cited was Australia's lack of forewarning that Papua New Guinea planned to fight in the Bougainville civil war last year.
Australia spends about A$140 (US$88) million a year on its intelligence gathering community, which comprises 1,500 personnel.

DOC.HEADLINE: BANGKOK WORRIES OVER A DEVALUED RENMINBI'S IMPACT

TEXT.P: Thailand is deeply worried that a devaluation of the Chinese renminbi would inevitably lead to a slowdown in Thai exports, an article released by the public relations department of the Prime Ministry of Thailand said on Thursday.

"Major Thai and Chinese export markets include the United States, Japan, the European Union, Hong Kong, South Korea, Taiwan and Singapore," the department said in its June 18 "Thailand News Bulletin." Some 70 percent of Thai exports go to these seven markets, the government said.

"China is Thailand's major competitor in these markets," a Thai official is quoted in the article as saying. Thai and mainland Chinese exports to the markets include garments, fabrics, electrical circuit boards, electrical appliances, iron and steel, footwear and children's toys.
There is concern in Thailand that a falling Japanese yen could force mainland China to devalue its renminbi to keep exports competitive, according to the bulletin.
The report marks the Thai government's first official comments on the prospect of a devalued renminbi.

"China has several strong factors that boost its competitiveness in export," according to the report, which noted that the efficiency of mainland Chinese industrial production has risen 20 percent annually from 1993 to 1997.

"China enjoys lower production and labor costs than Thailand, moreover, China has received trade privileges for its textile and garment exports to the USA and the EU markets," the Thai government complained.

It also indicated that the devaluation of the yuan would cause Thailand to suffer a trade deficit with Beijing, despite the fact that Thailand enjoyed a trade surplus with the country during the first quarter of this year, its first surplus in the past 11 years of trade relations.

The devaluation of the yuan would discourage Chinese investors from investing in Thailand despite strong efforts by Thailand to attract more foreign investment, the report said, adding that arrivals from mainland Chinese tourists, which dropped 3.7 percent last year, could fall further.

DOC.HEADLINE: JAPAN'S ATTENTION CENTERED ON UPPER HOUSE ELECTION

TEXT.P: Following the end of the 142nd ordinary session of the Diet on Thursday, Japan is focusing its attention on the 18th election of the House of Councilors in July, where 126 seats, or half of the 252 seats in the Upper House, will be up for grabs.
Economic recovery will be the major issue in the election, held once every three years.

Attention will also be focused on whether the ruling Liberal Democratic Party can win all its 61 seats being contested and an additional eight seats, giving it a total of 127. It would be the first time in nine years the party controlled Japan's upper house. The LDP currently has a total of 119 seats.
Voting is scheduled to take place July 12, and balloting will be extended two hours this year to 8 p.m. The move is aimed at boosting voter turnout, which stood at only 44.52 percent in 1995.

If the LDP fails to win back at least 61 seats, Prime Minister Ryutaro Hashimoto, also LDP president, is expected to be held responsible for the party's performance. A dismal showing could imperil his political career.
Owing to the weakness of the opposition, however, the LDP stands a good chance of winning more than 61 seats, though it is uncertain whether the party can capture a majority in the upper house.

Of the 126 seats being contested, 76 will be filled by votes cast in electoral districts, while the remaining 50 will be filled on the basis of proportional representation. In all more than 400 candidates will compete in the elections.

The total number of seats, as well as the number being contested, of Japan's major political parties in the Upper House are as follows: LDP, 119 (61 being contested); Democratic Party, 38 (18); Komei, 24 (11); Social Democratic Party, 20 (12); Communist Party, 14 (6); Liberal Party, 11 (5).
The LDP regained its majority in Japan's lower house, the House of Representatives, last summer, capturing 261 of 500 seats.

DOC.HEADLINE: WASHINGTON'S ACTION TO PROP UP JAPANESE YEN PRAISED

TEXT.P: US intervention to prop up a sagging Japanese yen is giving Asia's troubled economies some breathing room, according to a new analysis by James Flanigan, The Los Angeles Times' senior economic editor.

Washington's action signaled a more forceful US role in helping the Japanese economy rebound and in helping the rest of Asia recover from its financial crisis. The US moves also, in effect, placed a floor under the yen and other major currencies in Asia, according to Flanigan.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROTH REAFFIRMS US COMMITMENT TO TAIWAN'S SECURITY
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, June 18 (CNA) (By Jay Chen and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: A senior US official reaffirmed on Thursday that the Clinton administration remains steadfast in its commitment to meet Taiwan's defense needs.

Stanley Roth, assistant secretary of state for East Asian and Pacific affairs, made the statment while testifying before a Senate subcommittee on President Bill Clinton's upcoming state visit to mainland China.

"The administration remains firmly committed to filling the security and arms trasfer provisions of the TRA, Taiwan Relations Act," Roth told the Subcommittee on Asian and Pacific Affairs under the Senate's Committee on Foreign Relations.

Noting that the commitment is not a matter of rhetoric, Roth said the Clinton administration has demonstrated it through the transfer of F-16s, Knox-class frigates, helicopters and tanks, as well as a variety of other equipment.
"And we will continue to assist Taiwan in meeting its defense needs," Roth pledged.
Consistent with its obligations under the TRA, Roth said, the US regularly consults with Taiwan as to how it can best address a broad range of security threats, including posed by ballistic missiles.
For instance, Roth said, the Clinton administration has briefed Taiwan on the concept of theater missile defense, or TMD.
"Officials in Taiwan are currently assessing their own capabilities and needs. They have not to date indicated interest in acquiring TMD," Roth noted.

At this moment, Roth said, "requiring a study of this kind thus gets ahead of the situation on the ground in Taiwan, and may not even be consistent with the approach Taiwan officials will ultimately want to take."

Against this background, Roth said, the Clinton administration is opposed to the legislation of a bill passed by the House of Representatives last November demanding the Department of Defense to produce a study of the architecture requirement for the establishment and operation of a theater ballistic missile defense system for Taiwan.

The House passed the bill with a vote of 301-116 on Nov. 6, 1997 sortly after mainland Chinese President Jiang Zemin made a high-profile state visit to the United States. The bill has been referred to the Senate for deliberation and approval.
Roth went on to say while making it possible for Taiwan to acquire the wherewithal to defend itself, Taiwan's long-term security relies on more than military factors.
"In the end, stability in the Taiwan Strait will be contingent on the ability of the two sides of the strait to come to terms with each other on a political basis," Roth observed.

For this reason, Roth said, the Clinton administration has encouraged both Taiwan and Beijing to reopen dialogue, making clear to both sides that dialogue is the most promising way to defuse tensions and build confidence.

Touching on the possible impact on Taiwan of Clinton's June 25-July 3 mainland visit, Roth said he has stated publicly on numerous occasions as well as privately to Taiwan officials that there will not be a fourth communique on any subject affecting Taiwan.
"We will not be doing anything to undermine their interests," Roth said in response to an inquiry by Sen. Craig Thomas, chairman of the Senate Subcommittee on Asia and Pacific Affairs.

DOC.HEADLINE: HONG KONG PEOPLE TAKE NOTICE OF TAIWAN
DOC.DATELINE: Hong Kong, June 18 (CNA) (By Jorge Liu & Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: More than 60 percent of Hong Kong residents take notice of news about Taiwan, according to a recent survey.

The survey, which was commissioned by the Hong Kong-based Cross-Strait Relations Research Center, was conducted by Hong Kong University on June 11-13. Respondents included people living on Hong Kong Island and in Kowloon and the New Territories.
While 60.6 percent of respondents claimed to notice news about Taiwan, 31 said they do not take special notice of such news and 8.4 percent said they have no interest in news about Taiwan.
Television was the medium through which most Hong Kong people receive Taiwan-related news, followed by newspapers, magazines and radio broadcasts, the survey showed.
Politics in Taiwan was the topic of interest to 40.2 percent of respondents, while 27.3 percent expressed a keen interest in social news and 8.3 percent focused on economic news and trade reports.

The survey results also showed less than 10 percent of those surveyed have visited Taiwan within the past three years, and among those who have more than half did not come until Hong Kong was handed back to mainland China last July.
Among those polled who traveled to Taiwan, 50 percent said they visited the island for sightseeing, 22.2 percent for calling on friends or relatives and 19.4 percent for business activities.
About 87 percent of the surveyed said they wish Hong Kong would set up a liaison office in Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN FACES DIFFICULTY CUTTING TARIFFS IN FISHERY SECTOR

TEXT.P: Taiwan will face difficulty cutting tariffs in the fishery sector, Vice Economic Minister Lin Yi-fu said on Friday.

Lin made the remarks in advance of a three-day ministerial meeting of the Asian Pacific Economic Cooperation (APEC) forum which opens on June 21 in Malaysia. Top of the agenda at the meeting will be "early voluntary sectoral liberalization (EVSL)."
Lin said that other countries will also face similar difficulties in achieving a target of zero tariffs by 2005 in the fishery sector.

APEC leaders launched the EVSL plan in a previous meeting in Vancouver, with the aim of lowering trade barriers in nine sectors -- environmental goods and services, medical equipment, chemicals, energy, forestry products, fishery products, gems and jewelry, toys, and electronic commerce.
Trade ministers this year will review the progress made regarding the nine sectors during the June 21-23 meeting in Kuching, Malaysia.
However, Lin pointed out that although it will be difficult for Taiwan to lower tariffs on fishery products, it will have fewer problems with the other sectors.

He noted that according to the results of talks with World Trade Organization members on Taiwan's terms for joining the world trade regulatory body, tariffs on fishery products should be cut to 20.9 percent by 2004. The APEC cuts are so much lower than this target that Taiwan cannot possibly agree to them, he added.
He said that Japan, South Korea, Association for Southeast Asian nations, and mainland China, will also face similar difficulties in meeting the goal of zero tariffs by 2005.

DOC.HEADLINE: NT DOLLAR UP

TEXT.P: The New Taiwan dollar climbed NT$0.028 against the greenback on the Taipei foreign exchange market Friday, closing at NT$34.073.
The local currency opened at the day's high of 33.946 and had a low of 34.33.
The interbank US dollar trading reached US$456.5 million.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN ACADEMIC ASSOCIATION CALLS FOR REFERENDUM ON TAIWAN'S FUTURE
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, June 19 (CNA) (By Elizabeth Hsu) (By Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: Taipei, June 19 (CA) A group of Taiwan professors has called for a referendum at the end of the year to decide on the future of Taiwan.
Officials from the Taiwan Association of University Professors said on Friday it has proposed that the referendum be held on Dec. 5 to coincide with the legislative election in Taiwan.

In a declaration opposing damage to the island's sovereignty by big powers, the officials said that the people of Taiwan have the right of self-determination, and that only they should be able to decide their country's future.

They stressed that Taiwan needs to express this view before US President Bill Clinton's trip to mainland China next week, because his summit meeting with mainland President Jiang Zemin will have a serious effect on Taiwan's safety and future.
The 352-member association said that on June 27 it will stage a demonstration in front of the American Institute in Taiwan, the de facto American embassy, to highlight its stance.

The association also said it is soliciting support for the declaration, and has so far collected the signatures of more than 60 legislators and national assemblymen, as well as the support of more than 20 groups, and of many county chiefs and city mayors.
The total number in support of the declaration will be announced on Sunday in a broadcast by Formosa Television, a local cable TV station.

DOC.HEADLINE: SHARE PRICES DOWN ON TAIEX

TEXT.P: Share prices opened low and closed slightly higher on the Taipei Stock Exchange (TAIEX) on Friday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, falling by 13.88 points to close at 7,754.43.
The bourse opened at 7,732.28, and experienced a low of 7,700.23 and a high of 7,815.11.
Dealers said the market was curbed after four days of gains of around 800 points, with only electronics stocks and foodstuff shares continuing to move up.
Losers outnumbered gainers by 289 to 158, with 44 issues remaining unchanged.

A total of 2.72 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$145.33 billion, a decrease from the previous trading session which saw 2.96 billion stocks change hands on a market turnover of NT$149.12 billion.

Six of the major categories lost ground, with bank and insurance stocks moving down the most at 1.9 percent, followed by construction shares at 1.6 percent, textile issues at 1.3 percent, plastics and chemical shares at 0.8 percent, cement stocks at 0.6 percent, and pulp and paper issues at 0.4 percent.
Meanwhile, the electrical category registered a gain, moving up at 1.4 percent, followed by foodstuff shares at 1.1 percent.

The 10 listed companies enjoying the largest turnovers in Friday's trading were: United Micro Electronics; ASE; Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing; Winbond Electronics Corp.; Chuntex Electronic Co., Ltd.; Taiwan Tea Corp.; Ever Fortune Industries; Compal Electronic, Inc.; ACER; and Inventec Corp.

DOC.HEADLINE: US TRADE DEFICIT WITH MAINLAND CHINA TO HIT US$60 BILLION
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, June 18 (CNA) (By Herman Pan & Eva Chen)

TEXT.P: The US trade deficit with mainland China is expected to soar to a record US$60 billion in 1998, up from last year's figure of US$49.7 billion in Beijing's favor, according to US Department of Commerce statistics.
Since Washington and Beijing established diplomatic relations 19 years ago, the US has suffered 15 consecutive years of deficit in bilateral trade with the mainland, the statistics show.

The US suffered a cumulative deficit of US$15.778 billion in trade with mainland China in the first four months of 1998, a record high and an increase of 19.8 percent over the corresponding period of last year, the statistics indicate.

If Washington's trade deficit with Beijing continues at the current level, it will reach some US$59.6 billion by the end of 1998, which would surpass Washington's 1997 trade deficit with Japan by US$5 billion. Japan has long enjoyed the largest trade deficit with the US.

US President Bill Clinton is scheduled to visit mainland China next week, when he will have a summit meeting with his mainland counterpart Jiang Zemin. Issues such as the serious trade deficit imbalance and Beijing's bid for entry into the World Trade Organization will be high on the summit agenda, said US Secretary of Commerce William M. Daley.
However, the recent drastic depreciation of the Japanese yen, and the deteriorating financial situation in the rest of Asia, are likely to be factors in Beijing's favor at the summit.

Beijing has maintained the value of the renminbi and has not tried to take advantage of the exchange rate to promote exports, which the Beijing authorities are sure to point out when they face Washington's censure over the huge trade deficit.

DOC.HEADLINE: GAMBLERS ROUNDED UP IN TAOYUAN COUNTY

TEXT.P: Police arrested 24 gamblers early on Friday in a raid on an underground casino in Taoyuan County, northern Taiwan.

Among those arrested, 11 hold Indonesian passports, and some are ROC nationals whom the government helped evacuate from Indonesia last month at the height of severe riots in the Southeast Asian country.
Acting on a tip-off, police swooped on the residence of Chu Chi-chiang in Lungang Village, Taoyuan County, where they rounded up the gamblers and seized NT$373,000 (US$8,030) in cash.

A police spokesman said that the gamblers were engaged in a popular Indonesian dice game, and that Chu, the householder, had charged commission of between NT$500 and NT$1,000 (US$14.7-US$29.4) for each round of the game.
Police are still questioning the gamblers and have turned Chu over to the Taoyuan District Court.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRO-TAIWAN DEMONSTRATION HELD IN WASHINGTON

TEXT.P: Hundreds of Taiwanese Americans staged a demonstration in Washington Thursday, urging President Bill Clinton not to compromise the interests of Taiwan when he visits mainland China.

More than 10 US senators and congressmen, as well as several lawmakers of Taiwan's major opposition Democratic Progressive Party, also participated in the demonstration on the lawn in front of the Capitol. The demonstration was also held in a park near the White House.

The demonstrators requested President Clinton, who will leave here next week for a nine-day visit to mainland China, to urge Beijing to renounce the use of military force against Taiwan and to refrain from hindering Taiwan's bid to join international organizations. They also requested the President to show US support for the self-determination of Taiwan people.

Several US lawmakers made speeches during the demonstration. They praised Taiwan for its success in political and economic development, and reaffirmed their friendship and support for the people of Taiwan.

The demonstrators also shouted slogans during the demonstration sponsored by the Formosan Association for Public Affairs (FAPA), the Alliance for Taiwan Independence, and other organizations known for their advocacy of Taiwan independence. Many of the demonstrators came from the New York and Boston areas by bus.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI MAYORAL HOPEFUL FINDS STRONG SUPPORT IN US CHINESE COMMUNITIES
DOC.DATELINE: New York, June 18 (CNA) (By K.C. Huang & Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: A group of overseas Chinese leaders and scholars in the eastern United States got together in New York on Thursday for a preparatory meeting on the establishment of a supporters group for Taipei mayoral hopeful Ma Ying-jeou.

Those present at the meeting resolved to drum up all possible support for Ma, a former ROC justice minister, in his battle for victory in the mayoral election to be held in Taipei at the end of this year.

During the meeting, Jacob Ma, a commissioner of the Cabinet-level Overseas Chinese Affairs Commission and president of the Chinese-language World Journal of North America, said Ma's performance will be vital for the future of the ruling Kuomintang (KMT), as well as for the prospects of the ROC as a whole.

Ma Ying-jeou's elder sister, Ma Yi-nan, who is chairperson of the Overseas Chinese Academics Association in the Eastern US, noted at the meeting that her brother's entry into the race will not only consolidate the strained hierarchy of the KMT, it will also infuse new strength into the 100-year-old party, giving it the cohesiveness it needs to stride forward to the new millennium.
The meeting also resolved that the Ma Ying-jeou Supporters Group in the Eastern US will be formally established in mid-July after Ma makes a personal appearance in New York.
Ma, who is currently an associate professor at National Chengchi University, is scheduled to arrive in New York on July 8 at the start of a weeklong US visit.

The Ma Ying-jeou Supporters Group in Northern California, the first of its kind in America, was formally founded on Wednesday in San Francisco, with the aim of drumming up support for Ma in Chinese communities in the western US.
Similar groups are expected to mushroom in Washington, D.C., Los Angeles, Chicago, Dallas, Vancouver and Toronto, according to sources in the San Francisco group.

DOC.HEADLINE: EXHIBITION FEATURING IMAGES OF TAIWAN OPENS IN MOSCOW
DOC.DATELINE: Moscow, June 18 (CNA) (By Chang Hung-kuang & Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: An exhibition featuring images of Taiwan and the lives of the people who live there opened in Moscow on Thursday, with the aim of introducing the Republic of China on Taiwan to the people of Russia.

The "Taiwan Today" exhibition is being sponsored by the Taipei-Moscow Economic and Cultural Coordination Commission, which has also presented Russia with a range of books and information on Taiwan to facilitate research on the island.

Presiding over a ceremony to open the exhibition and present the books, Republic of China Representative to Russia Chang Wen-chung described the activities as a first step in Taipei-Moscow cultural cooperation.
The ROC set up its representative office in Moscow in 1993, while Russia opened a liaison office in Taipei in 1996. The two countries have no official diplomatic relations at present.

DOC.HEADLINE: 6 TAIWAN LEADERS MAKE BUSINESS WEEK'S 'STARS OF ASIA' LIST
DOC.DATELINE: New York, June 18 (CNA) (By K. C. Huang and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: Six prominent Taiwan personalities have made the "Stars of Asia" list featured by the US-based BusinessWeek in its June 29 Asian edition, which will hit newsstands on Saturday.

The weekly features a total of 50 Asian leaders who the magazine says are taking significant steps to help Asia emerge from its worst crisis in a half century. They include policymakers, managers, entrepreneurs, financiers and opinion leaders.
The six Taiwan "stars" are:

-- Yuan T. Lee, 61, president of Academia Sinica, Taiwan's highest research institute. Noting that Lee is the first Taiwan-born Nobel Prize laureate and a devoted education reformer, BusinessWeek said the new thinking introduced by Lee is like a gentle breeze sweeping through Taiwan's rigid, conservative education system.

The weekly further said Lee worries that Taiwan -- famous for its bright engineers who have built a thriving and globally competitive electronics industry -- will miss the next step up the technology ladder if it doesn't train more creative thinkers and invest more in research.

-- Chen Shui-bian, 47, mayor of Taipei. BusinessWeek said Chen, the first non-KMT mayor of Taipei, has dismantled the Kuomintang's patronage machine in the city and tackled long neglected problems that fueled the citizens' rage.

-- Morris Chang, 66, CEO of Taiwan Semiconductor Corp. "Chang's long career in the US -- he worked at Texas Instruments Inc. and General Instrument Corp. -- taught him to value the emphasis Western business places on employee welfare, innovation and strong links to customers. He thinks Asia's beleaguered companies must adopt those values," the weekly said.

-- Steve Chang, 43, CEO of Trend Micro. BusinessWeek praised Chang as a powerful force in the global market for anti-hacker software, a field dominated by the US. It quoted Chang as saying that there is no reason that more software companies can't be big successes in Asia.

-- Jonney Shih, 45, chairman of Asustek Computer. "By hiring top-caliber engineers, Shih has ensured that his company is a key link in the worldwide supply chains of top computer makers," the weekly said.

-- Hsu Ta-lin, 54, chairman of Hambrecht & Quist Asia Pacific. BusinessWeek said Hsu is helping restructure Corporate Asia. "Hsu wants to clean up the traditional Asian management practices -- and the balance sheet -- of acquired companies. And he rewards executives the Silicon Valley way: with stock options."

Also among the 50 "Star of Asia" are South Korean President Kim Dae-jung, 76; mainland Chinese Premier Zhu Rongji, 69; Singaporean Deputy Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong, 46; Hong Kong Legislator Martin Lee, 60.

The weekly said few of the 50 are saints. "But all of them show, in one way or another, how Asia must move forward ... Some of these stars may not succeed in their ambitions. But what is important is that they are changing the way Asians think about themselves, their problems, and the economies and societies in which they work and live... BuisnessWeek's stars are hoping and working for something different."

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT LEE, BILL GATES SHARE COMMON VISION

TEXT.P: President Lee Teng-hui received visiting Microsoft Corp. CEO Bill Gates on Friday at the Presidential Office, where they discussed their common vision of Taiwan's future success in the global market.
The president said that in an information society, information must be fully grasped and rapidly processed in order for a country and its enterprises to maintain a competitive advantage.

He went on to say that the successful development of "digital nervous systems" will be a big step forward for information technology, and that it will help the government and local industries to sharpen their competitive edge.

Gates agreed with Lee's concept of the importance of digital nervous systems, and later on Friday, at a symposium organized by the Executive Yuan's National Information Infrastructure task force, he shared his own ideas with the 2,000 attendees.

Gates explained that the basic concept behind a digital nervous system is the use of efficiently networked personal computers, reliable electronic mail, and software capable of processing huge amounts of data, to incorporate the best ideas and information from all levels of an organization to achieve a "group intelligence."
The digital nervous system relies on the constantly improving technology which has seen the advent of ever more powerful high-speed personal computers, Gates added.

By allowing all members of an organization to have access to a common digital nervous system, they can receive the newest, most accurate and most useful information at the fastest possible speed, Gates said, pointing out that this will be a major factor in improving a company's overall competitive edge.

With improved efficiency throughout the organization and the ability to react quickly to information, a company can make the best policy decisions and close the communication gap between the company and the client, he said.

Gates urged Taiwan to place greater importance on the development of digital technology and to build a global network, pointing out that Taiwan is better equipped than most other countries to respond quickly to market and technological changes.

He also noted that Taiwan has close relationships with many companies worldwide and is already making increasingly widespread use of networks. Coupled with the increasingly powerful capabilities of personal computers, Gates said that Taiwan should immediately focus on digital nervous system technology in order to maintain its global market position.
Gates arrived in Taiwan on Thursday evening, his seventh visit to the island since Microsoft established an office here nine years ago.
He is also scheduled to star in a ten-minute video commercial aimed at promoting the quality of Taiwan goods to consumers worldwide.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI CITY GOVERNMENT RETHINKS GARBAGE COLLECTION FEES

TEXT.P: The Bureau of Environmental Protection under the Taipei City Government is planning to collect garbage fees from city residents through the sale of garbage bags.
The bureau revealed at a press conference on Friday that if the plan receives the support of the Taipei City Council, it is expected to be formally implemented in Taipei City from July 1999.

Recent complaints of excessive garbage fees lodged by Wang Tso-yung, president of the Control Yuan, have drawn widespread public attention. Garbage fees in Taipei City are currently levied along with water fees.

The Bureau of Environmental Protection responded to the complaints by implementing a pilot scheme in April this year to collect garbage fees through the sale of garbage bags in seven Taipei City precincts.

A subsequent survey has revealed that each family in the experimental area has been spending an average of NT$167 per month for the special garbage bags, as opposed to the NT$214 garbage fees incurred by families not using the new system.
The survey also found that 59 percent of the householders in the pilot scheme are in favor of the new system, while 27 percent are against its continuation.
In addition, the bureau said, the new plan is helping to achieve vast improvements in the city's garbage recycling measures.

The pilot scheme, which is expected to conclude at the end of June, will be carried on and expanded to cover more city precincts in September, after which it will be submitted for approval by the city council. If approved, the plan will then be implemented formally throughout the whole city in July of next year.

DOC.HEADLINE: SAN TOME AND PRINCIPE PRESIDENT WINDS UP VISIT TO ROC

TEXT.P: President Miguel A.C.L. Trovoada of the Republic of San Tome and Principe left Taipei on Friday after a five-day state visit to the Republic of China on Taiwan.
President Lee Teng-hui presided over a military ceremony at the Chiang Kai-shek Memorial Hall complex in downtown Taipei to bid farewell to the top leader of the West African state.
Prior to the ceremony, Lee and Trovoada signed a joint communique, reaffirming their commitment to further promote bilateral cooperation in various fields.
In the communique, Trovoada threw his support for the ROC's stance on promoting eventual unification of the two sides of the Taiwan Strait based on dialogue, consultation and peaceful negotiations.

Trovoada also expressed his hope that the ROC will continue assisting his country in economic, social, cultural, educational and agricultral development. "By so doing, our cooperation will set a model in Africa," he noted.

For his part, Lee said he is delighted to see various bilateral cooperative programs proceeding smoothly since the two countries established formal diplomatic ties in May 1997. "Hopefully, our cooperation will be further expanded in the future."
Accompanied by an 11-member entourage, Trovoada arrived in Taipei on Monday for his first visit to Taiwan.

While here, Trovoada exchanged views with President Lee and other senior ROC officials on the general international situation, Taiwan's relations with African countries and other matters of mutual concern.

DOC.HEADLINE: ECONOMICS MINISTER LEAVES FOR APEC MEETING IN KUCHING

TEXT.P: Economics Minister Wang Chih-kang left for Kuching, Malaysia via Singapore on Friday to attend a ministerial meeting of the Asia Pacific Economics Cooperation (APEC) forum.
He is accompanied by Vice Economics Minister Lin Yi-fu, Chen Ruey-long, director-general of the Board of Foreign Trade, and other officials.
Prior to his departure, Minister Wang said the meeting will involve discussion of such important topics as early voluntary sectoral liberalization (EVSL) and intellectual property rights protection.
Commenting on the liberalization program, he said there are not many problems regarding tariff reductions on industrial products, but there are difficulties on tariff on fishery products.
The ministers will also discuss the implementation of APEC individual action plans (IAP) and the collective action plans (CAP), among others.
During the June 21-23 meeting, Wang will also hold bilateral talks with his APEC counterparts from the United States, Canada, Chile, Japan, Thailand and Indonesia.
On his way to Kuching, Wang and his group will have a lunch meeting with Taiwan businessmen in Singapore on Saturday during a one-day stopover there.
They will also attend a seminar with Taiwan businessmen in Kuala Lumpur on June 24 before returning to Taipei later that day.

DOC.HEADLINE: CLINTON URGED TO MEET WITH CHINESE DISSIDENT XU WENLI

TEXT.P: Fifty-five mainland Chinese dissidents Friday sent an open letter to US President Bill Clinton, urging him to meet with leading dissident Xu Wenli during his upcoming visit to mainland China.

In the letter made public through the Hong Kong-based Information Center of Human Rights and Democratic Movement in China, the dissidents said that, by meeting with Xu, President Clinton may show his real concern over the human rights condition in mainland China.

Xu, a leader of the 1979 Democracy Wall movement and the current democratic movement in mainland China, was sentenced to 15 years in prison on "counterrevolution" charges. He was released in 1993, when Beijing leaders were eager to win the privilege to host the 2000 summer Olympic Games.

If President Clinton fails to meet with Xu, 54, the upcoming visit would be meaningless, except helping Beijing leaders cast off the "political shadow" of the 1989 Tiananmen massacre, said the open letter. A copy of the letter has been sent to James Sasser, US ambassador to Beijing.

DOC.HEADLINE: GATES ANNOUNCES ESTABLISHMENT OF MICROSOFT CENTER IN TAIWAN

TEXT.P: Microsoft Corp. Chairman and CEO Bill Gates on Friday announced the establishment of his company's Asian-Pacific Dedicated System Solution Center in Taiwan.

Gates, who is in Taipei on a whirlwind 24-hour visit, said at a news conference that the center will help Taiwan's information industry exploit advanced platform devices for Windows CE and Windows NT.

He said Taiwan's excellent enterprise development environment and its outstanding capability in designing and mass production are the reasons why Microsoft chose the island as the site for its regional center.
Fan Cheng-chu, president of Microsoft Taiwan Co., said the center is expected to help the local information industry boost its design capability and expand its market share.
Gates said Internet connection and a non-paper environment will be the trend of future development of personal computers.
He said that with the popularization of PC's, government agencies and enterprises are now able to establish a high-speed Internet connection system to improve the flow of information.

For example, he said, several US business giants including GE and Boeing, have moved toward "non-paper offices," which are expected to sharpen their competitive edge by reducing production cost and increasing added-value to their products.

Asked to pinpoint the weakness of Taiwan in software development, Gates said that the island is facing a shortage of software R&D personnel, making it difficult for the island to attract investment from multinational software companies.
But Gates said that Microsoft is willing to come to Taiwan's aid in this field.

As a gesture to show Microsoft's support for both the ROC government and its private sector's efforts to develop software, Fan said his company will join forces with the Institute for Information Industry (III) to train local software talent.

Under the program, teachers and trainers will first be cultivated in local universities and colleges, and they in turn will train 20,000 to 25,000 software engineers in three years for the island, Fan added.

In addition, Software and III will jointly set up Windows DNA Application Development Lab and Distributed Internet Applications Architecture in Taiwan, which are expected to help businesses improve operations through the application of computer technology.
Gates arrived in Taiwan Thursday evening. It is his seventh visit to the island since Microsoft opened its Taipei office nine years ago.
Gates called on President Lee Teng-hui Friday morning and presented him with Window 98, which is scheduled to hit the stores next month.

Later in the day, Gates, who is considered the richest man in the world with an estimated fortune of US$40 billion, starred in a 10-minute video commercial aimed at promoting made-in-Taiwan goods worldwide.

DOC.HEADLINE: NO COMMENT ON LEE-CHEN PRESIDENTIAL TICKET: WANG CHIEN-SHIEN

TEXT.P: New Party Taipei mayoral candidate Wang Chien-shien said on Friday he has no particular comment on the possibility of a Lee Teng-hui-Chen Shui-bian ticket in the 2000 presidential election.

Wang said people can have different views on whether such a ticket involving the ruling Kuomintang (KMT) and the Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) is possible, but there is no need to devalue other people's point of views.
He was referring to the bold remarks made Wednesday by another party heavyweight Jaw Shau-kong, which prompted criticism from the KMT leadership and Chen.

Jaw, the New Party's campaign manager for the year-end legislative, mayoral and city council deputy elections, on Friday repeated his prediction that the friendly engagement between President Lee and Taipei Mayor Chen as well as their common belief in Taiwan independence might lead the two to run together in the next presidential election.
Speaking on another issue, Wang said he does not agree with Premier Vincent Siew's decision to suspend the future operation of the Build-Operate-Transfer (BOT) system.

Saying the BOT system was designed to encourage private investment in large-scale transportation projects, the former finance minister stressed that BOT is a vital strategy in the development of the country and should not be abolished.

Responding to disputes resulting from the bidding of Chiang Kai-shek Airport Rapid Transit Systems project, a BOT case, Siew on Thursday instructed the Council for Economic Planning and Development to work out a complete set of rules governing the operation of the BOT system. He said before such rules are set, all other proposed cases based on BOT should be put temporarily on hold.

Wang also said he would not drop of out the mayoral election even though his support rate in several recent surveys showed him lagging far behind incumbent Taipei Mayor Chen and KMT candidate Ma Ying-jeou. He vowed to fight a clean battle without any disreputable or sensational tactics.

DOC.HEADLINE: A JAPANESE BOY RECEIVES SUCCESSFUL LIVER TRANSPLANT IN TAIWAN

TEXT.P: After waiting in Taiwan three years for a life-saving liver transplant, a 7-year-old Japanese boy flew home Friday with a healthy new liver.

Kosuke Setsude contracted a fatal liver-related disease caused by biliary aresia, a kind of congenital bile duct defect, 63 days after birth. His only hope for survival was to receive a liver transplant.

In January 1995, Setsude, accompanied by his ethnic Chinese mother, was transferred to the Kaohsiung-based Chang Gung Hospital in southern Taiwan to await a liver transplant after undergoing several urgent medical treatment in Japan.

The wait for a transplant took three years. On Jan. 20, a 6-year-old boy living in Ilan, northeastern Taiwan, died in an accident. His parents donated the boy's liver and other organs to those who were on waiting lists.
Setsude was one of the lucky ones on that list and the next day, Setsude received a successful liver transplant. He was released from the hospital on March 5.

During his long-term stay on the island, Setsude learned how to speak Mandarin. Before leaving for Japan on Friday, Setsude said in his second tongue that his biggest wish was to visit Tokyo Disneyland with his father.

DOC.HEADLINE: LACK OF DOMESTIC DEMAND BLAMED FOR JAPAN'S SLUMP

TEXT.P: The Japanese yen will likely remain soft in the near foreseeable future, the Swiss Bank Corporation (SBC) predicted Friday.
The yen has lost about 20 percent of its value against the US dollar in the last year, and the current trend in Japan's fundamental economic data indicates the country is in for more of the same.

Japan's current slump is due to a lack of domestic demand, the SCB said. The weak economic outlook and the political reluctance to introduce needed reforms have dealt an additional blow to consumer confidence.
Recent economic indicators paint a gloomy portrait of Japan even as the outlook for the United States and Europe continues to be upbeat.

For the first time since 1991, the Japanese yen broke through the 140 barrier against the US dollar. Growing concerns about the Japanese economy, and the economies in East Asia which have close ties to Japan, have caused the latest worries.

The divergence in the economic trends shows that the Japanese yen is not merely suffering from the vagaries of the market, but that the drop in the currency is due to a deterioration in the country's economy.

The bank said it does not expect the government's fiscal packages, including an income tax cut, to provide much of a spark to the economy. The current crisis has unleashed a lot of insecurity about the future, so that the Japanese have been stashing away disposable income instead of spending it.

Under these circumstances, the Bank of Japan's expensive monetary policy has not had any impact, it continued. Japanese monetary authorities have been pumping liquidity into the economy to prop up the financial sectors, and will continue to do so for the time being, the SBC said.

"The economic crisis, in our opinion, is far from over. We expect the Bank of Japan to maintain its expansive policy, which means the Japanese yen is likely to drop further. A stronger Japanese currency will come about only when the economy begins to recover, which will not happen until next year at the earliest," the SBC concluded.

DOC.HEADLINE: FREEMAN UNDERESTIMATES TAIWAN'S POLITICAL WISDOM

TEXT.P: A Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) official said on Friday that former US Assistant Secretary of Defense Chas W. Freeman has underestimated Taiwan people's political wisdom by calling on the US to review its policy on arms sales to Taiwan.
Shen Lyu-shun, head of the MOFA's North American Affairs Department, said that Freeman has also misconstrued the joint communique signed by Washington and Beijing on Aug. 17, 1982.
Freeman made the call in an article titled "Preventing War in the Taiwan Strait" which was published in the August, 1998 edition of Foreign Affairs bimonthly.
In his personal view, Shen said Freeman committed three serious errors in the article.
First, US arms sales to Taiwan have never boosted independence sentiments in Taiwan as Freeman claimed. "Many pro-independence advocates have become more cautious regarding the issue," he noted.
Secondly, Taiwan is not as "childish" as Freeman described. Freeman said Taiwan would rather listen to voices in the US Congress than take notice of advice from the US administration.
"Actually, we understand and respect the interrelations between US Congress and the US administrative branch," Shen said.
Thirdly, Freeman misunderstood the 1982 communique. Beijing, not Taipei, is to blame for the changes in cross-strait relations, he continued.

Freeman wrote that "the United States cannot hold Beijing to its word if Americans do not keep theirs. The sales of 150 F-16 fighters to Taiwan in 1992 and some subsequent deals do not square with the 1982 agreement."

In response, Shen said it is Beijing which is attempting to change the situation across the Taiwan Strait by blocking Taiwan in the international community and by resorting to military threat by launching missiles off Taiwan.

Washington should blame Beijing if it wanted the two sides of the Taiwan Strait to maintain the status-quo, because Beijing pledged "to strive for a peaceful solution to the Taiwan question" in the communique, while Washington promised to "cap the quantity and sophistication of its arms sales to Taiwan," Shen argued.
Although the US promised to sell arms to Taiwan in the 1982 communique, he stressed, it is linked to a condition which requires Beijing to stick with a peaceful solution to the Taiwan question.

DOC.HEADLINE: SHEN EXPLAINS ROC'S CONCERN ABOUT CLINTON-JIANG SUMMIT

TEXT.P: The Republic of China's conern about US President Bill Clinton's upcoming visit to mainland China lies in Washington's stance on the Beijing-proposed "new three no's," a senior official said on Friday.

Shen Lyu-shun, director of the North American Affairs Department of the Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA), said the ROC would not like to see the United States discuss with Beijing any subject related to Taiwan.

"This is a matter of principle," Shen said. "If the US has any opinion about issues involving Taiwan, it should directly consult with us, not mainalnd China. More important, the US should not make any promise to Beijing on any ROC-related subject."
Mainland leaders have made it clear that they will bring up the so-called "Taiwan issue" when Clinton visits the mainland from June 25 through July 3.

Beijing is expected to ask Clinton to reaffirm the US commitment to the "one China" policy, which Beijing says is against the creation of "two Chinas or one China, one Taiwan," and opposes Taiwan independence and its entry to international organizations involving sovereign states.
Shen said it remains unclear how Clinton will respond to mainland President Jiang Zemin's demand for US promise on the above-mentioned "three no's."
Noting that the ROC has neither pursued "two Chinas, or one China, one Taiwan" nor Taiwan independence, Shen said what the ROC cares is not the content of the Clinton-Jiang talks.

"What we care most is that the US should not discuss ROC-related issues with Beijing," Shen explained, adding such move implies that mainland China is entitled to interfere with US relations with the ROC.

Recalling that the 1982 US-mainland China join communique, in which the US promised to gradually reduce arms sales to Taiwan, has greatly hurt Taiwan, Shen said the ROC would not like to see recurrence of such an event during Clinton's forthcoming mainland visit.
Shen also reminded the US that in its 1994 policy review, it once promised to support Taiwan's entry to international organizations whose memberships are not confined to sovereign states.

DOC.HEADLINE: VIETNAMESE CHILD RECEIVES FACIAL SURGERY

TEXT.P: A Vietnamese baby boy whose face is seriously disfigured from congenital abnormalities on Friday received the first in a series of facial surgeries at the Chang Gung Memorial Hospital in Linkou near Taipei.
Led by hospital president Chen Yu-jui, a seven-member medical team which included a plastic surgeon and a cranial nerve specialist, successfully carried out the operation in six and a half hours.

A spokesman for the team said Ar Fu, the baby boy, was born with a harelip and suffered from serious facial damage. Blood vessels within his cranium were also seriously dislocated. He said the doctors decided to undergo a craniotomy operation to reshape the patient's cranium.
According to Chen, Ar Fu is in stable condition and will wait five days before a second operation to rectify his cleft palate is performed.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN, ISRAEL AVOID DOUBLE TAXATION ON OCEAN SHIPMENTS

TEXT.P: Taiwan and Israel on Friday pledged to avoid the double taxation of business income earned by ocean shipment forwarders from the two countries.
Akiva Tor, acting representative of the Israel Economic and Culture Office in Taipei, signed the agreement on behalf of his government.
Officials from Taiwan's foreign, economics, finance, and transportation and communication ministries as well as local ocean shipment forwarders were present to witness the signing ceremony.
The effective date for the agreement will be Jan. 1, 1998.
However, the agreement must first be signed by Chung Chen-hung, representative of Taipei Economic and Trade Office in Tel Aviv before becoming official.

Taiwan officials said the agreement is expected to promote trade and economic relations between the two countries. The 1995 figures showed that Taiwan exported US$288 million worth of goods to Israel, while imports from the Asian country totaled US$110 million during the same period.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAINLAND URGED TO ARRANGE VISIT BY KOO CHEN-FU

TEXT.P: Taiwan on Friday urged mainland China to take action in organizing a visit by Koo Chen-fu, Taiwan's top negotiator with the mainland, to Beijing this autumn.

Taiwan's Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) on Friday wrote a letter to its mainland counterpart, the Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Straits (ARATS), suggesting that SEF Chairman Koo visit the mainland in the fall.
The visit is expected to lead to a resumption of the highest- level cross-strait talks between Koo and ARATS Chairman Wang Daohan.
SEF and ARATS are semi-official intermediary bodies formed to handle civilian exchanges in the absence of official contacts between two sides of the Taiwan Strait.

The letter said a visit by Koo in the fall would comply with a consensus reached in late April between the deputy secretary-generals of the two semi-official bodies that Koo would visit the mainland by the end of the year.

The letter also suggested that to pave the way for Koo's visit, SEF Deputy Secretary-General Jan Jyh-horng visit the mainland in mid-July at the head of a delegation comprised of legal experts, and that SEF Vice Chairman Shi Hwei-yow make a separate visit in mid-August at the head of a delegation made up of SEF board members.

Meanwhile, SEF said it also welcomes ARATS deputy secretary- generals or Vice Chairman Tang Shubei to visit Taiwan. It also urged ARATS to respond to the proposals so SEF could make necessary preparations.

DOC.HEADLINE: ELECTRICITY PRODUCTION INCREASES

TEXT.P: A total of 47.4 million megawatt/hour of electricity was generated in the first four months of this year, the Cabinet-level Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics (DGBAS) reported on Friday.

The figure represents an increase of 7.1 percent over the same period in 1997, the DGBAS said. Thermal power made up 54 percent of the total, while nuclear power accounted for 27 percent. Hydraulic power and co-generation contributed the remaining 20 percent.
Hydraulic generated power posted the largest increase of 27 percent from last year due to abundant rainfall, the DGBAS noted.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN VISITORS TO AUSTRALIA SEEN FALLING SHARPLY

TEXT.P: The number of Taiwan tourists traveling to Australia is expected to drop dramatically in 1998 after the One Nation Party's big showing in recent Queensland state elections, tourist promoters said.

The One Nation Party advocates racist policies and is considered anti-aboriginal, anti-Asian immigration and anti-multiculturalism. Due to the perception that many people in Queensland support the same racist views, visitors from Asia may feel it is unsafe to travel down under, they said.
To make things worse is the new levy of A$50 (US$32) on visitors from various countries including Taiwan. There are 27 countries exempt from the levy, they include the United States and Britain.

The Taiwan Visitors Association (TVA) in Sydney has been flooded with inquiries from Taiwan and Sydney among other major cities since the One Nation Party stunned political observers with its unprecedented victory in the June 13 elections.
The common question is whether it is safe to travel in Australia, especially in Queensland, according to TVA representative Joseph Ru.
"The rise of the One Nation Party and the new visa levy will have a considerable impact on Taiwanese tourists in Australia," he told CNA Friday.
Tourism from Taiwan is expected to fall by 30 percent this year due to the One Nation Party's popularity, travel agents said.
They said Taiwanese tourists are among the biggest spenders in Australia with an average expenditure of almost A$2,000 (US$1,250) per person. Taiwan is a major tourist market for Australia.

"One Nation is definitely affecting tourism from Asia," said Jason Huong, managing director of Victoria Teleworld Travel in Sydney. "(Asian tourists) see there is a race problem in Australia and they are worried about traveling here."
Travel promoters said the Australian government is making the situation worse with its new levy on visitors visas. The levy is aimed at deterring travelers from overstaying their visas.

The Department of Immigration recently released figures showing tourists from mainland China, Britain and the United States and eastern Europe had overstayed their visas for various reasons, but very few tourists from Taiwan overstayed their visas, travel promoters said.
The Australian government said the levy on Taiwanese tourists was due to the fact that the island country is not included in the Electronic Travel Authority (ETA).
The United States, Britain and 25 other countries are members of the ETA. However, the irony is many Americans and British are among those who overstayed their visas in Australia.
"This new visa levy makes Australia a country that does not welcome tourists from Taiwan or has some kind of discrimination (against) Taiwanese tourists," said one promoter, who declined to be named.
In 1997, about 153,000 tourists from Taiwan visited Australia and one of their favorite destinations was Queensland, TVA statistics showed.

In March alone, the total number of foreign tourists to Australia dropped by 13.4 percent from 1997 to 338,557. The number of tourists from Taiwan plunged 31.3 percent to only 10,196 in the same month.
The decline of tourist arrivals has forced Australia to revise its forecast for total visitors in 1998 down eight percent from last year's 4.3 million.
In their efforts to reverse the trend, tourism leaders in Australia are calling on the Australian government to counter the damaging fallout from One Nation.

DOC.HEADLINE: ASIAN FINANCIAL CRISIS DRAGS DOWN HK-TAIWAN TRADE
DOC.DATELINE: Hong Kong, June 20 (CNA) (By Wang Man-nah & Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: The Asian financial crisis has battered the financial markets of Taiwan and Hong Kong, and has also deflated trade between the two areas, a Republic of China official based in the former British colony said on Saturday.

Two-way trade between Taiwan and Hong Kong declined 7.5 percent in the first five months of this year, mainly as a result of the regional financial turmoil which began to bite in the second half of last year, according to Wu Chieh-min, director of the Hong Kong branch office of the Far East Trade Service Inc., which represents the ROC Ministry of Economic Affairs in the absence of official contact between Taiwan and Hong Kong.

Taiwan's exports to Hong Kong amounted to US$10.3 billion in the first five months of the year, down 5.4 percent from the same period of a year ago. In May alone, Hong Kong-bound Taiwan exports totaled US$2.23 billion, down 8.5 percent from the corresponding month of 1997.

In comparison, Wu said, Hong Kong's exports to Taiwan posted increases for both the five-month period and for May alone, US$812 million for the first five months, up 5.8 percent, and US$164 million for May alone, up 8.2 percent.

Wu attributed Taiwan's declining Hong Kong exports to the fall in exports to mainland China. About 80 percent of Taiwan-Hong Kong trade is transit trade between Taiwan and mainland China, since direct Taiwan-mainland China trade is prohibited, he added.

Since the mainland Chinese authorities seem dead set on maintaining the value of the renminbi despite the regional financial meltdown, the mainland's domestic economy has slowed, pushing down commodity demands from Taiwan, Wu noted.

Meanwhile, Wu attributed Hong Kong's increased exports to Taiwan in the January-May period mainly to Taiwan's increasing need for parts and components made by Taiwan-financed factories in mainland China, which are then re-exported to other countries.
Despite the Asian financial morass, Wu said, Hong Kong remains Taiwan's second-largest overseas market and its third-largest trading partner.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN SWIM TEAM CROSSES ITALIAN CHANNEL

TEXT.P: A swim team from the Republic of China on Friday completed a successful crossing of Italy's Circeo Channel.

Team leader Wang Han said the five-member team was elated after reaching land at 8:31 p.m., 12 hours and 56 minutes after starting their swim across the 45-kilometer channel, located about 100 kilometers south of Rome.

Wang said the water temperature was about 20 degrees Celsius, and that the sea was quiet most of the time, making the team optimistic that it might arrive earlier than scheduled. However, the sea became rougher in the final four kilometers, which made the final leg of the trip a challenging three-and-a-half-hour battle for the swimmers.
Wang gave special thanks to the Italian military, port authorities, and several of his friends, for helping the team complete its preparations for the channel crossing.
The team was forced to suspend an earlier attempt on Wednesday after the Italian military decided that the adverse conditions at the time could endanger the safety of the swimmers.

Sources familiar with the Circeo Channel said that the average swimmer would take eight to 12 hours to cross the channel in perfect sea conditions, and expressed admiration that Wang's team was able to complete the crossing in less than 13 hours while swimming against strong seasonal currents.

Wang is the first swimmer from the ROC to have swum the Strait of Gibraltar. Since then, he has also crossed the English Channel, the Bosporus, Hawaii's Maui Channel, Canada's Juan de Fuca Channel, Japan's Tsugaru Channel, Australia's Platypus Channel, New Zealand's Cook Strait, and the San Pedro Channel in the United States, as well as rounding the Cape of Good Hope at Africa's southernmost tip.
His next goal is to take on the Taiwan Strait by 2000.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC LAUNCHES NEW CRACKDOWN ON COMMERCIAL PIRACY

TEXT.P: The Republic of China government launched a new crackdown on commercial piracy on Saturday as part of its efforts to eradicate this type of illegal trade practice from the island.
The Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) said it will cooperate closely with law enforcement authorities in carrying out the massive "Anti-counterfeiting Operation."
"The operation will focus on raiding upper-stream computer software counterfeiting plants and underground factories," an MOEA official said.

The crackdown will last through the end of August, as the summer vacation is usually a boom season for sales of pirated software, the official said, adding: "Hopefully, the operation will let commercial pirates understand there are no vacations in the fight against crime."

The official further said the Ministry of Justice Investigation Bureau (MJIB) has managed to gather detailed information about several software counterfeiting plants. "Our inspectors will work hand-in-hand with MJIB agents, police and prosecution authorities to bring to justice all those involved in commercial piracy."
Meanwhile, the National Police Administration (NPA) said it has directed all police offices around the island to make "probes of commercial piracy" part of their routine weekly spot checks.

The MOEA's anti-counterfeiting task force also said it will assign personnel to visit major computer exporters to gain a better understanding of production and sale of microchips, particularly those for video game use, as well as printed circuit boards with built-in software.
The MOEA inspectors are also expected to remind computer exporters not to counterfeit any brand-name goods or produce any copyrighted items without legal authorization.
In addition, the ministry has decided to ban any local company which has a criminal record of counterfeiting from making investments in mainland China.
