DOC.HEADLINE: INVESTIGATORS TO VISIT FRANCE TO PROBE ALLEGED RAPE

TEXT.P: Investigators will travel to France on Wednesday at the latest to probe an alleged rape carried out by Cheng Chuan, acting director of the Investigation Bureau, the convener of a special investigative task force said on Saturday.

Vice Justice Minister Chiang Hao said that although Taiwan has contacted French authorities regarding the alleged rape, the information gathering has not proceeded as smoothly as expected, as the task force is finding it difficult to collect information from French police and hospital records.

The acting Investigation Bureau chief claims he was only trying to cure the daughter of his former friend Yang Wan-Ching with Chihkung, a traditional Chinese martial art believed to have curative powers during a trip to Paris between Sept. 9 and 13, 1996.

Cheng refuted allegations by Yang's wife that he had touched the girl's breast and private parts under the pretext of administering treatment to her in his Paris hotel room, causing the girl great distress.

Although Cheng has categorically denied any wrongdoing, many questions surrounding the case remain unanswered, prompting the Ministry of Justice to finally decide to send a team to France to collect related information first-hand.
Chiang said the task force will continue to communicate with Yang, who is now a French citizen, despite that fact that he has not shown much intention of working with the task force on the case.

DOC.HEADLINE: MEXICAN `WOLF MAN' TO RECEIVE DIPLOMA FROM LOCAL PRIMARY SCHOOL
DOC.DATELINE: Taichung, central Taiwan, June 20 (CNA) (By Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: Mexico's "wolf man," who has received only three years of formal education, will be awarded an honorary diploma from Taichung's Wen Hsin Primary School next week.

Jesus Manuel Fajardo Aceves, a 24-year-old Mexican man whose face is shrouded in thick, dark hair as a result of a genetic disorder, and who has been called "wolf man" since childhood, will receive the honorary diploma on Tuesday to reward his diligence in academic pursuits and his warm-heartedness toward children, a Wen Hsin spokesperson said on Saturday.
It will be the first time that the central Taiwan primary school has ever bestowed an honorary diploma on an adult.
Fajardo, who arrived in Taiwan in April, is currently on a six-month goodwill visit to Taiwan at the invitation of the Guinness Museum of World Records in Taichung City.
According to the spokesperson, Wen Hsin decided to confer the honorary diploma after children from the school visited the museum and developed a friendship with Fajardo.
Despite his extraordinary appearance, Fajardo said he is virtually a normal man who yearns to make friends with other people.
A victim of hirsutism, a genetically inherited disorder which was passed down by his great grandmother, Fajardo said he was generally shunned by society as a youth.

He became a circus performer shortly after leaving a primary school in Mexico at the age of 13, but his scant income meant he was unable to continue his formal education. "One of my dreams is to receive higher-level education," he said.
Fajardo, who stands 160 cm tall and is very shy, said he is satisfied with his current way of life and has no intention of seeking to change his appearance.

Fajardo got married during his years as a circus performer, but the marriage did not last, and before coming to Taiwan, he had been living with his mother and his five-year-old daughter in a Mexican village. His family now makes a living from farming.

Fajardo said he likes it in Taiwan and is pleased to be part of a goodwill program. This is the first time he has lived alone for such a long time abroad, although he has previously enjoyed brief visits to Japan and Brazil.

DOC.HEADLINE: DEATH TOLL FROM VIRAL OUTBREAK RISES TO 50

TEXT.P: A killer intestinal virus epidemic has claimed the lives of four more children in Taiwan, bringing the official death toll to 50 babies and toddlers in recent months, the Department of Health (DOH) said on Saturday.
One of the new fatalities was reported in Taitung County, DOH officials said, adding it was the first confirmed enterovirus-caused death in the eastern part of the island.
Another two casualties were reported at Chang Gung Memorial Hospital and the remaining case occurred at Mackay Memorial Hospital, both in Taipei, the officials said.
According to DOH tallies, one out of every five children admitted to hospital with the enterovirus infection has died.
With the death toll rising, the DOH urged all city and county governments not to sponsor any large-scale activities for children for the time being to try to prevent the further spread of the virus.

It also demanded that local health offices intensify sterilization measures at all swimming pools in their cities or counties to eradicate the killer virus. Parents have been advised to discourage their children from swimming in public pools.

Meanwhile, China Medical College Hospital in the central city of Taichung reported that two young children who died at the hospital early on Saturday morning were suspected of having been afflicted by the intestinal virus.
"Both of them had shown symptoms of the enterovirus infection and were unconscious when they arrived at the hospital," said Chiu Hsiu-hui, a pediatrician at the hospital.
If these two deaths are confirmed to have been caused by the virus, the epidemic will have claimed the lives of 12 children in the Taichung area.
"Five young enterovirus patients are still in our hospital's intensive care wards, one of whom is in critical condition," Chiu added.

As enterovirus-related cases are still emerging here and there, Chiu said, the epidemic apparently is not yet over. He warned: "Parents must remain on high alert to protect their children from being attacked by the killer virus."

A pathological autopsy on an eight-year-old girl has confirmed that enterovirus type-71 was the culprit of her death. Autopsies on four other children suspected to have died of similar infections have also been completed, but it remains unclear whether their deaths were also caused by the same type of virus.

Infants and young children are most susceptible to enterovirus. Early symptoms of the infection resemble the fle, with fever, headache and vomiting. Ulcers or blisters in the mouth and a rash on the palms and feet can also develop. Later, possible deadly complications include encephalitis, meningitis and acute inflammation of the heart muscle.
Parents are advised to keep their kids away from public places, and make sure that their children change clothes and wash hands frequently.

DOC.HEADLINE: BEIJING TO USE TAIWAN ISSUE AS BARGAINING CHIP WITH US: ROC OFFICIAL

TEXT.P: Mainland China will use the Taiwan issue as a bargaining chip at the upcoming summit between mainland Chinese President Jiang Zemin and US President Bill Clinton, a high-ranking ROC official said on Saturday.
Vice Secretary-General of the President's Office Su Chi made the remarks while he was attending a seminar sponsored by the Cabinet-level Mainland Affairs Council (MAC).

He said that Beijing will certainly put the Taiwan issue on the agenda during the Clinton-Jiang talks, because Beijing has always believed that this is one of its "aces" in its engagement with the US.

Su said that mainland China has always stressed that the Taiwan issue is the most sensitive problem and the crux issue relating to improved relations with the US, and that it is sure to use it as a bargaining chip.

But he stressed that there is no need to worry too much, saying that the US side does not consider Taiwan to be the most important issue. It is Beijing who wants to raise the issue as a bargaining chip, because it really doesn't have much else up its sleeve.
Su said that while the US can raise the Tibet, human rights, and trade issues, Beijing will have only the Taiwan issue to raise.

Furthermore, he said, the US has repeatedly vowed not to damage the safety and interests of Taiwan during the talks. Taiwan will just have to wait until after the meeting to see what develops, Su added.

He reiterated the ROC's basic stance that it will not oppose any engagement between the US and mainland China as long as the engagement helps regional stability and peace, helps upgrade Taiwan's relations with the US, and improves its relations with the mainland.

DOC.HEADLINE: SOUTH AFRICAN OFFICIALS TO ATTEND WORLD BANK FORUM MEETING

TEXT.P: South African Deputy President Thabo Mbeki, accompanied by Deputy Foreign Minister Aziz Pahad, will visit Senegal to attend a World Bank Forum meeting on Sunday, his office said on Friday.
Heads of state of several other African countries are also scheduled to attend, Mbeki's aide said.
Topics to be discussed include globalization and integration, development, and the management of natural resources.

DOC.HEADLINE: US POW ALLIANCE OFFERS REWARD FOR MISSING SERVICEMEN IN CHINA

TEXT.P: The American National Alliance of Families - POW/MIA on Friday offered a US$2.4 million reward for the return of any living US serviceman on the official US list of prisoners of war and missing in action transferred to mainland China after the Korean War, Cold War, or the Vietnam War.

The alliance appealed to the Beijing government for assistance in returning their loved ones, adding that members of public who can provide photos or other information related to the missing US servicemen will also be rewarded.

According to a statement, the alliance decided to join forces with the American Defense Institute in offering the reward because "our plea to President Bill Clinton to ask for our live POWs and information on the missing has fallen on deaf ears. The priorities of big business, once again, prevail over morality."
There have been reports over the past decades of American POWs being seen in many cities and provinces of mainland China, the alliance noted, adding: "China knows what happened to them."

DOC.HEADLINE: SINGAPORE'S APRIL RETAIL SALES UP BY 14 PERCENT

TEXT.P: Singapore's retail sales in April rose by 14 percent over March, according to figures released by the Singapore Department of Statistics on Friday.
Total retail sales value in April 1998 were estimated at S$1,807 million (about US$1,095 million), compared with S$1,586 million in the previous month.
The department pointed out that the rise in April's retail sales was attributed to an increase of 158.1 percent in the turnover of motor vehicles.
All other retail activities, however, encountered negative growth, it said.

DOC.HEADLINE: BEIJING ACCUSED OF BUILING PAKISTAN'S NUCLEAR PROGRAM

TEXT.P: A leading US think tank has accused Beijing of almost single-handedly building Pakistan's nuclear program -- from the blueprint for the bomb to the missiles to launch the bomb.

"The Economic Times," a New Delhi-based English-language newspaper, reported from Washington that the Heritage Foundation said: "China's role in helping Pakistan to acquire nuclear weapons has raised serious concerns about China's part in fostering instability in South Asia."

The foundation said that since the 1970s, mainland China has been instrumental in Pakistan's nuclear and missile programs and has provided Islamabad with "highly enriched uranium, ring magnets necessary for processing the uranium, and education for nuclear engineers."

In 1990 and 1992, according to the foundation, mainland China provided Pakistan with "nuclear-capable M-11 missiles" that could strike targets within a 360-mile range . It also said that "China's deep involvement with Pakistan's nuclear program contributed to the Indian government's decision to test nuclear weapons last month."

DOC.HEADLINE: WORLD HERITAGE'S HELP SOUGHT IN STOPPING URANIUM MINING

TEXT.P: Environmentalists and Aboriginal people in Australia are seeking support from the World Heritage Bureau in Paris to help them stop uranium mining near the Kakadu National Park, a listed heritage site, in Australia's Northern Territory.

Despite launching a series of demonstrations and after two months of blocking access to portions of Kakadu National Park, the demonstrators have failed to prevent Energy Resources Australia from mining uranium.
The group of demonstrators has left for Paris, where they will appeal to the World Heritage Bureau to have Kakadu listed as an endangered park.

ERA, Australia's biggest uranium miner, received a license to mine the site from the federal government in Canberra. ERA has been mining uranium near the world-heritage listed area for about 18 months.
Australia is one of the world's leading uranium producers and exporters after the United States and South Africa.

DOC.HEADLINE: FALLING CURRENCY, FINANCIAL CRISIS AFFECT OLYMPIC GAMES

TEXT.P: Asia's financial crisis and a depreciating Australian dollar are threatening the 2000 Olympic Games in Sydney.
The games' budget, originally A$2.3 billion (US$1.44 billion), has ballooned to an estimated A$6 billion (US$3.75 billion).
Contributions from sponsors to the Sydney Organising Committee for Olympic Games, however, are still nearly A$200 million (US$125 million) short of the group's target.
Olympic organizers intended to finalize a revised budget by month's end, but SOCOG chief executive Sandy Hollway said a final budget may be weeks or months away.
New South Wales Olympics Minister M. Knight said the NSW government may be forced to raise the ticket prices for the opening and closing ceremony.

DOC.HEADLINE: SINGAPORE MAY SEE NEGATIVE GROWTH BY 3RD QUARTER

TEXT.P: Singapore's economic growth is grinding to a halt and will likely enter negative territory by this year's third quarter, the Hong Kong-based Political and Economic Risk Consultancy (PERC) said in a report released Friday.
Calling the government's 2.5 percent to 4.5 percent growth forecast for this year "too optimistic," the report quoted some analysts as saying the economy might actually contract.

PERC puts Singapore's economic growth rate at 1.5 percent for this year and 3 percent next year. Economic contractions in Malaysia and Indonesia support such scaled-back growth estimates, according to the report.
The report's findings come just three days after the Singapore government said it would revise downward its growth forecast for this year. The new forecast is expected later this month.

Singapore's economy grew 5.6 percent in this year's first quarter. Speaking in Parliament earlier this month, Finance Minister Hu Tsu Tau said that the government would initiate special measures if preliminary second-quarter figures point to a "significant economic slowdown."
Among the danger signs highlighted in the PERC report were faltering non-oil domestic exports, falling domestic demand, rising interest rates, depressed company profits and increased unemployment.

The report suggests retrenchments by government-linked companies and financial institutions may be enacted in the coming months. An overly optimistic outlook and trade union resistance have delayed the measures' implementation, but with several countries in the region expecting negative growth, the retrenchments are almost inevitable, the report said.

DOC.HEADLINE: BALLADARES REASSURES TAIWAN PANAMA-ROC TIES ARE SOLID
DOC.DATELINE: Panama City, June 19 (CNA) (By Eduardo Chen & Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: Panamanian President Perez Balladares said on Friday that relations between Panama and the Republic of China are cordial and will be long lasting.
Balladares met with a group of ROC legislators at the Presidential Office and reassured them that Panama is satisfied with existing bilateral relations with Taiwan.

He admitted that Panama encountered great pressure from Beijing last year when Panama City hosted the World Congress of Panama Canal. "Despite the pressure, the meeting was convened and we had the guests we wanted to have," Balladares said.

Balladares said Panama and Taiwan maintain very close economic ties. Citing the Fort Davis Export Processing Zone as an example, he said his government's policy of strengthening economic cooperation with Taiwan has been fruitful and proved correct. "I don't see any reason for Panama to alter existing relations with Taiwan, now or in the future," he said.

Parris Chang, a legislator representing Taiwan's opposition Democratic Progressive Party, lauded Balladares' wisdom and courage in supporting Taiwan. He suggested that Panama and Taiwan further bolster bilateral relations by forging more accords on economic and trade cooperation, such as the signing of a free trade zone agreement.
The ROC legislators' group, led by Lin Che-fu (Kuomintang), arrived in Panama City on Thursday for a three-day visit.
Lin and his colleagues met with their Panamanian counterparts on Friday for the second meeting of the ROC-Panama Parliamentary Bilateral Committee, jointly established by the two countries in 1997.
During the meeting, lawmakers from the two countries vowed to further strengthen bilateral exchanges and cooperation, such as joint efforts to crack down on drug trafficking and related crimes.
They also decided that the third bilateral parliamentary meeting will be held in Taipei in 1999.

DOC.HEADLINE: ACER & MICROSOFT TO DEVELOP X COMPUTERS

TEXT.P: Two computer industry heavyweights, Microsoft and Acer, have announced plans to jointly develop "XC" computers, user-friendly machines designed to perform fewer functions than today's personal computers.

In addition to announcing the establishment of a new Microsoft technology development center in Taiwan, Microsoft Chairman Bill Gates announced the deal with Acer Group, one of the world's largest computer manufacturers during a whirlwind visit to Taiwan Friday.
"Consensus on cooperation on the XC plan has been reached," said Acer executive Lin Chien-ming.
Gates met with 19 Taiwan-based information technology companies, including Acer, during his visit.

The XC, or X computer, concept, was introduced by Acer Chairman and CEO Stan Shih during the 1997 Asia-Pacific Information Technology Summit last November. He described the XC as an easy-to-use, single-function computer that will be built according to specific demands.

XCs will be designed for people who require simple, small-sized, and inexpensive computers to run specific programs, such as games or educational or financial management software. Acer predicts global demand for XCs will be 10 times current demand for PCs.
The forthcoming XCs, which will rely on Windows CE operating system, are expected to be introduced in the second quarter of next year, Lin said.
Microsoft's Taiwan technology development center will specialize in the development and promotion of the CE operating system, designed for hand-held computers and consumer electronics equipment.
Gates said in a speech Friday at the Taipei International Convention Center that Taiwan is well-positioned to develop market-friendly consuming electronics.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN TIGHTENS ANTI-PIRACY CONTROLS

TEXT.P: Local companies that have been charged with violating copyright laws must first undergo an official investigation before they can invest in mainland China, the Ministry of Economic Affairs announced Friday.
Economics Minister Wang Chih-kang initiated the measure, aimed at preventing local manufacturers of pirated products from relocating their operations to the Chinese mainland.
The practice hurts Taiwan's economic development and its profile in the international community, MOEA officials said.
Shortly after the announcement, an anti-copyright violation task force of the MOEA, accompanied by police and investigators from the Ministry of Justice, launched a nationwide crackdown on piracy.

Law-enforcement personnel on Friday raided four underground factories producing various CDs and pornographic videotapes. More than 8,000 pirated products were seized and seven people arrested during the raids, police said.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN, HK ACTIVISTS TO SET SAIL FOR DISPUTED ISLAND

TEXT.P: Activists from Taiwan, Hong Kong and the United States will set sail for the disputed Tiaoyutai islands in the East China Sea next Wednesday in a further attempt to claim them as Chinese territory, a spokesman said on Saturday.

"This will be the first time that Taiwan and Hong Kong activists launch a joint campaign since Hong Kong reverted to mainland Chinese rule last July," said Chin Chieh-shou, head of the Taiwan Task Force for Defending the Tiaoyutai Islands.
Chin, also a Taipei County councilor from the right-wing opposition New Party, said a 30-member Hong Kong delegation, aboard the 100-ton vessel Diao Yu Tai, will leave Hong Kong late Sunday.

The boat is scheduled to arrive at waters near the northern Taiwan port of Keelung on June 24 to join vessels operated by activists from Taiwan and Chinese communities in the United States, Chin said.

The ships will then set sail for the disputed islands, known as the Tiaoyutais in Taiwan, the Diaoyus in mainland China and the Senkakus in Japan. The uninhabited island group is claimed by Taiwan, mainland China and Japan.

Chin said group members plan to arm themselves with crossbows and will dive from their boat into the water before trying to land on the island to evade any Japanese patrol boats that may attempt to block their path.
Noting that crossbows are considered sporting goods, not firearms, Chin said their action will not violate Taiwan's anti-firearms law.
"Hopefully, we'll land on the Tiaoyutais and tear down a wooden Japanese flag installed on one of the islands," Chin said.
In October 1996, Chin and other Taiwan and Hong Kong activists made a brief landing on one of the disputed islands and planted two flags, one each from the Republic of China and mainland China.
Japanese coast guards, however, forced the activists away from the islet and removed the flags.
Last year, a group of Taiwan and Hong Kong activists, also led by Chin, was prevented from approaching the islands by a large number of Japanese coast guard patrol ships and military helicopters.

The annual landing attempts by Taiwan and Hong Kong activists began after the ultra-rightist Japanese Youth Federation erected a makeshift lighthouse on one of the islands in July 1996 and Japan later included the Tiaoyutais in its 200-mile exclusive economic zone.

The event will also mark the death of David Chan, a Hong Kong activist who drowned after jumping into the sea when Japanese coast guard vessels blocked his ship near the archipelago in September 1996.

DOC.HEADLINE: SINGAPORE'S TRADE FALLS 6.1 PERCENT IN MAY

TEXT.P: Singapore's trade for the month of May totaled S$27.31 billion (US$16.55 billion), a 6.1 percent decline from year-earlier levels, the Singapore Trade Development Board said Saturday.
The country exported more than S$14.3 billion in goods, while it imported nearly S$13 billion.

Exports increased a marginal 0.1 percent in May on a three-month moving average basis, with non-oil domestic exports and non-oil re-exports increasing 1.1 percent and 3 percent, respectively, according to TDB statistics.
Domestic oil exports, however, fell 16.4 percent during the same period.
Non-oil domestic exports, meanwhile, dropped 4.8 percent in May after a 1.7 percent decline in April.
The weak performance reflects the continued oversupply of key electronic products in the global market, as well as the regional economic crisis which has affected Singapore's exports, the TDB said.

Disk drive exports dropped 8.2 percent in May, while integrated circuit and assembled printed circuit board exports fell 6.6 percent and 8.9 percent, respectively, the two products' first declines in about a year.

Non-oil imports, a short-term leading indicator of the manufacturing sector, shrunk by 18.1 percent in May, following a decline of 11.1 percent in April, which suggests moderate export growth in the months ahead, the TDB said.

DOC.HEADLINE: RAMOS RECEIVES FELIX HOUPHOUET-BOIGNY PEACE PRIZE

TEXT.P: Philippine President Fidel V. Ramos said on Saturday that his acceptance of the 1997 Felix Houphouet-Boigny Peace Prize, along with Governor Nur Misuari of the Autonomous Region in Muslim Mindanao, was international recognition of Philippine efforts to achieve peace in Mindanao.

"Such International recognition of our collective efforts to build a just and lasting peace coupled with a focused development agenda in Minadanao, is of high significance to those whose countries still suffer from bloody strife," Ramos said.

He said Director-General Federico Mayor of the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization and other African heads of state who attended the award ceremonies, all agreed that the Philippine experience could be used as a model for countries troubled by violent internal or regional conflict.

DOC.HEADLINE: NO NEW INITIATIVES ON TAIWAN IN CLINTON-JIANG SUMMIT: ROTH
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, June 19 (CNA) (By Jay Chen and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: A senior US official reassured Taiwan on Friday that no new initiatives vis-a-vis Taiwan will come up during President Bill Clinton's upcoming visit to mainland China.
Stanley Roth, assistant secretary of state for East Asian and Pacific affairs, made the remarks while briefing foreign correspondents stationed here on Clinton's June 25-July 3 mainalnd visit.

Asked whether Taiwan-related issues will be discussed during the trip, Roth said: "Well, of course Taiwan will come up. It always comes up in every meeting at any senior level with the Chinese. But the question is, I think, from our perspective simply a reiteration of policy. We do not expect any new initiatives vis-a-vis Taiwan."

As for Taiwan's worry that there will be a fourth communique or a fourth joint statement concerning its future to be issued after a summit meeting in Bejing between Clinton and mainland Chinese President Jiang Zemin, Roth said there will not be a fourth communique at this summit.

Asked if Clinton will take advantage of the upcoming trip to urge Beijing to renounce the use of force against Taiwan, Roth said it's pretty clear that the United States, at every opportunity, has impressed upon Beijing the need for a peaceful resolution of the Taiwan issue.

"This is a key element of US policy and one on which Beijing can have absolutely no doubt. I think the United States demonstrated, in march of 1996, just how clear it was on its determination to see that this issue only be resolved peacefully by the actions it took in response to some destabilizing Chinese missile tests. So the answer is, of course the United States makes its position clear about a peaceful resolution," Roth explained.

Asked whether the "six guarantees" the US gave to Taiwan following the signing of the 1982 Washington-Beijing joint communique remain valid, Roth said he has tried his best to make it clear that the US policy toward Taiwan will not be changed because of Clinton's upcoming mainland visit.

The "six guarantees" include that the US will continue to furnish Taiwan with defensive arms, and will not consult with Beijing prior to its arms sales to Taipei. The US has also promised not to mediate cross-strait disputes and not to force Taiwan to negotiate with Beijing.
Roth further denied that the US will pressure Taiwan to the negotiating table with mainland China.
Noting that the security of Taiwan ultimately depends on its relations with mainland China, Roth said cross-strait disputes are not an issue that's going to be resolved militarily.
"It's going to have to be resolved, I think, by virture of the relationship between both sides of the strait," Roth said.
He went on to say that the US has consistently encouraged the two sides of the Taiwan Strait to embark on peaceful dialogue. And this move should not be interpreted as pressure to Taiwan, Roth added.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN RESEARCHER TALKS ABOUT CLINTON-JIANG SUMMIT

TEXT.P: A leading Taiwan researcher said here Saturday that Taiwan should be cautious, but not overly worried, about President Bill Clinton's upcoming summit meeting with President Jiang Zemin in Beijing.

Shaw Yu-ming, director of the Institute of International Relations of the National Chengchih University in Taipei, made the remarks at a seminar cosponsored by the Mainland Affairs Council of the Executive Yuan and a private organization on the current cross-strait and international political and economic situations.
He said that such a meeting may be held each year in the future as the two countries try to improve long-term relations, and that such meetings will not necessarily be harmful to Taiwan.
Shaw pointed out that officials of the Clinton administration have testified in Congressional hearings that the US will not improve its relations with mainland China at the expense of Taiwan.

He also said that Washington, while trying to expand engagement with Beijing, hopes to change communist China into a democratic country. Taiwan's achievement in democratization serves as a "trump card" in the hand of Washington to achieve that goal, he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: MEETING BETWEEN TAIPEI, BEIJING LEADER COULD BE PROPOSED

TEXT.P: Su Chi, deputy secretary general of the Presidential Office, said Saturday that President Lee Teng-hui would be glad to meet mainland Chinese President Jiang Zemin in Beijing.

He said that Chairman Koo Cheng-fu of the Strait Exchange Foundation (SEF) and his mainland Chinese counterpart Wang Daohan, head of the Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait (ARATS), are likely to talk about the possibility of a meeting between Lee and Jiang in Beijing, if Koo and Wang meet in autumn as proposed by the SEF.
The SEF and ARATS were established in Taipei and Beijing respectively in 1991 to handle the civilian exchanges between Taiwan and mainland China in the absence of official ties.

Anticipating that Beijing will actively push for dialogues with Taipei on the matter of unification after the summit meeting between Jiang and President Bill Clinton next week, the SEF recently requested the ARATS to make arrangement for Koo to visit Wang in autumn in mainland China.
Su pointed out that President Lee has said many times that he would like to make "a journey of Peace" to Beijing in his official capacity, and that Lee was "very sincere" when he said so.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN INVESTMENT TO MALAYSIA JUMPS 140 PERCENT
DOC.DATELINE: Kuching, Malaysia, June 21 (CNA) (By C. L. Chi & Lin Wen-fen)

TEXT.P: Despite the Asian financial turmoil, Taiwan's investments to Malaysia jumped by 140 percent in the first four months of the year compared to the same period in 1997, Taiwan economic officials said here Sunday.

Officials quoting statistics complied from the Malaysian Industrial Development Bureau said Taiwan is the third-largest foreign investor in Malaysia with its investments amounting to US$148.50 million during the four-month period, behind only the United States and Japan.

The United States invested a total of US$669.3 million in Malaysia between January and April, while investment made by Japan reached US$348.10 million. Other top investors included Singapore, Switzerland, Germany, Britain and South Korea.
Taiwan officials said investment from Taiwan focused on the textile and chemical industries, which account for 35 percent and 32 percent of the total investments, respectively.

From 1987 to the present, Taiwan took part in 1,540 investment projects in the Southeast Asian country with a combined value of US$8.46 billion. The investment figure in 1997 represented an increase of 54.82 percent from 1996.
Currently there are about 1,540 firms or factories in Malaysia are operated by Taiwan businessmen.

As most of Taiwan businessmen are engaged in export-oriented business, the depreciation of the Malay ringgit has helped improve their competitiveness. However, businessmen who are focused on the local market for income have suffered substantial losses.
In the face of the ongoing financial turmoil, Taiwan businessmen have sought Taiwan's help with loans as Malaysia's tight monetary policy has forced the increase of lending rates to 15 percent.

Responding to such requests, Taiwan's central bank has announced that it will offer US$20 million in deposits to overseas branches of Taiwan-based banking corporations to offer as loans to Taiwan businessmen.

ROC Minister of Economic Affairs Wang Chih-kang is currently in Kuching to attend an Asian Pacific Economic Cooperation (APEC) ministerial meeting. At the end of the meeting on June 24, Wang will visit Kuala Lumpur to meet with Taiwan businessmen to gain a better understanding of their operation and to learn their opinions on what assistance Taiwan might offer.

DOC.HEADLINE: THREE LINKS CAUSE FOR WORRY AMONG TAIWAN PEOPLE: SURVEY

TEXT.P: Nearly 70 percent of Taiwan citizens recently polled are in favor of establishing the three direct links with mainland China, but 50 percent express concerned it would pose a threat to national security.
Taipei currently bans direct postal, trade and transportation links with the mainland.
Up to 80 percent of respondents said they favored direct postal links across the Taiwan Strait, the survey released Sunday by the Rising People Foundation showed.

Only 55 percent said they supported the establishment of direct trade relations with mainland China, while 63 percent and 66 percent, respectively, are in favor of setting up sea and air links with the mainland.

Respondents generally felt direct transportation links would pose the biggest threat to Taiwan's security as 52 percent and 51 percent, respectively, said establishing direct aviation and marine links with mainland China would seriously affect Taiwan's security.
The poll also found that party affiliation has little influence in people's stance regarding the three links.

As many as 86 percent of the pro-independence Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) supporters advocated establishing direct telephone links, while only 76 percent of Kuomintang supporters agreed with this suggestion, the survey results indicated.
On the issue of cross-strait financial exchanges, 62 percent of DPP supports voiced agreement for the proposal, higher than 56 percent of KMT backers who had the same opinion.
At the same time, supporters of the pro-unification New Party posted the greatest backing for the three links, with nearly 80 percent of voicing support for such ties, the survey showed.
The survey was conducted between June 5-8, and 1,090 Taiwan residents aged over 20 were questioned.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN INVESTMENT IN MAINLAND CHINA DOWN

TEXT.P: Amid the Asian financial crisis and Beijing's reluctance to depreciate the renminbi, Taiwan investment in mainland China has declined since the beginning of this year, the Economic Daily News reported Sunday.

Citing statistics made public by the Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA), the report said a total of US$83.2 million worth of 65 Taiwan investment projects in mainland China were approved by the ministry in May, down US$37.4 million from April.

Investment scale has also shrunk as average figures for individual investments was around US$2 million in the January-May period, noticeably down from US$2.21 million and US$3.21 million registered in the same period in 1997 and 1996, respectively, the report said.

Although mainland authorities have taken measures to attract foreign investment and stimulate local demand, Taiwan investors operating in the mainland said business conditions remained sluggish there.
They said they would adopt a wait-and-see attitude at present but expect demand in both foreign and domestic markets to rebound to previous levels.

DOC.HEADLINE: CALIFORNIAN UNIVERSITY TO OFFER COURSE IN CHINESE MEDICINE
DOC.DATELINE: Los Angeles, June 20 (CNA) (By J. S. Chu & Lin Wen-fen)

TEXT.P: As traditional Chinese medical treatment gains greater acceptance among the medical profession in the United States, a university in California will offer a course in such treatment.

The medical college of University of California, Irvine will offer an introductory course in traditional Chinese medicine this coming quarter. It will provide students with basic theories behind the practice of Chinese medical treatment.

According to a survey conducted by a professor at the school, people in Southern California, home to an increasing number of Asian and Chinese residents, will often turn to Chinese herbal doctors after failing to find satisfactory results with western treatments.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI YOUTHS EXPERIENCING DECAY IN PHYSICAL STRENGTH

TEXT.P: The level of physical fitness among young Taipei City residents is similar to that of middle-aged residents, a recent health survey showed.

A health examination campaign, conducted by the Republic of China Health Promotion Association at the request of the Kuomintang Central Youth Activities Department, was held in Taipei City's 10 administration areas from March to May this year.

More than 3,700 people underwent physical check-ups. At least 50 percent of residents in the 19-to-45 age group were found to suffer from a narrowing of blood vessels and early symptoms of damage caused by smoking.

Even worse, the level of health among these youths was not much different from that of middle-aged residents, said Liu Chi-fung, chairman of the association. The city is facing a serious problem with the physiological decay of its young generation, he added.
Liu criticized the government's legislation prohibiting smoking in public places as nothing more than posters on walls.
He also reminded Taipei residents to pay special attention to high blood pressure which is being blamed for a higher incidence of apoplexy among increasingly younger people.
For a healthier life, people should exercise more, as well as eat and drink moderately, the association said.

DOC.HEADLINE: AI OFFICIAL REAFFIRMS TAIWAN EFFORTS IN HUMAN RIGHTS PROTECTION

TEXT.P: Taiwan has made great progress in its democratic reforms and has been very active in providing its people with human rights protection, a visiting official from Amnesty International (AI) said Sunday.

Rory Mungoven, an official in charge of AI's Asian Pacific affairs, made the remarks in an interview with CNA. He is on his first trip to Taiwan to attend a seminar on Eastern Asian Culture and Human Rights, sponsored by Fujen University.

When asked if the Republic of China could be described as the nation that most values human rights in Asia, Mungoven said Taiwan's efforts in pushing for human rights protection have been widely recognized, but he could not say which country was better than another with regards to human rights.
While saying democratic political systems and human rights protection are highly related, Mungoven stressed that this is not always strictly the case.

However, it is only through a democratic system that laws and constitution to protect human rights can be built on a solid legal basis, he said. The verbal guarantees to human rights protection are not enough, he noted.

Mungoven said this is the reason why it is difficult to find sufficient human rights protection in a communist country like mainland China. He pointed out that although people in the mainland are eager to embrace a democratic system, the Beijing authorities turn a deaf ear to people's voices.

As to how Beijing could improve its human rights record, Mungoven said the mainland authorities should abolish communism and practice democracy, allow international human rights organizations to monitor the situation there and sign human rights protection agreements with international organizations such as the UN and AI.

DOC.HEADLINE: NATIONAL ASSEMBLYMEN CONCERNED ABOUT CLINTON-JIANG TALKS

TEXT.P: A group of National Assembly deputies have expressed concern over the upcoming meeting between US President Bill Clinton and mainland Chinese President Jiang Zemin.
Tsai Chih-hung, secretary-general of the group which is comprised of Kuomintang National Assembly deputies, said on Sunday they hope the United States will continue selling arms to Taiwan.

They have also expressed the hope that Clinton and Jiang do not discuss the so-call "three no's" nor should they produce any written statement on the matter, he said. The three no's refer to no Taiwan independence, no "two-Chinas" or "one China, one Taiwan" and no United Nations membership for Taiwan.

Tsai led the 19-member mission to the United State from May 18 to 20. They toured the US Senate and House of Representatives and met with congressmen such as Rep. Gerald Solomon and Sen. Daniel Akaka. They were also interviewed by the Voice of America and the Sing Tao Daily.

According to Tsai, Rep. Solomon told the mission that both Clinton and Secretary of State Madeleine Albright had assured him the US would not compromise the interests of Taiwan in exchange for improved relations with mainland China.
The mission visited Canada on May 22 to 23 to exchange views with Canadian congressmen before returning to Taipei.

DOC.HEADLINE: 'GO WEST' INVESTMENT POLICY DEBATED IN SEMINAR

TEXT.P: A seminar sponsored by the Rising People Foundation to discuss the impact of the coming summit between US President Bill Clinton and mainland Chinese President Jiang Zemin turned into a debate over the "go west" investment policy Sunday.

Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) Chairman Hsu Hsing-liang voiced strong support for Taiwan investment in mainland China , while Y.M. Shaw, an international relations expert, urged caution on the issue.
Hsu, who will step down from the party's top post in July, said Taiwan should set up the three currently banned direct links with mainland China.

Taiwan, which has a more advanced economy than mainland China, should not forswear the vast mainland Chinese market, Hsu said, calling the government's "no haste, be patient" policy regulating Taiwan investment in the mainland a "big mistake."
He said Taiwan's economy would progress even further and claimed that establishing the three links would benefit Taiwan.
Shaw, director of the Institute of International Relations (IIR) under the National Chengchi University, called for a more reserved mainland investment policy.
Shaw said Taiwan must take its security into account before deciding to establish the direct postal, trade, and transportation links with the mainland.
He said a "bold go west" investment policy would only hurt Taiwan, as it is far from its goal of becoming a high-tech island.

Describing the relations between mainland China and Taiwan as that of a "sugar and ant," the IIR director said Taiwan investors must be very careful not to be swallowed up by the vast mainland market.
S.C. Hsu, an associate professor of mainland China affairs at the Chinese Culture University, also is supportive of establishing the three direct links across the Taiwan Strait.

Amid an international globalization trend, Hsu said Taiwan should seek to create "multilateral links," more than the just "three links," with the mainland. He said only such creative moves will help Taiwan gain an advantage in its globalization efforts.

DOC.HEADLINE: PROFESSOR GROUP ISSUES STATEMENT ON "SOVEREIGNTY OF TAIWAN"

TEXT.P: The Association of Taiwan Professors, a private organization known for its advocacy of Taiwan independence, issued a statement Sunday, saying that the future of Taiwan shall be decided by its people, not by international powers.
The statement, issued a few days before President Bill Clinton's visit to Beijing, also urged the government to hold a referendum on the future of Taiwan.
The statement said members of the association "deeply believe that the people of Taiwan are entitled to self-determination, and that the future of Taiwan shall be decided by the people of Taiwan,"
They said the people of Taiwan are worried that President Clinton's summit talks with President Jiang Zemin next week in Beijing may seriously affect the security and future of Taiwan.

"Taiwan's future shall be determined by its 21.8 million people, no international powers are allowed to do it for them," it said, adding that "We seriously ask the central government of Taiwan to hold a referendum on the future of Taiwan on December 5 to coincide with the elections of legislators."

The statement was endorsed by at least seven mayors and county magistrates, 22 legislators, 26 national assemblymen, and one member of Taipei City Council. It was also endorsed by at least 15 private organizations, including the Alliance for Taiwan Independence, the Voice of the Country of Taiwan, and the Association for Promotion of Referendum. Many of the endorsers are members of the major opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP).

Meanwhile, Legislator Trong R. Chai of DPP Sunday called for an early enactment of a law governing referendum in Taiwan, so that a referendum on the future of Taiwan may be held on December 5, as proposed in the statement. Chai has been the founding president of the Alliance for Taiwan Independence, the Formosan Association for Public Affairs (FAPA), the Association for Promotion of Referendum, and some other pro-independence organizations.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAINLAND CHINESE TV REPORTER MA XIAOMING ARRESTED IN XIAN

TEXT.P: Ma Xiaoming, a reporter of the Shaanxi TV Station, was taken away by public security authorities Saturday from his home in Xian, capital of Shaanxi Province in north China.

A news release from the Hong Kong-based Information Center of Human Rights and Democratic Movement in China said it is certain that Ma has been arrested by public security authorities, but his whereabouts is unknown.
Ma, 47, and eight other dissidents jointly sent a letter to the National People's Congress of mainland China in March, calling for an early release of former premier Zhao Ziyang from home arrest.
The TV reporter was suspended sometime ago from his job for one year for reporting pro-democracy events in Shaanxi, according to the news release.

DOC.HEADLINE: ECONOMIC SLOWDOWN TESTS SINGAPORE'S STRENGTH: GOH

TEXT.P: The regional crisis and Singapore's economic slowdown will test the people's social strength, fighting spirit and unity, Singapore Prime Minister Goh Chok Tong said Saturday.
To face the challenge, the emotional bond among Singaporeans must be strengthened, he said.
By building on the strong ties and togetherness developed over the past 32 years, he said, "we will evolve a sturdy Singapore spirit that binds us all through both good and bad times."
As for the economy, Goh said it was too early to say whether or not Singapore will slip into a recession this year. He urged Singaporeans to be prepared for slower growth this year and next.

"We have no choice but to adapt to the changed environment. Let us accept the reality and make the necessary adjustments ... However strong our fundamentals, we cannot escape injury when we are in the path of the typhoon," he said.

While bracing for the storm, Singapore must also look ahead and prepare for the future, said Goh. The government, for its part, will increase investments in education and worker training. Manufacturing and financial industries, as well as the port and airport would also be strengthened, he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: COUNTRIES MUST PROMOTE FREE TRADE: WTO

TEXT.P: Efforts to promote free trade will continue despite environmental and labor problems, Renato Ruggiero, Director General of the Geneva-based World Trade Organization (WTO), said Saturday.
However, the WTO chief insisted that countries must cooperate more to reconcile free trade with those concerns.
"We must stop viewing the world through a narrow lens and begin to look at the various challenges we face as pieces of a larger puzzle demanding broader, more integrated solution," Rugierro said.
Despite protests that the free trade system contributes to poverty, unemployment and environmental problems, ministers last month told the WTO to prepare for talks to further open the world economy.
US President Bill Clinton and others pledged to try to make the organization and the global trade system more sensitive to environmental and labor concerns.
Ruggiero said the best way to address the worries is through the system itself.

"If people, especially young people, say unemployment is too high, they are right. If environmentalists say growth must be sustainable -- and not destroy the planet's essential equilibrium -- they are right.

"But none of these international -- and national -- problems will be resolved any easier by restricting trade, closing borders, or undermining the international rule of law as embodied in the WTO," Ruggiero said.

DOC.HEADLINE: ASIAN CRISIS SENDS US TRADE DEFICIT SOARING

TEXT.P: Asia's mounting economic troubles took another big bite out of US exports to that region in April, sending the US foreign trade deficit soaring to a record level, the Los Angeles Times reported Friday.

Commerce Department figures showed that the United States imported US$14.5 billion more than it exported over the month, up from a revised US$13.2 billion deficit in March. The increase was blamed largely on the hard-hit Asian economies which bought fewer US exports.

The figures are further evidence that the Asian financial crisis and its aftermath are likely to have a larger-than-predicted effect on the US economy, slowing growth from the robust pace of the past several months.

The April figures were compiled well before US President Bill Clinton's initiative this week to help stem the slide of the Japanese yen in the foreign exchange markets. The yen's decline against the dollar aggravates the trade imbalance by making US exports to Japan more expensive and imports from there cheaper.

DOC.HEADLINE: SEF CHAIRMAN COULD BLAZE MAINLAND TRAIL FOR PRESIDENT LEE: MAC

TEXT.P: The Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) said Monday that it will evaluate prospects for a visit to mainland China by ROC President Lee Teng-hui as it arranges for a trip for Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) Chairman Koo Chen-fu, to be made this fall.
President Lee first revealed in his 1996 inaugural speech his willingness to make a so-called "journey of peace" to mainland China, said MAC Chairman Chang King-yu.
Lee reiterated his stance during a recent interview with Time, Chang said.

Such a visit, however, would require efforts and agreements from both the Republic of China and mainland China, Chang said, adding that it is too early to speculate on when Lee's visit will take place.
President Lee, backed by Taiwan's 21 million people, has always wished to visit the mainland because he hopes there will be genuine peace across the Taiwan Strait, Chang said.

The cabinet-level MAC is Taiwan's top government agency in charge of charting the island's mainland China policy, while the SEF is a semi-official organization that handles negotiations with the mainland in the absence of formal relations.

DOC.HEADLINE: CZECH FIRST LADY VISITS TAIWAN

TEXT.P: Madame Dagmar Havlova, first lady of the Czech Republic, arrived in Taipei on Monday for an eight-day, private visit, according to Ministry of Foreign Affairs sources.

Madame Havlova, who had been first diva at the Theatre Vinohrady in Prague before she married playwright-turned-president Vaclav Havel, is being accompanied by first daughter Nina Veskrnova, Veskrnova's husband Shalev Ad-El and a four-member entourage.

Havlova and her companions will meet with President Lee Teng-hui, Vice President Lien Chan, Foreign Affairs Minister Jason Hu and Jeffrey Koo, chairman of the Taipei-based Overseas Investment and Development Corp. (OIDC).
She will also meet with local business and industrial leaders, at the invitation of the OIDC. The first lady is expected to solicit Taiwan investment in the Czech Republic.

During her stay, Havlova will visit the National Fu Hsing Dramatic Arts Academy, the National Palace Museum, an Industrial Technology Research Institute research center that studies Chinese herbs, and the Tzuchi Compassion Foundation.

Havlova is now devoted to charity work. Her Foundation Vision 97, founded last year, concerns itself with cancer prevention and research and children's welfare, as well as cultural developments within the Czech Republic.
Havlova's husband, President Havel, once appealed in a speech to the United Nations' General Assembly for the Republic of China's re-admission into the world body.
The Czech Republic recognizes Beijing but maintains friendly ties with Taiwan. Vice President Lien Chan made a private visit to Prague in June 1995.

Hualon Textile Co., one of Taiwan's largest textile companies, has set up a fabric production facility in the Czech Republic, and the state-run Aerospace Industry Development Corp. has signed a cooperative accord with Prague-based Aero Vodochody Co. on joint production of small aircraft.

DOC.HEADLINE: AUSTRALIAN PRIME MINISTER TO PUT ONE NATION LAST

TEXT.P: Australian Prime Minister John Howard announced on Monday that he will put the One Nation candidate seeking election in Howard's constituency of Bennelong in Sydney last on his voting ticket for the upcoming federal election.
Under Australia's voting system, all major political parties must rank other parties' candidates in descending order of preference.
Federal elections are expected in August or September.

Howard's decision follows One Nation's stunning victory in recent state elections in Queensland, in which the party captured 11 seats, two more than Howard's Liberal Party. Howard said he had decided to put One Nation last on his ticket before the Queensland state elections.
Howard said he hoped fellow Liberal Party candidates would follow in his footsteps and put One Nation last in their tickets.
But opposition Leader Kim Beazley said Howard's decision came "too late" to stop the One Nation Party from spreading its influence to other states.

"In my constituency (in Western Australia), there is a very substantial support for One Nation, but I'll take the stand persistently (against One Nation) because it's in the national interest," said Beazley.
Ethnic community leaders in Victoria said Howard's announcement stopped short of telling Liberal Party members to put One Nation last in their tickets.

DOC.HEADLINE: DISCORD OVER US-MAINLAND CHINA TRADE LINGERS

TEXT.P: With US President Bill Clinton's trip to Beijing less than a week away, the US and mainland China are trying to resolve one of their prickliest political problems: how to counter the United States' trade deficit with mainland China, according to reports from the Geneva-based World Trade Organization.

Both the United States and mainland China calculate the deficit differently, leading to starkly divergent views of bilateral trade relations that are at the heart of persistent tension between the two countries, the report said.
The United States claims the deficit reached about US$50 billion in 1997, second only to its trade deficit with Japan, and argues that Beijing protects its home markets while exploiting US openness.
Mainland China says last year's deficit was US$16.4 billion and charges the United States with fiddling with deficit figures to gain further advantages in mainland markets.

"The deficits between the two countries are not as big as what the US side calculated," mainland Chinese Foreign Ministry spokesman Zhu Bangzao said Tuesday. Contrary to US figures, mainland China claims the United States enjoyed a trade surplus with mainland China from 1988 to 1992.
Now experts in the two countries are working together to find a mutually agreeable method of calculating the deficit, Zhu said. He did not elaborate.

But the United States, anticipating a flood of inexpensive exports from Asia, sees its growing trade deficit -- particularly with mainland China, where the deficit grew 26 percent in 1997, according to US figures -- as an ever-increasing threat to its economic well-being.

Many of mainland China's US-bound products pass through Hong Kong, but the mainland does not include all of them when calculating its trade figures. The United States does count them, although it does not count US products that pass through Hong Kong en route to the mainland in determining its trade figures.
Zhu urged the United States to ease restrictions on high-technology exports to Communist China and lift trade sanctions against Beijing before Clinton arrives in the country June 25.

The sanctions and export restrictions, which include a ban on financial support for US companies in mainland China from several US government agencies, date back to mainland China's bloody crackdown on democracy protesters in June 1989. US officials, including US ambassador to mainland China James Sasser, hinted that Clinton could announce an easing of such sanctions during his visit, the WTO report added.

DOC.HEADLINE: SINGAPOREAN PM WARNS OF POSSIBLE RECESSION

TEXT.P: Singapore could enter a recession if government efforts to boost the economy are unsuccessful or if the country cannot withstand pressure from a regional recession that an ailing Japanese yen may induce, Prime Minister Goh Chok Tong warned on Sunday.
Pointing to a Japanese economy in recession and a weakening yen, Goh said the entire region may be plunged into recession within a year or two as a result of Japan's economic problems.
"So ask yourself what will happen to Singapore? What will happen to you? I think we are going to see slower growth," he said in an off-the-cuff speech at a local community function.
Goh's comments came a day after the government announced Singapore's all-important non-oil domestic exports had fallen 4.8 percent last month, after a drop of 1.6 percent in April.
On Sunday Goh also reminded Singaporeans of the impact that the economic crisis that has swept through Asia has had on the region's currencies.
The Indonesian rupiah has lost 80 percent of its value, while the Malaysian ringgit and Thai baht have both fallen 35 percent. The Singapore dollar, meanwhile, has slipped 17 percent.
Given that Singaporeans are going "to face much more difficult times ahead," Goh urged Singapore's Community Development Councils to help families cope with the crisis.

DOC.HEADLINE: AUSTRALIAN DOLLAR AT THE MERCY OF JAPANESE YEN

TEXT.P: The Australian dollar is at the mercy of the Japanese yen and is facing a renewed attack in financial markets after emergency talks in Tokyo failed to achieve a clear timetable for reforming the Japanese economy and financial system, economists said.
The Australian dollar was trading at 60.86 US cents early Monday morning, down from 61.38 US cents at Friday's close.
Japan is Australia's largest trading partner.
The All Ordinaries Index dropped 4.5 points in early morning trade on Monday from Friday's close of 2,588.8.

Despite US intervention last week and a chorus of criticism over its economic mismanagement, Japan has been resisting intense pressure from members of the Group of Seven and other Asian countries to give details of how and when it will stimulate its economy and reform its financial structure.

Japan is not only Australia's biggest trading partner but also a major investor of Australian currency and bonds. Whenever Japan encounters economic problems, it tends to sell Australian dollars and bonds, lowering their prices.
Economists said Japan's indecisiveness will once again hurt the Australian currency and stock market.
