DOC.HEADLINE: WANG DAN'S MOTHER PERMITTED TO MEET SON IN US IN AUGUST: REPORT
DOC.DATELINE: Tokyo, June 22 (CNA) (By Victor Lai & Eva Chen)

TEXT.P: The mother of a leader in the 1989 pro-democracy movement has been permitted by Beijing authorities to visit her son in the United States in August, a story in Monday's Yomiuri Shimbun from Beijing said.
Wang Dan's mother, Wang Linyun, verified in a phone call with the Japanese newspaper that she has received a passport and plans to have a reunion with her son in the US.
Wang, 29, a symbol of the Tiananmen Square student demonstrations, was freed in April this year on medical parole and has been exiled to the US.

The approval for the visit, which comes days before US President Bill Clinton's trip to mainland China from June 25 to July 3, was intended to show Beijing's efforts at improving its human rights conditions.

DOC.HEADLINE: YAMAGUCHI GUMI ELEMENT NABBED IN SOUTHERN TAIWAN
DOC.DATELINE: Kaohsiung, Southern Taiwan, June 22 (CNA) (By Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: An underground Japanese gang member who was wanted in Japan on weapons charges was nabbed Saturday in the southern Taiwan township of Fengshan.

Masayoshi Ishida, an action chief in Yamaguchi Gumi's branch operations in Yokohama, Japan, was handed over by Fengshan police to the Alien Detention Center under the National Police Administration (NPA) in Taipei on Monday.
Ishida, who has not committed any crime in Taiwan, has been detained and will be repatriated back to Japan for overstaying his visa, NPA officials said.

According to Fengshan police, Ishida, 34, was very cooperative with the police when he was arrested in the residence of his Taiwanese girl friend. The woman, surnamed Lai, lives in Fengshan with her six-year-old son.
Ishida, however, refused to disclose why he was wanted by the Japanese police, and what he has been doing in Taiwan during the past three or so months.

According to NPA investigators, Ishida, a veteran gangster who has been a member of the Yamaguchi Gumi for 18 years, fled to Taiwan in March this year after he fired two gun shots at a pub in downtown Yokohama. No one was hurt in the incident.

Ishida had loaned about NT$6 million to the Taiwanese-Japanese woman who owns the pub, Lai said. The woman refused to pay back the loan, and Ishida fired shots to the pub to vent his anger, according to Lai.
Ishida was a wanted criminal by Japanese police and was on the Interpol cross-border wanted list, according to NPA officials.

DOC.HEADLINE: INCREASED APATHY TOWARD UPPER HOUSE ELECTIONS IN JAPAN

TEXT.P: Nearly half of Japan's eligible voters are indifferent toward upcoming House of Councilors elections, according to a poll conducted by a major Japanese newspaper.
In results published Monday by The Yomiuri Shimbun, 45 percent of respondents said they were uninterested in the election, in which half of 252 seats in Japan's Upper House will be contested.
Similar polls conducted before previous Upper House elections, held once every three years, revealed that less than 40 percent of respondents held such a view.
More than half of respondents in the recent poll pointed to economic recovery as the most important campaign issue.

Seventy-six seats in the election will be filled through ballots cast from electoral districts, while the remaining 50 will be filled through proportional representation. For those 50 seats, however, voters will choose a party rather than an individual candidate.

Thirty-one percent of respondents said they would vote for the ruling Liberal Democratic Party for seats filled through proportional representation. The largest opposition party, the Democratic Party, received support from only 10 percent of respondents.

The LDP already holds a majority in Japan's Lower House and could capture one in the Upper House as well if it wins a total of 69 seats in the July elections. Of the seats currently held by the LDP, 61 are up for grabs.
The survey was conducted on June 13 and 14, with 1,975 people taking part.

DOC.HEADLINE: SHARE PRICES DOWN ON TAIEX

TEXT.P: Share prices opened high but closed lower on the Taipei Stock Exchange (TAIEX), with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, dropping 124.36 points to close at 7,692.91.
The bourse opened at the day's high of 7,867.41, and experienced a low of 7,678.7.
Dealers said the market was drawn down by electronics stocks which were moving lower.
Losers outnumbered gainers by 303 to 129 with 53 issues remaining unchanged.
A total of 2.46 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$120.15 billion.

Seven of the eight major categories lost ground, with electrical stocks suffering the most dramatic drop at 3.1 percent, followed by construction shares at 2.4 percent, cement issues at 1.2 percent, bank and insurance stocks at 1.1 percent, pulp and paper issues at 0.8 percent, foodstuff shares at 0.4 percent, and textile issues at 0.3 percent.
Meanwhile, only the plastics and chemical categories remained unchanged.

The 10 listed companies enjoying the largest turnovers in Monday's trading were: Taiwan Tea Corp.; United Micro Electronics; Winbond Electronics Corp.; Kuei Hung Industrial; Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing; ACER; Tatung; China Manmade Fiber; ASE; and China Petrochemical.

DOC.HEADLINE: US AID DELINKED FROM PACE OF REFORM IN INDONESIA

TEXT.P: The United States will not link economic support for Indonesia to the pace of its political reforms, The Straits Times reported Sunday.

Signaling a change in the United States' approach to Indonesia's financial crisis, an administration official said Sunday that the United States continues to believe that economic and political reforms should proceed in tandem in Indonesia, but recognized that the gravity of the economic situation is such that it needs to be addressed urgently on its own terms.
The official, speaking on condition of anonymity, was clarifying US Secretary of State Madeleine Albright's remarks about Indonesia last week, the report said.
Albright had insisted that it was not too early for the United States to reaffirm its "commitment to do all we can to help the Indonesian people."
US officials say privately that though Habibie began his presidency amid low expectations, he has performed better than expected, the report said.

DOC.HEADLINE: US MAY OPEN CHANNEL FOR THREE-WAY DIALOGUE

TEXT.P: The United States plans to open a channel for Taipei-Beijing-Washington dialogue after President Bill Clinton's upcoming visit to mainland China, a senior official said on Monday.

Lin Chong-pin, vice chanirman of the Mainland Affairs Council (MAC), made the statement in a speech on the possible impact on relations across the Taiwan Strait of the Clinton's June 25-July 3 mainland visit.

Quoting retired senior American officials, Lin said the Clinton administration intends to open a channel for delegates from Taipei, Washington and Beijing to engage in three-way dialogue on cross-strait issues after Clinton holds a summit meeting with mainland Chinese President Jiang Zemin in Beijing later this month.
"Several ex-American officials have told me that such dialogue can be held either in the United States or in an international setting," Lin said.

Following the Clinton-Jiang meeting, Lin said he is convinced that the US will continue to encourage the two sides of the Taiwan Strait to conduct peaceful dialogue in addition to pushing Beijing not to use force against Taiwan. "At the same time, I expects the US to reinforce engagements with Beijing while developing parallel ties with Taipei."

As for Beijing, Lin said he believes Beijing will more actively pressure Taipei to hold political talks in the wake of the Clinton-Jiang summit meeting. "Beijing is also expected to become more nimble in handling cross-strait issues," he added.

Turning to the agenda of the upcoming Clinton-Jiang summit, Lin said Beijing looks forward to realizing two goals -- demanding the US to cease arms sales to Taiwan and to enshrine the "three no's" in a formal document.
Judging from the current development, Lin said, Clinton is not likely to sign a fourth joint communique nor promise to change the US arms sales policy during his mainland visit.

As for the "three no's", Lin said it remains unclear whether Clinton will issue a joint statement with Jiang reaffirming the US opposition to the creation of "two Chinas" or "one China, one Taiwan," the declaration of Taiwan independence and Taiwan's participation in international organizations involving sovereign states.

DOC.HEADLINE: SCHOLARS HAVE MIXED OPINIONS ABOUT CLINTON-JIANG TALKS

TEXT.P: Scholars expressed mixed opinions in a seminar on Sunday over a scheduled summit meeting between US President Bill Clinton and mainland Chinese President Jiang Zemin.
Professor Ma Chih-hua of the National Chengchi University and a participant of the seminar, said Clinton's trip will result in nothing but harm.

Ma also said the intent behind arranging Clinton's visit to Hong Kong was obvious. If Clinton is satisfied with what he sees in the former British colony, Beijing will be able to say the "one country, two systems" model could also apply to Taiwan, Ma said.

Professor Pan Hsi-tang of the Tamkang University said Taiwan should not be too optimistic about the Clinton-Jiang meeting. He said the Taiwan issue is bound to be on the agenda in the meeting, and mainland China knows the US plays a crucial role in the solution of cross-strait problem.
Beijing also knows that only through engagement with the US can it seek cooperation from Washington and undermine its support of Taiwan.
Pan predicted that Beijing will ask the US to abide by the 1972 communique in which the US promised to gradually reduce arms sales to Taiwan.

The US will find it hard to refuse such a demand, Pan said, adding that if the US complies, then the quality and quantity of US arms to Taiwan will be cut. This may be made easier as some in the US have recently advocated cutting arms sales to Taiwan and have said arms sales have promoted the sentiment of Taiwan independence.
Pan noted that if such views gain momentum in the US, then it would increase the pressure on the US to reduce its arms sales to Taiwan.

Kuo Chang-li of the Chinese Cultural University has different views about the negative effect of the talks, saying that no new communique will be signed by the two sides, and the US will not review its policy regarding arms sales to Taiwan at the present stage.
Kuo stressed that the US will not turn its back on Taiwan for now, and the US will not sacrifice the interests of Taiwan because of pressure from the mainland.

He said Taiwan does not need to pay attention to the "new three no's" Beijing seeks to get Washington to agree to. These are no US support for an independent Taiwan, no US support for two Chinas or "one China, one Taiwan," and no US support for Taiwan's bid to enter the United Nations.
Kuo added that Beijing has already been operating under such a policy toward Taiwan which has not threatened the safety of Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: LEGISLATIVE MISSION WARNS OF 'THREE NO'S' TREND IN US

TEXT.P: A group of ROC legislators who just returned from the US said on Monday bilateral Taipei-Washington ties may be affected even if there is no public statement on Beijing's "three no's" demands.

The "three no's" refer to no US support for an independent Taiwan, no US support for "two Chinas" or "one China, one Taiwan," and no US support for Taiwan's bid to enter the United Nations. US President Bill Clinton and mainland Chinese President Jiang Zemin are expected to discuss the Taiwan issue when they meet later this week.

Rau Ying-chi, a ruling Kuomintang lawmaker and leader of the 19-member non-partisan delegation, made the remarks at a news conference after concluding a four-day visit to the United States. The delegation traveled to the US to express the ROC's position in the face of the upcoming Clinton-Jiang summit.

There have been many assurances by the US that Taiwan's interests would not be sold out in the Clinton-Jiang summit, there would not be a fourth communique on Taiwan, and Washington will not change its policy on arms sales to Taiwan. However, Rau warned Taiwan not to ease its guard on the issues.

"Even though Taiwan's interests will not be sacrificed in the Clinton-Jiang meeting, two-way relations between Taiwan and the US may be affected," Rau said, as "mainland China is playing an increased role in the US' strategical deployment."

"Beijing has been actively lobbying Washington, and we cannot loosen our efforts," the KMT heavyweight said. "Even though Washington will not publicly declare a statement on the 'three no's,' the US administration, Congress and media believe that all issues concerned will be unavoidable trends."
Nevertheless, Rau, who also doubles as executive director of the KMT's Policy Coordination Committee, was upbeat about the delegation's trip which took place from June 14-17.
"What makes us happy is that the ROC's four stances were fully reflected to the US side and we have gained widespread praise and support," he stressed.

During the trip, Rau said all delegates took advantage of every occasion to explain the ROC's position regarding the Clinton-Jiang summit when meeting with US officials, congressmen, think tanks, and media representatives.
According to Rau, the following four major stances were conveyed to the US side:

I -- The ROC is an independent sovereignty and the future of Taiwan's 21 million people should be decided by themselves. The ROC strongly opposes any bilateral negotiations on Taiwan between the US and mainland China and will never accept any agreement reached between the two sides regarding Taiwan;

II -- Peace and security across the Taiwan Strait are not only crucial to Taiwan's future, but also are of great importance to the US' strategical interests. Taipei wishes Washington can urge Beijing to renounce its use of force against Taiwan;
IV -- Taiwan hopes the US can play a leadership role in tackling the Asian financial turmoil to help prevent the crisis from further damaging world peace and prosperity.

Through comprehensive and sincere discussions and exchanges of opinions, Rau said he and other delegates all deeply felt strong support and friendship from the US. They were assured that there will not be changes in the US' arms sales policy to Taiwan and there will not be a fourth communique on Taiwan.

Delegates such as KMT Legislator Chen Hung-Chi, New Party Legislators Kao Hui-yu and Tsai Chen-yang, and Democratic Progressive Party Legislators Hseng Fu-hsiung and Lee Ying-yuan, all hailed the trip as "successful," saying that they will continue to promote such overseas visits by lawmakers in the future to win greater international support.

DOC.HEADLINE: CLINTON'S CHINA STRATEGY SEEN FALLING SHORT

TEXT.P: Few US presidents have worked the sound bite or photo opportunity better during an overseas trip than former President Ronald Reagan or President Bill Clinton, the Los Angeles Times reported Sunday.

In a front page story entitled "Failure seen in Clinton's strategy towards China," writer Tyler Marshall wrote that Reagan stumbled badly only once when he laid a wreath at a West German war cemetery in Bitburg where members of Adolf Hitler's notorious SS units are buried.

Clinton's equivalent could come Saturday, the Washington-based writer said. Bowing to Beijing's demands, Clinton has agreed to be officially welcomed in Tiananmen Square, the site of a bloody military crackdown against pro-democracy demonstrators in June 1989.
But unlike in Reagan's case, Clinton's willingness to go through with the welcoming ceremony has an added dimension -- it is seen by many as symbolic of a larger failure.

To a wide cross-section of US foreign affairs specialists, the decision stands as a striking example of Clinton's inability to reap benefits from his policy of "engagement." It has been his strategy to cooperate with Beijing on issues of common interest without letting serious differences, particularly those on human rights, get in the way.

"I can't think of a single situation with regard to Beijing where the administration hasn't backed off," said Warren Cohen, director of the Asia program at Woodrow Wilson Center, a Washington-based think tank.

"This isn't a poker game, but if you say an issue is important to you, then you need to get at least something on that issue," Cohen said. "This administration has gotten nothing out of the Beijing regime except promises the regime haven't kept."

DOC.HEADLINE: EX-LIBERAL PM CALLS FOR REJECTION OF ONE NATION PARTY

TEXT.P: Former Liberal Prime Minister Malcolm Fraser called on major parties and voters to reject the One Nation Party because the right-wing party will hurt Australia's foreign investment, jobs and exports.

In an article entitled "This Obscenity Must Be Repulsed" published in The Australian newspaper Monday, Fraser said, "Liberal compromise with race has resulted in One Nation emerging as the third largest party in the Queensland Parliament, with more seats than the Liberal Party."
He blamed the Liberal Party in Queensland for giving preference votes to the One Nation Party, which scored a stunning victory on June 13 by winning 11 seats at the Queensland Legislative Assembly.

"No decent community can compromise with racist policies. There is one honorable option: absolute rejection, refusal to cooperate, refusal to lend credibility to those promoting the evil of racism," he wrote.

Due to the massive defeat in Queensland, Prime Minister John Howard bowed to internal party pressure and announced Monday that he would put the One Nation Party last in his constituency at Bennelong in New South Wales because Asian-Australians have begun to feel "unwelcome" in their own country.
Howard said he believed all state branches except perhaps Western Australia would also put One Nation last in lower-house seats and in the Senate.

Almost all of Howard's senior ministers, including Deputy Prime Minister Tim Fischer, Foreign Minister Alexander Downer, Treasurer Peter Costello, Health Minister Michael Woodridge and Primary Industrial Minister John Anderson, will not give any preference votes to One Nation in the federal election.
However, Opposition Leader Kim Beazley blasted Howard, saying his decision is "not enough and too late."

DOC.HEADLINE: INVESTIGATORS VISIT FRANCE TO PROBE ALLEGED SEXUAL MISCONDUCT

TEXT.P: A three-member team from the Ministry of Justice (MOJ) is currently in France to probe allegations of sexual misconduct committed by a senior ministry official, Vice Justice Minister Chiang Hao reported on Monday.

"The team, headed by Huang Shyh-ming, chief secretary of the ministry, left for Paris on Sunday and is scheduled to stay there for one week," said Chiang, who is serving concurrently as the convener of a special task force set up to investigate the allegations against Cheng Chuan, acting director of the ministry's Investigation Bureau.

"The team will try its best to interview Yang Yu-chen, the victim of the alleged attack, and obtain her medical records," Chiang said. "It may not be easy to reach these two goals, but the team will nevertheless do its utmost to win the trust of the Yang family."
The investigative task force also includes Wu-Chen Huang, an adviser to the ministry, and Li Tsui-lien, division chief of the ministry's Department of Rehabilitation and Social Protection.

The acting chief of the Investigation Bureau has claimed that he was only trying to cure the daughter of his former friend Yang Wan-ching with Chikung, a traditional Chinese martial art believed to have curative powers, during a trip to Paris on Sept. 9-13, 1996.

Cheng refuted allegations by Yang's wife that he had touched the girl's breast and private parts under the excuse of administering treatment to her in his Paris hotel room, causing great distress to the girl who was then 19 years old and suffering from anorexia nervosa.

Although Cheng has categorically denied any wrongdoing, many questions surrounding the case remain unanswered, prompting the MOJ to send the team to France to attempt to collect related information first-hand.

Chiang said Huang's mission is to maintain lines of communication with Yang, who is now a French citizen, despite the fact that he has not shown much interest in working with the investigative task force on the case.

DOC.HEADLINE: SWEDEN GOVERNOR TO VISIT TAIWAN

TEXT.P: Wiggo Komstedt, Kronoberg County governor of Sweden is scheduled to arrive in Taipei on Tuesday for a 12-day visit.
Komstedt and his wife will call on Vice Chairman of Mainland Affairs Council Sheu Ke-sheng, Deputy Director-General of Government Information Office Chang Pin-nan and other government officials.
They will also visit several cultural and economic establishments of the Republic of China before leaving Taipei on July 4.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC LEGISLATORS LEAVE PANAMA FOR COSTA RICA
DOC.DATELINE: Panama City, June 21 (CNA) (By Edward Chen and Maubo Chang)

TEXT.P: A group of visiting legislators from the Republic of China left Panama for Costa Rica on Sunday afternoon.

During their three-day visit in Panama, the 11-member group, led by Lin Che-fu, convenor of the Foreign and Overseas Chinese Affairs Committee, attended a meeting of the ROC-Panama Bilateral Parliamentarian Committee.
A communique signed at the end of the meeting vowed to strengthen bilateral ties as well as beef up cooperation in international affairs.
Panama President Ernesto Perez Balladares later received the legislators at his office and promised to help tighten up Panamanian relations with the ROC.
The group also visited Taiwan-based shipping company Evergreen's container wharf in Panama, and met with representatives of the local Chinese community.

DOC.HEADLINE: SINGAPORE DEPUTY PM NAMED ONE OF `THE STARS OF ASIA'

TEXT.P: Singapore's Deputy Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong has been named by BusinessWeek magazine as one of 50 "Stars of Asia" who will play leading roles in bringing Asia out of its worst economic crisis in half a century.

In a special feature titled "The Stars of Asia," published in its latest issue, the American magazine listed 50 Asian policymakers, managers, entrepreneurs, financiers and opinion shapers, whom it said are "stepping forward to help Asia reinvent itself" in the midst of the turmoil.

These people, it said, are pushing Asia towards greater accountability to shareholders and voters, modernizing financial systems, rooting out government mismanagement, fighting corruption, making gutsy bets on expansion during the downturn, streamlining their companies, improving productivity, and slashing costs.
On Lee, who is also chairman of the Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS), the magazine said he has become "Singapore's economic policy czar.

"He has opened up fund management and banking to foreign competition, phased out separate stock prices for foreigners, allowed the currency to fall, and has shaken up the central bank. He is looking like a reformer and a future prime minister," the article concluded.
Among the others singled out by the magazine are mainland Chinese Prime Minister Zhu Rongji and Malaysian Deputy Prime Minister Anwar Ibrahim.

DOC.HEADLINE: EXPORT ORDERS RECEIVED BY TAIWAN FIRMS DECREASING

TEXT.P: The value of orders received by Taiwan firms from foreign buyers amounted to US$48.32 billion in the first five months of this year, a reduction of 3.31 percent from the same period of last year.

Chang Yao-chung, director general of the Statistics Department of the Ministry of Economic Affairs, which compiled the statistics, said Monday that the reduction of export orders is partly attributable to the Asian financial crisis.

The export orders received in May totaled US$10.04 billion, down US$400 million or 3.86 percent from the same month of 1997. The value of orders received from the United States in May amounted to US$3.22 billion, 3.4 percent or US$10 million less than a year earlier.

Lee Kao-chao, vice chairman of the Council for Economic Planning and Development of the Executive Yuan, said he is not pessimistic about it, because if calculated in Taiwan currency, the value of export orders received in May was 15 percent higher than the same month of last year.

A survey conducted in May indicated that 40.42 percent of Taiwan exporters believed they might receive the same amount of export orders in June as in May, while 33.24 percent predicted the amount would reduce, and 26.34 percent believed the amount would increase, the official said.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAINLAND CHINESE TOP LIST OF ILLEGAL IMMIGRANTS TO JAPAN

TEXT.P: Japan captured 7,117 illegal immigrants in 1997, and 43 percent of them were from mainland China, according to a statistical report by the Justice Department of Japan.

The report said that, although Japan has been in economic recession, the number of illegal immigrants captured last year was 2,290 more than those captured in 1996. Of those captured last year, 3,045 were from mainland China, 1,487 from Thailand, and 1,089 from the Philippines.
The report also said that 49,566 foreigners were expelled last year for overstaying their visa or working illegally in Japan.
A total of 14,189 foreigners were denied entry last year, 66 percent of whom suspected of attempting to work illegally in Japan.

DOC.HEADLINE: FOREIGN DIPLOMATS CONCERNED ABOUT VIRAL OUTBREAK

TEXT.P: A killer intestinal virus outbreak that has claimed the lives of 50 young children around the island in recent weeks has caused concern among foreign diplomats stationed here, Foreign Minister Jason Hu said on Monday.
"To allay their misgivings, we invited a senior Department of Health (DOH) official to brief them on the current situation of the enterovirus epidemic this morning," Hu stated.

A total of 14 foreign ambassadors and 45 representatives from countries which do not maintain foreign diplomatic ties with the Republic of China attended the presentation given by Hsu Kuo-hsiung, acting director of the DOH's Bureau of Communicable Disease Control, at the Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA).
"Hopefully, the presentation will help clarify misunderstanding or speculation about the viral outbreak," the minister noted.

MOFA Vice Minister David Lee said although many foreign diplomats have voiced concern about the enterovirus epidemic, none of them has advised expatriates from his or her home country to leave Taiwan simply for the outbreak.
"They only want to get more information in order to help their fellow countrymen take precautionary measures to protect their children from contracting the killer virus," Lee said.

Meanwhile, the DOH again demanded all city and county governments from sponsoring any large-scale activities for children for the time being as part of efforts to curb the further spread of the virus.
Under current ROC law, the DOH has no legal basis to ban local governments from sponsoring cultural or recreational programs for children.
Nevertheless, Hsu said, it's risky and unwise for local governments to ignore the DOH's directive and sponsor large-scale children's programs at the moment.
"They run the risk of exposing children to the killer intestinal virus," Hsu warned.

Hsu also urged local health authorities to intensify sterilization measures at all swimming pools in their cities or counties to eradicate the virus. Parents have been advised to discourage their kids from swimming in public pools.

In related developments, the kindergarten affiliated to Taipei's Chang Chun Elementary School decided to close for a week starting Monday as two of its pupils were confirmed to have been infected by the virus last week. It was the first kindergartern in Taipei to have announced a temporary closure since the epidemic broke out in May.

Infants and toddlers are most susceptible to enterovirus. Early symptoms of the infection resemble the flu, with fever, headache, and vomiting. Ulcers or blisters in the mouth and a rash on the palms and feet can also develop. Later, possible deadly complications include encephalitis, meningitis and acute inflammation of the hear muscle.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC PRESIDENT'S 1995 US VISIT NOT INTENDED TO CAUSE CONFLICT: FM

TEXT.P: Minister of Foreign Affairs Jason Hu said on Monday that President Lee Teng-hui's visit to the United States in June 1995 was not intended to cause any conflict between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait.

Hu made the remarks when asked to comment on a Washington Post report on the Taiwan Strait crisis of March 1996, when mainland China staged war games, including missile tests, in waters near Taiwan, to protest against Lee's US visit and the holding of the island's first direct presidential election in March, 1996.

The foreign minister said that Lee's visit was private and low-profile, pointing out that the president met with no federal officials during his visit, while his meetings with governors and city mayors were made in a private capacity.

Hu said that Taiwan had not expected the Beijing authorities to react in such a radical manner to Lee's visit, but he stressed that Taiwan had not intended to cause trouble. Instead, he claimed, it was Beijing that created cross-strait tension by suspending regular cross-strait talks and conducting controversial war games near Taiwan in the run-up to the presidential election.

Describing a peaceful Taiwan Strait as the island's biggest wish, Hu pointed out that the modernization of Taiwan's defenses is aimed only at enhancing their deterrent force. He added that should any tension appear in the Taiwan Strait, it is his hope that all international peacekeeping forces will contribute to helping maintain peace in the region.

He also denied allegations contained in the report that Taiwan spent US$5 million to lobby the US Congress to support the president's visit to Cornell University, his alma mater. Hu stressed that for the past 30 years, the US Congress has given Taiwan its firm and active support as an affirmation of Taiwan's economic and political achievements.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC OFFICIAL DISCUSSES FISHERY TARIFFS WITH US TRADE REPRESENTATIVE
DOC.DATELINE: Kuching, Malaysia, June 22 (CNA) (By Chi Ching-lin and Ben Wu)

TEXT.P: ROC Economics Minister Wang Chih-kang on Monday held bilateral talks with US Trade Representative Charlene Barshefsky and exchanged views with her on a range of issues, in particular the question of fishery tariffs.

Pacific Rim ministers are attending the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation (APEC) forum ministerial meeting which opened in Kuching on Monday, to discuss accelerated free-trade plans in nine specific sectors.

Wang and Barshefsky discussed the so-called Early Voluntary Sectoral Liberalization (EVSL) process, which was launched at the November Vancouver APEC meeting in an effort to speed up progress toward APEC's goal of free trade for all countries by 2020.

Under the terms of the EVSL process, the nine sectors in which negotiators want to lower trade barriers are: environmental goods and services; gems and jewelry; fishery products; medical equipment; energy; chemicals; forestry products; toys; and electronic commerce.
Negotiators have so far failed in their attempts to finalize details of accelerated free-trade plans in the nine specific sectors, especially as regards fishery products.

Mainland China, Taiwan, Japan, and South Korea have all expressed their opposition to lowering tariffs on fishery products to zero by the year 2005, while the United States, New Zealand, Australia, and Canada have been insisting on the principles of the EVSL plan, in which the tariff rate should be lowered to zero by 2005.

As a result of strong opposition from domestic fishery organizations, the Council of Agriculture (COA) under the Executive Yuan has suggested the adoption of a different method of calculation for fishery products, based on substantive tariff reductions instead of tariff abolition.

Wang told Barshefsky that Taiwan faces difficulty in lowering fishery tariffs to zero by 2005. The island currently imposes a tariff rate of 8 percent, and the COA hopes this rate can be lowered to 5 percent by 2019.

Meanwhile, at a Sunday meeting on the sidelines of the APEC meeting, Linda A. Chaves, director of the Industry and Trade Program of the United States, and Chen Siu-sien, a fishery industry representative from the southern Taiwan city of Tainan, also exchanged views on the issue.

APEC groups Australia, Brunei, Canada, Chile, mainland China, Hong Kong, Indonesia, Japan, South Korea, Malaysia, Mexico, New Zealand, Papua New Guinea, the Philippines, Singapore, Taiwan, Thailand, and the United States.
Russia, Vietnam and Peru, which are slated for admission in November, are attending the meeting as observers.

DOC.HEADLINE: BEIJING NOW ASIA'S SOFTWARE PIRACY KING

TEXT.P: The US software industry claims that its piracy-related losses in mainland China more than doubled last year to over US$1.4 billion, according to reports from the Geneva-based World Trade Organization (WTO) on Monday.
Mainland China also displaced Japan as the largest source of piracy losses in Asia, despite the fact that there are more installed software applications in Japan, the WTO report said.

The reason is mainland China's 96 percent piracy rate -- far higher than the 32 percent rate reported for Japan. The figures are contained a study released by the US Business Software Alliance and the Software Publishers Association.

Japan led Asia as a source of such losses until 1996, when it accounted for nearly US$1.2 billion in unauthorized software use. Last year, though, stronger copyright enforcement trimmed piracy losses to US$752 million. The sheer growth in mainland China's computer use, without any improvement in copyright observance, has sent losses in the mainland soaring.

In mainland China, "the basic problem is that computer sales are far outpacing software sales," the WTO report quoted Mark Traphagen, a spokesman of the Software Publishers Association, as saying. The group attributes much of the industry's losses in mainland China and elsewhere to "workplace piracy." That typically occurs when a company obtains a program legitimately but makes numerous unauthorized copies for its employees.
Unless these trends are reversed, US Trade Representative Charlene Barshefsky will be authorized to impose trade sanctions on mainland China, the report added.

DOC.HEADLINE: NEW PARTY MAYORAL CANDIDATE REITERATES DETERMINATION TO RUN

TEXT.P: The opposition New Party's candidate for the Taipei City mayoral election, Wang Chien-shien, on Monday reiterated his determination to run for office, despite a low support rate revealed in a number of recent surveys.

Wang said that Taiwan's social value system is decaying, posing a serious threat to the country. He claimed that rebuilding a social value system based on credibility, justice, and love, is in the nation's best interest.

Wang made the remarks when he opened his campaign office to the media, to rebut a suggestion made last week by Hsu Li-nung, dubbed the party's "spiritual leader." Hsu had called on Wang to think of teaming up with ruling Kuomintang candidate Ma Ying-jeou in a joint effort to beat incumbent mayor Chen Shui-bian of the main opposition Democratic Progressive Party, saying that the national interest should be higher than an individual's credibility.

Wang said that he would take advantage of the mayoral election to let the people realize the importance of credibility, stressing that it is more important than whether one runs in or wins an election.

Meanwhile, Jaw Shau-kong, the New Party's campaign manager for year-end legislative, mayoral and city council deputy elections, stated flatly that if Wang drops out of the election, the party might as well dissolve, saying: "Who else is willing to be nominated by the party? Who else is willing to support the party?"

Jaw went on to say that the party must be represented in the mayoral election, otherwise it will lose a good chance to promote its policies. He added that Wang will submit his first administration paper on Tuesday, in which he will offer a proposal on improving Taipei City's notorious traffic.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAYORAL CANDIDATE SEEKS COOPERATION WITH KMT YOUTH AFFAIRS DEPARTMENT

TEXT.P: The ruling Kuomintang (KMT)'s Taipei City mayoral candidate Ma Ying-jeou on Monday paid a courtesy call on Lai Kuo-chou, director-general of the KMT Department of Youth Affairs, to seek opportunities for cooperation.
They exchanged views on topics ranging from housing projects for single young people, youth demographics, and traffic issues.

Concerning the problem of so-called "snails without shells" -- people unable to afford Taipei's astronomical real estate prices -- Lai suggested that in the future, the city government could adopt the build-operation-transfer (BOT) method to construct houses for single young people.

Ma pointed out that as far back as when he was serving as justice minister, he noticed that there was not enough affordable housing for single personnel employed in his ministry. He said that as a result, fewer and fewer people like working and living in Taipei.

According to his understanding, Ma said, the city's population is falling by about 20,000 people each year, but the numbers of automobiles and motorcycles on the roads have not shown a comparable downward trend.

Both men agreed on the difficulties posed by the city's traffic problems. Ma noted that while Singapore has adopted a "flow volume control" system to solve the city-state's traffic problem, he and Lai agreed that people here might not adapt themselves to such a system.

The mayoral hopeful also expressed special concern for the city's young voters. According to statistics, young residents in the 20 to 39 age group now account for more than 50 percent of Taipei City's eligible voters.
He and Lai exchanged their experiences of serving youngsters in the past, and discussed possible plans for cooperation in the year-end elections.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN PROVINCE OFFERS HUGE SOFT LOANS TO BUSINESS AND HOUSE-BUYERS

TEXT.P: In an unprecedented gesture to businesses and prospective house-buyers, the Taiwan provincial government on Monday unveiled a package of soft loans worth NT$420 billion (US$12.35 billion).

The provincial government, which is facing dissolution at the end of the year, decided to provide NT$300 billion (US$8.82 billion) to small- and medium-sized enterprises and NT$120 billion (US$3.52 billion) to first-time house buyers.

The loans will be extended through the seven banks controlled by the provincial government at a rate which is O.375 percent to 1.25 percent lower than the current one, and is expected to stimulate the island's stagnating real estate market.

Taiwan Provincial Governor James Soong, who has been criticized by his Kuomintang party leaders for spending his budget too generously before stepping down, stymied any possible flack from his comrades on Monday by defending his measures at the provincial council at Nantou, central Taiwan.

He said he can't imagine that anyone other than those jealous of his good job performance will oppose his policy, which he said will help the island's economic development without imposing an extra financial burden on the government.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN WORKING GROUP TO MONITOR WASHINGTON-BEIJING SUMMIT

TEXT.P: Although it does not anticipate any surprises from the upcoming Washington-Beijing summit, Taiwan's Cabinet has set up a special working group to monitor closely the talks in Beijing which begin on Saturday.

David Tawei Lee, vice minister of foreign affairs, said after the first meeting of the working group at the Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) that the group, made up of officials from the National Security Council and the Mainland Affairs Council, as well as MOFA personnel, will greet the summit results immediately with appropriate measures and statements.

Noting that the ROC government is "cautiously optimistic" that the summit will not result in any harm to the island's interests, Lee said Taipei will take no chances and will pay close attention to US President Bill Clinton's talks with his Beijing counterpart Jiang Zemin. He said the government will keep a variety of responses up its sleeve to meet any possible scenario.

Washington has promised to debrief Taipei on the summit after Clinton winds up his June 25-July 3 trip to mainland China, said Lee, but he refused to disclose the identity of the US official who will come to Taipei to conduct the debriefing.

Meanwhile, an anonymous ROC official said that the summit will result in a "fact sheet" listing the agreements reached, rather than a "communique," which is more formal and therefore has more binding force.

This fact sheet will not include the worrisome "three noes," policy, which refers to Beijing's desire for US promises not to back Taiwan independence, not to back the "one China, one Taiwan" or "two Chinas" formulas, and not to back Taiwan's entry into international organizations, said the official.
Nevertheless, he said, Taiwan is taking nothing for granted, and will brace for the worst.

DOC.HEADLINE: AUSTRALIAN GIRL BIDS ADIEU TO ADOPTIVE PARENTS

TEXT.P: The Australian girl of Taiwanese origin who came to Taiwan two weeks ago to locate her birth parents, on Monday saw her adoptive parents off at the Chiang Kai-shek International Airport.
Kartya Wunderle cried when she hugged and said good-bye to her Australian parents, Orthma and Nola Wunderle, who adopted her some 17 years ago when she was just seven months old.

Kartya's birth mother, identified only as Mrs. Hsu, and Kartya's sister, were also at the airport to say good-bye. With the help of the media and the Criminal Investigation Bureau, Kartya was finally reunited with her birth mother on June 16 after DNA testing established their relationship.
Mrs. Hsu said that her gratitude to Mr. and Mrs. Wunderle was beyond description, adding that Kartya will always be their daughter.

Mrs. Wunderle, who accompanied Kartya to Taiwan on June 5 to begin the search for her roots, said that she felt very sad to be separated from Kartya, but added that she believes they will have a chance to meet their daughter in the near future.

Mr. Wunderle said that he was impressed by the assistance and warmth extended by the people of Taiwan to her daughter, adding that he is delighted by the happy outcome. Mr. Wunderle arrived in Taiwan on June 17 after learning that Kartya had found her birth mother.

According to Mrs. Hsu, Kartya was sold to an illegal adoption broker by her biological father for NT$36,000 at a time when she was unmarried and already had another daughter. Kartya's biological father died several years ago.

DOC.HEADLINE: OFFICIAL HINTS CLINTON WON'T MEET CHINESE DISSIDENTS
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, June 22 (CNA) (By Nelson Chung & Eva Chen)

TEXT.P: US President Bill Clinton will not meet with dissidents during his state visit to mainland China, hinted US State Department spokesman James Rubin on Monday,
Rubin said the president can promote improved human rights conditions without meeting dissidents when he begins his nine-day visit to mainland China on Thursday.

Stanley Roth, Assistant Secretary of State for East Asian and Pacific Affairs, also said last week that Clinton would not meet with dissidents. However, White House national security advisor Samuel Berger's response to recent media questions left an impression that officials may have given the idea a second thought.

In Monday's State Department news briefing, there were questions over whether the US government would reconsider the propriety of a meeting between Clinton and mainland Chinese dissidents or families of the victims of the Tiananmen Square massacre.
Questions regarding the president's itinerary and its possible revision must be made through the White House, Rubin said.

After several high-level meetings, state officials have decided that they can achieve their goal of promoting better human rights conditions in mainland China without a meeting between President Clinton and Chinese dissidents, he said.

Rubin illustrated the point with an earlier visit by Secretary of State Madeleine Albright to Beijing, where she met a broad spectrum of people including government officials as well as civilians such as outspoken pro-democracy intellectuals.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN-OWNED PLANT SIGNS US$150M CONTRACT WITH THAILAND'S PTT

TEXT.P: Tycons Worldwide Group (Thailand) Co., a Taiwan-owned wire, rod and iron product manufacturing plant, signed a 10-year contract with Petroleum Authority of Thailand (PTT) to buy 4,500 tons of liquefied petroleum gas annually.
Vichai Polvanich, senior vice president of the state-run PTT, said on Monday the deal is worth six billion baht (about US$150 million at Monday's exchange rate).

The Tycons plant is currently under construction and is located in an industrial estate in eastern Thailand's Rayong. It is expected to begin receiving the supply of liquefied gas next month when it is due to start its trail run.
Commercial operation of the Taiwanese plant, promoted by the Board of Investment of Thailand, is scheduled to start in January 1999.
Tycons' projected annual output includes 500,000 tons of wire rods and 60,000 tons of screws. Its production is split equally between domestic and export markets.
