DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWANESE COLLEGIAN GROUP APPEALS TO CLINTON IN STATEMENT

TEXT.P: A Taiwanese student group in the US released a statement Sunday, asking President Bill Clinton not to make any concessions to Beijing in regards to Washington's relationship with Taipei.
The statement comes as President Clinton prepares to leave for a nine-day visit to the Chinese mainland on Thursday.

Taiwanese Collegian said the US should make it clear to Beijing that it will support and respect any decision made by the people of Taiwan on the island's status and relationship with the mainland if such decisions are made through a democratic process.
To ensure peace in the Taiwan Strait, the US should recognize Taiwan and develop diplomatic ties with Taipei, the statement said.
"The United States, in accordance with the principles of international justice, should support Taiwan's right to international participation and membership in the United Nations," it added.
Taiwan has made no compromises in its transition to a democracy, the group said, despite Beijing's attempt to intimidate voters with its missile tests held in 1996 near the island.
The realization of a democratic and independent Taiwan is the best guarantee for the protection of American interests as well as peace, prosperity and stability in Asia, the statement concluded.

DOC.HEADLINE: GIO HEAD SAYS ROC DESERVES BETTER AND MORE FAIR TREATMENT

TEXT.P: A free and democratic Republic of China deserves better and more fair treatment from the international community, a government spokesman told an international panel on Monday.

Chen Chien-jen, ROC Government Information Office director general, said Taiwan should at least be allowed to join non-political international organizations such as the World Health Organization (WHO). Beijing recently blocked efforts by Taipei to join the WHO as an observer.

Chen made the comments in a discussion of Taiwan's foreign and security policy held at the Royal United Services Institute for Defense Studies. In his keynote speech, the government spokesman said as the ROC is now better off, it wants to be a useful member of the international community and play a more positive role in the world.

Being not a member of international organizations, Taiwan has been excluded from many important global endeavors. Its offer to provide aid to Rwanda was rejected, as was a donation to UNICEF, Chen said.

It has been made clear that Beijing has no intention of changing its hostile behavior toward Taipei now or in the foreseeable future. The blocking of Taiwan's entry to WHO is only one recent example, Chen said.
"This is certainly most unfortunate at a time when we are trying to resume the cross-strait dialogue and to improve relations," he added.
People in Taiwan "want to be treated fairly, justly and with dignity and not as second class citizens," he said.

As Taiwan now enjoys full democracy, the government simply can not ignore the public's demand for "international status commensurate with their country's importance in the global economy, and with the contributions the ROC is making to regional stability and world peace."
The diplomat-turned government spokesman said Taipei's foreign and security policies are "directed at ensuring our continued survival and development as we consolidate democracy on Taiwan."

Efforts by the international community to bring Beijing further into the international order are "fine as long as they do not involve sacrificing the interests of democratic countries such as mine which respect human rights," he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: SOUTH AFRICA ACCUSES BRITISH NEWSPAPER OF FABRICATING ARMS DEAL

TEXT.P: Johannesburg has accused a British newspaper of fabricating a report on a secret deal for weapons and military parts in return for lower oil prices between South Africa and Libya.

In a statement issued Monday, the presidential office said neither President Nelson Mandela nor the government and its agencies had entered into any talks -- let alone concluded any deals -- with Libya on an arms-for-oil agreement as reported by the London Sunday Telegraph.
If such a decision were ever made, the government would publicly declare its intentions and fully state its reasons for doing so, the statement said.

It added that "what is utterly disgusting about this article is that it is a pure fabrication, invented by the newspaper and its unnamed sources .... Besides the other untruths contained in the article, the references to chemical and biological weapons defy the imagination."
The government said it would have expected a newspaper that claimed a measure of integrity to have at least tried to verify its information with South African government officials.

"We are therefore compelled to conclude that those who elected to peddle these untruths are either part of a massive disinformation campaign against our new democracy, or they have allowed themselves to be used in such a campaign," the statement said.
Referring to the United Nations arms embargo against Libya, it said South Africa has abided by the UN decision on Libya.

DOC.HEADLINE: FORMER SOUTH AFRICAN PRESDIENT P.W. BOTHA REMARRIES

TEXT.P: Former South African President P.W. Botha, 82, married legal secretary Barbara Robertson, 57, in a ceremony at his home in Western Cape province Monday. The wedding ceremony was attended by about 14 guests, including Botha's daughters, son and close friends.
In an interview in Sunday's Afrikaans newspaper Rapport, Botha spoke of his sadness at losing his wife Elize just over a year ago. They had been married for 54 years.
Botha was introduced to Robertson by one of his daughters at the launch of his autobiography "Voice in the Wilderness" last year.

DOC.HEADLINE: US NOT LIKELY TO SIGN NEW COMMUNIQUE DURING CLINTON-JIANG TALKS

TEXT.P: US President Bill Clinton will not sign a communique with mainland China that relates to Taiwan in his upcoming visit to the mainland, ROC Vice Foreign Minister David Lee said on Tuesday.

Lee said US policy-making officials have openly stated or assured Taiwan in the past month that the US will not sign a fourth communique. They said the US will not hurt the interests of Taiwan nor change its arms sales policy toward Taiwan, he added.
On the likely result of Clinton's meeting with his mainland counterpart Jiang Zemin, Lee said that he believes that the US would not sign the fourth communique with the mainland.
It is also unlikely that the US will commit to any written statement regarding the "three no's" when Clinton meets with his mainland counterpart Jiang Zemin, Lee said.

The "three no's" refer to no US support for Taiwan independence, no US support for "two Chinas" or "one China, one Taiwan", and no US support for Taiwan's bid to enter international organizations that require sovereign statehood.
The US would at most issue a "fact sheet," which Lee said is not as binding as a communique or joint statement.

He said as the two sides of the Taiwan Strait are poised to resume talks, any gesture that shows the US is leaning favorably toward mainland China could affect the prospect of resumed cross-strait talks.

Lee reiterated the ROC government's position toward the Clinton-Jiang talks, saying that he hopes the US government will continue to abide by the 1979 Taiwan Relations Act, the six promises to Taiwan in 1982 and the review of policy toward the ROC in 1994.

The ROC has no intention of interfering with US efforts to develop relations with mainland China, he added. In fact, it is happy to see that the Clinton-Jiang talks will contribute to peace in the Taiwan Strait, stability in the Asia Pacific region, and contribute to reforms, democracy and human rights in the mainland.
But he stressed the engagement between Beijing and Washington should not be conducted at the expanse of the ROC, and should not have any negative impact on ROC-US relations.
Lee urged the US to develop parallel relations with the ROC as it engages with the mainland, adding that the ROC cherishes the same ideals of human rights, freedom and democracy as does the US.

DOC.HEADLINE: REFUGEE STATUS TO CHINESE IN AUSTRALIA ANGERS BEIJING

TEXT.P: Beijing expressed its strong opposition to an Australian federal judge's ruling that granted refugee status to a Chinese couple and their son due to possible persecution under mainland China's one-child policy.
In a dispatch from Beijing, the Australian Associated Press reported that China's State Family Planning Commission was angry over the decision because it was contrary to the UN covenant on refugees.
A 1989 ruling made allowances for Chinese citizens who had children abroad and returned to the mainland, the report said.
Australian Federal Court judge Robert French last week ruled in favor of refugee status for Chen Renbing, his wife and their two-year-old son. The couple left China illegally in 1994.
French said the child would be persecuted as illegitimate in China as he was born outside family planning guidelines and the birth was not registered in China, according to the report.
The Department of Immigration in Canberra said the case was unlikely to have implications for Australian immigration policy.

DOC.HEADLINE: US-BASED SCHOLARS REFUTE REPORT IMPLYING TAIWAN IS 'TROUBLEMAKER'
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, June 22 (CNA) (By Jay Chen and Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: Some scholars here came out in defense of Taiwan after a Washington Post story implied that the island was a "troublemaker" causing friction between Beijing and Washington.

The report in Monday's issue said when mainland China lobbed missiles into the Taiwan Strait in March 1996 as Taiwan was preparing for its first popular presidential election, it brought relations between Beijing and Washington to a nadir.

At that time, US officials including then US Defense Secretary William Perry, then US Secretary of State Warren Christopher and then national Security Advisor Anthony Lake all voiced warnings of "grave consequences" -- an implied military response -- if Beijing were to attack Taiwan.
The report detailed how the US handled the missile crisis and how the face-off over Taiwan later led to a strategic partnership.
Yeh Wan-hui, researcher at the Heritage Foundation, said Charles Freeman, former assistant secretary of defense, who is a major source in the Washington Post story, affected the views of the report.

Yeh identified two fallacies in the story. The report states that the US Congress, after a "US$5 million lobbying campaign by Taiwan," voted overwhelmingly to grant President Lee Teng-hui a visa to visit the US. Yeh said if US lawmakers could be bought, then all bills could clear through the Congress without hitch.
The second fallacy was that President Lee's visit to the US alone led to the missile crisis and the deteriorating relations between the US and mainland China, Yeh said.
But he noted that even under Beijing's new "three no's" policy, the US has not prohibited high-ranking Taiwan officials from visiting the US.

The "three no's" refers to no US support for Taiwan independence, no US support for a "one China, one Taiwan," and no US support for Taiwan's bid to enter international organizations that require statehood.

Clinton was lauded by the American public for his decision to order a large contingent of US naval ships into the region as tensions across the strait grew, Yeh said. Freeman is now offering his opinion which may become more common among US policymakers if it is not refuted.

James Przystup, director of Asian Studies Center of the Heritage Foundation, said that he believes the US Congress and most Americans do not support the views of Freeman nor those of Joseph Nye, a former assistant secretary of defense.

Both have recently written that Washington should review its arms sales policy to Taiwan. Nye also suggested that the US explicitly warn Taipei that if the island were to declare independence, the US would not provide protection.

John Tai, research associate of the Center for International and Strategic Studies, said policy-making circles in Washington are not very clear on the real goals behind President Lee's "pragmatic diplomacy" and believe the stalled cross-strait talks should be blamed on Taiwan.

Tai said the US government will not likely change its current policy and it will play a more aggressive role in cross-strait ties, but Taiwan should not give the impression that it is dragging its feet to resume talks and should display more sincerity in cross-strait dialogues.

DOC.HEADLINE: 17 US CONGRESSMEN URGE CLINTON NOT TO CODIFY 'THREE NO'S'
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, June 22 (CNA) (By Jay Chen and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: Seventeen members of the US House of Representatives have sent a joint letter to President Bill Clinton urging him to reject Beijing's proposal to codify the so-called "Three No's" policy toward Taiwan.
The congressmen, led by Rep. Peter Deutsch (D-FL), addressed the letter to Clinton on June 19, a week before his departure for a high-profile state visit to mainland China.

"First, we urge you to reject any plans to codify any aspect of US policy toward Taiwan which would deny Taiwan's existence as a separate political entity and deny the Taiwanese people their right to self-determination as defined in Article 1 of the United Nations charter," the congressmen said in the letter.

More specifically, they asked Clinton to refrain from a commitment to formalize the three policy points generally referred to as the "three noes." These are: no support for the "One China, One Taiwan" policy, no support for Taiwanese independence, and no support for Taiwan's membership in international organizations.

Meanwhile, the congressmen urged Clinton to call on Beijing to renounce the use of force against Taiwan and to cease blocking Taiwan's bids for membership in international organizations such as the United Nations, the World Health Organization and the World Trade Organization.

More important, the congressmen said, Clinton should reaffirm to Beijing the terms of the Taiwan Relations Act with regard to both the continuation of arms sales to Taiwan and the peaceful resolution of disputes across the Taiwan Strait.

The other 16 signatories to the letter were Gerald Solomon (R-NY), chairman of the House Rules Committee, Sherrod Brown (D-OH), Tom Lantos (D-CA), Peter King (R-NY), Dan Burton (R-IN), Steve Chabot (R-OH), Dana Rohrabacher (R-CA), Bob Wexler (D-FL), Rober Andrews (D-NJ), Steve Rothman (D-NJ), Donald Payne (D-NJ), Brad Sherman (R-CA), Ileana Ros-Lehtinen (R-FL), Robert Menendez (D-NJ), Howard Berman (D-CA) and Pete Sessions (R-TX).

Twelve influential senators also sent a smiliar letter to Clinton earlier this month reiterating their opposition to enshrining the "three noes" in any formal document during Clinton's June 25-July 3 mainland visit.

DOC.HEADLINE: COSTA RICA COMMITTED TO HELPING ROC JOIN INTERNATIONAL GROUPS
DOC.DATELINE: Panama City, June 22 (CNA) (By Edward Chen & Lin Wen-fen)

TEXT.P: Costa Rica President Miguel Angel Rodriguez on Monday told visiting legislators from the Republic of China that his country will continue to support Taipei's efforts to join international organizations.

Rodriguez lauded Taiwan for the great progress it has made in democratic reforms and economic development. He said the ROC government's ability to cope with the Asian financial turmoil has kept possible damage on the island to a minimum.

He also expressed hope that Taiwan businessmen can increase their investments in Costa Rica to help develop the economy, adding that his government offers a variety of incentives to foreign investors.

Lin Che-fu, head of the seven-member ROC legislative delegation, told Rodriguez that Costa Rica serves as a good role model in carrying out democratic reform and providing human rights protection. He added that he hopes the ROC and Costa Rica can maintain friendly ties and increase the promotion of cultural exchanges.
The mission was accompanied by ROC Ambassador to Costa Rica Mao Kao-wen. Other members of the delegation were Wu Hui-tsu, Ke Yu-chin, Lee Chun-yi, Tsaur Eel-jong, Hsu Shao-ping and Chang Ching-chen.

Earlier in the day, the ROC legislative delegation called on Costa Rica Foreign Minister Roberto Rojas Lopez to exchange views on issues of mutual concern. Lopez reaffirmed his country's commitment to helping the ROC expand its presence in international organizations.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN CLAIMS FLEXIBILITY IN APEC FISHERY TALKS
DOC.DATELINE: Kuching, Malaysia, June 23 (CNA) (By C. L. Chi and Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: Taiwan seems to be demonstrating greater flexibility in its stance on fishery tariffs in an industry and trade ministers' meeting of the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation forum, which officially opened Monday.

Australia, Canada, New Zealand and the United States proposed the Early Voluntary Sectoral Liberalization package at last November's APEC meeting in Vancouver to promote free trade in 15 sectors among all member countries by 2020. Nine sectors, including the fishery industry, were selected as priority targets whose customs duties are scheduled to be slashed to zero by 2005.

Following a series of sideline meetings over the past few days, Taiwan, mainland China and South Korea, which had been opposed to eliminating the tariffs, seem more flexible, although Japan, in response to strong domestic pressure, continues to oppose the plan.

Republic of China Economic Affairs Minister Wang Chih-kang left Kuching to visit Kuala Lumpur Tuesday morning, missing the day's meeting. Attending in his place were ROC Vice Economic Affairs Minister Li Yi-fu and Board of Foreign Trade Director-General Chen Juei-long.

Fishermen Rights Promotion Association representative Chen Hsiu-hsien, who took part in a sideline APEC meeting on Sunday, complained about Wang's absence from Tuesday's meeting. Under APEC rules, ministers who do not voice objections to the plan are considered as agreeing to it.

Wang did discuss the proposal in a sideline meeting with US Trade Representative Charlene Barshefsky on Monday. Saying Taiwan remains flexible toward the issue, Wang told Barshefsky that it is hard for Taiwan to lower fishery tariffs to zero by 2005. Implementation of the plan should be carried out only after all member states have agreed to it.

Taiwan's softening of its stance has been widely viewed as a result of US pressure, since the island is close to signing a formal agreement with the United States on its bid to join the World Trade Organization.
The ROC Council of Agriculture arranged for Chen and Barshefsky to meet on Tuesday to assuage the discontent of the Taiwan's fishery sector. No agreement, however, was reached during the meeting.
Taiwan currently maintains an average customs duty of 8 percent on fishery imports. The COA has said that it hopes to lower duties to 5 percent by 2019.

Meanwhile, officials with the ROC Ministry of Economic Affairs were reluctant to comment on whether Wang will meet with ranking Malaysian government officials during his stay in Kuala Lumpur, saying only that the minister will pay a visit to Malaysia's "multimedia super corridor."

DOC.HEADLINE: CHRISTIANS WRITE CLINTON OVER RELIGIOUS PERSECUTION
DOC.DATELINE: New York, June 22 (CNA) (By David Wang & Eva Chen)

TEXT.P: Hundreds of Christians from mainland China's Fujian Province co-signed last week an open letter to US President Bill Clinton, calling on him to tell his mainland Chinese counterpart, Jiang Zemin, personally about Fujian local officials' acts of religious persecution.

The Fujian Christians, most of whom now reside in New York, said in the letter that some local government officials in Fujian are dismantling churches that were built with donations from overseas Christian Chinese.
Those bridges, roads and schools, even though they, too, were funded by overseas Christian Chinese from Fujian Province, meanwhile, are being left intact, according to the letter.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT LEE MEETS CZECH FIRST LADY

TEXT.P: President Lee Teng-hui met with Madame Dagmar Havlova, first lady of the Czech Republic, on Tuesday for wide-ranging talks in an amicable atmosphere.

During their meeting, President Lee expressed admiration and respect for Czech President Vaclav Havel for his dedication to promoting democracy, freedom and human rights both in his writings and throughout his political career.
Lee also lauded Madame Havlova for her operatic achievements and for her charitable work.
Madame Havlova had been a prima donna at the Theater Vinohrady in Prague before she married Havel, a playwright-turned-politician. Havlova now devotes herself to charity work.
Lee said although one may play different roles at different stages of life, the basic spirit is consistent. "I think the most important is to enrich one's mind and spiritual life," he said.

The president told Madame Havlova that he has initiated numerous reforms, particularly spiritual reforms, in recent years in hopes of building Taiwan into a mature democracy in which all people lead prosperous, peaceful and spiritually enriched lives.
Madame Havlova arrived in Taipei Monday for an eight-day private visit in the company of first daughter Nina Veskrnova, her husband Shalev Ad-EI and a four-member entourage.

While here, Madame Havlova will visit the National Fu Hsing Dramatic Arts Academy, the National Palace Museum, a government-funded Chinese herbal research center and the Buddhist Compassion Relief Tzu Chi Foundation.
In addition, the Czech first lady will meet with local business and industry leaders to solicit Taiwan investment in her home country.

The Czech Republic recognizes Beijing but maintains friendly, substantive ties with the Republic of China. President Havel once appealed in a speech to the United Nations General Assembly for the Republic Of China's re-entry to the world body.

ROC Vice President Lien Chan made a private visit to Prague in 1995. Hualon Textile Co., one of Taiwan's largest textile companies, has set up a production facility in the central European country, and the state-run Aerospace Industry Development Corp. has signed a joint-venture deal with Prague-based Aero Vodochody Co. to produce small aircraft.

DOC.HEADLINE: NT DOLLAR DROPS

TEXT.P: The New Taiwan dollar fell NT$0.335 against the US dollar on the Taipei foreign exchange on Tuesday, closing at NT$34.202. The local currency opened at the day's high of 33.860 and had a low of 34.285. Interbank US dollar transactions totaled US$152 million.

DOC.HEADLINE: SHARE PRICES DOWN ON TAIEX

TEXT.P: Share prices opened high but closed lower on the Taipei Stock Exchange Tuesday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, dropping 59.55 points to close at 7,633.36.
The bourse opened at the day's high of 7,729.91 and fell to 7,598.27 before rebounding.
Losers outnumbered gainers 307 to 113, with 65 issues remaining unchanged.

A total of 1.77 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$95.63 billion, a decline from the previous session, which saw 2.46 billion stocks change hands on a market turnover of NT$120.15 billion.
Dealers attributed the day's light trading to mixed sentiments over the market's long-term prospects and a wait-and-see attitude from investors.

Seven of the eight major categories lost ground, with pulp and paper issues moving down the most at 1.6 percent, followed by electrical stocks at 1.3 percent, plastics and chemical shares at 0.8 percent, bank and insurance stocks at 0.6 percent, foodstuff issues and cement shares both at 0.5 percent and construction issues at 0.4 percent.
No categories gained ground, although textiles remained unchanged.

The 10 listed companies with the largest turnovers in Tuesday's trading were Taiwan Tea Corp., United Micro Electronics, CIS Technology, Winbond Electronics Corp., Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing, Compeq Manufacturing, ASE, Compal Electronic Inc., Mitac International Corp. and Inventec Corp.

DOC.HEADLINE: JAPAN SET TO OVERHAUL ITS EDUCATIONAL SYSTEM

TEXT.P: As Japan enters the next century, large-scale changes are planned for its educational system, with reductions of nearly one-third to its elementary and junior high school curriculums.
The Curriculum Council, an advisory council to the Education Ministry, made public Monday its revised draft of the government's guidelines.

"With the report, Japan's education will make a major turn, as schools shift from a place for teachers to teach to a place for students to actively learn," said Shumon Miura, chairman of the advisory panel, after submitting the report to Education Minister Nobutaka Machimura Monday afternoon.

Under the draft, which will be finalized in July, Japan's educational system will likely become more individualized, empowering local schools to make many of their own decisions for the first time. For example, schools will determine for themselves how much classroom time will be allocated to each subject.

Under the proposed changes, students graduated from elementary schools are expected to have mastered only 825 Chinese characters compared to 1,006 at present. As for senior high schools, the number of credits required for graduation will be reduced from 80 to 74.

To help students better cope with the country's push toward internationalization, the report suggests that a foreign language course other than English be made mandatory for junior and senior high school students. It also suggests introducing foreign cultures and English as part of general studies in elementary schools.

DOC.HEADLINE: NEW PARTY TO ESTABLISH BEIJING OFFICE

TEXT.P: Chen Kuei-miao, head of the Mainland Affairs Committee of the pro-unification New Party, left for Beijing on Tuesday to make arrangements for the establishment of a New Party office in Beijing.

Chen is scheduled to arrive in Beijing Tuesday night and will meet with Taiwan businessmen and mainland Chinese officials in charge of Taiwan affairs, said New Party election manager Jaw Shau-kong on Tuesday.
The New Party's planned Beijing office, Jaw said, will offer services to Taiwan people in the mainland at a time when bilateral communication channels remain clogged.

Commenting on Mainland Affairs Council Vice Chairman Lin Chong-pin's remarks Monday that the United States wants to set up a Taipei-Washington-Beijing dialogue channel after US President Bill Clinton meets mainland Chinese President Jiang Zemin later this week, Jaw said the New Party prefers instead to help set up a "second communication channel" between Taiwan and mainland China.
Meanwhile, New Party mayoral candidate Wang Chien-shien promised to, if elected, open service centers in mainland Chinese cities with a large number of Taiwan businesspeople.

Chou Yang-shan, head of the New Party's National Development and Election Committee, warned that Taiwan will be isolated in trilateral Washington-Beijing-Taipei relations if Taiwan fails to improve ties with the mainland, adding that closer and improved Washington-Beijing ties will hurt two-way Taipei-Washington relations, he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: NO FOREIGN EMBASSIES PLAN EVACUATION BECAUSE OF VIRAL OUTBREAK

TEXT.P: Senior diplomatic officials denied reports on Tuesday that some foreign business people have evacuated their children from Taiwan because of the outbreak of a killer intestinal virus.

"Although the foreign community here has shown concern about the enterovirus epidemic, we have not been informed that business people from any foreign country have evacuated their kids simply for that reason," said a Foreign Ministry official.

Ann Breiter, acting spokesperson for the Taipei Office of the American Institute in Taiwan (AIT), or the de facto US embassy in the Republic of China, told CNA that the office has no plans to evacuate children of American expatriates despite the viral outbreak.

Breiter further said the AIT even has not advised US nationals to evacuate their children from Taiwan. "We have just suggested them to contact Taiwan's health authorities, particularly the Department of Health, for detailed information about the epidemic," she added.
The AIT also has not issued any travel warning to discourage ordinary American people from traveling to Taiwan for the time being, Breiter noted.

"We plan to brief US nationals here on the current situation of the enterovirus epidemic, but the exact briefing date has yet to be decided," said Breiter, who attended a Foreign Ministry-sponsored briefing on the epidemic on Monday.
Among all major countries, the United States has the largest number of expatriates in Taiwan.
Many other foreign embassies and representative offices also said they have not advised their nationals to evacuate their children from Taiwan to shun the epidemic.

A spokesperson for the Canadian representative office told CNA that many young foreign students have left Taiwan for their home countries in recent days simply because the Taipei American School began summer vacation last week.

In accordance with the Canadian government regulations, the spokesperson said the Canadian office has informed Canada's Foreign Ministry and health authorities of the enterovirus outbreak here. "However, we have not advised Canadian people not to travel to Taiwan for sightseeing or business," he added.

Canadians were informed in an official travel bulletin issued on June 16 that the enterovirus outbreak has been reported in Chile, the Philippines, Indonesia and Taiwan. The bulletin also said children under 12 years of age are susceptible to the virus and that there are already casualties in Taiwan. The bulletin only provides information and does not discourage Canadians from traveling to this island.

Meanwhile, an official with the Mexico's representative office in Taipei said he cannot confirms a newspaper report that some Mexican diplomats stationed here have sent their children back to their home country to protect them from being infected by the killer virus.

The enterovirus outbreak has so far claimed the lives of at least 50 babies and toddlers in Taiwan. Although the number of enterovirus infections has declined here, health officials said, it will take one more month or two before the warning against the epidemic can be lifted.

Infants and young children are most susceptible to enterovirus. Early symptoms of the infection resemble the flu, with fever, headache and vomiting. Ulcers or blisters in the mouth and a rash on the palms and feet can also develop. Later, possible deadly complications include encephalitis, meningitis and acute inflammation of the heart muscle. Parents are advised to keep their children away from public places, and make sure that their children change clothes and wash hands frequently.

DOC.HEADLINE: CLINTON SAYS HE WILL REAFFIRM COMMITMENTS TO MAINLAND CHINA
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, June 23 (CNA) (By Jay Chen and Ben Wu)

TEXT.P: President Bill Clinton has said he hopes his upcoming trip to mainland China will promote greater understanding between the two countries.
Clinton made the remarks in a June 19 roundtable discussion with mainland Chinese journalists.

Taipei is concerned over whether Clinton will openly support the so-called "three noes" -- no to an independent Taiwan, no to a "two Chinas" or "one China, one Taiwan" policy and no to Taiwan's joining the United Nations -- during his visit.

When asked about his intentions regarding the three noes, Clinton said he will re-affirm previously made US commitments. "Our relationship is embodied in the three communiques and the Taiwan Relations Act passed by our Congress," he said.

"And our long friendship with and economic relationships with the people of Taiwan clearly must be understood by them (the people of Taiwan) and by the people of China within the context of the three communiques and our support for the One China policy.
"And all of our decisions going forward will be made within that framework, so I will clearly make that statement when I'm in China to the Chinese leaders."
Clinton said he hopes to discuss human rights and the rule of law during his visit, according to transcripts of the discussion.

DOC.HEADLINE: CAL RATED WORLD'S FOURTH MOST DANGEROUS INTERNATIONAL AIRLINE
DOC.DATELINE: Geneva, June 23 (CNA) (By Maurus Yang and Lin Wen-fen)

TEXT.P: Taiwan's China Airlines is the world's fourth most dangerous international airline in terms of the likelihood of a crash, according to a report from a US-based financial consultancy.
Aero Peru was named by Airsafe Financial as most dangerous, followed by Cubana Airlines and Africa's Air Zimbabwe. The list was based on global airline's aviation disaster records since 1970.
Rounding out the top 10 were, in order, Royal Jordanian, Turkish Airlines, Air India, Egypt Air, US-based Air Tran/Valujet and Korea Air.
The financial organization also listed five airlines that have perfect aviation records: US-based Southwest, Sweden's SAS, America West, Australia's Qantas and Air Jamaica.
Meanwhile, the world's most dangerous airports are located in Hong Kong, San Francisco and southern France's Nice, according to the Association of Pilots of International Federations.

Hong Kong's airport is seen as dangerous because of the number of skyscrapers surrounding it, while heavy air traffic makes San Francisco's airport dangerous. Both heavy traffic and a large number of private airplanes make Nice's airport dangerous to international pilots.

DOC.HEADLINE: WORLD'S WEALTHIEST INCLUDE EIGHT FROM TAIWAN
DOC.DATELINE: New York, June 22 (CNA) (By J.J. Huang & Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: More Taiwan businessmen were listed among the world's wealthiest individuals this year than last, despite Asia's financial crisis.
Eight Taiwan entrepreneurs were included in Forbes magazine's list of the world's wealthiest people this year, compared to six last year. The list was released by the magazine Monday.

Tsai Wan-lin, chairman of Cathay Life Insurance, was the world's 19th and Taiwan's wealthiest individual with a net worth of US$8.5 billion, down about US$2.8 billion from last year because of Asia's financial meltdown, according to Forbes.
Tsai, 73, who started out as a grocer, is Asia's third richest entrepreneur, and his sources of income include insurance and financial services and construction companies.
Wang Yung-ching, founder and chairman of Formosa Plastics Group, was 81st in the world with a net worth totaling US$3.9 billion, down US$1.6 billion from last year.

Douglas Hsu, chairman of the Far Eastern Group, whose net worth reached US$2 billion, was cited by Forbes as one of the most influential entrepreneurs in Taiwan. Hsu, a prominent art collector, is on the New York Metropolitan Museum of Art's board of directors.
Jeffrey Koo, chairman of Chinatrust Group, is Taiwan's fourth richest and the world's 182nd wealthiest entrepreneur with a net worth of US$1.7 billion.

Four other Taiwanese entrepreneurs made the list were Terry Kuo, chairman of Hon Hai Precision Industry; Chiao Ting-piao, chairman of Walsin Lihwa Electric Wire and Cable; Tsai Chi-chien, chairman of Bao Cheng Industrial; and Chang Chien-sheng, chairman of ASE Semiconductors. The four men's net worth ranged from US$1.6 billion to US$1.1 billion.
Microsoft Chairman Bill Gates, whose net worth jumped 40 percent from last year to US$51 billion this year, topped the list for the fourth straight year.

DOC.HEADLINE: NO LINK BETWEEN ENTEROVIRAL INFECTION AND FMD EPIDEMIC: DOH

TEXT.P: Taiwan health officials on Tuesday denied a possible link between the enteroviral infection that is affecting mainly infants, and the foot-and-mouth disease (FMD) epidemic that decimated the island's hog population last year.

Hsu Kuo-hsiung, acting director of the Bureau of Communicable Disease Control under the Department of Health (DOH), said it is very clear that the enterovirus that has claimed the lives of at least 50 children is totally different from the FMD virus that swept Taiwan's pig farms last year.

Several professors at National Chengkung University Hospital in Tainan, southern Taiwan, suspect that the enterovirus might be related to, or a mutant of, the FMD virus. They said that the inefficient methods used to dispose of nearly 4 million FMD-infected pig carcasses last March might have contaminated the ground water in certain areas.

Hsieh Wen-ju, one of three epidemiologists called in earlier this month from the US Disease Control and Prevention Center to assist in tracking down the cause of the outbreak, agreed with Hsu's statement. Hsieh said that the FMD virus only affects cloven-hoofed animals and is not communicable to humans.

Panicked parents have been pressing the authorities to tell them whether the epidemic has been brought under control. Last Monday, the DOH announced that the epidemic was abating, evidenced by a descending curve in the official death toll. However, just four days after the announcement, seven more children fell victim to complications caused by the infection, such as pulmonary edema, meningitis, encephalitis, or inflammation of the heart.

Alarmed by the new fatalities, which included the first death in eastern Taiwan's Ilan County, the DOH has suggested that children's summer camps and festivals be scrapped immediately in an effort to curb the spread of the epidemic. They also advise parents not to take children aged under 12 to swimming pools.

The identity of the virus is of great concern. On June 16, the DOH said the results of an autopsy on an 8-year-old girl confirmed that enterovirus type-71 was behind the viral epidemic. The autopsy revealed the presence of enterovirus type-71 in the girl's spinal cord and medulla. However, subsequent autopsies failed to isolate the virus, and DOH officials said more autopsy results will be needed to confirm the cause of the epidemic for sure.

Hsu stressed that the fact that no enterovirus type-71 has been found does not necessarily mean the victims did not succumb to the virus, pointing out that inefficient sampling or poor cultivation methods could lead to inaccurate results.

In an attempt to allay public anxiety, the officials pointed out that most infected children who develop the common symptoms of fever and an ulcerated rash on the hands, feet and mouth, will recover, although they warned that if they develop an unrelieved high fever, nausea, headache, rapid breathing, and lack of appetite, parents should take them to see a doctor.

According to the latest statistics issued by the DOH on Tuesday afternoon, the virus has so far claimed the lives of 50 children, with 248 children still hospitalized. Northern Taiwan has reported 126 cases with 18 deaths, the central area has 77 reported cases with 26 deaths, the southern area 42 cases with five deaths and the western area three cases with one death.

DOC.HEADLINE: PROTESTS PLANNED FOR EVE OF CLINTON-JIANG MEETING

TEXT.P: Several local pro-Taiwan independence groups are planning a series of protests and demonstrations on the eve of US President Bill Clinton's visit to mainland China.
A representative of the groups called on Foreign Affairs Minister Jason Hu on Tuesday afternoon to express their concern about Clinton's impending meeting with his mainland counterpart Jiang Zemin.

On Wednesday morning, the Action Alliance against Aggression will submit a petition containing the signatures of 5,000 local people to the Taipei office of the American Institute in Taiwan (AIT), the de facto US embassy here.
Alliance members will then begin a sit-in protest in front of the AIT office which is planned to continue until Saturday.

On Wednesday night, the alliance will hold a candle-lit vigil at the 2-28 Memorial Park in downtown Taipei which will be attended by opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) legislators Hung Chi-chang and Lin Cho-shui, and by DPP official Frank Hsieh.
The alliance spokesman explained that the vigil is being held to express their feeling of the inalienable right to Taiwan independence.

Also on Saturday, the 350-plus members of the Taiwan Association of University Professors will hold a large demonstration to underscore their concern over the Clinton-Jiang talks, and to highlight their determination to seek independence for Taiwan.
Meanwhile, the Taiwan Independence Party will protest in front of the Kaohsiung AIT office on Friday, and will conduct a seminar on the Clinton-Jiang meeting on Saturday.

DOC.HEADLINE: HONDURAN AMBASSADOR PRESENTS CREDENTIALS TO FOREIGN MINISTER

TEXT.P: Margarita Duron De Galvez, the newly appointed ambassador of the Republic of Honduras to the Republic of China, on Tuesday presented her credentials to Foreign Minister Jason Hu.
Duran was accompanied by Francisco L.Y. Hwang, director of the Central & South American Affairs Department, and Feng Chi-tai, director of the Protocol Department of the Ministry of Foreign Affairs.
The new ambassador was born in 1937. After graduating from Complutense University in Madrid, Spain, she continued her studies at Tampa University in the US, and at England's Cambridge University.
She worked as a journalist from 1967 to 1979 before embarking on a diplomatic career. She has occupied various diplomatic posts in Italy, Spain, Britain, and the US.
The veteran diplomat served as director of the Export and Investment Promotion Department of the Honduran Foreign Ministry before being appointed as ambassador to Taipei.

DOC.HEADLINE: SUSPENSION OF MILITARY DRILLS NOT LINKED TO CLINTON-JIANG MEETING

TEXT.P: The Ministry of National Defense (MND) said on Tuesday that the ROC armed forces will temporarily suspend all large-scale military exercises planned for late June as part of a trimming program due to start on July 1.

MND spokesman Kung Fang-ting said at a regular news conference that the decision has nothing to do with the upcoming summit between US President Bill Clinton and mainland Chinese President Jiang Zemin later this week, and called on the public not to speculate over the reason behind the move.

Kung added that the MND informed all concerned parties of the decision as far back as April, when it ordered all troops to suspend large-scale military maneuvers and live-fire training drills from the end of June in order to more efficiently carry out the trimming program scheduled for the second half of this year.

The MND spokesman also denied a recent report by the Washington Post that a missile fired by mainland China passed almost directly over Taipei City during the 1996 missile crisis in the Taiwan Strait. He said it would be impossible for a ballistic missile to pass undetected through the skies above Taipei, and emphasized that the military is on permanent alert to monitor military movements in neighboring countries.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN, HK ACTIVISTS SET SAIL FOR DISPUTED ISLANDS

TEXT.P: Braving bad weather, activists from Taiwan, Hong Kong and the United States set sail for the disputed Tiaoyutai islands in the East China Sea Tuesday evening in a further attempt to claim them as Chinese territory.
The ships operated by activists from Taiwan and Chinese communities in the US left the Shenao fishing port near Juifang township on northern Taiwan coast at 8 p.m.
They were later joined by the 100-ton vessel Diao Yu Tai, with some 30 Hong Kong activists aboard, in waters near the northern Taiwan port of Keelung. The Diao Yu Tai left Hong Kong last Sunday.
This was the first time that Taiwan and Hong Kong activists have launched a joint camptain after the former British colony reverted to mainland Chinese rule last July.
Taipei County Councilor Chin Chieh-shou, also leader of the Taiwan activists, said prior to his departure for the Taioyutais that they originally planned to start the voyage on Wednesday.
"After careful considerations, we decided to advance the departure time in hopes to reach the destination early in Wednesday morning," said Chin, a member from the right-wing New Party.

"Hopefully, we can break Japanese coast guard's blockade and land on one of the uninhabited islands before dawn," Chin said, adding they intend to remove a wooden Japanese national flag erected there last year.

Earlier in the day, Chin led a group of activists to protest Japan's control of the disputed islands in front of the Japanese Interchange Association (JIA), which represents Japanese interests in Taiwan in the absence of formal diplomatic ties.

A JIA official accepted a protest letter from the demonstrators. This was the first time that the de facto Japanese embassy here had given a goodwill response to such protests. "Against this backdrop, we have decided not to take with us crossbows on our trip to the Tiaoyutais," Chin said.

He further said all Taiwan activists agree with a recent overture by the Japanese consul-general to Hong Kong that the disputes surrounding the islands be resolved through peaceful, rational consultations.

"Nevertheless, the target Japan intends to negotiate is apparently mainland China. We must remind the Japanese that the Tiaoyutais are under the jurisdiction of the Ilan County Government under the Republic of China," Chin said.

Chin made the assurances that the activists will declare Chiense sovereignty over the Tiaoyutais in a peaceful, rational manner. "We hope Japanese coast guard patrol boats will not ram our vessels this time. Otherwise, we'll stage a long-term sit-in in front of the residence of the de facto Japanese ambassador to Taiwan after we return from the trip."
In October 1996, Chin and other Taiwan and Hong Kong activists made a brief landing on one of the disputed islands and planted two flags, one each from the Republic of China and mainland China.
Japanese coast guards, however, forced the activists away from the islet and removed the flags.
Last year, a group of Taiwan and Hong Kong activists, also led by Chin, was prevented from approaching the islands by a large number of Japanese coast guard patrol ships and military helicopters.

The annual landing attempts by Taiwan and Hong Kong activists began after the ultra-rightist Japanese Youth Federation erected a makeshift lighthouse on one of the islands in July 1996 and Japan later included the Tiaoyutais in its 200-mile exclusive economic zone.
The event also marked the death of David Chan, a Hong Kong activist who drowned after jumping into the sea when Japanese coast guard vessels blocked his ship near the archipelago in September 1996.

DOC.HEADLINE: REGIONAL MEETING OF AMNESTY INT'L TO OPEN IN TAOYUAN WEDNESDAY

TEXT.P: The 1998 Asian Pacific Regional Conference of Amnesty International will be held Wednesday in Taoyuan.
Founded in 1961 in London, Amnesty International is an independent worldwide human-rights organization, which gave a helping hand to Taiwan's former dissidents 20 years ago.
Some 50 representatives from 18 other Asian countries will come here to take part in the meeting.

Taiwan participants in the annual meeting will include Hsu Hsin-liang, out-going chairman of the major opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP); Lin Yi-hsiung, chairman-elect of DPP; Annette Hsiu-lien Lu, magistrate of Taoyuan County, and other former dissidents of Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: MEXICAN 'WOLF MAN' AWARDED HONORARY DIPLOMA

TEXT.P: A "wolf man" from Mexico was awarded an honorary diploma from a primary school in the central Taiwan city of Taichung on Tuesday for his dedication to public services.

Jesus Manuel Fajardo Aceves, who has been called "wolf man" since childhood because his face is shrouded in thick, dark hair as a result of a genetic disorder, said he was excited by receiving the first school diploma in his life.

"It's a dream come true," said an emotional Fajardo when he received the honorary diploma from Hsu Hsien-chung, president of the Wen Hsin Elementary School in Taichung. "Only two words -- appreciation and gratitude -- can describe my feelings at the moment."

The Spanish-speaking 24-year-old Mexican further said he highly cherishes the diploma even though he cannot read the Chinese letters printed on it. "The diploma serves as a stimulant to encourage me to pursue further study."

Speaking on the same occasion, Hsu said the school has decided to present an honorary diploma to the 24-year-old Mexican man in recognition of his optimism, urge to learn and devotion to public services.
"The move is also aimed at calling for government attention to educational problems surrounding the underprivileged," Hsu said.

Fajardo has received only three years of formal education because of proverty and his extraordinary appearance. He arrived in Taiwan in April for a six-month goodwill visit at the invitation of the Guinness Museum of World Records in Taichung.
A victim of hirsutism, a genetically inherited disorder which was passed down by his great grandmother, Fajardo said he was generally shunned by society as a youth.

Fajardo, who stands 160 cm tall, became a circus performer shortly after leaving a primary school in Mexico at the age of 13. He said he is satisfied with his current way of life and has no intention of seeking to change his appearance.

Fajardo got married during his years as a circus performer, but the marriage did not last, and before coming to Taiwan, he had been living with his mother and his five-year-old daughter in a Mexican village. His family now makes a living from farming.
This is the first time he has lived alone for such a long time abroad, although he has previously enjoyed brief visits to Japan and Brazil.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN GOVERNOR REFUSES TO SPECULATE ON HIS FUTURE
DOC.DATELINE: Wufeng, central Taiwan, June 23 (CNA) (By Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: Taiwan Governor James Soong said on Tuesday that he would like to rest for a while and then "visit the dentist" after his tenure expires at the end of this year.

The governor, who was seen bleeding in the Taiwan Provincial Assembly recently as a result of dental work, refused to speculate on the prospects of his becoming premier or holding other prominent political posts after December 20, when he formally steps down as the last popularly-elected Taiwan governor.
Under a government plan to streamline the island's administration, the Taiwan provincial government will be downsized from the end of this year.
Soong also said he would not oppose the founding of self-help groups by provincial government staff, who are facing the threat of redundancy as the December deadline approaches.
The popular governor said his heart goes out to his staff, and he promised to throw his full support behind them if their pursuit of their rights is in compliance with justice and rationality.
However, he stressed that he would rather not see any conflict or confrontation between the central and provincial government staff during the downsizing process.
Soong said he hopes that the central government will meet with the provincial staff to work out the best and least painful method of dismantling the provincial government.

DOC.HEADLINE: AI URGES TAIWAN TO ABOLISH CAPITAL PUNISHMENT

TEXT.P: Amnesty International (AI) on Tuesday urged Taiwan to abolish capital punishment, while appealing for the lives of three of the island's death row inmates.

AI Asia representative Rory Mungoven told a press conference called by Democratic Progressive Party Legislator Fan Hsun-lu that various studies by both the United Nations and Taiwan itself show that execution is not an effective crime deterrent.

Noting that Taiwan carried out 16 executions in 1995, 22 in 1996, and 38 in 1997, Mungoven said the island uses capital punishment more often than many other countries which, he said, does not match the giant strides the country has made in expanding freedom of speech, political rights, and the right of free association.
The much-used capital punishment and "widespread torture" against suspected criminals underlines the faulty system for human rights protection in Taiwan, said Mungoven.

In addition to the abolishment of the death penalty, he recommended the establishment of an independent human rights committee to advise the government on human rights-related issues and to carry out investigations into complaints of human rights abuses carried out by police, military and other authorities.

The new measures would not harm the island's social stability, he said. On the contrary, they would help improve Taiwan's social and democratic development and earn the country international plaudits.

At the same press conference, Mungoven also appealed for the lives of Su Chien-ho, Liu Ping-lang and Chuan Lin-hsun, who were sentenced to death for robbing, raping and murdering a couple in Taipei County in 1991.
Calling their trial "the most unfair ever seen," Mungoven implored President Lee Teng-hui to order a probe into allegations of police torture in the case and to commute their sentences.

DOC.HEADLINE: CLINTON SEEN KOWTOWING TO MAINLAND CHINA

TEXT.P: US President Bill Clinton's willingness to attend a ceremonial welcome in Tiananmen Square and his decision to prop up the Japanese yen are indications that the leader of the world's only superpower is kowtowing to mainland China over its threat to devalue the renminbi, according to a recent story in the Australian Financial Review.

"Today, we stern capitalists are placing great faith in the willingness of the People's Bank to be a 'good international citizen' and not wreck havoc on the global financial system by devaluing the yuan," wrote author Brian Toohey.

He said Mao Zedong's theory of power growing out of the gun barrel is wrong and the power now resides in the People's Bank of China, which was amply demonstrated by President Clinton's willingness to attend the ceremonial welcome in Tiananmen Square on Thursday.

Earlier Toohey attributed US intervention in currency markets, aimed at propping up a sagging Japanese yen, to mainland China's hints that further declines in the yen's value might prompt mainland China to devalue its currency.

"Clinton's priorities are clear. Given that it was only nine years ago that the PLA (People's Liberation Army) crushed the democracy movement in Tiananmen massacre, the symbolism of his decision to start his six-day visit to China in the square is unmistakable," Toohey wrote.
Jean-Michel Severino, a senior official of the World Bank, urged mainland China not to devalue its currency while touring Australia last week, Toohey noted.
Regardless of Clinton's wishes, however, the markets are now putting intense pressure on mainland China to devalue to improve its competitiveness.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI'S GRAND HOTEL RESUMES ITS FORMER GLORY

TEXT.P: Taipei's Grand Hotel, its magnificence ravaged by fire three years ago, reopened in all its former glory on Tuesday following a complete refurbishment.

Vice President Lien Chan and Premier Vincent Siew jointly pressed the buttons to switch on the hotel's laser lights and mark the rebirth of the establishment that was formerly one of the world's top ten hotels, and the brainchild of Madame Chiang Kai-shek, widow of the late generalissimo.

In a speech marking the happy occasion, Lien expressed the hope that the hotel, one of the city's leading landmarks, will not only regain its clout as the country's leading hotel, but will also solicit more visitors from abroad.
Siew for his part saluted the hotel as unique in the whole world, and praised its significant contributions to the Republic of China's diplomatic efforts.
Its "rebirth" is a shot in the arm to Taiwan's tourism industry, and is poised to raise the island's international competitiveness in this sector, Siew noted.

The Grand Hotel, founded by Mme. Chiang 46 years ago as a state banquet venue, boasts nine banquet halls, six restaurants and 500 distinguished guest rooms. Its recreational facilities include an Olympic-sized swimming pool, tennis courts and bowling alleys.

The hotel, renowned as a "modern architectural delight in a classical Chinese palace style," is now in the hands of a superb management team chaired by Koo Chen-fu, business tycoon and Taiwan's top negotiator with mainland China, and presided over by Yen Chang-shou, a seasoned hotelier whose latest achievement is the commendable performance of the Ritz Taipei Hotel.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN'S JOBLESS RATE DECLINES TO 2.37 PERCENT

TEXT.P: Taiwan's unemployment rate stood at 2.37 percent in May, the Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics (DGBAS) under the Executive Yuan announced on Tuesday.

The figure was 0.14 percentage points lower than that of the same month of last year, but after a seasonal adjustment, the figure rose slightly to 2.53 percent, about 0.16 percentage points lower than May, 1997.

During May, a total of 225,000 people were out of work, 8,000 more than in the previous month. Cheng Suo-liang, a DGBAS official, attributed the increase to closures or downsizing of businesses, as well as the end of the seasonal work period.
The official said the nation's overall workforce hit nearly 9.28 million in May, up about 138,000 from the same month of 1997.

Meanwhile, the average period of unemployment in May averaged 21 weeks, a week longer than in April. Among the unemployed, first-time job seekers remained jobless for 24 weeks, about one week longer than in the previous month, while other job seekers took an average of 20 weeks to find employment, similar to the previous month's figure.

The DGBAS statistics also show that Taiwan's labor participation rate stood at 57.84 percent in May, the lowest level in 14 years. The May figure was 0.03 percentage points lower than that of April, and a drop of 0.16 percentage points from the same month in 1997.
Cheng attributed the continuous decline to earlier retirement among laborers, as well as longer terms of employment.

DOC.HEADLINE: SEF HAPPY TO ARRANGE TAIWAN TRIP FOR ARATS OFFICIAL

TEXT.P: The Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) would be happy to arrange a trip to Taiwan for Li Yafei, deputy secretary-general of Beijing's Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait (ARATS), an SEF official said on Tuesday.
However, any plans for such a visit should be submitted to the SEF by letter rather than via a telephone call, said Jan Jyh-horng, SEF deputy secretary-general.
Jan was responding to news reports that Taiwan had failed to reply to a request from Li to visit the island.
Li is said to have telephoned the SEF last week to request permission to visit in July at the head of an education inspection delegation from Beijing.

Jan said he was not in the office when the call was made, adding that subsequent checks with the Ministry of Education, Ministry of the Interior, and Bureau of Entry and Exit, failed to confirm the scheduled arrival of any Beijing education groups in July.
Since the proposed trip was not on record, Jan said, he was under no obligation to reply to an unconfirmed telephone request.

Although the current rules require two or three months to process applications for visits by groups from mainland China, Jan said the SEF would be prepared to coordinate the related agencies to speed up their procedures in order to accommodate Li's July itinerary.

He pointed out that Taiwan would welcome a visit by Li, as it could provide an extra chance for the SEF and ARATS to negotiate the upcoming meeting between their respective heads, Koo Chen-fu and Wang Daohan, in Beijing.

The SEF has suggested staging the Koo-Wang meeting this fall, and has called for two working-group meetings in July and August, with the Taiwan side represented by Jan and SEF Vice Chairman Shi Hwei-yow, respectively, to lay the groundwork for the Koo-Wang meeting.
Beijing has yet to respond to the SEF's suggestion.

DOC.HEADLINE: ILLEGAL ARMS SUPPLIER NABBED IN TAIPEI

TEXT.P: A man suspected of selling firearms to Chen Chin-hsing, Taiwan's most notorious criminal, was nabbed on Tuesday, allowing the police to draw a clearer picture of the series of crimes committed by Chen and his accomplices.

Hsiao Tah-lung, 43, was arrested at his Peitou apartment early Tuesday morning on charges of arms trafficking and dealing, although the police failed to find any weapons at Hsiao's residence, and Hsiao denied having sold guns to Chen.

However, according to Chen, who was arrested some seven months ago for a spate of crimes ranging from kidnap, rape, and murder, to the holding hostage of a South African diplomat and his family, Hsiao sold him weapons on three occasions from 1996 onwards.

In three separate deals, Chen said, Hsiao had supplied him with a total of 17 guns at a price of NT$250,000 (US$7,353) apiece, as well as more than 1,000 rounds of ammunition. Most of the deals were conducted at Hsiao's company, an air-conditioning firm in downtown Taipei, or in the parking lot of the Taipei World Trade Center.
The police suspect Hsiao of being one of the elements of an arms smuggling ring in northern Taiwan which is believed to have smuggled hundreds of guns into the country in a single operation.

DOC.HEADLINE: IT PRODUCT TARIFF TALKS AT KEY JUNCTURE IN WTO

TEXT.P: Global talks to eliminate all import duties on more than 400 information technology (IT) products enter their final crucial phase on June 26 at the World Trade Organization (WTO).

The talks face a June 30 deadline to reach agreement on which products will be included on an extended list that will be attached to the original 1997 Information Technology Agreement (ITA), a WTO report said on Tuesday.
The US, the world's top exporter and importer of IT products, stands to reap huge benefits if an accord is reached to extend the ITA product coverage.
In 1996, US exports of IT products totaled US$104.6 billion, while US imports of IT products reached US$140.6 billion.

Products proposed for possible zero tariffs by 2000 include machines for making and testing semiconductors, automatic teller machines, telephone answering machines, fiber optics, and parts for IT products.

Expectations are running high that the talks will end on a successful note following the progress reported in the last round of talks held in Geneva on June 5. During those talks, mainland China, which in 1996 exported IT products worth US$17.2 billion and imported IT products totaling US$13.9 billion, submitted its initial draft list, the WTO report said.
The US welcomed the move, but noted that Beijing needs to do more, as quite a number of products were missing from its list, trade officials said.

DOC.HEADLINE: FLURRY OF OVERSEAS VISITS BY ROC LEADERS IN PIPELINE

TEXT.P: A series of overseas visits by ranking ROC officials are in the pipeline, scheduled to begin following the Clinton-Jiang summit on June 27, according to government sources.
The summit has absorbed most of the attention of Taiwan's leaders in recent weeks, as the Taiwan issue is expected to be on its agenda.
After that, the sources said, Examination Yuan President Hsu Shui-teh is expected to lead a delegation to attend Liberia's national day celebrations on July 26.
Exactly one month later, Speaker of the National Assembly Fredrick Chien might visit Paraguay to attend the inauguration of that country's new president.
If Chien goes to Paraguay, he will be traveling as the personal envoy of President Lee Teng-hui, replacing Vice President Lien Chan.

Lien will be unable to travel to the South American country as he is expected to attend the ruling Kuomintang's central committee conference, slated for August 22, in his capacity as party vice chairman.
The government will also send a delegation, possibly headed by Siew, to celebrate Swaziland's 30th anniversary of independence which falls on September 6.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN ABORIGINAL YOUTHS TO CHALLENGE HIGHEST PEAK IN S.E. ASIA

TEXT.P: A group of youths from the Aboriginal Bunun tribe in central Taiwan are preparing to challenge the highest peak in Southeast Asia in August as a test of their physical strength and ability.

The 15 youngsters, aged between 9 and 13, are scheduled to leave for Malaysia on Aug. 17 and will prepare to scale Mount Kinabalu which stands 4,100 meters above sea level in the northeast part of Sarawak and Sabah.

Most of the members of the group have already scaled Taiwan's and Northeast Asia's highest peak, Mount Jade. They were selected from 40 youngsters who have received mountain-hiking training since last November.

According to team coach Wu Ah-hao, a Bunun tribeswoman in her 40s and a trained athlete from the Taipei Physical Education College, the youths are good hikers because of their Bunun blood. The Bunun people, indigenous to Mount Jade and Taiwan's Central Mountain Range, are brave people and are born athletes, she said.

To qualify for the team, each member had to pass a two-week test in steep hiking conditions in Tatajia, a 2,400-meter range of Mount Jade. After the Tatajia test, the youths ran up the 2,881-meter Lulin Mountain. Those who could not sustain the physical challenge failed to make the team.

Team leader Wu Hung-sheng, 12, said he wants to challenge Mount Kinabalu for his father, a Bunun mountain climber who died during a rescue mission in Hsuehshan, a high-altitude mountain range in central Taiwan several years ago.

Other members include Wu Li-wei and Wu Shih-wei, 11-year-old twin brothers, who come from a mountain climbing family. Their grandfather carried the bronze statue of Yu You-jen, a former president of the Control Yuan, the Republic of China's highest watchdog agency, to the top of Mount Jade where it now sits.
Among the 15 youths, four are girls. Their gender by no means makes them physically inferior to their boy peers, coach Wu said.

DOC.HEADLINE: ACTIVISTS STAGE PROTESTS IN FRONT OF AIT

TEXT.P: Two groups of activists demonstrated in front of the American Institute in Taiwan's (AIT) Taipei office Wednesday, urging the US not to sell out Taiwan during President Bill Clinton's visit to mainland China.
The activists were led by Wang Shih-chien, an adviser to the pro-independence Democratic Progressive Party (DPP), and Taipei City Councilor Chen Shueh-fen, respectively.
They demanded the United States not to sacrifice or sell out Taiwan's interests during Clinton's summit meeting with his mainland counterpart, Jiang Zemin, in Beijing later this week.

Wang presented a petition signed by more than 10,000 local citizens to acting AIT Taipei Office Director Lloyd Neighbors. The signatures were collected by the Action Alliance against Annexation in the past few days.

Chen, a member of the ruling Kuomintang, also gave Neighbors a petition expressing strong opposition to Beijing's proposed codification of the so-called "three no's" policy. The "three no's" refers to no US support for a "One China, One Taiwan," no US support for Taiwan independence and no US support Taiwan's membership in the United Nations.
Neighbors promised to pass on the petitions and convey their messages to concerned US authorities.
Meanwhile, Wang invited staff members of the AIT Taipei office to take part in an all-night, candlelight vigil at the 2-28 Peace Memorial Park in downtown Taipei starting Wednesday evening.

"The vigil, to be organized by the Action Alliance against Annexation, is aimed at reminding Clinton not to impair Taiwan's interests during his June 25-July 3 mainland visit," said Wang, chief executive of the alliance.
The AIT represents US interests in Taiwan in the absence of official diplomatic ties between the two countries.
