DOC.HEADLINE: GIO HEAD INTERVIEWED BY BBC ON CLINTON-JIANG MEETING
DOC.DATELINE: London, June 23 (CNA) (By Mark Ou and Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: Taipei would welcome improved ties between Washington and Beijing if it helped maintain peace and stability in the Asia-Pacific region, a Republic of China government spokesman said here Tuesday.
Chen Chien-jen, head of the ROC Government Information Office, made the remarks during an interview with the British Broadcasting Corp.

Commenting on the planned meeting between US President Bill Clinton and mainland Chinese President Jiang Zemin later this week in Beijing, Chen said the ROC welcomes the meeting if it does not hurt Taiwan's interests and is helpful to the region.
Although improvement in Washington-Beijing relations does not mean a retrogress in Washington-Taipei ties, he said, the ROC is very concerned about the meeting between Clinton and Jiang.

Mainland China has made noticeable progress in economic development in recent years, but the international community should take into account that it still lags far behind in the area of human rights and democracy, Chen said. He urged Beijing leaders to improve in these areas and catch up in these world trends.
The ROC government spokesman also pointed out that the "one country, two systems" formula implemented in Hong Kong is not suited to Taiwan and the Taiwan people will never accept such a system.

Stressing that Taiwan's economy remains strong amid the Asian financial turmoil, Chen said the ROC is willing to help other Southeast Asian countries through the crisis to create greater prosperity in the region.
Chen will proceed to Spain after concluding his visit here on Tuesday.

DOC.HEADLINE: AI ASIA-PACIFIC REGIONAL MEETING OPENS IN TAOYUAN

TEXT.P: The 1998 Asia-Pacific Regional Conference of Amnesty International (AI) opened Wednesday in the northern Taiwan county of Taoyuan, some 30 kilometers south of Taipei.

Addressing the opening ceremony, Taoyuan County Magistrate Annette Lu, a political dissident-turned-politician, spoke highly of AI's contribution to political democratization around the world and global humanitarian relief work over the past 37 years.

Lu also credited the organization with giving much needed assistance to a number of Taiwan's former political dissidents and prisoners in their fight for the island's transformation from an autocracy to a full-fledged democracy.
"Nearly all of jailed Taiwan political dissidents in the martial law era, including myself, had received AI's assistance or rescue," Lu recalled. Taiwan lifted martial law in 1987.
Lu, a former legislator from the opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP), said she is delighted to see AI convene its annual Asia-Pacific regional meeting in her hometown.

More than 60 representatives from 18 countries, including Pakistan, Syria, Bangladesh, Thailand, Malaysia, Japan, South Korea, the Philippines, New Zealand, Australia, the United States and the host Republic of China, are participating in the three-day AI conference.
This is the first time the London-based human rights promotional organization has held its annual regional meeting on the island.

As a sign of her gratitude for AI's previous assistance, Lu said she has pooled resources from several private groups to sponsor a party to give thanks to the group at the Taoyuan County Cultural Center on Wednesday evening.

Many former political dissidents, including incumbent DPP Chairman Hsu Hsin-liang, DPP Chairman-elect Lin Yi-hsiung, will also attend the party to express their gratitude to AI. Several local performing arts troupes, including an aboriginal dancing workshop, will perform folk music and dances to entertain party goers.
Rory MunGoven, AI's Asia-Pacific affairs director, personally presided over the opening session.
The AI was founded in 1961 and now has branches in more than 100 countries around the world.

DOC.HEADLINE: AUSTRALIA'S COMMODITY EXPORTS HIT BY ASIAN CRISIS

TEXT.P: Australia's commodity exports will drop by over 1 percent in fiscal 1998-99 thanks to the Asian crisis and Japan's recession, the Australian Bureau of Agricultural and Resource Economics (ABARE) said in its updated forecast.
In its June-quarter outlook, ABARE predicted a 1.2 percent fall in Australia commodity exports to A$64.5 billion (US$40.3 billion) in 1998-99 following a rise of 7.3 percent in fiscal 1997-98.

ABARE said the Japanese economy would contract by 0.7 percent in 1998 and grow by just 1 percent next year. It also forecast China's economic growth at only 6 percent this year, down from the earlier rate of 7.5 percent.
The latest ABARE report estimates South Korea's economy will contract by 3 percent compared to the earlier zero percent.

The lower than expected growth in these three countries will definitely affect Australia's commodity exports, ABARE officials said. Japan is Australia's largest trading partner, South Korea is the second and mainland China is the third.

DOC.HEADLINE: FOUR HONG KONG ACTIVISTS MISSING IN TIAOYUTAI LANDING MISSION

TEXT.P: Four members of a group of Hong Kong activists attempting to land on the disputed Tiaoyutai Islands in the East China Seas were reported missing on Wednesday.
The four men, who joined others from Taiwan to highlight Chinese sovereignty over the islands, were aboard the 100-ton vessel Diao Yu Tai along with 26 other Hong Kong activists Wednesday morning.
The four took off in a rubber boat at around 10 a.m. about 12 miles away from the islands in an attempt to get closer to the islands so they could swim ashore.

The Diao Yu Tai lost contact with the four men as chaos ensued as a group of Japanese coast guard patrol boats circled and rammed the vessel at about 10:30 a.m., according to Taipei County Councilor Chin Chieh-shou, leader of the Taiwan activists.
Fortunately, the vessel did not suffer any leakage from the damage, Chin said.

As of noon Wednesday, neither the Diao Yu Tai nor any of the three Taiwan fishing boats trying to make a landing attempt had heard from the four -- Chuang Li-kun, Lin chuo-kuang, Ku Ssu-yao from Hong Kong, and Wu Xiaoming from mainland China, Chin said. All four were reportedly equipped with diving gear.

Chin's group aboard the three fishing boats had also failed to land on the islands as of noon Wednesday. Chin said the four vessels would not return to Taiwan until the four missing activists were found.

The Tiaoyutais are a group of uninhabited islands about 200 kilometers northeast of Taiwan and 300 kilometers west of the Japanese island of Okinawa. They are claimed by Japan, mainland China and Taiwan.

Chin, along with other Taiwan and Hong Kong activists made a brief landing on one of the disputed islands in October 1996. During that landing, Chin and his friends planted two national flags, one each from the ROC and the PRC. The banners were soon dismantled by the Japanese, however,
In September 1996, David Chan, a Hong Kong activist, drowned after jumping into the sea when Japanese coast guard vessels blocked his ship from the archipelago.

Patriotic sentiments in Taiwan and Hong Kong were prompted by the construction of a makeshift lighthouse on one of the islands in July 1996 by the ultra-rightist Japanese Youth Federation. Japan later included the Tiaoyutais in its 200-mile territorial zone.

Japan claims its control of the Tiaoyutais began in 1972 when the United States, which had administered the islands along with Okinawa since the end of World War II, passed on the control of the islands.
The Chinese claim the Tiaoyutais have for centuries been a part of Chinese sovereignty and were most recently under the jurisdiction of the Ilan County Government of Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: NEW PARTY EXPLORING POSSIBILITY OF BEIJING LIAISON OFFICE

TEXT.P: An influential figure in Taiwan's pro-unification New Party said on Wednesday that a liaison office the party is planning to set up in Beijing is not intended to be a branch office.

New Party Election Manager Jaw Shau-kong stressed that the proposed office would be aimed only at offering services to Taiwan people in mainland China, and would not engage in party branch office functions such as recruiting new members in the mainland.

Jaw's remarks came after a New Party announcement on Tuesday that Chen Kuei-miao, head of the party's Mainland Affairs Committee, had departed earlier the same day for Beijing to discuss the opening of the office with the relevant mainland authorities.

Although Jaw said he is not very optimistic about the likelihood of permission being granted to establish the office, he pointed out that it would be a major breakthrough if the mainland authorities approved its establishment.

As Washington and Beijing are expected to begin strengthening their bilateral relationship after US President Bill Clinton and mainland Chinese President Jiang Zemin meet later this week in Beijing, Jaw said the New Party is willing to set up a "second communication channel" between Taiwan and mainland China in the interests of Taiwan's 21 million people.

Expressing grave concern over reports that the US is very likely to become involved in cross-strait affairs by establishing a Taipei-Washington-Beijing dialogue channel following the Clinton-Jiang meeting, the New Party heavyweight said his party, though small, expects to help bring about changes in mainland China through active contacts and exchanges.

DOC.HEADLINE: AUTHOR SEES CLINTON'S VISIT TO M'LAND AS HASTENING COMMUNIST DEMISE

TEXT.P: US President Bill Clinton's visit to China this week will weaken the dictatorship and hasten the demise of Chinese communists, according to British author Robert Elegant.

In an article headlined "Clinton Scales China's Wall," in Wednesday's The Australian newspaper, Elegant wrote that US cooperation with Beijing on the international front will help the two sides take action against Asia's economic problems, moderate the nuclear arms race between India and Pakistan, and put pressure on North Korea to resist increasing tensions in the region.

"Paradoxically, perhaps, Clinton's visit will also accelerate, however slightly, the political effect of China's commercial, financial and technological opening to the outside world: The erosion of Beijing's power," Elegant wrote.

"New information and ideas must be permitted entry if industry and trade are to continue to expand. Thus the Clinton visit, in the long run, will further weaken the dictatorship it strengthens in the short run," he said.

Elegant said as commerce, finance and industry grow in importance, political factors decline. However, Beijing still rules the country with harsh authoritarian methods in the provinces and will continue to do so for as long as it can.

With this trip, Clinton risks being seen as another humble envoy obedient to the mainland leadership unless he speaks out forcefully for more freedom of expression and greater democracy in the government of China, Elegant wrote.

DOC.HEADLINE: US GROUP CRITICIZES BEIJING OVER WITHDRAWAL OF VISAS FOR JOURNALISTS

TEXT.P: The United States Broadcasting Board of Governors (BBG) Tuesday expressed deep regret over the Chinese government's decision to withdraw the visas of three Radio Free Asia journalists.
"The decision dramatizes Beijing's apparent determination to continue to restrict the Chinese public's access to a variety of opinion and news reporting," it said in a statement.
The three journalists were planning to cover US President Bill Clinton's trip to mainland China which is scheduled to begin Thursday.

"My colleagues and I believe that the action of the Chinese government barring these professional journalists casts an unnecessary and unwarranted pall over this important summit. We hope and expect that the administration will continue to spare no effort in convincing Beijing of this," David Burke, chairman of the bipartisan presidentially appointed BBG, said.

The BBG expressed appreciation over President Clinton's statement criticizing the Chinese government's decision, and said Radio Free Asia has also received comments of support from a number of key members of Congress.

DOC.HEADLINE: SINGAPORE'S CONSUMER PRICE INDEX STABLE IN MAY

TEXT.P: Singapore's consumer price index in May remained the same as in April but was 0.5 percent higher than the same period last year, according to figures the Singapore Department of Statistics released Tuesday.

Food prices rose by 0.4 percent in May based on higher prices for leafy vegetables while clothing prices rose by 0.9 percent due to dearer ready-made garments and footwear. Meanwhile, housing costs fell by 0.8 percent as a result of lower electricity tariffs, the department said.
Transportation and communication costs were 0.4 percent higher in May over the previous month, but declined by 3.4 percent compared to May 1997 due to lower prices for vehicles.
Prices of miscellaneous items and the education index dipped by 0.1 percent each while health care costs remained stable in May, according to the statistics.

DOC.HEADLINE: QANTAS BANS PAULINE HANSON FROM INFLIGHT NEWS

TEXT.P: Qantas Airways plans to censor its inflight news programs to exclude coverage of Independent Member of Parliament Pauline Hanson and her One Nation Party after receiving a complaint over "unacceptable" news items.

The Sydney Morning Herald daily on Wednesday quoted Qantas public affairs head Bernard Shirley as confirming that an inflight entertainment office staff had written to Channel Nine's program manager Michael Healy last Friday, asking the network to eliminate any reference to Hanson and her party in the news bulletins.
Shirley said the letter was sent after a Qantas staff member returning to Australia complained about inflight news items he found "unacceptable."
The unnamed staff member, who was returning to Australia from Indonesia, felt the news items about Hanson and her party were offensive to Indonesia passengers on the flight.

Channel Nine initially resisted Qantas' request but later agreed after receiving a clarification from Shirley, who explained that Qantas does not want "(Channel Nine) to include reports which contain material that is offensive to any particular ethnic group."

"You will appreciate that in providing services to people from throughout the world, we try to ensure that we do not offend them through insensitivities in our inflight video programs," Shirley said in a letter to Channel Nine's news director Paul Fenn.

Hanson was reportedly angry over the Qantas ban. Her adviser David Oldfield was quoted by the daily as saying, "It was a disgraceful, un-Australian activity asking Channel Nine to be political censors on behalf of Qantas."

DOC.HEADLINE: SINGAPORE TO UNVEIL OFF-BUDGET MEASURES MONDAY

TEXT.P: Singapore will unveil its package of off-budget measures aimed at reducing business costs and helping companies cope with financially difficult times on Monday in Parliament,
Singapore's Second Minister for Trade and Industry Yeo Yong Bong made the announcement Tuesday night.
The measures will be introduced to help businesses rather than pump prime the economy or stimulate the country's consumption, he said.
"Preliminary figures from the second quarter show that growth momentum continues to slow down.

"The expected growth rate for this year will have to be revised downward, although it is still not likely to be negative," Yeo said, referring to the government's earlier forecast that economic growth for this year would be in the 2.5 percent to 4.5 percent range.

Off-budget measures are tools governments use to tackle unexpected economic situations that arise after the annual budget has been approved. They may include tax rebates, infrastructure spending or tax cuts.

Singapore's Finance Minister Hu Tsu Tau told the Parliament earlier this month that the decision to implement comprehensive off-budget measures would be taken if preliminary second-quarter figures pointed to a significant economic slowdown.
Last week, a senior official of the Monetary Authority of Singapore said the growth forecast for the year would be revised downward to the lower end of the 2.5 percent to 4.5 percent range.
Private sector analysts have been more pessimistic. Some have forecast a recession in Singapore's economy later this year.

Speaking at a dinner at Business Week's 8th Annual Asia Leadership Forum last night, Yeo said Singapore was exposed to the regional crisis even though it had no external debt and its banks and financial institutions were among the strongest in Asia.
Whatever measures the government takes, "Singapore can not be fully insulated from the regional crisis", he said.
"Unlike 1985-86, the causes of this economic downturn are largely external to us and beyond our control," he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: AUSTRALIA SPEEDS UP PRODUCTION OF LNG TO MEET ASIAN DEMAND

TEXT.P: Two leading liquefied natural gas (LNG) companies in Darwin, Australia have accelerated their development plans so they can export to the Chinese mainland, India, Taiwan, Japan and South Korea a year ahead of scheduled.
Shell Australia and Woodside Petroleum's development of a A$10 billion (US$6.25 billion) project is expected to be completed in 2004.
Shell chief executive Roland Williams and Woodside chief executive John Akehurt will travel to mainland China in July to secure a long-term contract to supply LNG.

They said mainland China and India are the major targets for potential LNG sales because both countries are expected to import LNG in the next several years as their economies will demand more power stations to cope with the economic development projects.
"China and India hold considerable promise for growth in gas/LNG demand as third generation markets," Williams said Tuesday.

The Australian Financial Review, Australia's leading business daily, Tuesday quoted Williams as saying that: "By 2010, growth in markets of Japan, South Korea, Taiwan, India and China could push annual LNG demand in the region beyond 140 million tons. Of course, the Asian crisis will affect energy demand in the region in the short to medium term."
In addition to promoting sales of their LNG to mainland China and India, Shell and Woodside also plan to export LNG to Taiwan, which is interested in diversifying its import sources from Australia.
Taiwan has long-term contracts now with both Indonesia and Malaysia and imports millions of tons of LNG. But the island country is also interested in buying the fuel from Australia.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN STUDENT WINS 1998 DISCOVER CARD TRIBUTE AWARD SCHOLARSHIP

TEXT.P: A Taiwan high school junior has been selected as one of three Gold Award winners of the 1998 Discover Card Tribute Award Scholarships worth US$20,000.

Susane Ko, a student at the Taipei American School, was one of over 11,000 students who applied for the Tribune Award Program this year. This scholarship program honors US high school juniors who exhibit excellence in many areas of their lives, not just academics.

Ko, who was born with anchondroplasia, a form of dwarfism, moved with her family to Taiwan from the United States when she was in elementary school. She spoke very little Chinese and could read and write only in English when she arrived in Taiwan.
She spent four years pushing herself to learn Chinese and overcame the physical difficulty of attending classes on crutches carrying a heavy backpack.
Now she actively participates in groups such as the Orphanage Club, where she helps orphans, lepers, the blind and others.
"After graduation, I plan to continue working with people who need my help by pursuing a law degree," said Ko.

She won the 1998 Gold Award in the category of Arts & Humanities. There are only two other Gold Award winners under the categories of Science, Business & Technology Studies and Trade & Technical Studies.
Discover Card, in cooperation with the American Association of School Administrators will hold a special ceremony honoring Ko and the other winners in Washington, D.C. June 24.
Since 1992 the Discover Card, a general purpose credit and financial card issued by Morgan Stanley Dean Witter & Co., has granted high school juniors over 2,700 scholarships nationwide.

DOC.HEADLINE: ALBRIGHT REASSURES CONGRESS OF NO COMPROMISE ON TAIWAN
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, June 23 (CNA) (By Jay Chen and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: US Secretary of State Madeleine Albright has reassured congressional leaders that the United States will not "sell out" Taiwan during President Bill Clinton's visit to mainland China, an influential congressman said on Tuesday.

Rep. Benjamin A. Gilman (R-NY), chairman of the Committee on International Relations of the House of Representatives, made the statement after a breakfast meeting with Albright. Several other senior House and Senate members were also present at the meeting.
Gilman said Albright had briefed them on the agenda of Clinton's June 25-July 3 mainland visit.
He also quoted Albright as saying during the meeting that for mainland China, Taiwan is certainly a major topic in its engagements with the US.
Although Beijing hopes the US changes its policy toward Taiwan, Gilman said: "Albright reiterates that the US policy toward Taiwan remains unchanged."
According to Gilman, Albright had assured congressional leaders that Clinton will reaffirm to Beijing that the two sides of the Taiwan Strait should resolve their disputes through peaceful dialogue.
"Albright also assured us that the US is unlikely to sacrifice Taiwan's interests during Clinton's summit talks with his mainland counterpart, Jiang Zemin," the House heavyweight said.

Gilman further said the Congress will demand the executive branch abide by its promises to Taiwan. "The people of Taiwan do not need to worry too much about Clinton's mainland visit. Congress will protect them," he added.
The House passed a non-binding concurrent resolution earlier this month, urging Clinton to take advantage of his upcoming mainland visit to push Beijing to renounce the use of force against Taiwan.
Clinton is scheduled to leave Washington on Wednesday and will arrive Xian, the first leg of his nine-day mainland visit, on Thursday.

DOC.HEADLINE: NATIONAL ASSEMBLY SPEAKER DENIES US VISIT RELATED TO CLINTON-JIANG SUMMIT
DOC.DATELINE: San Francisco, June 24 (CNA) (By Neil Lu & Eva Chen)

TEXT.P: ROC National Assembly Speaker Fredrick Chien arrived in the US on Tuesday, where he denied reports that he will convey messages regarding relations between Taipei and Washington.

Chien's visit has aroused much media speculation because it is so close to US President Bill Clinton's mainland China trip, and in light of his high official position and background. He is a former foreign minister.

Chien strongly rebuffed the speculation when he met the press at San Francisco airport en route to the annual meeting in Denver of the World Forum, a convention sponsored by the American Enterprise Institute.
He said the meeting, which is designed to help world business leaders understand issues of worldwide concern, was scheduled a year ago, and thus has nothing to do with Clinton's trip.

Since the meeting is not open to outsiders, Chien refused to disclose what he plans to say during the June 25-28 session. However, he admitted that Beijing-Washington relations, and relations across the Taiwan Strait, will certainly be mentioned.

The World Forum will be presided over by former US President Gerald R. Ford. Political VIPs including former British Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher, former French President Valery Giscard d'Estaing, and former German Chancellor Helmut Schmidt, will attend, together with renowned scholars and world-class corporate chiefs.

DOC.HEADLINE: NICARAGUAN PRESIDENT RECEIVES ROC LAWMAKERS
DOC.DATELINE: Panama City, June 23 (CNA) (By Edward Chen and Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: Nicaraguan President Arnoldo Aleman said on Tuesday that his country firmly supports the Republic of China's entry into the United Nations and other international organizations.
Aleman made the remarks while receiving a visiting ROC legislative delegation.
He told the lawmakers that the ROC and its 21 million people have as much right to join the UN as any other nation in the world.

The president promised that when the UN opens its next general assembly in September, he will again request that the ROC be allowed to join the UN based on the principle of universality under the UN Charter.
The delegation, led by Legislator Lin Che-fu, was accompanied during its meeting with Aleman by ROC Ambassador Augustine C. T. Wu and Nicaraguan Foreign Minister Emilio Alvarez.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN'S FOREIGN TRADE CONTINUES TO DECLINE

TEXT.P: Taiwan's foreign trade continued to fall in the first five months of this year as the Asian financial crisis has continued to grip the region by the throat, the Board of Foreign Trade (BOFT) reported on Wednesday.
In the January-May period, Taiwan's exports amounted to US$45.38 billion, down 6.9 percent from the same period of 1997, while imports totaled US$44.63 billion, down 2 percent.
As a result, the island was left with a trade surplus of US$750 million in the five-month period, a record 76.6 percent decline over the same period of a year ago, BOFT officials said.

The US remained Taiwan's largest export market in the five months, absorbing US$11.52 billion-worth of Taiwan goods, up an insignificant 0.6 percent from the year-earlier level. Meanwhile, imports from the US declined 5.2 percent to US$8.87 billion, leaving Taiwan with a surplus of US$2.66 billion in the five-month period.

Exports to Hong Kong amounted to US$10.31 billion, down 5.4 percent, while imports totaled only US$810 million, up 5.8 percent from the same period of 1997, giving Taiwan a trade surplus of US$9.49 billion with Hong Kong, and making the area Taiwan's largest source of surplus in the world, the officials noted.
Exports to Japan dropped a worrisome 22.5 percent to US$3.94 billion in the January-May period, while imports grew 1 percent to US$11.55 billion, leaving the island with a deficit of US$7.62 billion.
Exports to the Association of Southeast Asian Nations fell a whopping 26.3 percent to US$4.86 billion, while imports dropped a slight 1.8 percent to US$5.28 billion.

Taiwan's two-way trade with the European Union in the five-month period was the only sector which proved profitable for both exporters and importers. Exports to the EU totaled US$7.64 billion, up 6.2 percent, while imports increased 2.1 percent to US$7.23 billion.

Meanwhile, Taiwan's exports and imports in the first 20 days in June fell by 3.4 percent and 9.4 percent, respectively, from the same period of 1997, to US$6.5 billion and US$6.2 billion, respectively, the officials said.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT CHAIRMAN RECEIVES MAYORAL HOPEFULS

TEXT.P: ROC President Lee Teng-hui, acting in his capacity as chairman of the ruling Kuomintang (KMT), on Wednesday received Ma Ying-jeou and Wu Den-yih, the party's mayoral candidates for Taipei and Kaohsiung cities, respectively, and pledged full party support in the year-end elections.

Lee told the mayoral hopefuls that the whole party will support them, and that Chen Chien-chih, speaker of the Taipei City Council, and Wu Poh-hsiung, senior advisor to the president, have already begun to organize election headquarters, as well as a support system, for Ma.

The KMT chairman advised Ma that he should have more contact with the party grassroots and seek assistance from officials, experts and his comrades, in order to fully understand Taipei City administrative affairs. According to Lee's observations, a candidate's high popularity does not necessarily add up to more votes.

He also instructed both candidates to join forces with candidates for the legislative and city council elections, in the hope that voters will cast their votes evenly for all KMT candidates in all three elections.

Ma said after the meeting that Lee was very candid and that his directives and observations were sincere, to the point, and helpful. He pledged to do his best to strengthen his advantages and to reduce his shortcomings.

For his part, Wu said Lee is quite concerned about both him and Ma, as evidenced by his inviting them to the meeting. The incumbent mayor of Kaohsiung expressed his appreciation for Lee's encouragement and pledged to do his best to win reelection.

DOC.HEADLINE: US URGED NOT TO SACRIFICE TAIWAN INTERESTS

TEXT.P: The New Taiwan Alliance issued a strong public declaration on Wednesday imploring Washington not to sell out Taiwan's interests during Saturday's Beijing summit between US President Bill Clinton and mainland Chinese President Jiang Zemin.
Legislators Chen Yung-hsing and Hsu Tien-tsai, both from the pro-independence opposition Democratic Progressive Party, called a news conference to make public the declaration.

Chen and Hsu said the New Taiwan Alliance, a political organization which promotes Taiwan independence, welcomes the meeting between Clinton and Jiang if it can help boost peace and stability in the Asia-Pacific region.
However, the alliance is strongly opposed to the signing of any joint communique or statement on the "three noes" issue which might hurt Taiwan's interests, they pointed out.
The alliance also raised three other points in the declaration:
-- The US should continue arms sales to Taiwan in compliance with the "Taiwan Relations Act" to maintain peace in the region;
-- Taiwan's future and sovereignty must be decided by its 21 million people without any outside interference or control;
-- The country should be allowed to join the United Nations under the name of "Taiwan," and the international community should help Taiwan play a more constructive role on the world stage.

Hsu, who has just returned from a lobbying trip to the US, said that although the US has given repeated assurances that there will be no public statement on Beijing's "three noes" demand, no one can guarantee whether Clinton will touch on the concerned issues during meetings with reporters.

DOC.HEADLINE: CLINTON URGED TO HIGHLIGHT HUMAN RIGHTS DURING MAINLAND TRIP
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, June 24 (CNA) (By Jay Chen & Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: US President Bill Clinton's decision to receive military honors from his communist Chinese hosts at Tiananmen Square -- site of the bloody 1989 crackdown -- continued to meet with protests Tuesday from leaders of Congress and various civic groups.

In a statement to the press, House Minority Leader Richard Gephardt, D-Mo., said that he and 61 of his colleagues in the House of Representatives have called on Clinton to make human rights the central topic of his nine-day visit to mainland China which starts on Thursday.
Gephardt also urged Clinton to use all the leverage at his disposal, including sanctions, to promote American national interests and values.

During a Congress press conference Wednesday afternoon, Clinton was urged to raise the issue of talks with the exiled Tibetan spiritual leader the Dalai Lama, deliver a speech in remembrance of the Tiananmen massacre victims, visit some of the victims' families, and demand that Beijing release political and religious prisoners.

Xiong Yian, a mainland student leader who was jailed for 19 months for his part in the 1989 pro-democracy protest, also attended the press conference. He implored Clinton not to forget Beijing's mass killings and not to embrace the mainland Chinese dictators.

Meanwhile, "Free China Movement" members staged separate protests in front of the mainland Chinese embassy and the White House, where an open letter to Clinton was read which contained the following four appeals:
-- Pressure Beijing into releasing all prisoners jailed for their pro-democracy beliefs;

-- Take the previous demands into consideration when planning to continue mainland China's most-favored nation trade status, when discussing Beijing's entry into the World Trade Organization, and when enhancing economic and political relations between Washington and Beijing.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN'S FOREIGN EXCHANGE RESERVES TOTAL US$84.44 BILLION

TEXT.P: Taiwan's foreign exchange reserves stood at US$84.446 billion at the end of May, the Central Bank of China (CBC) announced on Wednesday.

The CBC said that the foreign exchange reserves held by Taiwan are the third-highest in the world, behind Japan's US$205.76 billion as of the end of April, and mainland China's US$140.3 billion as of the end of February.
Taiwan's foreign exchange reserves in May increased US$414 million from the previous month, the second growth recorded in four months.

The CBC attributed the increase to relatively slight intervention by the CBC in the foreign exchange market during May, as well as interest on foreign exchange reserves which amounts to almost US$500 million each month.

However, due to the depreciation of the new Taiwan dollar to about NT$35 to the US greenback in recent fluctuations, the CBC has sold a large amount of foreign currency to protect the local currency from further dropping in value, so that June's growth has attracted much public attention. (by Ben Wu)

DOC.HEADLINE: NT DOLLAR DOWN

TEXT.P: The New Taiwan dollar plunged NT$0.15 to the greenback in Taipei on Wednesday due to low market confidence resulting from the seemingly unstoppable devaluation of the Japanese yen.
The local currency opened at the day's high of 34.196, and dropped sharply to 34.5 before buying increased. It closed at 34.351 against the US dollar at the end of the six-hour session.
Since the beginning of June, the NT dollar has slid 1.06 percent, or NT$0.363, because of an overall Asian currency crisis caused by the weak yen.
Interbank US dollar trading reached US$330 million in Wednesday's trading.

DOC.HEADLINE: RESTAURATEUR GIVES AWAY US DOLLARS AS PROMOTION

TEXT.P: Want some valuable US dollars since the Taiwan dollar has depreciated so sharply against the greenback in recent days? Go to the northern Taiwan city of Taoyuan over the next two days.
A restaurateur on downtown Taoyuan's Chungcheng Road has thought up a novel way of promoting his establishment -- giving away US dollars.
The restaurant owner, nicknamed Ah Ping, on Wednesday produced NT$200,000 (US$5,800) worth of US one-dollar bills, as well as restaurant coupons, and threw them into a crowd which had gathered.

The waiting crowd had worked itself into a state of frenzy by the time the first stack of bills and coupons fluttered down from the sixth floor of a building. The scene as people fought and scrabbled for the cash was chaotic, with children screaming in fright as their parents eagerly entered the melee.

The money was gone in less than a minute, but Ah Ping said he will give away more on Thursday and Friday at the same location in front of the Central Theater. Interested parties are welcome to try their luck, he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: HAIG SAYS A PROSPEROUS ASIA BENEFITS US

TEXT.P: The better Asia does, the better the United States does, said former US Secretary of State Alexander Haig in response to suggestions that a loose conspiracy of Western nations has sought to keep Asian economies down.
"Nothing is further from the truth," he said in an interview in Singapore with The Straits Times Tuesday.
Haig, who from 1981 to 1982 served in the Reagan administration, said Americans would be helping themselves by helping Asia's economies recover.
"The US does 30 percent more business with the Pacific basin than with Europe. The Asian economic flu has hurt the US and this will continue until the situation stabilizes here," he said.
The United States has been doing its part to help beleaguered Asian economies through contributions to the International Monetary Fund and the World Bank, which have provided loans and aid.
The United States has also kept pressure on Japan to follow through on commitments to economic reform, said Haig, 73, who is in Singapore as a special guest at a mobile communications conference.

Delays in US contributions to the IMF are not an attempt to deny Asia aid, he said. The delays, aimed at bringing about reform in the organization, came in response to criticism that the IMF was too bureaucratic and had not been doing its job properly, he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: FOREIGN MINISTRY REAFFIRMS CLAIM TO TIAOYUTAIS

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) on Wednesday reaffirmed the Republic of China's sovereign claim to the disputed Tiaoyutai Islands in the East China Sea.
MOFA spokesman Roy Wu said the Tiaoyutai archipelago is part of traditional Chinese territory. "Our sovereignty over the island group is undisputed," he stressed.
Wu's reiteration came after a group of activists from Taiwan, Hong Kong and Chinese communities in the United States made a failed attempt to land on the uninhabited islands on Wednesday morning.

The activists aboard six ships were blocked by the Japanese coast guard when they approached the disputed rocky islets, known as the Tiaoyutais in Taiwan, the Diaoyus in mainland China and the Senkakus in Japan. They have been administered by Japan since 1972, but also claimed by Taiwan and mainland China.
Wu said the ROC has consistently maintained that the sovereign dispute should be resolved through peaceful, rational negotiations, not by force or any non-peaceful means.

Wu further said the ROC will not seek cooperation of mainland China in resolving disputes over the Tiaoyutais. "Hopefully, Japan will respect Taiwan fishermen's legitimate rights to operate in their traditional fishing grounds near the disputed island group," he stressed, adding that Japan should under no circumstances impair Taiwan fishermen' vessels or endanger their physical safety.

Meanwhile, Wu expressed recognition of patriotism of the Chinese activists who have made annual landing attemps after the ultra-rightist Japanese Youth Federation erected a makeshift lighthouse on one of the islands in July 1996 and Japan later included the Taioyutais in its 200-mile exclusive economic zone.

In October 1996, Taiwan and Hong Kong activists made a brief landing on one of the disputed islands and planted two flags, one each from the ROC and mainland China. Japanese coast guard, however, soon forced the activists away from the islet and removed the flags.
Last year, a group of Taiwan and Hong Kong activists was prevented from approaching the islands by a large number of Japanese coast guard patrol ships and military helicopters.

DOC.HEADLINE: MORE FOREIGN WORKERS, VISITORS OVERSTAY AUSTRALIAN VISAS

TEXT.P: Australia detained more than 11,600 foreign workers and visitors, including people from mainland China, Vietnam, Syria and Pakistan, for overstaying their visas in fiscal 1997-98, the Department of Immigration and Multicultural Affairs reported Wednesday.
The detentions are part of an effort to crack down on illegal foreign workers and visitors in Australia.

In a statement faxed to CNA Wednesday afternoon, Immigration Minister Philip Ruddock said: "This reflects the strong record of the coalition government in ensuring that visitors to Australia abide by our laws."
"During our first year in office, locations of overstayers and illegal workers increased by 30 percent -- from 7,800 in 1995-96 to 10,138 in 1996-97."

"Locations have further increased to more than 11,600 between July 1, 1997 and May, 31 1998 as the government continues to take a strong stand against people who flagrantly abuse immigration laws," he said.

In New South Wales, about 6,400 people overstayed their visas; in Victoria, more than 1,800; in Queensland, 1,200; in Australia's Northern Territory, 800; in Western Australia, 780; in the Australian Capital Territory, more than 360; in South Australia, almost 280; and in Tasmania, 35.

"Australia strongly encourages bona fide visitors, students and business people to travel to Australia, and the vast majority abide by the conditions of their visas and return home before they expire. However, a small but persistent number of people overstay their visas or work without permission," he said.
The government spends millions of dollars tracking down those who overstay their visas. Moreover, they are taking jobs away from Australians, he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: INVESTIGATORS HOPE TO MEET ALLEGED SEXUAL ASSAULT VICTIM

TEXT.P: Vice Justice Minister Chiang Hao said on Wednesday that he has asked investigators probing an alleged sexual assault to make every effort to meet the alleged victim.
Chiang is the convener of a task force set up to probe the allegations against Cheng Chuan, acting director of the Investigation Bureau under the Ministry of Justice.
Chiang said he has asked the investigators to persuade Yang Wan-ching to allow them to meet the victim, his daughter Christine.
She has checked into a hospital in Paris, where the alleged incident took place.

Yang, Cheng's former friend, has accused Cheng of attempting to rape Christine while he was administering Chihkung, a traditional Chinese martial art believed to have curative powers, in a Paris hotel room on September 13, 1996.
Yang said that Christine, then 19, told him that Cheng touched her breast and private parts during the treatment. But Cheng denied categorically any wrongdoing.
Newspapers here have printed Yang's story, who claims he is in anguish after seeing his daughter descend into severe mental distress following the incident.
However, Chiang said that he has requested the investigators, who are currently in France to collect information related to the case, to try to obtain Christine's side of the story.

He said he does not want to see Yang claiming grievance while at the same time refusing to let the investigators meet his daughter, saying that this could lead people to challenge the truth of the allegations.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN'S STATUS SHOULD BE DECIDED BY REFERENDUM: DPP LEADER
DOC.DATELINE: Tokyo, June 24 (CNA) (By Mike Chang & Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: Lin Yi-hsiung, the newly-elected chairman of Taiwan's opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP), has said that the island's future should be decided by a nationwide referendum.

Such a vote should be conducted with international support, but not until the people of Taiwan believe a referendum is necessary to decide whether Taiwan should declare independence or continue seeking reunification with mainland China, he said.
The DPP leader made the remarks during an interview in Taipei with Japan's Mainichi Shimbun which was carried in the newspaper's Wednesday edition.

Lin was quoted as saying that Taiwan needs to make the international community aware that it is a sovereign country. Holding a referendum would show the international community the true stance of the Taiwan people regarding independence, which would provide international safeguards for Taiwan, Lin told Mainichi reporters.
He explained that Taiwan and mainland China are two different nations, but pointed out that this fact is not accepted by the majority of countries, including mainland China.
Lin also said that friendly relations between Taiwan and the mainland will not only be conducive to peace across the Taiwan Strait, it will also help preserve stability in the entire Asian region.
He also expressed his hope that Taiwan's interests will not be sacrificed at the upcoming talks between US President Bill Clinton and mainland China's President Jiang Zemin.

DOC.HEADLINE: SHARE PRICES UP ON TAIEX

TEXT.P: Share prices on the Taipei Stock Exchange surged at the opening of Wednesday's trading but slid throughout the rest of the day.
Still, the TAIEX's weighted index, the market's key barometer, closed at 7,670.71, 37.35 points higher than Tuesday's close.
The bourse opened at 7,733.71 and fluctuated between 7,783.99 and 7,670.71.
Dealers said the market was initially encouraged by surges in US hi-tech shares, but the optimism gave way in the face of declines in the Japanese yen and New Taiwan dollar.
Gainers outnumbered losers 293 to 130, with 66 issues remaining unchanged.
A total of 2.46 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$126.14 billion.

Seven of the eight major categories gained ground, with both foodstuff stocks and pulp and paper issues moving up the most at 1.7 percent, followed by bank and insurance shares and textile issues both at 0.6 percent, plastics and chemical stocks at 0.4 percent, construction shares at 0.3 percent and cement issues at 0.2 percent.
Electrical shares, meanwhile, remained unchanged.

The 10 listed companies with the largest turnovers on Wednesday were CIS Technology, Kuei Hung Industrial, Mitac International Corp., First International Computer, United Micro Electronics, Compeq Manufacturing, Taiwan Tea Corp., Wei Chuan Food, OPTO Tech Corp. and Inventec Corp.

DOC.HEADLINE: SIX PERCENT ECONOMIC GROWTH IMPOSSIBLE: SURVEY

TEXT.P: The results of a recent survey show that 80 percent of those interviewed believe Taiwan will be unable to reach the 6 percent economic growth predicted for this year by various domestic research institutes.

The poll, conducted by the mass-circulation China Times among 100 listed and over-the-counter companies, also found that 80 percent of the respondents feel that Taiwan will need at least one year to recover from the current Asian financial turmoil.

While agreeing that modest depreciation of the local currency will help upgrade the competitiveness of Taiwan's exports, the respondents said the new Taiwan dollar should be kept at between 32-34 against the US dollar.

As the Asian financial storm takes its toll on Taiwan's economy, with the island's exports declining 6.7 percent in the first quarter, the government has decided to boost the economy by stimulating local demand.

However, over half of those polled expressed pessimism over the success of this policy, on the grounds that a number of large-scale construction projects are lagging behind schedule, with some respondents questioning the government's efficiency.

DOC.HEADLINE: HOWARD SAYS RAILWAY PROJECT SUPPORT NOT TIED TO ONE NATION'S GAINS

TEXT.P: Australian Prime Minister John Howard has announced support for the construction of a A$9 (US$5.6) billion railway linking Melbourne in Victoria and Darwin in the Northern Territory, making it Australia's largest infrastructure project.

Political analysts said Howard's support for the project was an attempt to woo back disenchanted rural voters following a woeful performance by Howard's Liberal Party in recent state elections in Queensland.

The Liberal Party won a mere nine seats, compared with 11 for Pauline Hanson's One Nation Party, which has been described as racist, anti-Asian, anti-Aboriginal people, anti-multiculturalism and anti-foreign investment.

Howard, however, denied he was reacting to the rising popularity of the 1-year-old One Nation Party, whose support has soared to a record 12.5 percent in nationwide polls, up 5.8 percent in just four weeks.
The rail link will run through Victoria, New South Wales and Queensland.

"This project has been conceived quite in isolation from many political developments," Howard said. "But there has always been within the Australian community, because of the vastness of our nation, a hunger for long-term national development projects."
"It's one of the deepest things in the emotion of the Australian people," he said.
The project is jointly proposed by the Australian Transport and Energy Corridor Pty. Ltd. and engineering and construction company Abigroup Ltd.

DOC.HEADLINE: CLINTON-JIANG SUMMIT NOT TO AFFECT ROC-US TIES: DING

TEXT.P: US President Bill Clinton's visit to mainland China will neither affect substantive Taipei-Washington relations nor undermine the Republic of China's national interests, a senior official said on Wednesday.
Ding Mou-shih, secretary-general of the National Security Council, made the remarks on the eve of Clinton's departure for a nine-day state visit to the mainland.

Ding, who made a secret trip to the United States to meet high-ranking American officials in March 1996 when communist China was conducting missile tests and live-fire war games in waters near Taiwan, said local people need not worry too much about Clinton's June 25-July 3 mainland visit.

Ding, who once served as the ROC's de facto ambassador to the US, said American authorities have informed Taipei in detail about the agenda for a summit meeting between Clinton and his mainland counterpart, Jiang Zemin, in Beijing later this week.

The veteran diplomat said senior Clinton administration officials have on many public occasions, including congressional hearings, assured Taiwan that Clinton's mainland visit will by no means affect ROC's national interests nor weaken substantive Taipei-Washington ties.

"The American officials have repeatedly explained that Clinton's mainland trip is mainly aimed at promoting Asia-Pacific regional stability and incorporating Beijing into international norms and systems," Ding noted.
Ding, a former foreign minister, further said there are many communciations and dialogue channels between Taipei and Washington at various levels. He, however, would not elaborate.

Meanwhile, C. F. Koo, Taiwan's top negotiator with mainland China and a senior adviser to President Lee Teng-hui, said the ROC should focus attention on developments in several issues expected to come up in the Clinton-Jiang summit.
Such issues include the so-called new "three no's", the Beijing-proposed "one country, two systems" unification formula and US policy on arms sales to Taiwan, Koo explained.

The chairman of the semi-official Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) further said he expects to meet his mainland counterpart, Wang Daohan, chairman of the Beijing-based Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait (ARATS), this autumn.
SEF and ARATS are quasi-official intermediary bodies authorized by their respective governments to handle cross-strait exchanges in the absence of official ties.

DOC.HEADLINE: THREE LOCAL AIRLINES TO MERGE

TEXT.P: UNI Airlines, Taiwan Airlines and Great China Airlines will merge together on July 1 to form Taiwan's largest domestic carrier.
The new airline will operate under the name UNI Airlines.
UNI Airlines Chairman Hsu Juei-yuan will retain his post, as will UNI Airlines President Lin Chih-hong. Great China Airlines Chairman Sih Chung-ching will become UNI's vice chairman.

The airline will own 32 aircraft and operate 28 local flights. It will continue to offer one international flight between Kaohsiung and Kota Kinabalu in Malaysia, as well as charter flights from Taipei and Kaohsiung to Rangoon in Burma and from Kaohsiung to Laoag in the Philippines.
UNI Airlines expects to reduce its operational costs by 15 percent after the merger, said officials. The airline's workforce, meanwhile, will total nearly 2,000.

The merger comes in response to a call for consolidation from the Civil Aeronautics Administration (CAA). In the wake of a Formosa Airlines crash in March that claimed 13 live, the CAA proposed that Taiwan have no more than three or four local carriers. So far, however, no other local carriers have shown interest in the proposal.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN PEOPLE'S WILLINGNESS TO WORK RANKS 11TH

TEXT.P: Taiwan people's willingness to work is the 11th highest in the world according to a survey conducted by the Swiss-based International Institute for Management and Development.
The top ten countries in terms of their people's willingness to work are Norway, Switzerland, Japan, Sweden, Denmark, Finland, mainland China, the Netherlands, Singapore and Austria.
The United States placed 14th in the survey, Germany 17th , South Korea 25th, Thailand 36th and Indonesia 43rd.

DOC.HEADLINE: LOCAL GOVERNMENTS GEAR UP TO CURB SPREAD OF INTESTINAL VIRUS

TEXT.P: The Taipei City Government on Wednesday ordered all private and public kindergartens around the city to suspend operations for the time being to help prevent further spread of a killer intestinal virus.

The city government also directed all public and private elementary schools not to offer any programs during summer vacation and all swimming classes at various levels of municipal schools should be closed immediately.
Meanwhile, all public and private elementary schools are required to close the current semester immediately after the end of the third periodic academic examination.

Kuo Sheng-yu, director of the municipal Bureau of Education, said all these measures are aimed at facilitating cleaning and sterilization work at all campuses as part of efforts to contain the spread of enterovirus.
In case the current epidemic is brought under control during summer vacation, Kuo said, the bureau will organize special programs for the participation of students, parents and ordinary citizens.

As for city government-run day-care centers, the Bureau of Social Affairs said parents can decide on their own whether or not to continue sending their kids to the centers. Nevertheless, the bureau said parents should voluntarily stop sending their kids suspected of being infected by the virus to the day-care centers to help curb the spread of the virus.

Statistics compiled by the municipal Bureau of Health show that 4,387 cases babies and young children suspected of being infected by the intestinal virus had received medical treatment at hospitals throughout Taipei as of Tuesday. Among them, 417 had been hospitalized because they had developed complications. And the city's enterovirus-related death toll stands at four.

Municipal health officials said although medical records of hospitalized patients shows a downturn in the number of enterovirus infections, it's still too early to announce that the epidemic has been controlled.

For one thing, the officials said, there is no vaccine to prevent its spread in the first place. Moreover, they said, there is still no effective medicine to treat the enterovirus-caused complications.

Following in the footsteps of the Taipei City Government, the Taipei County Government and several other city and county governments around the island also decided to advance the closing date of the current semester by about a week.

Chan Chi-hsien, director-general of the Department of Health (DOH), quoted medical reports provided by major local hospitals as saying that the number of enterovirus infections has declined steadily. "Nevertheless, all DOH disease control unites will continue to keep alert on the development of the epidemic."

Chan further said the DOH will work out a package of measures and regulations to help various private cram schools or talent classes take precautionary measures to protect their young students from contracting the killer virus.

The enterovirus epidemic has so far claimed the lives of at least 50 infants and toddlers around the island. Parents are advised to keep their children away from public places and make sure that their kids change clothes and wash hands frequently.

Children under the age of five are most susceptible to the virus. Early symptoms resemble the flu, inclduing fever, headache and vomiting. Later, possible deadly complications include encephalitis, meningitis and acute inflammation of heart muscle.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN TRAVEL AGENCIES PROTEST AUSTRALIA'S VISA APPLICATION FEE HIKE

TEXT.P: Australia's decision to raise visa application fees for 26 countries, including Taiwan, has irritated local travel agencies.
Most of the 26 countries targeted for fee hikes, effective July 1, are developing nations.

"The Republic of China should not be put on the list," said Taipei Association of Travel Agents President Teng Ming-chang. The measure, he said, is aimed at reducing the number of illegal workers and visitors in Australia.
The TATA has sent a letter to Australia's visa-issuing office in Taipei, requesting that Taiwan be removed from the list. Fees for Taiwan tourists will rise from NT$900 (US$26) to more than NT$1,000.
Taiwan currently grants Australian nationals 14-day, visa-free entry, Teng said, noting that the privilege is not reciprocated.
If Taiwan is not removed from the list, the TATA will spearhead an Australian travel boycott, Teng said.
According to Tourism Bureau statistics, 153,000 Taiwan nationals visited Australia last year, with Taiwan ranking second Asia behind Singapore among Asian countries.

A conference on the fee hikes was held Monday. The meeting was attended by TATA members and representatives of EVA Airways Co. and Mandarin Airlines, an affiliate of China Airlines. Some attendees suggested petitioning the Ministry of Foreign Affairs to help persuade Australia to drop Taiwan from the list.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOEA MINISTER MEETS WITH TAIWAN BUSINESSMEN IN MALAYSIA
DOC.DATELINE: Kuala Lumpur, Malaysia, June 24 (CNA) (By Chi Ching-ling and Ben Wu)

TEXT.P: ROC Economics Minister Wang Chih-kang said on Wednesday the government's go south policy has remained unchanged over the past two years and that Taiwan businessmen's investments in Malaysia have totaled US$8.5 billion.

Wang made the remarks at a seminar in which he met with more than 60 Taiwan businessmen in Kuala Lumpur. Wang was accompanied by Paul J.K. Tso, representative of the Taipei Economic and Cultural Office in Malaysia.

The most serious problem faced by Taiwan businessmen in Malaysia at present is financing, said Chen Kun-huang, president of the Taiwan Business Association in Malaysia. He asked Wang to tell the Central Bank of China to offer assistance.
Malaysia, meanwhile, is freezing its foreign labor workforce, said Chen. The move poses further difficulties for Taiwan factories in Malaysia, he said.
In addition, Taiwan businessmen wonder whether the government will maintain its go south policy in the wake of the region's economic turmoil and political upheaval in Indonesia, Chen said.

Wang said the government will maintain its policy, adding that it has signed agreements with Malaysia on investment protection and double taxation avoidance to improve Malaysia's investment climate for Taiwan companies.
The economics minister and his group arrived in Kuala Lumpur after attending a ministerial meeting of the Asia Pacific Economic Cooperation forum in Kuching from June 21 to 23.

DOC.HEADLINE: BEIJING TO CONSIDER NEW PARTY'S REQUEST FOR BEIJING LIAISON OFFICE

TEXT.P: Beijing's official in charge of dealing with Taiwan did not give a definite response to the New Party's request to establish a liaison office in Beijing, said Chen Quei-miao, head of the New Party's mainland affairs committee.

Without giving a definite answer, Tang Shubei, vice chairman of Beijing's Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Straits, said he will seriously consider the request, according to Chen, who met with Tang in Beijing on Wednesday.
In a telephone briefing to reporters at the New Party's Taipei headquarters, Chen said that Tang, somewhat surprised by the initiative, replied that he is not in a position to make the decision.
Tang was quoted as saying he was worried that a green light to the request would herald hordes of similar requests from other political parties in Taiwan.

Chen said Tang promised to relay the request to the appropriate authorities after Chen argued that multiple contacts between mainland China and Taiwan would lead to further exchanges and improve Beijing's international standing.

Claiming the proposed office is intended to serve Taiwan businessmen in mainland China, Chen dismissed as media speculation reports from Taipei that quote unnamed mainland officials as saying Beijing would reject the proposal.
"If Tang, Beijing's point man in dealing with Taiwan, was not authorized to give an answer, how could other mainland officials reject the request out of hand?" asked Chen over the phone.
He predicted Tang will answer the party's request quickly.
Chen was asked by Wang Chien-shien, the party's candidate for Taipei mayor, to convey the request to the authorities in Beijing.

Calling the semi-official Straits Exchange Foundation nothing more than an agency for faxing letters, Wang advocated the establishment of the liaison office to better serve Taiwan businessmen in mainland China and has made it a campaign promise.

Wang's campaign manager, Jaw Shao-kong, who first conceived of the idea, said the office would not be a branch office for the party but a service station for Taiwan businessmen and another communications channel between the island and Beijing.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRIVATE KINDERGARTENS ALLOWED TO REOPEN JULY 1

TEXT.P: Contradicting an earlier ruling, Kuo Sheng-yu, director of the Taipei City government's Bureau of Education, said Wednesday that private kindergartens in the city may re-open on July 1.

Kuo had previously announced all private kindergarten must suspend classes indefinitely starting Thursday. The suspensions were designed to stem the spread of an enterovirus outbreak that has claimed more than 50 lives, mainly babies and young children, in Taiwan.

Kuo's initial decision prompted protests from private kindergartens, which called the decision rash. They said the suspensions would cause problems for families with two working parents. Also, students' families might ask for refunds, which could result in disputes between parents and schools.

After hearing the schools' grievances, Kuo admitted the original policy had not taken into account the fact that private kindergartens remain open during both summer and winter vacations, nor had possible inconveniences to parents been considered.
To avoid inconveniencing families with children in private kindergartens, Kuo agreed to allow the private kindergarten to re-open starting July 1.
Between now and then, however, the bureau hopes the schools will work to make sure they are cleaned and disinfected, Kuo said.

DOC.HEADLINE: CZECH FIRST LADY VISITS EASTERN TAIWAN

TEXT.P: Madame Dagmar Havlova, first lady of the Czech Republic, visited Taroko National Park in Hualien, eastern Taiwan, Wednesday.

Accompanied by Foreign Minister Jason Hu's wife Shau Hsiao-ling, Havlova also visited Hualien's Tzu Chi Hospital, sponsored by the Buddhist Compassion Relief Tzu Chi Foundation, Taiwan's largest and most highly renowned charitable organization.

Havlova, who devotes herself to charity work within the Czech Republic, said that she was impressed with the hospital. The first lady said she hopes that her country will one day have an organization similar to Tzu Chi.
Havlova arrived in Taipei Monday for an eight-day private visit, accompanied by first daughter Nina Veskrnova, her husband Shalev Ad-EI and a four-member entourage.

The Czech first lady met with President Lee Teng-hui on Tuesday. During the remainder of her visit, she will visit the National Fu Hsing Dramatic Arts Academy, the National Palace Museum and a government-funded Chinese herbal research center.

DOC.HEADLINE: CANDLE-LIT VIGIL HELD ON EVE OF CLINTON-JIANG MEETING

TEXT.P: A legislator from the opposition Democratic Progressive Party on Wednesday presented a "new three noes" on the eve of US President Bill Clinton's visit to mainalnd China.
Legislator Yeh Chu-lan, who is convenor of the Action Alliance Against Aggression, made the remarks in a candle-lit vigil sponsored by the alliance at the 2-28 Peace Memorial Park in downtown Taipei.
She said the "new three noes" are no to mainland China, no to major powers using Taiwan as a pawn and no to unification with mainland China.

Yeh's remarks contrast sharply with the better-known "three noes" -- no US support for Taiwan independence, no support for a "one China, one Taiwan" or "two Chinas" and no support for Taiwan's bid to join the United Nations.
In addition to Yeh, DPP legislators Lin Cho-shui and Chang Chun-hsiung, as well as officials from Taiwan Independence Party, spoke at the rally.
During the rally, hundreds of participants shouted pro-independence slogans.
Frank Hsieh, the DPP's candidate for Kaohsiung Mayor, called for a public referendum to determine whether Taiwan should be an independent country.
Taiwan will be a major topic in talks between Clinton and his mainland counterpart, Jiang Zemin, during Clinton's June 25-July 3 visit.

DOC.HEADLINE: ACTIVISTS ABANDON SHIP IN FAILED ATTEMPT TO LAND ON TIAOYUTAIS
DOC.DATELINE: Hong Kong, June 24 (CNA) (By Stanley Chang and Maubo Chang)

TEXT.P: A group of Hong Kong activists abandoned their ship on Wednesday after it took on water amid an failed attempt to land on the disputed Tiaoyutai islands in the East China Sea.
All activists and crew members left the 100-ton Diao Yu Tai at 1 p.m. and boarded three Taiwan ships carrying fellow supporters who intended to joint them in their landing attempt.
The Diao Yu Tai was blocked and rammed by Japanese patrol boats Wednesday morning. The ship had traveled to the islands to underscore the Chinese people's claims of sovereignty over them.
Damage to the boat left it unable to circle the islands as originally planned, let alone return to Northern Taiwan's Keelung Harbor for repairs, crew members said.
The Tiaoyutais, lying about 100 nautical miles northeast of Taiwan and 60 nautical miles northwest of the Japanese island of Ishigaki, are claimed by Japan, mainland China and Taiwan.
The three Taiwan ships the Hong Kong activists boarded returned safely to Shenao, a small fishing village in northern Taiwan, Wednesday evening.

DOC.HEADLINE: LOTT URGES CLINTON NOT TO KOWTOW TO MAINLAND CHINA DURING VISIT

TEXT.P: Senate Majority Leader Trent Lott urged US President Clinton to continue to support Taiwan on the eve of Clinton's departure to mainland China for a nine-day visit.

The Mississippi Republican wrote in The Washington Times Wednesday that mainland China's leaders will no doubt attempt to persuade Clinton to agree to a new joint communique, adding that Clinton should not be seduced.

"Our interest is in the peaceful resolution of differences between Beijing and Taipei, but we are not in the business of pressuring Taiwan. Strengthening deterrence supports that fundamental interest," wrote Lott.

Clinton should support developing and deploying effective missile defenses in Taiwan and throughout the region -- and not accede to mainland Chinese hopes for further concessions on Taiwan, noted the senator.

President Clinton has argued strongly for engagement with, rather than the isolation of, mainland China. But Lott said the key issue is what kind of engagement Clinton pursues at the summit. Engagement can be passive accommodation or it can be reciprocal advocacy of interests, he wrote.

Lott also called on Clinton to keep at the top of his agenda talks on easing tensions on the Korean peninsula, addressing mainland China's threats toward India and ending mainland China's proliferation of weapons of mass destruction.

Lott suggested Clinton meet Chinese democrats, visit Japan on his way back, honor the heroes of Tiananmen Square, highlight religious freedom, remember Tibet, be serious about national security, cooperate on investigating campaign contributions and apply US nonproliferation laws.

DOC.HEADLINE: GLOBAL LEADERSHIP NEEDED TO TACKLE ASIAN CRISIS

TEXT.P: The world needs decisive global leadership from the United States, Japan and mainland China now or the Asian crisis could worsen, Singapore's Information and Arts Minister, Yeo Yong Bong, warned on Tuesday.
"Like all crises, this Asian crisis will either strengthen or weaken us," he said at a welcome dinner ahead of Business Week's eighth annual Asia Leadership Forum.
"If there is sufficient global leadership, the promise of the Pacific century will eventually be realized. If not, Asia will still emerge, but it will be a troubled world."

Noting that the world is searching for a new equilibrium in times of change, Yeo, who is also second minister for trade and industry, likened the global changes to "tectonic shifts on the earth's crust."

Among these shifts are the evolution of the United States' relationship with Japan, the rise of mainland China's political and economic power and the weakening of traditional hierarchies and government monopolies, which have resulted from an information technology revolution.
He pointed out that the underlying tension between the United States and Japan manifested itself in the regional havoc now being wreaked by the volatility of the dollar-yen exchange rate.
While Japan is powerful economically and has the ability to pull Asia out of its crisis, it is unable to do so because of internal political weaknesses, he said.
On the other hand, he said, the US economy, despite being the largest in the world, is increasingly debt ridden.

"We thus have a situation where the greatest power on earth is also the world's largest debtor nation, while the world's greatest creditor nation is, for historical reasons, unable to lead. This creates a dangerous fault-line in world politics and economics."
Underlining the growing importance of mainland China, Yeo noted how a hint from its officials about devaluing the renminbi had sent regional financial markets tumbling.

"The triangular relationship between the US, Japan and China will be of decisive importance to peace and prosperity in the region. The Asian crisis today is partly the result of tensions in that relationship," he said.
While the tectonic shifts would send "earthquakes throughout the region for many years to come," the region's survival strategy was three-pronged, he said.
First, individuals and corporations have to return to basics and recognize the value of good education, hard work, thrift and honesty.
Second, political systems must meet the test of good leadership, good government and wider political participation.
Third, problems of world governance must be tackled. International institutions created in the post-war era are becoming less relevant to new needs, he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER VINCENT SIEW TO VISIT SOUTH PACIFIC IN JULY

TEXT.P: Premier Vincent Siew is scheduled to visit Tonga, Fiji and the Solomon Islands from July 2-9 to further cement bilateral ties between Taiwan and the South Pacific islands, according to Foreign Minister Jason Hu.
In his report to Premier Siew on the upcoming trip on Wednesday, Hu said relevant arrangements are almost complete as only a number of details have yet to be confirmed.

Canberra has agreed to grant transit visas to Siew and his entourage, which will consist of four Cabinet-level officials and about a dozen business leaders, allowing them to transit in the eastern Australian city of Brisbane before heading for Tonga.
Australia authorities, however, insisted that Siew and his party conduct no public activities nor meeting the press during their stay in Brisbane, Hu said.
The premier may also make a transit stop in Hawaii on his return trip, he added.

Siew, in his capacity as a special envoy of President Lee Teng-hui, will attend celebrations marking the 80th birthday of King Taufa'ahau Tupou IV of the Kingdom of Tonga, and will attend the 20th anniversary celebrations of the founding of the Solomon Islands.
A Taiwan aboriginal dance troupe will join Siew's delegation in Tonga and the Solomon Islands to attend and perform in the festivities.

The premier will likely represent Taiwan in the signing of a fishery cooperation agreement with the Solomon Islands and contracts to purchase timber and plywood from that South Pacific island country.
King Tupou of Tonga, who turns 80 on July 4, paid a four-day state visit to the Republic of China in August last year.
Tonga and the Solomon Islands are two of the ROC's four diplomatic allies in the South Pacific, which also include Nauru and Tuvalu.

Fiji, which has no formal diplomatic ties but maintains cordial relations with the ROC, opened its representative office in Taipei late last year. President Kamisese Mara traveled to Taipei and personally presided over the opening of the office on Dec. 15, 1997.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI RESIDENTS WORRIED OVER AFTERMATH OF CLINTON-JIANG SUMMIT

TEXT.P: A large number of Taipei residents expressed worry that the results of an upcoming summit between US President Bill Clinton and his mainland counterpart Jiang Zemin would harm Taiwan's interests, an opinion poll showed.
The poll, conducted by Taipei City Assemblywoman Chen Hsieh-fen, found that 43 percent of those surveyed are worried about the aftermath of the Clinton-Jiang summit, while 42 percent are not.
It also found that 81 percent of the respondents know of Clinton's current mainland Chinese trip, which began on Thursday, while 18 percent do not.

The survey of more than 600 Taipei residents through online websites on Tuesday and Wednesday, found that 36 percent of respondents think Taipei Mayor Chen Shui-bian should take the initiative to express Taiwan's stance to the US on the eve of Clinton's arrival to the mainland.

Some respondents said since Chen has been active in promoting "city diplomacy," and has visited the United States several times during his tenure, he should take the initiative to tell Washington Taiwan people are opposed to any deals that might be made during the trip that could put Taiwan at risk.
The poll also found that as many as 35 percent of respondents said Mayor Chen does not need to take that initiative as a spokesman for Taiwan.
Those conducting the poll urged respondents to express their opinions about Clinton's Beijing trip to the White House and US Congress through online channels.
