DOC.HEADLINE: US-CHINA RELATIONSHIP AWKWARD

TEXT.P: The relationship between the United States and mainland China remains an "uncomfortable embrace" despite a desire on both sides for an improvement in ties, the San Jose Mercury News said Monday.

In a dispatch headlined "China, US in awkward new dance" from Beijing, the Mercury said mainland China hopes a friendly United States would boost its status and power, and improve China's standard of living with American investment and technology.

Beyond seeking US investment and technology, it said, China needs US cooperation for its goal of reunifying with Taiwan. Beijing would have a more difficult time convincing Taipei to cooperate if Washington continues to assure Taiwan of its military protection and provide arms.

But to the United States and most Americans, China still appears menacing. It is a country that has nuclear missiles pointed their way, one that crushed a democracy movement by killing hundreds and imprisoning more, and one that may have tried to buy influence in the 1996 elections and the White House itself.

The Mercury cited enormous opposition to Clinton's visit to China, the first US presidential trip to the mainland since the Tiananmen Square massacre. The visit cannot help but reward the Chinese and help cement Jiang Zemin's power as leader as it restores international approval of China that was lost in 1989.

Clinton's visit "will be the final formal step in ending America's post-Tiananmen diplomatic isolation," wrote Robert Ross, a research associate at the Fairbank Center for East Asian Research at Harvard University.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC SPENDS NT$52 BILLION ANNUALLY TO HANDLE CASH

TEXT.P: The cost of handling cash in the Republic of China amounts to NT$52 billion a year, according to a new study.

The study, conducted by the Asian Banker Journal (ABJ), evaluated the cost of handling cash in the ROC, Australia, Malaysia, Indonesia, the Philippines, Thailand and Hong Kong, using Singapore as a benchmark.

The total amount includes all the interest lost for cash kept in float, the salaries of staff employed to deal with cash, transport costs, lost opportunity costs if the money could be more profitably used elsewhere, and invisible cost items.
The study showed Singapore's cost of handling cash in a year amounted to S$656.6 million. This figure is up to 12 times lower than the cost of handling cash in other Asian countries.

"The cost in Singapore is lower than other Asian countries because it is physically smaller than the other countries, and also because the interest rates here are also lower, resulting in lower opportunity cost," ABJ's managing director and editor-in-chief Emmanuel Daniel was quoted as saying.

The study pointed out that while using cash makes sense for the individual customer as the cost per transaction is insignificant, it saddles organizations involved in processing cash with high costs, as total costs over a year accumulate substantially.
According to the study, the total amount required in handling cash per year by the eight Asian countries and area are as follows:
1. Australia A$7.9 billion S$8.1 b.
2. Hong Kong HK$7.0 b. S$1.5 b.
3. Indonesia 6,125 b. rupiah S$0.8 b.
4. Malaysia M$3.6 b. S$1.6 b.
5. Philippines 14.6 b. pesos S$0.68 b.
6. Singapore S$0.66 b.
7. Taiwan NT$52.0 b. S$2.7 b.
8. Thailand 39.9 b. baht S$1.7 b.

DOC.HEADLINE: CONTINUED US COMMITMENT TO PEACE IN EAST ASIA, ROC SEEN NECESSARY

TEXT.P: US President Bill Clinton must reaffirm the US' commitment to security in East Asia and Taiwan when he meets with mainland Chinese President Jiang Zemin in Beijing, the Sydney Morning Herald editorial said Thursday.

"Australia will wish to see a continuing US commitment to maintaining security in East Asia through the US-Japan Security Treaty, which Australia maintains is not directed at China, but is necessary to underpin stability in the region," the editorial headlined "Mr. Clinton in China" said.
"Continuing US support for Taiwan is part of the same exercise in maintaining an equilibrium essential for peace," it added.

Clinton is also expected to address concern over China's human rights record as well as the huge US trade deficit with the mainland. The former concern has been somewhat muted by the latter due to the Asian region's economic turmoil, the Herald said.

"Mr. Clinton should not ignore the importance of human rights in China. Freedom from human rights abuses is important not just for its own sake, but also as an essential precondition for China's transformation as an increasingly free and prosperous nation," the editorial said.

DOC.HEADLINE: AUSTRALIAN BUSINESS LEADERS CONFIDENT OF ASIAN ECONOMIC PICK-UP

TEXT.P: Australian business leaders expressed optimism over prospects in Asia despite the current turmoil and are looking for new opportunities in the hope that Canberra will play an active role in dealing with the crisis.

In a joint survey of 2,200 business directors by the Australian Institute of Company Directors and the KPMG Australia, 64 percent of the 563 respondents from the companies in Australia want the government to pressure their Asian counterparts to institute reforms, and 31 percent would like a review of the Australian export grant scheme.

About 14 percent of the respondents want Canberra to take other measures such as tax reform. There is little support for interventionist measures to protect the Australian economy from foreign competition with only 8 percent in favor of tariff protection and 5 percent who want more trade barriers.

About 86 percent of the directors surveyed believe conditions in Asia will improve within two years. Optimism for domestic recovery is higher as 73 percent expect their situation to improve within a year.
A majority of 69 percent of the respondents believe business in Asia will be more competitive after the economic shake-up.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN DAREDEVIL TO ATTEMPT BALLOON CROSSING OF TAIWAN STRAIT

TEXT.P: Taiwan daredevil Ke Shou-liang is reportedly preparing to fly across the Taiwan Strait in a hot-air balloon, sources from mainland China said on Thursday.
Ke, known as "Blackie" to his fans, told friends in Wuhan that the cross-strait balloon flight is scheduled for August or September next year when the winds are favorable.
He said he may invite three other men, one each from Taiwan, Hong Kong and mainland China, to take part in the trip. He expects it may take 15 days to complete the crossing.
In preparation for the trip, Ke has trained for six months and plans to travel to the United States to take a test for his balloonist license before embarking on the cross-strait flight.
Ke jumped over the Great Wall of China north of Beijing on a 150 cc motorcycle in 1992. He also used a specially-built car to leap over the Yellow River in June 1997.
During the 1997 stunt, his customized Mitsubishi managed to leap 60 meters over the churning river at Hukou waterfall in the northern part of mainland China.

His vehicle accelerated from zero to 140 km/h in seven seconds, giving Ke the necessary velocity to race up a 240-meter long ramp in Ji County in Shanxi Province, shoot over the river and land on a 150-meter long cushioned runway in Yichuan County in Shaanxi Province.
Death-defying stunts are nothing new to the 45-year-old stuntman, who was born in Zhejiang Province in eastern China and moved to Taiwan when he was 3.

The latest reports have said that Ke is also planning to fly over the Three Gorges on the Yangzi River in central mainland China. Ke himself, however, said he has not yet decided whether to take on that stunt or not.

DOC.HEADLINE: BEIJING TO SHOW LENIENCY TO ALLEGED TAIWAN SPIES

TEXT.P: Mainland Chinese authorities will show leniency to four alleged Taiwan spies, a quasi-official Beijing-based intermediary body said on Thursday.
The Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait (ARATS) made the statement in a faxed message to its Taiwan counterpart, the Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF).

The ARATS said it has appealed to relevant mainland agencies for lenient treatment of the four Taiwan merchants who have been detained on the mainland since early March on charges of spying for Taiwan.
The association also said the accused -- Ko Chien-ming, Han Yueh-ting, Chen Shao-yu and Chou Chang-ming -- are being detained in Beijing and are all in good health.
According to mainland regulations, the men's families cannot meet them at the moment. Such meetings may be possible after the trials begin, mainland sources said.
The association promised to convey the opinions of the SEF and the families of the detained to concerned mainland authorities and to deliver letters or household articles sent by their families.
"We will also push related agencies to try the case as soon as possible and to give lenient punishments to those found guilty within legal limits," it added.
The ARATS and SEF are semi-official bodies authorized by their respective governments to handle cross-strait exchanges in the absence of official ties.
This was the first time that the ARATS has given a clear response to SEF's inquiries about the case.

Upon receiving the ARATS' letter, SEF Vice Chairman and Secretary-General Shi Hwei-yow reiterated Taiwan's basic stance that mainland China will handle the case based on the principles of openness and transparency. "This will be the best way to reduce suspicion and animosity between the two sides," he added.

Beijing announced on May 28 that it has broken a Taiwan spy ring and arrested four Taiwan nationals on charges of espionage. It accused the four men of having been recruited by Taiwan's Military Intelligence Bureau (MIB) under the Ministry of National Defense to engage in espionage on the mainland.

Mainland China's Ministry of State Security alleged that Ko Chien-ming was recruited by the MIB shortly after he founded the Chinese Association for the Promotion of Cross-Strait Civil Exchanges in Taipei in 1991.

The mainland ministry also accused the MIB of having financially supported the association in hopes of planting its agents in the association and using it as a cover for espionage operations in mainland China. It said the three other alleged spies were recruited by Ko in 1996 and 1997, respectively.

According to a May 28 resport by mainland China's state-run Central TV Station, all the four accused had confessed to working for the MIB and one of them was found to be in possession of the MIB's "spy manual."
Taiwan's Ministry of National Defense has categorically denied all the mainland allegations, saying it has never had any contacts or connections with Ko's association.

DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER EXPRESSES SINCERE APOLOGY OVER VIRAL OUTBREAK

TEXT.P: Premier Vincent Siew on Thursday apologized to the public for an enterovirus outbreak as the Department of Health (DOH) announced new measures to curb the spread of the intestinal virus.
Siew said the outbreak of the epidemic has caused great concern and even panic among the public, and he wished to express his sincere apology over the outbreak.
Siew made the remarks after he listening to a report by DOH Director-General Chang Chi-shean about the latest situation on the epidemic.
The official death toll from the enterovirus has increased to 51 after a 15-month-old baby died in Linkou Chang Gung Memorial Hospital in suburban Taipei Wednesday.
Siew said health and medical institutions have pulled all the stops in fighting the disease and the rate of deaths and the number of those infected have eased since the peak of the outbreak.
However, he warned that according to collected data, the epidemic has not yet come under control.
Siew said the top priority now is to use all medical resources and facilities to curb the spread of the disease at an earliest possible date.

The DOH, noting that the enterovirus is usually spread by physical contact, mapped out guidelines for nurseries and kindergartens Thursday following a decision Wednesday by the Taipei City Government to suspend operations of public and private kindergartens for the time being.

According to the guidelines, the number of students in each class must be less than 30. If two students in the same class have been infected with the enterovirus, the class must immediately be suspended and operators must conduct a thorough cleaning and disinfecting of the premises.

The enterovirus usually attacks children under 5 years. The virus breaks down the immune system and can leave infants susceptible to encephalitis, meningitis and acute inflammation of the heart muscle.
Early symptoms are similar to the flu, including fever, headache and vomiting. The rate of death from viral infection is low if victims are offered timely and proper medical treatment.

DOC.HEADLINE: EXPERT URGES CBC NOT TO REDUCE RESERVE REQUIREMENTS

TEXT.P: Despite increasing domestic calls for a loose currency policy to encourage stock trading, now is not the best time to lower reserve requirements for banks, a prominent scholar said Thursday.

Taiwan Institute of Economic Research director Tung Jui-pin said a decline in reserve requirements would trigger a further depreciation of the New Taiwan dollar because released capital is expected to flow into the foreign exchange market rather than share investments.

Tung also pointed out that on Oct. 16, 1997, the Central Bank of China implemented its largest reserve requirement reduction, announcing a day later it would let the market decide the NT dollar's value. The move caused huge losses in the currency.

The experience showed that improperly releasing funds into the market does not help resolve financial and economic chaos but benefits foreign exchange profiteers, Tung said, warning the CBC not to fall into the trap.

He said there are currently fewer demands for short-term loans than long-term fund-lending, he therefore suggested the CBC first take effective measures, such as release postal deposits to relieve pressure from long-term fund demands, then it can consider moderate adjustment of high-leveled reserve requirements for banks.
The CBC's current reserve requirements averages at 8.3 percent, and CBC officials have indicated the level will gradually decrease depending on the island's economic and financial changes.

Affected by the Asian financial crisis, the NT dollar slid from 28.48 against the greenback last July to 33.989 in May. According to CBC statistics, the local currency was seen drops in the July-May period, with the exception of last September and February.
The largest plunge during that 11-month period was 7.6 percent in last October, the statistics showed.
As of Wednesday, the NT dollar dropped to 34.351 against the US dollar. There were no optimistic signs of an upturn as the Japanese yen continues in its seemingly unstoppable depreciation.

In the face of the currency fluctuation which has effected local business trade and economic development, the CBC will hold a board of directors meeting Thursday afternoon to discuss how to settle Taiwan's financial problems.

The top concerns at the meeting will likely be how to maintain Taiwan's currency and goods-price stability, the topics identified by CBC Governor Perng Fai-nan in an urgent board of directors meeting held in early June.

DOC.HEADLINE: CONSUMERS' FOUNDATION URGES UNIFORM TRAFFIC ACCIDENT COMPENSATION

TEXT.P: The Consumers' Foundation questioned on Thursday the standard for compensating families of victims who die in air and land accidents.
Jason F. Lee, the foundation's secretary-general, made the remarks in a foundation-sponsored seminar.
One person's life is as valuable as another's, he said. Likewise, compensation should be equal, regardless of whether the victim died on land or in the air, he said.

Foundation officials pointed out that the families of victims in two major air crashes earlier this year each received NT$10 million (US$289,855) in compensation. Thirteen people died in a Formosa Airlines crash in March, while 196 died in a China Airlines crash in February.

In comparison, they said the Ministry of Transportation and Communications only recently raised the compensation to up to NT$4.4 million (US$127,536) for families of victims who die in train accidents. And compensation for victims of families in automobile accidents remains unchanged at NT$1.2 million (US$34,782).
In addition to calling for standard compensation amounts, Lee said adjustments should be made for cost of living increases.

Foundation officials suggested local traffic accident compensation should be NT$5 million per person. That amount, they said, is five times a household's average disposable income in 1996, plus a tax-free funeral expense.
That amount will meet the needs of bereaved families and the demands of social justice, they said.
But Chang Shun-ching, senior specialist of MOTC's Railways and Highways Department, said the uniform compensation proposal must be studied further.
Chang said it may be inappropriate to set a uniform standard through an administrative order.

DOC.HEADLINE: BEIJING STEPS UP MEASURES TO CONTROL DISSIDENTS
DOC.DATELINE: New York, June 24 (CNA) (By Huang Kwan-chun & Eva Chen)

TEXT.P: Authorities in Beijing are stepping up dissident arrests and efforts to control dissidence throughout mainland China on the eve of US President Bill Clinton's visit.

Yen Jun, a dissident from Xian City, Shaanxi Province, was taken from his home Wednesday afternoon. His whereabouts is still unknown to family and friends, according to a news release from the Hong Kong-based Information Center for Human Rights and Democratic Movement in China. Xian, an ancient mainland Chinese capital, will be Clinton's first stop.
Yen was one of 70 people who co-signed an open letter to Clinton two days ago, urging the US president to meet with Chinese dissidents during his visit.
Xu Wenli, a prominent dissident from Beijing who has been repeatedly interviewed by the media, was recently placed under house arrest and 24-hour surveillance.
Four of Xu's middle school classmates who planned to pay Xu a visit were removed from his doorstep by security police on Wednesday. The four were released after a four-hour detainment.
Shanghai dissident Han Lifa applied last week for a permit to hold a rally to welcome Clinton. Instead Han was placed under police surveillance, as were his sister and brother.

Besides arresting and detaining dissidents, authorities are ridding themselves of other potential nuisances by allowing them to leave the country. For example, the mother of Bao Ge, a dissident exiled to the United States, finally received a visa to visit the United States just a few days before Clinton's trip.
Clinton's trip, which runs from June 25 to July 3, will include visits to Xian, Beijing, Shanghai and Gueilin.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN'S 'SACRED TREE' TO BE FELLED
DOC.DATELINE: Chiayi, southern Taiwan, June 25 (CNA) (By Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: The "Sacred Tree" on Alishan (Mt. Ali) in southern Taiwan, generally regarded as the symbol of Taiwan, is slanting to such a degree that it will be pulled to the ground with a cable in a few days, the Taiwan Forest Bureau reported on Thursday.

The slanting red hinoki cypress, which is more than 3,000 years old, drew a group of specialists, including sociologists, botanists and agricultural and tourism officials, to the site three years ago to determine how the revered tree should be handled.
The slant has become so pronounced, especially after torrential flooding hit the mountain last July, that the tree could collapse. It will be felled for safety reasons.

A section of railway on the mountain will be closed to traffic while the tree is pulled down. A series of activities, including a retrospective of the tree's history, will be held to mark the occasion.

The Sacred Tree was first made known to the world in 1906 when Taiwan was under its 11th year of Japanese rule. After the Japanese found the tree within a huge forest, they built a mountain railway to Mt. Ali and began exploiting the rich source of lumber there.
The Sacred Tree was twice hit by lightning in the 1950s. It was badly burned when first struck in 1953. Three years later, another bolt finished off the tree.
In 1962, experts from the Yushan Forest Administration planted hinoki cypress seedlings in the trunk of the Sacred Tree.
As of last July, the dead tree stood 52.7 meters tall with a girth of 19.39 meters.

DOC.HEADLINE: CROSS-STRAIT TIES TO SOUR IF CLINTON-JIANG SUMMIT HURTS TAIWAN

TEXT.P: The Republic of China will definitely adopt countermeasures if the impending summit meeting between the United States and mainland China impair its interests, a senior official said on Thursday.

Wu An-chia, vice chairman of the Cabinet-level Mainland Affairs Council (MAC), made the statement at a seminar on the possible impact on Taiwan of US President Bill Clinton's June 25-July 3 state visit to the mainland.

"We'll certainly cry out and adopt countermeasures if we feel insecure or hurt by the results of Clinton's summit meeting with his mainland counterpart, Jiang Zemin, in Beijing later this week," Wu said.

He would not reveal which countermeasures the ROC may adopt. "It's inappropriate to unveil such measures at the moment," he said, adding the ROC would not like to see such a scenario emerge becasue it would mean worsening of relations across the Taiwan Strait.

Reiterating that Taipei has never intended to interfere with Beijing-Washington engagements, Wu said the ROC will be delighted to see the Clinton-Jiang summit contribute to peace in the Taiwan Strait and stability in the entire Asia-Pacific region.
"We also hope the Clinton-Jiang meeting will contribute to reform and human rights development in mainland China," Wu added.
The senior mainland affairs official recognized the US efforts to bring mainland China more closely into the international community.

Nevertheless, Wu stressed that the United States should not sacrifice Taiwan's interests in engaging mainland China. "Hopefully, the United States will simultaneously reinforce ties with Taiwan while improving relations with the mainland."
Wu further said it's unfair to define cross-strait disputes as a "Taiwan issue." There is only a "mainland China issue," he asserted.

"The competition between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait lies in systems and way of life," Wu said, adding that as long as the gaps between political, economic and social systems as well as lifestyles on both sides are narrowed, cross-strait unification will be realized easily.

Against this backdrop, Wu said the ROC hopes the upcoming Clinton-Jiang meeting will contribute to peace and stability in the Taiwan Strait and to positive cross-strait interaction. "Hopefully, long-stalled cross-strait dialogue will resume shortly after Clinton's mainland visit," he added.
Beijing unilaterally suspended institutionalized cross-strait dialogue shortly after ROC President Lee Teng-hui made a landmark visit to the United States in June 1995.

DOC.HEADLINE: NEW COLD WAR SEEN LOOMING IN SOUTH ASIA

TEXT.P: A new cold war is looming, this time in Asia, as the United States ignores mainland China's nuclear technology transfers to Pakistan while criticizing Russia for similar transfers to India, according to the Australian Financial Review.

An Indian delegation led by Defense Secretary Ajit Kumar visited Russia and reportedly agreed to further collaboration on radar, electronic warfare, submarine and missile systems. It also discussed further purchases of Russian Sukhoi Su-30 long-range fighters, which have been proposed by Indian officials as a delivery system for a nuclear strike against mainland China.

In addition, Russia's Atomic Energy Minister, Yevgeny Adamov, has signed a US$3 billion deal with the chairman of the Indian Atomic Energy Commission to supply two nuclear reactors, which the United States worries could be used to produce nuclear weapons.
The US State Department has criticized the dealings between India and Russia, and Washington has accused Moscow of undermining sanctions against New Delhi for its recent nuclear tests.

But, at the same time, Washington has ignored Chinese assistance to Pakistan, which has followed in India's footsteps. The daily reports that New Delhi believes mainland China has supplied Pakistan with nuclear bombs, leading to perceptions of US hypocrisy.

The daily reported that the Indian government is expected to blame Pakistan for a bomb that recently derailed a train in the disputed region of Kashmir, while Pakistan will likely blame terrorist bombings within its borders on India.
"It's as if the old Cold War never ended. Except now there's a new one in South Asia," according to the paper.

DOC.HEADLINE: AUSTRALIAN LABOR PARTY FORMS GOVERNMENT IN QUEENSLAND

TEXT.P: After several rounds of haggling during the past week, Queensland Premier Rob Borbidge is out of a job and will be replaced by Labor Party leader Peter Beattie.
Beattie will attempt to form a minority government within the "Sunshine State."

Beattie, whose Labor Party won 44 of the 89 seats contested during Queensland's recent legislative elections, won support from Independent Member of Parliament Peter Wellington, giving him the 45 seats needed to form a government.
He foiled an attempt by Borbidge to form a government with the support of the National Party, two independent parliamentarians and the One Nation Party, which won 11 seats in the recent elections.
Borbidge's failure to build a government was welcomed by Asians in Australia who worried about the prospect of the One Nation Party being part of a coalition government.
Analysts said the Labor Party government under Beattie would not adopt One Nation's policies and would instead emphasize stability and good management.
However, the 11 One Nation parliamentarians are expected to hold the balance of power after Beattie becomes Queensland's premier.
Beattie earlier told Australian media that he would introduce workable and reasonable policies that would benefit Australians in his state, particularly those in Queensland's rural areas.

Beattie's victory is a boost for the Australian Labor Party in its quest to regain power at the federal level since being ousted in favor of a coalition forged between the Liberal and National parties after elections in March 1996.

DOC.HEADLINE: MEXICAN 'WOLF MAN' VISITS TAIWAN SCHOOL CHILDREN

TEXT.P: Mexico's "Wolf Man," Jesus Manuel Fajardo Aceves, visited Panchiao Primary School in Taipei County, northern Taiwan, on Thursday.
He was warmly welcomed by teachers and by students, who asked Fajardo to pose for pictures with them and sign autographs.
Fajardo introduced himself by saying, "Hola, Ta-Chia-Hau," a combination of Spanish and Mandarin that can be translated as, "Hello, how is everybody?"
Fajardo suffers from a genetic disorder called hirsutism that has caused his face to be shrouded in thick, dark hair, giving him a wolf-like appearance.
The 24-year-old, who is listed in the Guinness Book of World Records, was accompanied by Taichung's Guinness Museum of World Records executive Chen Wen-hua.
Fajardo told students it has taken him a long time to learn to accept his condition and that he has struggled to gain confidence. As a young man, he was shunned by society, he said.

He was awarded an honorary diploma from Wen Hsin Elementary School in Taichung, central Taiwan, Tuesday, which he called "a dream come true." Fajardo received only three years of formal education before joining a circus.

He arrived in Taiwan in April for a six-month goodwill visit at the invitation of the Taichung museum. Chen said the Taiwan trip is a breakthrough step in Fajardo's efforts to emerge from his closed world.
Chen said he hopes Fajardo's experience will make Taiwan people more tolerant and accepting of people with physical or mental disabilities.

DOC.HEADLINE: NT DOLLAR DOWN DESPITE CENTRAL BANK INTERVENTION

TEXT.P: The New Taiwan dollar dropped NT$0.105, a loss of 0.3 percent, to close at 34.457 against the greenback on Thursday, as steep declines triggered intervention by Taiwan's central bank.
The NT dollar plunged soon after opening at the day's high of 34.203. Demand for the US dollar pushed the NT below 34.5 to as low as 34.547.
In response, the Central Bank of China dumped about US$6 million to shore up the currency, said dealers, noting the bank has acted decisively to defend the NT dollar whenever it nears the 34.5 level.
Interbank US dollar trading amounted to US$296 million.

DOC.HEADLINE: SHARE PRICE UP ON TAIEX

TEXT.P: Taiwan's share prices climbed 0.7 percent on Thursday as investors expected Central Bank of China to lower bank reserve requirements.
The Taiwan Stock Exchange's weighted price index, the key barometer of the market, moved up 51.93 points to close at 7,722.64.
The bourse opened at 7,762.32 and fluctuated between 7,777.29 and 7,695.74.
Gainers outnumbered losers 276 to 149, with 67 stocks remaining unchanged.
In all, 2.29 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$114.47 billion (US$3.33 billion) during the three-hour session.
All eight major stock categories posted gains, with exception of paper and pulp issues which dropped 0.5 percent.

Cement and textile shares were the largest winners of the session -- both surging 1.3 percent. Foodstuff issues ranked second with 0.9 percent. Electronic engineering stocks rose 0.8 percent; plastic and chemical issues, 0.6 percent; financial stocks, 0.4 percent; and construction shares, 0.1 percent.

DOC.HEADLINE: AUSTRALIA WANTS STABILITY BETWEEN THE US AND MAINLAND CHINA

TEXT.P: Australia expects talks between presidents Bill Clinton and Jiang Zemin can sharply reduce conflicts between the United States and mainland China and enable them to establish and maintain a stable balance of power, according to the Australian Financial Review.
If that does not happen, however, Canberra could be sandwiched between the two countries should hostilities erupt over Taiwan.
Despite assurances of a new era in Sino-US relations, the two countries will remain competitors, according to the author of the analysis, Geoffrey Barker.

Barker noted that for all Clinton's talk of cooperation, the United States ultimately sees mainland China as a rising economic and strategic power which, one way or another, it has to coax or change or co-opt in order to limit its potential ability to impact adversely US interests and influence. Powerful anti-mainland China lobbies in Washington advocate attempts to contain mainland China.
While mainland China is expected to pressure the United States to reduce arms sales to Taiwan, Clinton has vowed not to further relations with Beijing at Taipei's expense, Barker wrote.
In addition to Taiwan, there are tensions over the Korean peninsula, the United States' commitment to keep 100,000 troops in Asia, nuclear non-proliferation and military technology transfers.
Barker said that none of these differences has prevented strategic or economic cooperation between the two countries when it is in both their interests to do so.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAINLAND CHINA WILL STRESS COMMON INTERESTS WITH US: INDIAN DAILY

TEXT.P: Beijing will show US President Bill Clinton during his visit that the United States has common interests with mainland China, interests that pit them against Japan and India, a New Delhi-based newspaper said in its editorial Thursday.

The Hindustan Times said mainland Chinese officials have already begun pointing out such interests. For example, the two countries' alliance against Japan during World War II has been noted, according to the paper.

"For Mr. Jiang Zemin, there could not be a better timing of the visit than this when Japan is in the throes of a severe economic crisis and its earlier role as the major economic player in Asia has been considerably diluted."

The paper said mainland China has an opportunity to persuade Clinton that the country has acted responsibly during Asia' economic meltdown and that its political, economic and military strength entitle it to a prominent position in Asian affairs.
Noting that Clinton wants mainland China to play a bigger role in Asia, The Hindustan Times said that emerging strategic relations between Beijing and Washington bode ill for India.

Although mainland China is now projecting itself as a "reformed responsible power which is seeking peace and stability in Asia," the editorial warned Washington and Asian countries that Beijing's real goal is to make Americans and Asians "forget its role in actively assisting the North Korean and Pakistani nuclear programs."
India has rightly rejected third-party intervention in bilateral matters with Pakistan after Clinton suggested mainland China's participation in any future Indo-Pakistani talks, it said.

DOC.HEADLINE: NZ FOREIGN MINISTER SEES ONE NATION DAMAGING AUSTRALIAN TRADE

TEXT.P: The One Nation Party is damaging Australia's relationship with its biggest trading partner -- East Asia, according to New Zealand Foreign Affairs and Trade Minister Don McKinnon.
The New Zealand Press Associates quoted McKinnon as saying that One Nation was negatively impacting Australia.
McKinnon made the remarks when he opened an international quantity surveyors' conference in Queenstown Wednesday.
He said people he had met throughout East Asia recently were very uncomfortable with One Nation and its leader, Pauline Hanson.
"I continue to tell people that Pauline Hanson is not a New Zealander," McKinnon said.
Australia has to recognize that 60 percent of its trade is with East Asia, he said.
"That's important part of the economy, so if they start alienating large sections of that community, that will not help at all," he said.
McKinnon was dismissive of the possible emergence of a One Nation-aligned party in New Zealand.
"We've had them before -- far right, Nazi-oriented, white-faces-only parties. If that's going to occur, I think New Zealanders will treat it with the contempt it deserves," he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: DEMONSTRATION HELD AT AIT TAIPEI OFFICE

TEXT.P: A group of representatives from several organizations staged a demonstration at the Taipei Office of the American Institute in Taiwan (AIT) on the occasion of President Bill Clinton's visit to mainland China.
In a statement to the AIT Taipei Office, the demonstrators said they hope the United States will understand that it is the people of Taiwan who have the right to decide the future of Taiwan.

The demonstrators included Huang Chao-yen, president of the Association of Taiwan Professors; Legislator Trong R. Chai of the major opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP); Chairman Kao Chen-yen of the Green Party; Wang Shih-chien, adviser to the DPP, and leaders of other civilian organizations known for their advocacy of Taiwan independence.
The statement said it is an unalienable right of Taiwan people to build "the Republic of Taiwan," no matter whether the United States supports it or not.

They also said that the sovereignty of Taiwan should not be put on the agenda of the submit meeting to be held Saturday between President Clinton and mainland Chinese President Jiang Zemin in Beijing.

An acting spokesman for the AIT Taipei Office said that the demonstrators' concern over the submit meeting will be conveyed to the US government. The AIT official also said that Taiwan's interests will not be compromised in the submit meeting, and that no communique concerning Taiwan will be issued during the meeting.

DOC.HEADLINE: PROBE INTO ALLEGED SEXUAL MISCONDUCT HITS SANG
DOC.DATELINE: Paris, June 24 (CNA) (By M. J. Tzou and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: Investigations of alleged sexual misconduct committed by a senior Taiwan law enforcement officer have hit a snag because of the accuser's uncooperative attitude, investigators said here on Wednesday.

Huang Shih-ming, head of a three-member investigative team from Taiwan, told a group of Taiwan journalists stationed in Paris that the team still has no opportunity to interview Christine Yang, the presumed victim of the alleged sexual assault by Cheng Chuan, acting director of the Ministry of Justice Investigation Bureau (MJIB).
Huang, also chief secretary of the Justice Ministry, said he and his colleagues managed to meet with Christine's parents shortly after they arrived in Paris on June 22.

"We have got important, useful information about the case from talking with the Yangs," Huang said, adding that the team on Tuesday visited the hotel where Cheng's alleged sexual misconduct took place.
"We have taken photos of the hotel room where Cheng stayed during his 1996 Paris trip," Huang said. "Nevertheless, we have so far been unable to meet Christine in person."

Huang said getting Christine's testimony is very important. "Her statement can serve as direct evidence and has strong legal effect, while her parents' testimonies can only serve as indirect evidence and their legal effects are weak."

Christine checked into a Paris hospital on the very day of Huang's arrival. A hospital spokesperson said Christine's father, Yang Wan-ching, has asked the hospital not to let any guest meet his daughter. As a result, neither Haung's mission nor any Taiwan journalist has managed to gain access to Christine.
Huang said Yang had given him a copy of Chinese transcript detailing Christine's statements to French police two days after the alleged sexual assault happened.
The transcript was reportedly written by Yang himself. "Further verification is needed before we can ascertain the transcription's authenticity," Huang said.
At her father's insistence, Christine filed a complaint about Cheng's alleged sexual misconduct with the police station near her home in September 1996.
Huang said his team looks forward to obtaining the original French transcript of Christine's complaint to the French police as well as her doctor's diagnosis report.

"We fully understand it won't be easy to acquire the two original documents because French law offers strict protection for privacy," Huang explained, adding that the team has sought the assistance of the French Institute in Taipei, which handles Taiwan-France exchanges in the absence of official ties between the two countries.

Huang quoted a French police officer as having told his team that according to French law, Christine's complaint with the police cannot be used as evidence to prove the accused's misconduct. Under the French law, the police are even not required to probe such complaint.

"Should Christine have 'reported the crime' to the police after the alleged misconduct took place, the French police would have investigated into the case at that time," Huang quoted the French police officer as saying.

Yang and his wife had accused Cheng of having touched Christine's breast and private parts under the excuse of administering Chikung, a traditional Chinese martial art believed to have curative powers, to their daughter when he made a private trip to Paris on Sept. 9-13, 1996.
The Yangs alleged that Cheng's sexual misconduct had caused great distress to Christine who was then 19 years old and suffering from anorexia nervosa.

Although Cheng has categorically denied all the Yangs' allegations, many questions surrounding the case remained unanswered, prompting the Ministry of Justice to send Huang's mission to France to collect related information first-hand.
The team originally planned to leave for home on Saturday. As investigations have not proceeded smoothly, Huang said the team may postpone its return until next Wednesday.

DOC.HEADLINE: 12% OF POPULATION INVOLVED IN PYRAMID SELLING

TEXT.P: Twelve percent of Taiwan's population is, or has been, involved in direct sales as of the end of 1997, according to statistics released on Thursday by the Fair Trade Commission (FTC).

The FTC reported that by the end of 1997, a total of 845 pyramid enterprises had registered with the commission, although the number of companies actually in operation stood at only 240. Some 2.72 million people have been recruited as salespeople for these pyramid, or multilayer marketing schemes.

The turnover of this sector in Taiwan reached NT$38.07 billion (US$1.12 billion) in 1997, with the leading sales categories listed as health foods, beauty care products, fitness equipment, and detergents.
The FTC survey found that during 1997, some 873,000 people ordered products from pyramid schemes, while 582,000 salespeople received rewards or commissions during the same period.

DOC.HEADLINE: SIX TOWNSHIPS IN PINGTUNG COUNTY CONTAMINATED BY TOXIC WASTE

TEXT.P: Six townships in the southern Taiwan county of Pingtung have been contaminated by toxic waste, the county's environmental protection chief reported on Thursday.

Hsu Ho-cheng, director of the Environmental Protection Bureau under the Pingtung County Government, said unscrupulous property developers have illegally extracted large quantities of sand and gravel from many tracts of farmland in the six townships because the county government has completely banned gravel extraction from local rivers.
Hsu said the developers have then filled the resulting craters with industrial waste in an attempt to cover up their unethical practices.

"As industrial waste usually contains large amounts of toxic chemicals, the affected farmland has become unarable. Worse yet, poisonous substances in the waste have contaminated soil and ground water in the nearby regions," Hsu said.
The six most seriously contaminated townships are Kaoshu, Likang, Yenpu, Neipu, Hsinyuan and Hsinpei, according to Hsu.

Quoting field surveys conducted by the government-funded Industrial Technology Research Institute, Hsu said soil and ground water near large tracts of farmland in the six townships contain dangerous levels of such toxic chemicals as phenol, toluene, trichloroform, styrene and dichloroethylene. Exposure to these substances can cause many diseases, including cancer and other deadly ailments.

In addition to reporting the case to the Cabinet-level Environmental Protection Administration (EPA), Hsu said the county government has set up a 20-member task force to intensify patrols of farmland in the six townships.

"We have also asked the EPA to give us financial and manpower support," Hsu said, adding the county government will make further surveys to understand how serious the contamination is and how large the contaminated acreage is.

EPA Administrator Tsai Hsun-hsiung has agreed to earmark NT$5 million to help finance the county's first-stage clean-up project in addition to dispatching a 12-member team to assist in the patrol mission.

DOC.HEADLINE: SEF CHAIRMAN KOO INVITED TO VISIT MAINLAND

TEXT.P: The mainland Chinese Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait (ARATS) Thursday invited Taiwan's chief negotiator Koo Chen-fu to visit the Chinese mainland this fall.

In a letter to its Taiwan counterpart, the Strait Exchange Foundation (SEF), the ARATS said SEF Chairman Koo Chen-fu is invited to visit Fu Jiang, Shanghai, Nanjing, Xian, and Beijing this fall, and to meet with ARATS Chairman Wang Daohan during the trip in Shanghai. SEF Vice Chairman Shi Hwei-yow is also invited to visit the mainland with Koo.
The invitation was sent to the SEF on the occasion of US President Bill Clinton's visit to the Chinese mainland. President Clinton arrived in mainland China Thursday for an eight-day visit.
The ARATS and SEF were established in 1991 in Beijing and Taipei respectively to handle civilian exchanges between mainland China and Taiwan in the absence of formal relations.
The ARATS' invitation is in line with the SEF proposal made on Nov. 7, 1997, except that the SEF wanted Shi to meet with ARATS Vice President Tang Shubei before Koo's visit to the mainland.

Meanwhile, SEF Deputy Secretary General Jan Jyh-horng said in Taipei Thursday that the SEF is glad to see this development in the relationship between the two organizations. The SEF will exchange views with the Mainland Affairs Council of the Executive Yuan on some of the arrangements proposed by the ARATS, he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPOWER SEEKING URANIUM ENRICHING SERVICE FROM NETHERLANDS

TEXT.P: Taiwan Power Company (Taipower) on Thursday confirmed that it is seeking a uranium enriching service from the Urenco Group of the Netherlands.

A Taipower official, who requested anonymity, said in a telephone interview that if the Dutch government approves the deal, the Dutch-British-German consortium will be the third to offer the service to Taipower, along with the US and France.

Although the Associated Press reported on Thursday that the Dutch government has approved the deal, the official said that the state-run enterprise has not yet received any approval document from the Dutch government.

She said that the uranium ore imported by Taiwan from the US, Canada, and South Africa has to be enriched before it can be manufactured into fuel bars for use in Taiwan's three nuclear power plants, pointing out that the density of uranium in the ore must be increased from 0.7 percent to 3.5 percent for nuclear power use.
Taipower decided to approach the Urenco group in order to diversify its sources of enriched uranium, in preparation for the completion of the island's fourth nuclear power plant, the official said.

According to the AP report, Dutch Economics Ministry spokesman Lucc van Zipp said on Thursday that the Dutch government has approved the "sale of uranium" to Taiwan for use in two nuclear power plants, while Dutch Foreign Ministry spokesman Frank de bruin stressed that the uranium will only be used for peaceful purposes.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT LEE REAFFIRMS ROC STANCE ON REUNIFICATION

TEXT.P: President Lee Teng-hui said on Thursday that neither the government nor the people of the Republic of China will ever change their stance on pursuing national reunification.

"Our stance and determination (to seek China's reunification) is unshakable," Lee said at his office while meeting a visiting Honduran parliamentary delegation led by parliament Speaker Rafael Pineda Ponce.
The president said it is an undeniable fact that China and Taiwan are now separate entities under the rule of two different governments.
"The goal of national reunification we are pursuing can only be achieved under a system featuring freedom, democracy and equal distribution of wealth," Lee told his guests.
He also said that the "one country, two systems" formula originally implemented by Beijing to govern Hong Kong is totally unacceptable to Taiwan.
Lee said that in addition to having a vigorous and well-developed national economy, the ROC government has also dedicated itself to promoting political reforms.
He called on Honduras and other democracy- and freedom-loving countries to join the struggle for just causes.

Pineda for his part expressed his government's appreciation to Lee for the assistance Taiwan his given to Honduras to aid its economic development, and said he hoped that bilateral cooperation will be further strengthened in the future.
Pineda and his 12-member delegation arrived in Taipei on Tuesday for a week-long visit.

DOC.HEADLINE: NZ FOREIGN MINISTER SEES ONE NATION DAMAGING AUSTRALIAN TRADE
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, June 25 (CNA) (By Bear Lee) (By Peter Chen)

TEXT.P: Canberra, June 25 (CNA): The One Nation Party is damaging Australia's relationship with its biggest trading partner -- East Asia, according to New Zealand Foreign Affairs and Trade Minister Don McKinnon.
The New Zealand Press Associates (NZPA) quoted McKinnon as saying that One Nation was having a negative effect in Asia for Australia.
McKinnon made the remarks when he opened an international quantity surveyers' conference in Queenstown Wednesday.
He said people he had met throughout East Asia recently were very uncomfortable with One Nation and its leader, Pauline Hanson.
"I continue to tell people that Pauline Hanson is not a New Zealander," McKinnon said.
Australia had to recognise that 60 percent of its trade was with East Asia.
"That's important part of the economy, so if they start alienating large sections of that community, that will not help at all," he said.
McKinnon was dismissive of the possible emergence of a One Nation-aligned party in New Zealand.
"We've had them before -- far right, Nazi-oriented, white-faces-only parties. If that's going to occur I think New Zealanders will treat it with the contempt it deserves," he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: QUEENSLAND'S NEW PREMIER PLEDGES TO IMPROVE TIES WITH ASIA

TEXT.P: Queensland Labor Party leader Peter Beattie, who will be sworn in as premier of Australia's "Sunshine State" on Friday, pledged on Thursday that his government will welcome foreign investment, trade and tourist ties with Asia.
"We will get back on the business again with people overseas," he said in an interview with the Australian Broadcasting Corporation (ABC).
Beattie came from behind as the winner of the Queensland state government election after he received the support of newly elected independent parliamentarian Peter Wellington.
The support gave the Beattie government 45 seats in the Queensland Legislative Assembly, more than 50 percent of the total 89 seats required.
Most Asian immigrants in the state welcomed Beattie's victory in the June 13 election because the new premier is expected to push closer ties with Asian countries.

In an interview with the CNA on Thursday, Associate Professor C.L. Chieou of the University of Queensland, said: "Beattie's victory will certainly give a positive message to Asian people that Queensland will expand its trade, tourist and other relations with Asian countries."
He said Beattie is very friendly toward Asians, pointing out that he recently visited Taiwan, making him the first Australian opposition leader to visit the Republic of China in many years.
Chieou said Beattie knows the importance of ties with Asian countries, because many Queensland products, including seafood, sugar, and other agricultural products, are exported to Asia.
In addition, Queensland is a favorite destination for many Asian tourists, he said.

Many Asians in Australia had been worried that a coalition between the Liberal, National and One Nation parties would have made Queensland anti-Asian, anti-multiculturalism and anti-foreign investment.

DOC.HEADLINE: CLINTON URGED TO BACK TAIWAN'S SELF-DETERMINATION

TEXT.P: Several pro-independence groups on Thursday urged US President Bill Clinton to support the right to self-determination of the people of Taiwan.

In an open letter to Clinton, the groups, including the Association of Taiwan Professors, said that it is natural for the US and mainland China, now the world's only superpowers, to seek to improve their bilateral relations.

"We hope the summit between President Clinton and his mainland counterpart Jiang Zemin on July 27 will be a big success," the groups stated in the letter which was issued when Clinton departed on his nine-day mainland China trip on Wednesday.
"What we want to tell you is that it is the people of Taiwan, not the US or the People's Republic of China, who should decide the future of the island."

"The right of self-determination by the people, proclaimed by former US President Woodrow Wilson at the end of the First World War, has taken deep root in the political tradition of the US," the letter stated.

The human rights diplomacy initiated by former US President Jimmy Carter in 1978 provided substantial encouragement to the people of Taiwan to struggle for their right to self-determination, it added.
"It is our undeniable right to establish a `Taiwan Republic,' either with or without US support," the letter continued.
It went on to say that Taiwan conforms totally with the criteria of a sovereign country, as it has independent jurisdiction over interior, diplomatic, defense and judicial affairs in its territory.
"Besides, the US should understand the fact that the PRC has not ruled the island for a single day since 1895," the letter pointed out.
Taiwan is extremely concerned about the result of the impending talks between Clinton and Jiang, as the so-called Taiwan issue is expected to be high on the agenda.

DOC.HEADLINE: NO REDUCTION IN RESERVE REQUIREMENT: CBC

TEXT.P: The Central Bank of China (CBC) announced on Thursday that the reserve requirement will not be lowered, a decision sure to disappoint investors.
CBC Governor Perng Fai-nan said that at a time when the foreign exchange market is unstable, any move to reduce the reserve requirement might further aggravate the prevailing currency volatility.

He admitted that the current 8.31 percent reserve requirement is higher than those of some other countries, but said that while the CBC is set to gradually reduce the requirement, now is not a good time to make such a cut.

There is some concern over whether there is sufficient capital to support a decision by the Legislative Yuan to boost the economy by stimulating local demand. However, Perng estimated that this capital demand will not emerge until early next year, rather than in the second half of this year.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI CITY COUNCILOR ANNOUNCES `LETTER TO WHITE HOUSE' CAMPAIGN

TEXT.P: A Taipei City councilor on Thursday called on the people of Taiwan to express their concern to the White House over the upcoming summit meeting between US President Bill Clinton and mainland Chinese President Jiang Zemin.
Councilor Chen Hsue-fen said during a question-and-answer session that the friendly engagement between Beijing and Washington should not come at Taiwan's expense.

She then announced a "one person one letter to the White House" campaign, which would see concerned Taiwan citizens individually making their feelings known to the American government via the Internet.

Taipei Mayor Chen Shui-bian said he supported the councilor's proposal, adding that the municipal government will also send e-mails to the White House and to Taipei's 12 sister cities in the United States to express concern over the possible effect on Taiwan of the Clinton-Jiang meeting.

The opposition Democratic Progressive Party mayor also used the occasion to reiterate his pro-Taiwan independence stance, pointing out that Taiwan is not a part of mainland China and that the people of Taiwan do not want to be under mainland Chinese rule.
He also said that the future of Taiwan should be determined by its 21 million residents.

DOC.HEADLINE: US-CHINA ENGAGEMENT SHOULD NOT DAMAGE TAIWAN'S INTERESTS: HU

TEXT.P: Taiwan's interests should not be damaged as Washington and Beijing improve relations, ROC Foreign Minister Jason Hu said during an interview with the Cable News Network Thursday.
Taipei is pleased to see benign interaction between the United States and mainland China, provided it does not come at Taiwan's expense, Hu said.

"We have been assured and assured that nothing will be done to damage our interests during Clinton's nine-day mainland China trip," Hu said in a story aired after US President Bill Clinton arrived in the ancient mainland Chinese capital of Xian.

"People worry about the possibility of a deal behind closed door," said Hu. "The United States is a very trustworthy friend, but there have been ups and downs in our relationship. Basically, of course, people have that kind of concern and worry."
"We do not hope to see the US and mainland China reach any agreement on Taiwan, either verbal or in written form," Hu said.

When asked about Beijing's "one country, two systems" formula, Hu said Clinton's trip to Hong Kong at the end of his China tour must not been seen as tacit agreement that the formula, originally designed for Hong Kong, can be extended to Taiwan.
"Taiwan and Hong Kong are completely different. Therefore whatever is being done, the so-called 'one country, two systems' could never be applied to Taiwan," he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: VIRAL OUTBREAK CAUSES CONCERN IN OVERSEAS CHINESE COMMUNITY
DOC.DATELINE: San Francisco, June 25 (CNA) (By Neil Lu and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: The deadly enteroviral outbreak that has claimed the lives of at least 51 infants and young children in Taiwan in recent weeks has sparked concern in overseas Chinese communities in North America.
Many parents in northern California have canceled plans to take their children to Taiwan for summer vacation, community sources said Thursday.

Also, some parents have decided not to allow their children to participate in an annual six-week summer camp organized by the Republic of China's Overseas Chinese Affairs Commission (OCAC) for ethnic Chinese children living in the United States and Canada, sources said.
"Some of them have decided to cancel their children's registration for the summer camp program scheduled to start early next month," said an OCAC official.
The official added that the representative office has conveyed the Chinese parents' concerns and inquiries to Taiwan authorities.
So far about 1,000 Chinese adolescents, with more than 130 of them from northern California, have registered for the program this year.
Chinese families in North America often send their children to Taiwan to receive instruction in Chinese culture, history and customs.
The Republic of China's representative office in San Francisco has received many inquiries from Chinese parents about the status of the enteroviral epidemic in Taiwan, sources said.

Meanwhile, a US public health official stationed at the San Francisco International Airport denied reports that the Atlanta-based US Centers for Disease Control has issued a directive regarding the outbreak.
The American official said that without a formal CDC directive, the public health office would not take any precautionary measures or issue a travel warning.

The official was responding to a local press report that a 17-year-old Taiwan student in the United States had twice developed a high fever after visiting Taiwan in March. The report cited medical reports that indicated the student had developed symptoms similar to Taiwan's enterovirus patients. The report further said the student is almost certain to have been infected by the intestinal virus.

Spread by physical contact, the enterovirus usually attacks children under 5 years old. The virus breaks down the immune system and can leave infants susceptible to encephalitis, meningitis and acute inflammation of the heart muscle.

Initial symptoms include fever, vomiting, drowsiness and ulcers in the mouth and on the feet and hands. Of those infected, however, only a small number develop more severe complications such as encephalitis or meningitis.

DOC.HEADLINE: AUSTRALIA'S PATRICK STEVEDORES, UNION REACH ACCORD

TEXT.P: An Australian waterfront dispute ended Thursday after Patrick Stevedores Ltd. and the Maritime Union of Australia reached an agreement that permitted both sides to claim victory.

Patrick Chairman Chris Corrigan said the new deal would boost the company's annual profit by between A$30 and A$40 million (US$19 to US$25 million) -- about the amount the waterfront dispute cost Patrick.
The Australian Council of Trades Union, the MUA's major supporter, rejected Corrigan's claim that the agreement delivered the most sweeping changes on the waterfront in decades. (by Peter Chen)

DOC.HEADLINE: MOVIE ON THE DALAI LAMA PROVES AN AUSTRALIAN BOX-OFFICE HIT

TEXT.P: "Kundun," the epic tale of the early life of Tibet's spiritual leader, the Dalai Lama, has become a box-office hit in Australia.

"Kundun," which was previously banned in Australia over fears of protest from mainland China, has taken in almost A$450,000 (US$281,250) since it opened on 21 screens last Thursday, according to Friday's Sydney Morning Herald.
"Kundun" is fifth in box-office rankings, behind such blockbusters as "Godzilla" and "Deep Impact," according to the paper.
At Paddington's Academy Twin Cinema in Sydney, "Kundun" earned a record A$50,000 (US$31,250) in its first week.

Meanwhile, Nicolas Whatson, general manager of Palace Cinemas News South Wales, said demand is so strong that it is now being shown on both the cinema's screens. Calling the movie's proceeds unprecedented, at least within the past 20 years, he said, "We've had an absolutely extraordinary response. It's really exciting to see a quality adult film do terrific business."

The impressive screen average of A$21,303 (US$13,314) for the opening week of "Kundun" has encouraged its distributor, NewVision, to order more prints and begin negotiations with Australia's big three distributors: Hoyts, Village and Greater Union. All three distributors have expressed interest, said Frank Cox, NewVision's managing director.
The daily reported the movie's success in Australia comes after a difficult release in the United States.

DOC.HEADLINE: AUSTRALIAN PAPER CALLS ON CLINTON TO PRESS BEIJING TO REFORM

TEXT.P: US President Bill Clinton should, during his trip to mainland China, pressure Beijing to launch immediate political reforms, free all political and religious prisoners and scrap restrictions on freedom of speech, according to The Sydney Morning Herald.

"The US leader should make it clear Beijing has the choice of either launching reforms which will give China a chance to minimize the pain from its looming crisis -- or continuing down the path to political chaos and oblivion," wrote author David Lague.

Lague noted Clinton's visit is important because he is in an unrivaled position to influence President Jiang Zemin and the post-Deng leadership at a time when "China needs the US much more than the US needs China."

"The major danger China poses for the region and the world is not that it rises to become a belligerent superpower but that it follows an Indonesian-style path to economic and political collapse, which would destabilize the region and lead to a colossal refugee exodus."

He said the United States' conclusion that mainland China's refusal to devalue its currency amid the Asian financial crisis is a sign that this ancient nation is ready to assume a leadership role in the international community is wrong.

"This is an absurd and possibly dangerous fiction. The reality is that when Air Force One touched down last night in the ancient Silk Road capital of Xian, the leader of the world's superpower landed in a vast and desperately poor country mired in a monumental political and economic mess," he noted.

Mainland China has maintained the value of its currency because it makes sense for them to do so. "If it is judged that depreciation is necessary to boost sagging exports and maintain economic growth, the yuan will be devalued -- because the government does not have the luxury of making grand gestures. It's too busy struggling to survive," Lague wrote.

DOC.HEADLINE: ARATS OFFICIAL TO VISIT TAIPEI IN JULY

TEXT.P: Beijing will arrange for Li Yafei, deputy secretary-general of the semi-official Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait, to visit Taipei in late July to help resume long-stalled cross-strait talks, an ARATS source said Friday.
Beijing would like Li to visit Taipei prior to a possible visit to mainland China this fall by Taiwan's top cross-straits negotiator, Koo Chen-fu, according to the source.

ARATS on Thursday invited Koo, chairman of the Taipei-based Straits Exchange Foundation, a semi-official body authorized to handle cross-strait exchanges in the absence of formal contacts, to visit the mainland in the fall.
In a letter to the SEF, ARATS invited Koo to visit Fujian, Shanghai, Nanjing, Xian and Beijing in September or October.
SEF Deputy Secretary-General Jan Jyh-horng said upon learning of the letter that the SEF welcomes a visit by Li and is pleased with this latest development.
SEF in a June 19 letter to ARATS proposed that Jan visit Beijing in July and SEF Vice Chairman Shi Hwei-yow visit in August to pave the way for a visit by Koo in September or October.
Thursday's letter was ARATS' first response to the proposal. Although requests that Jan and Shi visit in advance of Koo were not answered, the reply did invite Shi to accompany Koo on his visit.
Local political observers said the ARATS letter was apparently a result of the impact of US President Bill Clinton's visit to mainland China, which began the same day.

Regular cross-strait dialogue, initiated in 1993 after SEF Chairman Koo Chen-fu and ARATS Chairman Wang Daohan met in Singapore, was unilaterally suspended by Beijing in 1995 after ROC President Lee Teng-hui visited the United States. Beijing viewed the visit as an effort to promote Taiwan independence.

DOC.HEADLINE: US TO BRIEF TAIWAN ON CLINTON-JIANG SUMMIT: RUBIN
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, June 25 (CNA) (By Nelson Chung and Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: US State Department spokesman James Rubin on Thursday confirmed that Taiwan will be briefed on the upcoming summit between US President Bill Clinton and mainland Chinese President Jiang Zemin.

Rubin made the confirmation in a news briefing to foreign reporters in Washington in response to a question on whether Richard Bush, chairman of the American Institute in Taipei, will fly to Taipei to offer a report after Saturday's Clinton-Jiang talks.
Rubin said he did not know when, exactly, the briefing might take place. "We'll tell them what transpired, in general terms, with China," he said.
The only scheduled briefing on Clinton's mainalnd visit is one to be made by Secretary of State Madeleine Albright to Japan as she returns to the United States, he said.

As for Congressional approval for renewing mainland China's most favored nation trade status, Rubin said the White House is delighted that Congress understands the administration's belief that engaging mainland China is the best way to deal with US concerns over human rights and weapons proliferation.

Noting that Beijing has released several political dissidents, such as Wang Dan and Wei Jingsheng, and has agreed to sign the United Nations' International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights, Rubin said such developments have proved the effectiveness of the administration's policy.
Despite strong criticism of Beijing's human rights record, the US House Ways and Means Committee approved MFN, endorsed by Clinton, in a voice vote on Thursday.

DOC.HEADLINE: CLINTON TRICKED INTO ACCEPTING XIAN WELCOMING CEREMONY: PAPER

TEXT.P: US President Bill Clinton was tricked into accepting a welcoming ceremony ill-befitting his status when he arrived in mainland China Thursday, a Hong Kong newspaper reported Friday.

The Sing Tao Yih Pao daily quoted an unnamed Beijing University professor as saying that the meticulous ceremony arranged by mainland authorities to welcome Clinton into the ancient city of Xian was by no means a ritual accorded Chinese emperors.
Although grand in style, the history professor said, the ceremony mainly imitated a ritual performed to welcome an envoy from a vassal state who had come to pay tribute to an ancient Chinese emperor.
As the head of state from such a powerful country as the United States, the professor said, Clinton should not have accepted such a welcome.
"With limited knowledge about Chinese culture, Clinton fell into a trap set up by his mainland counterpart, Jiang Zemin," he said.

Xian was the capital of 12 ancient Chinese dynasties, the professor said. "Most of the 72 emperors reining in those periods were buried in the city. Many Chinese people have thus believed that Xian is filled with spirits of the deceased. Senior communist leaders, from Mao Zedong on down, have been reluctant to set foot in the city."

The professor further said Clinton was apparently unaware of the taboo when he chose the northwestern city as the first leg of his nine-day state visit, which will also take him to Beijing, Shanghai, Gueilin and Hong Kong.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI WELCOMES ARATS INVITATION TO SEF CHAIRMAN

TEXT.P: Taipei on Thursday welcomed a written invitation extended to the chairman of the Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) by mainland China, and has decided to respond quickly.

The Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait (ARATS), mainland China's quasi-official body authorized to handle bilateral exchanges in the absence of official contacts, invited SEF Chairman Koo Chen-fu to lead a delegation to Fujian, Shanghai, Nanking, Xian and Beijing in mid-September or mid-October.
SEF Vice Chairman and Secretary-General Shi Hwei-yow has also been invited.

Sheu Ke-sheng, vice chairman and spokesman of the Mainland Affairs Council (MAC), Taipei's top agency in charge of mainland policy, told a press conference on Friday that Taipei is glad to see "concrete progress" between the SEF and the ARATS, adding that he believes it will benefit cross-strait exchanges and mutual understanding.
Koo's visit to mainland China will be of great significance, Sheu remarked, adding that the trip will have to be planned carefully by high-level SEF personnel.

Shi also welcomed the invitation, but said the SEF will have to confer with the MAC before replying. He stressed that an "appropriate arrangement" will have to be made before any meeting between Koo and his ARATS counterpart, Wang Daohan.

Jan Jyh-horng, director of the MAC's Department of Research & Planning, pointed out that Taipei's stance on the issue is that Koo's trip will have to be preceded by a meeting between ARATS Vice Chairman Tang Shubei and his SEF counterpart, Shi Hwei-yow.

DOC.HEADLINE: NT DOLLAR DOWN

TEXT.P: The New Taiwan dollar slid NT$0.095 against the greenback in Taipei, closing at 34.552.
The local currency opened at the day's high of 34.1, then sharply dropped to 34.705 before buying relieving the fall.
The interbank US dollar trading reached US$275 million.

DOC.HEADLINE: US CHINA POLICY DESCRIBED AS VACILLATING
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, June 25 (CNA) (By Jay Chen and Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: The United States' China policy over the years has been vacillating, and displaying a lack of consistency and stability, a China analyst said here recently.
Harry Harding of George Washington University made the remarks during an interview with the Central News Agency earlier in the week.

The China expert has access to high-ranking Clinton Administration officials, and in fact briefed President Bill Clinton for the second time on Tuesday before Clinton embarked on his visit to mainland China.

Harding noted that both sides of the Taiwan Strait have been actively lobbying for US support, each side trying to tilt US policy in its favor, which could be a cause of the lack of consistency in US policy.
Taiwan is therefore especially worried about what will develop regarding US policy toward Taiwan after the US improves its ties with the mainland, he said.
Harding said he believes both sides of the Taiwan Strait have focused too heavily on trying to influence US policy, and have not shown enough enthusiasm in trying to develop cross-strait ties.
He also said that the two sides of the Taiwan Strait should open another channel for dialogue so as to help ease misunderstanding and explore possible frameworks for future relations.

Asked whether the Clinton administration has begun to address its vacillating policy toward China, Harding said that the US seems to be becoming more explicit about its policy toward mainland China, pointing out that the US has said that it wants to develop a "constructive strategic partnership," with Beijing.
He said he is opposed to the US maintaining a "strategic ambivalence" approach toward Taiwan, saying that the US should state clearly its four basic principles, which he described as follows:
-- The US insists that the future of Taiwan must be resolved by both sides of the Taiwan Strait through peaceful means;
-- The US will support any arrangement to which the two sides of the Taiwan Strait agree;

-- The US is against either side imposing its will on the other, for example, the US will not accept a unilateral announcement of independence by Taiwan, nor will it accept an unprovoked invasion of Taiwan by mainland China;
-- The US believes that only through continued reforms and the steady development of cross-strait relations can the Taiwan issue be finally resolved.

Harding said he believes the US should continue to provide Taiwan with defensive weapons under these principles, and voiced his opposition to a recent article by Chas Freeman, former US assistant secretary of defense, which said that the US should review its policy regarding arms sales to Taiwan.

He also stated his opposition to the setting up of a time schedule to resolve the Taiwan issue, and to the idea that the US should make any explicit statement in favor of the eventual reunification of China.

He described these principles as being in line with the US stance of not wanting to act as a mediator between the two sides, and of wishing to stop the efforts by both sides to try to dictate US policy.

DOC.HEADLINE: SHARE PRICES DOWN ON TAIEX

TEXT.P: Share prices moved down 0.5 percent in Friday's stock market trading session, a result of the weak Japanese yen.

The Taiwan Stock Exchange's weighted price index, the market's key barometer, slid 40.68 points to close at 7,681.96. The index lost 135.31 points, or 1.7 percent, over the week due to the currency impact.

The bourse opened at 7,717.37 and fluctuated between 7,771.65 and 7,656.13. A wait-and-see sentiment triggered by US President Bill Clinton's high-profile visit to mainland China dominated the day's trading, dealers said.
Gainers outnumbered losers 221 to 216, with 55 issues remaining unchanged.
In all, 2.64 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$117.98 billion (US$3.43 billion) during the three-hour session.

Paper and pulp stocks rose 1.5 percent, the largest gain among the eight major stock categories. Textile issues gained 1.3 percent, Foodstuff and construction shares each rose 0.8 percent, cement stocks climbed 0.7 percent, and plastic and chemical issues rose 0.5 percent.
Electrical engineering issues plunged 2.2 percent, and financial stocks moved down 0.4 percent.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAINLAND MEDIA BANNED FROM LIVE CLINTON FOOTAGE

TEXT.P: Beijing authorities have banned mainland Chinese media from transmitting live broadcasts of US President Bill Clinton's activities in mainland China, a Hong Kong newspaper reported on Friday.
The Sing Tao Yih Pao daily said that although major foreign news media have been giving extensive coverage to Clinton's ongoing mainland visit, Beijing has tightened control of its own media.
All official mainland media, including China Central Television Station, have received directives that they should not broadcast live Clinton footage during his nine-day state visit, the paper said.

The daily continued that although Beijing's leaders regard Clinton's visit as one of the country's most important diplomatic events of this century, the 1.2 billion mainland residents will be the last to know about Clinton's activities in their land.
The paper quoted Beijing sources as saying the ban was imposed out of three considerations:

-- While mainland China is willing to accord Clinton a grand welcome, it wants to keep all ceremonial rituals low profile to avoid causing suspicion or panic among neighboring powers such as Russia and Japan;
-- Beijing is afraid that Clinton may touch on some sensitive topics, such as the bloody Tiananmen massacre, which could fuel pro-democracy sentiments on the mainland.

The paper said all official media in the four mainland cities -- Xian, Beijing, Shanghai and Gueilin -- on Clinton's itinerary have been instructed to use as many dispatches from the Xinhua News Agency as possible with regard to Clinton's activities. Xinhua is the official mouthpiece of the Chinese Communist Party.
Clinton arrived in the ancient city of Xian in northwestern China on Thursday for a nine-day visit.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC AIMS TO BOOST TIES WITH WESTERN DEMOCRACIES: PREMIER

TEXT.P: Premier Vincent Siew said on Friday that the Republic of China hopes to strengthen cooperative ties with Western democratic nations, as the ROC shares identical values and common interests with them.

In an exclusive interview with Fortune magazine conducted at his Executive Yuan office, Siew said the ROC shares identical freedom, democracy and human rights values with Western democracies, and has common interests with them in areas such as economics, politics and security.

The premier said Taiwan has remained relatively unscathed by the Asian financial turmoil thanks to its solid economic base, well-developed high-tech sector, healthy financial systems and well-concieved government policies.

However, the island needs to continue to bolster high-tech research and development, as well as promote economic liberalization and financial globalization, if it intends to head off further challenges in the future, Siew added.
The interview will be published in Fortune's August issue, together with a special report on Taiwan's high-tech development, according to a Government Information Office source.

DOC.HEADLINE: HONDURAN AMBASSADOR PRESENTS CREDENTIALS

TEXT.P: Margarita Duron De Galvez, new Honduran ambassador to the Republic of China, presented her credentials to President Lee Teng-hui at the Presidential Office on Friday morning.
Duron was accompanied by John Feng, director-general of the Department of Protocol under the Ministry of Foreign Affairs.
Lee welcomed Duron, who takes over from former ambassador Daniel Edgardo Milla Villede.

The president said the ROC hopes to increase its relations with the nations of Central America, noting that last September's Central American summit meeting, in which he participated, helped the ROC to establish new relations with the nations of the region.
Lee said that the ROC and Honduras enjoy a long-standing relationship, adding that the two have cooperated closely in diplomatic, economic and cultural fields.

He expressed the hope that Duron's arrival will help further boost exchanges and cooperation between the two nations, and urged her to persuade local businessmen to invest in the Central American nation.
Duron, a career diplomat, vowed to do her best to promote every aspect of cooperation between the two nations.
She also expressed her country's appreciation for the ROC's support over the years.

DOC.HEADLINE: ECONOMIC MINISTER HOPES CLINTON-JIANG SUMMIT WILL HELP WTO BIDS

TEXT.P: Economic Minister Wang Chih-kong said on Friday that the ROC would like to see the US and mainland China make progress on Beijing's bid to enter the World Trade Organization (WTO).

Wang made the remarks when asked by a CNA reporter whether US President Bill Clinton's meeting with his mainland counterpart Jiang Zemin will help Beijing's WTO entry. He was also questioned on the summit's possible effect on Taiwan's bid to join the world trade regulatory body.

The minister said that mainland China's progress in WTO talks has been very slow, but pointed out that talks on Taiwan's entry have entered the final stages. Out of the 26 WTO signatory parties that requested bilateral talks with Taiwan, only one, the European Union, has yet to complete them.

He said his ministry is watching closely the development of the Clinton-Jiang talks, and would welcome any progress made by Beijing and Washington on WTO entry, especially if it could contribute to early entry for both sides of the Taiwan Strait.
Taiwan applied to enter the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade, the WTO's predecessor, in 1991. It now enjoys WTO observer status.

DOC.HEADLINE: SALVADORAN PRESIDENT COURTS TAIWAN INVESTMENT
DOC.DATELINE: Panama City, June 25 (CNA) (By Edward Chen and Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: Bilateral ties between the Republic of China and El Salvador remain close and strong, Salvadoran President Armando Calderon Sol said on Thursday.
