Calderon told a visiting ROC parliamentary delegation that El Salvador welcomes Taiwan investment to help its economic development.

Calderon also said he hopes the bilateral relationship can be further strengthened through reciprocal visits by lawmakers of the two countries. Salvadoran Foreign Minister Ramon Gonzalez was also present at the meeting.

The 12-member delegation, led by Lin Che-fu, head of the Foreign Affairs and Overseas Chinese Affairs Committees under the Legislative Yuan, arrived here on Wednesday from Nicaragua for a two-day visit.
The mission, accompanied by ROC Ambassador Yen Bing-fan, also called on Juan Duch Martinez, speaker of the Salvadoran parliament.
Lin later delivered a speech at the Salvadoran parliament, in which he stressed the importance of boosting bilateral exchanges.
Duch was scheduled to host a welcome party in honor of the delegation on Thursday night, to which more than 100 dignitaries were invited.
The delegation is due to proceed to the US city of Miami on Friday, en route to the Dominican Republic.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI CITY GOVERNMENT TO SUBSIDIZE ENTEROVIRAL PATIENTS

TEXT.P: Taipei Mayor Chen Shui-bian said on Friday the municipal government will help foot medical bills for city residents hospitalized for enterovirus infections.
Chen made the announcement after a meeting of a contingency task force founded by the city government to handle enterovirus-related affairs.
Chen said the city government will subsidize each hospitalized enterovirus patient up to NT$15,000 (US$434) in hospital fees not covered by the National Health Insurance Program.

Starting on Thursday, Chen said the 23 nurseries under the jurisdiction of the city government's Bureau of Social Affairs will offer temporary child care services for working mothers. The service fee is NT$100 per hour and the 23 nurseries will be able to offer services for 1,000 kids.

Meanwhile, Chen said, the Bureau of Health will join forces with the bureaus of Social Affairs and Education to intensify sanitary inspections of private kindergartens, nurseries, talent classes and after-school classes.
Chen said the city government will abide by a package of guidelines set by the Department of Health for those day-care centers around the island to contain the further spread of the epidemic.
According to the DOH rules, each class at all those centers should accommodate no more than 30 children and at least two tutors should be provided for each class.

If two children are found to have been infected in each class, then the class should be closed. All those centers should give a 30-minute sanitation education to the children in the morning, with emphasis on handwashing.

In addition, Chen said, the municipal government will furnish each household with a copy of manual within the next five days to help city residents better understand the enterovirus-related symptoms and complications as well as effective precautionary measures to prevent the viral infection.

All city government-run hospitals will offer round-the-clock counseling services and the city government has also set up hotlines, fax lines and an Internet website to offer counseling and information about the latest development of the epidemic.
Chen also called on all citizens to cooperate with the city government to tide over the current enterovirus crisis.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN DOES NOT WANT TO BE PAWN IN CLINTON-JIANG SUMMIT: GOVERNOR

TEXT.P: Taiwan Provincial Governor James Soong said on Friday that he does not expect the Clinton-Jiang summit to harm the interests and rights of the people of Taiwan.
Soong said that Taiwan's people have the right to pursue a system based on the principles of freedom and democracy, and they do not want to be treated as a pawn in Washington-Beijing negotiations.
"No country or individual has the right to use the well-being of the people of Taiwan as a political bargaining chip," Soong stressed.

He said the people of Taiwan treasure the friendship between Taiwan and the US, and will continue to pursue democracy and freedom. Both of the Clinton government and Beijing authorities should "never ignore the will and determination of the people of Taiwan."
The governor added that the cross-Taiwan Strait dispute should be resolved in a peaceful and rational way.

He said Taiwan's people enjoy life under a free and democratic system and that while they do not desire to engage in any form of armed conflict, they will never accept being ruled by a communist Chinese regime.
Mainland China and Taiwan have been divided and ruled by separate governments since the 1949 civil war, with each side claiming sovereignty over the whole of China.

However, most countries around the world recognize Beijing as the sole legitimate ruler of China, and the Beijing government as a result uses every means at its disposal to isolate the Republic of China in the international community.

DOC.HEADLINE: SINGAPORE RECESSION SEEN WORSE THAN THAT IN 1985

TEXT.P: Singapore's economy is heading for a recession worse than the one it experienced in 1985, economists from Nanyang Technological University (NTU) said Friday.
The forecast for Singapore's gross domestic product (GDP) is expected to shrink by 1.7 percent this year and the economy will experience a mild recession, they said.
In the 1985 downturn, the economy contracted 1.6 percent.
Falling external demand -- both regionally and globally -- will push Singapore into recession this year even though its economic fundamentals are sound.
The good news is that the recession will be short-lived and the economy will bounce back next year to register a mild growth of 3.2 percent.
The NTU forecast for this year is the gloomiest so far. Based on a quarterly econometric model, it predicts the economy will have shrunk by 2.7 percent in the April-June quarter ending on Tuesday.
The drop would worsen in the third and fourth quarters this year and spill over into the first quarter of next year before a turn-around will occur.
The Singapore government is due to present an updated official forecast on Monday when a package of off-budget measures to boost the economy is unveiled in Parliament.

The NTU economists said Singapore's economic outlook had worsened due to the following four factors: another cyclical slowdown in the global electronic industry, which hit Singapore's manufacturing sector and thus exports; prolonged political and economic uncertainties in Indonesia; a weak Japanese economy and yen; and a meltdown of Singapore's services exports.
Singapore's two growth engines -- the manufacturing sector and financial and business services sector -- are both heading for a contraction, the economists predicted.
Manufacturing output is likely to contract by 3.3 percent, hit by the downturn in the global electronics industry and significant reduction in Singapore's manufactured exports.

Similarly, the financial and business services sector output is predicted to decline 2.9 percent this year due to a contraction in loans and advances, a tapering off in volatility in share prices and falling property prices.
The recession will likely keep consumer prices down even though the Singapore dollar would be soft at 1.78 to the US dollar before recovering.
The economists said economic growth next year would be led by manufactured exports, expected to rebound with a full recovery in the global electronics industry.
However, for financial and business services, the recovery would only take place toward the second half of next year, they added.

DOC.HEADLINE: DISSIDENTS WANT TO ESTABLISH OPPOSITION PARTY IN CHINA

TEXT.P: Three dissidents living in Hangzhou, capital of Zhejiang Province in eastern China issued Thursday a statement, saying that they want to establish "the Democratic Party of China".

They also filed an application Thursday for establishing the political party with the Civil Affairs Department of the Zhejiang Provincial People's Government, according to a press release from the Hong Kong-based Information Center of Human Rights and Democratic movement in China.

The dissidents' open declaration of their plan to establish an opposition party in mainland China is unprecedented, and therefore is an epoch-making event, the information center said in the news release.
The dissidents also made public Thursday the constitution of the political party.
The party will bring direct democratic elections to the Chinese mainland, establish a constitutional democratic system, and eliminate totalitarian and corruptive rule, the statement said.
The statement also said that political power comes from the general public, and that the government must be built on the basis of free elections.

The three dissidents are Wang Youcai, Wang Donghai, and Lin Hui. Wang Youcai was one of the 21 student leaders wanted by the public security authorities for their part in the 1989 Tiananmen incident. He was captured later and sentenced to four years in prison. He was released from prison in 1991.

They called upon all democracy campaigners in the country to join the party so that a national congress of the party can be convened in the not too distant future, although it is uncertain whether the Chinese communist government will tolerate such an activity.

DOC.HEADLINE: NO CHANGES IN US' TAIWAN POLICY, CLINTON ASSERTS
DOC.DATELINE: Beijing, June 26 (CNA) (By Wang Chung-yi and Maubo Chang)

TEXT.P: US President Bill Clinton said Washington does not plan to change its policy with regard to Taiwan despite continued pressure from Beijing to officially denounce Taipei's bid to join international organizations.

Clinton told a group of US journalists accompanying him on his trip to Xiahe Village in Shannxi, mainland China that the United States will stick to its policy shaped by the three communiques between the Washington and Beijing as well as the Taiwan Relations Act.

Although the 1978 communique acknowledges there is only one China and Taiwan is a part of it, Washington has resisted Beijing's demand for a proclamation that it would not support an independent Taiwan.
Taiwan authorities were delighted that Washington did not bow to Beijing pressure to reverse its long-standing policy.
The president's comments were in response to a question from the press. The exchange was released by Clinton's press secretary and went as follows:

Question: There have been some suggestions that you're going to sort of accept the Chinese insistence, that during the press conference you're going to sort of declare the United States decision not supporting Taiwan independence, not supporting Taiwan's bid for the United Nations, and not supporting one China, one Taiwan, (or) two China's. Is it going to happen?

Clinton: Well, first of all, you should come to the press conference to see what happens. But our position with regard to Taiwan is embodied in the three communiques and in the Taiwan Relations Act and in the facts of our relationship over the years. So I think it's obvious that there will be no change in our position one way or the other on this trip.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN ECONOMY TO REMAIN SLUGGISH

TEXT.P: The Cabinet-level Council for Economic Planning and Development (CEPD) warned Friday that Taiwan's economy may further decline in the coming months as major economic indicators showed signs of sluggishness in May.
The CEPD said Taiwan's economy continued to flash a "yellow-blue" light in May in accordance with a government rating system, with the composite index standing at 20 points, the same as in April.

The CEPD uses a five-color rating system to gauge the domestic economy. A "red" light means the economy is overheated, a "yellow-red" light reflects the heating up of an economy, "green" indicates stable growth, while "yellow-blue" refers to an economic slowdown. A "blue" light indicates a recession.

The highest government agency in charge of drawing up the nation's economic policy said it would be hard for the local economy to receive a "green light" for June because of a weaker New Taiwan dollar and a dull financial sector.

Although the government has taken measures to stimulate local demand as a means of propping up the island's economic performance, the CEPD pointed out, the domestic economy may further slide in the third quarter since the May leading economic indicators have shown signs of deterioration.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN EXPORTS TO EUROPE UP 6 PERCENT

TEXT.P: Taiwan's exports to Europe from January to May this year totaled US$8.17 billion, up 6 percent from the same period last year, according to statistics made public by the Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA)

The Board of Foreign Trade (BOFT) under the MOEA said two way trade between Taiwan and Europe reached US$16.74 billion during the five-month period, accounting for 17.6 percent of Taiwan's total foreign trade.
BOFT officials said computers and related products remain Taiwan's leading export items to Europe, making up 40 percent of the island's exports to Europe.

Taiwan has seen its exports to Asian countries drop significantly due to the Asian financial crisis. As the purchasing ability of Asian consumers will not likely recover in the near future, the island has worked out promotion programs targeting Europe and America.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI WELCOMES CLINTON'S COMMITMENT TO TAIWAN POLICY

TEXT.P: Taipei welcomed remarks made by US President Bill Clinton on Friday in mainland China, over Washington's determination to maintain its Taiwan policy.

Hailing Clinton's comment as a clear and firm signal that Washington will stay on course with its current Taiwan policy, Ministry of Foreign Affairs spokesman Roy Wu said "we appreciate and welcome it."

In response to a journalist's question about the possibility that he will officially announce a decision not to support Taiwan, Clinton said "there is no change in our position" with regard to Taiwan.

It is the first hint Clinton has given that he will not make any promises over Taiwan other than those already provided in the three communiques with Beijing. He also quelled speculation that Washington will knuckle under Beijing pressure to denounce support for Taiwan.
However, Vice Minister of Foreign Affairs David Tawei Lee called Clinton's remark as a "generalized term" which reflected Washington's desire, but it remains to be seen how events will develop.

Lee said a special Cabinet-level group has been set up to monitor Clinton's mainland visit and will keep a close eye on the summit despite the president's reassurances. A defense official will join the group on Saturday to help it respond if the issue of US arms sales to Taiwan is taken up at the summit.
Clinton, who arrived in Xian, northern China on Thursday, flew to Beijing on Friday ahead of a summit with Beijing's leader Jiang Zemin on Saturday.

Beijing's Foreign Minister Tang Jiaxuan is expected to meet with Clinton on Friday night at Diaoyutai Guest House to finalize details of the summit. Taipei will pay close attention to this pre-summit meeting because the longer the meeting lasts, Lee predicted, the more Taiwan-related issues will be raised in Saturday's summit.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC FOREIGN MINISTER TO SPEAK AT CONFERENCE IN POLAND

TEXT.P: Republic of China Minister of Foreign Affairs Jason Hu is scheduled to deliver a keynote speech at a conference in Warsaw, Poland on Saturday.
Hu, invited to attend the Conference on International Relations and Democracy held from June 26-28, will speak on issues related to the improvement of democracy and its sustained growth.

The conference, jointly organized by the Stefan Batory Foundation, Warsaw, International Forum for Democratic Studies, Washington, D.C. and Institute for National Policy Research, Taipei, has brought together policy makers and scholars from more than 30 countries including Samuel Huntington from Harvard University, and former US national security advisor Zbigniew Brezinski.

Hu, along with ROC Vice Economics Minister Chang Chang-pang and Secretary General of International Cooperation and Development Fund Loh Ping-cheung are the first ROC officials ever invited to Poland by the Stefan Batory Foundation.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC'S NET FOREIGN DEBT ONLY US$2.9 BILLION

TEXT.P: Taiwan's net foreign debt incurred by domestic banks totaled only US$2.9 billion as of the end of June 1997, the Central Bank of China (CBC) said Friday.

The CBC made the statement to clarify a report by the US-based Standard & Poor's (S&P) credit rating corporation. In its recently released report, S&P gave Taiwan's long-term foreign currency and domestic currency debt credit rating an "AA+" and the rating for the nation's short-term foreign and domestic currencies an "A-1+".
S&P considers the general situation for Taiwan's foreign debt stable.

However, S&P indicated Taiwan's international reserves amounts to US$84 billion, almost three times of that of total short-term foreign debt of the nation, implying the nation's total short-term foreign debt was near US$30 billion. The CBC said that figure does not reflect reality.

The CBC indicated the statistics released by the Bank of International Settlement (BIS) showed total amounts of the nation's foreign debt claimed by foreign countries as of the end of June 1997 at US$25.1 billion. But the figure only includes the domestic banks' branches in offshore financial business and does not include the debt right claimed by the nation.
According to The CBC's data, Taiwan's debt right totaled US$28.3 billion, while the net foreign debt was only US$2.9 billion.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT SEES NO MAJOR ACCOMPLISHMENTS FROM CLINTON-JIANG SUMMIT

TEXT.P: No major accomplishments will be made by US President Bill Clinton and mainland Chinese leader Jiang Zemin during their summit in Beijing on Saturday, according to a report by the Kuomintang.

Bargaining, compromises and an exchange of interests will feature in the summit, said the report which was carried in the latest issue of "Mainland Situation" a biweekly published by the KMT's Mainland Research Department.

In the face of strong support for Taiwan in the US Congress and other sectors, Clinton is not expected to make any big concessions to Jiang on US policy toward Taiwan and other major issues, said the report.

However, Clinton and Jiang will likely reach a consensus on certain other issues, including the framework of a Washington-Beijing strategic partnership, trade, regional security and human rights protection, the report said.

Clinton's visit will help boost mainland China's international status, increase its confidence, willingness and ability to take part in international affairs and give it ample room to play in the international community.
Although Clinton is not expected to concede to Jiang on the Taiwan issue, he will likely make a "certain degree of compromise" in this regard, the report added.
If this is the case, the "psychological impact" it will have on Taiwan will be more than substantial, the report said.

But if Clinton agrees to Beijing's demand to codify the so-called "three no's" policy -- no US support for Taiwan's membership in the United Nations, no US support for "one China, one Taiwan" or two Chinas, and no US support for Taiwan independence -- then an additional barrier will be erected to Taiwan's bid to increase its international profile, it added.
On the issue of cross-strait relations, the report said as Taiwan's strategic position remains unchanged, maintaining the status quo on cross-strait relations will be in the US' best interests.
Although the US will likely ask both sides of the Taiwan Strait to increase contact and exchanges, Beijing's manner is key to whether cross-strait ties can be substantially improved, the report said.

DOC.HEADLINE: NO US SUPPORT FOR BEIJING'S WTO BID
DOC.DATELINE: Beijing, June 27 (CNA) (By Wang Hsin-chung & Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: Beijing has apparently failed to win any concrete US support during Saturday's Clinton-Jiang summit for its efforts to accelerate accession to the World Trade Organization (WTO).
After the two-hour summit meeting with mainland Chinese President Jiang Zemin, US President Bill Clinton said he regretted that no breakthrough agreements were reached on Beijing's WTO bid.

"President Jiang and I agreed on the importance of China's entry into the World Trade Organization. I regret we did not make more progress on this front. We must recommit ourselves to achieving that goal," Clinton said.
The key factor causing Beijing's WTO bid to lag behind is that it wants to join the WTO as a developing, rather than a developed, country.

During previous rounds of WTO talks with the US, mainland China has argued unsuccessfully that it should receive favorable membership terms as a developing country. In other words, Beijing does not want to assume the responsibilities of a developed country in its foreign trade dealings.

A day earlier, US Trade Representative Charlene Barshefsky said in Beijing that the US wants greater access to mainland China's agricultural, industrial, and service markets before it will fully support Beijing's WTO bid.
Meanwhile, ROC Vice Economic Affairs Minister Lin Yi-fu said in Taipei on Saturday that Taiwan's accession to the WTO should not be affected by the results of the Clinton-Jiang talks.
Lin said Taiwan is expected to sign a WTO agreement with the US in the next two weeks, as only the wording on seven product items needs to be reconfirmed.

Among the 26 WTO member countries which have conducted bilateral consultations with Taiwan on its terms for WTO membership, only talks with the European Union have yet to be finalized, while negotiations with the US, Argentina, Thailand and Hong Kong have concluded successfully, but without the signing of formal agreements.

Lin said that the agreements with Thailand and Argentina are also expected to be signed in the near future, while talks with the EU are expected to be concluded next month when Economic Affairs Minister Wang Chih-kang visits Europe to take care of the matter personally.

Hong Kong has been reluctant to formally ink its accord because it fears angering Beijing, Lin noted. The mainland China authorities feel that Taiwan should not be allowed WTO entry before the mainland, irrespective of negotiations or agreements.

DOC.HEADLINE: BEIJING OVERTURE AIMED AT 'FORMALIZING' ROC'S DEMISE: SEF

TEXT.P: Beijing's proposal that the two sides of the Taiwan Strait hold political talks to end their state of hostility is aimed at "formalizing" or "confirming" the Republic of China's demise, an experienced negotiator with mainland China said on Saturday.

Shi Hwei-yow, vice chairman and secretary-general of the Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF), the quasi-official intermediary body authorized to handle cross-strait exchanges in the absence of official ties with mainland China, made the remarks at a seminar marking the first anniversary of Hong Kong's reversion to Beijing's rule.
Shi said mainland China intends to use the conduit of political talks to formally end the civil war between the ROC government and communist forces.
"By so doing, Beijing will be able to formally declare the demise of the ROC and assert its claim that the so-called `one China' means the People's Republic of China," Shi explained.

As a matter of fact, Shi said, the ROC, founded in 1911 as Asia's first republic, has continued to exist even after it lost the mainland to the Chinese communists and moved its seat of government to Taiwan in 1949.

Shi further said that the "one country, two systems" unification scheme imposed by Beijing on Hong Kong last July is absolutely inapplicable to Taiwan, pointing out that the ROC is an independent sovereign state, while Hong Kong is a former British colony. The ROC will never accept the "one country, two systems" formula, he said.

Speaking on the same occasion, Wu An-chia, vice chairman of the Cabinet-level Mainland Affairs Council (MAC), said the ROC looks forward to seeing Hong Kong retain its freedom, democracy and prosperity.
"A liberal, democratic and prosperous Hong Kong will certainly benefit increased ties with Taiwan and also contribute to positive interactions across the Taiwan Strait," Wu said.
Wu also reiterated the ROC's opposition to Beijing's "one country, two systems" formula, saying it in no way befits Taiwan's status.
"As a democracy, the ROC formulates its policy based on public opinion. At the moment, the majority of its people oppose communist China's one-party dictatorship and socialist system," Wu explained.
Moreover, he said, many public opinion polls have shown that nearly half of Hong Kong's residents also believe the "one country, two systems" formula is unsuitable for Taiwan.

"As a sovereign state, the ROC has its own defense and foreign policies and can decide its own destiny," Wu said, adding that Hong Kong, in contrast, is just a special administrative region under Beijing's jurisdiction. "Against this backdrop, it's extremely inaccurate to compare Taiwan to Hong Kong," he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: FRENCH PRESIDENT CALLS FOR ECONOMIC COOPERATION WITH SA

TEXT.P: French President Jacques Chirac arrived in Pretoria on Friday for a three-day South African visit.
Chirac and South African President Nelson Mandela witnessed the signing of bilateral agreements on police cooperation, sport, and maritime transport.
Chirac also met Vice President Thabo Mbeki at a Franco-South African business forum in Midrand, about 30 km north of Johannesburg.
The French president called for more economic cooperation between France and South Africa, saying French business is ready to play a bigger role in the local economy.
Chirac will visit Johannesburg and Cape Town before he travels to Mozambique on Sunday.

DOC.HEADLINE: TENSION RISES AS CLINTON BEGINS MAINLAND CHINA VISIT

TEXT.P: A dispute over dissidents has caused some tension in the early stages of US President Bill Clinton's visit to mainland China, the Canadian Broadcasting Corp. (CBC) reported on Friday.
The report said US officials formally complained to Beijing about several dissidents who were arrested just before Clinton's arrival on Thursday.

Two of them were freed on Friday shortly before Clinton left the area. Yang Hai, 29, who was jailed for a year for his role in the 1989 pro-democracy demonstrations, said he was "kidnapped" by police on Thursday to stop him meeting US journalists, according to the CBC.
Yang Jun was freed after being held overnight, the report said.

It noted that Clinton was expected to raise the issue on Saturday during his meeting with President Jiang Zemin in Beijing. Clinton has said that one of the reasons for his trip is to discuss issues of personal freedom.
The US president is also to receive a formal welcome in Tiananmen Square, the site of the massacre of pro-democracy supporters in June, 1989.

DOC.HEADLINE: CLINTON PLEDGES NO CHANGE IN US TAIWAN POLICY

TEXT.P: US President Bill Clinton has reassured the Republic of China that the US will continue to supply weapons and defend Taiwan from any unprovoked aggression from mainland China, Australia's mass circulation daily The Sydney Morning Herald reported on Saturday.
Clinton said the US stance is laid out in the three communiques with mainland China and the US' Taiwan Relations Act, combined with the history of Washington's ties with Taipei over the years.
"So, I think it would be obvious there will be no change one way or the other on this trip," Clinton was quoted as saying during a day of sightseeing near the ancient Chinese capital of Xian.
The daily reported that US support for Taiwan is the source of the most friction in the difficult relationship between Washington and Beijing.

Taipei is worried that the US will bend to pressure from Beijing over arms sales which allow the heavily outnumbered Taiwan military to retain a technological edge over the three million-strong People's Liberation Army, the daily reported.

DOC.HEADLINE: ONE NATION BLASTED FOR AUSTRALIAN JOB LOSSES

TEXT.P: Prime Minister John Howard on Friday blasted the One Nation party for the rise of racism in Australia and job losses in Queensland.
Australia's northernmost state has been hit by the loss of millions of dollars-worth of projects, and at least 120 jobs, as a result of investment cancellations by Asian investors.
In an interview published in the Sydney Morning Herald, business consultant Tardy said: "It's high time it was realized Pauline Hanson and her party are going to cause a lot of distress to people."

DOC.HEADLINE: RUSSIA SELLS MISSILES TO INDIA

TEXT.P: Russia has sold S-300 mobile air defense missiles to India, according to a report in The Indian Express newspaper.

The report in the New Delhi-based newspaper said the multi-billion dollar deal was clinched by a high-level Indian defense delegation after several rounds of "meticulous negotiations" with the Russians.
The deal is to be carried out under a long-term Indo-Russian defense cooperation program which was extended last year by 10 years.
According to the report, the missiles will be deployed along India's borders with Pakistan and mainland China.

DOC.HEADLINE: AUSTRALIAN ASIAN LANGUAGE PROGRAM MAY BE AXED

TEXT.P: Australian states are becoming angry at a plan by the government to cancel an Asian language education and training program in schools.

The program, launched in 1995 by former Prime Minister Paul Keating, is designed to boost Australian trade skills in Asia by funding Australian schools to run courses in Mandarin, Japanese, Indonesia and Korean.
But the Howard government has refused to commit to funding beyond the end of 1999, which means the program will be axed.

New South Wales Education Minister John Aquilina told The Australian newspaper on Saturday that the absence of any federal government commitment beyond the end of 1999 "is a clear indication they plan to ax it."
The 12-year language program was to have improved Australia's economic penetration of Asia by boosting levels of literacy in key Asian languages among Australia's schoolchildren.

Australian exports to Asia account for about 60 percent of its total sales, and there are tens of thousands of Australian businessmen and hundreds of companies operating in Hong Kong, Taiwan, mainland China, Southeast Asia, Japan and South Korea.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC AND ARGENTINA SIGN MOU ON FRUIT QUARANTINE

TEXT.P: The Republic of China and Argentina on Friday signed a memorandum of understanding (MOU) on fruit quarantine which allows Argentinian agricultural produce to be imported into Taiwan.

The MOU was signed at Argentina's Ministry of Agriculture and Livestock by Vice Chairman of the ROC Council of Agriculture Ling Shiang-nung and Director of the Argentine National Agrifood, Health and Quality Service Luis Barcos.

ROC Representative to Argentina Larry Y.Y. Wang, who witnessed the signing, told the CNA by telephone that because of quarantine problems, Argentina has not been able to export fruit in bulk to Taiwan for many years.

He said that the signing of the MOU will reduce the trade imbalance in Argentina's favor, and is an example of the strengthened trade ties between the two countries. It is also expected to help with Taiwan's bid to enter the World Trade Organization, he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: SINGAPORE'S MANUFACTURING OUTPUT FALLS 4.5 PERCENT

TEXT.P: Singapore's manufacturing output in May fell 4.5 percent from the same month of 1997, dragged down by a 9.6 percent drop in electronics production, the Singapore Economic Development Board (EDB) said Friday.
All major segments of the electronics cluster, except computer peripherals and printed circuit-board assembly had lower output.
"Weak demand lowered the output levels of personal computers and telecommunication equipment," the EDB said, adding that excess supply decreased the output of disk drives and semiconductors.
Singapore's manufacturing output for the first five months of this year grew 3 percent compared to the same period last year.
Chemicals and engineering clusters managed to chalk up positive growth in their output in May at 4.9 percent and 0.6 percent respectively.

The petrochemical, pharmaceutical and petroleum segments powered the output growth of the chemicals cluster, which expanded a healthy 14.1 percent for the January-May period year-on-year, statistics showed.

A small May production increase in the engineering cluster was due to "the decline in the precision engineering segment and was almost nullified by increases in the transport and process engineering segments," the report said.

Overall, engineering output expanded 9.2 percent in the first five months of this year. Production in transport engineering grew 17.4 percent, while that of process engineering, rose 10.5 percent. By Conrad Lu

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN SEALS COOPERATION PACT WITH ASCENT COMMUNICATIONS
DOC.DATELINE: San Francisco, June 26 (CNA) (By Neil Lu and Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: Two ROC information technology development institutes on Friday forged a joint strategic alliance with Ascend Communications Inc. of the United States to upgrade Taiwan's telecommunications and Internet services technologies.

Ascend Communications, founded in 1989, is the world's leading provider of technology and equipment solutions for telecommunications carriers, Internet service providers (ISPs) and corporate customers worldwide.

Ascend won the trust of the Industrial Technology Research Institute (ITRI) and the Institute for Information Industry (III), two of Taiwan's telecommunications research heavyweights, because of its ability to deliver a comprehensive set of solutions to build a complete high-performance, cost-effective public and private network infrastructure.

III President Kuo Yun, ITRI electronic communications director Yang Chun-chung, and Ascend President and CEO Mory Ejabat, signed a letter of intent on the cooperation agreement at Ascend headquarters in Alameda near San Francisco City. Taiwan's Vice Economics Minister Yin Chi-ming witnessed the signing.
Yin told the audience that he expects the resulting trilateral interaction to benefit all three sides of the agreement.

Ascend's Vice President of Marketing Tim Kranskey, who also took part in the signing ceremony, said the agreement represents the first step of a significant and comprehensive cooperative venture to further penetrate the global information market.
According to the III and ITRI, Taiwan hopes Ascend will set up a technology support center on the island and transfer its advanced technology in the field of telecommunication.

DOC.HEADLINE: CLINTON-JIANG SUMMIT SCARCELY TOUCHES ON TAIWAN AFFAIRS
DOC.DATELINE: Beijing, June 27 (CNA) (By Wang Hsin-chung & Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: US President Bill Clinton did not mention the so-called "three noes" policy toward Taiwan during a joint press conference at the end of his two-hour summit with mainland Chinese President Jiang Zemin on Saturday.
In an ensuing report on the summit achievements, the US authorities also did not mention either Taiwan, or the cross-Taiwan Strait issue.

The "three noes," which Beijing was keen to discuss at the summit, are: no US support for the "one China, one Taiwan" policy; no US support for Taiwan independence; and no US support for Taiwan's membership in international organizations.

Throughout the Clinton-Jiang press conference, little was mentioned about Taiwan, except for Jiang's remark that "the issue of Taiwan is an important and sensitive one and the US must stick to its policy of recognizing only one legitimate Chinese government `in the interest of smooth growth' in US-China relations."

Jiang mentioned Taiwan a second time when he was talking about Tibet. He said there are two preconditions for Beijing to resume talks with the Dalai Lama, Tibet's spiritual leader. Firstly, he said, the Dalai Lama must recognize that Tibet is a part of China, and secondly, the Dalai Lama must also recognize that Taiwan is a province of China.

Clinton, for his part, reaffirmed the US' "one China" policy, which opposes independence for Taiwan, and he encouraged more direct dialogue between Taipei and Beijing. The pursuit of the "cross-strait discussions that recently resumed is the best path to a peaceful resolution" of differences between the two sides, he said.

Clinton made no further references to Taiwan, not even toward the end of the press conference when he was responding to Jiang's remarks about Tibet. Clinton said only that the US recognizes Tibet as a part of China, without mentioning Taiwan.

Clinton's paucity of words about Taiwan seemed in line with the administration's original intentions regarding the summit agenda, as well as a recent call by several US congressmen not to codify the "three noes" during his mainland China trip.

DOC.HEADLINE: BUSINESS PEOPLE HAVE HIGH EXPECTATIONS FOR KOO-WANG MEETING: POLL

TEXT.P: The majority of Taiwan companies with interests in mainland China have high expectations for an early resumption of dialogue across the Taiwan Strait, according to a recent opinion poll released on Saturday.

The survey, conducted by the Chinese National Federation of Industries (CNFI), found that 87.2 percent of the respondents believe that reopening of long-stalled cross-strait dialogue will benefit bilateral trade and economic cooperation. Only 12.3 percent said they don't think resuming talks will have a great impact on cross-strait commercial ties.

The CNFI dispatched questionnaires to 2,000 local enterprises randomly selected from the 18,000 corporations with legally registered mainland investments on May 15-31. The federation received 385 valid replies for a 19.25 percent return rate.

Among the respondents, 71.4 percent said economic issues should be given the top priority if the two sides resume dialogue; 18.1 percent said functional or practical issues should be discussed first; 7.6 percent said political topics should top the agenda; while 2.9 percent said diplomatic issues whould be addressed first.

The survey also found that most local business people have become more optimistic about the future of cross-strait relations. Nearly 53 percent said they are convinced that cross-strait ties will improve gradually in the next two years. In a similar CNFI poll, only 30 percent gave an optimistic forecast for the development of cross-strait ties.

According to poll results, 77.3 percent of the respondents said they think mainland China's currency will depreciate in the next two years, while 21.1 percent said they expect the yuan to remain stable over the coming year.
As much as 82 percent said they believe if the mainland currency does not depreciate, the competitiveness of mainland-produced goods will be seriously weakened or affected.

The CNFI released the survey results shortly after the Beijing-based Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait (ARATS) invited C. F. Koo, chairman of Taipei's Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) to visit the mainland either in mid-September or in mid-October.
SEF and ARATS are quasi-official intermediary bodies authoritized by their respective governments to handle cross-strait exchanges in the absence of official ties.

Beijing unilaterally suspended institutionalized dialogue between the two bodies shortly after ROC President Lee Teng-hui made a landmark visit to the United States in June 1995. Beijing interpreted Lee's US visit as a move to promote Taiwan independence.

The Republic of China has on many occasions called for early resumption of regular SEF-ARATS dialogue, including a long-stalled meeting between SEF Chairman Koo and his ARATS counterpart, Wang Daohan.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN'S FROZEN FOOD INDUSTRIES EYES US MARKET
DOC.DATELINE: Los Angeles, June 26 (CNA) (By L. S. Chu & Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: A group of representatives from Taiwan's frozen food, frozen seafood and frozen vegetable industries are in Los Angeles to promote their products and solicit buyers.

The Taiwan industries of frozen foods, frozen seafood and frozen vegetables and fruits -- which altogether exported an average of US$300 million worth of products annually -- are aggressively seeking sales overseas as the domestic market in Taiwan is saturated, said Shen Dah, head of the Taiwan Association of Frozen Food Industries.

Shen said products they are seeking to promote in the United States are frozen vegetables, fruits, vegetarian food and seafood. They will not introduce any animal products as the US prohibits meat imports.
America is now Taiwan's second largest overseas market of frozen seafood, said Hsu Chuo-ying, head of the Taiwan Regional Association of Frozen Seafood Product.

With frozen seafood exports to the US reaching US$188 million last year, more than half of Taiwan's entire frozen foods exports, the frozen seafood industry is encouraged and is attempting to increase its presence in the US market, Hsu noted.
The frozen food industry representatives will proceed to the east coast of the United States Saturday to continue their promotion of Taiwan-processed frozen foods.
Taiwan's exports of frozen foods once reached a high of US$2.3 billion a year, a level comparable to that of the textile and garment exports.
The industry, however, shrank to about US$300 million over the last two decades as a result of smaller plantations and reduced output of produce.

DOC.HEADLINE: WORLD DEMOCRACIES MUST STAND TOGETHER: ROC FOREIGN MINISTER

TEXT.P: Republic of China Foreign Minister Jason Hu on Friday delivered a keynote speech at an international conference in Warsaw.

The three-day "International Relations and Democracy" conference which opened on Friday, is being jointly sponsored by the Stefan Batory Foundation of Poland, the Institute for National Policy Research of the ROC, and the International Forum for Democratic Studies of the United States.
In his address, Hu discussed the need for the world's democracies to stand together in defense of democratic principles, and to join together in efforts to strengthen democracy throughout the world.

Emphasizing that democracy fosters sustainable economic policies over the long term, the minister said that in the wake of the Asian financial crisis, the advantages of democracy have become clearer. An authoritarian regime can quickly change its economic policies, he said, while a democracy is better able to make a sustainable commitment to policy reform.

He elaborated on this by saying that while authoritarian rulers can reverse their decisions overnight, mature democracies have institutionalized constraints such as constitutional checks and balances, due process, and legislative deliberation. These constraints make it more difficult for policy to be changed on a whim or for the benefit of a select group.

"For my country, the Republic of China on Taiwan, it is paramount that the global democratic transformation of our time should spread and take root. We know that the fate of democracy is mainly determined from within, but we have come to appreciate how much of a difference international support and solidarity can make," He said.
Hu concluded his one-day visit to Warsaw and flew back to Taipei after delivering his speech.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHEN HAILS TAIWAN'S ECONOMIC, POLITICAL DEVELOPMENT

TEXT.P: Taiwan's economy remains robust despite the Asian financial crisis, government spokesman Chen Chien-jen told members attending a meeting sponsored by the German-Chinese Society here on Friday.

The Republic of China's Government Information Office director-general said Taiwan is a country full of vitality, hope and openness, adding that these are also the qualities which characterize relations between Taiwan and Germany.
Taiwan, with its strong economic foundation, efficient financial management, stable industrial base and healthy domestic enterprises, has been spared the turmoil plaguing its neighbors.
Chen was speaking to over 100 members of Germany's political, economic and academic circles at a meeting held to further enhance ROC-German relations.

The official went on to explain the intricacies of the cross-strait relations. He said the core problems are based on a conflict of systems. The policies, economies and lifestyles of both sides of the Taiwan Strait are very different. It may take a long time for people to narrow that gap.

The people in Taiwan hope Beijing will eventually accept and appreciate freedom and democracy, as it is the only way to guarantee the peaceful reunification of a democratic and prosperous China, Chen said.
Chen arrived in Bonn Thursday for a three-day visit. He has met with German politicians, scholars of think thanks and reporters.
Bonn is the third leg of his European trip after London and Madrid. He leaves Bonn Saturday for Paris on a two-day visit before he is scheduled to return home.

DOC.HEADLINE: PASSENGER LINER SUPERSTAR CAPRICORN TOWED BACK TO KEELUNG

TEXT.P: A passenger liner which stalled en route from Japan's Okinawa to Keelung due to a power outage, arrived in Taiwan's northern port of Keelung Saturday afternoon with the assistance of two ROC navy towboats.
The Star Cruises Superstar Capricorn left Keelung Wednesday for Okinawa's capital city Naha to begin a routine three-day, two night voyage, with 515 crew and 218 passengers on board.
According to schedule, the Panama-registered vessel should return to Keelung at 4:00 p.m. Friday, but it stalled about 30 miles off Keelung due to a power failure.

The liner's Taiwan agency, Barwil Agencies Inc., sought assistance from the ROC navy. Five of navy boats rushed to the scene, but due to rough waves and poor nighttime visibility, towing did not start until early Saturday morning.

Before the towing began, Keelung mayor Lee Ching-yuan and officials from Star Cruises took a fishing boat to approach the Superstar Capricorn. They tried to calm the passengers down and explain what the towing process entailed.
The ship finally reached port at 1:30 p.m. and passengers were allowed ashore soon afterward. Many passengers expressed gratitude for being able to return safe and sound.

Most of the passengers looked tired as they spent a sleepless night without electricity and water. Some passengers told reporters that they were not afraid during the crisis as they sang to pass the time on deck.

Several passengers said they felt the captain and crew had done their best and helped calm them during their horrible 23-hour ordeal. One woman passenger said the captain told them they were the best passengers in the world, adding that unity and calmness helped them get through the night.

Barwil Agencies Inc. apologized to passengers for the inconvenience and gave them red envelopes containing NT$500 as they stepped off the vessel. The company said it would refund the full fare to passengers and offer a free ocean trip.

The 28,000-ton vessel measuring 673 feet in length with a 82.7 feet mast, belongs to an Indonesian group. The 25-year-old 10-decked ship has 400 guest rooms for 800 passengers with entertainment facilities such as pubs, karaoke clubs, video game parlors, swimming pools, and a sauna.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN TO MEET ON MAINLAND POLICY AFTER CLINTON-JIANG SUMMIT

TEXT.P: Taiwan's policy-making leaders will hold a plenary meeting of the National Unification Council some time in late July, government sources said Saturday.
It will be the first such meeting this year for the top advisory board, which advises Republic of China President Lee Teng-hui on policy over Taiwan's unification with mainland China.
The meeting will be aimed at forming the ROC government's guidelines in response to Saturday's high-profile summit between US President Bill Clinton and mainland China President Jiang Zemin.
Reports on the summit, as well as the current mainland and cross-strait relations will be delivered to Lee, who will then give a speech on Taiwan's mainland China policy, the sources said.
Clinton, who arrived in the mainland on a nine-day state visit Thursday, reaffirmed the US' "one China" policy during a news conference after his meeting with Jiang in Beijing.
He urged Beijing to pursue "the cross-strait discussions that recently resumed," which he described as "the best path to a peaceful resolution" of the dispute.

Contact between Taiwan and mainland China, which was suspended unilaterally by Beijing in June 1995 to protest Lee's US visit, was renewed in April when Chan Hung-chih, deputy secretary-general of the quasi-official Straits Exchange Foundation visited the mainland.
The foundation, an intermediary body, was founded by ROC authorities to handle cross-strait exchanges in the absence of official links with Beijing.

DOC.HEADLINE: SUMMIT ENDS, US URGED TO ABIDE BY PRINCIPLES OF THREE COMMUNIQUES
DOC.DATELINE: Beijing, June 27 (CNA) (By Wang Hsin-chung & Eva Chen)

TEXT.P: Mainland Chinese President Jiang Zemin Saturday urged the United States to abide by the "three Sino-US joint communiques and joint statement to ensure the smooth development of bilateral ties."

Jiang made the call in his opening remarks at a joint news conference held with US President Bill Clinton after the two leaders met at Beijing's Great Hall of the People Saturday morning. Jiang said that the Taiwan issue is the most important and sensitive issue in Beijing-Washington relations.

During the long-anticipated summit meeting some agreements were forged, but division on several issues remained, most notably those regarding human rights. Jiang argued that since the two countries differ in social system, ideology, historical, cultural and traditional backgrounds, they have different ways and means to realize human rights and fundamental freedoms.

Leaders of the two sides reached an agreement not to target their respective nuclear missiles at each other's country. This move indicates to the world that "China and the United States are cooperative partners instead of adversaries," Jiang said.
He said mainland China has promised not to be the first to use nuclear weapons under any circumstances since it first possessed nuclear weapons.
In their meeting, Jiang and Clinton promised to strengthen their dialogue and cooperation between the two countries on major international issues.

The two agreed that mainland China and the US, as permanent members of the UN Security Council, should continue to make concerted efforts to promote peace and stability in the Asia-Pacific region and the world as a whole, Jiang said.
He pointed out that, "common interests of China and the US are not reducing, but increasing; and the foundation for bilateral cooperation is not weakened, but consolidated."

Jiang said he and Clinton believe the two countries should also work together to prevent the proliferation of weapons of mass destruction, strengthen environment protection, crack down on international crime, drug trafficking and international terrorism.
The visiting US president said that "a stable, open and prosperous China is good for the United States."

Clinton reaffirmed the "one China" policy, saying that "I reaffirmed our long-standing 'one China' policy to President Jiang, and urged him to pursue the cross-strait discussions recently resumed as the best plan to a peaceful resolution."

DOC.HEADLINE: CLINTON STANDS FIRM ON TAIWAN ISSUE: DPP CHAIRMAN

TEXT.P: The chairman of Taiwan's main opposition party said on Saturday he is satisfied with US President Bill Clinton's firm stance on the issue of Taiwan.

Hsu Hsin-liang, chairman of the pro-independence Democratic Progressive Party (DPP), made the statement shortly after Clinton and mainland Chinese President Jiang Zemin held a joint news conference in Beijing.

Clinton said at the press conference that in his summit meeting with Jiang Saturday morning, he had reaffirmed the United States' "one China" policy. He also advocated the pursuit of the "cross-strait discussion that recently resumed as the best path to a peaceful resolution" of disputes between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait.

"Judging from Clinton's statement, the United States has not made any concessions to communist China over the Taiwan issue," Hsu said, adding that Clinton did not touch on such sensitive issues as US arms sales to Taiwan and the so-called 'three no's' policy.
Hsu said Clinton's firm attitude will help improve Taiwan's status in the international community. "His friendly gesture has enabled Taiwan to face mainland China on an equal footing," he added.
Hsu also lauded Clinton for bringing up human rights issues and the bloody Tiananmen massacre in his talks with Jiang.

Even though Beijing failed to make major breakthroughs in issues related to Taiwan and its bid to join the World Trade Organization, Hsu said Clinton's current high-profile state visit will still help upgrade mainland China's international status.

DOC.HEADLINE: THOUSANDS DEMONSTRATE FOR TAIWAN INDEPENDENCE

TEXT.P: Thousands of Taiwan independence advocates took part in a demonstration Saturday, demanding that the government hold a referendum on Dec. 5 to allow voters to determine the future of the island.
The event was organized by about 20 pro-independence groups such as the Taiwan Independence Party (TAIP) and Association of Taiwan Professors.

Organizers said they wanted to express concern over the possible effects on Taiwan of the summit meeting between US President Bill Clinton and mainland Chinese President Jiang Zemin, and highlight the right of Taiwan citizens to self-determination.

Demonstrators gathered in front of the Chiang Kai-shek Memorial Hall at 3:30 p.m., each wearing orange bands on their heads. They also carried banners reading: "One Taiwan, One China" or "Protecting Taiwan, Founding A New Country".

Lee Chen-yuan, TAIP honorary chairman and leader of the demonstration, said Clinton was doing quite well in the summit. He pointed out that in the news conference following the meeting between the two leaders, Clinton did not say Taiwan is a part of mainland China.

Lee said that the so-called "Taiwan issue" cannot be tackled by only the US and the mainland. Through self-determination by Taiwan people and peaceful pressure from the international community can the dispute between the mainland and Taiwan be peacefully solved, he said.

Professor Kao Cheng-yen at the National Taiwan University said the results of the Clinton-Jiang meeting showed that US policy toward China has not changed much. He said at a time when the Kuomintang still seeks unification, the people of Taiwan demand the right to decide if they want to establish a new country.

Legislator Yeh Chu-lan of the opposition Democratic Progressive Party said no matter what the results of the Clinton-Jiang meeting are, it would not affect the determination of the people of Taiwan to declare their own country. She expressed hope that the demonstration will let the international community know the wishes of the people of Taiwan.

Demonstrators marched to the American Institute in Taiwan, the American de facto embassy to Taiwan. A declaration was read in front of the institute, stressing that the future of Taiwan should be determined by its 21 million residents.

The statement said although the group feels Clinton's proposal that "the Taiwan issue should be peacefully solved" is in line with the common interest of maintaining international peace and development, the island's sovereignty and the people's dignity should be respected.
It urged the government to immediately institute a referendum law to allow people to vote on the independence issue on Dec. 5, a date that coincides with legislative elections.

DOC.HEADLINE: US URGED TO STRENGTHEN PARALLEL TIES WITH TAIWAN

TEXT.P: Washington should strengthen parallel ties with Taipei as it engages in closer relations with Beijing, Vice Minister of Foreign Affairs David Lee said Saturday.

In a news conference held in Taipei following the summit between US President Bill Clinton and his mainland Chinese counterpart Jiang Zemin, Lee urged the people in Taiwan not to overreact to the summit, which did not result in any surprises as the US administration had promised.

As expected, the news conference held after the summit at Beijing's Great Hall of the People Saturday did not touch on the so-called "three no's" policy toward Taiwan, causing no apparent damage to Taiwan's interests, Lee said.
He, however, asserted that the Republic of China is a sovereign state, and that any issues involving the ROC's interests should be discussed with Taipei, not with Beijing.
It was not yet known as of Saturday afternoon how much of the discussion between Clinton and Jiang was devoted to Taiwan, he said.
The Taiwan issue was not included in any of the nine major topics of the Clinton-Jiang summit agenda, he said.

Lee said under Washington's policy of engagement with Beijing, more high-level meetings between the US and mainland China in the future are inevitable. He called for the people of Taiwan to view such developments as casual as possible.
"We need not be over-worried about such developments," Lee said, "because if such engagement policy is conducive to bolstering regional peace and stability, it is what we are pleased to see."

On Clinton's remarks calling for Beijing and Taipei to resume a cross-strait dialogue, Lee said over the past several years, Taiwan has repeatedly expressed willingness to return to the negotiating table with Beijing.
"President Clinton's remarks today indicated that the United States is fully aware of Taipei's sincerity in this effort," he noted.

Meanwhile, Mainland Affairs Council Vice Chairman and spokesman Sheu Ke-sheng said he personally did not understand what was in Jiang Zemin's mind when he linked Taiwan to Tibet during the post-summit news conference in Beijing.

Jiang said there are two preconditions for Beijing to resume talks with the Dalai Lama, Tibet's spiritual leader. First, the Dalai Lama must recognize that Tibet is a part of China, and second, the Dalai Lama must also recognize that Taiwan is a province of China, Jiang said.

On Clinton's calls for the resumption of the cross-strait talks, Sheu said Taipei's stance has always been very clear. Taipei hopes to solve its differences with Beijing through negotiations in a practical and rational manner.

DOC.HEADLINE: BEIJING URGED NOT TO DOWNGRADE ROC AS 'LOCAL GOVERNMENT'

TEXT.P: Vice President Lien Chan on Saturday protested Beijing's downgrading of the Republic of China's status as a "local government."

"We can never accept Beijing's attempt to 'localized' the ROC's status," Lien said in a live radio program shortly after a summit meeting between US President Bill Clinton and his mainland counterpart, Jiang Zemin, in Beijing.
Jiang told a news conference after his meeting with Clinton that Taiwan is a province of the People's Republic of China.
Responding to Jiang's remarks, Lien said he hopes mainland China will deal with its relations with Taiwan with new thinking or openminded thinking.

Lien reiterated Taiwan's flexible and pragmatic attitude toward differences between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait. "We have always kept our doors open for cross-strait dialogue and consultation."

Noting that the Republic of China is a sovereign state founded in 1911, Lien said it absolutely cannot accept the "one country, two systems" scheme that Beijing has imposed on Hong Kong. "Nor can we accept Beijing's attempt to downgrade the ROC as a province or region under its jurisdiction."
Lien further said cross-strait issues cannot be resolved by military means because the key points lie in differences between systems and lifestyles.
"The two sides should respect each other and work hand-in-hand to promote constructive exchanges and positive interactions," Lien said.

Over the past three years, Lien said, the ROC has held out olive branch on many occasions. "We have called for early resumption of cross-strait dialogue broken unilaterally by Beijing in mid-1995, signing of a peace agreement, exchanges of visits by the top leaders on both sides and joint actions in helping resolve the Southeast Asian financial crisis."
Much to Taiwan's regret, Lien said, Beijing has failed to make positive response to all those goodwill overtures.

Lien said he hopes Beijing's Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait (ARATS) will resume its institutionalized dialogue with Taipei's Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) as soon as possible. SEF and ARATS are quasi-official organizations authroized by their respective governments to handle cross-strait exchanges in the absence of official ties.

Asked whether the United States is likely to mediate cross-strait disputes, Lien said Washington already promised not to act as a go-between, nor to pressure Taipei to negotiate with Beijing in 1982 when it offered "six guarantees" to Taiwan. "The US guarantees and policy toward Taiwan have remained unchanged," he explained.

Lien said he was not surprised by the fact that the just-concluded Clinton-Jiang summit has not achieved major breakthroughs in issues related to Taiwan. "We were aware that the Clinton-Jiang summit would not focus on issues related to the ROC," he said.
Lien further called on the United States to continue reinforcing relations with Taiwan while seeking to expand engagements with Beijing.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAINLAND CHINA AND RUSSIA GRANTED OBSERVER STATUS IN RIMPAC

TEXT.P: Mainland China and Russia will participate in the biennial Rim of the Pacific Exercise (RIMPAC) as observers in early July, sources said Saturday.

Naval war games off Hawaii involving the United States and its Pacific allies will include over 50 ships, 200 aircraft and 25,000 service members from six countries, an official from Japan's Maritime Self-Defense Force said.
Mainland China and Russia will take part in the exercise as observers for the first time since they began in early the 1970s.

Starting July 6, naval forces from the United States, Japan, Australia, South Korea, Canada and Chile will engage in month-long exercises sponsored by the US Navy's third fleet, to assess the ability of their ships and improve tactical skills.
Due to financial constraints, the scale of RIMPAC 1998 will be smaller than the one in 1996. The US Navy does not plan to dispatch aircraft carriers this year as they have in the past.

It was also reported Saturday that mainland China hopes to participate in the US armed forces' regular exercises as an observer from 1999, and an agreement is likely to be reached for such participation during US President Bill Clinton's current tour of mainland China.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT OFFICIAL APPRECIATES CLINTON'S REMARKS ABOUT TAIWAN

TEXT.P: An official of the ruling Kuomintang said he appreciates the remarks President Bill Clinton made Saturday in Beijing about Taiwan and the efforts the US government has made to maintain peace and stability in the Asian Pacific area.

At a press conference in Beijing on Saturday afternoon, President Clinton reaffirmed the "one-China" policy and urged the pursuit of "the cross-strait discussions that recently resumed as the best path to a peaceful resolution" of the differences between Taiwan and mainland China.

Chang Rong-kung, director general of the Mainland Affairs Research Department of the Kuomintang Central Committee, told the press Saturday afternoon that, although President Clinton did not mention the "three nos" Beijing leaders reportedly wanted him to mention during his visit to mainland China, Taiwan still has to be cautious about it, because Beijing officials may continue to pressure Clinton into mentioning the "three nos" before the end of his visit in mainland China.

The "three nos" refer to the US position of no support for Taiwan independence, no support for the idea of "one China, one Taiwan" or "two Chinas", and no support for Taiwan's bid to join the United Nations and similar international organizations.

Chang said that, judging from the remarks of President Clinton about Taiwan, he believed the dialogues between Taiwan and mainland China could be resumed next year. The dialogues were disrupted unilaterally by Beijing in 1996.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN SHOULD RELY ON ITSELF: PREMIER

TEXT.P: Republic of China Premier Vincent Siew said although there are no signs indicating the United States has softened its support of Taiwan, the island must rely on itself in international relations.
Siew made the comments after a joint news conference held by US President Bill Clinton and mainland China President Jiang Zemin which followed their high-profile summit in Beijing Saturday.
Siew expressed the hope the United States will abide by the Taiwan Relations Act. He also hoped the summit will help foster peace and stability in the Asia-Pacific region.
A task force comprised of ranking officials from relevant sectors under the Executive Yuan has been formed to study the details in the Clinton-Jiang summit and any further developments, he noted.

The Taiwan Relations Act, enacted in 1979, was designed to help maintain peace, security and stability in the western Pacific region. It helps promote the foreign policy of the United States by authorizing the continuation of close and friendly commercial, cultural, and other relations between the peoples of the United States and Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN-WASHINGTON TIES AFFECTED BY CLINTON-JIANG SUMMIT: SCHOLAR

TEXT.P: A political scholar warned Saturday that even though Taiwan's interests were not sacrificed at the Clinton-Jiang summit meeting, relations between Taipei and Washington will be affected.

Chang Wu-yue, dean of the Graduate Institute of Mainland Studies in Tamkang University, said as Washington-Beijing ties are expected to improve further after the summit between US President Bill Clinton and mainland Chinese President Jiang Zemin, Taiwan has to prepare for a change in relations with the US.

Chang said the Ministry of Foreign Affairs' task force, established to tackle the possible effects on Taiwan of the Clinton-Jiang summit meeting, should become a standing committee to respond to any development in Washington-Beijing ties.
In reference to the so-called "three no's" policy, he said "no support" is somewhat different from "being opposed to."
The "three no's" refers to no US support for an independent Taiwan, no US support for "two Chinas" or "one China, one Taiwan," and no US support for Taiwan's bid to enter the United Nations.

Chang said no US support for Taiwan independence and no support for "two Chinas" or "one China, one Taiwan" is in line with Washington's current policy, and if the summit meeting restates this support, it would not hurt Taiwan very much.

However, if Clinton said in the meeting that the US does not support Taiwan's bid to enter the UN or other international organizations, it could hurt Taiwan at a time when it seeks to increase its international profile, Chang noted.

Meanwhile, Ying Nai-ping, an economics professor at the National Chengchi University, said the US has delinked the human rights issue with trade and economic issues because of successful lobbying by US businessmen.

Ying said despite the fact that the US government has gradually accepted the "three no's" policy, he believes the Clinton-Jiang meeting will help bring the two sides of the Taiwan Strait back to the negotiating table.

Wu Chai-yi, a researcher at Taiwan Research Institute, said at a time when Beijing continues to block Taiwan's diplomatic efforts, Taiwan can only use its economic strength to expand its international profile.
The three experts and professors made the remarks in a seminar sponsored by former National Assembly deputy Mu Ming-chu.

DOC.HEADLINE: RENMINBI TO BE DEVALUED: SURVEY

TEXT.P: Despite Beijing's repeated assurances that it will not devalue the renminbi, more than three-quarters of Taiwan businessmen believe otherwise, a recent survey found.

A devaluation of the renminbi is expected within the next two years by 77.3 percent of the survey's respondents, while, 21.1 percent believe the currency will not be devalued. The survey results were made public Saturday.

Some 82.3 percent of respondents said that amid mainland China's declining exports, there will be pressure for a renminbi devaluation. The survey, which was conducted between May 15 and 31 by the Taipei-based Chinese National Federation of Industries, polled 18,000 Taiwan businessmen with operations in the mainland.
The findings were released following a summit between US President Bill Clinton and mainland Chinese President Jiang Zemin in Beijing Saturday.

Local newspapers reported that mainland Chinese Premier Zhu Rongji guaranteed US Treasury Secretary Robert Rubin, a member of Clinton's delegation, at a Saturday luncheon that the renminbi will not be devaluated.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI MAYOR FEELS RELIEVED AFTER CLINTON-JIANG SUMMIT

TEXT.P: Taipei Mayor Chen Shui-bian on Sunday said that he felt that the just-concluded Clinton-Jiang summit did not hurt Taiwan's interest.

Chen said that prior to the meeting between US President Bill Clinton and mainland Chinese President Jiang Zemin, people of Taiwan were concerned that Taiwan's interests might be sacrificed at the meeting.

The popular mayor of opposition Democratic Progressive Party said that he was glad the summit meeting did not result in any surprises, as high-ranking US officials had assured him during his US visit in mid-March.

The summit signified that Taiwan's future cannot be decided by any country, any government or any individual, Chen claimed, pointing out that it can only be determined by Taiwan's 21 million residents.
Saying there is only one Taiwan and there is only one national interest, the pro-independence mayor urged people in Taiwan to unite to let their voices be heard beyond the island.
Taiwan must currently deal with issues of dignity, security and development, Chen said. Only through unity, he said, can Taiwan's people create a better tomorrow.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC TO CONTINUE MONITORING CLINTON'S MAINALND VISIT

TEXT.P: The Republic of China will continue to closely monitor US President Bill Clinton's mainland China visit until its conclusion on July 3, Foreign Affairs Minister Jason Hu said Sunday.
Hu's remarks came after Clinton and mainland Chinese President Jiang Zemin met Saturday in Beijing.
Hu said the Republic of China will make a formal response to the Clinton-Jiang meeting after the United States provides the Republic of China a detailed report on Clinton's trip.
"So far, no signs have shown that the US has done anything that is not in keeping with its promises," he said.

Washington has repeatedly pledged to Taipei that Taiwan's interests would not be hurt in the Clinton-Jiang meeting and that there would be not a fourth communique or joint statement regarding Taiwan following the summit.

As to the question of whether Washington will cling too closely to Beijing in trilateral Washington-Beijing-Taipei ties, Hu said many countries, including Japan, are concerned about such a development, and urged Washington to take measures to ease their concerns.
Hu said his ministry will further enhance contacts and exchanges with both the US Congress and administration in the future and that it has worked out a three-year package with that aim.

Hu made the remarks after returning from a whirlwind visit to Poland on Saturday, where he had been invited by the Stefan Batory Foundation to deliver a keynote speech at the opening of the three-day "International Relations and Democracy" conference in Warsaw.

Describing the fast-developing countries in central and east Europe as a "new Europe" emerging on the world stage, Hu said strengthened relations with countries in the region will produce greater trade and commerce opportunities and help Taiwan lay the groundwork for improved European ties.

Hu, who also presided over a working meeting with ROC diplomatic personnel stationed in eastern European countries in Prague earlier this month, went on to say that during his recent trips to Poland and the Czech Republic, he felt that the two countries are very friendly toward Taiwan and that the ROC government is willing to boost bilateral exchanges with them.
Stressing the importance for the nation to "reach out," the foreign minister said he decided to visit Poland even though his trip coincided with the Clinton-Jiang meeting in Beijing.
Despite his 72-hour absence from Taipei, Hu said a task force led by Vice Foreign Minister David Lee set up to monitor the Clinton-Jiang meeting was operating smoothly.

Lee said at a Saturday news conference following the summit that the Republic of China welcomes the agreements reached between Washington and Beijing on weapons proliferation, de-targeting missiles at each others' cities and a joint response to Asia's financial crisis.

Lee also praised Washington for keeping its promises and for its guarantees that no joint communique or public declaration on Taiwan would be announced, pointing out that Clinton's call on mainland China to resume negotiation as soon as possible with Taiwan is in line with the ROC government's stance on cross-strait ties.

DOC.HEADLINE: TEAM INVESTIGATING SEXUAL ASSAULT CLAIM RETURNS FROM PARIS

TEXT.P: Three Taipei law enforcement officials probing allegations that the head of Taiwan's Investigation Bureau sexually assaulted a 19-year-old girl in Paris in 1996 returned to Taipei Sunday afternoon.
The three-member team, led by Huang Shih-ming, secretary general of the Justice Ministry , refused to discuss the investigation with reporters at the Chiang Kai-shek International Airport in Taoyuan.
But speaking at a brief press conference in Paris after wrapping up their probe there on Saturday, Huang said the team had interviewed the victim of the alleged assault, Yang Yu-chen, on Friday.
Yang, 20, has accused Chen Chuan, the investigation bureau's acting director, of attempting to rape her.

Yang's mother, Chiu Pai-lien, permitted Li Tsui-lien, the team's sole female investigator, to meet with Yang at a Paris area hospital where she is being treated for psychic trauma stemming from the alleged incident.
Although the hospital refused to disclose Yang's mental status, the woman seemed mentally competent during the interview and answered questions with what little Chinese she knew, said Huang.
Chiu Pai-lien was present at the interrogation but did not interrupt the meeting, said Huang.

Huang did not reveal details of the interview at the press conference in Paris, saying only that all information and evidence collected by the team will be presented to the six-member panel that commissioned the probe.

Yang Yu-chen's interview capped the Paris leg of the team's investigation, which also included interviews with Yang's mother and her father, Yang Wan-ching, as well as a spot-inspection of the hotel where the alleged incident took place, said Huang.

Huang expressed regret that the team failed to obtain a copy of Yang's complaint to the French police and the hospital's diagnosis of the woman's mental state. The team will continue to seek the information through Taipei's representative office in Paris, said Huang.

Cheng is accused of sexually assaulting Yang while performing Chihkung therapy, in which the practitioner channels and focuses positive energy, ultimately projecting it into a recipient. He has admitted performing the therapy on Yang while visiting her parents in Paris two years ago.

Yang's father filed complaints with Taipei authorities to no avail. His allegations received public attention, however, after an opposition parliamentarian made them public and called for an investigation after Cheng had been tapped to become the bureau's permant director.
The Justice Ministry set up a special panel on June 7 to look into the allegations.

DOC.HEADLINE: CLINTON CRITICIZED FOR CONSIGNING TIANANMEN TO HISTORY

TEXT.P: US Congresswoman Nancy Pelosi criticized President Bill Clinton on Saturday for trying to relegate the Tiananmen Square tragedy to history.
She said the president's approach is "a rejection of former Communist Party chief Zhao Ziyang's brave initiative to get China's leaders to reverse the Tiananmen Square verdict."

The Californian Democrat, who has been critical of President Clinton's mainland China policy, added that the press conference after the Beijing summit meeting was a victory for mainland Chinese President Jiang Zemin, because without making any concessions on trade, proliferation or human rights, mainland China's president has accrued all of the benefits of standing side-by-side with the president of the United States.

In a statement on the Clinton-Jiang summit, Pelosi noted that President Clinton was right when he said the American people believe that the use of force and the tragic loss of life at Tiananmen Square was wrong. But he was wrong in trying to relegate the Tiananmen Square tragedy to the realm of "past action" and missed an opportunity to associate himself with mainland China's reformers.

As long as people are still being held in prison for the peaceful expression of their religious and political beliefs, and dissidents are not free to speak freely in mainland China, the Tiananmen Square era continues, claimed the congresswoman, adding that "on human rights, President Clinton has said just enough for US domestic consumption, and not enough to produce results for the Chinese people."

Results were lacking in other areas, too. Progress at this summit has been limited to a rehashing of earlier announcements and the acceptance by the Clinton administration of a series of promises the mainland Chinese government has already made and not kept, sometimes repeatedly.

Once again, said Pelosi, the mainland Chinese government has gotten away with promising to study the Missile Technology Control Regime and promising to sign, at a later date, the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights.

DOC.HEADLINE: JIANG USES TIBET ISSUE TO DOWNGRADE TAIWAN'S STATUS: SCHOLAR

TEXT.P: When mainland Chinese President Jiang Zemin equated Tibet with Taiwan at a joint press conference with US President Bill Clinton, he intended to downgrade Taiwan's status to a local government, said a Taiwan political scholar on Sunday.

Pan Shi-tang, a professor at the Graduate Institute of Mainland Chinese Studies under Tamkang University, said that during the press conference after the summit meeting, Jiang used the Tibet issue to stress the country's "one China" policy, contending that both Tibet and Taiwan are part of mainland China.

On the Tibet issue, Jiang gave preconditions for talks between Tibet's spiritual leader, the exiled Dalai Lama, and himself, saying that "if he acknowledges that Tibet is an inseparable part of China -- at that same time he also must admit that Taiwan is a province of China -- then, as far I see it, the door to negotiation is open".

Pan also said that although Taiwan was not a focal point in the summit, which focused on the nonproliferation of nuclear weapons, regional security and international cooperation, Taiwan should recognize the possibility that the Taiwan issue might be raised in talks outside an official summit.

Another scholar Liu Yi-chun, assistant researcher at Academia Sinica, echoed Pan's views, warning that the government must be alert that the two countries might have reached an under-the-table agreement on Taiwan issue.

Taiwan diplomatic officials felt relieved when Clinton did not mention the so-called "three noes" during the conference. But Liu questioned whether officials have considered the possibility of a tacit agreement being reached.
