Liu pointed out that according to reports, after the press conference, US National Security Adviser Samuel Berger said during a briefing that Clinton had reaffirmed to Jiang his support for the United States' "one China policy" including the "three No's" policy toward Taiwan.

The "three noes" are no support for an independent Taiwan, no support for a "two Chinas" or "one China, one Taiwan" policy and no support for Taiwan's admission to the United Nations or other international organizations into which admission is restricted to recognized countries.
Liu said that even though Taiwan's interests were not sacrificed at the summit meeting, Taiwan has to keep watching closely any development in Beijing-Washington relations.
Pan and Liu made the remarks in a seminar, titled "Clinton-Jiang Summit Meeting and Cross-Strait Relations," sponsored by the Chinese Culture Association.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT AND FOREIGN MINISTRY AT ODDS ON IMPACT OF 'THREE NOES'

TEXT.P: The ruling Kuomintang and Foreign Ministry do not see eye to eye on the impact of the "three noes" promises demanded by Beijing from Washington during the just-concluded summit between US President Bill Clinton and mainland Chinese President Jiang Zemin.

Vice Foreign Minister David Tawei Lee played down the effects of the call for support for the "three noes" -- no US support for an independent Taiwan, no support for a "two Chinas" or "one China, one Taiwan" policy and no support for Taiwan's membership in international organizations that require statehood. Lee's remarks were made in a seminar sponsored by a local think tank.

Dismissing the first two noes as nothing more than a rehashing of promises embodied in previous communiques between Beijing and Washington, Lee said that only the third promise of not supporting Taiwan's membership in international organizations is new and could negatively affect the island's efforts to promote its international profile.

Claiming the third no conflicts with the results of a 1994 review of Washington's Taiwan policy, Lee called on the United States to live up to its promises and help Taiwan join functionary international bodies.
Chang Jung-kung, director of the KMT's Mainland Affairs Department, disputed Lee, saying that any public declaration of the "three noes" would spell disaster for Taiwan.

The "three noes" were not raised at the joint press conference held by Clinton and Jiang on Saturday, but US National Security Adviser Samuel Berger mentioned them in a background briefing to reporters.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC DIPLOMAT EMBROILED IN OVERSEAS SEX SCANDAL: REPORT

TEXT.P: Fast on the heels of allegations that the acting head of Taiwan's investigation bureau sexually assaulted a woman in Paris in 1996, another official has been charged with raping an overseas Chinese woman in Panama last year, according to a local newspaper.

The China Times reported on Sunday that the angry father of the woman, identified only by her surname of Lin, filed a claim demanding NT$100 million (US$2.94 million) in damages, as well as a public apology from the government.
The alleged rape occurred during President Lee Teng-hui's high-profile trip to Panama from Sept. 7 to 9, 1997.

An ROC diplomat, identified only by his surname of Chen, was stationed in Peru by the Government Information Office and temporarily transferred to Panama City for Lee's trip. Chen is accused of raping Lin, whose father is a leader among the city's Chinese community and owns a company and several plants there, the China Times reported.

Lin's father was quoted as saying that the official raped Lin at least five times, in the workers' living quarters of the makeshift press office built for President Lee's visit and in the official's hotel.
Lin's father further accused Chen of luring Lin into Chen's hotel room and sexually assaulting her for more than four hours, during which time he seriously injured the woman's vagina.

Chen was summoned by the GIO to Taipei after Lin's father filed a complaint. Chen was later dismissed for abandoning his post, as he had returned to Panama City a second time without permission. He was also accused of conduct unbecoming an official.

A GIO official told the newspaper that Vice Foreign Minister David Tawei Lee, then secretary general of the GIO, as well as several senior GIO officials had apologized to Lin and her father personally, but had denied their claims for damage on grounds that the GIO should not be held responsible for its staff's personal conduct.
The case has flared up at a time when the acting head of the island's Investigation Bureau, Cheng Chuan, is under investigation for allegedly attempt to rape a Chinese girl in Paris in 1996.
A team probing the allegation returned to Taipei from Paris on Sunday.

DOC.HEADLINE: CLINTON-JIANG MEETING MAY HURT TAIWAN: SEMINAR

TEXT.P: Academics attending a Sunday seminar said the meeting between US President Bill Clinton and his mainland Chinese counterpart, Jiang Zemin, will hurt Taiwan to some extent and urged the ROC government to take preventive measures to reduce the possible damage.

J. K. Chang, head of the ruling Kuomintang's Mainland Affairs Operations Department, said the Clinton-Jiang summit will undoubtedly hurt Taiwan. He urged the government to work to improve relations with the United States and to let the world know Taiwan's position.

Chang said Clinton fell short of speaking publicly on Beijing's demands for support for its "three noes" in his Saturday meeting with mainland Chinese President Jiang Zemin because Beijing has not renounced the use of force against Taiwan.
The "three noes" are no US support for an independent Taiwan, no support for "two Chinas" or "one China, one Taiwan" and no support for Taiwan's bid to join the United Nations.

H. T. Pan, a professor of mainland affairs at Tamkang University, warned the government not to be too optimistic. Expressing his belief that Clinton and Jiang must have discussed the "three noes" issues and even Beijing's demand that the United States reduce arms sales to Taiwan, Pan said the government cannot judge the substantive contents of the Clinton-Jiang summit talks solely by its resulting news conference.
Although the impact of Clinton-Jiang meeting on Taiwan will be limited in the short term, Pan warned of a long-term effect, especially in US arm sales to Taiwan.
As Washington and Beijing may hold regular bilateral talks in the future, Taiwan should pay greater attention to changes in the two countries' relations, Pan said.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN URGED TO USE ITS DEMOCRACY TO WIN INTERNATIONAL SUPPORT

TEXT.P: Rather than focus too much on the so-called "three noes," Taiwan should use its democracy and economic strength to establish a new, strategic value to the world, several scholars suggested Sunday.

They said in a public TV program -- "Face the Audience" that although the United States is engaging in closer relations with mainland China, the United States' insistence on democracy and human rights bodes well for Taiwan. They stressed Taiwan should take advantage of its democratic and economic achievements to win international support and respect.

Regarding the "three noes," Shaw Yu-ming, director of the Institute of International Relations, said that no US support for Taiwan independence and no support for "two Chinas" or "one China, one Taiwan" was implied in the 1972 Shanghai Joint Communique. If US President Bill Clinton restates this support, it would not hurt Taiwan very much, he said.

If, however, Clinton said that the United States does not support Taiwan's bids to enter international organizations into which admission is restricted to recognized countries, it will hurt Taiwan at a time when it seeks to enhance its international profile, Shaw said.

Shaw suggested that the ROC Ministry of Foreign Affairs press the United States to adhere to a 1994 review of its 1979 Taiwan Relations Act. In the review, the US government promised to help Taiwan join functionary international organizations.

He said that when the US and mainland China are moving toward closer ties, Taiwan has to make efforts to promote relations with Washington as well as Beijing. He warned that if the government cannot strengthen cross-strait exchanges, Taiwan's position in trilateral Taipei-Beijing-Washington relations will be weakened.

Shaw said that the ultimate goal of the defense policy is to win support from people on the mainland. One of the best ways to promote mutual understanding is to allow mainland Chinese students to study in Taiwan, he said.
Relief programs offered by Taiwan's Buddhist Compassion Relief Tzu Chi Association in the mainland also serve as a bridge between Taiwan and the mainland, he noted.

DOC.HEADLINE: CLINTON, JIANG TRADE TAKES ON TIANANMEN AT SUMMIT

TEXT.P: Once again, US President Bill Clinton gained the ideological and moral high ground when he confronted his Chinese counterpart, Jiang Zemin, over the issue of human rights.

Mainland China was obviously put on the defensive when it came to such matters, with the Tiananmen incident the most glaring example, The Straits Times said Sunday in a news analysis report from Beijing on the Clinton-Jiang summit Saturday.
Jiang seemed to be defending an indefensible case, it noted.

The fact that he had to read carefully from a prepared text, uncharacteristic of him when addressing other less-sensitive matters, underlined the sensitivity and difficulty he has experienced over this particular issue.

For years, the mainland Chinese were told that the military crackdown in Tiananmen Square was justified on the grounds of national stability. Jiang reiterated that line at a press conference following the summit.
Clinton said that he went into some length exploring with Jiang on ways that those "imprisoned for non-violent activities in June 1989" may be released.

The fact that China has allowed blatant US interference in its affairs may be seen as the Chinese leadership conceding that the Tiananmen action was not entirely right, whatever the justification, the report said.

DOC.HEADLINE: TIME NOT ON TAIWAN'S SIDE: NEW PARTY

TEXT.P: Time is not on Taiwan's side, and the island will lose its advantage in cross-strait negotiations if talks cannot be resumed soon, a heavyweight with the pro-unification New Party said Sunday.

Wang Chien-shien, the New Party's candidate for Taipei mayor, said Taiwan must push for an early resumption of cross-strait negotiations, because Taiwan will gradually lose ground in cross-strait talks while mainland China gains ground.

Commenting on the Saturday meeting between US President Bill Clinton and mainland Chinese President Jiang Zemin in Beijing, Wang said it seems that Taiwan's interests were not hurt as a result of the meeting. But he warned that Taiwan's interests will eventually be sold out if Washington and Beijing continue their engagement.

The United States has sold out the Republic of China several times, he said, but added that Washington will not do so again at present because it is playing the "Taiwan card" in its dealings with Beijing.

It is very dangerous if a country's fate is determined by another country, Wang said. He called on the people of Taiwan to stand up and build a better country to maintain Taiwan's advantage in cross-strait competition.
Jaw Shau-kong, election manager of the New Party, also warned on Saturday that the Clinton-Jiang meeting means a strengthening of Washington-Beijing ties, a signal of danger to Taiwan.

Although no signs of change in cross-strait relations have been seen following the Clinton-Jiang meeting, Taiwan will face greater difficulties in future trilateral Taipei-Washington-Beijing ties as relations between Washington and Beijing improve, Jaw noted.

Jaw said Taiwan should reduce its reliance on the United States and conduct negotiations with the mainland under the framework of "one China," which means that the two sides of the Taiwan Strait belong to the same China, but each side remains independent of each other. "One China" does not refer to the "People's Republic of China," he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN LEADERS POSITIVE ABOUT CLINTON-JIANG SUMMIT (1)

TEXT.P: Taiwan leaders have indicated that they are positive about Saturday's summit meeting between Presidents Bill Clinton and Jiang Zemin in Beijing.
They expressed the hope that the summit will be beneficial to the Asian Pacific region, and not be harmful to the relations between Taiwan and the United States.

In the summit Clinton and Jiang agreed to work together for progress in pollution control and prevention of nuclear proliferation. They also talked about cooperation in stabilizing the financial situations in Asia and improving the legal and judicial system of mainland China. The two leaders also agreed, among other things, not to target each other with nuclear missiles.

In the press conference held after the meeting, Clinton reaffirmed the United States' "one China" policy and urged the pursuit of cross-strait dialogues as the best path to peaceful resolution of the differences between Taiwan and mainland China.

To Taiwan leaders' relief, Clinton did not mention in the press conference the "three nos" Beijing leaders reportedly wanted him to mention during his visit to Beijing. The "three nos" refer to the US position of no support for Taiwan independence, no support for the idea of "one China, one Taiwan" or "Two Chinas", and no support for Taiwan's bid to join the United Nations and other international organizations of sovereign countries.

Premier Vincent Siew said Saturday the remarks made by Clinton in the press conference indicated that there is no change in the attitude of the United States toward Taiwan. He expressed the hope that the US government will continue to stick to the Taiwan Relations Act and its long-standing attitude toward Taiwan.

Siew also said that he hopes the submit meeting will eventually contribute to the stability and peaceful development of the Asian Pacific region, and will not undermine the relations between Taiwan and the US.

When asked Sunday whether the summit has tipped the balance of US foreign relations in favor of Beijing, Foreign Minister Jason Hu said many people, including those in Japan, have such feeling at the height of rapprochement between Washington and Beijing. The US government should pay attention to this "psychological effect" and do something about it, he added.

Vice Foreign Minister David Tawei Lee said Saturday that the summit has resulted in some agreements, which will be conducive to the stability and prosperity of the Asian Pacific region and beneficial to mainland China's programs of reform and openness. "We would be glad to see these happen," he said.
Lee also pointed out that the US and Taiwan share many ideals and values, and have common interests. Taipei will continue to try to enhance its relations with Washington for mutual benefits, he said.

"We are confident in the development of relations between the two countries," Lee said, adding that he hopes Washington will take concrete steps to improve its relations with Taipei, so as to help create a "win-win-win situation" for the US, Taiwan, and mainland China. He said Taiwan will request US support for its bid to join functional international organizations such as the World Health Organization.

Lee also said that mainland China has not renounced the use of military force against Taiwan and has been trying to hinder Taiwan's activities in the international community. This is an important factor affecting peace and stability in the Asian Pacific region, he added. (more)

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN LEADERS POSITIVE ABOUT CLINTON-JIANG SUMMIT (2)

TEXT.P: Wu An-chia, vice chairman of the Mainland Affairs Council of the Executive Yuan, said Sunday at a seminar on "The Effect of Clinton-Jiang Summit on the Situation in the Asian Pacific Region" that he believes the meeting will be conducive to more dialogues between Taiwan and mainland China.
Wu said that it is the policy of his government to pursue dialogues with mainland China, and that he believes cross-strait discussions will progress gradually in an orderly manner.

He however pointed out that the differences between Taiwan and mainland China in economic, political and social systems and developments will remain for quite a long time, hindering the progress of discussions between them.

In the seminar, Shaw Yu-ming, director of the Institute of International Relations of the National Chengchi University in Taipei, said the summit indicated Beijing leaders apparently believe that the shortest way to grab Taiwan is going through Washington.

Under such circumstances, Taiwan has to try to improve its relations with the US, and at the same time try to manage cross-strait relations "in a pragmatic, sincere, rational, far-sighted manner." Taiwan must be active in dealing with mainland China and avoid misunderstanding, he said.

In an interview with the Taipei-based Broadcasting Corporation of China Saturday, Vice President Lien Chan urged Beijing leaders to be "open-minded" and handle its relations with Taiwan on the basis of mutual respect.

He said Taiwan will try to improve its relations with mainland China in a pragmatic and flexible way. "Our door is always open for consultations," he said. "But we can never agree to Beijing's attempt to downgrade us to a local government."
Lien expressed the hope that Washington will improve its relations with Taipei while trying to expand engagement with Beijing.

DOC.HEADLINE: ALBRIGHT SAYS RELATIONS WITH TAIWAN WILL REMAIN UNCHANGED
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, June 28 (CNA) (By Nelson Chung & Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: The United States government has adhered to the Taiwan Relations Act, and nothing in the act has been -- or will be -- changed, US Secretary of State Madeleine Albright said in Beijing on Sunday.

"The message to the people of Taiwan is the same as it has always been, which is that we believe there needs to be a peaceful dialogue," Albright said during an interview with the CBS television program, "Face the Nation."

"The Shanghai Communique governs the way that we deal with the issue. We have urged the Chinese, mainland Chinese, to have a peaceful dialogue (with Taiwan), and our policy is the same as it has always been, which is a one China policy," she said.
Albright said that the United States will continue to urge both Taiwan and mainland China to enter into a peaceful dialogue with each other to resolve their differences.

The Taiwan Relations Act, enacted by the US Congress and approved by then-US President Jimmy Carter in 1979, regulates Washington's unofficial ties with Taipei and promises to provide Taiwan with defensive weapons.

Regarding human rights in mainland China, Albright said "there is a long way to go." On the Beijing authorities' refusal to allow meetings between Clinton and mainland Chinese dissidents, she said the president has met many mainland Chinese people, and through his televised speech to some 700 million mainland Chinese citizens, "he virtually spoke to the dissidents."

DOC.HEADLINE: US ARMS SALES IN NO WAY UNDERMINES 'ONE CHINA' POLICY: CLINTON

TEXT.P: US arms sales to Taiwan will in no way undermine its "one china" policy, visiting American President Bill Clinton said on Monday.

"Our policy is that weapons sales to Taiwan are for defensive purposes only. We are in no way trying to undermine our 'one China' policy," Clinton said in reply to a question from a Beijing University student.

Clinton said the US' China policy is embodied in the three Washington-Beijing communiques and the Taiwan Relations Act, a US law which requires the United States to furnish Taiwan with defensive arms to ensure its security.

Noting that the United States already recognized communist China and adopted a "one China" policy 20 years ago, Clinton said he reaffirmed this policy to mainland President Jiang Zemin during their summit talks on Saturday.

While committing himself to the "one China" policy, Clinton also reiterated the the consistent US stance that unification between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait should occur strictly by peaceful means.
Against this background, Clinton said, the United States has encouraged cross-strait dialogue to achieve eventual peace unification.

Clinton further said mainland China should not think US arms sales to Taiwan will hinder cross-strait unification or spoil its commitment to the "one China" policy. "US policy is not an obstacle to the peaceful reunification of China and Taiwan," he added.

In his off-the-cuff response to students' questions following his 20-minute speech, Clinton also sought to dispel Beijing's contention that Washington's security treaty with Tokyo is aimed at containing mainland China.
Clinton explained that the US-Japan defense cooperation guidelines, which were amended last year, are designed for revamping strategic relationship between the two countries.
The treaty is not designed to contain any specific country, but for supporting stability in Asia, Clinton stressed.

He pointed out that the United States has stationed troops in South Korea to prevent a military invasion by North Korea. For ensuring Asia-Pacific regional stability, Clinton said, the US has also stationed troops in Japan and signed a security pact.
"We cannot see the agreements of today through the mirror of yesterday's conflicts," Clinton said.

In fact, he noted, most countries in the world hope to forge security partnership with mainland China in the 21st century. The United States, for instance, looks forward to cooperating with mainland China to help reduce tensions caused by the recent nuclear tests in India and Pakistan.
"I believe there will be more cooperation in this field in the future," Clinton said.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOFA DENIES ROC CASH AID TO POLAND

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Foreign Affairs on Monday categorically denied that the Republic of China has promised to give US$20 million in cash aid to Poland to help the eastern European country develop its small and medium-sized enterprises.

MOFA spokesman Roy Wu discounted a report in Monday's China Times that Foreign Minister Jason Hu reached an agreement with Warsaw on the aid during his one-day visit to the country this past weekend. Wu said the report was absolutely untrue.
The foreign minister was invited by the Stefan Batory Foundation to deliver a speech at the opening of a three-day "International Relations and Democracy" conference in Warsaw, Wu said.
Hu did not discuss with any Polish officials the prospect of Taiwan providing Poland with financial aid, nor did he make any agreements during his trip, Wu stressed.

According to the China Times, however, Hu reached an agreement with Warsaw officials on the US$20 million aid package, as well as achieving a consensus with Polish officials on agreements for investment guarantees and double-tax exemptions between the two countries.
Two-way trade between Taiwan and Poland totals about US$440 million annually, with Taiwan usually enjoying a surplus of about US$50 million.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC WARNED OF POSSIBLE DEAL IN CLINTON-JIANG MEETING

TEXT.P: A lawmaker with the opposition Democratic Progressive Party warned the government on Sunday of the possibility that an under-the-table deal was reached between US President Bill Clinton and mainland Chinese President Jiang Zemin during their Beijing summit on Saturday.

In a written inquiry to the Executive Yuan, DPP Legislator Trong Chai said the joint Clinton-Jiang news conference following their meeting showed that the two were reserved about the substantive contents of their talks.

He urged the government to gain a detailed understanding of the agreement reached between the two sides to de-target missiles at each other's cities, saying it could affect future US arms sales to Taiwan.
Chai said Jiang spent some time explaining the Taiwan issue to Clinton during their meeting. Jiang asked the United States to abide by the three joint communiques.

Clinton, meanwhile, urged Taiwan and mainland China to resume dialogue soon in the news conference. Citing informed sources, Chai said Clinton assured Jiang that the United States would sell only defensive weapons to Taiwan.

The DPP lawmaker said that if the US government reduces arms sales to Taiwan, it would be a loss to the United States. He called on the government to stress this to Washington when the United States sends an envoy to Taiwan next month to brief the Republic of China government on the results of the summit.
As the United States is still Taiwan's major arms supplier, Chai said the government should keep supplies stable to help safeguard Taiwan's security and build public confidence.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN'S HUANG RANKS 2ND IN JAPAN WOMEN'S OPEN GOLF TOURNEY

TEXT.P: Huang Yu-chen, who won the Dunlop Ladies Golf Championship one week ago, carded a one-over-par 73 on Sunday to rank second with a four-day total of 288 in the 31st Japan Women's Open Golf Championship.
Huang was awarded a cash prize of 7.7 million yen (about US$55,000), bringing her cash prize total for this season in Japan to 22.61 million yen (about US$161,000).
Japan's Natsuko Noro sank an even-par 72 on the 6,320-yard course of the Miyoshi Country Club, Aiichi Prefecture, to capture the title with a 286.
Noro took home 14 million yen (US$100,000) for capturing the title. This was her first victory in three years and the second in her professional career.
Taiwan amateur Wei Chun-chieh performed well in her first try in the competition with a 293, tying for ninth place with three Japanese players.
Other players from Taiwan scored as follows: Li Wen-lin, 296; Huang Yueh-chin, 299; Cheng Mei-chi, 299; and Tseng Hsiu-feng, 301.
The outstanding performance by 25-year-old Huang caught the attention of sports writers who are portraying her as a new hope from Taiwan.
In her amateur days, Huang was twice rated best amateur player in the Japan Women's Open and won the 1994 Hiroshima Asian Games Women's Golf.

DOC.HEADLINE: THE NETHERLANDS UNVEILS NEW WTO TRAINEE PROGRAM

TEXT.P: The Netherlands announced Sunday the creation of a new WTO program, due to start in September 1998, for trainees from developing countries, according to the Geneva-based World Trade Organization.
The program is designed to help trainees learn, while working for the WTO, about trade and development-related matters and further their understanding of trade policy.
After a maximum of two years, trainees will return to their ministries and contribute to the strengthening of their countries' institutional capacities.

"Effective integration of developing countries in the international trade system is crucial, not only for their development, but also for the credibility of the WTO as a world trade organization. This requires institutional capacity in these countries to deal with WTO matter. Through this initiative, we hope to make a modest contribution to this effect," said Ambassador Eveline Herfkens, permanent representative of the Kingdom of the Netherlands.
Initially, there will be up to three trainees per year in the program, and they will be considered WTO staff members for the duration of their involvement in the program.

The Netherlands will cover the cost of the program. Further details regarding candidate selection and recruitment, as well as trainee supervision, will be released in the coming weeks, according to the WTO.

DOC.HEADLINE: CLINTON ADDS SUBSTANCE TO SYMBOLISM AT TIANANMEN: PAPER

TEXT.P: US President Bill Clinton has injected substance into the symbolism of his reception at Tiananmen Square, the site of brutal massacre in 1989, according to a well respected Australian columnist.

"The extraordinary Clinton-Jiang news conference, broadcast live and uncensored to hundreds of millions of Chinese and around the world, demonstrates the correctness of Bill Clinton's decision to go ahead with the reception at Tiananmen Square," wrote Greg Sheridan, foreign editor of the mass-circulation The Australian.

Harshly criticized by some Republicans and Democrats in the United States for agreeing to be welcomed at the square, Clinton however publicly rebuked the mainland Chinese leadership for the massacre by saying, "I believe, and the American people believe, that the use of force and the tragic loss of life was wrong."

Clinton also proposed that Jiang engage in direct dialogue with Tibet's spiritual leader, the Dalai Lama, a proposal that was perhaps as unwelcome to Jiang as Clinton's words on the Tiananmen Square massacre, Sheridan commented.

That the exchange took place in public and was broadcast on mainland Chinese television "is a win for both leaders. It has allowed Clinton to achieve the inestimable double for being true to America's profound commitment to human rights, while at the same time pursuing a constructive, calm, business-like relationship with China," Sheridan wrote.

In an editorial Monday, the paper commented, "Tiananmen Square again has become the focus of international attention -- this time for promoting the prospect of real harmony between two very powerful nations that are vital for Australia's long-term interests."
Calling the debate over Tiananmen Square unprecedented, the editorial welcomed it as an important development in bilateral relations between Washington and Beijing.

DOC.HEADLINE: ORGANIZERS TO SELL 300,000 EXTRA TICKETS TO OFFSET OLYMPIC COSTS

TEXT.P: Organizers of the Olympic Games in Sydney have decided to sell 300,000 extra tickets at higher prices than normal to help offset a US$100 million increase in the cost of staging the 2000 Games.
The Sydney Organising Committee of Olympic Games (SOCOG) confirmed Sunday that its expenditures would rise to about A$2.6 (US$1.6) billion, despite a range of savings programs.
SOCOG chief executive Sandy Hollway said an extra 300,000 tickets would be sold. He did not give details.
The Sydney Olympic Games will be staged in September 2000 with more than 10,000 athletes from more than 100 countries taking part.

DOC.HEADLINE: HANSON CALLS FOR ZERO IMMIGRATION GROWTH, ENGLISH PROFICIENCY TESTS

TEXT.P: The leader of Australia's One Nation Party said she wanted Australia to substantially reduce immigration to zero-growth levels because she does not want to see the country "Asianised."

In a TV program Sunday, One Nation leader Pauline Hanson said that if her party scores a victory in the upcoming federal elections similar to the one it enjoyed in recent state elections in Queensland, she would introduce policies to curb immigration and demand the government test potential immigrants' English proficiency.
"I think there should be a test on English. I think everyone should have some knowledge of the English language," she said.
But both the federal government under Prime Minister John Howard and the opposition under Kim Beazley slammed Hanson's policies as divisive and unworkable.

"These prepositions are absurd in the least," said Immigration Minister Philip Ruddock. "This would deny ordinary Australians the right to marry people who did not speak English, and would not allow Australians to bring their own children into Australia if they didn't speak English," he added.
He said about 26,000 of the 80,000 people who migrate to Australia each year are spouses or life partners whom Australians met overseas or are dependent children of Australians.

About 30,000 to 40,000 Australians go abroad to work each year, and Hanson said she agreed to allowing the same number of migrants into Australia to fill the loophole, thus halving Australia's current quota of about 80,000 immigrants.
Hanson said the Racial Discrimination Act should be repealed on the grounds that it discriminates against white Anglo-Saxons and prevents criticism of non-whites.
Her One Nation Party won 11 seats in Queensland's legislature.

DOC.HEADLINE: LEE WARNS SINGAPOREANS NOT TO SAVE THEMSELVES INTO RECESSION

TEXT.P: Singaporeans should not reduce spending so much that the economy further contracts, said Singapore Senior Minister Lee Kuan Yew on Sunday.
"Our consumers should not become over-pessimistic and over-save, as in Japan. Otherwise, we will have a recession through our pessimism," he cautioned.
Lee made the remarks in a speech at a fund-raiser on Sunday marking the first anniversary of his constituency's community development council.

Recent statistics bear out Lee's warnings on consumer spending: an April report showed 60 percent of Singaporeans were spending less on entertainment, clothes and shoes, while more than half were eating out less often.

In his speech, Lee also said the government would take steps to cut business costs and help businesses obtain credit to tide them over the current economic downturn. Local companies are finding it difficult to obtain loans because foreign banks are tightening credit lines under orders from their head offices, Lee said.

Local banks, meanwhile, are nervous about lending money to companies with negative cash flows, he added. The government will discuss the problem with banks and will enact programs similar to one that has offered loans at preferential rates to smaller businesses, he said.

Discussing Singapore's economic picture for this year, Lee said that while preliminary figures showed positive growth in the second quarter, the figures appear to be moving downward. Singapore will likely avoid negative growth this year, although the region's slowdown will extend into 1998 and even 1999, he said.
Lee said Asia's economic turmoil is no longer confined to East Asia and has spread to regions such as Japan.

Japan's recession risks affecting the United States and Europe as well. "Singapore and the region will not fully recover until Japan recovers," he said. "Nobody at present can say with confidence when that will be."

DOC.HEADLINE: NSW'S ONLY HIGH-PROFILE MP OF CHINESE DESCENT QUITS LIBERAL PARTY

TEXT.P: Helen Sham-Ho, the only high-profile member of the New South Wales Parliament of Chinese descent, announced on Monday that she has left Prime Minister John Howard's Liberal Party.

Sham-Ho said her departure is due partly to Howard's weakness in dealing with the One Nation Party and its leader, Pauline Hanson. In particular, Sham-Ho expressed disappointment in Howard for not speaking out against Hanson for a speech she delivered in the federal parliament in 1996.
The speech contained remarks regarded as anti-Asian immigration and anti-Aboriginal people.
Sham-Ho has been a Liberal Party member for 11 years and has been a member of the NSW Legislative Council for 10 years, according to her spokesperson.
Sham-Ho did not mention during the press conference whether she would join another party. But the spokesperson told CNA that Sham-Ho would compete as an independent in the next NSW state election.
The Liberal Party, which along with the National Party, forms Australia's coalition government, has lost two high-profile party members of Chinese descent in the past 10 days.

Last week Peter Wong, former chairman of the Federation of Chinese Communities in NSW and director of the herbal medicine department at the University of Sydney, quit the party because it had not condemned Hanson and her One Nation Party.
Wong migrated to Australia from Indonesia and has lived in Sydney for more than 35 years.
The One Nation Party captured 11 seats in recent state legislative elections in Queensland and has seen a groundswell of support in the run-up to federal elections, scheduled for later this summer.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC PLEASED CLINTON REAFFIRMS SECURITY COMMITMENT: MOFA

TEXT.P: The Republic of China is delighted that US President Bill Clinton has reaffirmed US security commitments to Taiwan, Foreign Ministry spokesman Roy Wu said on Monday.
Wu was responding to Clinton's remarks made during a question-and-answer session with students following a speech at Beijing University Monday morning.

Clinton said the US stance on relations across the Taiwan Strait is based on the "one China" policy embodied in its three joint communiques with Beijing, as well as in the Taiwan Relations Act of 1979. That act requires the United States to furnish Taiwan with defensive weapons to ensure its security.
"We are pleased to see Clinton again clearly mention the US obligation to provide us with defensive weapons, in line with the Taiwan Relations Act, to help beef up our defense capability," Wu said.
Clinton's remarks are the second time he has reaffirmed US security commitments to Taiwan since arriving in mainland China last Thursday for a nine-day state visit.
In a press conference following his summit meeting with mainland President Jiang Zemin last weekend, Clinton made similar remarks on the issue.

Wu urged mainland Chinese leaders to take note of Clinton's reiterations of US security commitments to Taiwan and the United States' stance that the two sides of the Taiwan Strait should resolve their dispute through strictly peaceful means.
"We also earnestly hope that mainland leaders will understand that our basic policy and stance is consistent with America's," Wu added.
In his off-the-cuff response to a Beijing University student, Clinton said the US policy toward Taiwan is not an obstacle to the peaceful reunification of mainland China and Taiwan.
"Our policy is that weapons sales to Taiwan are for defensive purposes only. We are in no way trying to undermine our one China policy," Clinton explained.

He further said the United States has consistently encouraged the two sides of the Taiwan Strait to engage in peaceful dialogue to resolve their problems and that cross-strait reunification should be achieved strictly by peaceful means.

DOC.HEADLINE: VIRAL DEATH TOLL REACHES 54

TEXT.P: As of Monday, 262 people have been hospitalized for enterovirus infections, and of them 54 have died, according to sources from the Department of Health.

The two most recent deaths were those of a 2-year-old boy who died at Taipei's Sun Yat-sen Memorial Hospital on June 24, only 10 days after he was diagnosed as being infected with the virus, and a 9-month-old girl who died the same day at Taichung's Veterans General Hospital.

The girl had lived two months after being diagnosed as having the virus, the longest period of time anyone in Taiwan has lived after being infected, said Hsu Hsu-mei, deputy director of the DOH's Communicable Disease Control Bureau.
To more effectively treat the disease, Hsu suggested doctors check patients' brains with the aid of the magnetic resonance imaging.
Previous autopsies have shown victim's brain stems had fatal lesions, whereas doctors originally thought the children had died from edema pulmonary, meningitis or encephalitis.
Some doctors have been able to save the lives of patients infected with the virus by curing the lesions on their brain stems.

Although the DOH has said the epidemic has already peaked in Taiwan, the number of suspected infections totaled more than 1,000 islandwide as of Monday. The virus first began ravaging children on the island in mid-February.
The DOH initiated an islandwide "hand-washing" campaign on Monday, urging the public, especially children, to wash hands more frequently and more thoroughly to help stop the spread of the epidemic.

DOC.HEADLINE: TASK FORCE READY TO REVIEW ALLEGED SEXUAL ASSAULT CLAIM

TEXT.P: A task force established to investigate a sexual assault charge against Cheng Chuan, acting director of the Investigation Bureau, is ready to review information in the case, the convenor of the investigation said Monday.
Vice Minister of Justice Chiang Hao made the remarks after a three-member team returned from a fact-finding trip to Paris on Sunday.

Cheng has been accused of sexually assaulting Yang Yu-cheng in a Paris hotel room in 1996. He has denied any wrongdoing in the case, saying that he was performing the traditional Chinese physical therapy "Chihkung" on the young woman.
Investigators will question Cheng regarding some issues that arose from information gathered by the task force, Chiang said.

The task force has initially reported to have met with Yang at a Paris hospital where she is being treated for mental stress stemming from the alleged incident. However, only Li Tsui-lien, the team's sole female investigator interviewed Yang.
Li made notes but did not record her conversation with Yang, who appeared to be mentally competent when answering questions, Chiang was told.
Investigators will continue to try and obtain a copy of Yang's complaint to the French police and the hospital's diagnosis of Yang's mental state through the ROC representative office in Paris.

The task force will now carefully sift through the related information and scrutinize every detail and the timing of the alleged incident, Chiang said. He added that he could not predict when the task force would be able to give a formal report on the case.

Meanwhile, Cheng has declined to speak with the media about the matter other than to say he would cooperate fully with the investigation. He again apologized to the staff of the Investigation Bureau for tarnishing the reputation of the bureau with this personal matter.

DOC.HEADLINE: US TO CONSIDER LEE'S VISA ISSUE ON CASE-BY-CASE BASIS: BERGER
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, June 28 (CNA) (By Nelson Chung and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: The United States will consider ROC President Lee Teng-hui's visa applications on a case-by-case basis, a senior official said Sunday.

White House National Security Adviser Sandy Berger, who is currently accompanying US President Bill Clinton on a high-profile state visit to mainland China, made the statement during a live broadcast interview with CNN.

Asked whether the US government would grant President Lee a visa if Cornell University were to invite him to give another speech in Ithaca, New York, Berger said, "We make those decisions on a case-by-case basis."

Berger went on to say the United States made a decision back in the Nixon administration to have a one-China policy -- and then carried it forward through a bipartisan administration for the past 25 years.

"That is to recognize the government of China as the overall government. And that means we don't have a one China/one Taiwan policy. But, we have a good relationship with the people on Taiwan," Berger said.

He also expressed the US hope that the Taiwanese and Chinese resolve their differences peacefully. "We think that a cross-strait dialogue, which is perhaps about to begin again, is the best way to do that."

Asked if the United States will continue to sell advanced warplanes to Taiwan, Berger said Washington will follow the Taiwan Relations Act as well as the three joint communiques with Beijing, which govern the US' defense supply relationship with Taiwan. The US agreed to sell 150 F-16 jetfighters to Taiwan in 1992, and at least 60 of the advanced warplanes have been delivered to Taiwan.

President Lee delivered a speech at a Cornell University alumni reunion during his visit to the United States in June 1995. The visit angered Beijing authorities as they viewed the trip as a veiled move to promote Taiwan independence. In retaliation, Beijing conducted a series of missile tests and live-fire war games in waters near Taiwan between mid-1995 and March 1996, and unilaterally broke off regular cross-strait dialogue.
Beijing's show of force prompted the Clinton administration to send two aircraft carrier battle groups to help stabilize the situation in Taiwan Strait.

DOC.HEADLINE: CLINTON STRESSES PARTNERSHIP WITH MAINLAND IN SPEECH
DOC.DATELINE: Beijing, June 29 (CNA) (By Wang Hsin-chung & Eva Chen)

TEXT.P: US President Bill Clinton, in a speech to students Monday at Beijing University, stressed the importance of a US partnership with mainland China.
During his 30-minute speech, which was broadcast live on mainland Chinese state television, Clinton pointed out that Washington wants to build a new relationship with Beijing.
"America wants to build a new relationship with you for a new century. We want China to be successful, secure and open," he said.

He also mentioned the necessity of cooperation with Beijing on the nonproliferation of nuclear and chemical weapons. Mainland China and the US are pursuing a joint strategy to ease tensions on the Indian sub-continent, Clinton said.
The US president departed from the text of his speech to make a personal plea for students to help save the environment.

However, human rights was the overriding theme of Clinton's speech at Beijing University, the cradle of the 1989 pro-democracy movement. He cited the declaration of the United Nations to show the importance of human rights. He said freedom is universal and "indivisible" from economic prosperity.
"Economic security is an essential element of freedom," said Clinton, adding that "true freedom must mean more than economic opportunity. In America we believe that freedom itself is indivisible."

Clinton praised the mainland for not devaluing the Chinese currency. He said when the financial turmoil hit Asian countries such as Indonesia and South Korea, it was no longer an isolated problem within one or two individual countries, but an issue for Asia as a whole. He expressed his hope to cooperate with Beijing in stabilizing Asian financial situation.

There are some both in the US and the mainland who have doubts as to whether engagement between Washington and Beijing is rational and beneficial to both sides, Clinton said. In view of the tendency of world events and challenges faced by this generation, cooperation between Washington and Beijing would be much better than alienation and isolation, he concluded.
The president also presented a collection of books to the university library's American Studies Reference Collection after his keynote speech and a question-and-answer session on Monday.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC HAPPY TO SEE IMPROVED BEIJING-WASHINGTON TIES
DOC.DATELINE: Paris, June 29 (CNA) (By M. J. Tzou and Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: The Republic of China is happy to see the United States improve its relations with mainland China, but only if it does not affect the interests of Taiwan, an ROC government spokesman said over the weekend.
Chen Chien-jen, director-general of the Government Information Office (GIO), made the remarks in an interview with the Paris-based Asia Magazine.
Chen said the ROC hopes Clinton's trip to the mainland will help resolve their differences and boost the mainland's sense of responsibility in Asia and world peace.
He also said improved ties between Beijing and Washington will help people on the mainland get to know a system of freedom, democracy, and prosperity, so they can compare it with their system.
Asked about the effects of the Hong Kong handover on Taiwan, Chen said the status of Hong Kong and Taiwan are completely different.

Noting that Hong Kong is a former British colony without a constitution, sovereignty, and defense capabilities, he said it has implemented a weak democratic system and press freedoms are deteriorating.
These point to the "deficiency" of the one country, two systems, Chen said.

In contrast, Taiwan has enjoyed full-fledged press freedoms rivaling that of the west. Taiwan has more than 370 papers, nearly 5,000 magazines, 74 broadcasting stations and more than 20 TV stations, he added.

On the issue of cross-Taiwan Strait relations, Chen said the policy of the Kuomintang has been to promote unification gradually, while the opposition Democratic Progressive Party advocates Taiwan independence, and New Party hopes for early unification, and the Taiwan Independence party hopes for early independence.
Chen said 85 percent of people in Taiwan hope to maintain the status quo, while those who advocate early unification or independence are minimal.

He also said although the DPP won in the year-end mayoral and magistrate elections last year, it does not necessarily reflect the independence aspirations of voters as they were local elections. The legislative and mayoral elections coming up in December are more important.

On economic relations with the mainland, Chen said the ROC government will not stop Taiwan businessmen from investing in the mainland as long as such investment does not affect the economic development and security of Taiwan.

As both sides of the Taiwan Strait have yet to establish an investment guarantee agreement, he said the ROC government will continue to restrict the categories and amount of Taiwan investment permitted in the mainland.

Regulations regarding Taiwan's small- and medium-sized enterprises that want to invest US$50 million in mainland China will remain unchanged so those in the mainland can share Taiwan's development experience, Chen added.

DOC.HEADLINE: HIGH-LEVEL MAINLAND CHINESE CULTURAL DELEGATION ON VISIT

TEXT.P: A high-profile cultural delegation from mainland China arrived in Taipei Sunday for a 10-day visit as a part of Taiwan's efforts to bridge the cultural and academic gap across the strait.
It is the highest-level visit to Taiwan by cultural officials from the central and local governments from the mainland.

The 12-member delegation is headed by Liu Deyou, former vice minister of culture and chairman of the Chinese Culture Association (CCA). The CCA is a key mainland organization that has extended invitations to Taiwan cultural and academic leaders to visit mainland China.

Other delegates include Yin Zhiliang, director of the Ministry of Culture's Department of Hong Kong, Macao and Taiwan Affairs; Qu Ruenhai, vice president of the Institute of Chinese Arts and former director of the Art Bureau under the Ministry of Culture; and directors or deputy directors of cultural departments from the provincial governments of Jiangsu, Zhejiang, Fujian and Shaanxi and the Beijing municipality.
During their stay, the mainland officials are expected to attend a seminar on cross-strait cultural exchanges to be held at the Taipei International Convention Center on Tuesday.
They are also scheduled to visit the National Palace Museum, the National Museum of History, several art institutes and major government-run cultural centers around the island.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN STOCK MARKET SAID WORTHWHILE INVESTMENT

TEXT.P: Foreign investors should increase their investment in Taiwan's stock market as the "greater China" economies have performed better than other Asian countries amid the financial crisis, an industry expert said.

John S. Wadsworth Jr. an executive in charge of Far Eastern operations with the Morgan Stanley Dean Witter, a world leading investment bank, made the remarks to reporters after a meeting with Economic Affairs Minister Wang Chih-kang.
Wadsworth met with Wang on behalf of Morgan Stanley President Philip Purcell, who is sidelined from long-distance travel due to poor health.

Wadsworth praised the ROC's handling of the crisis, including the Central Bank of China, and suggested that foreign investors increase their shares in the Taiwan stock market to 5 percent as prices have fallen below reasonable levels.
Foreign capital accounts for 3 percent currently in the local bourse.
Taiwan's electronics sector is very competitive but also highly risky, Wadsworth said, adding that a weaker yen will keep stronger pressure on the electronics sectors of Taiwan and South Korea.

The yen may continue to fluctuate, and changes in the value of the yen will play a crucial role in the overall economic situation in Asia, he said. This is particularly true after the recent guarantee by mainland Chinese Premier Zhu Rongji to US Treasury Secretary Robert Rubin that the renminbi will not be devaluated.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAC REITERATES OPPOSITION TO 'ONE COUNTRY, TWO SYSTEMS' SCHEME

TEXT.P: The Cabinet-level Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) reiterated on Monday that the "one country, two systems" scheme imposed by Beijing on Hong Kong is not applicable to Taiwan.
The council issued the statement two days before the first anniversary of the British handover of Hong Kong rule to mainland China.
Although Beijing managed to use the 'one country, two systems' formula to take over Hong Kong on July 1, 1997, the MAC said the Republic of China on Taiwan can never accept such a format.
First and foremost, the council said, the format offers no guarantee that Taiwan will permanently be able to retain its current free, democratic and prosperous way of life.
The MAC further pointed out that Beijing's "one country, two systems" proposal is a contradictory, transitional and suppressive scheme aimed at annexing Taiwan into its one-party dictatorship.
The council also cited several fundamental differences between Taiwan and Hong Kong. First, the ROC is an independent sovereign state, while Hong Kong was a British colony.
Second, the ROC has diplomatic ties and its own self-defense force. In contrast, Hong Kong did not have either of these two critical characteristics of a sovereign state, the council said.

Moreover, the council said, since the ROC is now a full-fledged democracy, its future should be determined by its people, while Hong Kong residents had no right to determine their own future through elections to begin with.
Last but not least, it said, the handover had been decided long ago as a part of a lease agreement, but there is no timetable for the reunification of Taiwan and mainland China.
Noting that Taiwan and mainland China are now ruled by two separate but equal political entities, the MAC said Beijing should drop its communist system and opt for a "good system."
The "good system" refers to freedom, democracy and equitable distribution of wealth, the MAC explained.

"We look forward to seeing this good system implemented in mainland China as early as possible. By then, Taiwan, Hong Kong, Macau and mainland China can be unified under this 'one country, one good system' formula," the MAC said in its press statement.
To facilitate its takeover of Hong Kong, Beijing has promised to retain Hong Kong's capitalist system and way of life for 50 years.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN BOURSE PLUNGES

TEXT.P: Concern about the grim prospects in Taiwan's semi-conductor industry and the sell-off of mutual funds drove stock prices down Monday.
The Taiwan Stock Exchange's weighted index, the main barometer of the market, gave off 146. 23 points to close at 7,535.73.
A total of 2.19 million shares changed hands with a turnover of NT$99.75 billion (US$2.93 billion).
Losers overwhelmed gainers 352 to 96, with 43 remained unchanged.

All of the eight listed categories lost ground with cement stocks trimmed by 0.4 percent, foodstuff issues 0.5 percent, plastic stocks 1.0 percent, textile and fiber issues 2.1 percent, electronic engineering stocks 4.2 percent, paper and pulp issues 0.5 percent, construction shares 2.4 percent, and financial stocks 0.1 percent.

DOC.HEADLINE: WOMAN ARRESTED FOR SMUGGLING 'ECSTASY'

TEXT.P: A woman was arrested Sunday night for trying to smuggle the drug ecstasy into Taiwan, the National Police Administration (NPA) said Monday.
NPA officials said Han Ching-ching, 48, was returning from Holland on a Cathay Pacific flight when she was found to have in her possession unidentified pills in wine and hair spray containers.

After an analysis, police confirmed that the drugs were MDMA, also known among Taiwan locals as "rape pills" after some rapists spiked their victims' drinks with the drug to make them more susceptible to their advances.
Han admitted under initial questioning that she was commissioned by a couple named Hsu Chun-fa and Chen Juei-chu to smuggle nearly 6,000 pills at US$1 apiece.
Police arrested the couple who were living in Yungho, Taipei County. The three have been turned over to the Prosecutor Office for violating drug regulations.

DOC.HEADLINE: COMMUNISM HAS NO FUTURE: LIEN

TEXT.P: Vice President Lien Chan on Monday told visiting Guatemalan Foreign Minister Eduardo Stein Barillas that communism has no future and time stands on Taiwan's side.

Lien said the rivalry between Taiwan and mainland China is a contest between a democratic system and an authoritarian system. He added that people on both sides of the Taiwan Strait should have the right to choose which system they want.
He said the Republic of China would like to share its economic and democratic achievements with its allies to pursue prosperity and development together.

The vice president also expressed gratitude for the support Guatemala extended to the ROC in its bid to enter international organizations. Lien said he hopes the two countries continue their cooperative projects and establish closer relations.

Barillas, on behalf of his government, thanked the ROC for its assistance in helping Guatemala's development in various fields. He also reaffirmed his country's commitment to supporting the island's bid to increase its international presence.

DOC.HEADLINE: HONG KONG GRADUALLY BEING 'MAINLANDIZED': MAC

TEXT.P: Hong Kong has gradually been "mainlandized" since it reverted to Beijing's rule last July, a senior mainland affairs official said on Monday.
Lin Chong-pin, vice chairman of the Cabinet-level Mainland Affairs Council, made the remarks in a report on Hong Kong's post-handover developments over the past year.
Lin said Hong Kong has maintained close interaction with mainland China since its handover. "As a result, the former British colony has been gradually 'mainlandized,'" he stated.

The mainland policy planner also pointed out that although major countries such as the United States and Japan have generally recognized the territory's smooth handover, they have taken note of a potential threat to Hong Kong's freedom and legal system.

Since the territory reverted to Beijing's rule under a "one country, two systems" scheme, Lin said the people of Hong Kong have become increasingly dissatisfied with the performance of their government.

"While the Hong Kong Special Administrative Region government has functioned generally smoothly, its operational efficiency has declined as compared with previous levels, particularly in its crisis handling," Lin said.

He also cited public opinion polls conducted by Hong Kong Chinese University as showing that the approval rating of Tung Chee-hwa, Hong Kong's chief executive, declined from 63.34 percent in February to an all-time low of 56.2 percent.
Generally speaking, Lin said Hong Kong's post-handover politics has proceeded within the framework set forth in the Basic Law and its operations have gone more smoothly than many had expected.
"While the Hong Kong government has followed Beijing's guidelines in handling political affairs, mainland authorities have not explicitly interfered with Hong Kong's internal affairs," Lin said.

Nevertheless, Lin said Hong Kong people have become increasingly discontent over the slow progress in democratic development, the increasingly worsening financial woes and structural problems within Hong Kong.

Lin also said although Hong Kong's press freedoms have generally been maintained, mainland Chinese forces have gradually entered Hong Kong media organizations and self-censorship among Hong Kong media has become more common.

Touching on Hong Kong-Taiwan relations, Lin said, bilateral civilian exchanges have remained almost the same. Nevertheless, he said, official exchanges remain limited because stringent restrictions imposed by the Hong Kong government.

DOC.HEADLINE: ASIAN FINANCIAL STORM SEEN AFFECTING SINGAPORE BANKRUPTCIES

TEXT.P: A total of 725 Singaporeans went bankrupt between January and May this year, a 9 percent increase over the same period of last year, according to the latest figures from Singapore's Official Assignee (OA) under the Ministry of Law.
Meanwhile, a total of 107 companies were wound up in court, up 9 percent from last year and a third more than in 1996, according to Singapore's Official Receiver.
A total of 12,356 people are legally bankrupt in Singapore at present, said the OA, which handles personal bankruptcies.
When compared to the 384 new bankruptcies for the January to May period of 1996, when the regional financial turmoil had yet to engulf Asia, the increase is a striking 90 percent.

Of the 107 companies wound up, thirty were in the commercial sector, while 23 were in the construction sector, a significant figure as there were no construction companies liquidated during the five-month period for either 1996 or 1997.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN'S WTO BID INDEPENDENT OF MAINLAND CHINA'S: US OFFICIAL
DOC.DATELINE: Beijing, June 29 (CNA) (By C.H. Wang & Lin Wen-fen)

TEXT.P: A visiting high-ranking US official said on Monday that Taiwan's bid to enter the World Trade Organization (WTO) will not be linked to that of mainland China.

US Secretary of Commerce William M. Daley said that there is no timetable for the mainland's accession into the international trade regulatory body, and that only after it obtains WTO membership can the mainland be granted permanent most-favored nation status by the US.

Asked if Taiwan's bid to join the WTO will be delayed because the Clinton-Jiang summit did not produce any new agreements on Beijing's WTO progress, Daley replied that Taiwan's entry and Beijing's entry are two different issues and that Taiwan's WTO progress will not be affected by the summit results.
Daley said that trade negotiations on terms for Beijing's WTO entry are progressing, but stressed that many trade and economic differences remain between the two sides which need to be ironed out.
He stressed that Beijing will have to further open its markets to US enterprises, saying that this will create a "win-win" situation for both the US and the mainland.

DOC.HEADLINE: GERMAN PAPER COMMENTS ON LIVE CLINTON-JIANG BROADCAST

TEXT.P: The German daily "Die Welt" said on Monday that mainland China's President Jiang Zemin achieved two purposes by allowing a live broadcast of the joint press conference which followed his summit meeting with US President Bill Clinton.

"Die Welt" correspondent Johnny Erling said that Jiang on the one hand wanted to help relieve Clinton from US pressure due to his participation in the official greeting ceremony in Tiananmen Square; and on the other, Jiang is expecting a change in his own country.

Erling also said, however, that Jiang's move was not well-tolerated by the party, and that the live broadcast has not been replayed. The party has also forbidden the official mainland press from discussing or commenting on the statements, he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT LEE CALLS FOR OVERALL REVIEW OF CLINTON-JIANG SUMMIT

TEXT.P: President Lee Teng-hui has ordered the Ministry of Foreign Affairs to conduct an overall review of the possible impact of a summit meeting between Washington and Beijing, a senior official said on Monday.

Foreign Minister Jason Hu told a press conference that Lee gave the directive after hearing his briefing on the talks between US President Bill Clinton and his mainland Chinese counterpart, Jiang Zemin, in Beijing last Saturday.

Hu quoted Lee as directing that the Foreign Ministry should continue keeping close watch on the possible impact of Clinton's current mainland visit on relations between Taipei and Washington as well as on Taiwan's security and future development.

"In addition, the president wants us to evaluate the impact of the Clinton-Jiang summit in three dimensions: prospects of human rights and democracy, regional peace and stability, and interaction across the Taiwan Strait," Hu said.

He added that the ministry's North American Affairs Department and an interministerial task force formed earlier this month to tackle with the possible impact of the Clinton-Jiang summit will carefully study all related issues in accordance with Lee's instruction.

Meanwhile, Hu also briefed Premier Vincent Siew on the Clinton-Jiang summit. "The premier has demanded the ministry to furnish him with an in-depth comprehensive report on the event's possible impact on our relations with the United States and on our country's overall pragmatic diplomacy after the US briefs us on Clinton's current mainland visit."

As Siew will be on a South Pacific visit when the US envoy comes to brief ROC officials, Hu said the premier has asked the Foreign Ministry to try to let the US better understand Taipei's stance and action guidelines in addition to listening to US views and positions.

Hu quoted Siew as saying that the US is not expected to sacrifice or undermine Taiwan's interests in its engagement with mainland China because such moves are not in the US interests and would hinder regional peace and development.
Commenting on Clinton's speeches in mainland China in the past few days, Hu said Clinton has so far not deviated from basic US policy toward Taiwan.

"Nevertheless, we must remain cautious and vigilant as mainland China still wants to take advantage of Clinton's current visit to pressure the US to make concessions or compromise on Taiwan-related issues," Hu explained.

To his knowledge, Hu said, the US didn't intend to talk much with mainland China concerning cross-strait issues. "It is Beijing that has always taken the initiative to discuss Taiwan-related issues," he added.
Clinton arrived in mainland China last Thursday for a nine-day state visit.

DOC.HEADLINE: GREENBACK DIPS ON TAIWAN FOREX

TEXT.P: The US dollar dipped by NT$0.001 on the Taiwan foreign exchange market on Monday, to close at NT$34.551.
A total of US$299.5 million dollars was traded during the day's session.
The greenback opened at NT$34.451, and fluctuated between NT$34.451 and NT$34.646.

DOC.HEADLINE: AUSTRALIA'S LIBERAL PARTY SHOCKED BY MP'S RESIGNATION

TEXT.P: The Liberal Party of the Australian state of New South Wales is stunned by the sudden resignation of Liberal Member of Parliament Helen Sham-Ho, a veteran MP of Chinese descent.
Ho had intended to compete for the speakership of the NSW Legislative Council, but failed to obtain support from her party because it feared offending the One Nation party.
One Nation and its leader, Pauline Hanson, are known for their anti-Asian, anti-multiculturalism, anti-Aborigine and anti-foreign investment stance.
Saying she was disappointed by her party's rejection, Ho on Monday made a sudden announcement of her resignation.
She said another factor behind her decision to quit the Liberal Party was her disappointment at the weak leadership of Liberal Prime Minister John Howard in his dealings with One Nation.
At a press conference in Sydney, Ho, who migrated to Australia from Hong Kong, said she was disappointed by Howard's failure to take a strong stand against Hanson.
The Liberal Party, which governs Australia in a coalition with the National Party, has now lost two high-profile members of Chinese descent within 10 days.

Last week, Peter Wong, former chairman of the Federation of Chinese Communities in NSW, and director of the Herbal Medicine Department at the University of Sydney, announced his resignation from the party because the party under Howard did not condemn One Nation, resulting in racial tension between the Asian community and One Nation supporters.

Ho had been a Liberal Party member for 11 years and a member of the NSW Legislative Council for 10 years, according to her spokesperson, who told the CNA that Ho will contest the next NSW state election, expected in 1999, as an independent.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT CONFIDENT ON TAIWAN-US RELATIONS

TEXT.P: A high-ranking ruling Kuomintang (KMT) official said on Monday that he feels relations between Taiwan and the US will not be affected much by the just-concluded Clinton-Jiang summit.

KMT Secretary-General John Chang said the people of Taiwan should not worry too much about the possible effect of the summit on Taiwan, adding that as an independent sovereign state, the Republic of China will defend its existence.

Meanwhile, Huang Li-ching, director of the KMT's Cultural Affairs Department, said that although Beijing is expected to increase its pressure on Taiwan for direct trade links and political talks in the wake of the summit, the government and ruling party are confident of tackling this challenge.
She said that in addition to this external pressure, Taiwan is also facing internal pressure as a result of differences of opinion among the island's various political parties and factions.
Huang called on Taiwan's parties to forsake these differences and work for the national interest of Taiwan's 21 million residents.

She also quoted a report compiled by her department which said the fact that US President Bill Clinton did not mention the so-called "three noes" policy toward Taiwan during the joint press conference at the end of the meeting signifies that the US is keeping its promise not to sacrifice Taiwan's interests for enhanced US-mainland ties.
However, the report also said that despite their differences on human rights and other issues, Washington and Beijing are expected to engage in a closer, more constructive relationship.

At one point during the joint press conference, Jiang referred to Taiwan as being part of mainland China, which the report described as a signal that Beijing has not given up its attempts to downgrade the ROC's status to that of a local government.

DOC.HEADLINE: JAPAN DESCRIBES CLINTON-JIANG SUMMIT AS `POSITIVE'

TEXT.P: Japan's Chief Cabinet Secretary Kanezo Muraoka on Monday said his government is happy with the results of the Clinton-Jiang summit talks which took place on June 27.
Speaking at a regular press conference in Tokyo, the spokesman for the Japanese government termed the summit "positive, constructive and productive."
"To ensure sound and stable relationships among Japan, the US, and China is very important for the stability and prosperity of the whole Asia-Pacific region," Muraoka said.
Some Japanese people have expressed worry that the US efforts to enhance bilateral relations with mainland China might affect the importance of the US-Japanese alliance.

In order to dispel these worries, US Secretary of State Madeleine Albright is scheduled to fly to Tokyo to brief Prime Minister Ryutaro Hashimoto on what Clinton discussed with Jiang and other mainland leaders in Beijing.
Clinton has also invited Hashimoto to visit Washington in the second half of July to exchange views on pressing regional and global economic and political issues.

Meanwhile, the Sankei Shimbun said in dispatch from Beijing on Monday that the US government will send Richard Bush, chairman of the American Institute in Taiwan, to Taipei early next month as a "special envoy."
The report said Bush will meet with President Lee Teng-hui and other high-ranking ROC leaders for briefings on the Clinton-Jiang summit.

DOC.HEADLINE: ALISHAN'S SACRED TREE RELEGATED TO HISTORY

TEXT.P: Alishan's "sacred tree," one of Taiwan's oldest landmarks, was relegated to the history books after being pulled down on Monday for safety reasons.
Some 200 spectators were on hand to witness the historic event as the 35-meter-high tree was sawn short and felled.
The red hinoki cypress, which was more than 3,000 years old and had a girth of 23 meters, died nearly 40 years ago after being hit twice by lightning.
Despite this, it had remained standing, and was one of Alishan's major attractions. People had even tried to revive it by inserting small cypress buds into its decaying trunk.
However, torrential rain last July undermined the tree's roots to such an extent that it tilted and partly collapsed, leaving what remained a potential danger to visitors.
After exhausting every method to preserve the tree, and after consulting various experts, the Taiwan Forestry Bureau was forced to make the unhappy decision to pull it down for safety's sake.

The tree, which was first recorded in 1906 when the island was ruled by the Japanese, was declared sacred because of its age and great height -- reported at the time to be 185 meters, according to sight measurements.

After the island reverted to the Republic of China in 1945, a more scientific measurement found it to be only 52 meters high and actually two cypress trees growing intertwined. A later survey ranked it the island's second-highest tree, although it was struck off the list of the top ten big trees earlier this year.

DOC.HEADLINE: US URGED TO LIVE UP TO ITS COMMITMENT TO TAIWAN SECURITY
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, June 30 (CNA) (By Jay Chen and Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: A legislator from the Republic of China urged the United States to live up to its commitment to Taipei so it would not have to resort to the development of nuclear weapons to deter a possible attack from mainland China.
Parris Chang, a legislator from the Democratic Progressive Party, made the comment in the latest issue of Defense News, a weekly magazine.
The chairman of the legislative Defense Committee said there are several reasons why Taiwan has not developed nuclear weapons, the most important is that the US is committed to Taiwan's security.

Chang noted that Beijing leaders have refused to renounce the use of force against Taiwan. The US could help preserve a nuclear-free Taiwan by living up to its commitment outlined in the Taiwan Relations Act through the support of a democratic and independent Taiwan free from Beijing's aggression and control.

In the article entitled "US holds key with Taiwan," Chang also said the recent tit-for-tat nuclear testing between India and Pakistan raised once again a similar debate in Taipei -- "should Taiwan go nuclear to deter an unpredictable and belligerent China."
The answer to that question is categorically "no," Chang said.

Chang said Taiwan has expertise and financial resources. If Taiwan were to perceive that there was no guarantee to its security or sense the US were selling out Taiwan in an effort to develop a strategic partnership with China, the motivation to go nuclear would be there, he added.
However, the people on Taiwan would never permit such a weapon of mass destruction to be used on their compatriots in the mainland, Chang said.

Moreover, if Taiwan were not able to strike first, it would not have second-strike capability after absorbing an initial attack due to its small size. It would therefore be irrational for Taiwan to acquire nuclear weapons as it would be a massive waste of resources, he added.
"Most importantly," Chang said, "the 1979 US-Taiwan Relation Act commits Washington to provide Taiwan with adequate defensive weapon to deter Chinese aggression."

"When Taiwan gave up its research and development of nuclear weapons 10 years ago under US pressure, it was with the tacit understanding that the United States would provide Taiwan with a protective nuclear umbrella," the lawmaker wrote.
Chang added "such US commitment has been the basis for Taiwan government policy not to develop nuclear weapons."

DOC.HEADLINE: SINGAPORE SCALES DOWN 1998 GROWTH RATE

TEXT.P: Singapore on Monday revised its official forecast for economic growth in 1998 from the 2.5 percent to 4.5 percent range to between 0.5 percent and 1.5 percent.

Finance Minister Hu Tsu Tau made the announcement in a parliamentary statement on Singapore's economic performance which included the government's off-budget measures aimed at cushioning Singapore's economy from the regional economic slowdown.

Although Singapore achieved 5.6 percent growth in the first quarter of this year, the finance minister said the growth rate for the second quarter is expected to fall to negative 0.5 percent to 2.4 percent. The growth rate may possibly dip into negative figures in the second half of the year, he added.
The off-budget measures include the following which are intended to help stabilize Singapore's property market:
1. Deferment of the Government Land Sales (GLS) Program;
2. Suspension of the 5 percent premium for extension of project completion period;
3. Allowing re-assignment of GLS parcels; and
4. Deferment of stamp duty payment for the purchase of uncompleted properties.

These measures have been chosen to help avoid exacerbating over supply in the property market and to facilitate an adjustment and consolidation of the market in this period of economic slowdown, the Singapore Ministry of National Development said Monday.
A stable and healthy property market is essential to maintaining market confidence and the proper functioning of the economy, it added.

DOC.HEADLINE: BEIJING URGED TO BUILD PEACE IN ASIA
DOC.DATELINE: Paris, June 29 (CNA) (By M. C. Tzou and Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: A ranking ROC government official said Monday that Taipei is delighted to see an improvement in Washington-Beijing ties and urged Washington to encourage Beijing to safeguard peace and security in Asia.

Chen Chien-jen, director general of the Government Information Office (GIO), made the remarks in interviews with a number of leading French newspapers, magazines and radio stations during his two-day stay here.
Chen, as the ROC government spokesman, hailed the remarks made by US President Bill Clinton who is currently visiting mainland China.

The spokesman said Clinton fully reflected how the United States values freedom, human rights and democracy in his speeches. Chen said Clinton's comments will go far to boost progress and development in the mainland.
The GIO director general also called on Washington to urge Beijing to take an active role in easing tensions brought about by India and Pakistan's nuclear weapons tests.

Referring to the question of whether Washington-Beijing engagement will affect Taipei-Washington or Taipei-Beijing ties, Chen said the impact of Clinton's trek to mainland China on cross-strait relations remains to be seen.

As Beijing has continued to be reluctant to renounce the use of force against Taiwan and end its efforts to block Taiwan in the international community, Chen said he does not believe Beijing will relax its stance toward Taiwan because of warming ties with the US.

Due to mainland China's constant military threat in the Taiwan Strait, the GIO head said Taiwan has to maintain sufficient defensive capabilities to ensure its security. He added that Taiwan is very willing to improve its ties with the mainland to the benefit of both sides of the Taiwan Strait.
If Beijing does not alter its hostile attitude toward Taiwan, it will affect peaceful cross-strait development and hinder the process of China's unification, he stressed.

Commenting on the mayoral elections for Taipei and Kaohsiung slated for the end of this year, Chen predicted both will be fierce contests. Latest surveys showed that candidates for the Kuomintang have an advantage over Democratic Progressive Party candidates.
"Democracy has come of age in Taiwan," Chen noted.
