DOC.HEADLINE: DOMESTIC OIL PRICES TO BE LOWERED BY 1.57%

TEXT.P: Starting Wednesday, domestic prices for various oil products will be lowered by an average of 1.57 percent, Chinese Petroleum Corp. (CPC) announced on Tuesday.
After the adjustment, the price for gasoline will drop to NT$18 (US$0.53) per liter from the current NT$18.2.
Prices for diesel and unleaded gasoline will also be cut by NT$0.2 per liter, while the price for fuel oil will be slashed by NT$95 per kiloliter.
The air pollution fee imposed on fuel oil consumers will also be removed beginning from Wednesday as the Environmental Protection Administration (EPA) has decided to cancel the measure.

The state-run oil company said the adjustment is mainly aimed at reflecting its declining crude oil import costs. The new pricing formula is based on two criteria: crude oil price at US$14 per barrel and the currency exchange rate at NT$34.4 against the US dollar.
"We have also taken into account our profit target for fiscal 1999, projected at NT$22.2 billion, in deciding the adjustment range," said a company spokesperson.

Crude oil prices have remained weak in the international market in recent months. The CPC spokesperson said the company may adjust its oil products prices again in tandem with international crude oil prices and the New Taiwan dollar's exchange rate.

"We have adopted a floating pricing system aimed at more effectively pegging domestic oil prices to the general international market trend," the spokesperson said, adding that under the new system, the company has conducted a weekly review of domestic oil prices since March.
After the adjustment, the domestic-use liquefied petroleum gas (LPG) price will be lowered to NT$10.88 per liter from NT$11.11, and vehicle-use LPG will fall to NT$10.6 from NT$10.8.
The new prices for 92-unleaded gas and 95-unleaded gas will stand at NT$16.8 and NT$17.8, respectively.
In response to the price cut announcement, state-run Taiwan Power Co. said it would not cut its power rates for the time being because the decrease in fuel costs is small.

The company said it will save an estimated NT$630 million in annual power generation cost because of the CPC's new oil price cut. This translates to a decrease of a marginal NT$0.005 in per kilowatt-hour power generation cost.

Meanwhile, the Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics said the oil price adjustment will help drive down the domestic consumer prices and wholesale prices by about 0.054 percent and 0.069 percent, respectively.

The directorate said although vegetable and fruit prices rose significantly in June due to inclement weather in several parts of the island, the consumer price index climbed less than 2 percent in the first half of this year.

Nevertheless, the directorate said, the effect of the oil price cut may be offset by typhoon-caused damage in the coming months. As a result, it added, the consumer price index may rise faster in the second half of the year than in the first half.

DOC.HEADLINE: HEROIN SMUGGLING RING BUSTED

TEXT.P: About 30 kilograms of heroin with a market value of NT$800 million (US$23.19 million) was seized in a drug raid in Taichung, central Taiwan, Investigation Bureau under the Ministry of Justice reported Tuesday.
It is the largest haul of illegal drugs seized this year. Police also arrested two key suspects Lo Chi-kuang, 44, and Chang Wan-jui, 39.
Police were tipped earlier that an international drug ring was planning to smuggle heroin produced in the golden triangle bordering Thailand and Burma into Taiwan.

The heroin was shipped to mainland China from the southwest border region and made its way to Guangzhou in southern China. The drugs were then hidden inside hollow construction bricks and delivered to Taiwan.
Lo and Chang asked a trading company to ship the bricks in 12 shipping containers to Taichung Harbor. The company was unaware of the drug smuggling operation.
Police arrested the two when they went to the trading company to claim the containers Monday afternoon.
During a 13-hour search, investigators were unable to find any drugs in the first 11 shipping containers. They eventually found the heroin in the last remaining container.

Investigators said in the past, drug smugglers have resorted to storing drugs inside picture frames and car parts. This was the first reported incident of drug smuggling through the shipment of construction bricks.

DOC.HEADLINE: VISITORS TO SOUTHEAST ASIAN COUNTRIES WARNED OF DENGUE FEVER

TEXT.P: Health officials on Tuesday warned the public to be on guard against dengue fever during visits to countries in Southeast Asia.

Hsu Hsu-mei, deputy director of the Department of Health's Bureau of Communicable Disease Control, said a dengue fever epidemic is currently sweeping Southeast Asia. In Indonesia alone, more than 30,000 cases have been reported with 777 fatalities.

Hsu said that so far this year 32 cases of dengue fever have been reported in Taiwan. All were contracted during visits to Southeast Asian countries, she said, adding that this year's figure is double that of the same period last year.
Of the 32 cases, nine originated in Indonesia, seven in the Philippines, six in Thailand, five in Malaysia, two in Burma, two in Cambodia and one in Vietnam.

So far no locally contracted dengue fever cases have been reported, but Hsu said that the public should be aware of the possibility of an epidemic in Taiwan as the weather becomes hotter and the rainfall is more abundant.

Hsu urged the public to eradicate the places in which the Ades mosquito -- the carrier of the sometimes-fatal disease -- breed, including discarded containers and tires. This is the most effective way of preventing an outbreak, she said.

DOC.HEADLINE: MANY AMERICANS FEEL THEY'RE BETTER OFF THAN BEFORE

TEXT.P: US crime rate is down and the economy is booming, and Americans are decidedly upbeat. According to recent polls, many believe they are better off today than in the good old days.
The economy looks great. The stock market is shrugging off the Asian flu. The crime rate is down. The price of oil is at a 25-year low. Most of the world is at peace.
So it should be no wonder that public opinion polls are finding Americans in an optimistic mood -- more confident about the future, by some measures, than at any time in 30 years.

This spring, public opinion surveys found that about 70 percent of Americans think the economy is not just good but getting better. More than half believe that the nation is heading in the right direction, compared with 28 percent who felt that way in 1996.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC PROTESTS CLINTON'S REMARKS

TEXT.P: The United States and mainland China are neither entitled nor in a position to negotiate issues concerning the Republic of China on Taiwan, a senior official said on Tuesday.

Foreign Ministry spokesman Roy Wu made the statement in response to reports that US President Bill Clinton mentioned the so-called "three noes" policy toward Taiwan at a roundtable meeting in Shanghai Tuesday morning.

The reports quoted Clinton as confirming at the closed-door meeting that he told mainland President Jiang Zemin during their summit meeting in Washington last October that the United States will not support independence for Taiwan, a "two Chinas" or "one China, one Taiwan" policy or Taiwan's membership in international organizations in which statehood is a requirement.

Commenting on the reports, Wu said Washington and Beijing lack legitimate power to negotiate any Taiwan-related issues. "The United States should refrain from doing so, because such moves will give mainland China and other countries misconceptions," he added.

Wu said the Republic of China has clearly outlined its national policy in the National Unification Guidelines. "Our government has also reiterated on many occasions that its goal to pursue national unification under a free, democratic system has remained unchanged."
The spokesman went on to say he sees no need for Clinton to repeat the so-called "three noes" at this moment. "I don't think Clinton's statement adds anything to the substance of the US policy."

Wu stressed that the Republic of China has no intention of interfering with Beijing-Washington relations. "We also hope the United States will discuss with the ROC, not mainland China, any issues related to Taiwan or relations between our two countries," he said. "Otherwise, relations across the Taiwan Strait mill be adversely affected and long-term US national interests will also be undermined."
Clinton arrived in Shanghai Monday evening. He has already visited Xian and Beijing and will later travel to Gueilin and Hong Kong before ending his nine-day visit on July 3.

DOC.HEADLINE: ASIAN MIGRANTS TO HELP BEAT ONE NATION IN COMING ELECTIONS

TEXT.P: Australian migrants from Asian countries are uniting in an effort to beat the One Nation Party in the next state and federal elections in the face of growing disarray in the Liberal and National Party coalition government.

Over 20 Asian community associations have offered to raise funds for any candidate willing to go up against One Nation candidates in coming state and federal elections, said Lee Fu-yuan, a leader of Melbourne's Chinese community.
The One Nation Party is divisive and anti-Asian, he told CNA, and many Chinese and Asian migrants do not want to see the party's influence spread to Melbourne and Victoria.

In Sydney and New South Wales (NSW), Chinese and Vietnamese community leaders have vowed not to support the Liberal and National Party candidates if they do not put One Nation candidates last on voting cards in the next elections.
In Brisbane, Queensland, there are over 50 Asian community associations, according to Associate Professor C.L. Chieou of the University of Queensland.
Most of Asian migrants are more than willing to help stop the influence of One Nation from spreading to the federal parliament, he said. (by Peter Chen)

DOC.HEADLINE: AUTHORITIES DESIGN MOST QUESTIONS RAISED BY BEIDA STUDENTS
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, June 29 (CNA) (By Herman Pan & Eva Chen)

TEXT.P: Five of the seven questions posed to US President Bill Clinton during a question-and-answer session at Beijing University were directed by school authorities, according to Monday's Washington Post.
The questions were put to Clinton after he delivered a speech at the university, commonly known as Beida.

University officials and students discussed and deliberated for an entire week which questions would be raised, according to an international studies graduate student at the university who was cited in the report.

Often referred to as the craddle of mainland China's pro-democracy movement, Beida today is populated by students who are more pragmatic and prudent than those who participated in demonstrations nine years ago, the paper said, adding that the students' sharp questions challenged Clinton's position on human rights.
Wang Yangmei, a Beida law student, told the Post that she thought it was good the students had the guts to raise the questions, which reflected most students' thoughts and beliefs.
Clinton is a great diplomat, she said. Although students were not completely satisfied with the president's replies, Clinton enabled students to understand his attitude, she said.
Fellow law student Wang Bin said Clinton is entitled to promote human rights, "but don't pin much hope on that ... we Chinese have our own problems based on current reality."
But Bian Xueqi, also a law student, said he believes Clinton's trip would contribute to better relations between Beijing and Washington.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN TRADE MISSION TOURS EUROPE

TEXT.P: A 21-member trade mission organized by the Taiwan Importers and Exporters Chamber of Commerce is on a two-week trade promotion tour of Germany, the Czech Republic, Slovenia, Hungary and Austria.
Group members include manufacturers of furniture, machinery, bicycle parts, chemical products, textiles and consumer goods.

Statistics compiled by the Taipei Trade Office in Frankfurt indicate that in 1996 two-way trade between the Republic of China and Germany amounted to US$8,668 million, of which ROC imports from Germany totaled US$5,024 million against US$3,644 million in exports. The Republic of China has had a trade deficit with Germany for the past several years.

The trade mission will leave Berlin for Prague on July 1. The group will meet with members of the Economic Chamber of the Czech Republic on July 2, and visit the Bratislava Trade Exhibition Center and engage in discussions with the Hungarian Chamber of Commerce and Industry on July 6. Two days later, members of the group will call on the Taiwan Trade Center in Vienna.

Among eastern European countries, Hungary and Czech Republic are growing markets for Taiwan products. Yet the Republic Of China's trade volume in the region remains relatively small. In 1996, ROC exports to Hungary amounted to US$172.6 million; to the Czech Republic, US$86.4 million; and to Slovenia, US$4.57 million.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC STILL HAS AMPLE DIPLOMATIC ROOM: OFFICIAL

TEXT.P: US President Bill Clinton's reiteration of the so-called "three noes" is not expected to significantly impact ROC national interests, a senior official said on Tuesday.

"The 'three noes' has long been an established US policy. Clinton's reiteration will only have limited impact on our interests," said Shen Lyu-shun, director of the Foreign Ministry's North American Affairs Department.
Even though Clinton has reaffirmed no US support for Taiwan's membership in the United Nations, Shen said, the ROC government will continue to seek international support and sympathy for its cause.

Noting that over the past six years, the Republic of China's bid to rejoin the United Nations has won much sympathy in the international community, Shen said, "We'll continue to promote our bid. Even if we can't realize our goal in the near future, it is a good strategy to help the international society understand our stance and win more support for our cause."

According to foreign wire service reports, Clinton said at a roundtable meeting in Shanghai on Tuesday morning that the United States does "not support independence for Taiwan, or two Chinas, or one Taiwan-one China." Clinton further said the United States does not believe Taiwan should be a member in any organization for which statehood is a requirement.
In response, Shen said the Republic Of China has endured the adverse impact of the policy ever since it was adopted by the United States.
"Even if Clinton's reiteration does afflict new harm to Taiwan, the impact will not be very great," Shen said at a public hearing on the possible impact of Clinton's current mainland China visit.
Shen said local people need not worry about the future of the Republic of China merely because Clinton reiterated his country's position.

So far Clinton's visit has not damaged Taiwan's interests, Shen said, adding that the ROC still has ample room to further develop US relations and will be able to maintain its pragmatic diplomacy strategy.

The Republic of China lost its UN seat when the world body admitted Beijing in 1971. Starting in 1993, ROC's diplomatic allies have consistently urged the UN General Assembly to study a feasible measure for the 21.3 million people in Taiwan to be represented in the organization. However, such a proposal had been unable to make the agenda for the annual UN General Assembly meeting because of Beijing's opposition.

DOC.HEADLINE: CONFIDANTE STUNS AUSSIE POLITICS BY QUITTING HANSON'S ONE NATION

TEXT.P: A confidante of Independent Member of Parliament Pauline Hanson has resigned, accusing Hanson of allowing herself to be used by One Nation's senior adviser, thus shattering the unity of the fledgling party following its stunning victory in June 13 state elections in Queensland.

In an exclusive interview with the mass-circulation The Australian, Barbara Hazelton, Hanson's private secretary, said both Hanson and her party were being manipulated by the party's senior adviser David Oldfield.

Describing herself as "a heart-broken supporter" of the One Nation Party, Hazelton said Oldfield "is exerting undue influence over her (Hanson) and that Pauline Hanson's One Nation has become David Oldfield's One Nation."

One Nation stunned Australian politics and attracted international media attention after winning 11 seats in the Queensland elections. The party is now winning considerable support in other states as well. Nationwide support for the party now stands at 13 percent, up from 4 percent prior to the Queensland elections.
In comparison, a recent poll shows support for Australia's coalition government has fallen from 46 percent in mid-May to 34 percent. The coalition comprises the Liberal and National parties.

DOC.HEADLINE: SINGAPORE UNVEILS S$2 BILLION STIMULUS PACKAGE

TEXT.P: The Singapore government announced Monday a S$2 billion (US$1.2 billion) stimulus package that will result in a budget deficit of S$800 million, the country's first deficit in more than 10 years.
The government also revised downward this year's economic growth estimates from earlier predictions of 2.5 percent to 4.5 percent to a more modest 0.5 percent to 1.5 percent.
The package was unveiled in parliament by Finance Minister Hu Tsu Tau against a backdrop of what he described as a "deteriorating external environment ... not problems inherent in our own economy."

Growth in the second half of this year could be "very weak, and possibly even become negative," he said, adding that Singapore must prepare for slower economic growth over the next few years as the region recovers from its current financial turmoil.

Included in the plan is a near doubling of the size of the Local Enterprise Financing Scheme credit line, which helps provide Singapore businesses with working capital. The line will be increased from S$900 million to S$2 billion. Absent from the plan, however, were cuts in personal or corporate income taxes, as well as a reduction in interest rates.

The plan also includes a one-year suspension of stamp duties on share transactions. The measure, which is expected to cost the government S$50 million, is aimed at helping stockbrokers cope with sharply lower trading volumes.

Starting Wednesday, the government will also incur a S$400-million revenue loss from a property tax rebate of 40 percent on commercial and industrial properties. This comes in addition to a 15 percent rebate announced in February.

Hu noted that, given the Singapore economy's open nature, it is difficult to stimulate domestic growth through pump-priming or boosting local consumption. However, several ongoing public sector infrastructure projects will be speeded up.

"We must brace for slower economic growth during the next few years," Hu said. "Some companies will feel the fall in demand and profits more acutely than others. Retrenchment will increase as businesses consolidate and restructure. This process will be painful but we must accept it as the only way to adapt to the changed economic conditions and resume growth."

DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER SAYS NO NEED FOR CLINTON TO SPELL OUT 'THREE NOES'

TEXT.P: ROC Premier Vincent Siew said on Tuesday that he saw no need for US President Bill Clinton to spell out the "three noes" policy toward Taiwan during a meeting with mainland Chinese local leaders earlier in the day.
Siew said that if the United States is really concerned about ROC policy, US officials are welcome to hold talks with ROC officials at any time.

Siew's remarks were in response to news reports that while meeting with community leaders in Shanghai, Clinton told them that "We don't support independence for Taiwan, or two Chinas .... And we don't believe that Taiwan should be a member in any organization for which statehood is a requirement."
The premier's response is the first time he has commented on Clinton's historic nine-day visit.
In related news, Vice Foreign Minister David Lee said on Tuesday that he did not think Clinton's remarks added anything substantial to the United States' policy.

The ROC government, however, will express its concern over the matter when a US envoy comes to Taiwan later this week to brief the government on Clinton's visit, Lee said. The ROC government will also make clear its position, as well as its expectations, on issues of mutual concern.

The United States and mainland China are neither entitled nor in a position to negotiate issues that relate to the Republic of China's sovereignty, said Lee, who is also in charge of an inter-agency task force set up to address new developments in Beijing-Washington relations that occur during Clinton's visit.

Asked if Clinton's statements will affect ROC efforts to rejoin the United Nations, Lee said that the US government told Taiwan in 1994 that it would not support Taiwan's bid to join international bodies whose members are sovereign countries. Taiwan, however, has not changed its position and is still seeking membership.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP NEEDS FLEXIBLE ADJUSTMENT DUE TO NEW SITUATION

TEXT.P: Ranking officials with the pro-independence Democratic Progressive Party said on Tuesday that the DPP needs a more flexible strategy in the face of possible changes in trilateral Taipei-Washington-Beijing ties.

Commenting that "the current situation across the Taiwan Strait will continue at least another 10 years," DPP Secretary-General Chiu Yih-jen said he is not worried about possible changes in cross-strait relations.
"As the United States has already set up a strategic partnership with mainland China, Washington should prefer the two sides of the Taiwan Strait maintain the status-quo," he said.
Chiu's remarks came after US President Bill Clinton reiterated US support for the "three noes" policy toward Taiwan during a forum in Shanghai Tuesday morning.

"We don't support independence for Taiwan or two Chinas ... And we don't believe that Taiwan should be a member in any organization for which statehood is a requirement," Clinton told participants in the forum.

Chiu said he does not believe that this new development in trilateral Taipei-Washington-Beijing relations will affect the DPP's pursuit of Taiwan independence. But he noted that the DPP needs to adopt a more flexible strategy as its goal of independence for Taiwan has become harder to achieve in light of Clinton's announcement.
The DPP will discuss the issue Wednesday in a meeting of the party's policy-making central standing committee, he said.

Pointing out that situation between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait is no longer a zero-sum game, Chiu said Taiwan must adjust its thinking, since "what communist China has gained does not necessarily mean a loss for Taiwan."

Yen Wan-chin, director of the DPP's mainland affairs department, said Clinton's public declaration of not supporting Taiwan independence will make it harder for the country to obtain legal status in the international community. The DPP needs to further ponder the issue of Taiwan independence, which has always been the party's goal, he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: SICA SECRETARY GENERAL LEAL ARRIVES IN TAIPEI

TEXT.P: Ernesto Leal Sanchez, secretary general of the System of Central American Integration (SICA), arrived here Tuesday to attend the Seventh Conference of the Mixed Commission of Cooperation Between Central American Countries and the Republic of China.

The annual ministerial conference will be held in Taipei July 2-3 with dozens of officials from Guatemala, El Salvador, Costa Rica, Honduras, Belize, and Nicaragua participating. Officials of the Dominican Republic will attend the meeting as observers. The officials who will attend the meeting include Foreign Minister Eduardo Stein Barillas of Guatemala, Foreign Minister Ramon Ernesto Gonzalez Giner of El Salvador, Foreign Minister Roberto Rojas of Costa Rica, Foreign Minister Jose Fernando Martinez Jimenez of Honduras, Minister of Tourism and Environmental Affairs Henry Young of Belize, Vice Foreign Minister Carlos Guardian of Nicaragua, and Vice Foreign Minister Gloria Milan Lugo of the Dominican Republic.

In addition to attending the conference to exchange views on how to enhance cooperation and exchanges, they will also call on President Lee Teng-hui and visit cultural and economic establishments in Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOST TAIWAN PEOPLE OPPOSED TO 'ONE COUNTRY, TWO SYSTEMS': POLL

TEXT.P: More than half of Taiwan people are opposed to the Beijing-proposed "one country, two systems" unification scheme, according to a public opinion poll released on Tuesday.

The poll, released by the Cabinet-level Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) on the eve of the first anniversary of Hong Kong's handover by Britain to Beijing, found that 51.1 percent of the respondents said they can't accept the "one country, two systems" model even if the formula is successfully implemented in Hong Kong.

A similar poll conducted in Hong Kong, however, found that 48.6 percent of Hong Kong residents interviewed think that the "one country, two systems" scheme is suitable for Taiwan; while 36.9 percent said they don't think the formula is applicable to Taiwan.

The MAC survey also showed that 35.4 percent of Taiwan respondents feel that Hong Kong's overall situation has worsened since it reverted to mainland China's rule on July 1, 1997; 17.3 percent said they feel the territory's situation remains almost the same; and only 6.6 percent said the situation there has become even better than before.

While 36.2 percent of Taiwan respondents feel that Taiwan-Hong Kong relations have become less close than before, 63.9 percent said they hope to see bilateral ties get ever closer. Nearly 52 percent of Hong Kong residents also said the current Hong Kong government should maintain close relations with Taiwan.

The MAC poll further found that 29.1 percent of Hong Kong respondents expect the two sides of the Taiwan Strait to gradually move toward unification, compared to 48.1 percent who forecast the status quo on both sides of the strait will be maintained.
The poll also found that 34.9 percent of Hong Kong residents hope to see the cross-strait status quo be maintained, while 48.8 percent said they hope the two sides will reunify.
According to poll results, 54.7 percent said they support Taiwan's bid to expand its diplomatic frontier, while 26.2 percent said they oppose such moves.

Meanwhile, 59.4 percent of Taiwan respondents threw their support behind the proposal that Taiwan and Hong Kong exchange official representative offices; while 74.2 percent of Hong Kong respondents said they feel Taiwan needs to set up an official representative office in the territory.

DOC.HEADLINE: CROSS-STRAIT CONFERENCE ON TECHNOLOGICAL EXCHANGES TO OPEN

TEXT.P: The first conference on scientific and technological exchanges between Taiwan and mainland China will open in Taipei on July 15.

Wang Shaoqi, director of mainland China's State Department of International Cooperation in Science and Technology, and Liu Zhentao, chief of the Taiwan Affairs Office's Economic Bureau, will jointly lead a 100-member delegation to the five-day conference.

The delegation will include 30 scholars from 15 prominent universities, such as Beijing-based Qinghua University and Shanghai's Jiaotong University. Four members of the mainland Chinese Academy of Engineering will be included as well, according to the conference's sponsor, Taiwan's Chinese National Federation of Industries.

In addition to an exhibition which will present some 200 various mainland China's technologic products, 22 workshops in fields such as telecommunications, aeronautics and petro-chemistry will also be held as a part of the conference, according to CNFI.
The CNFI started seeking cooperation with mainland technological research and development institutes in 1995 to introduce scientific and technological achievements of mainland China in Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: ACTING MJIB HEAD TO MEET INVESTIGATIVE TEAM ON THURSDAY

TEXT.P: A senior law enforcement officer has promised to brief a Ministry of Justice investigative team on Thursday on his side of story about his alleged sexual misconduct committed in France in 1996.

Vice Justice Minister Chiang Hao, who concurrently serves as head of the investigative task force, said Cheng Chuan, acting director of the Justice Ministry's Investigation Bureau, has agreed to meet with the team to explain his role in the case.
Cheng has been accused of sexually assaulting Christine Yang, the daughter of his former friend Yang Wan-ching, in a Paris hotel room in September 1996 when he was on a private trip to France.

However, Cheng has categorically denied any wrongdoing, insisting that he had just performed the traditional Chinese physical therapy "Chikung" on Christine, who was then 19 years old and suffered from a chronic disease.

The Justice Ministry sent a three-member team to Paris earlier this month to collect information about the allegations. The team's only female member, Li Tsui-lien, managed to interview Christine in a hospital room in Paris last weekend. Christine was admitted into the hospital before the arrival of the Taiwan team to receive treatment for mental stress stemming from the alleged sexual assault incident.
According to press reports, Christine had told Li that Cheng had touched on her breast and private parts while administering Chikung on her.

The task force is now carefully sifting through related information and scrutinizing every detail. Chiang said it's still too early to predict when the task force will be able to come up with a formal report on the case.

Investigators are still trying to obtain a copy of Christine's complaint to the French police filed shortly after the alleged sexual assualt and the hospital's diagnosis of her mental state through the country's representative office in Paris. The two documents can serve as evidence to help justify Christine's allegations.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHINA SHIPBUILDING CORP. BENEFITS FROM ASIAN FINANCIAL TURMOIL

TEXT.P: Taiwan's China Shipbuilding Corp. (CSC) is benefiting from the Asian financial storm which has halted the economic development of most countries in the region.
The state-run company has obtained new orders which had originally gone to South Korean shipbuilders, until recently the company's biggest competitors, a CSC spokesman said.
Most of the South Korean outfits have shut down due to financial straits caused by over-expansion during the regional financial meltdown, the spokesman explained.
South Korea is one of the regional countries hit hardest by the financial assault.

The spokesman said CSC has so far received orders for six container vessels which were originally contracted to South Korean manufacturers. It is expected that this market introduction will lead to more business opportunities, he added.
The Kaohsiung-based CSC lists Germany, the United States, France and Denmark as its major customers.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN WILL CONTINUE TO PURSUE CROSS-STRAIT DIALOGUES: MAC

TEXT.P: President Bill Clinton's mentioning of the "three nos" Tuesday in Shanghai will not change Taiwan's mainland policy and its decision to pursue dialogues with mainland China, an official of the Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) said.

Clinton said at a forum in Shanghai that, during his summit with mainland Chinese President Jiang Zemin in Beijing, "I had a chance to reiterate our Taiwan policy which is that we don't support independence for Taiwan, or 'two Chinas' or 'one Taiwan one China,' and we don't believe Taiwan should be a member in any organization for which statehood is a requirement." The US position is known as the "three nos."
President Clinton's public mentioning of the "three nos" has apparently made Taiwan leaders indignant.

When asked Tuesday by the press to comment on Clinton's mentioning of the "three nos" at the forum, MAC Vice Chairman and Spokesman Sheu Ke-sheng said that Taiwan's policy to pursue national unification under the principles of democracy, freedom, and equal distribution of wealth will not be changed and that Taiwan will actively make arrangements for cross-strait dialogues this fall.

Taiwan's chief negotiator Koo Chen-fu, chairman of the Strait Exchange Foundation (SEF), has received an invitation from the Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait (ARATS) to meet with his mainland Chinese counterpart Wang Daohan this fall in Shanghai. The SEF and ARATS were established in Taipei and Beijing respectively in 1991 to handle civilian exchanges between the two sides in the absence of formal relations.

Sheu expressed the hope that Beijing will handle cross-strait relations realistically. It will certainly be harmful to the development of the relations if mainland China continues to make all-out efforts to hinder Taiwan's activities in the international community, he added.
He said Taiwan will try to step up exchanges and consultations with mainland China and hopes that the Koo-Wang meeting this fall in Shanghai will be fruitful.

DOC.HEADLINE: US SHOULD NOT IGNORE ITS PROMISES TO TAIWAN: FOREIGN MINISTER

TEXT.P: The United States should not ignore its promises to support Taiwan's efforts to have a voice in international organizations, ROC Foreign Affairs Minister Jason Hu said on Tuesday.

Hu said that in its 1994 review of US policy on Taiwan, Washington made clear that the US does not support membership for Taiwan in international organizations for which statehood is a requirement. Nevertheless, he added, Washington also said in the review that it supports efforts that would help Taiwan to be heard in international organizations.

Commenting on US President Bill Clinton's remarks on Tuesday in Shanghai of the so-called "three noes" policy toward Taiwan, Hu said that although the policy is not a new development, it seems unnecessary for Clinton to spell it out at this time.

Clinton's affirmation of the "three noes" -- no support for independence for Taiwan, no support for "two Chinas" or "one China, one Taiwan," and no support for Taiwan's membership in international organizations in which statehood is a requirement -- was an effort to please the Beijing authorities, who have been pushing the US to codify the policy, Hu said.
The foreign minister said he is aware of concern in the government hierarchy over Clinton's latest statement, as well as the aftershocks the statement has caused among the Taiwan public.
However, he stressed that the Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) has not been "caught unprepared" by Clinton's words.

Clinton's statement does not necessarily mean that the US' firm policies regarding the pursuit of peace and stability have changed, Hu said, adding that the motive behind the statement was simply to dissuade Beijing from making any rash or sudden moves on the Taiwan issue.

He stressed that the MOFA will further bolster its efforts on all its diplomatic fronts, as well as in its relations with the US, so as to diminish the harm caused by Beijing's schemes to suppress Taiwan in the international community.
At the same time, he said, Taiwan will also continue to improve its relations with mainland China. By doing so, Beijing's hostile attempts will lose their meaning, the foreign minister said.

DOC.HEADLINE: `THREE NOES' NOT NEW US POLICY: SCHOLAR

TEXT.P: US President Bill Clinton's affirmation of the so-called "three noes" policy in Shanghai is not a new development in US policy toward Taiwan, an independent world affairs scholar said on Tuesday.

Dr. Hsieh Shu-yuan, who is the only member from Taiwan of the Pugwash Conference on Sciences and World Affairs, winner of the 1995 Nobel Peace Prize, said Clinton's Tuesday remarks of the "three noes" policy is unlikely to alter the existing situation across the Taiwan Strait. In fact, she said, the affirmation may contribute to bolstering stability in the region.
Hsieh urged the Taiwan public not to be over-worried about Clinton's latest remarks, as the policy has been a set and consistent part of US policy on Taiwan for years.

Reports from Shanghai said that Clinton confirmed at a closed-door meeting on Tuesday that the US will not support independence for Taiwan, will not support "two Chinas" or "one China, one Taiwan", and will not support Taiwan's membership in international organizations in which statehood is a requirement.
Although it is the first time a US president has voiced the "three noes" policy, the development is not expected to cause any additional harm to Taiwan's interests, Hsieh noted.

Hsieh, who has taught at National Taiwan University and at Marshall University in the United States, said that no matter when or where Clinton made the remarks, they are still in compliance with the US policy of "ambiguity" toward Taiwan, and the US support for Taiwan has not been affected or limited.

Hsieh, who has also taught at universities in Africa and Italy, said Taiwan's worries over Clinton's remarks are absolutely unnecessary, and she urged the people of Taiwan to learn to view the Clinton-Jiang summit from a broader perspective.

Since the US policy toward Taiwan remains unchanged despite the fact that it has been publicly spelled out by a US president, the people of Taiwan should turn their attention to the brighter side of the summit, which is poised to defuse nuclear proliferation, enhance economic stability in Asia, uphold human rights values and result in better Washington-Beijing ties.
Taiwan itself could even end up benefiting from these developments, Hsieh concluded.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN STOCK INDEX FUTURES EXCHANGE TO OPEN ON JULY 21

TEXT.P: Trading in Taiwan stock index futures will begin on July 21, Finance Minister Paul Chiu announced on Tuesday.
Each transaction will be taxed at a rate of 0.0005 percent, Chiu said.
The Taiwan Stock Index Futures Exchange will be open for trading every working day between 9:00 a.m. and 12:15 p.m.

DOC.HEADLINE: CLINTON'S REMARKS WILL NOT AFFECT TAIWAN'S WTO BID: ECONOMIC MINISTER

TEXT.P: Taiwan's bid to join the World Trade Organization (WTO) will not be affected by US President Bill Clinton's statement on the so-called "three noes" policy toward Taiwan, Economic Affairs Minister Wang Chih-kang said on Tuesday.
Issues involving Taiwan's and mainland China's membership in international organizations should be handled separately, he said.

Clinton spelled out the US' "consistent" policy toward Taiwan during the Shanghai leg of his mainland China tour on Tuesday, saying that the US does not support independence for Taiwan, does not support "two Chinas," or "one Taiwan, one China," and does not support Taiwan's membership of any organization for which statehood is a requirement.

The economics minister said the "name issue" has always been a sensitive one in terms of Taiwan's membership in international organizations. Taiwan joined the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation (APEC) forum under the name "Chinese Taipei," while it applied for WTO membership under the name of "the Customs Territory of Taiwan, Penghu, Kinmen and Matsu." Clinton's remarks, therefore, exert no affect on Taipei's bid to join the WTO, Wang said.
Wang also welcomed US Commerce Secretary William Daley's recent remarks that there is no direct relationship between Taiwan's and mainland China's accession to the WTO.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI CITY MAYORAL CANDIDATES URGE ADJUSTMENT OF `GO SLOW' POLICY

TEXT.P: Two candidates for the year-end Taipei City mayoral election on Tuesday urged the government to adjust its "go slow, be patient" policy toward investment in mainland China.

Ma Ying-jeou of the ruling Kuomintang (KMT) and Wang Chien-shien of the opposition New Party made the suggestions at a meeting in Taipei sponsored by the National Federation of Certified Public Accountants to mark Public Accountant Day.
They also expressed their views on the government's "three noes" policy.

Wang said that if Taiwan continues its policy of no direct trade, postal, or transportation links with the mainland, then it stands to lose valuable trade opportunities as the mainland economy continues to grow. He pointed out that by 2002, the mainland economy is expected to have expanded seven-fold.
He suggested that the ban be lifted immediately, and that the three direct links be listed on the agenda of high-level cross-strait talks scheduled for September.
Ma said that once Taiwan joins the World Trade Organization, it will be unable to avoid contact with the mainland, by which time, Taiwan will be forced to adjust its "go slow, be patient" policy.
But he also stressed that until that time arrives, Taiwan need not adjust the policy hastily, but should maintain some flexibility regarding when and if the policy should be changed.
He predicted that questions regarding the policy will be resolved after the September talks.
Commenting on remarks on the US' "three noes" policy on Taiwan made by President Bill Clinton in Shanghai on Tuesday, Wang said the damage to Taiwan will not be too great.

The "three noes" in this case refers to no support for an independent Taiwan, no support for "two Chinas," or "one Taiwan, one China," and no support for Taiwan membership in any international organizations for which statehood is a requirement.
Wang said that resources now being channeled into Taiwan's UN bid should be diverted back to domestic issues, and that Taiwan should focus on its internal affairs and public construction works.

Ma, on the other hand, said that Taiwan need not panic. He said he believes that Taiwan will not be so easily sold out, and that Taiwan should improve its relations with mainland China at the same time that the US is improving its relations with the mainland.

DOC.HEADLINE: AUSTRALIAN SENATOR STRESSES NEED FOR STRONGER AUSTRALIA-TAIWAN TIES

TEXT.P: The chairman of the Australia-Taiwan Parliamentary Group has stressed the need to strengthen bilateral ties between Canberra and Taipei.

In a speech to the Senate in Canberra last week, Senator Sandy MacDonald of the National Party said the pursuit of free trade is "immensely important to every Australian -- not just farmers and exporters, but to all of us."
"I am conscious of the need to build the strong personal, economic and political links between our two countries," he said.
He said two-way trade between Australia and Taiwan totaled A$6.7 (US$4.5) billion in 1997.

Taiwan is a major and growing source of services for Australia, he said, citing Australia's export revenue, especially tourism and education, which was valued at A$707 (US$532) million in 1995-96 and the fact that Taiwan is potentially a significant source of investment for Australia.
Despite the Asian financial crisis, Australian exporters continue to sell their products in the region, which accounts for about 60 percent of Australia's total exports.
MacDonald criticized the anti-Asian policy of Australia's One Nation party, saying: "To be anti-Asian equals fewer jobs; to be anti-foreign investment equals fewer jobs."
"Isolationism hurts the poorest and least trained people in the community the most," he said.

He warned that One Nation could only damage Australia and cost Australian jobs, and called on the Senate to realize that "One Nation does not speak for this nation, because on this very important aspect of our foreign policy it is wrong, and ordinary Aussie wage earners will be the losers.
"We rely on our trade links and our reputation and we do not want to be thought of as some backward-looking, unsophisticated, aggressive place," the senator said.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN BUSINESS MIGRANTS IN AUSTRALIA VOICE CONCERN OVER ONE NATION

TEXT.P: A group of Taiwan business migrants from New South Wales flew into Canberra on Tuesday to meet Members of Parliament and ministers for the first time to discuss the policies of the coalition government in the face of the rise of the One Nation party.
The group members included executives of Australia Teco Ltd., Pan Australia Pty., Ltd. and the Sydney-based branch office of the International Commercial Bank of China.

It was the first ever group of Taiwan business migrants to express grave concern over Australian government policies, including immigration, foreign investment, two-way trade between Australia and the Republic of China, banking deregulation, and other subjects of mutual concern.
Taiwan business migrants have been gravely concerned about the rise of One Nation because of its anti-Asian, anti-foreign investment, anti-multiculturalism and anti-Aborigine stance.
The party stunned Australian politics by winning 11 seats in the Queensland government in a June 13 election.

DOC.HEADLINE: SOUTH AFRICAN FORENSIC STAFF AT HIGH RISK OF INFECTION

TEXT.P: Personnel in forensic laboratories who have a high daily workload are at high risk of contracting HIV and other serious infectious diseases, according to a team of medical researchers at Pretoria University.

The researchers from the Department of Medical Virology and the Institute of Pathology of Pretoria University took blood from 263 bodies autopsied at an urban forensic center. Of the samples examined, 21 percent were infected.
The researchers said the results indicate that forensic personnel in South Africa are at high risk from blood-borne viruses.
"The risk is further compounded by the high daily workload in South African forensic laboratories," they said.
The researchers were reporting at the annual congress of the Federation of South African Societies of Pathology being held at Pretoria University.

DOC.HEADLINE: CLINTON'S STATEMENT ADDS NOTHING TO SUBSTANCE OF US POLICY: MOFA

TEXT.P: The ROC Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) said on Tuesday that it sees no need for US President Bill Clinton to repeat the so-called "three noes" at this point, as such a statement adds nothing to the substance of the US policy.
The MOFA said in a press release that the US and mainland China have neither the right nor the position to conduct bilateral negotiations on issues concerning the Republic of China.
"Otherwise, this will give communist China and the international community a false impression," it added.

The ROC has no intention of interfering with the development of US-Beijing relations, the release said. "However, we must point out solemnly that the US should discuss with us, instead of communist China, on relevant issues concerning the ROC or the ROC-US relations," it continued.
"Otherwise, it will not only have negative impacts on cross-strait relations but also affect the long-term national interests of the US," it said.

"The MOFA is of a positive opinion concerning the repeated affirmation by the US side that its policy toward Taiwan remains unchanged, that it will adhere to the Taiwan Relations Act, and that the cross-strait issue should be resolved by peaceful means," the statement said.
When answering questions at a discussion in Shanghai on Tuesday, Clinton confirmed that he stated the "three noes" to Jiang Zemin at last year's summit meeting in Washington.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP CHIEF DOWNPLAYS SIGNIFICANCE OF US `THREE NOES' POLICY

TEXT.P: The United States has no intention of heightening the political significance of its "three noes" policy towards Taiwan, said Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) Chairman Hsu Hsin-liang on Tuesday.

"This is the reason why US President Clinton chose to spell out the `three noes' policy at an informal meeting with community leaders rather than announce it at a formal press conference," Hsu said at a press conference.

Earlier in the day, Clinton said in Shanghai that "we don't support independence for Taiwan, or `two Chinas' or `one Taiwan one China,' and we don't believe Taiwan should be a member in any organization for which statehood is a requirement."

In addition, Clinton also emphasized that US arms sales to Taiwan will not affect its adherence to the "one China" principle, which further decreases the significance of the "three noes" policy, Hsu added.

The DPP heavyweight said that by answering questions raised by students at Beijing University and by radio listeners at a call-in program in Shanghai, Clinton has performed very well by talking about human rights and freedom to the Chinese, and even the people of the whole world. "The influence is far-reaching," he added.
Hsu urged the government to establish a "cross-strait affairs advisory committee under the Presidential Office" as soon as possible to solicit consensus on mainland policy.

Meanwhile, DPP Secretary-General Chiu Yi-jen said that the "three noes" policy will not prompt the DPP to adjust its pro-independence stance, as Hsu and former party chairman Shih Ming-teh already took that step years ago when they announced that the DPP will not declare Taiwan independent should it become the island's ruling party.
Taipei Mayor Chen Shui-bian, another DPP heavyweight, said Clinton did not clearly declare US opposition to the three issues, saying "no support" is not equal to "opposition."

DOC.HEADLINE: HALF WORLD'S BLACKFACED SPOONBILL POPULATION FOUND IN TAIWAN

TEXT.P: The world's largest congregation of 327 blackfaced spoonbills can be found at the mouth of the Tsengwen Creek in southern Taiwan's Tainan County, representing 53 percent of the world's population of the endangered birds.

Professor Huang Chin-ming, a member of Taiwan's Coast Protection Association, on Tuesday released the number, which was provided by an international survey task force on blackfaced spoonbill conservation.

He cited Dr. Tom Dahmer, leader of the survey mission, as saying that Taiwan, South Korea, Japan, mainland China, Macao, and Vietnam were covered in the 1998 investigation, and that a total of 613 of the wetland birds were found in those regions.

Dahmer said the task force has so far been unable to ascertain whether the population is increasing or decreasing, or whether or not it is stable, and warned that if no effective protection measures are taken, the birds will face extinction.
The mouth of Tsengwen Creek has been listed as a major habitat of the blackfaced spoonbill, with around 300 migrating every winter from the north to the wetland area.

Despite urging from domestic and international wildlife conservationists to list the wetland as a wildlife protection area, industrial development has never stopped, and there are now plans to drain the whole area to build an industrial park.
